column4:
1. Of, acquired by. This a forms part of the possessives, as in ka'u, mine, and kāna, his.

2. Abbreviation of ʻākau, north, as in surveying reports.
Pas/imp. suffix.

1. . Jaw, cheekbone. Fig., to talk a lot, jabber, jibber jabber.

2. An instrument made of smooth bone, formerly used for abortion, lancing, or bleeding. Also āʻōʻō, piercing ā.

3. Mold found in souring foods, especially poi, generally known as Oidium lactis or Oospora lactis, but now called Geotrichum candidum.

4. When, at the time when, until, to, as far as, and, or (rare), and then, but (usually preceding verbs, whereas a me usually precedes nouns; ā may also connect words translated by English adjectives, as he po'e kuli ā ʻāʻā, a people deaf and dumb; nani ā pumehana kēia kakahiaka, this morning is beautiful and warm).

1. Pejorative suffix, often written wā after o or u. See ʻaiā, haiā, hainā, huā (huwā), kauā (kauwā), lonoā, (lonowā), makoeā, naʻauʻauā (naʻauʻauwā), poluā (poluwā),

2. Personal article occurring only after the preposition i, written ia.a.)
Simulative ligature in the sequence ‘verb + noun’ compounds. See ʻai ā manō, holoāiʻa.

1. Prefix to numbers from one through nine, especially for counting in series. See ʻalua, ʻakolu, Pōʻahā. (PNP kaa-.)

2. Same as ʻā-.

1. Fiery, burning; fire; to burn, blaze. Fig., to glitter or sparkle, as a gem; to burn, as with jealousy or anger.

2. Aa lava, or lava rock, as distinguished from smooth unbroken pāhoehoe lava (formerly preceded by ke); to flow, as aa lava.

3. Same as ʻaʻa 1, to dare.

4. Red-footed booby bird (Sula sula rubripes), brown booby (Sula leucogaster plotus), masked or blue-faced booby (Sula dactylatra personata); all indigenous and also breeding elsewhere. Also ʻaʻa. Legendary birds believed to have taken the shape of this bird are ʻā ʻaia, ʻā-ʻai-ʻanuhe-a-Kāne and ʻā-ʻaia-nui-nū-keu; ʻā by some were considered ʻaumākua. See also Kep. 33.

5. Young stage of damselfish (ʻāloʻiloʻi). Also ʻaʻā.

6. Oh! Well! Ah! Er … (PNP kaa.)

7. To drive, as fish or cattle.

8. The letter “a.” Eng.
In the nature of (as hina, white, ʻāhina, somewhat white, gray; pali, cliff, ʻāpali, like a cliff). There are many examples, as ʻālewalewa, ʻālualua, ʻāmokumoku, ʻāoʻo, ʻāpono, ʻāwela. (PNP kaa-.)

1. Small root, rootlet, vein, artery, nerve, tendon, muscle. Fig., womb, offspring. See ex., cerebral hemorrhage.

2. To send greetings or love; joyous hospitality; joy at greeting a loved one. Cf. haaʻa.

1. To brave, dare, challenge, defy (1 Sam. 17.10), check, venture; to accept a challenge; to volunteer, involving a difficulty; to act wickedly or presumptuously (Kanl. 1.43); bold, venturesome, valiant, intrepid. See ex., mea 1.

2. Belt, girdle, waist; to gird, tie on.

3. Bag, pocket, caul, envelope for a foetus, scrip (1 Sam. 17.40); fiber from coconut husk; clothlike sheath at base of coconut frond; cloth; chaff, hull (Ier. 23.28); skin covering eyeballs. See ʻaʻa moni.

4. Same as Maʻaʻa, a wind.

5. Same as ʻā 4, booby bird.

1. To burn, blaze, glow; fire; staring, as eyes (see ʻaʻā maka). Fig., angry; fury.

2. ʻAʻā lava; stony, abounding with ʻaʻa lava.

3. Sirius, a zenith star that passes over Tahiti and Raʻi-ātea, formerly believed used by navigators; one of the brightest stars in the heavens. See Sirius for var. names.

4. Young stage of damselfish (ʻāloʻiloʻi). Also ʻā.

1. Dumbness, inability to speak intelligibly, a dumb person (Puk. 4.11); dumb, silent, still; to stutter and stammer, as a dumb person.

2. Dwarf, small person; dwarfish, small.

3. Demented, panic-stricken. See ʻaʻā maka, ʻaʻaia.

4. Probable var. of ʻā 4, booby bird.

5. Male ʻōʻō bird.kaa.)
Network of veins.
Clothlike sheath at base of coconut frond; vascular bundles in taro corm, chaff, tissue; fibrous, stringy. Also hāʻaʻa.

1. Redup. of ʻaʻā 1; lava cave.

2. Redup. of ʻāʻā 1.
Redup. of ʻaʻaʻa.
Scion or shoot of sandalwood.
Bag for carrying fire-making equipment (ʻaʻa, bag, and ahi, fire).
Redup. of ʻaʻaki.
Second or third crop, as of taro; taro patch where the taro has been pulled up. Also ʻae.
The sound ay that infants make in calling for attention; to make this sound.
Netted carrier for a calabash, made of sennit or olonā cord. More commonly called kōkō. Cf. ʻaha, sennit.
Same as ʻiliahi, sandalwood. (And.)
Burning fire.
Pas/imp. of aʻa 2.

1. Thatch purlin; rails, as in a fence. See ʻahohui, ʻahopiʻo, ʻahopueo.

2. Container, as for pia, arrowroot starch; to put pia in small packages so that it may keep sweet. Rare.
Same as haupia, coconut and arrowroot pudding.
Clothing in general, garment, array, attire, costume, mantle, gown; to put on or wear clothing, especially shirt, suit, or coat; to cover or wrap, as the body with a blanket.
Pas/imp. of ʻaʻahu.
To speak reproachfully, contemptuously, deride, jeer; jealous challenge.
See ʻaʻahuā
Regal attire, a royal robe, a type of colored tapa worn by people of rank.
A fabulous being said to have had extraordinary strength, to have come from the center of the earth, and to have been the creator of all dwarfs. Cf. haʻakualiki.
Head shield; protection for the head in war, as helmet, shield. (Epeso 6.16.)
Aching veins, varicose veins.
Armor, war garment.
Tendon. Lit., pulled vein. See ex., wikani.
A long malo or ornamented band made of the soft makaloa rush; to put on or wear this garment.
Full regalia, dress uniform. Lit., full professional garment.
Garment made of pāwehe, patterned mat; mat made of soft material and woven in the pāwehe pattern; to put on and wear this garment.
Var. of ʻahu ʻula.
Var. spelling of ʻaʻahuā.

1. Redup. of ʻai 1; eating, spreading, festering, increasing, as a sore; ulcerous, cancerous, malignant; to eat away, corrode; to take bait readily, as fish; erosion. See ʻaʻaiole.

2. Bright, vivid, as of contrasting colors.

3. Same as ʻaʻei, a net.
Demented.
Legendary bird believed to have taken the shape of the ʻā, booby bird. See ʻā 4.
Legendary bird. Lit., caterpillar eater of Kāne. See ʻā 4.
Redup. of ʻaʻina.
Inferior, weak, said of breadfruit or fruit with a weak stem that may fall before maturity; weak object. (Kep. 93.) Fig., of persons dying before their time.

1. Surly, cranky, roiled, complaining, irritable, peevish, bad tempered, cantankerous, cross; severe, as labor. See ex., papaioa.

2. Dry, as coral of the reef at low tide; parched, wrinkled, dry and thirsty; peeling off, as the tough skin of such fish as the humuhumu after it has been in the fire; to crackle, burst, as a ripe melon.

3. Rocky undersea cavern, (PH 219, Malo 26.)

4. Wood of the naio, bastard sandalwood.

Redup. of ʻaki 1; to nip repeatedly; to take a nip and hold on (cf. nahu, to bite with the whole mouth, and nau, to chew); a bite, nibble. Fig., thick, obscure, dark, penetrating; to feel pangs, as of love or childbirth.
A hook nibbler, said of small fish that nibble away the bait; to nibble at a hook.
Redup. of ʻako 1, 2; repeated plucking; insatiable lust; to get into action (rare).
Vein, blood vessel.
A root running horizontally that produces roots below and above; a rhizome, creeping root.
Name of a combination of diseases: liver complication resulting in hardening of the veins, bloody dysentery accompanied by fever.
Varicose veins. Lit., raised veins.

1. Fragrant, sweet-smelling; fragrance, perfume, 
fume, aroma, sweet scent. Fig., of high rank, royal.

2. Winds.
Name of a wind accompanied by rain associated with Hilo. Lit., earth fragrance.
A fish (no data; perhaps a local name for one of the chaetodons).
Young of the ʻalaʻihi fishes.
Wild, demented person; uncivilized.

1. Insipid, unsavory, tasteless.

2. Large, plump. Cf. ʻuʻulukai.
Wind name.

Velvety-green, succulent-appearing seaweeds, one of several species of Codium. It yields a red liquid when placed in a container overnight with brine, after chopping or pounding. Both the liquid and the seaweed are well liked, being eaten plain or with other food. (KL. line 47.) ʻAʻalaʻula is the common name on Kauaʻi and Maui, wāwaeʻiole elsewhere.
Pulse. Lit., leaping vein.
Redup. of ʻali 1; scarred, marked, grooved; depression, groove; wattles of a fowl; slight depression under the gills of a fish.

Native hardwood shrubs or trees (Dodonaea, all species), 30 cm to 10 m high, more or less sticky at branch tips; leaves narrow, 2 to 10 cm long; flowers small; fruit a yellow, red, or brown papery capsule about 1 cm long and with two to four wings. Fruit clusters are made into leis with their own leaves or ferns and worn in the hair. A boast of the people of Kaʻū, is: He ʻaʻaliʻi au, ʻaʻohe makani e hina ai, I am an ʻaʻaliʻi shrub, no wind can push me over. See similar ex., ʻulaʻa. (Neal 536–7, FS57.) Also ʻaʻaliʻi kū makani (ʻaʻaliʻi standing [in] wind), ʻaʻaliʻi kū ma kua (ʻaʻaliʻi standing in back).
Same as pūkiawe, shrubs.

1. Scarred. (PH 218.)

2. Large, fat, weak, as a fat person.
Redup. of ʻalo 1, 2.
Clothlike sheath at base of coconut frond; European cloth.
Nerve. Lit., brain vein.
Ravine, small stream, valley, depression. Cf. ʻalu, depression.

1. A large, black, edible crab (Grapsus grapsus tenuicrustatus) that runs over shore rocks.

2. To spread and relax, as the fingers. [The ʻaʻama crab was offered in sacrifices so that the gods would loosen (aʻama) and grant the request.)

3. Redup. of ʻama 1; to talk.
To stare or glare with wide-open eyes, as in desire, fear, or intent to frighten; one who does so.
Coconut-leaf or pandanus-leaf bag used for carrying birds.
Same as ʻamo 2; contraction of anal muscles.
Broken blood vessel.
Purse. Biblical.

1. Young clothlike sheath at base of coconut frond; gauze, as of a veil; diaphanous cloth. Lit., ʻaʻa portion

2. Snakeskin; slime, as on fresh water. Lit., lizard ʻaʻa.
To use abusive language, revile, malign. Cf. ʻaʻa, daring.
Redup. of ʻanai.
Var. of kakanaliʻi, stunted.
Redup. of ʻanapuʻu, bumpy.
To criticize maliciously; malign.
Clothlike sheath at base of coconut frond.
Overbearing, arrogant, bold, defiant, daring; bully. Cf. ʻaʻa.

1. Greedy, voracious.

2. Uncultivated bananas. Rare.
Same as ʻao kahi.
Redup. of ʻapa. Rare. Cf. ʻapaʻapa.
Valve of a vein.
ʻA ʻā lava or flow, volcanic.
Warped, curved.
To learn quickly, to catch the meaning quickly, apt. Cf. ʻapo, ʻapoʻapo.
Same as aʻapau.

1. Coconut-shell cup; cuplike. Also ʻapu.

2. To warp, bend, ruffle.
Arrow case, quiver.
Girdle, belt. Lit., loin belt.

1. Capsular ligament.

2. Knots in a fish net.
Sharp or waterworn, coarse gravel or rock.
Same as ʻapuwai, a variety of taro.

1. To move here and there, wander, rove; to ripple, as the sea.

2. Redup. of ʻau, stalk.
Coarse, as wrinkled or blotched skin; lean, as fish. Also ʻaua, māʻaua.

1. Wrasse fishes, Hawaiian hogfish (Bodianus bilunulatus), considered ʻaumākua by some. The name ʻaʻawa may be qualified by the terms ʻeʻa, hai ʻeʻa, lelo, ule holu (pliable penis). Also poʻou.

2. Same as ʻaʻawa hua kukui.

3. Name given for an insect that destroys potatoes. (And.)

A native tree (Pittosporum hosmeri and its varieties), about 6 m high, with leaves 10 to 25 cm by 1.5 to 6 cm, shiny and wrinkled above, brown-wooly beneath; small, clustered, cream-colored flowers; ovoid fruits about 5 cm long, each with two to four thick valves containing orange pulp and black oily seeds. Also hōʻawa, hāʻawa. (Neal 382–4.)
Same as ʻawe, to carry.

1. Several native trees, the soapberry (Sapindus saponaria f. inaequalis), and all species of Zanthoxylum (also known as Fagara, Zanthoxylum having yellowish wood formerly used for digging sticks and spears); seeds of all (largest in the soapberry) are black, round, and used for leis. Also mānele.

2. Northeast tradewind. Cf. A ʻe Loa, Moaʻe, naʻe.

3. Blight. (Malo 199.)

4. directional. Upward, sideways, nearby, contiguous, adjoining, next, approaching (often expresses space and time near the addressee, table 2, ).

5. Replacement of e in songs (commonly written a e, but a glottal stop is pronounced before ʻe).

6. Maui name for maua 2, trees.

1. interj. Yes; to say yes, consent, conform, grant, agree, approve, let, confirm, admit, permit, allow, accept, yield; approval, admission, permission. Cf. aʻe nei.

2. Sap wrung from seaweed or leaves of plants such as taro; liquid remaining after dregs have settled, as of pia, arrowroot starch; saliva, drooling of the mouth.

3. Fine, mashed, comminuted, as dust or powder; silky soft, as down; smooth, as well-mixed poi or bread dough.

4. To rise, of the tide.

5. A native fern (Polypodium pellucidum) commonly seen at Kī-lau-ea Volcano. It has oblong fronds 15 to 40 cm long, once divided into about fifteen or more pairs of oblong segments, each of which bears many round fruit dots. (Neal 25.) Cf. ʻae lau nui.

6. Same as ʻaʻae.

7. Shoots from main root portion of the wauke plant. See ohi 3.

8. See ʻae kai, water's edge.

To step over, get on top of, tread upon, trespass; to raise; to massage the back with the feet; to break a taboo or violate a law; counter sorcery; to inflict sorcery on a sorcerer; to get into by stepping up, as into a car; step. Fig., oppressed.
To rise up; to raise the head; to come up from under water.
Cord, as used in joining two or more nets into a larger one. Rare.
Wandering, shiftless, unstable; to wander, stray; tramp. Cf. hōkū ʻaeʻa.
Pas/imp. of ʻaʻe 1.

1. A prolonged sound, wail; to prolong, stretch.

2. Andante.

1. Mixing of a dark or brilliant color with a lighter one, as feathers in a lei; of dark hair of a young person with streaks of gray; to mix, as drinks.

2. A kind of banana with green and white striped leaves and fruits. (Neal 249) Also koaʻe and manini.

3. A fish (no data).

1. Redup. of ʻae 3. See lole, mehelu.

2. A small native shrub (Lycium sandwicense) growing near salt marshes and among rocks near the sea. It has light-colored bark; succulent, narrow pale-green leaves about 2.6 cm long; small white to blue-tinted flowers; and small red berries. (Neal 740) Also ʻākulikuli ʻaeʻae, ʻākulikuli ʻōhelo, and ʻōhelo kai.

3. Water hyssop, a succulent herb (Bacopa monnieria).

4. Redup. of ʻae 4.
Redup. of ʻaʻe.
A small green fish resembling the hīnālea, used as pani (food or drink taken to finish a medical treatment) for certain diseases of children of the ʻea type.
Name of a star (no data).

1. See ʻaeʻa.

2. . A variety of wild sweet potato, good only as pig food.
Fine net, as used for ʻōpelu and maomao fish; it was held open at the mouth by kuku, stretching poles.
Chant refrain.
Chant ending.
A Step, as on a carriage; running board of an automobile.
Place where sea and land meet; water's edge.
Ancient type of tapa (no data).
Falcon, vulture.
See ʻaekelona

1. Eagle.

2. Alto Eng. See ʻaleko.
See ʻaeko
Golden eagle.
Directional part. aʻe + demon.
Same as ʻae 5, with large leaves.
Agreement, contract, truce, accord, deal; to come to an agreement; contracted.
Rotten, of eggs that do not hatch due to infertility. Fig., spoiled, worthless.
Name for the trade wind. See ex., kiʻekiʻe. Cf. A ʻe 2, Moaʻe, welo 1.
Just now, lately; nearby, not far; ordinary, insignificant.

1. Stilts.

2. See "Hawaiian":  stilt bird (Himantopus mexicanus knudseni), an endemic subspecies of stilt, formerly common on the main Hawaiian Islands, endangered. Also kukuluaeʻo.

3. Same as kīholo 1, wood fishhook.
Train of a dress (origin uncertain). (Kam. 76:99.)
To be well supplied with comforts and necessities.
A kind of fine tapa, used in kuni and other ceremonies, as for divining with pebbles. Also kaha-loa, pālau-anahu.
Sandy beach.

1. Thin, tall spindly; to weave to and fro, as seaweed; to sway, as a branch or sea eddy. Cf. ewa, māewa.

2. Possessing a family or lineage. Cf. ēwe 1.

Why? What? For what reason? To do What? To ask what? (Aha frequently follows he and is often written heaha; cf. .) He aha? What is it? What? He aha kēlā? What is that? He aha kāna? What has he got there? What does he have to say about it? 
What business is it of his [sarcastic]? I ke aha? Why? What for? He aha ia mea? What of it [frequently spoken with an outward gesture of the right hand with palm upwards]? He … aha? What kind of? For what purpose? He hale aha kēlā? What kind of a house is that? What is it used for? He mea aha? What's it used for [annoyance]? Why? He aha ihola lā, no one knows why, for no apparent reason.
Aha (exclamation of surprise).

1. Meeting, assembly, gathering, convention, court, party. Many types of ʻaha are listed below.

2. Sennit; cord braided of coconut husk, human hair, intestines of animals; string for a musical instrument; to stretch the ʻaha cord for the outline of a house so that the posts may be properly placed; measurement of an edge or border.

3. A prayer or service whose efficacy depended on recitation under taboo and without interruption. The priest was said to carry a cord (ʻaha). (Malo 180–1.) Ua kaʻi ka ʻaha, the prayer is rendered.

4. Millepede, so called because it coils itself up like a string.

5. Any of the needlefishes of the family Belonidae. The young are called ʻahaʻaha. Varieties are qualified by the terms holowī, mele, and uliuli.

6. Design supposed to resemble the continuing track of a duck, carved on tapa beaters. Also ʻahaana and kapuaʻi-koloa.
num. Four (usually in counting in series): four times.
To pant, to breathe hard with heat, as a dog. Cf. hā, breath.

1. Cordage.

2. To sit with back stiff and upright, arms akimbo, head up, as with haughty air of superiority; to sit cross-legged; to stand with hands on hips (considered rude and overbearing).

3. Young of the ʻaha, a fish.
Feast, dinner party, banquet; to feast, Lit., meal gathering. Many types of ʻahaʻaina are listed below.
Holy Communion, Lord's Supper; feast of the Lord.
Feast of weeks. (Puk. 34.22.)
Feast of consecration or dedication, as of a house, church, canoe, or fish net.
Feast of dedication. (Ioane. 10.22.)
Commemorative or anniversary feast.
Feast given at the time of a boy's subincision. Called in Christian times ʻahaʻaina ʻoki poepoe.

Feast given at the completion of a student's first work (as mat, quilt, tapa, net), or of a child's first fish catch; one purpose was to ask the gods to grant greater knowledge and skill to the craftsman. Lit., feast to care for. Cf. kahukahu.
Feast given to ask pardon of the gods. Lit., feast to forgive sins.
Feast of Tabernacles. Biblical.
Initiation feast.
Feast held after completion of a joint project or cooperative undertaking, especially harvest.
Similar to ʻahaʻaina maka luhi.

Feast given to honor those who prepared the feast and served, the workers being served by those who had celebrated before; also a feast to celebrate completion of a particularly laborious project. Lit., feast for tired persons.
Funeral feast, intended to comfort the mourners.
Wedding feast or reception.
Feast given shortly after the birth of the first child, intended to clear the way (māwaewae) of misfortune for that child and for all others to follow.
Feast of the Passover. Biblical.
Holy Communion. Lit., feast of bread.
Feast on the first birthday of a child, or to celebrate any anniversary. Lit., feast for completion of the year.

Feast given principally to break the monotony of country life; those instigating the feast would sprinkle (pī wai) their friends with a little water; those sprinkled brought food to the feast or, later, gifts of coins.
Graduation feast.
Graduation feast, as for hula dancing or lua fighting.
Feast of tears, held on the first anniversary of a death, a happy occasion, as the death by this time has been accepted by the family (Na_na_ 138).
Design said to resemble duck tracks, carved on tapa beaters. Also ʻaha and kapuaʻi-koloa.
District court.
Convention of delegates; name for American presidential conventions.
Var. of ahahana.

Syllables repeated in chants, usually at ends of verses, similar to ēhē; a taunting singsong teasing phrase, used especially by children, meaning “Oh! Oh! Aha! Shame on you! You are going to catch it!” As a verb, to tease. See ex., lei 1, ʻuhene. Also ahana and ahana kōkō lele, both meaningless.
Cord support for gourd water bottles.

Ceremonial measuring of the dimensions of a mana house within a place of worship; a priest carried a line to the four corner posts of the mana, and the chief sacrificed a pig; name of the line. (Malo 166–7.)
Song festival, concert.
Annual meeting of Sunday Schools, as of Congregationalists.
Probate court.
General name for court assembly. Names of several types of courts are listed below.
District court.
Police court.
Circuit court.
Old name for ʻaha kākau, court of records.
Executive council.
Supreme Court.
Military court, court martial.
Superior court.
Lower court.
Administrative body, assembly.
Court of domestic relations.
Probate court. Lit., court settling inheritance property.
Society, club, association, organization, company, convention. Various types are listed below.
A term used in 1911 for evangelical conference of all the islands.
Christian Endeavor Society.
Temperance union. Lit., society forbidding intoxicating liquor.
Academy, learned society.
Hawaiian Sugar Planters' Association.
Sunday School association.
Secret society.
Sons and Daughters of Hawaiian Warriors. Lit., warriors' society.
Hawaiian Historical Society.

1. Corporation, association.

2. Congregational. Rare.

column2: ʻAhahui Wāhine Kalikiano Hōʻole Wai ʻOna
column3: ʻAhahui Wāhine Kalikiano Hōʻole Wai ʻOna
column4: Women's Christian Temperance Union.

1. Assembly for ballroom dancing; a ball.

2. Ancient assembly for the hulahula religious ceremony.
Bristle worm, a hairy sea creature (Eurythoe complanata).
Commemorative wooden or stone pillar (probably short for ʻā hailona, symbolic stone).
To carry off, chase, rout; to flee, run away.
Redup. of ʻāhaʻi.
To go with the wind, to disappear completely.
Small gathering for private conversation; small or secret council, as called in an emergency.
Reporter, messenger, bringer of news; in legends, the sole survivor of a disastrous defeat who reports the news; to tell news.
Short for aha ʻia ana. See aha.
Same as ʻāhaʻi.
Drinking party, as ʻaha inu waina, wine-drinking party, ʻaha inu lama, rum party.
Messenger; to carry word.
Circuit court.
Court of records.

1. A sacred assembly.

2. Sacred sennit cord belonging to a high chief and kept on a high place before his house; trespassers entering the house were killed if the cord remained in place, but if it fell down and the stranger stepped over it, this was a token of the stranger's high rank or kinship with the owner of the cord. Some chiefs had several such cords, each given a name, and some were used after the owner's death in making the kāʻai, container for his bones.
Session of the legislature.
An 1854 name for the highest court.
Probate court.

1. Native trees (species of Bobea) with small to medium-sized, oblong leaves; small greenish or white flowers; and small, purple-to-black juicy fruits. The wood is yellow and formerly was used for poi boards and canoe rims.

2. Same as haokea, a taro.
A small-leafed ʻahakea (Bobea elatior var.
A large-leafted ʻahakea (Bobea elatior).
Senate.
Supreme Court.
Grand jury.
Same as ʻAha Hoʻokolokolo Kiʻekiʻe. Lit., powerful court.
Cord used for measuring, as in laying out a garden or house.
Cabinet, assembly of ministers.
Council meeting, discussion meeting, advisory council, conference.
Privy council, secret deliberative meeting.
See limalima.
Rectangle. Lit., two equal sides.
Presbytery, meeting of elders.
Judiciary session, meeting of judges.
Place or assembly for practice of athletic games, as sham fights. Lit., assembly for relaxation.

1. Hammock, as of tapa, fastened to the manuea, center support of a house; hammock in general. Lit., sennit meshes.

2. Cord with which edges of cracks in gourd bowls were sewn together in crisscross patterns suggestive of net mesh; the technique for such repair.

3. Strangling in lua fighting, as with green vines.

4. Secret meeting of priests to pray for a chief.
A Yellow-spotted needlefish.
Concert, song concert, song festival.

1. An assembly watching a lua contest of the kind called hakakā-a-moa.

2. A cord made from the entrails of an enemy killed in a lua fight of the hakakā-a-moa type.
Island conference, with representative from a single island, especially of Congregationalists.
Same as ahahana.
Inquisition, inquest, ʻAha nīele kumu make, coroner's inquest.
Court of inquiry.
A native sedge (Machaerina mariscoides subsp.
Probably similar to hao 3, 4. (For. 6:472.)
Legislature, assembly, council meeting, congress; to hold such meetings; to serve in the legislature.
Legislature, lawmaking body.
Congress of the United States; national assembly.
Conference of elders.
Congress.
District court.
Convention of delegates from all the islands, especially as held by the Hawaiian Evangelical Association of Congregational Christian Churches.
A kind of tapa dyed with kukui bark and decorated with fine lines, for chiefs.
Congregation, prayer assembly.
Board of arbitration.
Council of chiefs. Lit., regal meeting.
Waterhead, beginning of a water-course; to overflow. (AP)
Breeze; to blow or breathe gently. waft; softly blowing.
, interj. To exclaim, to oh and ah; yes, so that's it, so, oh.
A hacking cough; to cough. Also ʻehē. Cf. ʻahēʻahē, ʻehēʻehē.

1. Timid, shy, wary.

2. Wild taro.

1. Pas/imp. of ahe.

2. When (future).
Same as ʻāheahea 2.
Redup. of ahe; soft, gentle in sound; weak.
Redup. of ʻahē.

1. To wilt, as a plant; warm, insipid.

2. A native shrub (Chenopodium oahuense) and air introduced weedy herb (C. album), both with narrow to triangular or rhomboidal, thickish leaves; flowers small, in panicles. Young plants, leaves, and plant tips are used for greens, wrapped in ti leaves and cooked on hot coals. Also ʻahea, ʻāhewahewa, alaweo; alaweo huna (Niʻihau), ʻāweoweo. (Neal 331.)

3. Var. name for pakai 2.

4. Same as heahea, to call.
Snare; to snare. Also pahele.

1. To condemn, blame, censure, reproach, convict; condemnation, blame, conviction.

2. Walleyed, cross-eyed (with maka).

3. Oʻahu name for the mānā fern.

4. A mimosa tree. (AP)
Same as ʻāheahea 2, a shrub.
Fire, match, lightning; to burn in a fire, destroy by fire. See ahikao, ahikoe, ahi koli, ahimakani, ipo, limu ahi, pau ahi.

Hawaiian tuna fishes, especially the yellow-fin tuna (Thunnus albacares), an important fish in the Honolulu market. The name ʻahi may be qualified by the terms hiʻu wīwī (thin tail) or kaʻakaʻalāʻau, kaha uli (dark stripe), kananā (young stage, lit., the defiant one; cf. he aha sananā), kihikihi or ʻōpū hemo (loose belly), lepalepa, maha ʻōʻō (piercing brow), mālailena, maoli, pālaha, and poʻo nui (large head). (PNP kasi.)
Faded.

1. Same as ʻāhiahia.

2. How many.
Tinder resulting from plowing with the fire plow; the powdery rubbings that ignite.
Evening, late afternoon; to become evening.
To defame, slander, tattle against; false report, defamation, slander.
Faint, obscure, faded; dim, as colors in tapa or cloth.
Pas/imp. of ahiahi; overtaken by evening.
Christmas Eve, Christmas night.
New Year's Eve.
Volcano, volcanic fire. Lit., fire destroying land.
Silvery gray, faded.

1. A low spreading bush (Metrosideros sp.), formerly numerous in Nuʻu-anu. Also ʻāhihi lehua, lehua ʻāhihi, ʻāhihi kū ma kua.

2. Any plant with long runners or creepers, as cup of gold; any creeping vine. Cf. hihi, entangled.
Same as kananā; a shark or a fierce and courageous fighter. See nanā.
Fireworks (perhaps from Eng. scow [kao], as fireworks were first displayed from ships of explores) Also kao lele.
Skyrocket, rocket.
Match. Also ahipele, kūkaepele. Lit., scratching fire.
To pass fire from one candlenut to the next on a chain (koli) or candlenut torch. Lit., to fire the torch.
num. Seven (especially in counting in a series); seven times.
Fire fountain, firebrands thrown over cliffs at Ka-maile, Kauaʻi. See ahi and chant, Ka-ua-hae.
Bits of crustacea and bones found at the opening of an octopus burrow.
Gasoline. Lit., wind fire,

1. Gray, gray- or white-haired.

2. Blue denim cloth, dungarees, blue jeans.

1. Same as ʻāhina 1, 2.

2. The silver-sword (Argyroxiphium sandwicense), a native plant found only at altitudes of 1,870 m or more on Maui and Hawaiʻi; the many long silvery leaves forming a rounded rosette to 60 cm in diameter; about a hundred purplish, daisy-like flowers borne on an erect, leafy stem, which is about 1.8 m high. (Neal 845–7.) Also hinahina.

3. A native spreading shrub to 1 m high, (Artemisia australis); leaves divided into narrow segments, hoary on under side; flowers in panicles, small, daisy-like. Pounded leaves are used for asthma. (Neal 852.) Also hinahina.

4. Same as hinahina 2, Florida moss.
A native fern (Cyrtomium caryotideum), with fronds 25 to 35 cm long, once divided into 6 to 18 broadly sickle-shaped pinnae, lobed at the base. Also kāʻapeʻape.
Lazy, indolent; to shirk work, loiter.
Albacore, Thunnus alalunga (family Scombridae). Lit., flat ʻahi.
Match.
Pinwheel (fireworks).

1. Wild, untamed, as animals or plants.

2. Name of a wind common in the mountains of Kahana, Oʻahu and by the sea.
Redup. of ʻāhiu 1.
Dark, dusky, somber.

1. Line, cord, lashing, fishing line, thong, kite string.

2. Breath; to breathe. 
See ahonui, pauaho, paupauaho.

3. It is better or preferable (used after e, sometimes in comparisons). See ahona.
Thatch purlin. Also ʻaʻaho. See ʻahohui, ʻaho-kele, ʻahopiʻo kuahui, ʻahopueo.
Thatch purlin support.
Small lashing on the pueo main purlin.
Horizontal thatch purlin. (Kep. 183.)
Name given for roof thatching on top of the ridgepole. Also weʻo (For. 5:645.)

An endemic fish (Kuhlia sandvicensis) found in both fresh and salt water. The mature stage is āhole, the young stage āholehole. Because of the meaning of hole, to strip away, this fish was used for magic, as to chase away evil spirits and for love magic. It was also called a "sea pig" (puaʻa kai) and used ceremonially as a substitute for pig. Foreigners were sometimes called āhole because of the light skin of the fish.
Stroke in lua fighting. See Ke-aho-lehi.
Young stage of the āhole, Hawaiian flagtail.
Sliding rock, landslide, avalanche. (For. 6:472.)
Same as more common ahonui. Lit., longbreath. For aho loa see aho 1.
See loto 4.
Better, well, well-being, fortunate, improved; to need (aho 3 + -na).
Patience; patient, enduring, long suffering; to tolerate. Lit., great breath. Cf. aholoa, pauaho, paupauaho; see ex., lawe 2, makua.
Lashing fastening kaupaku roof to kua ʻiole, upper ridgepole.
Thatch purlin support.
Lashing on the pueo main purlin.
Main purlin in a house. Also pueo.
Heap, pile, collection, mound, mass; altar, shrine, cairn; a traplike stone enclosure made by fishermen for fish to enter; laid, as the earth oven. Cf. ahu waiwai, ahuwale, Oʻahu.

Garment or covering for the upper part of the body and shoulders, as a cape, shirt, coat; to put on or wear such; fine soft mat, formerly often used as a cloak; mat used as a canoe cover; short for ʻahu ʻula. Cf. ʻaʻahu, ʻahu ʻao, ʻahu hīnano, ʻahu moena, ʻahunā liʻi 1, ʻahu ʻoʻeno, ʻahu ua, ʻahu uhi waʻa, ʻahu ʻula.

1. To swell, as a wave; heap, mound, hillock, knoll, pile; heaped, humped; tremendous.

2. Young, as of the aku, kawakawa and moano fishes. Cf. ʻōhua.
Healthy, vigorous; strength and vigor, as of animal or plant; to grow rapidly, thrive. Also ehuehu.
To overeat, waste food, squander.
Rare var. of ahuwale. (For. 4:533.)
See "Kukui":  branches strewn about, as after a storm.
Choice mat of fine strands of soft white young pandanus leaves, about 3 cm mesh.

1. A sedge (Cyperus javanicus) about .3 to 1.3 m high, with a basal tuft of long narrow leaves and a radiating inflorescence borne at the tip of a long slender stem. (Neal 86–7.) Also ʻehuʻawa, puʻukaʻa haole.

2. Another coarse sedge (Cyperus hypochlorus) similar to the preceding one, but with green instead of brown flowers.
Kava dregs. See ex., hoka 2.

The umbrella plant, a leafless ornamental sedge (Cyperus alternifolius), 30 to 180 cm high, the umbrella-shaped flowering head with about 20 grasslike rays at the top of a slender stalk. (Neal 84–5.) Also puʻukaʻa haole.
To make two thicknesses by folding; to double up, fold, as paper or tapa.
Soft, fine mat garment plaited from fine strands of dried bracts of male pandanus fruit.
Bunch or cluster, as of bananas, grapes; whole pandanus fruit consisting of keys.

1. Pandanus fruit.

2. Protuberance of the vagina resulting from syphilis; the roughness of the skin was thought to suggest the pandanus fruit.
To stone to death; slaughter by burying the victim under a pile of stones.
Ti-leaf raincoat or cape.
Pestilence, epidemic, heaped up, as dead bodies.
Overheated, as over stones; white-hot.
Overdone, overcooked; overcultivated, as soil.
Discolored, foamy, feathery, choppy, uneven, mussed.

1. Young of the kūmū fish. (PNP ʻafulu.)

2. Same as huluhulu 2.
Fine patterned mat, plaited with materials of different colors.
Pile, heap.
Coat, garment, ti-leaf raincoat.
A land division.

1. A tapa for chiefs, colored with candlenut and noni and striped red.

2. Issue of a union of a male chief and a commoner. Also waikī and kūkae pōpolo.
. Name given for a fish of the ʻōpakapaka type.
Matting with twilled pattern, associated with Kauaʻi. (Laie 479.)
Abbreviation for ahupuaʻa.
Cloth bound about the head of warriors. (Ellis 102.)

1. Land division usually extending from the uplands to the sea, so called because the boundary was marked by a heap (ahu) of stones surmounted by an image of a pig (puaʻa), or because a pig or other tribute was laid on the altar as tax to the chief. The landlord or owner of an ahupuaʻa might be a konohiki.

2. The altar on which the pig was laid as payment to the chief for use of the ahupuaʻa land.

Old type of raincoat made of dried ti leaves fastened to an olonā net, or consisting of a small mat about 1.2 by 1.8 m, made of makaloa sedge, and so supple that it could be rolled up; to wear this garment. Today, raincoat is kukaweke and kuka ua.
Mat canoe covering that protected paddlers in storms.

1. Feather cloak or cape made of the feathers of the ʻōʻō, ʻiʻiwi and other birds, usually red or yellow trimmed with black or green, formerly worn by high chiefs and kings. Today about 160 have been located in museums and collections of the world, the largest being in the Bishop Museum, Honolulu. Imitation cloaks of plush, felt, paper, or dyed feathers (rare) are worn today in pageants and by members of Hawaiian societies. Lit., royal cloak.

2. Same as Ka-ʻahu-ʻula.

3. See limuʻahuʻula.
See ʻupena ahuulu.
Storehouse, heap of goods.
Exposed, conspicuous, prominent, obvious, in plain view; heaped up.

1. Coition; to have sexual relations, cohabit (frequently pronounced ei).

2. Same as wai inter. pronoun.

3. Linking or anaphoric part. frequently pronounced ei.

4. Short for aia, there. Cf. ai loa, ai luna.
of surprise.

1. Same as aʻiaʻi 1.

2. replacing i often in songs; usually written a i. Cf. aʻe, aʻo.
nonproductive transitive suffix. See huaʻi, luaʻi, lumaʻi. Cf. Kauaʻi, kaulaʻi.

1. Score, points in a game, stake, wager.

2. Dancing style or type. Cf. ʻai ʻami, ʻai haʻa.

3. Stroke or hold in lua fighting; spear thrust.

4. Stone used in the kimo game other than the stone that is tossed and caught, which is the pōhaku kimo.
Neck, neck of a shirt or dress, neck of the iheihe fish net. Cf. ʻāʻīkū, ʻāʻīlepe, ʻāī oeoe, ʻāʻī ʻoloʻolo, ʻāʻī pahāha, ʻāʻī palaʻe, ʻāʻīpau, ʻāʻī puʻu, ʻāʻī uaua.

1. There, there it is, there are (sometimes shortened to ai, with loss of the following part. i, see ai lalo, ai luna). Cf. also aia hoʻi, aia kā, aia lā, aia naʻe, ai lā, ai loa.

2. Depending on, only if, only when, whatever, whenever.
Ungodly, godless, irreligious, wicked, unbelieving, careless of observance of taboos; wickedness.
Here! Here it is!
Behold! See there! Lo! Suddenly.
Same as ʻaiā.
See aiāhua

1. Bright as moonlight; fair, white, clear, pure, brilliant, shining; brightness, clearness.

2. A native tree or shrub (Streblus sandwicensis [Pseudomorus sandwicensis and P. brunoniana are synonyms]), with narrow-ovate leaves, and milky sap; a member of the fig family. (Neal 299.)

1. See ʻōpū ʻaiʻai

2. Dependent, one living on the resources of another.
See "hōʻaiʻai":  To release, as war captives.
Redup. of ʻaiā.
Swinging, unsteady motion.
To rule or own land.
Name given for persons sacrificed for not observing taboos during the offering of prayers by the priest (pronunciation not certain). (Kep. 139.)
There now! So it' there after all!
Same as hulu manu, a seaweed. Lit., food of the turtle.
A native trailing, woody plant (Coprosma ernodeoides), with narrow, tiny leaves and black, berry-like fruits. (Neal 803) Lit., food of the nēnē goose. Also kūkaenēnē, leponēnē, pūnēnē.
There! I told you so! There it is!
Same as ʻāʻīpalaʻe.
To rule (or eat) as a chief.
Attendant of the chief's household, intimate of a chief. Lit., eating [in the] presence.
To eat like a shark. Fig., to have a ravenous appetite.
Type of hula with little foot movement, but with hip revolving throughout the dance; to dance thus.
Clothes iron; to iron, press, as clothes. Eng.
But, furthermore.
To eat like a pig; to eat greedily; to wolf food.

1. To look about with covetous or jealous eyes; to practice sorcery or poisoning.

2. Weary, discouraged by long continued work. See ex., kupaliʻi 2.
Debt; to owe. See ʻaoʻao ʻai,ʻē, lawe ʻaiʻē.

1. All species of the endemic Hawaiian genus Nothocestrum, soft-wooded shrubs and trees with ovate or oblong leaves, yellowish flowers, and whitish to reddish berries. One slender species was used for thatching sticks (ʻaho) and fire-making.

2. Same as kāwaʻu, a native Ilex; holly.

3. Exhaustion. Rare.
Same as ʻaiea 3.

1. Hula step danced with bended knees; the chanting for this dance is usually bombastic and emphatic; to dance thus. Lit., low style.

2. Allegro.
See hamu 2.
Center of a taro corm. (Kep. 16.5.)
Where? See hea 5.
See ai hea
Similar to ʻai kū. (Kam. 64:87.) Lit., to eat walking.
To eat proudly of high-priced food, as a rich person; fig., to have many women.
Vagabond; to wander, roam. (And.)
To steal, rob, pilfer, filch, cheat; thief, robber, theft, larceny. Cf. Marquesan kaihue.
Pas/imp. forms of ʻaihue.
See ʻaihueea
See ʻaihueea
See ʻaihueea
To kidnap; kidnapper.
To eat in order to destroy; to destroy wantonly or by violence or sorcery.
To have the use of fish ponds (loko); to control the interior (loko) land division known as ʻili.
Hard and poor tasting, as thin or inferior fish.
See kahaʻula and cf. .
Collar. Lit., neck collar (Eng.).
Stiff collar.
Ice cream. Eng.
Unpounded taro. Fig., difficult problem that must be chewed, as whole taro.
Name of a star.
Cannibal, man-eater; to eat human flesh.
Friend; friendly; to become a friend. See hale aikāne.

A privileged friend who shares the profits of a friend's land, sometimes sharing in the work; one who shares a friend's spouse; to share land or spouse; to pay part of a debt but withhold the remainder. Lit., eat [on the] border.
To eat under taboo; to observe eating taboos.
See kāwele 2.
Sick and tired of a person or situation, surfeited, exhausted, discouraged, fatigued.
To cut or tear obliquely, as with teeth or edged instrument; to seize or tear with the teeth; to fit by rabbeting, rabbet.
Redup. of ʻai kepa; to snap the jaws; to speak rapidly, as with overlapping words; to talk too much or too fast; to jabber.
To light up dimly; to look furtively, peek, peer.
Name of a star, possibly Sirius. Also called Hiki-kau-e-lono.
Ethiopia; Ethiopian. (Gr.
See ʻAikiopa
of scorn or derision, especially rejoicing over others' misfortunes, with meaning “serves you right” or “I told you so”; as a verb, to use this term.
Name of a wind at Nuʻalolo, Kauaʻi. (For. 5:95.)
To eat freely; to do as one wishes; to break taboos or transgress. (Kam. 64:87.) See ex., ʻai 1.

1. High collar, stiff collar.

2. Spasmodic affection of the neck muscles which draws the head toward the affected side, a torticollis; stiff neck

3. Croup.
Medicinal juices mixed with poi or mashed sweet potato, used to build up strength. Lit., kneaded poi.
Egypt; Egyptian. Perhaps Gr.
See ʻAikupika
Short for aia lā
Any oil, grease, lard; to oil, grease, lubricate. Eng. Many kinds of oil and grease are listed below.
Scorched or sunburned.
Same as ʻailea.
Kerosene. Lit., earth oil.
Turpentine. Lit., oil for drying paint.
Castor oil. Lit., purge oil.
There, to be there.
See ai laila
Sperm oil. Eng.
Cod-liver oil.
Castor oil. Lit., castor-bean oil.
Down there.
See ai lalo
Kerosene. Lit., steam oil.

1. In love.

2. Island. Eng.
Thick grease.
Frying oil. Eng.
Lard, pork grease.

1. To eat a great deal.

2. A bundle of cooked taro wrapped in ti leaves.
Gasoline (contraction of ʻaila, oil, and ea, air).
Ruffles, folds, gathers about the neck; to make ruffles; to ruffle feathers, as a grouse. (AP)
To eat filth (insulting).

1. To struggle for breath; to breathe with convulsions, gasp, pant, twitch, jerk.

2. To pull, as weeds. (Kep. 157.)
Pas/imp. of ʻāʻili.
Same as ʻaikapa.
Redup. of ʻāʻili; spasm.
Irish. Eng.
See ʻAiliki
A method of lua fighting; to grab little finger of an adversary and twist it.
Away off in the distance.
See ai loa
Name of a wind at Kau-pō, Maui. (For. 5:101.) Lit., sea cucumber food.

1. Ceremony usually marking the end of training, so called because the student ate (ʻai) a portion of the head, and especially the brains (lolo), (of a fish, dog, or hog offered to the gods; to partake of the ceremony.

2. Skilled, adept, expert, trained, proficient.

See "hōʻailona":  Sign, symbol, representation, insignia, emblem, mark, badge, signal, omen, portent, target, credential, token of recognition, a lot that is cast; title (legal); depth sounding; to mark; to take a depth sounding; to draw lots. Cf. hailona, kila 2. Hōʻailona helu, plural sign or marker, algebra. Hōʻailona mahele, measure signature in music. Hōʻailona kūʻauhau, hōʻailona no ke kūlana, family crest or coat of arms. Hōʻailona mōʻī, badge or emblem of royalty, sceptre. Hōʻailona paʻi, printed stamp. Hōʻailona manawa, time signature in music. Hōʻailona lanakila, emblem or trophy of victory, trophy. Ka pana ʻana aku i ka hōʻailona (1 Sam. 20.20), shooting at the mark.
Up there.
See ai luna
Light meal, snack; to eat such.
Name of a wind at Hāna, Maui. (For. 5:101.) Lit., bait eating.
Linnet, California house finch, papaya bird (Carpodacus mexicanus frontalis), an early introduction to Hawaiʻi, now well established throughout the Hawaiian Islands. Lit., papaya eater.
Ruler of a moku, district or island; to rule a moku.
Sexual intercourse. (PCP kainga.)

1. Meal. Cf. ʻaina ahiahi, ʻaina awakea, ʻaina kakahiaka, and ʻai, to eat.

2. Pas/imp. of ʻai 1; eaten, consumed devoured. See ex., nūpolupolu.

3. Rejected, as refuse, especially of sugar cane.

4. See ʻaina kea, ʻaina kea melemele.
Sore aching; stiffness, as from overexercise.
Land, earth. Cf. ʻai, to eat; ʻaina, kamaʻāina.
Crackling, snapping; an explosive sound, sharp report, bang (rare), loud prolonged sound, peal (less common than ʻuʻina). Cf. ʻaʻaʻina.
Evening meal, supper, dinner.
Noon meal, lunch.
Foreign land, Kō nā ʻāina ʻē (Mat. 10.5), of the Gentiles; international.
Land of one's birth, native land, homeland, birthplace. See one hānau.
Foreign land, mainland United States.
Holy Land.
Pas/imp. of ʻaʻina.
Holy Land.
Homestead, homesteading land. Lit., land for security.
See pulapula.
Redup. of ʻaʻina.
Morning meal, breakfast.
A good-looking variety of sugar cane, of medium height, striped red and green or yellow, pith white and brown, leaves and leaf sheaths with white markings; used in medicine. Also pū kea.
A variety of sugar cane, the yellow mutant of ʻaina kea.
Navy blue cotton cloth.
Cane trash, bagasse. Cf. ʻaina 3.
Land purchased or for sale; land in fee simple.
Land free from all rent and taxes.
Crown lands.
Fatherland, mainland.
Short for makaʻāinana. (For. 6:39.)
Trust territory.
Great power, great land, mainland.
Not eaten or consumed; without vegetable foods.
Greenland.
Poetic name for China. Lit., flower land.
Continent. Lit., land not surrounded.
Said to be a name for the New Hebrides. (RC 293.) See Nānā-pua.
Exhausted by strain and trouble, tired, weary.
To criticize severely, hunt for flaws, split hairs.
Bad temper; bad tempered, cross. See niha and ex., kūpalaiki.
To eat freely, without observance of taboos.
Same as hāinu, hoʻohāinu, to give to drink.
See ʻāinu
Principle or staple food; to eat a lot.
Same as ioio, grooves.

1. A wave that rises and falls without breaking; a swell.

2. Heigh-ho. Eng.
Slim-necked; a slim or slender neck. Nickname for wives of early missionaries because their bonnets made their necks appear slim.
Cooked unpounded taro. Lit., whole taro.
Or.
Sagging of the chin and throat, as in old age; double chin; goiter.
Stiff neck. Fig., disobedience, obstinacy; obstinate.
Cooked taro pounded into a hard mass not mixed with water, sometimes preserved in ti-leaf bundles. Fig., a difficult problem. Lit., hard poi.
Mumps. Lit., swollen neck.
Scrofula, a scrofulous neck, abscess on neck. Also ʻāʻīʻalaʻala.
To eat a dab of bait. Fig., to take the leavings of others, to steal another's mate, one who does so; a beggar.
Same as ʻai pala maunu. Lit., to eat tooth tartar.
Glandular swelling in the neck, thyroid.

Eater of filth, scavenger; to eat rotten food; 
rotten food; and insulting epithet for a sorcerer who prays others to death. See manu ʻai pilau.
To gulp, choke, suffocate. Rare.
Feast to celebrate the completion of a hard task or project. Lit., food [for] workers [in the] sun.
To eat together (both sexes), formerly tabu.
To encircle, go around, encompass, environ. Cf. pōʻai puni.
Lumped, calloused, or swollen neck; swelling of the neck or shoulder, said to be caused by carrying heavy burdens; one with a calloused neck.
Lumpy poi.
Steward, butler, said to be so called because the chief's steward got calluses (puʻupuʻu) on his shoulders from carrying food.
Stiff neck. Fig., stubborn.
To eat wastefully; a wasteful or riotous eater.
Same as āiwaiwa.
num. Nine (usually in counting in a series); nine times.
Nursing, suckling, as an infant; to nurse, suckle; a nursing child, unweaned animal. Lit., to eat milk.

Inexplicable, mysterious, marvelous, strange, amazing, fantastic, fathomless, incomprehensible, wonderful because of divinity; wonderfully proficient or skilled; weirdly bad, notorious. See ex., kapolakā.
Abbreviation of ʻākau, north.

1. Shadow. Cf. hoaka 4.

2. Reflection, image, likeness (Nah. 12.8); faint glimmer preceding the rising of the moon; essence of an offering rather than the flesh; to appear, of moonlight. Many words compounded with aka express clarity, brightness, related to this meaning. Cf. hoaka 3.

3. Embryo at the moment of conception.

4. Newly hatched fish in the stage in which its body is still transparent. Cf. hāuli, mana, kākau.

5. Knuckles, as of hands or ankles; joints of the backbone; node and stalk of kava; kava slip for planting.
Carefully, slowly. Cf. akaʻai, akahai, akahana, akahao, akahele, akahoe, akaholo, akakuʻu, akalewa, akaluli, akanahe, akanoho, akaʻōlelo. (PCP ata-.)
But, however, nevertheless, on the other hand, notwithstanding.
To laugh; laughter. See ʻaka hene.
To tear off, peel; to break open, as a seal (Hoik. 5.2); to fall off or down, as old thatching of a house; to break up, as the sides of a house; to uproot; ruffled, as feathers.
A type of fine white tapa. (GP 8.) Cf. akaaka 2.
To eat slowly, carefully, Cf. Easter ʻaka kai, eat more.

1. Clear, luminous, transparent, visible, manifest, plain, intelligible; thin, as cloth; shining, bright, distinct. Cf. mōakaaka.

2. A white and very thin tapa. Cf. aka-ʻaʻamo.

3. A downy, thorny branching plant (Solanum aculeatissimum), 30 to 90 cm high, from tropical America. It bears round scarlet fruits 2.6 em in diameter, which are strung for leis. (Neal 742–3.) Also kīkānia lei.

4. Same as aka 5.
See akaaka
To laugh, ridicule; laughter, merriment.
Redup. of ʻākaʻa; peeled, as the skin by sunburn or by drinking kava; peeling; ruffled. Fig., exhausted, thin.

An endemic begonia (Hillebrandia sandwicensis), a succulent herb with oblique, rounded lobed leaves 10 to 20 cm in diameter and with sprays of small pink or white flowers, found only in shaded, damp ravines. (Neal 602.) Kauaʻi. Also pua maka nui.
Same as akahiʻu.

1. The great bulrush (Scirpus validus, formerly called S. lacustris) that grows on the edge of fresh or brackish water marshes in Hawaiʻi. The plants have unbranched, slender, green stems, 1 to 3 m high, looking like giant onion plants. Formerly Hawaiians used them for house thatch or plaited them into mats for the lower layers of beds or for some temporary purposes, as the material is not durable. (Neal 88.) S. californicus on Niʻihau.

2. The common onion (Allium cepa); the tops look like those of the great bulrush. (Neal 198.)

Perhaps akaakai. An ambiguous passage in For. 4:157: maluna o ka waʻa naku akaakai … kona waʻa akaakai, in the bulrush canoe … his bulrush canoe. (Reference is to a canoe bound tor Kahiki to search for ʻOlopana. Thrum's note [For. 4:156] says that canoes were not made of bulrushes and thinks naku here is ‘to search’ [see naku 2]. An alternative interpretation of akaakai is akaaka, clear, + -i, transitivizer, which might also mean ‘search’ in the sense of clarification.)
A common variety at onion.
Big, yellowish onion. Lit., earring onion.
A purplish annual onion.
Green onion (Allium fistulosum); its leaves are eaten with salt salmon. (Neal 198.) Lit., leaf onion.
A wild onion, used for sore throat. Lit., moon onion, so called because the curve of the section of the bulb suggests a crescent moon.
Bulrush.
Garlic (Allium sativum). (Neal 198–9.)
Garlic. Lit., bunched onion.
Afterglow.
Not clear, vague, indistinct.
A variety of seaweed.
A tall endemic climber (Smilax sandwicensis) with tendrils and shiny, leathery, heart-shaped leaves; used for tying rafters, (Neal 211.) Also hoi kuahiwi.
Same as ʻēkaha, bird'-nest fern.
Modest, gentle, unassuming, unpretentious, unobtrusive, docile, decorous, meek, suave; meekness, modesty.
Name of a kind of white tapa.
To work carefully or slowly.
To pick up carefully, as food.
Slow or moderate, cautious, careful, prudent (see ex., pukapai).
To laugh at teasingly, jeer.
See ʻaka hene

1. num. One (especially in counting in a series).

2. For the first time, never before (usually followed by nō).

3. To have just.
Inexperienced, trying out for the first time; novice, beginner.
Base of caudal fin. Also akaakahiʻu.
To paddle carefully, silently.
To sail or run cautiously.
By the sea.
Large, potbellied, plump.
To laugh a little, snicker.
Var. spelling of akaaka 1.

1. A rent, split, chink, separation; to crack, split, scale

2. Also agata n.
Hawaiʻi ʻākepa (honey creeper), Loxops coccinea coccinea, endangered. See ʻākepa.
Agate. Eng.
See ʻakake
Spry, quick, nimble, especially about getting into people's way or into trouble.
Agate. Eng.
See ʻakaki
Same as ʻakakē. Rare.
Negative of a photograph.
Destitution, poverty; poor.
See kino aka.
The phenomenon known as the Specter of the Brocken, seen at Hale-a-ka-lā Crater. Lit., rainbow apparition.
Lessened, diminished, mitigated; to cease, abate, grow calm, stop, as wind, surf, rain, anger, grief, pain; settled, calmed, quieted, appeased.

1. Pink

2. Two endemic raspberries (Rubus hawaiensis and R. macraei); and the thimbleberry (R. rosaefolius), from southeastern Asia. (Neal 390–1.) Also ʻākalakala, ʻōlaʻa.

3. Dye made from ʻākala juice.

4. A pink tapa.

5. Same as kala, a seaweed.

1. Same as ʻākala 2, 3.

2. Pinkish. Rare.
Same as akaakalani.
The ghost or spirit of a living person seen by others, a sign of calamity. Lit., many shadows.
String of multicolored glass beads. Lit., bead reflections.
To sway the hips daintily, deliberately, and gracefully. See aka-, lewa 2.
Farthing. (Latin assurius.)
See ʻakalio
To move slowly, carefully. See aka-, luli.
Adamant. Eng.
See ʻakama
Smart, clever, expert; smartness, skill, wit. Cf. akeakamai.
Adam. Eng.
See ʻAkamu
Careful, gentle in behavior and speech. See aka-, nahe.
To sit quietly, live cautiously. See aka-, noho 2.
To speak cautiously, deliberately, in moderation. See aka-, ʻōlelo.
Stingy, miserly, hard.
Same as ʻapapane, a bird.

1. Right (not left). Cf. mākaukau, hema.

2. North (when one faces west, the direction of the sun's course, the right hand is to the north).
To go here and there, vagabond; vagabond.
Red sunset, looked upon as a sign that rain will clear. Lit., red shadow.

1. Liver. Cf. akeloa, akemāmā.

2. To desire, wish, be eager, yearn [the emotions and intelligence were thought to be centered within the body].
To find fault, criticize, slander. See kē.

1. Broad, wide, spacious, open, unobstructed, public, at large; full, as a skirt; breadth, width. Fig., liberal.

2. Var. of Wākea.
Starboard or outer hull of a double canoe.
A lover of wisdom, seeker after knowledge, philosopher, scientist, scholar; philosophy, science; scientific. Lit., to desire wisdom.
Quick, ready, as to do a kindly, deed, helpful.
Hawaiian storm petrel (Oceanodroma castro cryptoleucura).

1. Same as hākeakea, faded; to fade.

2. A kind of gray tapa.
To block, hinder, obstruct, interfere; obstruction, block.

1. Var. of kēkē, potbellied.

2. Name given for the ʻoʻopu hue, puffer fish, and listed by Malo. (Malo 46.)
Cindery or pebbly soil; cinder.
A honey creeper (Loxops coccinea caeruleirostris). Usually called ʻākepa in Eng. Also ʻōʻūholowai.

1. Ruddy turnstone (Arenaria interpres), a winter migrant to Hawaiʻi, occurring in small flocks which rise and wheel together. Also keke.

2. To talk loquaciously in a friendly, hospitable manner, bidding a guest to feel at home, make himself comfortable, eat plenty. Cf. heahea.

3. Redup. of ʻākeke, cinder.
Atlantic. Eng.
See ʻAkelanika
Acre. Eng.
See ʻakele
To escape from danger or sickness; to have a narrow escape.
See ʻūhini ʻakelika.
See ʻakelika
Spleen. Lit., long liver.
Edible raw liver.
Lung. Also akemāmā, akepāhola. Lit., wind liver.
Lung. Lit., light liver.
To boast, brag, admire, praise.
Agent, factor. Eng.
See ʻākena
Notary public.
Traveling salesman, commercial traveler.
Redup. of akena.
Spleen. Lit., coconut-midrib liver.
See Ke-ake-o-Milu.

1. Group of small scarlet or yellow-green Hawaiian honey creepers (Loxops coccinea). See ʻakakane, ʻakekeʻe, ʻakepeuʻie.

2. Quick, nimble, sprightly, active.
Liver (more specific than ake). (Oihk. 3.4.) Lit., firm liver.
Lung.
Lung.

1. Unkempt, as hair; oblique.

2. Rare var. of kepakepal 1.
Tuberculosis, consumption. Lit., finished liver.
Oʻahu ʻākepa (honey eater), Loxops coccinea rufa, presumed extinct; Maui ʻākepa, L. c. ochracea, endangered.
Active, lively, quick; pleasant, sociable.
Redup. of ʻakeu.
To find fault, contradict, criticize, hinder.

1. To take a nip and let go, snap; to nibble, as fish; to bite off the bark of sugar cane to heal, as a wound; to scar over; sharp recurring pain, as in head or stomach. Fig., to attack, taunt, malign, snap at; slander (Hal. 50.20); backbiter (Roma 1.30).

2. Height, tip, top (preceded by ke).

3. Pillow.

4. Block on which a canoe is placed on the shore. Also lona.

5. Filled, as a canoe with waves.

6. Same as ʻakiʻaki 2, a rush. (KL. line 66.)

1. Hair switch; knot fastening plaits or braids of hair; to add long strands of hair.

2. To furl, as sails.

3. Same as kikī, fast. Rare.

1. Endemic shrubs and trees (Wikstroemia spp.) with small leaves, tiny yellowish flowers, and yellow to red, small, ovoid one-seeded fruits. The bark yields a fiber; the bark, roots, and leaves (as W. oahuensis) a narcotic used for fish poisoning (Neal 616), and according to Kep., used in ʻanāʻanā sorcery. Varieties are qualified by the terms lau nui. mānalo, and pehu. Also kauhi.

2. Solanum nelsoni.

3. To ferment; very sour, as poi.

4. Pas/imp. of ʻaki 1.

5. Also Asia nvs. Asia; Asian, Asiatic. Eng.
Same as kanawao 1, small endemic trees.

1. Redup. of ʻaki 1; to nibble, as a fish; constant snapping at, attacking.

2. Seashore rush grass (Sporobolus virginicus), a coarse grass growing on sandy beaches; used to exorcise spirits. (Neal 66–7.) Also mānienie ʻakiʻaki, mānienie māhikihiki, and mānienie maoli.

3. A kind of coarse red seaweed (Ahnfeltia concinna) which because of its toughness must be eaten in little bites; a good source of carrageenin, a colloid. (KL. line 41.) Called ʻeleau on Maui.

Buffalo grass (Stenotaphrum secundatum), an American grass used for lawns. Some people believed that buffalo grass could be used to exorcise spirits because it had been given the same name (ʻakiʻaki) as the seashore rush grass, which was used for this purpose (Neal 72–3.) Also mānienie ʻakiʻaki.

A group of Hawaiian honey creepers with long, curved bill, olive or yellow-green above, lighter below (Hemignathus obscurus), with subspecies on Hawaiʻi (H. o. o.), Lā-naʻi (H. o. lanaiesis), and Kauaʻi (H. procerus). The latter is endangered; it has the longest curved beak, for sipping honey at the base of ʻieʻie and hala pele leaves. Cf. ʻiwi, ʻiʻiwi. Also ʻakihi loa, kipi.
Same as ʻakihi poʻo lāʻau.
Birds. See below.
See ʻakihi
Same as ʻakialoa and ʻakihi loa. (Malo 39.)
A small black sea bird, probably a stormy petrel (Oceanodroma), of which two dark, sooty species are known about the Hawaiian Islands, especially those to the northwest. Lit., billow-treading ʻakihi.
Same as ʻakialoa.
A bird listed by Malo. (Malo 39.)
The nuku puʻu honey creeper of Hawaiʻi (Hemignathus wilsoni). See nuku puʻu.
Drydock, Lit., floating canoe-rest.
Dip net, as used in fishing uhu. Also ʻupena pākiʻikiʻi.
Acid. Eng., E mālama pono iho ʻoe i ke kīʻaha wai ʻakika (song), watch carefully for the glassful of acid.
See ʻakika
Carbolic acid. Eng.
See ʻakika kapolika

1. Dwarfed; dwarf. Cf. ʻukiki.

2. Same as ʻūkīkiki, young of ʻōpakapaka fish.
The endemic Kauaʻi creeper (Loxops maculata bairdi, formerly Paroreomyza bairdi).

1. A wrasse fish of the hīnālea type (Gomphosus varius). Also hīnālea ʻakilolo. This fish was used by priests as the pani or closing medicine for head diseases. The taro or sugar cane of the same name might substitute. Lit., brain biting.

2. A variety of sugar cane, striped with green and deep purplish-red when young, with yellow and red when older; named for the fish.

3. A variety of taro.
A variety of sugar cane, with purplish leaves. See nānahu.
To take with a lou or fruit-plucking stick.
Feast of unleavened bread.
See ʻakima
Admiral. Eng.
See ʻakimalala
Same as ʻinamona, kukui nut relish.
Biting; bite.
An endemic, small, hairy, pink-flowered shrub (Hibiscus youngianus), usually found in marshy places. (Neal 560.) Also hau hele.
See ʻakiohala
Axiom. Eng.
Archbishop. Eng.

1. To nip.

2. Round, as a leaf; compact, concise.

3. Name of a wind of Wai-jeʻe, Maui.

4. To center or concentrate in one place, as wind, rain. Rare.
To search, seek, probe, penetrate, spy.
Redup. of ʻakiu.
Thatching; to thatch.

1. To cut, shear, clip, trim, as hair; to break or pluck, as flowers.

2. Itch, throat irritation, venereal disease. Fig., lust.
A small tree resembling koa; dye was made from its bark, and to color tapa. (And.) But cf. kūʻoulena

1. Redup. of ʻako 6 1, 2.

2. Crest of a 
wave; to break or swell, as waves.
To assemble; assembled, collected, heaped.
Coral in general, coral head.
Mushroom coral (Fungi scutaria). Lit., vagina coral.
The crested honey creeper (Palmeria dolei), formerly endemic on Maui, endangered.
A variety or taro. (Heb.
A nut.
See ʻakoka
A variety of sugar cane, deep-red and green when young, changing to purple and brown-yellow; pith dark-brown; larger and stronger than ʻakilolo, especially in wet districts.

Endemic shrubs and trees (Euphorbia spp.) with jointed stems, opposite leaves, and milky sap (Neal 515–6). Buds and leaves of one species (E. multiformis) were chewed for debility. Also ēkoko, koko, kōkōmālei.
Bloody. Also kokoko.
Same as ʻaikola, gesture and expression of contempt.

1. Poor, destitute, shiftless.

2. A large endemic fern (Dryopteris unidentata), 1 m or more high, with triangular-oblong fronds much subdivided.

1. A native fern (Athyrium microphyllum syn. A. poiretianum) with beautiful, large, lacy fronds. See hākonakona 1. (Neal 25.)

2. A small mollusk (Epitonium perplexum). Often called pipipi ʻākōlea or kōlea.
Accordion. Eng.
Ostrich. Eng.
To creep, attempt to creep; to put out small roots, as potatoes.
num. Three (as in counting in a series); three times.
Atomic. Eng.
Adobe. Eng.
See ʻakopie

1. Bonito, skipjack (Katsuwonus pelamis), an important food; to run, of aku. Young of this fish are called kīnaʻu and ʻāhua.

2. expressing direction away from the speaker, and time either past (with nei) or future (without nei, sometimes translated soon). (Table 12 in .) Aku contrasts with mai and sometimes may be translated away.
An endemic lobelia (Cyanea tritomantha), a small tree 2 to 3 m high, with clustered leaves (up to 78 by 20 cm), somewhat downy beneath. The leaves were cooked and eaten like cabbage. Cf. ʻakūʻakū.

1. God, goddess, spirit, ghost, devil, image, idol, corpse; divine, supernatural, godly.

2. God (Christian).

3. “It” in a game of tag or hide-and-seek.

4. Name of the 14th night of the full moon. (PEP ʻAtua.)

5. Same as maiʻa Polapola, a banana.
Spirit eater of scraps, designation of a god sent on errands of destruction by sorcerers.
A spirit that destroys its keeper; a god sent on an evil errand who returns to destroy his keeper rather than the victim; any evil practice, as excessive drinking, gossiping.
Spirit eater of filth. Same as akua ʻai hamu.

Supernatural with dual roles as akua to unrelated persons and ʻaumakua to relatives, as formerly the four major gods to high ranking chiefs, and later only as Pele, Hiʻiaka, and Laka to mortals. (Na_na_ 36.)
A god to whom one appealed with offerings for help, as in fishing, farming, or killing an enemy. Lit.. work god.

1. Spirits, as of a recently dead kinsman, who were fed (hānai) offerings (such as food) and sent out to destroy an enemy.

2. The kauila, nioi, and ʻohe “poison” woods of Molokaʻi, which were kept by sorcerers in their houses, wrapped in tapa, and to which food offerings were made daily; scraps of these woods were used as poison, and poison itself was sometimes called akua hānai.
God sent on errands of destruction.
Feather image. (Ii 39.)

Stick image (general name); image wrapped in tapa; image consisting of a carved staff, with a tuft of feathers at the top, bound to its bearer by a sash (kāʻai) (Malo 80) and carried into battle; staff with a carved figure at the head, used in ceremonies to procure offspring (Malo 135, 139).
Holy Trinity. (Kep. 175.)
A god to whom offerings and sacrifices were made.
Same as ʻuhane kīhei pua.
Image representing a god.

1. Swaying, as a canoe in rough sea; not steady; bumpy, as a road.

2. Hasty, poorly done, rash.

3. An endemic lobelia (Cyanea rollandioides) 1 to 1.4 m high, with rough leaves to 50 by 15 cm. The leaves were cooked like cabbage or taro tops or sweet potato leaves, with pork or salt beef. Cf. ʻakū.
Similar to akua hānai 1, 2; sent out in the shape of fireballs to kill, or inserted in a victim's food, water, or tobacco. (Kam. 64:134–5.)
Ghost, specter, apparition, evil spirit.
Flying god, usually a poison god sent to destroy, sometimes in the form of fireballs (pōpō ahi). See akua hānai.

A tall image, especially an image of Lono carried on a circuit of the island during the makahiki, harvest festival; it was called loa, long, because of its “long” travels. The image consisted of a staff about two fathoms long. Pieces of pala fern, feather leis, and skins of the kaʻupu bird were fastened to a crosspiece tied near the top of the staff, in the center of which was a tiny carved head. A long and white tapa banner was attached. 
to the crosspiece. (Malo 143–5, but see Malo text, chapter 36, sections 22–4.) Tribute was collected. Also Lono Makua.
Foreign god, epithet often applied to Pele because she had come from a foreign land.
A spirit that takes possession of people and speaks through them as a medium. (Malo 115–7.)
Image representing the god of sports that accompanied the akua loa on its circuit, to preside at the sport festivals. (Malo 145, 154.)
The god of nightmares; a god who carried persons to distant places in their sleep, especially if they had eaten certain fish, as the weke.
Last and slow-moving image in a procession during kauila nui ceremonies, (Ii 41.)
Same as pepeiao akua.
Similar to akua loa, except that it was taken to a poko. See poko 3.
A god that inspires or possesses people.
Goddess.
Club-footed; deformity of the feet. Cf. kukuʻe.
Same as ʻōkuhekuhe, a fish; fish form of the god Kāne-milo-hai (HM 452).

1. To pound.

2. Probably similar to ʻākuʻikuʻi 2.

1. To pound. See kuʻi 1.

2. A long fish net; to drive fish into the net by striking the water with sticks. Also pākuʻikuʻi.
Same as kihe, a red seaweed.
Adjutant. Eng.
Adjutant general. Eng.
To beat, as tapa. (Kep. 99.)
Tossing about, agitated; jolting, as a vehicle on a rough road.
Directional part. aku + demon.
Big-eyed or goggle-eyed scad fish (Trachurops crumenophthalmus), Stages of growth are pāʻāʻā, halalū or hahalalū, and akule.
To give property or a right to it; to delegate responsibility.
Adultery. Eng.
See ʻakulekele
To collect, as leaves in a stream; to dam a stream thus; forest pool where leaves and rubbish have accumulated. Fig., to cast a reflection.

1. General name for succulent plants. (PCP ka(a)tuli.)

2. A coastal herb (Sesuvium portulacastrum), known in many warm regions, somewhat like wild portulaca (ākulikuli kula), but with longer, narrower leaves, and with small white to magenta flowers at leaf axils. (Neal 340.)

3. See "Portulaca cyanosperma": . Niʻihau.
Same as ʻaeʻae 2.

1. A tropical American, low succulent (Batis maritima), commonly forming a continuous green cover by salt marshes. Locally called pickleweed. (Neal 339.)

2. Same as ʻaeʻae 2.

Purslane (Portulaca oleracea), a cosmopolitan weed, a small succulent, prostrate herb, with spatula-shaped leaves and yellow flowers. It is eaten by people, poultry, and stock. (Neal 342.) Lit., plain succulent.
Same as ʻākulikuli kula.
Ice plant (Lampranthus glomeratus) from Africa, a low succulent, with thick, narrow leaves, and pink, rose, or orange flowers (used for leis). (Neal 341.)
Same as ʻaeʻae 2.
Broken or cut off, as a pencil point; blunt, stumpy.
Redup. of ʻakumu.
A while ago, last. See aku 2.

1. Same as ʻōkuhe, an ʻoʻopu fish.

2. A small endemic tree (Bobea mannii). Cf. ʻahakea.

1. Path, road, trail. Cf. alaloa, alanui, alawai.

2. To waken, stay awake; awake.

3. To rise up, arise, get up, come forward.

4. Rare var. of ale 1. Cf. alaō, alapoho.

5. There (same as the more frequent lā and -la). Cf. e lākou ala, e lauala, e (verb) ala.
Fast, quickly. Cf. alaheo, alamimo, alapine, alawiki.

1. Fragrant, sweet-smelling, perfumed; fragrance, perfume (preceded by ke). Fig., esteemed chiefly.

2. A variety of taro, said to be pungent-smelling when cooked. Varieties are qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, keʻokeʻo, ʻōpelu; cf. also ʻala-o-Puna.

Dense waterworn volcanic stone, as used for poi pounders, adzes, hula stones; hard lava, basalt. Kinds of ʻalā rock, as used for adzes, are qualified by the phrases pia maka hinu, shiny-faced arrowroot; mahinu, shiny; and maka hinu, shiny face. Also (Kam. 76:122) ʻalā haumeku ʻolokele, ʻalā lelekepue.

1. A large endemic tree (Planchonella spp.) with smooth, oblong leaves, shiny-green above, bronze beneath, the fruit yellow or black, to 5 cm long. The sticky, milky sap was used to trap birds, the wood for spears and ʻōʻō handles. (Neal 668.) Also āulu, ʻēlaʻa.

2. ʻŌʻō digging stick made of ʻālaʻa or any wood; to prod or dig with a stick, as in taro cultivation. Fig., to dig into the mind; to be dislodged, as by the wind.

3. Small corm, as of taro.
A strong Hilo wind. Lit. land-prodding.
Redup. of hoʻāla; to keep awake; to awaken or reawaken; to incite to action. Cf. ʻoālaala.
See laʻa 2.

1. Ink sac in octopus or squid; after salting, drying, and broiling on the fire, it is mixed with ʻinamona or chili peppers and eaten; mixed with ʻauhuhu juice it is used as bait. Fig., useless.

2. Scar of a scrofulous sore; to be so scarred; perhaps tuberculosis 
adenitis (Kam. 64:115).

3. Aerial tubers of bitter yam, hoi (Dioscorea bulbifera).
Small ʻalā stones.
Small tubers, as of taro.
Lukewarm; half-cooked
See "hoʻālaalahia":  Pas/imp. of hoʻālaala.
Same as māhoe 2, kinds of trees.

1. Redup. of ālai 1, to hinder

2. Type of taro patch built on artificial mounds, known near Hilo as kipi (HP 125); mucky claylike soil, as in this type of patch.

3. Same as waimakanui, a kind of large coarse endemic fern (Thelypteria keraudreniana).
Same as ʻuhaloa, a weed.
Redup. of ʻalawa.

1. All species of Peperomia, small native succulent forest herbs, related to ʻawa. (Neal 293). The name is qualified by the terms kāne (on Oʻahu) or kupa liʻi (on Hawaiʻi), pehu, pōhina. Also ʻawa-lau-a-Kāne.

2. A small weedy herb (Plectranthus parviflorus), in the mint family. (Neal 736.) This name may be qualified by the terms pua kī, wahine.

1. To tell publicly, as of the past

2. Type of ancient dramatic hula. (UL, chapter IX.)

3. Long cloud formation.
River ford; place on a trail where one swims or wades across a stream.

A West Indian shrub, night cestrum (Cestrum nocturnum), Chinese inkberry, with narrow leaves and narrow, tubular, green-to-creamy white flowers, which are most fragrant at night. (Neal 751.) Also kūpaoa, onaona Iapana.

1. Mudhen or Hawaiian gallinule (Gallinula chloropus sandvicensis), a black wading bird with red frontal plate; cry of this bird is believed a bad omen; some considered the ʻalae an ʻaumakua; endangered. For the coot, see ʻalae kea. Also koki. See saying, keʻu.

2. Same as ʻiwa, a fern.

1. Water-soluble colloidal ocherous earth, used for coloring salt, for medicine, for dye, and formaly in the purification ceremony called hiʻuwai; any red colloring matter; according to Dr. Frank Tabrah (Kam. 76:149), brick-red soil containing hematite. See ʻiʻoʻalaea, kuhi ʻalaea.

2. Flesh like redness, especially the dark red meat close to the spine of some fish, as of the aku.

3. Annatto dye plant (Bixa orellana), a tropical American shrub or small tree, bearing fruit with scarlet seeds, used for dyeing. Sometimes called ʻalaea lāʻau to distinguish from the earth; locally also called lipstick plant. (Neal 589.) Also kūmauna.

4. Tribe or clan; people in a district who have intermarried.

5. Bad breath, halitosis.

6. Fore part of thigh; long narrow thigh muscle. (And.)
Dark-red ʻalaea. Lit., male ʻalaea 3.
Light-red ʻalaea. Lit., female ʻalaea 3.
The introduced Australian gallinule Porphyrio poliocephalus, P. p. melanotus. Also applied to a form of ʻalae kea, with brownish frontal knob.
Same as ʻalae ʻula.
An edible crab of the Portunus sp., sandcolored, and found in shallow water.
Hawaiian coot (Fulica americana alai), a marsh and pond bird, distinguished front ʻalae ʻula by its ivory-white frontal knob; endangered.
Same as ʻalae kea.
Same as ʻōlaelae 1; having a number of capes and land points.
Var. of mālaʻelaʻe.
A wind of Mānoa Valley, Honolulu.
Same as ʻalae kea. Lit.;, white-beaked ʻalae.
Hawaiian gallinule or mudhen (Gallinula chloropus sandvicensis), distinguished from ʻalae kea reddish bill and frontal plate; endangered.
Plank bridge, rough road over ravines or chasms, trestle, ladder (Kin. 28:12).
Type of braid used in the pāpale ʻie.
Mountain ladder or steps cut into a cliff.
Railway, railroad track. Lit., iron road.

A large native shrub or small tree (Canthium odoratum; synonym Plectronia odorata) with shiny leaves and small, fragrant, white flowers. The wood is hard and was formerly used in making the ʻōʻō digging stick; also used medically.(Neal 797.) Also ʻōheʻe.
See alaheʻe
Mock orange (Murraya paniculata), an ornamental hedge plant (Neal 480) with shiny, dark-green leaves, small fragrant white flowers, and red berries. Also walaheʻe haole.
Pathway, route, road, way to go, itinerary, trail, highway, means of transportation.
Pedestrian's road, sidewalk.
Gone, departed.
Pas/imp. of ala 2, 3. Rare.
Hem or finished border of a plaited mat or hat.
Wooden bridge.
To wake up early for no reason
Name of a light Hilo breeze. Lit., land fragrance. Also ʻAʻala-honua.
Name of a Molokaʻi wind. (For. 5:103.)
Resurrection; to rise again, resurect.
Marine railway. Lit., road to pull ships.
A frequented and well-known path; to frequent such; to tread or trample, as on a taboo being broken (And.).

1. Obstruction, hindrance, block, bar, screen; to obstruct, hinder, block, defend, stand in the way, oppose, hamper. Cf. ala'ala, ānai.

2. Two sticks carried with the akua loa in the makahiki festival; they were used to mark the boundry of the taboo area.
Gentle, as a breeze. Cf. laʻi.
Small thin surfboard, as of breadfruit or koa wood, and heavier than the olo board. Also omo.
An upland bird, gray, about rite size of the ʻelepaio, reported in 1863. See ʻeʻea. (KL. line 308.)

1. Various species of squirrelfishes of the family Holocentridae, including Flammeo sammara (spotfin squirrelfish, 185 mm), Adioryx lacteoguttatus (whitespotted, 117 mm), A. diadema, (crown, 109 mm), A. xanterythrus (Hawaiian, 132 mm), A. tiers (Tahitian, 259 mm). The young are called ʻaʻalaʻihi. Unidentified kinds are qualified by the terms ākoʻakoʻa, kala loa or kanaloa, lā kea, māhū, maoli, and pilikoʻa.

2. Pale pink tapa; any faded color

3. A variety of sugar cane named for the fish, either a deep-red mutant of ʻāwela or related to it; internodes barrel-shaped, leaves purple. (HP 221, 224.)
Appropriation of property by force, as practiced by some chiefs on their travels; to do so
See laila.
Obstacle, obstruction.
Alaska. Eng.
Sea course, path where one must swim past a projecting cliff.
To lead, guide, direct; leader, guide, conductor, head, director (a putative PCP ala, to lead [cf. Maori arahi] + -kaʻi, transitivizer: ).
Potbellied, bloated.
Leadership, guidance.
Detour.
Allspice. (Neal 634–5.) Eng..
To jump, hurry from place to place.

1. Name of a star, probably used in navigation.

2. Name of a downtown Honolulu street. Lit., white road.
Arsenic. Eng.
See ʻalakenika

1. To drag, pull along.

2. Bird-catching pole. Also ʻaukuʻu.
A large crab (Carpilius maculatus), with 11 dark red spots on its back, usually found concealed in rocks or under stones.
Place for climbing a cliff, usually with ropes.
Var. spelling of -alaala.
Sweet potatoes that bear front branch (lālā) vines.

1. To bawl, bleat, squeal, cry, caw, yelp, wail, scream; such noises.

2. Hawaiian crow (Corvus tropicus), named for its caw; endangered.

3. A style of chanting with open mouth vibration and tremor of the voice, and prolonged vowels; to chant thus

4. To gargle. Rare.
Redup. of ālai.
To dry or wither leaves over a fire, as of tobacco. Also lala 2, ʻōlala, ʻōlani
Bleating, wailing. See ʻalalā 1.
Young of the red ʻāweoweo fish. Appearance of schools of this fish near shore was an omen that royalty would die. Also ʻalauwā.
Sickly, weak, fretful, as a child; fretfulness.
Sharp shrill yelp, sudden screech; to yelp, screech.
Highway, main road, belt road around an island, a long road
Protection, defense. (Eng. arms.)
See ʻalama
Bowling alley

1. Ripe

2. Precious, as a child

3. A bird (no data)

4. See iki ʻalamea
Hard volcanic stone, used for adzes
A common black crab (Metopograpsus thukuhar). Also ʻelemihi, ʻelepī. ʻAlamihi ʻai kupapaʻu, corpse-eating black crab [a scavenger].
Quick, fast.
An endemic fresh-water ʻoʻopu fish (Len tipes concolor).
Cut off or unfinished road, dead-end road. Fig., an incomplete rainbow, rainbow fragment
Awakening, rising. See ala 2, 3.
See kīkē ʻalāna.

1. Offering, especially a free-will offering, contrasting with a mōhai that was prescribed by a priest; to offer.

2. Light, buoyant, easily floating. See lana.
Peace offering, offering of love.
Burnt offering, offering to procure death by sorcery.

1. Clear, calm, serene, unclouded, free from impediment; clearness, calm, stillness; emptiness, nothing; desolate (Ier. 50.3).

2. Of a single color or texture, especially of a feather cloak without design and made of feathers of a single kind and color.

3. Swelling disease, dropsy, generalized edema, kidney disease.

4. Name of a class of 12 male supernatural beings called papa pae māhū, said to be hermaphrodite healers from Kahiki. One at least was according to legend turned to stone and has been moved to Kuhiō Park, Waīkīkī, Oʻahu. See Pae-māhū in Pukui, Elbert, and Mookini, 1974.

1. Brown seaweeds (Dictyota spp.), regularly divided into narrow segments. They are so bitter that they will taint other seaweeds put with them and can be eaten but little and by some are considered poisonous. Medical kahunas used them in small quantities to treat asthma. This name is sometimes qualified by the terms kai and ʻula. Also maka and false līpoa. Cf. kūālani.

2. An Oʻahu tree (Pelea sandwicensis or P. oahuensis), with oblong, fragrant leaves (like the mokihana of Kauaʻi), which were used for scenting tapa. The bark, was used for medicine. Also other species of Pelea.

3. An upland moss.
Any kind of orange, both fruit and tree, as Citrus sinensis. (Neal 483.) Eng. Melemele ʻili ʻalani, orange-yellow color.
Smooth, even, not rough.
Calamondin (Citris mitis), a small tree with flattened-globose fruits to 2.6 cm in diameter, orange-colored, few-seeded, sour. (Neal 484.)
Long tattoo stripe. Lit., tooth path.
All species of Pelea. Also kūkaemoa.

Tangerine, mandarin (Citrus reticulata cv. ‘deliciosa’), a small tree with small leaves and small, loose-skinned, orange, flattened globose, sweet fruits. (Neal 482.) Lit., Chinese orange. On Niʻihau, identified as C. grandis; cf. Neal 481.
A low native shrub (Pelea waialealae), found only on high, wet parts of Kauaʻi. Also ʻanonia.
Street, road, highway, thoroughfare, waterway, course. Lit., large path.
Avenue, boulevard, wide street.
Sidewalk.
See alanui hele ʻaoʻao
Pathway of the navigator stars; star course followed by navigators. Probably also hōkū ʻai ʻāina.

1. To swallow whole, as a fish or shrimp. Also alaʻoma. Ke alaō mai nō i nā wahi ʻoʻopua me nā wahi ʻōpae, swallowing whole small ʻoʻopu fish and shrimps.

2. Heiau or temple that had no lele altar.
Road cut, short cut.
Name of a Kauaʻi wind, said to bring good weather. (For. 5:97.) Lit., happy path.
Narrow path, lane, alley.
Var. of alaō 1, and alaʻume.
A variety of taro, growing wild, also cultivated dry in Puna, Hawaiʻi; fragrant when cooked, like kāī. Also welowelo-lā.
Athletic, active; athlete; an epithet for Kamehameha I; name of a company of Ka-lani-ʻopuʻu's warriors.
Slander, falsehood, deceit; slanderer; to slander, defame, deceive, lie.

1. Alpaca. Eng.

2. Also alabata, Alabaster, ointment vase of alabaster. (Luka 7:37.) Eng.
Same as ʻalapaka 2. (Probably Gr.

Tunnel.
Alfalfa. Eng.
Athletic person aspiring to the lineage of Kū (said of Ka-mehameha).

1. Arabia, Arabian. Eng.

2. (Not cap.) n. A heavy cloth resembling serge.

Lua fighting stroke. Lit., stairway of the shrimp.
Steep road or path.
Escalator, moving stairs.
Musical scale.
