Endemic Hawaiian honey creepers (Loxops maculata), Oʻahu creeper (L. m. maculata), endangered; Lā-naʻi creeper (L. m. montana), presumed extinct; Maui creeper (L. m. newtoni); Hawaiʻi creeper (L. m. mana), endangered.
Homely, vile, slovenly, worthless; homeliness, vileness, dregs of society.
Light of early dawn, sunset glow. Lit., flaming road.
Red dust in a road, red dust.
Same as ʻaʻalaʻula, a seaweed (Codium spp.).
Clothes, tapa, mats; to envelop, clothe. Rare. Cf. laulau, wrapper.
Sheer trail as for climbing a cliff. Also hūlili.
To draw, pull, attract, as a magnet.
Var. spelling of ʻalauā.
Var. spelling of ʻalauahio, a bird.
Same as ʻalauahio.

1. To glance, look quickly; glance.

Channel, canal.
Dark lines on stomach of a pregnant woman, converging near the navel. Lit., burned path.

Same as ʻāheahea 2, a shrub, Niʻihau.

1. To shriek; shrill. Cf. wī, to squeal.

2. Upland bird, reported to be the young of the ʻanianiau, and on Kauaʻi, the ʻamakihi.
To hurry; quick, fast. Cf. wiki.

1. To swallow, engulf, gulp, absorb.

2. Hollow or cavern on the sea floor. (PCP ale(ale).)

1. Wave, crest of a wave, billow; to ripple, form waves, stir; to well, as tears in the eyes; rippling, stirring. See poale. Many types of billows are listed below.

3. Also are. n. Are, a unit of measure. Eng.
Marshy; marsh, swamp.

1. Pas/imp. of ale 1.

2. A fish, said to be short for hīnālea, or a kind of hīnālea. Also ālealea.
Area. Eng.

Sweet-voiced.
A swamping wave, as one striking a canoe broadside from prow to stern, See ʻaki 5.
Wounded, pierced; wound, sore. Less common than pōaleale.

1. Tongue, language. Also elelo. Cf. pelu.

2. Meat of the sea egg or sea urchin (wana), so called because of resemblance to a tongue.

3. Concave curve of the lower portion of the lei palaoa, whale-tooth pendant, suggestive of a tongue.

4. Point at the tip of a paddle.
A kind of introduced flower (no data).

Tongue-tied, paralyzed tongue.
Paralysis of the tongue, believed sometimes caused by a kahuna. Also alelo pehu, alelo pelu, lelo puʻu.

A lowland perennial weed (Boerhaavia repens), with long, thin, prostrate branches, bearing small leaves and flowers. The swollen roots were used medicinally, acting as a diuretic. (Neal 336–7.) Anena on Niʻihau.
Same as kōnane, clear.
Tower, high lookout, gazebo; towering.
Billows that follow one after the other.
Alpha. Eng.
Alphabet. Eng.
See ʻalepapeka
Old, worn-out, as tapa, mats, clothing; worn-out tapa, clothing; objects of inferior quality. Also pāleuleu.
Same as ʻālewalewa.
Buoyant, floating.
Same as aliali.

(Perhaps a var. of ani.) hoʻāli (a) To signal, wave; to stir, as coffee or a fire; signal, stirring; wavy, undulating. (b) To make an offering to the gods with signals and signs or prayers with gestures. Cf. mōhai hoʻāli.

1. Scar, depression, groove, imbedded mark. Also ʻeli. Cf. ʻaʻali, ʻālina.

2. Var. of ʻeli, to dig. (PNP kali.)
To wait, stop; before; usually as a command: stop! wait a minute! Alia kāu puke, away with your book.

1. Salt bed, salt-encrusted area; salty, brackish.

2. Name of two kauila or māmane sticks carried by priests before the makahiki god; also the two crossed spears with upright spear in the center, used as insignia for the present-day Māmakakaua society; small flag or streamer. See ʻAhahui Māmakakaua.
Crystal clear, white; clarity, whiteness. Also aniani.
See "hoāliāli":  Redup. of hoʻāli.
Redup. of ʻali1; scarred, grooved; profound, Cf. ʻeliʻeli.
Same as ālia.
Same as ʻoliana, let me see.

1. Cords or fine ropes threaded through marginal meshes of upper and lower edges of nets, to which were attached floats and sinkers; loops at the top of a kōkō net holding a calabash. See below and ʻupena ʻalihi. (PCP kalifi.)

2. Horizon (sometimes qualified by lani or moana). Cf. lihi, edge.

3. Deceit, trickery; to deceive, cheat. (AP)
General, commander in battle, strategist.
Commander in chief.
Lower cord in a net to which lead sinkers were attached.
Dragnet, mullet net.
Line for lashing down the paūʻū mat covering of a canoe.
Upper cord in a net to which floats were attached.
Lower cord in a net to which stone sinkers were attached.

Chief, chiefess, officer, ruler, monarch, peer, headman, noble, aristocrat, king, queen, commander; royal, regal, aristocratic, kingly; to rule or act as a chief, govern, reign; to become a chief. Fig., kind (see naʻau aliʻi, ʻōpū aliʻi).
Chief who rules a moku (district)
Archangel.
Presiding officer, ruling officer; chairman, viceroy.
Male chief, king; husband (polite, not said of one's own husband or to him).

Commissioned officer.
Warrant officer.
Independent chief, aristocrat.
True chief, commissioned officer (old term).
Power behind the throne. Lit., supplementary king.
Same as Ke-aliʻi-o-Kona-i-kalewa.
Non-commissioned officer, petty officer (old term).
Offspring of a high chiefess and commoner (or lesser chief) father. Cf. papa aliʻi.

The ornamental cannas (Canna indica, forms and hybrids), large tropical American herbs, with large oval or narrow leaves and large red or red and yellow flowers. The round black seeds are worn in leis and are also placed in fruit shells of the laʻamia for hula rattles.
Lesser chiefs who served other chiefs. Cf. kauā.
An exalted chief (probably from pūʻōʻā, tower). (For. 6:303.)
Boatswain.
Chiefess, queen; wife (polite, not said of one's own wife or to her).
Arctic. Eng. Aia i ʻĀlika ku ihu o ka moku (song), the prow of the ship turns to the Arctic.
See ʻĀlika
Clammy, sticky, tenacious, tough. Fig., stingy. Cf. lina, linalina, nina, ninanina, ʻūlika, ʻūlikalika.
Alike (often repeated: ʻālike ʻālike, like ʻālike, alike, just alike, identical, equally, midway.
Alligator. Eng.

To tighten, tie tightly.
The common turbo shell (Turbo sandwicensis).

num. Five (especially in counting in a series); five times.
Arithmetic Eng.

Scar, blemish; scarred, disfigured, injured, maimed (preceded by ke). Fig., low, disgraced, degraded, dishonored.
Limpet (Cellana sandwicensis).

Front, face, presence; upper surface, as of a bowl; leeward. Cf. ʻaialo, aloaliʻi, pali. (Alo refers to a wife: cf. pilialo.) Ka moʻopuna i ke alo, the favorite grandchild, a grandchild reared by grandparents.

1. To dodge, evade, elude, avoid.

2. To be with, come near, go with, attend, escort, accompany, share an experience, endure, resist.

1. Same as makaʻāloa, a crab.

2. Name recorded for olonā fiber.

3. To lengthen, enlarge.
In the presence of chiefs; royal court.

1. All kinds of hibiscus, including the native white hibiscus (Hibiscus arnottianus); often called pua aloalo, pualoalo. A law was passed in 1923 making the aloalo the flower of the Territory of Hawaiʻi. Qualifying terms: hua moa (egg) or pele (bell) (Abutilon pictum, Neal 550), koʻakoʻa (Hibiscus schizopetalus or coral hibiscus, Neal 558; see also kulapepeiao); lahilahi (all single-flowered forms), pahūpahū (Malvaviscus arboreus var.

2. Squilla (Pseudosquilla ciliata, Lysiosquilla maculata), highly desired as food. Also Squilla sp.

3. Loved and served by many persons, as a chief or favorite child; esteemed. Cf. alo.

4. Tapa made from māmaki mixed with wauke. (Kam. 76:115.) (Perhaps PNP aloalo.)

1. Redup. of ʻalo 1; to dodge rapidly or continuously; to look about slyly; evasive.

2. Redup. of ʻalo 2; one who follows, escorts, accompanies.

3. Lumpy, as poi, Rare.

4. A kind of small inshore fish (no data).
Far, at a distance.

1. Same as hāloʻaloʻa, turbulent, rough.

2. Pitted, as rocks. Also loʻaloʻa.
Var. spelling of ʻalolio.
Aloe, any plant of the genus Aloe; also the pānini ʻawaʻawa. Eng.

, nvs. Aloha, love, affection, compassion, mercy, sympathy, pity, kindness, sentiment, grace, charity; greeting, salutation, regards; sweetheart, lover, loved one; beloved, loving, kind, compassionate, charitable, lovable; to love, be fond of; to show kindness, mercy, pity, charity, affection; to venerate; to remember with affection; to greet, hail. Greetings! Hello! Good-by! Farewell! Alas! The common greetings follow: Aloha ʻoe, may you be loved or greeted, greetings (to one person).
Brotherhood.

Love of the land or of one's country, patriotism; the name of a Hawaiian-language newspaper published 1893–1920; aloha ʻāina is a very old concept, to judge from the many sayings (perhaps thousands) illustrating deep love of the land. (Pukui, Elbert, and Mookini 268–9.) Cf. the song Kaulana nā Pua (Elbert and Mahoe 62–4).
Bible spelling of aloha ai. (Mele. 5.6.)
See aloha.
Redup. of aloha (less used than hōʻālohaloha).
Name given to the kāmole plant used in hana aloha sorcery. Lit., mutual love.
See aloha.
Pitiless, merciless, ungrateful, without love or affection.
To shine, glitter, sparkle; bright, brilliant; splendor, brilliancy.
Pas/imp. of ʻalo.
Families united by marriage, in-laws.
Brightness of heaven, a term applied to the heavenly courts of the goddesses Uli and Kapo.
Redup. of ʻalohi; radiant.
Mud puddle, pool. Cf. loʻi.
Same as ʻāloʻiloʻi.

1. A damselfish (Dascyllus albisella). Also loʻiloʻi. The young stage is ʻā or ʻaʻā.

2. Humble.

3. Same as loʻiloʻi 1.
Single weft in plaiting; mat of a single thickness, with only one shiny side. Cf. alolua. Lit., single side.

1. Attractive, of fine appearance.

2. A red bird reported by Kepelino (no data).

Depression, gutter, ravine; lines of the hand, loose skin over the eyeball; tuck in a garment, shirring, ruffling; descent, as of trail or road; of low rank (Kep. 125); to bend, duck, hang, sag, slacken, stoop; to relax; to ruff, as a mat. Cf. pūʻalu.

2. Multiplication tables.
Loose, as a bundle not securely tied; flabby, ill-fitting, loose-jointed.

An endemic member of the lobelia family (Brighamia spp.), presently known only on Molokaʻi and Kauaʻi, believed extinct on Maui and Niʻihau, an unbranched, succulent, thick-stemmed perennial about 1.5 m high, topped with a rosette of large oval leaves and racemes of long, white, fragrant flowers. (Neal 815–7.) Also hāhā. See pua ʻala, ʻōlulu.
To incline the head, sway.
See alu.
Quickly, hastily (used after hele, hana, holo, holoholo, hopuhopu).
Descent, loosening, slackening, stooping. See ʻalu 1.

1. Mullet (Mugil cephalus), a very choice indigenous fish. Stages are (finger length) pua ʻama, pua ʻamaʻama, pua poʻolā, ʻoʻolā; (hand length) kahaha (or pahaha); (20 cm) ʻamaʻama; (30 cm or more) ʻanae. Fig., an easy mark (modern slang). See ʻōpele 2.

2. Redup. of ʻama 1, 2.
In rapid succession. Cf. maʻamau.
To cause death, defeat.

A group of small endemic Hawaiian honey creepers, Loxops virens; abundant on Hawaiʻi (L. v. v.), Maui (L. v. wilsoni), and Kauaʻi, uncommon on Oʻahu (L. v. chloris) and Molokaʻi, rare on Lā-naʻi. The feathers are yellow and greenish, and were formerly used in feather capes. The Kauaʻi form was also called alawī kihi.
Armorer, blacksmith. Eng.

Finished, of a pre-Christian prayer (said almost at the end of a prayer); to finish a prayer, to pray and sacrifice.

Y-shaped crosspiece at the end of a pole (as of a lāʻau kia); horizontal line on an upright; branches of a tree in the form of a Y; gallows; T-shaped; shaft of an octopus lure (Kam. 76:68). Cf. keʻa, koʻokoʻo ʻāmana, noho ʻāmana, peʻa, and mana, branch.
See "hoʻāmana":  To give authority, authorization; to empower, authorize, commission. Na wai ʻoe i hoʻā-mana mai? Who gave you permission?

1. All species of an endemic genus of ferns (Sadleria), with trunk more or less evident. The fronds are narrower, smaller, and less divided than those of the hāpuʻu. At least one species has at the top of the trunk a mass of soft scales (pulu)) used as pillow stuffing. Formerly, in times of famine, the tasteless pith of the trunk was cooked and eaten. The fronds were used to mulch dry-land taro, the stems for plaiting and as sizing for tapa. The ʻamaʻu was one of the forms that Kamapuaʻa, the pig god, could take at will. Also maʻumaʻu, maʻu. See maʻumaʻu. (Neal 22–3.)

2. Place where amaʻu ferns are found.

Oʻahu thrush (Phaeornis obscurus oahuensis), dusky, olive-brown above, ashy-gray beneath, endemic, presumed extinct, with subspecies on Hawaiʻi (ōmaʻo), Lā-naʻi (olomaʻo), Molokaʻi (olomaʻo), and Kauaʻi.
Similar to maumau 1.

2. Hawaiian soap plant (Colubrina asiatica), a twining shrub, distributed from Africa, India, and Australia to Polynesia, with ovate- to heart-shaped leaves and small round fruits. 1. Same as peʻapeʻa, bat.

to beat, as the pulse; to stir, as waves; palpitation, quivering.

1. To catch, grasp, grab, hug, seize and retain, catch, acceptance, admission. Fig., to perceive, understand. Cf. ʻaʻapo, ʻapoa, ʻapoʻapo.

1. Period of time, age, era, epoch, cycle, the passing of time. See aumoe, au nele.

1. Stingy, selfish, to withhold, detain, grudge, refuse to part with; stinginess; sparingly.

This word is related to uahi, smoke. One source says it refers to lowly or humble persons. Malo 109 says it may refer to a distant relationship.

An unknown herb, the bark and leaves of which were used as medicine.
Dishonest. See keʻe 1.
Ghost-ridden; haunted or unfriendly land. Lit., ghost bile. (Cf. Isa. 13.9.) ʻAʻohe maikaʻi kānaka o kēia wahi, he auakua, the people of this place are not good, they are most unkind.

Pole or stick used for carrying burdens across the shoulders; yoke, palanquin, burden; to carry on the ʻauamo. Lit., carrying handle. Also ʻaumaka and māmaka. See amo, pipi ʻauamo.

Where indeed (with implication of neglect or indifference)? Where's the interest? Where's the care? ʻAuhea hoʻi ka hele mai o lākou e kōkua, they'll never come and help, they don't care.

1. To turn aside, digress, deviate, pass by, decline, bend down. Cf. auinalā.

2. To swell and roll, as the sea; to pitch; billow, roller.

3. Declension, case; to name declensions or conjugations (term devised by Andrews based on Latin declinare, to turn aside); never used extensively and not entered in Hitchcock's 1887 English-Hawaiian Dictionary.

4. A hula step: the dancer turns to the side and points out one foot once or several times, drawing the foot well back between each pointing; at the same time the body is tipped, with a lowered hand pointing to the outpointing toes, and the other hand raised in the opposite direction; to dance thus. Cf. ue.
Ouch!

Midnight, late night.

August. Eng..
Bar of soap. Lit.., bar soap. Eng..

Name of a stroke in lua fighting. Lit.., tropic bird hastens, it is calm.

2. Same as ʻawaiāhiki.

1. Black-crowned night heron (Nycticorax nycticorax hoactli), a non-migratory land bird, which feeds on small fish and the larvae of insects in water. See sayings, heron. (PCP kautuku.)

2. Kind of fishhook with a long slender shaft, perhaps named for its resemblance to the heron's neck.

3. A long bamboo pole with two maile stalks across the top that were gummed with lime to catch birds. Also alakō.

4. To vomit, retch.

5. Cords held by the fishermen (hoʻāu) who managed the net in kuʻu fishing. Also kāwelewele.
A variety of ʻaukuʻu heron.

Name given by Kepelino for a bird resembling the kioea, and not an ʻaukuʻu.

To gather leaves to wrap fish in for cooking, as leaves of pōhuehue, mānewanewa, lauaʻe, ti; to frighten fish into a net with leaves.
Leaves strung on lines at ends of seines, as ti leaves.
To fly, as a frightened flock of birds.

Dark.

Pas/imp. of ʻau, to swim.

1. Even, smooth, as timber.

2. To treat kindly.
To swim evenly or abreast.

1. Bone of arm below elbow.

2. Stick held in the hand and rubbed in the fire-plow to produce fire by friction. Cf. ʻaunaki.
Mildew. Also kūkaeloli.

1. Rough, raging, as sea or wind; to injure, harm, rage.

2. To grow.

3. A tall endemic tree (Pisonia sandwicensis), with large, oblong, dark-green leaves; small, rounded flower heads, narrow, sticky fruits, and very soft wood. Cf. kaulu, pāpala kēpau.

4. Same as ʻālʻa 1, Planchonella spp.

5. Same as lonomea, Sapindus oahuensis.
Large-mouthed net placed at the wings of the papa hului net to receive fish; used in deep water. (Malo 212.)
Same as ʻauamo, carrying pole.
A variety of sweet potato.

1. Family or personal gods, deified ancestors who might assume the shape of sharks (all islands except Kauaʻi), owls (as at Mānoa, O'ahu and Kaʻū and Puna, Hawaiʻi), hawks (Hawaiʻi), ʻelepaio, ʻiwi, mudhens, octopuses, eels, mice, rats, dogs, caterpillars, rocks, cowries, clouds, or plants. A symbiotic relationship existed; mortals did not harm or eat ʻaumākua (they fed sharks), and ʻaumākua warned and reprimanded mortals in dreams, visions, and calls. (Beckwith, 1970, pp. 124–43, 559; Nānā 38.) Fig.., a trustworthy person. (Probably lit.., ʻau 4, group, + makua, parent.) See pulapula 2.

2. To offer grace to ʻaumākua before eating; to bless in the name of ʻaumākua. ʻAuhea ʻoe, ē ke kanaka o ke akua, eia kā kāua wahi ʻai, ua loaʻa maila mai ka pō mai ka pō mai; no laila nāu e ʻaumakua mai i ka ʻai a kāua (prayer), hearken, O man who serves the god, here is food for you [lit.., our food], received from the night, so bless our food in the name of the ʻaumakua.

3. To ask someone to hula; the request was not refused without giving the caller a lei or flower.
Plural of ʻaumakua.
Opposition, struggle, contention, strife; to struggle, oppose. Also ʻāʻuʻume. Ola ʻāʻumeʻume, struggle between life and death.
To float off in the air, as miasma; evil spirits thought to attend graves.
To grieve, regret, be sorry. Cf. mihi.

1. Outgoing current.

2. Fresh water mixed with noni juice, drunk after kava.

3. Same as miki 2; to sip.
To care for; protected. Cf. moamoa.

1. To travel on the open sea; sailor.

2. Name of laws enacted by Queen Ka-ʻahu-manu, so called in commemoration of her attempt to commit 
suicide by swimming out to sea. She was saved by a child who swam after her and refused to leave her. She returned to shore rather than cause his death.

3. Nautilus. Usually called ʻau-waʻa-lā-lua, moamoa, moamoa waʻa.
Late at night, as about midnight. Lit., time to sleep.
Fleet of ships.
Large group, flock, He kohu ʻāuna manu o ke kula, like flocks of birds of the plains.

1. Stick rubbed in obtaining fire by friction. Cf. ʻau lima.

2. Also ʻaunake, ʻauneki. Ounce. Eng.
A common gastropod (Nassa serta), a shellfish.
Hard times, depression, recession.
Shelter or shed, as for canoes; outhouse, temporary house; tabernacle.

1. Some representatives of an endemic genus (Isodendrion), members of the violet family. They are small shrubs beating greenish-white or reddish flowers, which have equal petals and none spurred. Cf. wahine noho kula.

2. See "Niʻihau":  name for naupaka kahakai.
Everything, as of things taken or lost; destitute.
A variety of aʻu fish.
According to Kepelino and Kamakau, a relationship extending back 24 generations. (For. 6:268.)
Fishing with a pula stick or pūlale to drive fish into a net.
Government, kingdom, dominion, nation, people under a ruler; national.

1. Same as makaloa 2, a shellfish

2. Same as mo'opuna-a-ka-līpoa, a common seaweed.
Breast stroke (swimming); to swim thus.
Same as ʻāʻumeʻume (For. 5:553).
Canoe fleet.
Paper nautilus (Argonauta argo). Lit., fleet of canoes with two sails. See ʻaumoana 3.

1. Chin. Fig., indifferent, scornful. Cf. papa ʻauwae.

2. Curved notch cut on the outer side of a post below the base of a tenon, also called maʻi wahine (For. 5:643).

3. Portion of the point of a pearl-shell lure which overhangs the shank.
Distant, remote, deep.
Tribute of the best selected (wae) hogs or fruits of the land to the landlord; to inspect land.
See Ka-ʻauwae-lewa.
Firmly opposed, set against. Lit., firm chin.
Mumps. Lit., puffed chin.
Close relative. (Malo 199, Emerson note.)

1. Indifference to work, discouraged. Lit., chin lump.

2. To squat.

1. Ditch, furrow, trench, gutter, canal, channel; groove, as in a tapa beater; to notch, as tops of house posts (For. 5:643).

2. Outhouse, as for storing canoes.
See "hōʻauwahawaha":  Redup. of hō-ʻauwaha.
Var. spelling of auahi.
Ditch, canal.
Same as ʻawaiāhiki.
Conduit, solid ditch.
Flume.

1. Entangled, snarled, as fishline.

2. Destitute, especially of the rich who lose ever everything.
See au 1.
Var. spelling of ʻauana, to wander.
Leg bone.
, vi. Same as ue 3.
Var. spelling of auē.
Var. of ʻauwaeʻāina.
Name recorded for kauā, outcasts.
Var. spelling of auēuē.
Var. spelling of auī.
Var. spelling of ʻauina.
Sharp end of a leaf; term of raillery applied to men, referring to the male member. Cf. wini 1, sharp.

1. Port, harbor, cove; channel or passage, as through a reef.

2. Milkfish (Chanos chanos). Stages of growth are pua awa (puawa), young; awa ʻaua, medium size; awa, commercial size; awa kalamoho, very large.
Noisy, loud; to talk loudly.

1. The kava (Piper methysticum), a shrub 1.2 to 3.5 m tall with green jointed stems and heart-shaped leaves, native to Pacific islands, the root being the source of a narcotic drink of the same name used in ceremonies (Neal 291), prepared formerly by chewing, later by pounding. The comminuted particles were mixed with water and strained, When drunk to excess it caused drowsiness and, rarely, scaliness of the skin and bloodshot eyes. Kava was also used medicinally.

2. Sour, bitter, poisonous.

3. Cold mountain rain, fog, mist; to rain or mist. Fig., tragic misfortune or ordeal; in PH this word is preceded by ke and may refer to volcanic eruption: Uwē au, puni ʻā i ke ʻawa (PH 193), I weep, surrounded by lava in the downpour.

4. A premature infant, believed caused by a “sour” condition of the mother.

5. A kind of bitter seaweed.
Long, narrow excavation, trench, ditch, gully; to dig a ditch or furrow.
Pas/imp. of ʻawaʻa.
Same as ʻāwa liʻi, a variety of kava. It is said that the god Kāne brought the first ʻawa to Hawaiʻi.
A variety of kava with long, light-green internodes and reddish nodes. Also ʻawa maha kea, ʻawa mākea.
A variety of kava.
A herring-like fish, sometimes called tenpounder or tarpon (Elops hawaiensis); according to some, a medium-sized awa fish.
Var. spelling of awāwa.

1. Redup. of ʻawa 2; bitter, sour, tart, acid, fermented, brackish; bitterness, sourness. Fig., un-pleasant, disagreeable, harsh, bad-tempered; unpleasant or tragic experience, anguish. (Ioba 7.11.) Iā Makaliʻi lau ʻawaʻawa o Puna, during the Makaliʻi season, innumerable disasters in Puna.

2. Redup. of ʻawa 3.

1. Uneven, furrowed, craggy.

2. Muscular.
Pas/imp. of ʻawaʻawa 1, 2. (PNP kawakawasia.)
Bitter, sour. Fig., crabbed in nature, bitter, ungrateful.
Bitterness.
To speak in a rude, harsh manner; rudeness.
Pas/imp. of ʻawa 2, 3.
A variety of kava with long internodes.
Similar to ʻawaʻawahua; ingratitude, meanness; to be mean, ungrateful, embittered, resentful. See make ʻawahua iho.

1. Rostrum, pulpit, speaker's platform, dais, scaffold.

2. Bundle, bunch, cluster, as of tied objects.

3. See ʻawaiāhiki.
Swelling in the groin, bubo; to have such a swelling. Also ʻaukoʻi, ʻauwaihiki, ʻāwai, ʻēwai, hahaʻi.
To bind securely, fasten, as of the marriage tie.
Good spirits, as the messengers of Kāne, who guarded people from evil ghosts and managed the rain, winds, and weather. (Malo 104.)
Kava root dug ceremonially by a priest and held up (kū) towards heaven while chanting a prayer of consecration and eulogy, after which the root was termed ʻawa-i-lani.
A large awa, milkfish.
Same as makou 1, all kinds of buttercups.
Noon, midday; to be at noon, to become noon.
Probably same as ʻawa papa kea. (HP 202.)
Same as ʻawa nēnē, a spotted variety of kava.
A variety of kava with green internodes of medium length.
Ship harbor or anchorage, port.
Avoirdupois. Eng.

1. To throw a knife or stock with a back flip; to throw back the head so as to grab dangling food with an open mouth. Cf. wala, to tilt.

2. To pull back steadily, as a line. Fig., to throw oneself into work.
See awa 1.
A young kava plant (root, stem, and leaves) used as an offering to the gods.
Same as ʻalaʻala wai nui 1, a succulent related to kava.
To burn for no particular reason; susceptible to combustion; spontaneous combustion; overcooked.
Type of hard stone from which adzes were made.
Same as ʻawa-a-Kāne, a variety of kava.
Place where bones of chiefs were hidden, as in a cave, Lit., eternal harbor.
num. Eight (usually in counting in a series).
Name for ʻawa ākea, ʻawa mākea at Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.
A variety of kava.
A variety of kava with short internodes and light-green stalk, reported at Wai-niha, Kauaʻi. (HP 202.)
A variety of kava with smooth, white stalk.
A variety of kava with short, dark-green internodes and whitish nodes, called ʻawa papa mōʻī at Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.
A variety of kava with short yellowish-green internodes and hairlike roots, named for the mokihana plant because of its fragrance, and yielding a strong brew; famous on Kauaʻi. (HP 202.)
A variety of kava with long, spotted internodes. Also ʻawa kua ʻea.

A variety of kava with short internodes and spotted stalk. This name may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, mōʻī, and kea (or keʻokeʻo), the last being the commonest variety, and whitish in general appearance.

1. Wild ginger (Zingiber zerumbet), a forest herb with narrow leaves arranged along a stalk 30 to 60 cm high, bearing on a separate stalk small yellowish flowers in an oblong head, and having aromatic underground stems; a native of India. (Neal 257.) The root was used to scent and dye tapa. Also ʻawapuhi kuahiwi, ʻōpuhi. Several varieties are listed below.

2. A variety of sweet potato.

3. A type of taro (no data). (For. 5.683.)
Same as ʻawapuhi Pākē. Lit., edible ginger.
Liparis hawaiensis, a small, endemic orchid with two large ovate leaves and small flowers. (Neal 273, 274.)
Same as kāhili 4.

The white ginger (Hedychium coronarium), a large herb from India, both wild and cultivated in Hawaiʻi. White fragrant flowers, popular for leis and perfume, are borne in heads at tips of leafy stems. (Neal 252–3.)

Torch ginger (Phaeomeria speciosa), a large herb, from the East Indies, grown in Hawaiʻi for its ornamental pink or red cone-shaped flower heads. These are borne on long stems separate from the longer leafy stems. (Neal 258–9.) Lit., walking-stick ginger.
See ʻawapuhi.

The shell ginger (Catimbium speciosum), a large ornamental herb from East Indies. 
Clusters of irregularly bell-shaped flowers that are white and marked with red and yellow bend downward from the top of leafy, arching stems, which are 1.5 to 3.5 m high. Lit., drooping ginger. (Neal 259–60.)
The yellow ginger (Hedychium flavescens), similar to ʻawapuhi keʻokeʻo and similarly used, but the flowers are yellow. (Neal 252.)

Ginger (Zingiber officinale), yielding a valuable commercial root spice. The plant looks much like ʻawapuhi kuahiwi and probably comes from southeast Asia. (Neal 257–8.) Lit., Chinese ginger. Also ʻawapuhi ʻai.
The red ginger (Alpinia purpurata), an ornamental plant having a long flower spike with many red bracts. It is a native of some islands of the western Pacific. (Neal 260.)
Valley, gulch, ravine. Cf. kuawa.
A variety of kava, an offshoot of ʻawa hiwa, with joints green on one side and dark on the other. (HP 202.) Lit., watery kava of the bird.

1. Strand, thread; thin, soft. (Probably PPN, PCP awe.)

2. Wake of a ship. (Note both awe and ʻawe in Hawaiian, awe and kawe in PCP.)

1. Pack, knapsack carried on the back; to carry on the back. Cf. ʻauamo, hāʻawe.

2. Tentacle, Cf. ʻawe puhi, ʻawe ule.
Pas/imp. of ʻawe 1.

1. Tenacious, sticky, threadlike, adhesive; glueyness, threads. Cf. aweawe poi.

2. Wake, as of a ship.
Redup. of ʻawe 1; pack knapsack; straps for a bundle; strips, as of wauke; runners, as on a vine; tentacles.

1. Faint trace, spot, glimpse; faint, dim; streaked, faded.

2. A kind of seaweed.
Traces of blood, as in vomit.
Drip of poi; an insult to the chiefs of Hawaiʻi, playing on the name of their chiefs, Keawe, with implication that poi is excreted in a sticky chain.
To hide rather than share wealth (perhaps related to weka, squid ink).

1. Young stage of the hou fish, Christmas wrasse (Thalassoma fuscum).

2. Heated, hot.

3. A flowerless variety of sugar cane, named for the fish; it is green and yellow striped, becoming flushed with rose in the sun; the internodes are barrel-shaped and the leaves variegated. (HP 221, 224.) Also puaʻole.
A variety of sugar cane, a bronze-yellow mutant of ʻāwela. Also uleʻohiʻu, uluhui. (HP 221.)
Redup. of ʻāwela 2.

1. Same as hāwele, to tie.

2. Goal, mark, line, goal post. (AP)
Average, pro rata. Eng.
See ʻawelika
Ragged, worn-out, torn; worn out garment.
Redup. of ʻāwelu.

1. Various Hawaiian species of Priacanthus, red fishes, sometimes called bigeye. Young are called ʻalalauā and ʻalauwā.

2. A variety of sugar cane named for the fish.

3. Same as ʻāheahea (Chenopodium oahuense).

4. A seaweed.
Eel tentacle, but referring to the octopus, a euphemism for ʻaweule.
A native variety of taro, often growing wild; good for poi, but too acrid for table taro; the corms are shaggy and fibrous outside, the flesh white with yellow fibers. Also māʻauea.
See ʻāweu
Lone octopus tentacle, said to wave in order to entice and ensnare a victim. Lit., penis tentacle.
Same as ʻāweu.
Same as ʻuwīʻuwī, an herb.
Same as ʻāweʻaweʻa.
Redup. of ʻāwiha.
To wink, ogle. See saying, lihilihi 2.
Redup. of ʻāwihi.
To hurry, be quick, swift.

1. Redup. of ʻāwiki.

2. . A vine (Canavalia spp.), native to Hawaiʻi, related to the maunaloa (C. cathartica), but with narrower pods; used for small, temporary fish traps. Also puakauhi.

3. Same as kōʻeleʻele, a seaweed.

1. To mix, interweave, entwine; mixed, agitated. Cf. koʻi ʻāwili.

2. Alligation (an old arithmetic term).
Redup. of ʻāwili 1.
Sharp, bold, forward. Cf. kīwini, wini.
A small native herb (Centaurium sebaeoides, syn.
To hurry; speedy, swift, quick, fast.

1. marking imperative/intentive mood. See e (verb) ai, e (verb) ana. (PCP e.)

2. By, by means of (follows a pas/imp.).

3. used before certain subordinate verbs.

4. See ē 1.

1. ; a second ē often follows the head word for emphasis.

2. , as in the common exclamation Auē nohoʻi ē!

3. Alas!
Prefix to numerals, inanimate, as ʻekahi, ʻelua, ʻekolu.

1. Different, strange, peculiar, unusual, heathen (Biblical), other; away off, elsewhere; beforehand, already, before, premature, in advance (sometimes translated ‘had’ and called by Andrews [] a sign of the pluperfect tense, although it is used after the imperative mood). Cf. ʻē aʻe, ʻano ʻē, mea ʻē.

2. Yes (unemphatic, as in mild agreement and indicating that one has heard; cf. ʻae).

3. The letter “e”. Eng.

4. Key of A (music). Eng.

1. Sovereignty, rule, independence.

2. Life, air, breath, respiration, vapor, gas; fumes, as of tobacco; breeze, spirit (Isa. 42.5). This ea, as well as ea 1, 3, 4, is sometimes pronounced or sung ʻea. Cf. eamāmā, eaolamāmā.

3. To rise, go up, raise, become erect. Cf. aea, eʻea, hōʻea.

4. To smell. Also ʻea. Cf. maea, māeaea.
Pejorative suffix. See hanaea, luea, nanaiea, poluea. (PNP -ea: cf. Rennellese -ea.)

1. Hawksbill turtle (Chelone imbricata), both land and sea species; the shell of this turtle. (PNP kea.)

2. Reddish-brown, as the color of the ʻea shell. Cf. ʻea mālani, ʻea ʻula.

3. A general term for infections and infectious diseases; coated tongue, sometimes accompanied by sore throat, the thrush disease of children. Many diseases of miscellaneous nature begin with ʻea and are listed below.

4. Spray. Cf. ʻeʻa, dust. These words are sometimes interchanged.

5. usually at the beginning or end of utterances. (, 1 Sam. 9.5; Lunk. 7.3.) ʻEa, hele mai! Say, come here! Hoʻolohe mai ʻoukou, ʻea, all of you there, listen.

6. Var. of ea 4, to smell.

7. Noisy; to yell, whoop; whoop.

8. Var. of ea 2, 3.

1. Isn't that so? That's it! ʻOia, ʻeā? Is that so? Ua hele aku ʻoia i Honolulu, ʻeā, she went to Honolulu, you know.

2. Song refrain. See ex., wawalo and . Also ʻeāʻeā.

1. Dust, dirt, dust cloud, spray (ʻeʻa and ʻea 4 are probably interchanged at times).

2. Mountain banana patch.

3. A fish similar to ʻaʻawa, but with dark flesh.
Gas. Lit., burning air.
Different, other, another, else.

1. Air, breath, air current. Some confusion exists in the uses of eaea, ʻeaʻea, and ʻeʻaʻeʻa.

2. Redup. of ea 3; to rise; high waves.

3. Redup. of ea 4; a smell, as of seaweed; to smell.

1. Redup. of ʻea 4, spray; encrusted with spray (sometimes confused with eaea and ʻeʻaʻeʻa).

2. Dignified, honorable. (And.)

3. A bird (no data).
See "hoʻeaea":  To approach.
at end of verses in some chants that maintains rhythm and affords pleasure in repetition, something like English tra-la-la.

Redup. of ʻeʻa 1, dust; dusty; obscure, darkened, 
cloudy, shady; to cloud, overshadow (sometimes confused with eaea and ʻeaʻea).
Condition of frequent colds. Lit., ʻea with hardened breath.
Great hunger, perhaps due to diabetes. Lit., loose-hanging diaphragm ʻea.
Dizzy spells, dizziness; latent ʻea disease (Kam. 64:103).
Particles indicating imperative/intentive mood and accompanying subordinate verbs (ai in this case is the anaphoric ai).
Impaired vision, perhaps labyrinthitis.
A disease, perhaps secondary lues (Kam. 64:115).
Condition of listlessness.
A variety of ʻea, a land tortoise. Lit., tortoise with back fitted into sections.
Disease with swelling symptoms.
Severe headaches, perhaps due to high blood pressure. Lit., ʻea at fontanel.
Same as e (verb) lā.
A type of ʻea described as evanescent. (Kam. 64:103.)
Light-brown in color. See ʻea 2.
Gas. Lit., light air.
Particles indicating incompleted action and future. . (PCP ʻe verb ʻana.)
Oxygen. Lit., light life breath.
Jaundice, hepatitis.
Dizziness, vertigo.
Wine-colored, such a color.
Osteomalacia, gradual softening of the bones.
Acute childhood ʻea disease. (Kam. 64:105.)

1. To climb on, mount, get on, go aboard, board, embark; one who climbs, mounts, boards; step. Cf. eʻe kuahiwi, eʻe moku, hikieʻe.

2. Same as aʻa 2, to extend greetings.
Hard, stiff, dry. Cf. kaʻeʻe.

1. Redup. of ʻē 1; contrary, peculiar, opposite; adversely.

2. Yellow underwing feathers of the ʻōʻō, a bird, as used in featherwork.

3. Armpit. Also pōʻaeʻae, poʻēʻē; see kuiʻēʻē. (PCP keekee.).
Redup. of ea 3; to rise up frequently, as in water; to bob up and down.

1. Quick ready, expert.

2. A bird, said to be an adult ʻalaiaha. (KL. line 307.)
Redup. of eʻe 1; to keep climbing over everything, as an active child; mischievous.
Same as hehi, to step on.
Overcome with fearful reverence, terror-stricken, awe-stricken; awe-inspiring, solemn; fear, reverence, awe, terror; wierd.
Same as ehuehu, healthy.
Redup. of ʻehu 5; reddish; a number of ʻehu persons.
Offensive, filthy, fly-ridden. (And.)
Rare. var. of pepeiao, ear.
Same as ʻeʻei. (AP)
To creak, crackle. Cf. ʻaʻina, ʻuʻina.
Same as ʻEka 2, a wind.

1. Redup. of ʻeke 2. Cf. mūʻeʻeke.

2. Name given for a hard-shelled crab (no data).
To tap a drum slowly, as to accompany a chant.
Same as ʻekuʻeku.
To climb mountains; mountain climber.
Same as ʻeleʻele 1, but used chiefly in old chants.
Stormy.
Redup. of ʻelekū; blackened or darkened, as leaves or fruit due to maturity or to pelting by storms; dark, gloomy, as clouds.

1. Redup. of ʻelo; drenched, soaked.

2. Loitering; to dilly-dally. Rare.
Name of a storm from the northeast of Waimea, Hawaiʻi. (And.)
To board a ship; ship passenger; immigrant.

1. Shy, timid, wary, wild, afraid, fearsome, untamed; to shy away. Cf. ʻena 2, hāʻeʻena.

2. Extraordinary. Cf. ʻē 1.

Extraordinary, incomprehensible, abnormal, deceitful, peculiar, as persons with miraculous powers; such persons. Many ʻeʻepa characters in mythology were born in strange forms, as a plant, an animal, or a piece of rope. Cf. ʻepa 1, ʻepaʻepa, kino ʻeʻepa. The menehune, Nāwā, and Nāmū of Wao-lani in Nuʻu-anu Valley were ʻeʻepa. Trickery or deceit that passes comprehension is also ʻeʻepa.

1. To crawl, creep, as an insect. Cf. ʻeu 2 (PCP kekeu.)

2. Shuddering sensation of revulsion (less strong than mania); to rise in horror, flinch (sometimes interpreted as a portent).
To make a wry face, pout, as in derision; to protrude the lips mockingly.
Same as ēhē.
Hurt, in pain, painful, aching, sore, pained; pain, injury, ailment, suffering, soreness, aching; to hurt, pain, cause suffering or pang. See mea ʻeha. .
num. Four; four times. See ex., hā 1.
Redup. of ʻeha; great pain, agony, tribulation, many small pains; painful.
To breathe hard, pant. Cf. hā, breath.
The Chinese lace-necked, or ring-necked dove (Streptopelia chinensis), an early introduction to Hawaiʻi, said to be named for its call ʻeha kō, prolonged pain.
Easily hurt, sensitive, having feelings easily hurt; to hurt for no reason.

Syllables repeated in chants at ends of verses, affording pleasure by repetition or sameness of sound harmonizing with repetition of sameness of drum beat; similar in function to English tra-la-la but different in mood, tending to be more serious. Cf. ēhā.
A hard, dry cough; to cough.
Redup. of ʻehē.
Song refrain. (Elbert and Mahoe 67.)

1. To laugh merrily, giggle in glee; laughter.

2. Syllables repeated for musical effect at end of verses, similar to ēhē.
Var. of ehehene 2.
Wings. Cf. ʻēheu.
Carved parallel or undulating lines on a tapa beater and on tapa. (AP)

1. Wing, as of bird, kite, or airplane; winged, soaring on wings; to fly, take wings (Kel. 140). Also ʻēkeu, pēkeu. Cf. ʻeheheu, ʻekekeu, pekekeu.

2. Rim of a hat.

3. Pectoral fin, as of a shark. Rare.

4. Flipper, as of turtle. Rare.

5. See Ka-ʻēheu.
Name recorded for adult stage of hāpuʻu fish.
num. inter. How many, how much, what price; also used with the meaning of no matter how many or much, so very much or many, just a few.
num. Seven; seven times.
Somewhat crooked, warped; not in sound mind. Rare. (Similar to but perhaps less strong than hipa and hepa.)

1. Stone pile, especially as used to mark land boundaries; stone image; heap of stones under water (at times fishermen block one end with a net and drive the fish in from the other end), also umu, imu; pillar (Kin. 35.20); red-hot stones put inside dressed animals in cooking (also pōhaku ʻeho).

2. Swelling or ulcerous sore, as caused by friction under the arm, tumor. See kuaʻeho.
Redup. of ʻeho, stone pile. (And.)
Name of a lua stroke. Lit., let the hero of Mānoa return, [it's] evening. (E- is sometimes omitted.)

1. Same as ʻehu 1–4. See kēhu.

2. Same as ehuehu 2, thriving.

3. Water or water mixed with fragrant herbs used in sprinkling or gently rubbing a patient to revive him from fainting.

4. Var. name for ʻolapa 2, Cheirodendron trees.
See "hoʻēhu":  To drive or shoo away; to stir, as a fire. Cf. ehuehu 1.

1. Spray, foam, mist. (Many older people say ehu for ʻehu 1–4, which is probably the older form; note lack of glottal stops in such forms as ehuehu, ʻehuehu, kaiehu, kēhu, kuehu, luehu, puehu.) See ex., moi 1.

2. Dust; dusty.

3. Pollen.

4. Faint, difficult to see; wisp.

5. Reddish tinge in hair, of Polynesians and not of Caucasians; one with ʻehu hair; reddish-brown complexion said to be characteristic of some ʻehu people; ruddy. (This ʻehu is invariably pronounced with an initial glottal stop.) Cf. ʻeʻehu, ʻehuʻehu.
The dust of evening. Fig., twilight, old age.
Same as ʻahuʻawa (Cyperus javanicus).

1. Animation varying from fury and storm to power and majesty; violent, furious, powerful, animated; violence, fury, anger, majesty, animation.

2. Healthy, vigorous. Less used than ahuahu.

3. A kind of rock, used for adzes. (Malo 19.)
Redup. of ʻehu 1–4 (this form was perhaps once ehuehu and is sometimes pronounced thus still).
Redup. of ʻehu 5.
Hīnano-blossom pollen.
Name of a wind of Hālawa, Molokaʻi. (For. 5:103.)
Sea spray, foam.
The dust of morning. Fig., dawn, youth, a shower that clears quickly.
Hair black at the roots that shades out to reddish at the tips, said to be characteristic of some ʻehu people.
Dust; dusty.
Flower pollen.
Spray from water.

1. Var. of eia, especially before words beginning with 
a-.

2. Var. of ai 1, coition.

3. Rather frequent variation of the anaphoric ai (ai 3) in fast speech, but seldom if ever found so in printed form.

1. Here, here is, here are, present (as response to roll call). Cf. ʻeiʻa. Numerous idioms are listed below.

2. This place.
Emphatic variation of eia: here! here it is!
Here close by, here approaching.
Approaching, nearby, soon.
Here, here it is; you over there, you. Cf. e ia nei.
And, finally, behold.
And again, furthermore. (Heb. 1.6.)
Wait a moment.
So at last, then.
But withal, moreover, furthermore.
Same as eia ala.
. You (sg.), you there (as between husband and wife, often affectionate and replacing such Eng. terms as darling; shortened vocative e + pronoun ia + zero-demon., ).
But, furthermore, however.
Scorched.
Short for e ia nei.
Here, here it is.
See ei neʻi

1. num. Nine, nine times.

2. See waoʻeiwa.

1. Dirty, foul, fecal (Kam. 64:109); filth, dirt, soil. See ex., kūlepe 1.

2. Name of a wind at Kona, Hawaiʻi.

3. A variety of bananas. (PH 173.)

4. Acre. Eng.
Hand of bananas. Compare maiʻa for pejorative connotations.

1. Redup. of ʻeka 1. Cf. hāʻekaʻeka.

2. Hawaiian name for a Japanese variety of taro (adado) grown in Hawaiʻi. (HP 32.)

1. The bird's-nest fern (Asplenium nidus), widespread in the tropics, forming large rosettes and in some forests perching on branches of trees. The fronds are large, entire, sword-shaped. The black midrib is used like the ʻamaʻu fern for decorating pandanus hats. (Neal 21.) Also ʻākaha. This fern is sometimes called ʻēkaha kuahiwi, mountain ʻēkaha, to distinguish it from the mosses or from ʻēkaha kū moana. (PCP ke(e)ta(f,s)a.)

2. A moss growing on rotted trees. Also limu ʻēkaha.

3. Same as ʻēkaha kū moana.
Same as pākahakaha, a small fern. (Neal 25.)

1. A species of flycatcher with subspecies on Hawaiʻi (Chasiempis sandwichensis sandwichensis), Kauaʻi (C. sandwichensis sclateri), and Oʻahu (C. sandwichensis gayi). The Kauaʻi subspecies is also called ʻāpekepeke. This bird was believed to be the goddess of canoe makers, hence the saying ua ʻelepaio ʻia ka waʻa, the canoe is [marked] by the ʻelepaio [an ʻelepaio bird pecking slowly on a tree trunk for insects signified that the trunk was insect-ridden and not suitable for a canoe (see kani 1); the saying may be applied to any failure]. The name also refers to one who craves fish but does not go fishing, as the cry of the bird was thought to suggest ʻono ka iʻa, ʻono ka iʻa, fish is delicious, fish is delicious.

2. A native variety of taro; the leaves are mottled with white. (HP 17).

A prefix similar in meaning to the causative/simulative hoʻo-. Before short vowels and glottal stop the form is usually hā-, as hāinu, to give to drink, and hāʻawe, to carry. Before consonants, both haʻa- and hā- occur, as haʻalele and hākuʻi. Before glottal stop plus a long vowel, ha- occurs, as haʻāpuka. For a few bases, derivatives with both haʻa- and hoʻo occur, as haʻakoʻo and hoʻokoʻo, which have the same meanings; with a few bases, meanings differ, as haʻalele (described with the h's) and hoʻolele (under lele). A few bases with haʻa- may form another derivative with hoʻo-, as inu, hāinu, and hoʻohāinu; heo, haʻaheo, hoʻohaʻaheo. Before colors the meaning is “-ish, somewhat,” as hākea, haʻakea, hāʻeleʻele, hāuliuli. For clear understanding, delete haʻa- and look up the base.

A native variety of taro in the piko group, characterized by having the two basal lobes of the leaf blade separated up to the piko (point of joining with the leaf stem); a hardy taro often grown commercially for poi, formerly common at Kaʻana-pali, Maui, where strong winds tore the leaves (hence haehae). (HP 29, 32.) Also piko uliuli.

A native lobelia (Clermontia clermontioides), found only in high mountains of Kauaʻi, a shrub or small tree with many branches; oblong and narrow leaves; greenish-purple, curved flowers; and sweet, edible yellow berries. Lit., hāhā, food of the birds, so called because the thick sap was used for catching birds.

A native tree lobelia (Cyanea leptostegia), found only on Kauaʻi. The trunk is slender, unbranched, to 12 m high, and bears a crown of narrow leaves that are up to 60 cm long. The many flowers are purplish-red, the fruits yellow berries.

1. Sin, vice, offense, fault, error; to sin (Kan. 9.21), err. See -hala manawa.

2. To pass, elapse, as time; to pass by; to miss; to pass away, die.

3. The pandanus or screw pine (Pandanus odoratissimus), native from southern Asia east to Hawaiʻi, growing at low altitudes, both cultivated and wild. It is a tree with many branches, which are tipped with spiral tufts of long narrow, spine-edged leaves; its base is supported by a clump of slanting aerial roots. The pineapple-shaped fruits are borne on female trees whereas the spikes of fragrant, pollenbearing flowers are borne separately on male trees. Many uses: leaves (lau hala) for mats, baskets, hats; the yellow to red fruit sections for leis, brushes; male flowers to scent tapa, their leaflike bracts to plait mats 
(see hīnano). (Neal 51.) The aerial root (uleule) tip is a good source of vitamin B and cooked in ti leaves was used medicinally, although unpleasant tasting. The tree is called pū hala. The hala lei is much liked today but formerly was not worn on important ventures because hala also means failure. For the same reason some persons will not compose songs about hala. Types of hala are listed below. Pineapples are hala plus qualifier. See ex., pō 2.

1. Older name for hala kahiki, pineapple. Lit., edible hala.

2. Sin of eating forbidden vegetable or fruit; failure to offer essence of such food to the gods before consuming it; to commit such offense. Cf. hala iʻa.
Var. spelling of Halāliʻi.

1. Redup. of hala 1, 2; correction, criticism, complaint, reproach.

2. Young stage of kāhala fish. (KL. line 147.) (PCP falafala.)

3. Bitter, soul, brackish. Rare.
Redup. of halakau.
Watery, wet, tearful, weeping.
To buzz, whiz by, as in missing a mark.
To fail to hit, miss.
A male pandanus bearing the hīnano blossom.
Similar to halahī; to fail, err, miss.

1. A female pandanus bearing fruit, contrasting with hala hīnano.

2. Nut in a pandanus key.
Consideration of grievances, disputes; councils for such consideration. Rare.
Same as laʻi, calm.
Sin of eating a forbidden fish or meat; failure to offer essence of fish or flesh to the gods before consuming it; to commit such offenses. Cf. hala ʻai.
A variety of hala with keys 7 cm long, lemon-colored at base, changing abruptly to bright-orange in upper half; when cut for leis, a rim of orange is left at top of each key used.
Pandanus key that is ripe and soft, suitable for leis. Cf. ʻiʻo hala.
Hard pandanus key, not suitable for leis. Fig., hard-appearing, dissatisfied.
See pāʻū halakā.

The pineapple (Ananas comosus), probably originating in Brazil, of great commercial importance. Lit., foreign hala. See hala kea and hala ʻula for what some Hawaiians call native varieties, still said to be growing wild in the forests at Puna, Hawaiʻi. Called hala on Niʻihau.
Sin of breaking clothing taboos; to sin thus.

1. To perch high, as a bird.

2. Large, as a pregnant woman. Rare.

1. Fair, light.

2. A yellowish tapa dyed with coconut oil.

Said by some Hawaiians to be a native variety of pineapple; plant spreading vinelike; leaves with thorny edges; fruit plain green when unripe, yellow when ripe, small, fragrant, good-tasting; pieces of the skin were used for hat leis (HP 214.) Lit., white hala.
Temporary support or prop in the middle of the house ridgepole.
To go off course, miss the way.
Same as holokū; plump.

1. Big, large, overgrown, oversized.

2. Name of Ka-lā-kaua's genital. See Elbert and Mahoe 67.

3. To bend low (For. 4:283); to travel far..
Redup. of hālaʻi.
High heavens, atmosphere.
To slurp, as soup; to eat noisily; to swish, as the sea; to spill or slop over; fat; not clear, as speech.
Far away and small.
Variety of hala with keys bright yellow at base, grading to bright orange-red at top, and smaller than hala ʻīkoi. Lit., red-edged hala.

1. Name of a pleasure-loving chief of Niʻihau in ancient times. His name became synonymous with fun-making.

2. A variety of sugar cane, vigorous, large, of the Lahaina type, perhaps named for Halāliʻi, Niʻihau, where a famous sugar cane once grew in the sand dunes. This cane was used in ceremonies for remission of sins (uku hala, wehe hala). Also pakaiea. See saying, kō 1.

1. To place under, lift up from beneath; to give an enema, douche.

2. Medicine. Cf. hālalo poʻi.

3. To gaze upon, reflect.
A fish (no data).
Gone a long distance or time; far.
Steaming decoction of herbs, as prescribed for sickness.

1. Young of the akule, a fish, about 14 or 15 cm long.

2. Weak, in poor health.

3. To rumble; to strum, as an ʻukulele (Kel. 137).
See "hoʻohala manawa":  To pass the time, agreeably or otherwise; to loaf; pastime. See hala 2.
Same as hala melemele.
A common form of pandanus with bright yellow keys.
A variety of pineapple. Lit., queen pineapple.

1. To overflow, flood. Cf. lana 1.

2. Quiet.
Redup. of hālana 1, 2.
Same as laʻo, mote.
Var. of halaʻoʻa.
To project, extend; to appear dimly, as in a vision; to see dimly. Fig., presumptuous.

1. Redup. of hālaʻo.

2. Stunted, poor, thin.
Same as hoʻolapa; ridge; active; flashing brightly. See lapa 1, 2.

Native trees (Dracaena [Pleomele] spp.) in the lily family, with narrow leaves in tufts at branch ends and with clustered round yellow fruits. (Neal 205–6). This was one of the five standard plants used in the 
hula altar to Laka. See more under palai (Neal 12). Also leʻie.

An indigenous variety of pandanus, with keys 4 cm long, canary-yellow and small; head small, about 15 by 12 cm., used in medical prescription and for exorcising evil spirits. It was much prized for leis.
A kind of pandanus. Lit., Borabora [Tahitian] hala.

1. Long house, as for canoes or hula instruction; meeting house.

2. Large, numerous; much.
Probably the same as the weed ʻuhaloa, a plant form of the pig god Kama-puaʻa, mentioned repeatedly in an 1851 version of the legend of Kamapuaʻa.

1. Pandanus with fruit sections entirely orange-red; same size as hala ʻīkoi.

2. A variety of pineapple similar to hala kea, but leaves and unripe fruit red-tinged. (HP 214).
A star, said to be observed in the month of Hilinehu.
Same as hala ʻula 1, 2.
Same as kālawa 1–3.

1. Meeting; to meet.

2. Horizon.
See hā 6, sinker.
Rally; inspirational meeting.
Redup. of hālawa.
To scrutinize. (And.)

2. Host, hospitable person. Cf. hale aikāne, hale kipa.

3. Name listed by Brigham for a pāwehe mat pattern; there is a central large lozenge with an enclosed rectangular figure internally enhanced with red on alternate weft crossings.

4. Also hare. Hare. (Oihk. 11.6.)
Restaurant.
House of Nobles.
Warehouse.

Restaurant, cafe, eating house, boardinghouse; in ancient times, the eating house for women.

Tapa-beater design. The panels between the hāluʻa lines are enhanced by regularly spaced small triangles. Lit., sharktooth hāluʻa.
A tapa-beater design. The triangles of the niho manō pattern are bordered by oblique lines pāwehe.
To make sturdy, as a banana plant (a word used in ancient prayers).
Tapa-beater design.

1. The two native species of Antidesma, medium-sized trees with hard wood, in the euphorbia family; leaves more or less ovate, fruits in grapelike clusters, purple, one-seeded. Formerly the wood was used for anvils for preparing olonā fiber, the fruit to color tapa red. (Neal 500). Also haʻā, haʻāmaile, hamehame, mehame.

2. Ham. Eng. Also ʻūhā hame, puaʻa hame.
Same as hame 1.
Calm, quiet. Rare.

Work, labor, job, employment, occupation, duty, office, activity, function, practice, procedure, process, deal, incident, reason, action, act, deed, task, service, behavior; to work, labor, do, behave, commit, make, manufacture, create, transact, perform, prepare, happen; to develop, as a picture; to have a love affair; to induce by sorcery; to handle (as a court case); to conduct (as a class). A rather common native variety of taro; the leaves are narrow, the piko, leaf attachment, light, and petioles light green. This taro supplies some gray commercial poi and lūʻau greens. It was formerly used both medicinally and in religious ceremonies, as for dedicating new fish nets. According to HP 17, it is a domesticated form of wild ʻāweu. The name may be qualified by the colors hāʻulaʻula and keʻokeʻo. Var. names reported include ʻahakea, haʻakea, and hāʻawikea.
Stirrups.
To be sturdy as steel. Lit., iron steel (Eng.).
Piston.
Branding iron.

White person, American, Englishman, Caucasian; American, English; formerly, any foreigner; foreign, introduced, of foreign origin, as plants, pigs, chickens; entirely white, of pigs (Malo 37; perhaps Malo actually means of foreign introduction). See kolea 1. References in traditional literature are few, but these have been noted: He haole nui maka ʻālohilohi, a big foreigner with bright eyes [referring to Kama-puaʻa, the pig demigod].
Probably similar to ʻoloʻolo 1–3.
Name of a fish (no data).

3. A-minor in music. See lele 7.
Harp. Eng. See pila hāpa.

1. To carry, bear, lift, elevate, raise, hoist, holdup; to support, as another's testimony. (Nah. 23.7.) Hāpai pū, to carry together; carry arms [a military command].

4. To encourage, support.
To carry or lift, as an invalid unable to raise himself in bed or walk.

1. An endemic tree fern (Cibotium splendens, formerly called C. chamissoi), common in many forests of Hawaiʻi, as at Kī-lau-ea Volcano, and now frequently cultivated. These ferns grow about 5 m high, and the trunks are crowned with large, triangular, lacy-looking fronds up to 2.7 m long, their light brown stems rising from a mass of silky, golden pulu (wool). Young stems were formerly used to make hats; the pulu was used as a dressing and to embalm the dead and later as stuffing for pillows and mattresses. The starchy trunk core has been used for cooking and laundry, the outer fibrous part to line or form baskets for plants. Young shoots are called pepeʻe. (Neal 10.) Also hāpuʻu pulu.

2. Grouper, a fish (Epinephelus quernus). The young stage is hāpu ʻupuʻu or ʻāpu ʻupuʻu. See ʻeheʻula.

3. Budding. Fig., child, baby; young, as of squid (rare).

4. A variety of taro, also hāpuʻupuʻu, that may be qualified by the colors ʻeleʻele, hāuliuli (favored by planters), kea or keʻokeʻo, lena, and ʻulaʻula. (HP 17, 18, 32.)

1. An endemic tree fern (Cibotium chamissoi, formerly called C. menziesii) much like the hāpuʻu and also known as hāpuʻu, but bearing stiff blackish hairs on the frond stems. (Neal 10–1.) Also ʻiʻi.

2. See "Dryopteris paleacea":  var. fusco-atra, a much smaller endemic fern (not a tree) with dark hairs at stems' base. Also ʻiʻi.
Same as hāpuʻu 1.

1. Young hāpuʻu ferns that have not yet developed trunks.

2. Young stage of hāpuʻu fish.

3. Same as ʻāpuʻupuʻu; rough, bumpy, pimpled; impediment, as of speech; to speak with an impediment; obscured, as by mist.

4. A mound, as for playing marbles. Also haʻapuʻu, hoʻopuʻupuʻu.

5. Same as hāʻupuʻupu, sweet potato sprouts.

6. Same as hāpuʻu, taro: the plant is said to be distinguished by its leaf stems: yellow-green above, and dark brownish on lower half. The corms yield good light-colored poi, the leaves good greens. This name is qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, keʻokeʻo, and maoli. (HP 17, 32.)

1. A lowland tree (Hibiscus tiliaceus), found in many warm countries, some spreading horizontally over the ground forming impenetrable thickets, and some trained on trellises. The leaves are rounded and heart-shaped, the flowers cup-shaped, with five large petals that change through the day from yellow to dull-red. Formerly the light, tough wood served for outriggers of canoes, the bast for rope, the sap and flowers for medicine. (Neal 559–60.) Of the two varieties of hau, a rare erect one (hau oheohe) was grown for its bast and a creeping one (hau) was planted for wind-breaks. (HP 196.) See ʻau hau.

2. Cool, iced; ice, frost, dew, snow (see ex., ʻale 1); a cool breeze; to blow, of a cool breeze. Cf. kēhau.

3. Same as hahau 1; to hit, smite, beat, tap.

4. Same as hahau 2; to lay before; to offer, as a sacrifice or prayer.

5. A soft porous stone, as used for polishing calabashes. Rare.

6. Mother-of-pearl shell. Rare.

1. Dirty, unpleasant. Cf. hauʻeka, haukaʻe, haumia, hauna. (PCP fau.)

2. Ruler (nonproductive, mostly in proper names, such as in the common names Haulani and Haunani).
To snort (Ier. 8.16), bray, puff; to chatter, as the teeth; to choke with sobs. Cf. puhaʻu.

1. Pas/imp. of hau 3; a blow, stripe; to whip.

2. Pas/imp. of hau 4.

An endemic genus of small trees (Kokia, four species), in the hibiscus family. The leaves are leathery, round, with three to seven shallow lobes. The flowers are large and red, and have three broad bracts at the base. (Neal 567–8.) See kokiʻo 2.
A kind of hau hele shrub.

A word known only in the chant called Haui ka lani, (For. 6:368–410); according to Andrews (For. 6:368), an ancient, poetical name for hāʻule which he translates “fallen” but more probably hau, to strike + -i, transitivizer. A more accurate translation of the chant's title is “the chief is struck down.” A less plausible interpretation is hau i ka lani, offer to the royal chief.

To quiver, shiver, (Nak. 78.)

Varieties of sea urchin are qualified by the terms maoli (natural) and poʻo hina (gray-head). (PNP saawak(e,i).)

Hawaiʻi (both the island and the group of islands); Hawaiian person; Hawaiian. Elsewhere in Polynesia, Hawaiʻi or a cognate is the name of the underworld or of the ancestral home, but in Hawaiʻi the name has no meaning; see Pukui, Elbert, and Mookini, 1974. See saying, kuauli.

1. Name of a legendary figure believed by some to have discovered Hawaiʻi, but see Barrère, 1969; place name.

2. Name of a line for ulua fishing in 17 or more fathoms of water.

1. Nut of the loulu, native palm, considered delicious to eat; also the tree itself. Also wāhane.

Unskilled, awkward, clumsy, incompetent, blundering; blunder, incompetence. Cf. waʻawaʻa. See saying, ʻō 2.

1. To tie, bind, lash, make fast; to snub, as cattle; net lashing, as for a hue wai, gourd; thong. Fig., umbilical cord; to eat.

indefinite article. A, an; to be a, have (with a possessive).

1. Grave.

2. General name for caterpillar. Cf. ʻanuhe, kāhē. (PCP fee.)

3. To scrape, rub, polish.

4. Swish, as of a whip; murmuring sound of wind or running water; to swish, sough.

5. Upper part of a crab's leg. Rare.

6. Poi from the center or core of taro, formerly reserved for chiefs, as it had not come into contact with dirt (Kep. 165).

7. Edges of the mouth of the square uhu (parrot fish) net. Rare.

8. Dividing line between lands. Rare.

9. Hollow container in which canoe paint was mixed.

10. The letter “h.” Eng.

11. Hay. Eng.
See "hoʻohē":  Same as hōhē, cowardly.

1. To call, name; to sing or recite a name chant; to give a name to. Cf. ʻauihea, kāhea.

2. Misty, clouded, smoky, obscure. Cf. Kona Hea.

3. Bank, as of a river. (Kep. 91.)

4. Which (in questions and after other words). Cf. ʻāhea, ināhea.

5. Where? (Usually following prepositions i, ma, mai, no, ʻo; mahea is often written as one word.) I hea ka puke? Just where is the book? Mahea ka puke? Whereabouts is the book? Mai hea mai? Where from? No hea ʻoe? Where are you from? Ā e hele ana ʻoe ʻo hea (For. 5:219)? Where are you going? Aia i hea ka puke? Where's the book (sometimes shortened to aihea)? ʻO kēia lio ā ʻo kēlā lio, mahea ʻoe? This horse or that horse, which for you? (See also ʻauhea.)
Stained red, inflamed, reddened; flattened and destroyed, as by lava; blood red; a blood sacrifice, as hog or man. Cf. heka, kiliheʻa, kīpalaheʻa.
Kauaʻi name for kāwaʻu, a kind of Zanthoxylum. Cf. aʻe.
See aha.
See he aha

of scorn. What does it amount to? It's of no value. (Perhaps nanā is from he ʻahi kananā, a phrase describing a fierce fighter; cf. nanā.) 
Also wesenanā.

1. To call frequently and hospitably; to welcome; friendly, hospitable, genial.

2. Warm, tepid, insipid. Cf. ʻāheahea, mūhea, ʻōheahea.
To imprint with spots, stains; smeared, as with red earth.
To give a name; to chant a name chant; to call a name in hospitable welcome; to call the roll; roll call; name chant.

1. Corpse, especially of one slain in battle; victim, human sacrifice; carcass (Mat. 24.28), remains.

2. Calling, as in greeting.
Human carcass, human sacrifice, an insulting name for kauwā, outcasts.

1. Place where fishermen set a basket fish trap, as for hīnālea.

2. See "Exocarpus":  spp., native shrubs and small trees (sandalwood family), with more or less leafless, jointed branches. (Neal 325.) Also au 12.

1. Octopus (Polypus sp.), commonly known as squid.

2. To slide, surf, slip, flee (Kin. 14.10). Cf. heʻe nalu, pūheʻe. See ex., puʻe one.

3. To melt, flow, drip, soften; to skim, as milk. Cf. heʻeheʻe, heheʻe.

4. To hang down, as fruit; to sag; to bear breadfruit. See ex., ule 1.

5. Line that supports the mast, stay.
To bleat.

1. Redup. of heʻe 2–4; avalanche (rare).

2. Breast disease, with caking and great pain during nursing.
See hōlua.
Flow of blood, hemorrhage, menstrual flow (Oihk. 15.25).
A variety of large red octopus (Octopus ornatus); it was rarely eaten because of its bitter taste, but was sometimes used as medicine.
Squid beginning to decompose, with a pinkish color and a bad odor, liked by some.
To ride a surfboard; surfing; surf rider. Lit., wave sliding.
Name of a misty rain observed off the coast of Hilo when nehu fish are running.
Season when nehu fish run; to run in schools, of nehu.
Each of two posts at the back wall of the ancient house, visible at the door. Rare.
A stroke in lua fighting.
An octopus settled on the ocean floor with tentacles spread out.
Tiny, young octopus that clings to rocks along sea pools, especially in certain seasons.
To surf toward the mouth of a stream or up the stream.
A long-headed, long-tentacled octopus (Octopus ornatus), very tough, tenderized only by much pounding; now called the night octopus. Lit., long-headed octopus.
Octopus slightly decomposed. Also heʻe mākole.
Body surfing; to body surf.
Miscarriage; to have a miscarriage.
Lazy, indolent, drowsy; weariness following sexual gratification.
A kind of bird (no data). (KL. line 348.)
Burst of laughter, guffaw; to guffaw.
A boil, running sore; ulcerous; botch [KJV] boils [RSV] (Kanl. 28.27).

1. Redup. of heʻe 2–4; to slide, sag, fade; landslide, avalanche; soft, watery, melting.

2. Discharge, as of pus; fluid.
Redup. of heheʻe 1, 2.
Redup. of hewa; a mistake by many.

1. Redup. of hei 1, to entangle.

2. Type of pāʻū (no data).
Pas/imp. of hehei.
Redup. and intensifier of heleleʻi.
Redup. of helo; reddish, bright, showy.
See "hoʻohehelo":  Proud, especially of one's appearance or dress.
Insane, raving mad, crazy, possessed; insanity, madness; lunatic, maniac. (1 Sam. 21.13, 14).
A swaggering or swishing walk; swishing, as of a skirt; to whirl, swish, strut.
To stamp, tread, trample, pedal, step on; trampling. Fig., to repudiate, deny, desecrate, loathe, break (as taboo). Also hahi.
Pas/imp. of hehi.
Redup. of hehi.
Misstep; to make a misstep.
To step firmly, stamp; to make a misstep and come down hard.
To break rules or taboos, disregard the rights of others, trample on their rights, trespass; willful; trespassing, violation.
Footrest; any place on which to step or tread; a stepping, treading.
To thresh wheat; threshing. Lit., tread flour (Eng.).
Rain name associated with Poʻo-kū, Kauaʻi. Lit., stepping upon pandanus flowers.

1. To uproot, dig up, put to flight, drive away, evict, shoo.

2. Young seedlings or plants, as for transplanting; sucker. Cf. ilo 2.

3. A purge, as of water and juice of gourd stems used as an enema; to purge.

4. Ceremony to drive away evil influence.

5. Pile, as of rocks. (GP 100.)

1. Net, snare, stratagem, ruse; to ensnare, entangle, catch in a net; to festoon with leis. See kāhei 1, 2; Luka. 5.4.

2. String figure, cat's cradle; to make such. Many kinds are listed by Dickey.

3. Motion of hands and fingers, especially of the dying, (Some persons did not make string figures, hei, at night because of the association of the figures with the motions of death.)

4. Adept, deft; to absorb, as knowledge or skill.

5. Var. of hai, to sacrifice. Cf. haiau, heiau.

6. Water oozing from a cliff and trickling down. Cf. hī 2.
See heleleʻi.

1. Same as mīkana, papaya. (Neal 600–1.)

2. A variety of sweet potato usually called ʻuala hēʻī.

3. Same as maiʻa Polapola, a wild banana. (PCP feekii.)

1. Pas/imp. of hei 1.

2. Piece of hair, tooth, fingernail, small bone, or the like of a deceased beloved, kept and offered food in order to please the spirit of the deceased.

Pre-Christian place of worship, shrine; some heiau were elaborately constructed stone platforms, others simple earth terraces. Many are preserved today. Several types are listed below. In Isa. 15.2, heiau is a high place of worship. See hei 5.
Heiau for treating sick.
See "Heiau":  where first fruits were offered to insure further growth. Lit., heiau for the increase of food crops.
Heiau where fish were offered to insure good fishing.
See "Heiau":  where offerings were made to insure rain.

Heiau for stopping rain, or (less frequently) for bringing rain. One such heiau named Imukālua-ua (rain-baking oven) was in the Kaunakakai quadrangle, Molokaʻi; a land section in Puna, Hawaiʻi, also has this name. Rain in leaf packages is said to have been baked in an oven.
Small temporary heiau covered with tapa stained green (maʻo), used for the hoʻoulu ʻai ceremony to bring food. (Malo 158.)
See "Heiau":  where human sacrifices were offered.
A heiau used for services to bring success in war.
Helper or apprentice to a priest.

1. Race, as foot race, canoe race, horse race; to race.

2. Redup. of hei 1–3; to festoon, drape. Cf. pāʻū heihei.

3. To enthrall, enchant.
See "hoʻoheihei":  To beat, as a heiau drum; sound of heiau drum.
Footrace.
A sacred place, as one where a priest stayed in seclusion to await a message from the gods, usually a small house on the heiau.
Red, sore, inflamed, bleary. Cf. heʻa, pīheka.
Redup. of heka.

1. Anchor, stone anchor, towline, line for fastening boats; warp; to anchor, make fast, tow; taut, stretched, anchored.

2. To come upon, happen, befall, strike.

1. Best, greatest, foremost. See ex., manomano.

2. Top gourd in a hula gourd drum. Cf. ʻolo 1.

3. Feathered top of an ʻulīʻulī, hula rattle.

4. Nail, pin, rack, as for hanging objects in a house.

5. Triangular sail, topsail. Also peʻa heke.

6. Shy, sensitive. Cf. ʻōheke.

7. Same as hekeheke. Cf. ʻuheke.
Plump.
Plump.
Redup. of hekili.

1. Thunder; to thunder. Fig., passion, rage. See hakikili.

2. A variety of taro.

3. A variety of sweet potato.
Thunder without rain.
See hekili pāmalō
Same as kuawa 1, valley.
See hēkuawa
Grave. (Nah. 19.16.)

1. Redness of the eyelids; rawness, as of scraped skin; to be red or raw.

2. To spread, as the arms. Cf. helahela, kāhela.

3. Hula step: one foot is placed at about a 45-degree angle to the front and side, with the weight on the opposite hip and with that knee bent; the foot is then returned to the original position and the step is repeated with the other foot; to dance thus.
Redup. of hela 1, 2; widespread.

1. To go, come, walk; to move, as in a game; going, moving; a gadabout. Fig., to die. Cf. hele wale, hele wāwae.

2. To become, get; like, in a state of, similar (frequently followed by ā).

3. When, by the time that (usually followed by ā).

4. following others bases, imparting idea of everywhere, here and there, continuously.

5. A relationship term. See hele hope, hele mua.

6. To tie, bind, lash, make fast; noose, snare.

7. To divide, cut apart. Rare. Cf. mahele.
Priest's helper.
Pas/imp. of hele 1, 6.
To flow like water.
To go drifting along. (For. 5:509.)
The planet Uranus, formerly called Hershel for its discoverer, Sir William Hershel, in 1781.
See Heleekela
Redup. of hele 7; to cut up, divide; divided; filled with ruts, as a road.
See "hoʻohelehele":  To help someone walk; to take walking, as a dog. Cf. hele 1.
Redup. and intensifier of helei 1, 2.
Features, face.
See "hoʻohelehele ʻōlelo":  To lead up to a subject in a roundabout way, hint, suggest.
To go wrong, take the wrong path, go astray, err.

1. To go suddenly, early, or for no apparent reason.

2. To tie or bind beforehand, as in preparation for a journey.
Younger brother or sister; descendant of a younger brother or sister; to go behind.

1. To straddle.

2. Stretched sideways, as the mouth; pulled down, as an eyelid with a finger (these were signs of contempt); inflammatory disease of the eye with a drawing down of the lower lid. See saying, maka helei.
To go from house to house, gad.
Heretic. Eng.
See helekika
To go quickly, fast.
To walk upright, wade.
To go by fits and starts, jerk.
Herald. Eng.
See helela
Quick-bearing kind of sweet potato. (Kam. 76:27.)
Falling; scattered, as rain, tears, grain; crumbling, as the earth; dilapidated; to shed, as a dog's hair. Cf. heheleleʻi.
See heleleʻi
To go or come far; to go with no hope of returning.
To travel together, of two.
To go to a place for the first time or as a stranger.
A rare native variety of dry-land taro, with dark purplish petioles and white corms; grown on Hawaiʻi. (HP 18, 32.) Also piko ʻeleʻele.
To travel in the mountains; mountain climber.

1. To go ahead; older sibling, descendant of an older sibling, senior.

2. Da capo (musical term).

1. Going. (See idiom, oneʻā and below.) Hoʻokahi helena, pau ka hana, in no time at all the work was finished.

2. Same as helehelena.
Greek, Grecian, Greece. (Gr.
See -helehele ʻōlelo.
Get out! Go away!
To go with, accompany.
Var. of hāleu.
Stone anchor, anchor. (Heb. 6.19.) Huki i ka heleuma, to weigh anchor.
To go naked; to go without fixed purpose or far and wide; to go empty-handed; to go without recompense.
To walk, go on foot, hike; pedestrian. (Hawaiian pidgin ‘walk feet’ is probably a loan translation.)
Quick step, quick time; to go fast.
Introduced, sweet-scented heliotrope (Heliotropium arborescens syn.
See heliokalope

1. To move back and forth rapidly; jerky pushing or sawing motion. Cf. helohelo, hula helo, ʻilihelo, ʻōhelo 2, 3.

2. Ramrod.

3. Red, as ʻōhelo berries; rosy. Cf. hehelo, helohelo, ʻōhelo.
Redup. of helo 1, 3; rosy, as cheeks. (Probably PPN felofelo.)

1. To count, number, compute, take a census, figure, enumerate, list, include, impute (Oihk. 7.18); to assess, as taxes; to chant a list of names, as of genealogy; including, counting, enumeration, census, list, rate, number, figure, total, inventory; statistics. Cf. heluhelu, huahelu, uē helu.

2. Arithmetic, score, reckoning, account; serial; volume (in a series); numbered.

3. A few He mau lā helu wale nō i koe, only a few days left.

4. To scratch the earth, as a hen; to dig with the fingers; to paw the earth, as an angry bull. See māhelu.

5. To grumble, list offenses or complaints, especially about lack of gratitude or appreciation.
Pas/imp. of helu 1, 4, 5.
Scorekeeper; to keep score.
Uneven totals, as ten bushels and three pecks.
Even numbers and totals, without fractions.
Best, “number one.”
Church census.
Factor, as in arithmetic.
Composite number.
Prime factor.

1. To read, count. (2 Nal. 23.2.) Mea heluhelu, reader (either a book, or a person who reads).

2. Redup. of helu 4; to scratch.
To proofread.
To take turns reading, read in turn.
Abacus.
Subtrahend.
Multiplier.
Multiplicand.

Census; to take a census.
Even number.

Multiple.

Number, count, total sum, amount; grade or mark (evaluation).

Grade or mark, as in school; number of a grade (class), enumeration.
Large number; plural number.
Exclusive plural, as in Hawaiian grammar.
Inclusive plural, as in Hawaiian grammar.
Whole number.
To count by, as helu pālua, to count by twos; helu pākolu, to count by threes; helu pāʻumi, to count by tens.
Counting game with chants; to play this game.

To count ballots; election teller.
To count or recite in order or consecutively.
List of the nights of the moon in the old Hawaiian calendar; to count the nights.
Perfect number.
Quotient, in division.
Inventory.
Abbreviation used in surveying for hema, south.

1. Left, left side.

2. South, southern.

1. Awkward, clumsy, unskilled, inexpert, incompetent, unprepared, inefficient, inexperienced; lack of skill; to not know well.

2. Want, need, necessity; lacking, destitute (Oihk. 22.23), needy.

1. Loose, separated, untied, unfastened, open, satisfied (see ex., hemahema 2), discharged, divorced, opened, weaned; taken off, as clothes. Cf. puhemo 1, Puk. 19.21.) Kuli hemo, dislocated knee.

2. Var. of ʻōhemo 1, weak, feeble. Cf. puhemo 2.
Faint, scanty, feeble, hungry, gasping, as of one near death.
Redup. of hemo 1; separation, loosening.

1. Perfect, faultless, flawless, holy, immaculate, saintly, pure in heart; complete; perfection, virtue, goodness, holiness; angel, person without fault.

2. Without restraint.
Shoo, be off, scat (perhaps from Eng. move).
To sound indistinctly, as a voice.
Buttocks; mons pubis; hollow of the thigh; nakedness.

1. Var. of henehene 1.

2. Redup. of hena.

1. Mons pubis. (PCP (f,s)ene.)

2. Slope, as of a hill.

3. Same as henehene; to snicker. Cf. pūhene 1.

4. var. of kīhene, basket.

1. To laugh at, ridicule, mock, tease, snicker, giggle; mockery, laughter.

2. Redup. of hene, slope. (KL. line 545.)
Inner side of the thighs where they join the body on either side of the genitals; groins.
Same as henoheno.
See "hoʻoheno":  Decorative plaiting on mat, fan; to decorate thus.
Lovable, sweet.

1. Knob of any kind, as of a door; end of the penis, prepuce. Cf. pūheheo; pūheoheo 2.

2. To depart in haste.

3. Proud, haughty (less common than haʻaheo). Cf. heheo.
Same as heo 1, and pōheoheo, knob.
Idiot, moron, imbecile; partial paralysis of the vocal organs causing indistinct articulation; feebleminded, moronic.

Week; seven years. Cf. pule. (Gr.

Pale yellow, of the domesticated ʻilima flower. Also pia.

Down or fine hair, fuzz, loose fibers on certain fruits or leaves, quicksilver or mercury on back of a mirror, hairlike growths or spines on sugar cane stalks or cactus; fuzzy, downy; to begin to grow, as a youth's beard or pubic hair; to sprout, of seedlings.

1. Hoot, as of an owl; to croak, hoot.

2. Deep-throated sounds made in Hawaiian chants and prayers; to chant thus.
Fine bits of broken or ground glass; mercury on glass made into a mirror.
Redup. of heu. (PEP feufeu.)
Redup. of heʻu 1, 2.
Beautiful, comely, attractive. (AP)

1. A reedlike grass, a bent grass (Agrostis avenacea, synonyms A. retrofracta and Calamagrostis forsteri), originally found in Australia, and now found through Polynesia; Panicum heupueo on Niʻihau. Lit., owl hoot.

2. Probable Hawaiian name for pili uka, a grass.

1. Mistake, fault, error, sin, blunder, defect, offense, guilt, crime, vice; wrong, incorrect, wicked, sinful, guilty; to err, miss, mismanage, fail, mis-.

2. Is it wrong to? Then why not? He hewa kā ʻoe ke kūʻai i ʻāina, loaʻa ke kahua paʻa? Why not then buy land and get security?

3. Offended, annoyed.

4. To the point of satiety; to be in great quantities; to do excessively. See ex., wai 1.

1. A great many, very, vast, in great quantities.

2. Crazy, demented, wild, aimless; to fail to recognize (Ier. 29.26). Cf. kala hewahewa.
See "hoʻohewahewa":  Twill plaiting.

1. To cast or troll, as for bonito, ʻahi, and kala.

2. Dysentery, diarrhea; to flow, hiss; to purge.
A rare transitivizer. See kilohi, ukuhi.
Desire, delight. Cf. hiamoe.

1. How many? How much? (Follows ʻa-, ʻe-, or pā-.)

2. Pas/imp.

1. To make fire with the fire-plow; the act of making fire thus.

2. Shuttle or needle for making nets; to knot or fasten the meshes of a net; to form a network; to bind, as house rafters (For. 5:651).
Indisposed to sleep, wakeful, sleepless; insomnia.
Pleased with, delighted with; delightful, pleasing.
Greatly pleased or delighted, most delightful; appetite for delicious food.
Same as the more common hiaʻā. See ex., hana aloha.

1. Faded, gray, hazy. Cf. ahia, faded.

2. Var. of hiehie.
Redup. of hiʻa 1, 2.
Shuttle or needle for making a fish net, sometimes of bone.
To cast for bonito; bonito casting.

1. Same as hiaʻai.

2. To eat heartily.
Restless, furtive.

1. Food offering to the gods.

2. To stir, as a fire; to signal with the hands. Rare.
Well trained, skilled.

1. Bald temple.

2. Same as ʻuhalou, a weed.
Sleep; to sleep, fall asleep, asleep.
A little sleep, nap; to take a nap.
To oversleep, sleep deeply; death, eternal sleep. Cf. moe loa.
Fast asleep; deep sleep. (Lunk. 4.21.)
Depression or hole, as under water.
Stems by which tubers are attached to vines. (Kep. 99.) Cf. ʻanakiʻu.
Foremost, expert.
First-born child; first born, oldest.
Attractive, distinguished, dignified, noble, becoming. Cf. māhie.
Redup. of hie; superb.

1. Kind of soft porous stone used to smooth and polish utensils; it is harder than the ʻana stone, which is used on wood.

2. Hyena. Eng.

3. Speckled bird of prey. (Ier. 12.9.)
Obliquely, indirectly, sideways. (For. 6:495.)

1. To entangle, creep, spread, intertwine, intermingle; entanglement, web, snare. Cf. pohihihi.

2. A large-meshed fish net.
See "hoʻohihi":  To take a fancy to, admire greatly, be enraptured with. Hoʻohihi ka manaʻo i ka nani o Kahana, the mind is entranced with the beauty of Kahana.
Redup. of hī 2; to hiss.

1. Entangled, interwoven, involved, perplexed, hampered, rank, snarled, obscure and difficult to understand (Kep. 167); snarl, entanglement, kink, thicket, difficulty, problem, trouble.

2. Lawsuit or case before the court, trial, Cf. hihia kalaima, hihia waiwai. (PCP fifia.)
Criminal case.
A plant with small yellow flowers. (And.)

The swamp fern (Ceratopteris thalictroides), an edible, somewhat succulent fern, distributed through the tropics. It grows in mud or water, as around taro patches, in tufts about 30 cm high. The fronds are triangular and are finely divided into long, narrow parts. Young fronds are eaten with fresh-water shrimps. (Neal 12.) Also palai kahawai.
Civil case.
Redup. of hihi 1.
To come or go, of many people. Cf. hiki 3, hihiki.
Redup. and intensifier of hina, to fall.
Redup. of hiki, to come, go.

1. Same as kākalaioa 2, 3, kinds of brambles.

2. Name of a legendary koa tree on Kauaʻi that was said to have no trunk.

3. See Ka-hili-kolo.
Net made of strong cord used for shark fishing. (Malo 213.) Also kāhala.

1. Various sting rays (Dasyatidae) and eagle rays (Actobatus narinari). Also lupe.

2. Lavish, magnificent, elegant; elegance.

3. A Kauaʻi peak. See saying, keha.

1. Redup. and plural of hina, to fall.

2. Entanglement, spreading. Cf. hihi.
Soft whistling sound, gust or draft of wind; to whistle.
A dream or vision (Kin. 15–1), as while dozing; to dream while dozing; to whistle or sough, as wind.
Jungle, tangled thicket; entangled. Fig., bewilderment, grief.
Spider web, cobweb.
