1. Wild, untamed.

2. Rare, uncommon.

1. Endemic grainy snail (Neritinu graposa), in both fresh and brackish water, eaten both cooked and raw. Also wī, if in fresh water.

2. A shellfish (Nerita vespertina). Also hapawai. See hūai 1.

3. A pelagic grapsid crab, probably Grapsus tenuicrustatus.

4. A tide in the high-tide zone.

1. To hold or carry in the arms, as a child; to bear; to nurse or tend a child (Hawaiians did not carry children unrelated to them, and commoners did not touch a chief's child; carrying a child symbolized love, kinship, and affection). Cf. Hiʻiaka, hiʻialo, hiʻikua, hiʻilani, hiʻilei, hiʻimoʻopuna, hiʻipaka, hiʻipoi, hoʻo.hiʻi Caus/sim.

2. Same as kūpoki, a plaiting process.

3. Tall, as cliff or mountain.
Pas/imp. of hiʻi 1.

1. First part of the names of the twelve younger sisters of the goddess Pele; the youngest and most famous was Hiʻiaka-i-ka-poli-o-Pele. See PH

2. A rare variety of taro with bronze-red leaf and stem, used in medicine.

3. A variety of sweet potato.

1. Carried in the arms, as a beloved child.

2. Nearby, in front. See ex., hiʻikua.
Hook used for kala, a fish, and baited with kala, a seaweed.

1. Carried on the shoulders, as a beloved child.

2. In back, far.

3. Name of a star said to rise on the night of Hoaka and to vanish on the night of Muku in the month of Welehu.
To nurse or care for, as an infant; to admire, exalt, praise, extol in poetry; praise.

1. To lift, carry.

2. Name of the highest waterfall in Hawaiʻi, and one of the highest in the world, with a vertical drop of about 300 m, at Waipiʻo Valley, Hawaiʻi. See Elbert and Mahoe, p. 49, for a famous song.
To carry, tend, and cherish a beloved child (lei).
Name of a star that rises and vanishes at the same times as Hiʻikua.
To bear a grandchild in the arms; to be a grandparent (a term of pride and affection).
To care for a child; to instruct a child.
To tend, feed, cherish, as a child.
Redup. of hiʻipoi.
Abbreviation for hikina, east.
Same as hīkākā.
To tilt back, as the head.
To stagger, totter, reel; spreading, as vines (Kep. 157); unsteady gait.
Gibberish; to talk gibberish; to speak a foreign language, especially English.
To pelt, throw.
Name of an unknown person, used something like so-and-so, usually followed by mā.

Name of the wife of the famous legendary navigator, Pākaʻa and of the coastal area, Molokaʻi, where she lived. She was lost during labor pains and her husband searched vainly for her, hence the saying applied to fruitless endeavors, Hikauhi i Kau-manamana, Hikauhi is at Kau-manamana [another place on Molokaʻi].
Similar to keʻa 1, 2.

1. Can, may; to be able; ability; possible. Cf. hiki nō, hikiwale, hikiwawe.

2. All right, O.K. (in sense of “able to do”), certainly, surely (used alone or preceding nō).

3. To get to or reach a place, come, arrive, approach, appear, arise. Cf. hikina.

4. Next.

5. To fetch, carry back and forth (less used than lawe).
Names of cardinal directions, stars, and portions of the sky, perhaps because of movement (hiki 3) of the sun. See below.
To aim carefully, as with stone, spear, or gun.
Zenith. Rare.
Probably the same as ikiʻalamea, a disease.
Spittle passed from a dying master, according to the belief that his knowledge was thereby handed on.
Name of a star, described as medium-bright and near the equator; visible from April to September; used as a guide to mariner and fisherman.
Kauaʻi name for the star Hikianalia.
Large Hawaiian couch. Lit., possible to mount.

1. Redup. of hiki 3; to come repeatedly, as voices.

2. Redup. of hiki 5, to fetch and carry; to fetch repeatedly or a little at a time.
Binding, tying; to tie, bind, make fast. Cf. hīkiʻikiʻi, nākiʻi, mūkiʻi.
Redup. of hīkiʻi. (Mat. 27.2.)
Pas/imp. of hīkiʻi.
Name of a star; according to some, Sirius.
See Hikikauelia
Name of a star. Also ʻĀ-iki-kau-e-lono.
The star Sirius.

1. To lean back, relax.

2. To spread, as mist; to rain, especially a slanting rain.
Portion of the sky immediately above the horizon.
To jump or start from shock, to gasp; shock, perturbation.
Star name, perhaps morning star. (For. 5:119.)
West. Lit., come to rest. Rare.
Progress, advance; to progress.
To come ahead or beforehand.

1. East

2. Orient.

3. Coming, advent.
Northeast.
Southeast.
All right, O.K., certainly, surely, it can be done. Cf. hiki 2.
Impossible, unable, can't or unable to do; inability, regrets.

1. To force one's way, as through a crowd or undergrowth. Rare.

2. Wind name associated with Hālawa, Molokaʻi.
Easy.
To come accidentally, alone, or without any particular purpose or reason.
Quickly, speedily, suddenly, prompt, quickly done; possible to do quickly; doubletime (military command).
Bloody dysentery, hemorrhoids; ulcers (RSV), emerods (KJV) (Kanl. 28.27.)
Tattoo brand on the forehead of a kauā outcast, or on the forehead of the caught seducer of a high chief's wife. (See figure 1, Malo 70.)
num. Seven, seventh (usually preceded by the numerical prefix ʻe). Cf. Nā-hiku, the Big Dipper.
To throw aimlessly, carelessly.

1. Many.

2. Confusion of sounds. (And.)

1. Same as hilahila 1.

2. Heel. Eng. Hila ʻauliʻi, high heels.

3. Hill. Eng. Cf. kuahiwi, mauna.

1. Bashful, shy, ashamed (2 Nal. 2.17), abashed, embarrassed; shame, bashfulness. Cf. puahilahila.

2. Same as iholena, a banana.
To exalt, praise. Rare.
To reel, lean or tilt sideways.
Dysentery caused by eating laulele greens; name of a famine during the sandalwood-cutting days when farms were neglected and the people lived on laulele greens.
Careless, shiftless (named for the people of Hīlea village, Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, reported to have brought poorly prepared poi to a chief).

1. To braid or plait, as a lei or candlenuts; a braid, plaiting, string. See lei hili.

2. To turn aside, deviate, miss the way, wander, stray. Cf. hilikau, pūhili.

3. To whip, smite, thrash, switch, bat; batter, as in baseball; stroke, as in fighting.

4. Bark used in dyeing, as hili kukui, hili kōlea, hili noni; the dark-brown dye made from this bark; a tapa dyed with hili; to dye with hili.

1. Pas/imp. of hili 1–4.

2. A native bird (no data).
In devious ways; to ramble; be indirect. See ex., neʻikū.
Var. of ʻilieʻe, plumbago.
Four-strand braid; to braid thus.
Tangled, confused; entanglement, confusion; to become entangled; to trip or fall.

1. Redup. of hili 1–3.

2. Redup. of hili 4; dark red or brown (less dark than hili 4).
To grope here and there. Rare.
Mixed, snarled, entangled; to mix, snarl. See saying makau.
To hit carelessly, at random.
Var. of hihikolo 2, a legendary tree.
Same as Ka-hili-kolo and Ka-hihi-kolu.
A three-strand braid; to braid such.
To lash against, whip.
Name of a star and of a Hawaiian month (same as Māhoe Mua: see month).
To believe, trust; to lean on, rely on; trust, confidence.
Name of the eleventh month (Molokaʻi) eighth (Kauaʻi), or tenth (Alexander); same as Māhoe Hope. Cf. alanui
Same as Hilina Ehu.
Same as heliokalope, heliotrope. Eng.

1. Square braid of eight or sixteen strands. (And.)

2. Ailment of the bowels or stomach, accompanied by gas pains. (And.)
Four-strand braid; to braid such.
Three-strand braid; to braid such.
To wander or grope aimlessly in the dark.
Sound or call of a wind instrument, as the conch shell. Rare.

1. To twist, braid, spin; twisted, braided; threadlike; faint streak of light. See lei hilo.

2. First night of the new moon. See Malo 35. (PCP filo.)

3. Name of a famous Polynesian navigator for whom the city and district may have been named. See sayings, Hilo (Eng.-Hawaiian) (PCP filo.)

4. Same as mauʻu Hilo, Hilo grass.

5. Gonorrhea; a running sore (Oihk. 15.3).

6. A variety of sweet potato.

7. See iwi hilo.

1. To lengthen a speech or story by inserting new matter; to embroider or spin out a tale.

2. Sweet juice of ti root. (And.)

1. Various species of reef fishes of the genus Coris. The name hilu may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, lauwili, melemele, moelola, pano (probably same as uli), pāniʻo, pilikoʻa (Paracirrhites forsteri), hawkfish), ʻula, uli. See saying, noʻenoʻe 2.

2. Quiet, reserved, well-behaved, decorous, unobtrusive, easygoing; such a person (a child born to a woman who craved hilu fish during her pregnancy was thought to be of this desirable type).

3. Strange.
Elegant, beautiful.
Himalayas. Eng. See song, hene 2.
Hymn, any song not used for hulas; to sing a hīmeni. Eng. Hīmeni wae, selected hymn or anthem. Ā hīmeni aku ka poʻe hīmeni (2 Oihn. 29.28), the singers sang.
Vocal solo.
Trio (musical).

1. To fall, tumble, or topple over from an upright position (cf. hāʻule, to drop); to be “controlled,” as a disease (Kam. 64:102); to fall morally; to throw down; a falling (a loaʻa-type word; see ).

2. Italics, probably so called because italics slant.

3. To blow in a straight course, of wind.

4. Gray- or white-haired; gray. Cf. ʻāhina.

5. Hin (a Hebrew measure). (Puk. 29.4O.) Eng.

6. A goddess.

1. Same as naʻenaʻe, shrubs or trees.

2. Name of a legendary goddess.

1. The silversword (Argyroxiphium sandwicense). See ʻāhinahina 2.

2. Florida moss (Tillandsia usneoides), an air plant, growing on tree branches 
and hanging baskets, forming masses of gray, thread-like stems and leaves. It is often substituted for the heliotrope (below) as the flower of Ka-hoʻolawe, and so called. (Neal 169–71.) Also ʻāhinahina and ʻumiʻumi-o-Dole, Dole's Whiskers.

3. Native heliotrope (Heliotropium anomalum var.

4. Native geraniums (Geranium cuneatum var.

5. Native artemisia (Artemisia australis). See ʻāhinahina 3.

6. Gray, grayish.

7. A variety of sugar cane, gray-green with a rosy flush, the whole covered with a wax bloom; pith dark brown; looks like lahi 2. (HP 224, 225.)

8. Redup. of hina 1. Rare.

Dusty miller (Artemisia stelleriana), a perennial herb in the daisy family, from northeastern Asia and eastern North America. The leaves and stems have a white, velvety covering and are aromatic. (Neal 852.)
A native Hawaiian plant of the water-leaf family (Nama sandwicensis).
Same as pōhinahina 2, the beach vitex
Same as hinahina 5, artemisia.
Same as hinahina 3, a beach (kahakai) heliotrope.
An unidentified plant.
An unidentified plant.
Basket or container made of braided ʻie vine, pandanus, or other material; a kind of basket fish trap, as used for shrimps, eels, hīnālea and ʻoʻopu. Also hīnaʻi hoʻoluʻuluʻu or hīnaʻi hoʻomoe iʻa.
A Hawaiian star and month name. See ʻumeke, month.
A round basket or container, as braided around a calabash.
Wire fish trap.
Handkerchief. Eng.
Neckerchief.
Pocket handkerchief.

Type of stone laid near the coral pile (umu) to attract fish; it was flat on one side and rounded on the other, and was believed to attract manini and young of other fish which resembled it in color. Lit., white gray.
Name of a star.
Thin, sickly.
To blow favorably, as wind. See ex., pēlā 1.

1. Small- to moderate-sized, brightly colored wrasses, family Labridae. In addition to those listed below, hīnālea may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, līpoa, lolo, nīʻau, nuku ʻiʻiwi, nuku ʻiʻiwi ʻula, nuku ʻiʻiwi uli, nuku loa, nuku loa ʻeleʻele. Cf. ōpule.

2. A variety of taro.
Yellowtail coris, Coris gaimard, up to 46 cm. See ʻakilolo.
Bird wrasse, Gomphosus varius, 23 cm.
A saddle wrasse up to 20 cm. long (Thalassoma duperreyi).
A blacktail wrasse up to about 18 cm. long (Thalassoma ballieui). Lit., old-lady wrasse.

1. Name of a chief in whose time occurred a famous deluge called kai a ka Hinaliʻi; the Biblical flood (Kin. 6.17). See saying ʻiliki 1.

2. Name of a star that appears in the month of Hilinehu and follows in its course the star Polo-wehi-lani.
Var. of hīnano.
Name of a star, said to be the tutelary star of Hāna, Maui.
To lie down to sleep; to lie low, as of smoke; to drop dead.
Young of ʻoʻopu, a fish, formerly caught in nets and greatly relished.
Same as hīnau. Rare.
Male pandanus blossom.
Type of pāʻū (no data).
Var. of Hina-mālailena, a star.
Var. of hinapē.
Too weak to stand alone.

1. A rare native variety of upland taro, with green leaves, reddish leaf juncture (piko), dark-green petioles, and white corm. (HP 18, 32.) Perhaps same as lauloa uliuli.

2. A variety of sweet potato.
To fall together, of several; to topple.
Thin, fine, as hair. Probably obsolete except in names.
A kind of seaweed.
To begin to gray, of hair.
Same as hīnawe, nānawaū, hīnewanewaū.
Same as hīnawenawe.
Thin, feeble, weak, spindling, slender, puny, debilitated.
Gaudy, showy, splendid.
Female, feminine. Cf. wahine, kaikamahine, kaikuahine, luahine.
A moss listed by Rock.
Hindu. Eng.
See Hinekū
Var. of hīnawenawe.
Weak, feeble, delicate. (PCP (f,s)ini.)

1. Redup. of hini; indistinct, faint, as a voice. (PCP (f,s)ini(f,s)ini.)

2. A variety of land shell. See hinihini konouli, hinihini kua mauna, See ex., māpu.

3. Cooked greens, as of ʻāheahea, pōpolo, pakai.
A land shell (Succinea casta orophila).
A land shell (Succinea casta).
Air upland moss (no data).
Oil, grease, ointment; oily, greasy; smooth and polished, lustrous, slick. Cf. maka hinu.
Pas/imp. of hinu.

1. Intensification of hinu; bright, glossy, shining, lustrous, glittering, as of polished stones or shells; splendid; splendor.

2. Var. of hiluhilu.

1. Same as maiʻa ʻeleʻele or ʻeleʻele, a mountain banana with shiny black trunk. See also hinu.

2. A native variety of upland taro. Also eleʻele.

1. A sweep or gust of wind; to blow in gusts.

2. Inside corners of a house, said to be so named because ghosts came whistling in at the corners.

3. To break wind silently. Cf. pūhiʻu.
To fall sideways, lean, slant, slope, incline, leaning, oblique, diagonal. See pahiō, wele 1.
Restless, active, flighty. See ex., palawili.

1. To whistle softly; to blow softly, draw in the breath, as of one eating hot food.

2. Gibberish; to jabber. See hiohio haole.

3. Lure for trolling, said to be named for its whistling sound tripping over the water.
To lean every which way.
Ruddy, bright red. Rare.
To jibber jabber in the white man's language, so called because English seemed full of whistling (hiohio), sibilant sounds.
To level off, as a flower bed. (Kep. 157.)
Redup. of hiolo.
Redup. of hiona.
Features, as of a face or landscape; sight, aspect.
To sleep, lie at ease, lounge, relax (this word sometimes replaces moe in poetry because moe suggests the sleep of death).
To tumble down, collapse; overthrown, defeated; collapse, landslide, falling.
Pas/imp. of hiolo.
Leaning, slanting.
General appearance, as of a person; impression. Cf. hiohiona.
Redup. of hīʻō.

1. Var. of hepa, imbecilic.

2. Sheep. Eng. (Ioane 10.2.) Hulu hipa, wool.

1. Same as puka wai, a coconut eye that is or may be pierced for drinking.

2. Hip, hip, hurrah! Cheers! (Eng., hip.) ʻEkolu hipahipa no ka mōʻī, three cheers for the king!
The star Aries.
Ram. Lit., male sheep.
Lamb.
Hippopotamus. Eng.
See hipopokamu
Resting place, as in the shelter of a tree or cave.
A concealed snare for plovers. Rare.

1. Knot, bond, fastening; to tie a knot.

2. Tied bundle, purse (Sol. 1.14, Isa. 3.22); to bundle up.
Redup. of hīpuʻu 1, 2.

1. To throw or fling violently; to haul energetically with ropes; to get into action, as play or sport; to pursue with energy, as love-making.

2. To elevate, hoist, as by block and tackle.

3. Stones used in games of kōnane, kinepeki, and āneo, usually polished and flat.

1. Hind part or tail section of a fish, considered less delicious than the head or front section. See saying, pau 1.

2. Caudal fin.

3. To break wind. Same as pūhiʻu.

4. To motion with the hands in a way destructive to the addressee. (Kam. 64:141.)

1. A game something like checkers, played on a board with five squares.

2. Menstrual.
Redup. of hiu 1, 2; to pelt repeatedly; to tug, lift again and again.
Last bits of odds and ends; remnants of matting strips that must be cut off after plaiting is finished; ends of knots in plaiting; wispy end of a braid. Cf. hiʻu, tail.
Fishtail fern (Nephrolepis biserrata cv.
Whole fish used as bait for trolling. Rare.
A single fishtail. Fig., limited knowledge.
A fresh-water ʻoʻopu fish with a pinkish tail (hiʻu kole). It is taboo to some because it is believed related to the moʻo lizard gods. Also ʻalamoʻo, hiʻuʻula, and nuʻukole.
Canoe stern. Fig., a straight tree suitable for a canoe.

1. Water purification festivities on the second night of the month of Welehu (near the end of the year). The people bathed and frolicked in the sea or stream after midnight, then put on their finest tapa and ornaments for feasting and games. (Kep. 97, 193–4.)

2. “Water-tailed,” said of one allegedly descended from a shark. (GP 10–1.)
A kind of ʻahi, a tuna fish. Lit., thin tail.

1. Entirely black, as of pigs offered to the gods, a desirable blackness contrasting with uli and ʻeleʻele, which have pejorative connotations. See polohiwa and its associations with the god Kāne. (PCP (f,s)iwa.)

2. Choice. See hiwahiwa.

3. A term qualifying coconuts and kava; see niu, ʻawa.

4. See ʻAeʻae-a-hiwa.
Corpulent, fat. Cf. ʻāwaʻawaʻa 2.
Precious, beloved, esteemed, petted, darling, indulged; favorite. See ex., luxury.
An all-black pig with white hoofs and white tips of tail, ears, and nose.
Esteemed chief; beloved child or favorite; royal favorite.
Coal-black, entirely black, solid-black. (A puaʻa hiwa might have a few white hairs, but none at all were on a puaʻa hiwa paʻa.)

1. Skinny, bony, thin, angular. Cf. iwi.

2. Sharp ridge of a mountain. Cf. more common kuahiwi. (PNP siwi.)
Redup. and intensifier of hiwi 1.

1. To give, transfer, go (followed by directionals). (Hal. 15.5.) No caus/sim. derivation with hō has been noted. For the word often written hooho, see oho.

2. To wheeze, breathe hard.

3. Hoe, colter of a plow. Eng. Me kāna hō, a me kāna koʻilipi (1 Sam. 13.20, with his colter and his axe.
Marker of the caus/sim.; same as hoʻo-, but commonly found before words beginning with a glottal stop followed by a long vowel, as ʻāpuka, hoʻāpuka.
marker before glottal stop and short vowel or before long vowel or vowels, as ʻike, hōʻike, ʻā, hōʻā, hōʻāʻā. .

Marker of the caus/sim.; same as hoʻo-, but commonly found before words beginning with a- or e- (or sometimes i-), with lengthening of the first vowel of the word, as ano, hoʻāno; emi, hoʻēmi; inu, hoʻīnu, or before words beginning with a long vowel, as ō, hoʻō.
Marker of the caus/sim.; same as hoʻo-; occasionally found before words beginning with i-, as ikaika, hōʻikaika.

1. Companion, friend, associate, colleague, comrade, partner, mate, peer, fellow, antagonist (if followed by a word such as kaua or paio). Cf. hoahānau, hoa hele, hoaloha, hoa paio, and saying, cold 1.

2. To tie, bind, secure, rig; rigging, lashing. See hoa waʻa.

3. To strike with a stick or club; to club; a club.

4. Same as mamo 1, the honey-creeper.

See "hoʻohoa":  To challenge, dare, provoke; daring, defiant. Cf. uahoa. Hoʻohoa nā manu hanina, the quiet birds are daring. Hana ka iwi a kanaka makua, hoʻohoa mai, get maturity into the bones before issuing a challenge.

1. To set on fire, burn, ignite, etc. See ʻā 1.

2. To drive, as cattle or fish; to herd. See -ʻā.

3. To talk much. See ā 1.

4. See hōʻā īpuka hale.
See aʻa 1, root, vein, etc.
To kindle, light. See ʻaʻā 1.
To blunder, stray. See ʻāʻā, demented.
To kindle fire.
To clothe. See ʻaʻahu.
Eating or dinner companion.
Tenant, caretaker, as on a kuleana.
Surly. See ʻaʻaka 1.
Companion of a chief, fellow chief, chief descended from the god Kāne (For. 6:266). Fig., the gods.
Var. spelling of hoaloha.
To stare, etc. See ʻaʻā maka.
To boast, defy. See ʻaʻano.
See ʻaʻapu.

1. To make fine, soft. See ʻae 3.

2. To rise. See ʻae 4.
To break taboo. See ʻaʻe.
To cause to wander. See ʻaeʻa.
A chant with lengthened vowels. See aeae.
To braid. See ʻaha 2.
Same as ʻahaʻaha 2.
Fellow worker, colleague, partner, accomplice.
Cousin; brother or sister, as a church member.
Relative of one's own generation.
Schoolmate.
Traveling companion, fellow traveler. (In Iosua 14.8 “kou hoa hele” seems to be the Hawaiian translation of “my brethren.”)
To blame, condemn. See ʻāhewa.
See ahiahi, evening.
See aho, breath.
See ʻaho, thatch.
Redup. of hoa 3; a rounded tapa beater (also called hohoa, pepehi); rapid beating, striking, as of tapa or pandanus leaves; a stick beater for washing clothes. Fig., bad-tempered.

1. Redup. of hoaka 3–5.

2. Comb of a rooster.
Shipmate.
See ahonui.
To collect, pile. See ahu.
Associate.
Joining, suture, joint. Rare. Cf. hoa 2, and below.
To feed. See ʻai, food.
See ʻaiʻē.

See -ʻailona.
Sign or emblem of victory. See -ʻailona.
Temporal suture.
Coronal suture.
Sweetheart, mate, spouse.
Same as hoaka ʻīpuka hale.

1. Crescent; arch, as over door of ancient house (Kep. 101); crescent-shaped design at base of temple drum; crest, as on a helmet.

2. Second day of the month. (Kep. 101) (PCP (F,S)oata, cf. Easter oʻata.)

3. Brightness; shining, glittering, splendid; to glitter, shine, flash as lightning, become daylight; to flame. Fig., glory. Also ʻoaka.

4. To cast a shadow; to brandish, as a spear (2 Sam. 23.18), to drive away, ward off, frighten. Cf. aka 1.

5. To open, as the mouth. (Hoik. 13.6.)

6. Spirit, apparition, ghost (For. 6:370).

7. Disease of the abdomen, perhaps appendicitis, rupture (followed by a qualifier). See hoaka ʻīpuka hale, hoaka kākala. Other qualifiers reported are hāwele, kū, kū kahi, kū lua.
See ʻaka, to laugh.
To clarify. See akaaka, clear.

See ʻakaʻaka, to laugh.
See akahele.

A disease (ruptured appendix?).

1. Canoe companion, mate.

A kind of hoʻawa (Pittosporum kauaiense), a tree to 12 m high, found only on Kauaʻi, with large leaves to 25 by 8 cm, more or less downy beneath, and with quadrangular fruits 1.3 cm in diameter.

To carry. See ʻawe, pack, burden.

1. Bitter yam (Dioscorea bulbifera, synonym D. sativa), a vine with cylindrical stem, heart-shaped leaves, small tuberous root, round aerial tubers. The tubers, used only in times of famine, need long washing to make them fit to eat. (HP 167, Neal 230.) Called piʻoi on Kauaʻi.

2. Same as hoihoi.

1. To leave, go or come back; to cause to come back. Cf. hoʻi hou.

2. To enter, as an institution or last resting place.

3. A parting chant to which hula dancers dance as they leave the audience.

5. intensifying preceding base. See kāhoʻi, nohoʻi.

6. Also, too, besides.

7. expressing doubt, uncertainty.

To go back, return, retreat, revert, backslide, deteriorate morally. (In Ier. 3.22 hoʻi hope seems to be the translation of “faithless” and “faithlessness” and in Ier. 6.28 the translation of “revolter.”) Poʻe lālā hoʻi hope, backsliding members [of a church].

altitudes (HP 214, Neal 25.) Cf. pohole, the Maui name.

2. See ʻiʻo 1.

Night of the full moon. When this moon set before daylight it was called Hoku Palemo, Hoku that slips away. When it set after daylight it was called Hoku Ili, grounded Hoku. (Malo 32.) Cf. hōkū, star.
See "Hoʻohoku-i-ka-lani":  n. Name of the daughter of Wākea and Papa. Hoku may be compared to Tahitian hotu, to produce fruit and Tongan fotu, to appear.
Star.

1. A small native tree (Ochrosia compta) related to the hao (Rauvolfia) and closely resembling it, but the leaves thicker, the yellow flowers fragrant, and the twinned fruits yellow and much larger. Formerly, bark and roots yielded a yellow dye for tapa. (Neal 691.)

2. Tapa dyed with hōlei; to dye thus.

3. An introduced yellow dotted cloth.

4. A variety of sweet potato.

1. Same as hōliʻoliʻo

8. Diagonal pole or strut attached to the inner side of the roof framework and extending obliquely from the upper end of a rafter at one corner to the lower end of the rafter at the other corner.

9. Loss of a pebble in the kōnane game. (For. 4:57.)

10. Hall. Eng.

See homeopakika

Bay, gulch, valley (as a part of place names such as Honolulu, Honokōhau, Honoliʻi, Honomanu; also in the poetic phrase nā Honō a Piʻi-lani, the bays beginning with Hono- of Piʻi-lani [a chief who ruled the bays on Maui, Molokaʻi, and Lā-naʻi that were visible from Lahaina].

var. for -hūnōai.

Wild spiderflower (Gynandropsis gynandra), a cosmopolitan tropical hairy annual weed, native to Africa, in the caper family, 30 to 90 cm high, leaves five-parted; flowers spider-like, white with a purple tinge; fruit narrow, cylindrical capsule with many seeds. (Neal 369.) Also ʻiliʻohu.

1. Short for honohono kukui.

2. The wandering Jew or dayflower (Commelina diffusa), known in many temperate and tropical countries, a creeping weed, rooting at the joints, and bearing grasslike, ovate leaves and small bright-blue flowers. (Neal 185.) Also honohono wai, and mākolokolo. Cf. honohono ʻula.

3. A very rare native mint (Haplostachys haplostachya), a downy erect herb with oblong or narrower leaves and white flowers. (Neal 732.)

4. See ʻokika honohono.

5. Same as hohono, bad-smelling.

6. A children's game; the child locked fingers of two hands and thrust them into the sand, letting the sand out through a small opening.
The basket grass (Oplismenus hirtellus), a creeping grass that originated in America, called kukui because it is often found under kukui trees. Also honohono maoli. (Neal 73–4.)
A variety of honohono.
Same as honohono kukui.
Wandering Jew or zebrina, an ornamental, now naturalized, native to Mexico (Zebrina pendula). (Neal 183–4.)
Same as honohono 2.

1. Land, earth, world; background, as of quilt designs; basic, at the foundation, fundamental. See lani.

1. A game in which player and opponent sat with legs crossed and tried to unseat each other; to play this game. (For. 4:35.)

1. A very active former of caus/sim. derivatives; see .

2. Causation and transitivization, as pono, correct; hoʻoponopono, to correct.

3. Pretense, as kuli, deaf; hoʻokuli, to feign deafness.

4. Similarity, as kamaliʻi, children; hoʻoka maliʻi, childish.

5. No meaning, as kāholoholo, to hurry; hoʻokāholoholo, to hurry. The meanings of some hoʻo- derivatives are quite different from the meanings of the stems, as maikaʻi, good; hoʻomaikaʻi, to congratulate.

A perennial herb (Lagenophora maviensis), found only in marshy high parts of West Maui. The leaves form a basal rosette, from which rises a stalk bearing a round daisy-like flower head with yellow center and white rays.

1. To rise or swell, as yeast or souring poi; to ferment, leaven, overflow (Isa. 8.7), percolate, effervesce, boil over; to surge or rise to the surface, as emotion; to gush forth; rising, swelling, outburst. Cf. huaʻi.

2. To roar, grunt, hum, whistle; huh (interj.)! Hū ka makani, the wind whistles or roars [of things going at great speed].

3. A spinning top.

4. To depart from the proper course, miss the way.

5. Gum, as of the ʻōlapa tree.

6. Commoners as a mass.

7. Var. of hui 2, to unite, join.

1. Fruit, tuber, egg, produce, yield, ovum, seed, grain, offspring; meat as in ʻopihi shell or ʻalamihi crab; to bear fruit, tuber or seed; to bear a child; fruitful. For kinds of eggs, see hua ʻaluʻalu, huamakani, hua moa.

2. Round object, as pill or bead. Cf. huaale.

3. Result, effect; credit, as for a university course.

4. Testicles, Ka hele ā pala nā hua i ka moana, testicles rot at sea [a sailor lacks a sex partner].

5. Same as huahua 3, a vulgar gesture.

6. Word, letter, figure, watchword, rallying cry, note in music; winning word in the Chinese gambling game of chee-fah; type; to speak. Cf. hua helu, hua ʻōlelo.

7. Name of the thirteenth night of the lunar month. (Malo 35.) (PEP (f,s)ua.) Kapu Hua, monthly taboo nights of Mōhalu and Hua.

8. Name of a star

9. The bulging of the broadest part of a paddle blade.

10. See pai hua.

11. See paʻi hua.

A small native naupaka (Scaevola kilaueae) found only on dry lava near Kī-lau-ea Volcano. It does not exceed a height of 80 cm, has narrow, thick leaves, dull-yellow flowers, and small black fruits that were used to dye tapa. Also papaʻahekili. (Neal 819–20.)

The red sandalwood tree (Adenanthera pavonina), from parts of tropical Asia and Malaysia, of moderate height and with rather widespreading branches. The tree is planted in parks, and its round, lens-shaped, red seeds are used for leis, and their long, yellow-lined pods for decorative arrangements. (Neal 414.)

1. Gourd, water calabash, any narrow-necked vessel for holding water, flask. Cf. ipu, pōhue.

2. Quick, as in stealing or deception; light-fingered; to steal, filch, move fast; to work the rope fast in skipping rope; theft (rare). Cf. ʻaihue. (Probably PPN fue.)

3. A type of hula dancing, usually at the end of a program, a kind of ʻai ʻami with a revolving of the hips as fast as the drummer can beat time, to see who can dance longest; to dance thus.

4. A way of connecting net sections by, interlocking meshes.

For hulas named for instruments see ʻiliʻili, kāʻekeʻeke, kā lāʻau, pahu, pā ipu, papa hehi, pūʻili, ʻulīʻulī. For hulas named for creatures see below or honu, ʻīlio, kōlea, manō, peʻepeʻemakawalu, puaʻa.

The punch (kuʻi) hula of Molokaʻi, an ancient, fast dance with stamping, heel twisting, thigh slapping, dipping of knees, doubling of fists as in boxing, vigorous gestures imitative of such pursuits as dragging fish nets, and unaccompanied by instruments. This dance originated on Molokaʻi, an island famous for sports. Many of the songs contain taunts, as a laʻa kō kū i ke aʻu, now you are jabbed by the swordfish. Cf. hula kuʻi under kuʻi, joined.
Sitting chant dance; the performer beats the gourd drum (ipu) and chants. Also pā ipū.
Name of hulas performed for the coronation of Ka-lākaua, probably slick hulas.

1. Shining, glittering, glossy, slippery; to shine, glitter, sparkle, reflect light. Cf. ali, lali.

2. A kind of loli, sea cucumber. Also kūnounou.

1. Redup. and intensification of hulali 1.

2. Same as hulali 2.
Dance with a thin flexible stick which the squatting dancer beats time as by striking the floor.
Sitting dance imitative of sharks..

Name of hulas performed for Kalā-kaua's coronation.
To praise extravagantly, gush.
Any sitting hula; to perform such.

Name of hulas performed for Kalā-kaua's coronation.

Name of chest-slapping hulas performed for Ka-lā-kaua's coronation.
Dance in which the dancers use the papa hehi, treadle boards; this dance is said to have originated on Niʻihau.

Sacred dance in honor of the goddess Pele.

To lift, raise, draw up, as a skirt; to pull, pry; to pitch and toss, as a ship on the waves; to move along, as a ship; to flap wings; to trot, as a horse. Cf. 
papa hulei.

Intensifier of hulei; to toss and pitch, trot, swing.

A green, velvety, carpet-like mountain moss. The spore cases rise above the plants. Lit., fur like a dog's.

1. A kind of bag fish net; to drag such a net. Also huli, papa hului.

2. To take or grab, as winnings.

1. A fine, red seaweed (Centroceras clavulatum), forming short, dense, regularly branching tufts, with tiny forked tips; not edible. Also hulu, pūhuluhulu, wāwaeʻiole. Lit., dog fur.

2. Fine, branching, edible brown seaweeds (Ectocarpus spp.), forming short, olive-brown clumps.

3. A fine, branching, green seaweed (Cladophora nitida), forming flexible, long, bright-green tufts; said to be edible.

4. A fine, feathery, green, fresh-water alga (Stigeoclonium amoenum), found in streams and ditches; said to be edible.

5. A fine, unbranched, green seaweed (Chaetomorpha antennina), looking much like 3 above. Also ʻīlio, nahawele.

6. A fine, nonedible, brown seaweed (Sphacelaria tribuloides), densely tufted, shorter and darker brown than Ectocarpus.

7. Some kinds of Polysiphonia seaweeds.
Same as wāwaeʻiole, a plant.
A pig that is reddish-colored about the hams. (Malo 37). Lit., ʻiwi bird feather.

A kind of grass.
Long tail feathers, as of a rooster.

1. Bird feathers.

2. Green seaweeds (Caulerpa spp.), growing like land plants, with roots, prostrate stems, and leaflike divided fronds; not edible. Also ʻai-a-ka-honu, hulu moa, līmoa.

3. Court favorites of Ka-mehameha III.

The Hawaiian mistletoes (Korthalsella spp. formerly called Viscum), small plants perching on trees and extracting part of their food from them. They have flat or cylindrical jointed green stems. (Neal 324–5). Lit., chicken feathers. Also kaumahana.
Same as hulu manu 2.

A moss said to grow only in Pālolo Valley, Honolulu, named for Kaʻau-hele-moa, a legendary cock defeated in battle by a hen. She pulled out his feathers, which fell and became this moss. It is used in leis.
Light brown, bay, as a horse.
Paintbrush.
var.
Body hair, animal hair, or feathers standing on end.
Beard hanging from the breast of mature turkey males. Lit., hog hair.

A small, matted, red seaweed (Spyridia spinella), its many branches covered with short bristles. It is rather common in shallow water near shore. It is eaten in South Hawaiʻi, but not generally elsewhere.
Same as huluhulu waena.
Downy feathers or beard, fuzz.
To bind about the loins, as a malo; to put on a malo; to wear a sanitary napkin.
Pas/imp. of hume.
Redup. of hume.
A girding on of a loincloth; part of the loins covered by the malo.

1. To sew, stitch; seam, stich; to bind together parts of a fishhook; to bind, as a book.

2. Hole by which parts of a hook were bound together.

3. The star Altair, in Aquila, said to have been used for navigation from Hawaiʻi to Tahiti. Also Hoʻohumu. (PNP Sumu).

4. Short for paehumu, taboo enclosure.
Back stitching; to sew with back stiching.

1. Redup. of humu; to sew, of many or continuously.

2. Trigger fish. The name humuhumu is qualified by the following terms (in addition to those listed separately as identified): kapa or kapu, lei, māneʻoneʻo (said to be irritating to the mouth), ʻuwīʻuwī (thought by some to be the young of the māneʻoneʻo)..

3. A variety of taro with coloring like that of the humuhumu (fish); the leaf stem is pink at base, dark-purple midway and green above. (HP 18, 32).

4. A dark-colored birthmark, 
believed to be the result of the pregnant mother's eating humuhumu (fish).

5. To destroy, ravage.

6. Seam. See komo humuhumu.
Black triggerfish (Melichthys niger), used as fuel when fuel was scarce.
Pinktail durgon (Melichthys vidua). Lit., red-tailed triggerfish.
Lei triggerfish (Sufflamen bursa).
Same as humuhumu-nuku-nuku-ā-puaʻa. (And.)
Bridled triggerfish (Sufflamen fraenatus). Lit., urine triggerfish, so called because of its odor.
Varieties of humuhumu (Rhinecanthus aculeatus, R. rectangulus). Lit., humuhumu with a snout like a pig.
Bookbinding.
Cloth bookbinding.
Paper bookbinding.
To darn, as socks.
Same as humuhumu hiʻu kole.
A variety of humuhumu fish (Balistes bursa). Lit., humuhumu with leis on its chest.
Cross-stitching; to do cross-stitching.
Same as humu hoʻoholoholo.
Chain stitch; to make chain stitches.
To sew in a diagonal line.
To embroider.
Name for the cluster of three stars in a row in the constellation Aquila. Lit., Humu and companions.
Sewing, seam.
Pattern in pāwehe plaiting, said to consist of a continuous row of red lozenges with their lateral angles touching.
Stitch used in tacking.
Lock stitch, a stitch that does not loosen easily; to sew thus.
To sew to a backing, as feather leis.
Sail-making; to sew sails.
Buttonhole stitch.

1. Red jasper stone, as used for adzes.

2. Name of a place on the slopes of Mauna Kea.
Overcasting stitch; to hem.

1. Minute particle, grain, crumb, gram, speck, tiny bit, scrap, minutia; small, little, powdery. (This word is similar to hune 2.) Cf. hunaahi, huna kai, huna kaua, huna lepo, hunalewa, huna olonā.

2. Hidden secret; hidden. Cf. huna, a stative usually following nouns, and the transitive verb hūnā.

3. Eleventh night of the month. (Malo 35.)

4. Common, fine, red seaweeds (Hypnea spp.), irregularly and more or less densely branching, thorny looking; eaten cooked, furnishes a good colloid when boiled.
To hide, conceal, disguise, secrete; confidential; covert. Cf. huna 2, peʻe 1.
Fire spark, live cinder. (Isa. 1.31.)
Fragments, particles, crumbs, scraps.
Redup. of hūnā; to hide frequently or be hidden by many persons; secretly.
A particle, as ua, e, i in Hawaiian.

1. White-flowered beach morning-glory (Ipomea stolonifera; synonym, I. acetosaefolia), distributed in tropical regions, with oblong to lyre-shaped leaves, and white flowers with yellow centers. (Neal 705.)

2. Sanderling (Calidris alba), a small winter migrant to Hawaiʻi, cinnamon brown with dark markings. Lit., sea foam, so called from the bird's habit of following close behind receding waves.
Sea spray, sea foam, Also hune kai.
Hungary; Hungarian. Eng.
See Hunakalia
A kind of tapa with white and yellow dots.
A battle unit, either a single individual or a group of men; host of an army (Iosua 10.5).
To hide in secret, as the body of a loved one in a secret cave; to keep a secret, conceal.
Dust particle.
Van of an army, front ranks. Cf. hunapaʻa.
Waste and refuse of olonā after the fiber is cleaned.
Rear guard of an army.
A species of Hypnea, a seaweed. Lit., brittle huna.
Same as pai, a native fern.
Drop of water, spray, mist.
Spray from a waterfall.

1. Poor, destitute; a poor person. Cf. ʻilihune, māhune.

2. Fine, tiny. Cf. huna, kilihune, Menehune.

See "hoʻohune":  To persist, nag, tease; to do with avidity and persistence. See ex., nē 1. Koi hoʻohune (Nak. 101), keep asking. He mea hoʻohune loa ka iʻa i ka makani hou, the fish are constantly going into the fresh wind.

1. Redup. and intensification of hune 2, very fine, delicate.

2. Bits, as of news, gossip; minutia.

3. Same as huna, a seaweed.
Sea spray, sea foam. Also huna kai.
Fine-grained sand, sand particles.
Relationship between parent- and child-in-law. See hūnōna, -hūnōai. (PNP funo.)
Father- or mother-in-law, usually after makua and followed by kāne or wahine for specific designation of sex. These terms apply also to uncle and aunt by marriage. (PCP fungawai.)
Son- or daughter-in-law, followed by kāne or wahine for specific designation of sex. These apply to nephew or niece by marriage.
Lumpy, coarse, as of certain skin diseases; humped; lumps.
Name of an unidentified star.
Suspicion. Rare.
Gum of the ʻōlapa tree, formerly used for embalming.
Unfermented, unleavened.
Unpalatable ferment.
Hoop. Eng. Ka hupa pahu, the barrel hoop.
Small bulging upper part of a gourd.
To draw together.
Mucus from the nose. Also ʻūpē.

1. Ambergris.

2. A variety of seaweed.
Running nose; to sniffle; snotty.
To squeeze, as to remove water; to wring. Rare. Also ʻuwī.
A kind of pilo 3.
Ignorant, foolish, unintelligent, stupid; fool foolishness. Lit., swelling darkness.
Name for one with one kauwā (outcast) parent.
Hypocrite (early used by translators of the New Testament, but replaced in later editions by hoʻokamani).
Collection; catch, as of fish. (This rare word is not clear.
Var. spelling of huā.
Var. spelling of hūai 1, 2.

1. marking direct and indirect object, agent, source (indefinite), instrument, causation. To, towards, at, in, on, by, because of, for, due to, by means of. (After loaʻa-type words i marks the agent. Before pronouns, the interrogative wai, who, names of people, and sometimes before names of places and titles of songs or stories, i is replaced by iā.)

2. preceding subordinate verbs and marking completed or past action and state or condition; sometimes the anaphoric ai follows the verb or verb phrase. (PCP i.)

3. preceding subordinate verbs and marking imperative/exhortative mood and purpose.

4. If.

5. While, at the time that, when, no sooner than, as soon as (replaced by iā in the same contexts as i 1).
Transitivizer suffix. Cf. haui, kālai, minoi.
Transitivizer suffix. Cf. panaʻi, pukuʻi,

1. To say, speak, suppose; saying.

2. Supreme, great, best (frequently a part of names, as Kaʻī-i-mamao (KL. title), the supreme one at a distance; ʻĪ-lālā-ʻole, supreme without branches).

3. Hard, close, stingy. Cf. ʻīʻī 1.

4. of scorn, used idiomatically.

5. The letter “i”.

1. . He, she, it. Cf. ʻoia, ʻo … ia.

2. This, that, aforementioned.
Pas/imp. Cf. malaia. .

1. Yard (unit of measure). Eng. Iā paʻaʻili ono, cubic yard.

2. Yard (spar on a sailing vessel). Eng.

3. replacing i 1, 5, and sometimes used before kai, uka, ʻō, neʻi, and after mai; coalescing with aʻu (iaʻu) and joined to ia (iāia), and usually joined to ʻoe (iāʻoe).
marking pas/imp. (sometimes written as a part of modified word).

1. Fish or any marine animal, as eel, oyster, crab, whale.

2. Meat or any flesh food.

3. Any food eaten as a relish with the staple (poi, taro, sweet potato, breadfruit), including meat, vegetable, or even salt. Also ʻīnaʻi.

4. Milky Way.
. The one there, you. Also iala.
See aha.
Fast pronunciation of i aha ai, sometimes written i ahaʻi. See aha.
Pearl oyster, once numerous at Pearl Harbor. Lit., sea creature that silences the voice, so called for a taboo of silence maintained by fishermen there.
Name of a stroke in lua fighting. Lit., fish touching skin of man.
Particles indicating completed aspect or state or condition and accompanying subordinate verbs; this ai is the anaphoric ai. .

1. Him, her; to him, to her; because of or due to him or her (the particle iā and ia, he, her; see i 1).

2. While he or she, as soon as he or she, at the time that he or she (the particle iā and ia, he, she; see i 5).
Name of a wind at Wai-luku, Maui, at Hoʻolehua, Molokaʻi (For. 5:101), and at Hāna, Maui. Lit., little fish.
Fish or relish eaten after kava. (For. 6:503.) Usually called pūpū.
Yak. Eng.
Jackass. Eng. See donkey.
Jackal. Eng.
Jasper. (Puk. 28.2O.) Eng.

1. Outrigger boom.

2. num. Forty, as in counting tapas, canoes, or feathers.
Run or school of fish.
Jaguar. Eng.

Ozena, a discharge of fetid matter from the nostril accompanied by vile smell; if a pregnant woman strung out fish (iʻa kui) to dry, it was believed that if some of the fish spoiled, her future offspring would acquire the affliction. Also ihu kilu, ihu pilau.
Same as ia ala. See ex., kīkoʻo.
Milky Way. Lit., fish jumping in shadows.

1. Embalmed body, mummy; to embalm, stuff.

Jamaica. Eng.
To jump into water from a height, feet first, without causing a splash. Also ʻiomo.
Ostrich (RSV), owl (KJV). (Isa. 13.21.)
. This person, he, she (after ʻo, subject marker; ). Cf. eia nei.

January. Eng.

1. Silversides (Pranesus insularum), a fish 5 to 8 cm long, in shallow pools, used as bait for such fish as aku. Also ʻiʻiao, ʻiomo.

2. Name of Jupiter appearing as the morning star; fig., dawn.

3. Valley and peak, West Maui.

4. A bird said to resemble the moho (no data).
An introduced fish (Ophiocephalus striatus) found in rice or taro patches and streams. Lit., Chinese fish.
Japan. Eng. Cf. Kepanī.

1. .

2. Me, to me; because of or due to me (the particle iā and aʻu, me; see i 1).

3. While I, at the time that I, when I, as soon as I, no sooner than I (the particle iā and aʻu, me; see i 5).
Goldfish (Carassius auratus), introduced from China or Japan in the time of Ka-ʻahu-manu. Lit., red fish.

Java. Eng.

Same as ʻiewe.
Tapa beater. For types of beaters, see Buck 169–79 and pepehi 2 and ho ʻopaʻi. A beater with a smooth surface was used finally (hoʻōki) to smooth out the cloth.

1. Aerial root of the ʻieʻie vine; the vine itself.

2. A woven basket.

3. A flat, plaited braid as used in hats; braided.

4. Wicker.

5. Name for fish traps, combined with the name of the fish, as ʻie kala, ʻie palani.

6. Same as ʻieʻie 3.

7. Canvas, cotton, linen. Rare.

8. Corduroy. Rare.
Jehovah. (Heb.

1. An endemic woody, branching climber (Freycinetia arborea) growing luxuriantly in forests at altitudes of about 300 to 600 m. The ringed stems end in tufts of long, narrow, spiny leaves, in the center of which flowers are borne on cylindrical spikes surrounded by leafy bracts, which are orange or green with orange bases. (Neal 54.) ʻIeʻie was one of five plants used on the hula altar (see palai). Also ʻie. (PNP kiekie.)

2. A native variety of taro with leaf blades and flowers suggesting ʻieʻie 1; the leaves are dark and glossy, the petioles reddish with yellow-green stripes. (HP 18, 32.)

3. High, conceited.
Barbed, as a hook; barb.
Rare. var. of ʻiewe.
Kind of brown tapa made at Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi. Lit., tapa beater with ridges of long stripes.
Jesuit. Eng.

See Iēkuiko
Tapa beater.
Tapa beater, as used to finish the tapa. Lit., finishing-beating mallet.
Fish-trap basket made of ʻie vine. Lit., portable ʻie.
pejorative suffix. Rare. See lōiele, luaiele, luluaiele, maiele, noiele.
Person of distinction, chief. (And.) Cf. ʻī, supreme.
Jerusalem. Eng.

Wastebasket.
Breadbasket.
Jesus. (Probably Heb.

inter. Where (indefinite), why, why not.

1. One of several halfbeaks (Hemirampus depauperatus).

1. Sacred, holy, majestic, dignified; treated with reverence or respect.

2. Wood sorrels (Oxalis, all species), perennial weedy herbs, creeping or not, and bearing cloverlike leaves and yellow, white, red, or pink bell-shaped flowers. The plants have a pleasant sour taste due to oxalic acid. (Neal 473–4.) Known to some as Portulaca spp.

3. See hue wai ʻihi.
A kind of ʻihi (Oxalis corniculata). (Neal 473.) Lit., edible ʻihi.
Same as holomoku 2. (Kam. 76:10.)
Same as ʻihi ʻai.
Storm accompanied by much thunder and lightning, and an epithet for the gods of thunder and lightning. Lit., stormy sacred ones.
To neigh, whinny.

1. Redup. of ʻihi 1; revered.

2. An unknown plant formerly growing at ʻIhiʻihi-lau-ākea, the western side of Hanauma Bay, Oʻahu.
Same as ihihī.
A mustard plant, Coronopus didymus.
Same as kūkaehipa, spiny bur (Acanthospermum australe). (Neal 837.) Also pipili 3.
Same as pāʻihi, a weed related to watercress.
A weedy sorrel. (Oxalis sp.).
See "Marsilea villosa": . Lit., medicinal sorrel. Niʻihau.
Heavenly splendor; sacredness of a chief; reverence due a chief.
Small, long-necked gourd as used for holding water.
Same as ʻihi mākole.
A creeping variety of ʻihi with red stems (differing in this from ʻihi ʻawa), yellow flowers, and no bulbs; used medicinally. Lit., red-eyed ʻihi. Also ʻihi maka ʻula.
A kind of sorrel (Oxalis martiana) with large leaves, pink flowers, bulbous scaly root, used medicinally. (Neal 473.)
Shamrock. Lit., white-flowering Oxalis.

1. To go down, descend; downhill, towards the sea; to subside; go south or before the wind; descent.

2. Core, as of an apple, breadfruit, or pandanus; cob, as or corn; heart, as of celery: spongy white growth in the center of a sprouted coconut, sometimes called coconut sponge (cf. lolo niu); pith, spadix; flesh of the octopus after the skin is removed; axis, as of the earth; axle, as of a wheel.

3. Collective terms for inner layers of white sleeping tapas below the kilohana.

4. Block used in plaiting a hat to give shape to the crown. Also pahu pāpale.

5. Battery, electric plug.

6. directionial. Down, below. (Table 12, ).

7. Same part. and reference as above but with reflexive meaning, often following words describing activities of the body, as eating, drinking, thinking.

8. Same part. and reference as above, with meaning “self” personally.

9. Same part. and reference as iho 6–8, but used with words of time, usually present or future, but past if followed by nei.
See "hoʻoiho, hoʻīho":  Besides that, also, furthermore, He kanaka waiwai ʻoia, a hoʻīho nō, he wahine waiwai kāna, he is a rich man and, besides that, has a rich wife.
Canoe paddler.
Wheel axis.

1. Redup. of iho 1.

2. Candle, torch.

3. Heart or heavy core of a tree.

Kukui-nut candle; candle.
Corn cob.
Directional and reflexive pair.

A favorite and common native variety of banana, eaten raw or cooked. The fruit bunches are small, the skin thin, ripening yellow, the flesh salmonpink. (HP 115). This was one of the few bananas permitted women. Also hilahila. Lit., yellow core.
Descent, incline.
See hope.
Descent of water, as a stream.

1. Nose, snout, beak, bill, trunk of air elephant, toe of a shoe; a kiss. Often qualified, as with the following: ʻami, irregular-shaped bridge; kikiwi, hooked; kū, piʻi, tilted (fig., haughty); lapalapa, highbridged; mamana, mene, papa, pepe, ʻū, broad and flat; manana, distended, of nostrils; meumeu, snub; nanā, snarling (fig., quarrelsome); winiwini, sharp. See ex., kaninonino and sayings, mau 1, maʻu 1.

2. Prow or bow of a canoe or ship.

3. Thick end of pearl-shell shank.
Name of an odoriferous tree or shrub.
Name of a wind blowing down from the uplands of Ka-wela, Oʻahu. Lit., cold nose.
To wrinkle up the nose, as to show scorn.
Dirty nose, a disparaging epithet.
To snore or speak with nasalized sounds.
Rising upward, as the prow of a canoe. Fig., scornful.
Toe of shoes.
Same as kilu 3 and iʻakui.
Name reported for a Hawaiian star, although it may be a general term for any guiding star standing (kū) above the bow (ihu) of a canoe.
Tilted nose, pug nose. Fig., haughty, snobbish, snooty, contemptuous.
Disobedient, impudent.
Name of a star.
To snore with prolonged sounds; such snoring. Lit., moaning nose.

1. Large nose.

2. Canoe with a large bow, hollowed from the large end of a log instead of from the butt end, as was customary. (Malo 131, 135).

1. Deadly stroke in lua fighting. Lit., nose of the pig.

3. See ihu 1.
Possibly a syphilitic saddlenose or damage from leprosy. (Kam. 64:115). Lit., no nose.

Expert, wise person, wisdom. Lit., closed nose, perhaps referring to deep diving and hence profound knowledge. Cf. ihu pōhue.
Scab nose, an insulting term for a lunkhead.
To breathe with difficulty due to partial obstruction of the nostrils, as of one with a cold. See pī 2.
Elevated nose, Fig., scornful, haughty, aloof, contemptuous, disdainful, snobbish, snooty.
Same as iʻakui.
Gourd nose, said of one with superficial knowledge or lack of skill, perhaps so called because one floats like a gourd rather than descends to the depths of knowledge (ihupani).
A variety of rarely cultivated bunana, wild in forests of Kauaʻi and Hawaiʻi, with short, slender green trunk, and yellow fruit with yellow flesh, edible only when cooked. (HP 175).
Snub-nosed.
Bow of a canoe, bowsprit.
Bristling, dishevelled (follows hulu, huhulu, huluhulu).

1. Small, stunted, undersized, dwarf.

2. Admired deep, rasping sound in chanting; tremor; guttural quality of some sounds, as back vowels or strongly aspirated “h”.

3. Same as ʻiʻini.

4. To gather, collect.

5. Short for hāpuʻu ʻiʻi 1, 2, ferns; ʻamaʻu ʻiʻi, a fern; pala ʻiʻi, a taro.

7. Same as ʻapapane, a bird.

1. Intensification of ʻiʻi 1, small, tiny.

To restrain, choke back; to groan, as with exertion.
Contracted, drawn, as facial features; wincing, as in pain; to contract, wince, shrivel, as octopus that writhes or turns while being broiled.
To see well; observant; to recognize and accost in a friendly way.
To seek again and again; one seeking everywhere, as for knowledge. Cf. ʻimi, ʻimiʻimi.
To blink. Cf. ʻimo, ʻimoʻimo.

To desire, crave, yearn for, wish; desire, liking.

1. Scarlet Hawaiian honey creeper (Vestiaria coccinea), found on all the main islands; its feathers were used extensively in feather work. Also ʻiwi, ʻiʻiwi pōlena, olokele. Cf. also ʻiʻiwi pōpolo and kikiwi.

2. Same as the honey creeper called ʻakialoa on Oʻahu (Hemignathus obscurus ellisianus).
Cape honeysuckle (Tecomaria capensis), a climbing shrub bearing narrow, curved, tubular, scarlet flowers and fernlike leaves (Neal 765), introduced to Kaʻū by George Jones.
Same as ʻiʻiwi 1.
Immature, greenish-yellow, blackspotted stage of the ʻiʻiwi bird, Lit., pōpolo berry honey creeper.
Strong. Cf. ikaika, lima ika.

1. To drift upon, strike against; to turn aside from a straight course; flotsam and jetsam.

Small, little, slightly; a little, trifle; not at all (with a negative). Cf. ʻauiiki.

1. Noisy, clamorous, loud-voiced; to make a din; din, clamor; voices of the gods in the elements.

2. Month of the Hawaiian year, named, according to Kepelino, for the roar of surf, thunder, and cloudbursts of this month. (Kep. 95.) ʻO ʻIkuwā i pohā kōʻeleʻele, ʻikuwā ke kai, ʻikuwā ka hekili, ʻikuwā ka manu, ʻIkuwā is the month when dark storms arise, sea roars, thunder roars, birds roar.

Var. of ukuwai; visiting place in a grass house.

1. A dark birthmark.

A variety of taro.
A skin or complexion prone to infection. Lit., corrosive skin. Cf. ʻili ʻawa.

1. All Hawaiian kinds of sandalwood (Santalum spp.), shrubs and trees, with fragrant heart wood, small pale-green or gray-green leaves, small, dull-red or greenish flowers, and small purple fruits. From about 1790 to 1830 sandalwood trees were cut and exported to China. (Neal 325–6.) Also ʻaoa.

2. One whose clothes wear out fast, as due to carelessness.
A fiery surface.
A small shrubby form of Hawaiian sandalwood (Santalum ellipticum), found rarely and near the beach. (Neal 325.)
Land inheritance

1. Land area.

2. An ʻili land division whose chief pays tribute to the chief of the ahupuaʻa of which it is a part, rather than directly to the king. Cf. ʻili kūpono.

An endemic woody plant (Wilkesia gymnoxiphium), related to the ʻāhinahina or silversword, found only in western mountains of Kauaʻi. It is 1 to 4 m high, unbranched, the stems ending in clumps of long narrow leaves. (Neal 845.) See ex., pūʻolo.
Skin not easily bruised or infected; one with such a skin is said to emit an acrid (ʻawa) odor; a strong-smelling fish caught by him (as pualu or palani) is said to become more offensive in odor.

Wild plumbago (Plumbago zeylanica), a native of tropics of the Eastern Hemisphere to Hawaiʻi, a shrub with white tubular flowers and thin, oval leaves that were used medicinally; the sap was used to blacken tattoo marks. (Neal 667.) Also ʻiliheʻe, hilieʻe; lauhihi on Niʻihau.
Contagious skin disease.
Black kōnane stone.
Bark of the hau tree, as used for rope and for modern grass skirts.
Same as ʻilieʻe.
Unsystematic or unskilled in farming, working spasmodically. (And.)

1. Pas/imp. of ili; to have gone aground.

2. Stricken with awe, reverence, dread (PH 33); overcome, thrilled, as by beauty.
A kind of haʻiwale (Cyrtandra begoniaefolia), on East Maui, having unequal heart-shaped leaves.
Patent leather. Lit., shiny leather.
Same as ʻilihelo.
Leather; fur, as about the neck.
Surface of the earth.
Poor, destitute; poverty, poor person. Lit., tiny skin.

1. Pebble, small stone, as used in dances or kōnane.

2. To pile, overlap.
Black kōnane pebble.
White kōnane pebble.

The birth pebbles of Kō-loa (a small section of the beach at Puna-luʻu, Kaʻū), which were believed to reproduce themselves, the smooth nonporous ones being male, the porous ones female. These stones were best liked for the pebble hula.
Redup. of ilihia.
Gravel, small stones.
Harness.

1. Surface of the sea.

2. Horizontal.
Skin of kala, a fish, sometimes stretched over a coconut shell to form the top of the small pūniu, knee drum.
A bird (no data).
Corm immediately under the skirt, as of taro.

1. A skin that sounds, as used in drums.

2. Tough skin.

1. Fair skin, of Hawaiians less dark than ʻilikou. Cf. ʻilipuakea.

2. A varnish, as made of candlenut bark, ti root, banana stump, and other plants.

1. Indian (of America). Eng. Also ʻInikini.

1. Poverty-stricken, very poor, destitute; pauper (stronger than ʻilihune). Lit., bare skin.

2. Flesh of half-ripe coconut.

A nearly independent ʻili land division within an ahupuaʻa, paying tribute to the ruling chief and not to the chief of the ahupuaʻa. Transfer of the ahupuaʻa from one chief to another did not include the ʻili kūpono located within its boundaries. Also ʻilikū.
Tree bark.
Unexpected rain, as from a sunny sky; to rain thus.
Portion of an ʻili land division separated from the main part of the ʻili but considered a part of it. Also lele.
New skin, as over a sore; new bark.
Epidermis; outer bark.

1. Small to large native shrubs (all species of Sida, especially S. fallax), bearing yellow, orange, greenish, or dull-red flowers; some kinds strung for leis. The flowers last only a day and are so delicate that about 500 are needed for one lei. Fruits of maʻo (Abutilon grandifolium), when green and soft, are used with ʻilima leis, one fruit at each end of the lei; or the pale-green, cap-like calyx of the ʻilima flower is used. A mild laxative for babies is made by squeezing out the juice of flowers; this is called kanakamaikaʻi. The ʻilima was designated in 1923 by the Territorial Legislature as the flower of Oʻahu. It is related to the hibiscus. (Neal 552–3.) See songs, nōweo, pue 1; cf. ʻāpiki.

2. Area where ʻilima plants may grow.
Same as ʻili kea.
A rare ʻilima with bronze-red flowers, domesticated on Oʻahu. (Neal 553.) Lit., kukui candle ʻilima. Also kolikukui.
A kind of ʻilima.
Dark-red bark, especially of koa trees.
Dark-skinned.
A kind of ʻilima creeping on sand on which beach dodder (kaunaʻoa) grows. (Neal 533.) Lit., ʻilima standing on beach.
A wild form of ʻilima, not so often used for leis as ʻilima lei, the cultivated form. Lit., ʻilima standing on plains. Also ʻilima papa. (Neal 553.)
Domesticated form of ʻilima.
A wild ʻilima growing on old lava beds in Kaʻū, with small flowers; of medium height. (HP 213.)
A kind of ʻilima, probably same as ʻilima lei.
Callus, calloused skin, thick leather; calloused.
A domesticated ʻilima, light yellow in color.
Same as ʻilima kū kula.

1. Dog (brought to Hawaiʻi by early Polynesians, considered an ʻaumakua by some). Cf. ʻapowai, hula ʻīlio, nūkea, , Titcomb 1969, Hal. 22.16, Hoik. 22.15. Many types of dogs are listed below.

2. A generic term for foreign quadruped. See below and .

4. Tie beam in a house, brace that holds rafter to crossbeam.

5. A seaweed, same as some of the hulu ʻīlio 5.

Same as līpahapaha, pahapaha, sea lettuce (Ulva and related genera).

A variety of taro with large, thick, firm leaf blades. The corms are very large, with white flesh tinged with pink; good as table taro but not for poi; leaves good for lūʻau. Lit., tough hide. Also kalo Pākē.

1. Maggot, grub, worm; to creep, as worms, to be beset by maggots. Cf. kuailo.

1. Underground oven; food cooked in an imu. Also umu.

Lit., long oven [with idea that a long life would follow].

(sometimes pronounced ʻīnisinisi in songs). Same as ʻiniʻiniki.

1. (in fast speech often preceded by ke). n.

2. Name, term, title.

3. Namesake.

4. An affectionate term for affinal relatives, or in-laws of in-laws, or relatives usually not related by blood; inoa may be followed by a kinship term indicative of generation (as moʻopuna, kaikamahine, keiki, makua, kupuna), or of the common relative (as puluna, hūnōna.) A grandchild's spouse's relatives united by affection to the speaker might thus be called inoa moʻopuna. Similarly the cousins of a puluna (parents-in-law of an offspring) might be inoa puluna, and the cousins or in-laws of a parent might be inoa makua. The relationship might also extend to close family friends.

5. Name chant or song.
Esteemed name, especially of a chief. Lit., fragrant name.
See kapakapa 2.
See inoa 3.

Denomination, as in arithmetic.
Dream name, as a name for an infant believed received in a dream; it was thought that if such a name were not given, the child would be sickly or die.

A name given to a child by a supernatural voice, usually heard just before the child's birth; a voice name.

1. Hawaiian hawk (Buteo solitarius), an endemic and endangered hawk with dark and light color phases, confined to forests on the island of Hawaiʻi, where it is regarded by some as an ʻaumakua. The ʻio signified royalty because of its lofty flight, and hence occurs in such names as ʻIo-lani, royal hawk. Cf. ʻio mea, ʻio uli, māpumāpu, mio 1.

2. To twitter, chirp, peep; peeping.

3. To flee. (PEP kio; cf. Marquesan ʻiʻo.)

4. A round, light-colored bitter gourd (Lagenaria siceraria), about 30 cm in diameter. Cf. ipu.

5. Tag; a Hawaiian game similar to tag; to play these games.

6. Bundle or food package; loaded with such bundles. Cf. ʻio paʻakai.

7. One who announces the presence of a chief; herald.

8. Probably the name of a stroke in lua fighting; also a low stroke in club fighting (RC 59).

1. Flesh, meat, flesh and blood, muscle, sinew, essence, substance. Fig., a relative; heart or gist of a matter. Many compounds and phrases with ʻiʻo are listed below. For the fern hōʻiʻo see hōʻiʻo.

2. True, genuine, significant, real; really, truly, surely, actually; true worth. Cf. ʻoiaʻiʻo, hanaʻiʻo.

Meat.

Mousy, like a rat.
Brisk, spirited, lively, quick-tempered, angry.

1. The bottle gourd (Lagenaria siceraria, also L. vulgaris), a wide-spreading vine, with large-angled or lobed leaves, white, night blooming flowers, and smooth green and mottled or white fruits varying widely in shape and size. The plant is a native of tropical Asia or Africa. Hawaiians have long used gourds as receptacles, small gourds with thin walls to hold water or food, or for rattles for dances (the ipu has a fine tone, halfway between that of niu and laʻamia), larger ones with thin to thick walls to hold tapa and other articles or to serve as drums. Orientals cook and eat the white pulp of green fruits. Hawaiians have distinguished between a kind with bitter pulp, used medicinally, and a kind with nonbitter pulp. (Neal 812–3.) For gourds classified according to shape and color see hōkeo, hue, hulilau, kūkaeʻiwa, ʻolo, poʻokanaka. Cf. pule ipu.

2. The watermelon (Citrullus lanatus), a wide-spreading vine from tropical Africa, with large, lobed leaves and yellow flowers. It is grown for its edible fruits, which are round or oblong, green or green with light stripes, and full of sweet, juicy, rose-colored pulp surrounding flat, black seeds, The watermelon was introduced to Hawaiʻi about 1792 and thrived until the melon fly arrived about 1910. Among many varieties that were developed were three outstanding ones: ipu huluhulu, ipu poʻo kanaka, and ipu oloolo. Today watermelons are again cultivated successfully because the fruits are commonly wrapped in paper or cloth during early stages. (Neal 810–1.) Also ipu ʻai maka, ipu ʻai waha, ipu haole.

3. General name for vessel or container, as dish, mug, calabash, pot, cup, utensil, urn, bowl, basin, pipe.

4. Drum consisting of a single gourd or made of two large gourds of unequal size joined together. See ipu hula, ipu paʻi, ipu wai.

5. Crown of a hat.
Censer, vessel for burning incense. (Nah. 4.14.)

1. An edible melon

2. Calabash or vessel for food or food offering.
Watermelon, melon (Nah. 11.5). Lit., melon to eat raw. See ipu 2.
Scrap bowl, slop basin, refuse container.
Same as ipu ʻai maka. Lit., melon to eat in mouth.
Same as ipu huluhulu. Lit., ghost melon.

1. Cantaloupe melon (Cucumis melo var.

2. Container for perfume or other fragrant matter. Lit., fragrant gourd.
Washbasin; container of water for a bath.
Large gourd calabash in which food was offered to the ʻaumakua family gods.
A variety of gourd (Lagenaria siceraria) with bitter-tasting pulp, used medicinally. (Neal 812.) Its strong odor is eradicated by soaking in sea water.
See ipu ʻawa
A kind of introduced muskmelon (Cucumis melo).
Chamber pot.
See ipu hana lepo
Iron pot; kettle or saucepan of any sort, skillet, whether glass, aluminum, or enamel. Lit., iron container.
Watermelon. Lit., foreign gourd. See ipu 2.
Still, for distilling.
Gourd drum with a top section (heke).
Gourd drum consisting of a single gourd without a top section.
Same as hoehoe, gourd whistle.
Same as hōkiokio, gourd whistle. Also puʻa.
Gourd containing fisherman's gear and bait, or a traveler's possessions, Lit., traveling container.
Washbasin.
Finger bowl. Lit., container wash hand.
Boiler.
Sugar boiler.
Dance drum made of two gourds sewed together. Cf. ʻolo.
A variety of watermelon with a slightly fuzzy (huluhulu) skin, and with whitish or pale-pink pulp; it is edible but not greatly liked; it formerly grew wild at Kaʻū. Also ipu akua. (Neal 810.)
Meat dish; fleshpot (Puk. 16.3).
Inkwell, inkstand.
Door, entrance, exit, gate, gateway, opening in the wall for the admission of light or air. Cf. puka, hole.
A dish for meat or any dish deep enough to hold gravy (kai); gravy boat. Fig., lowland areas, often an affectionate term and with a connotation of bountiful sea food. Cf. also hīnālea.
Baked pumpkin or squash.
See kāniʻo 3.
Same as ipu ahi.
Teapot.
Dipper.

Container for sacred objects; gourd calabash covered with a sennit net and suspended by a handle composed of four cords; food offerings were placed inside for the god Lono. (Neal 748.) Also ipu-o-Lono.
Short for ipu kuaʻaha.
Spittoon.
Churn. Lit., container for pounding butter.
Lamp, candlestick.
Lantern. Lit., light for going at night.

The cup of gold (Solandra hartwegi, often called S. guttata), a large climbing shrub from Mexico, with long-stemmed, oblong leaves. The large, showy, fragrant flowers bloom in winter, are about 23 cm long, goblet-shaped with five shallow lobes, and are yellow with five narrow purple longitudinal streaks. Lit., golden (Eng.) container. (Neal 748.)
Salt container. Lit., seasoning container
Incense burner, censer (Nah. 16.6). Lit., container burning fragrance.
Container for leis.
Fishhook container. Rare.
Earthenware pot, clay pot, vessel of earth (Oihk. 15.12), potter's vessel (Hal. 2.9); chamber pot. Lit., dirt container.
Boiler.
A variety of gourd with nonbitter pulp. (Neal 812.) Lit., sweet gourd.
Chamber pot, container for urine.
A large container; the great bronze laver in Solomon's temple. (2 Nal. 25.16.)
Same as ipu hōkiokio.
Shell container of the hiwa green coconut used in ceremonies honoring the god Kāne.
Speaking gourd, a gourd containing pebbles and other objects used in divination; oracle.

1. A variety of taro used as offering to the gods; it may be qualified by the terms kea and ʻulaʻula.

2. An agricultural heiau; a heiau where ceremonies seeking to obtain rain were held.

3. Shell of the yellow-husked or lelo coconut.

4. Same as ipu kuaʻaha.
A variety of watermelon with fruit like that of ipu poʻo kanaka, but ovoid and larger. (Neal 810.)
Gourd drum. Lit., gourd to beat.
A variety of cantaloupe. Lit., feast melon.
Tobacco pipe.
Gourd calabash decorated with designs.
A variety of watermelon with round, small fruit, smooth skin, and red pulp. (Neal 810.) Lit., human head melon.
Same as pū 3, a general name for pumpkin and squash.
Gourd with hourglass shape.
Wood rollers laid under a canoe being hauled to prevent it from being scratched or damaged.

1. Water container or bottle.

2. Gourd drum. (This word is actually ipu uai [uwai], movable gourd.)
Washbasin. Fig., chiefs' genealogists who were supposed to keep the characters of their masters clean.
. You. Eng. Inā ʻo iū maʻaneʻi (song), if you were here.
Taboo isolating menstruating women in a special hut.
Ceremonial feeding by the high chief of the messenger carrying the image Lono about the island during the makahiki festivals. (Malo 148.)
Intensification of ʻiu 1; majestic, lofty, very high; distant, far away; long absent and out of sight; a distant realm of the gods. Cf. hoʻomāʻiuʻiu.
See ʻiu
See uka.
Jew; Jewish. (Gr.
See Iukaio
July. Eng.
June. Eng.
Broom tree (RSV), juniper (KJV). (Neal 49, 1 Nal. 19.4.) Eng.

The planet Jupiter, originally known as Ka-ʻā- wela. Eng.

Jubilee. Eng. Ka pū iubile (Oihk. 25.9), trumpet of the jubilee.
See iupilē
num. Ninth, nine. Cf. ʻaiwa, ʻeiwa.

1. Frigate or man-of-war bird (Fregata minor palmerstoni); it has a wing span of 12 m. Fig., thief, so called because it steals food by forcing other birds to disgorge; also used figuratively for a handsome person, as follows: Kīkaha ka ʻiwa, he lā makani, poises the frigate bird, a windy day [of a handsome person who draws attention, as does the ʻiwa bird poised aloft].

2. A native fern (Asplenium horridum) with narrow, feather-shaped fronds 45 to 95 cm long, their dark stems bearing dark-brown hairs and scales. The stems were formerly used for making hats. Also ʻalae. (PCP kiwa.)
See waena.
See waho.

1. All maidenhair ferns (Adiantum spp.), from warm regions of the world, many grown ornamentally. The stems are dark, commonly shiny, slender, wiry; the fronds' subdivisions are four-sided, oblong, or wedge-shaped. (Neal 17–9.) ʻAʻohe i ana iho koʻu makemake i nā ʻiwaʻiwa o ka ua o Hāʻao (hula), my desire is not satisfied for the maidenhair ferns in the Hāʻao rain. (PCP kiwakiwa.)

2. A small, high-mountain fern (Asplenium adiantum-nigrum), with shiny, brown stems and triangular or ovate, subdivided, stiff fronds, the spores numerous, often found covering the under side of the fronds. Known in many countries.

3. Var. name for manawahua 2, ferns (Doryopteris spp.), listed by Rock and Hillebrand.
See ʻiwa

An endemic fern (Asplenium rhipidoneuron) with narrow, feather-shaped fronds, which are stiff, 10 to 30 cm long, dark-green, the divisions pointed and obliquely cut, their stems bearing many dark scales.
The curly-leaved maidenhair (Adiantum tenerum f.
Same as ʻiwaʻiwa ʻāpiʻipiʻi. Lit., Australian maidenhair.
The fan maidenhair fern (Adiantum tenerum), with each of the last fan-shaped subdivisions split into five to ten segments.

The Venus-hair, a kind of maidenhair fern (Adiantum capillus-veneris), known in many warm countries, both wild and cultivated in Hawaiʻi. The fronds are subdivided into many small, bright-green, fan-shaped divisions, borne on slender, black stems. (Neal 18.) Also ʻiwaʻiwa kahakaha.
Same as ʻiwaʻiwa hāwai. Lit., striped ʻiwaʻiwa.
A native fern (Asplenium macraei) with narrow, feather-shaped fronds 30 to 60 cm long, with subdivisions of each frond lobed or scalloped. Lit., small-leafed ʻiwaʻiwa. Also ʻiwa lau liʻi.
An endemic fern (Tectaria gaudichaudii) with thin, triangular fronds 30 cm to 1.2 m long, much divided into rather broad lobes. Lit., large-leafed ʻiwaʻiwa.
num. Twenty, twentieth.
num. Twenty-four.
num. Twenty-seven.
num. Twenty-nine.
num. Twenty-one.
num. Twenty-three.
num. Twenty-five.
num. Twenty-two.
num. Twenty-six.
num. Twenty-eight.
Same as ʻiwaʻiwa lau liʻi.
Same as mānā 2, a fern.

1. Bone; carcass (as of a chicken); core (as of a speech). The bones of the dead, considered the most cherished possession, were hidden, and hence there are many figurative expressions with iwi meaning life, old age: Na wai e hoʻōla i nā iwi? Who will save the bones? [Who will care for one in old age and in death?] Maʻaneʻi au me ʻoe a waiho nā iwi, here I am with you until leaving the bones [death].

2. Shell, as of coconut, candlenut, gourd egg, shellfish. Cf. iwi hala.

3. Remnants, pieces, as of coral in a lime pit after lime is extracted by burning, or as pieces of broken glass.

4. Corncob.

5. Stones or earth ridge marking land boundary.

6. Long line, as of surf.

7. Midrib, as of pili grass or ti leaf.

1. Var. of ʻiʻiwi, a bird; considered by some an ʻaumakua. (PCP kiwi.)

2. Reddish.

3. Twitching of the eye, sometimes accompanied by contraction of the mouth.
Jawbone.
A deified bone of an ancestor, an unihipili.

1. Rib, rib bone, spareribs. (2 Sam. 2.23.)

2. Wife (so-called because Eve is said to have been taken from Adam's rib); assistant leader in a hula troupe. Also paepae.
Sprain.
Hyoid bone at the base of the tongue. Lit., tongue bone.
Hard, upper part of pandanus key.
Thighbone, femur, the last rib bone; poetically the very core of one's being.
Shoulder blade.
Rock or shoal projecting on a coral reef. Lit., earth shell.
Bone forming the posterior segment of the skull.
Hipbone; round bone fitting into a socket.
Bony, skinny, emaciated.
Ischium, seat bone; spines on a fish fin.
Keel, as of a ship.
Same as iwi kaʻele; spines on fish fins.
Spines on dorsal fins of fish.
Spines on ventral fins of fish.
Cartilage, Also iwi kumumumu.
Human bone or skeleton.
Bone of the anterior part of the skull, forming the skeleton of the forehead.
Strong bones; possessing strong bones, strength.
Preaxial bone of the forearm.
Name of a star and of an ancient chief of Hawaiʻi.
Same as iwi kaʻele.
See iwi 1.
Name of a lua stroke.
Bone of the lower leg.

1. Spine, backbone

2. Near and trusted relative of a chief who attended to his personal needs and possessions, and executed private orders; family.
See kumumumu.
Stem and midrib of a ti leaf.

1. Collarbone. (PNP iwilei.)

2. Measure of length from the collarbone to the tip of the middle finger with the arm extended; yard. (PNP iwilei.)
A tall bone. Fig., a tall person.
Wishbone.
Kind of adze. Lit., fang bone.
Two bones between the occipital and frontal bones forming a part of the top and sides of the cranium; parietal bone.
Breastbone, as of a fowl.

1. Midrib of a blade of pili grass.

2. Double or united bone of arm of leg.
Kneecap.
Same as ʻiʻiwi pōlena, a honey creeper.
Hollow bone, as the eye socket; socket at the joint into which a round end of a bone fits.
Skull, head bone; leader (rare).
Pelvic bone.
Design on a tapa beater and on tapa consisting of a herringbone figure with a long ridge in the center; design in plaited hat braids, as forming the pāpale ʻie. Lit., eel bone.
Coconut shell. Fig., skull.
Humerus or bone of the upper arm. Lit., pillow bone.
Breastbone, sternum.
Marker of k-words (definite articles, possessives, demonstratives), with meaning singular/definite.

1. Definite singular article replaced by ke before words beginning with a, e, o, and k, and before some words beginning with the glottal stop and p (ka ʻaka, the laugh, ke ʻala, the fragrance; ka pā, the yard, ke pā, the dish). In documents in the State Archives dating from the 1850s, ke was used also before words beginning with other letters.

2. The one who, the person in question (usually followed by i, completed aspect, and a verb, a shortening of ka mea: ; see ke 2).

1. To hit, strike, throw, smite, hack, thrust, toss, fling, hurl, dash, especially with a quick hard stroke; to bail water, as from a canoe; to clean, as weeds or mud from a pond; to fling the arms or swing them while walking; to make net meshes; to tie, as thatch battens; to knit; to fish with a pole; to turn the soil; to turn a rope for children to jump; to remove, as a cataract from the eye with the edge of a blade of kūkae puaʻa grass; to snare, as birds; to curse (especially if used with ʻino; cf. kāmalū); to murder; murderous; murderer, dead shot.

2. Canoe bailer; to bail.

3. Beater, knee-drum beater made of dried ti leaves or braided fiber.

4. Cross-stitching.

5. Vine, as of sweet potato; to send out a vine, to vine, to grow into a vine. Cf. hīkākā, kāhihi.

6. Root cutting, as of breadfruit; to send forth shoots.

7. Pelvic bone.

8. Incoming, of a current (au).

9. Container, hanger. Cf. kā ipu, kā paka, kā ʻumeke.

10. of mild disapproval, annoyance, or surprise. Oh! So! Goodness! So that's it! Is that so! (If spoken alone it is frequently pronounced Chā! or Sah!) ʻO ʻoe kā! So it's you! ʻOia kā! Is that it! Eia aʻe nō kā! Still here! ʻO kā mākou kā kāu mea i manaʻo ai (For. 4.297), so ours is what you wanted.

11. Of, belonging to (a-class, ), as in the possessives kā kākou, our (inclusive), kā mākou, our (exclusive); kā ka haumana puke, the student's book. (PNP taʻa.)

12. Czar. Eng.

13. Also tā. n. Tar, asphalt. Eng.

1. Inclusiveness, in the first person dual and plural pronouns kāua, kākou.

2. Non-productive caus/sim. prefix similar to hoʻo-. Cf. kāhea, kāhili, kāhinu, kākoʻo, kāmaʻa, kāwili, and many others, and .-.)

1. To roll, turn, twist, wallow, wind, braid, revolve; to scud or move along, as clouds; to wield, as a club; rolling, twisting, turning, sloping. See ex., pōhaku 1.

2. Vehicle, carriage, wagon, automobile, car, cart, coach, buggy.

3. To go past, pass by, reach; to be in a state of; to be located at; to take effect, as medicine; gone, absent, past, turned over, transferred, delivered.

4. To pay; paid.

5. To manage, run, be in charge of; given, as work to a person; well versed, skilled (used very broadly to indicate custom, nature, character, habit: see kaʻa hele, kaʻa kaua, kaʻa lolohi, kaʻa maʻi, kaʻa moena, kaʻa nema, kaʻa nemo).

6. Resin. Cf. hūkaʻa, lāʻau-kaʻa, kēpau kaʻa.

7. To wipe dry with a cloth, as dishes.

8. Pulley.

9. See hoana kaʻa.

10. Tale, legend (now replaced by kaʻao).
Thread, line, as of olonā fiber; snell of a fishline, snood; ply, twist, strand; to make thread, as of olonā (Nak. 62). Cf. kaʻa kolu, kaʻā lua.
Train, railroad, locomotive engine. Lit., fire wagon.
Star name.
A lua fighting stroke.
Stick, rod, or wand with leaves and tapa at one end, held by the priest while sacrificing in the temple.
To grow thriftily, of plants.
Trailer, house on wheels.
Passenger conveyance. Lit., vehicle carrying passengers.
Freight (ukana) conveyance.
Horse-drawn trolley car. Lit., five-cent vehicle.
Feeble, near death; to labor for breath. Cf. -nākū.
To languish, pine. (For. 4:27.) hoʻo.kaʻa.hea To soothe.
Bicycle, tricycle. Lit., vehicle press feet.
To make a tour, travel about; a tour; in turns.
Short for kaʻaahi.
To struggle; to pant, as for breath.
To fall down and roll.
To mix up, disturb. Cf. hōkai.
To speed ahead, run.
Sled. Lit., car riding snow.
Arrears in a payment; to pass by.
Wheelbarrow.
Any two-wheeled vehicle, as cart or buggy.
Handcart. Lit., pull vehicle.
A lua fighting stroke. Lit., the feather cloak. (Also without Ka-.)

1. Sash, belt, girdle of any kind; sennit casket alleged to contain the bones of Līloa and Lono-i-ka-makahiki, in Bishop Museum in 1976; protective cloth wrapped around an object; to bind, tie around, encircle, gird on; to put on, as armor or a mourning garment. Also kāʻei, kāhei. See akua kāʻai.

2. To dig food crops, as taro, sweet potatoes.
Fellow, chap, wretch, person. Slang. (Possibly Tahitian, but see mahumahu, ʻōkole kaʻaka).

1. To open, as the eyes; open, watching.

2. Name of a star or constellation, said to be on the border of the Milky Way. (KL. line 1865).

3. variant of koʻa, coral head, fishing grounds.
See "hoʻokaʻakaʻa":  To cause to roll repeatedly. Also hoʻokakaʻa..
Actively and gainfully employed, successful; to make progress. Rare.
Same as hiʻu wīwī, an ʻahi, a fish.
Redup. of kaʻalalo. (Kep. 101).
To have enough, especially of material goods; ample.
Tough, stringy, as of banana trees; viscid, gluey.
Redup. of kaʻana.
Redup. of kaʻawili.
See kaʻa 1.

1. Skilled in warfare; strategist, war maneuvers, strategy

2. War tank; war chariot. (Puk. 14.25).
Trailer, tractor.
Diagonal, cut at an angle; to avoid, shy away from, take a short cut. See ex., keha.
Cable car.
Fire engine. Lit., vehicle extinguish fire.
Three-stranded; threefold.
To belt.
Violent dizziness; to lie down or lean back in pain, to roll over backwards.
