Period of mourning, especially wailing in grief; to mourn and wail.
Dull, of tools.
Hearse.
Widow, widower. (And.)

1. Same as moʻo ʻalā, a lizard.

2. Blind (used with maka). Rare.
An ʻopihi, a limpet.
Sling; to hurl stones with a sling.
var. of kāʻalaʻala.
Vigorous, sturdy, healthy, as of an infant or young animal.
To wield a war club; to send a curse by playing with seeming innocence with four or five sticks held in the hand (Kam. 64:141).
To sail to leeward. Fig., full of lies, underhanded, deceitful. Cf. kaʻakaʻalalo.
Those about a chief; members of the royal court.
Same as hukilau.
Coconut-leaf thatching.
Ambulance.
To sway, reel; to fly or soar, as birds.
Redup. and intensifier of kaʻalewa.
To speak loudly.

1. To revolve.

2. To drift, sail off and on. Cf. kālewa.
Pas/imp. of kaʻa 1. 3–5. Rare.
Ceremonial throwing of spears at a high chief returning from a voyage; he dodges or catches the spears to show his courage and skill; to hurl thus.
To bruise; to pelt, as rain. Cf. ʻālina.
Horse-drawn vehicle, wagon, carriage.
To pass by, go by. Cf. māʻalo.
Redup. of kāʻalo.
Same as kaʻalolohi.
Intrepid, fearless, as of one unafraid to brave the elements; bravery. Cf. loku.
Name of a star, said to be the tutelary star of Niʻihau.
Slow-moving, slow to anger.
Two-ply, two-stranded.
To sail or turn against the wind. Fig., to dominate; overbearing. Cf. kaʻalalo.
Steam-propelled vehicle.
Siege of sickness, a long or chronic illness; to suffer such.

1. To fall in (military command), to serve others, to roll beneath.

2. To be subject to.
To wipe dry, as dishes with a cloth.
To rise in station, to come up from under; to rule others.
To change, as the wind or an idea. Rare.
Var. of kāmehaʻi.
Bedridden. Rare.
To turn around loosely, as a screw or peg that does not fit; loose, unsteady.

1. To divide, share, apportion.

2. To decoy, especially to attract uhu fish with a live uhu decoy; to 
proselyte.

3. A rolling, as of stones.
Constipation. Rare. Cf. ʻanaʻana.
Same as ahupuaʻa, the altar marking the land division.
Strangling cord.
of surprise or scorn.
The local, as kā ʻaneʻi paia, the walls here (a-class; cf. kō ʻaneʻi).
Same as nemanema.
Smooth, rounded, as seeds. (Kep. 159).
To move or walk quietly.
Freed, as of a taboo.
To writhe, squirm, as a fidgety child or one in a tantrum; to run after in agitation; to go round and round, as a dog greeting a friend. Cf. niniu, spin.
Var. of kaʻanini. See saying, wiliwai.
An elevated place; sleeping place in a grass house.
Legend, tale, novel, romance, usually fanciful; fiction; tell a fanciful tale.

1. Ripe, of pandanus fruit; ripe pandanus. Cf. puhalu 1.

2. A favorable Hālawa, Molokaʻi, wind mentioned in For. 5:123; also associated with Hanamāʻulu, Kauaʻi (For. 5:97).
Name for a garden patch.
Vehicle carrying passengers for hire, as bus, taxi, stagecoach.
To finish or complete, as a canoe; to put on the last touches. Cf. kāʻokoʻa, oki.

1. Var. of kāʻokoʻa.

2. Entirely paid, as a debt.
Automobile. Lit., automobile (Eng.) vehicle.

1. Name of a month. See month.

2. Red or reddish-brown, due to being smoked, especially of fish, or of the stem of sugar-cane tassel to be used in a dart.

3. Attractive, of a child (children born in the month of Kaʻaona were thought to be attractive and lovable). Cf. pua kaʻaona.

4. Name of a star. (KL. line 1881).
To roll along with a rustling sound (ʻowē). Fig., a person with no property or means of support.
To toss from side to side, as a restless child in bed; in spasms.
Pushcart.
To cut off squarely or crosswise (kā, strike, and ʻāpahu, cut off short).
Bicycle. Lit., bicycle (Eng.) vehicle.
Same as kāwili palaoa.
Fire engine. Also kaʻa wai.
Servile, humble, fawning, cringing.
Headstrong, willful, obstinate (perhaps related to the ʻape plant which holds its leaves upright).

1. Same as ʻāhina kuahiwi, a fern.

2. A seaweed.

3. Same as kaʻapeʻapehā.
A deep-sea fish said to resemble the moano.

1. Large mass of clouds; impressively big, large, even corpulent in a distinguished manner; influential and important.

2. To spread wings or tail feathers. (For. 6:381.)

3. To fold over, as a bundle. (For. 6:381.)
Castor bean, more commonly known as kolī or pāʻaila.
Hack (carriage). Lit., bent vehicle, so called because of the top.
Taboo night in the ruling chief's heiau during October.
Ferris wheel. Also huila pōniuniu.

1. To make a tour, go around, surround, encircle, rotate, revolve, travel; circuit.

2. The hula step now called “around the island”: the dancer pivots on the ball of one foot in a complete circle; the other foot takes four or more steps to complete the circuit; to do this step.

3. Revolution, revolving.

1. num. Forty. See pākaʻau..

2. A fine rain in Kohala, Hawaiʻi.
See "hoʻokāʻau":  Witty, clever, funny, entertaining, humorous; to pass the time pleasantly; entertaining time. Hoʻokāʻau ʻana, time spent pleasantly.
Hard, mottled stone, as used for ʻulu maika stones. Rare.
Streetcar, electric bus, electric vehicle.
Truck.
A lua fighting stroke. Lit., the floating chin. (Also without Ka-.)
Large bowl in which kava was mixed and strained (short for kānoa ʻawa).
Vehicle carrying water, fire engine.

Separate, free, different, apart, spare, alone, unoccupied, empty; to separate, isolate or reserve, withdraw; free time, opportunity; to take interval (military command); distance separating places or objects.
To turn or roll freely, independently, or without control..
To tie anything tightly around the neck, to choke, strangle, hang; necktie.
Redup. of kāʻawe; choking, strangling sensation.
Name of a planet, probably Venus or Jupiter. (KL. line 1851). (Probably the same as Hōkūloa (Kep. 82), Hōkū-ao and Ka-lani-ʻōpuʻu).
To repeat, do over and over.

To turn, twist, writhe as in pain; to knead, as bread (Ier. 7.18). (ʻŌpelu fish that form a vertical wall as they swim, flapping to maintain this unusual position, are said to kaʻawili). Cf. pākaʻawili.

1. Lathe.

2. Perfumer (RSV), apothecary (KJV). (Puk. 37.29.) More commonly kāwili lāʻau.

1. Refuse or rubbish, waste, excrement (cf. kūkae); refuse from fibers, as of olonā;. raw bast and refuse of the wauke plant after soaking.

2. Treated with contempt, scorn.

1. Brink, border, margin, rim, brim, fringe, curb, bank, edge; toothless gums;. projecting brow of a hill. Cf. kaʻekaʻe, hakakaʻe.

2. Idiom following ʻaʻole and possessive o.

3. To sulk, fuss; sullen, cross.

4. To smudge, dab, besmear.

1. Cessation or lack of appetite or desire.

2. Tired. Eng.
Same as kāʻeʻaʻeʻa.
Expert, hero, fighter.
Hard, stiff, not soft or or pliable; dried up withered as by heat; evaporated.

1. A sea bean (Mucuna gigantea), native from southeast Asia, east into Polynesia, a high-growing vine, bearing greenish flowers and large pods, each pod containing two to four round and flattened seeds, black-spotted or brown. In Hawaiʻi, the seeds, known as pēkaʻa, are found on the beaches, and are used medicinally for their strong purgative effect and are also strung for leis (Neal 462).

2. Hand net hanging on an ellipsoidal wooden frame with one end pointed, used for ʻōhua and other inshore fish; to use this net or a skirt of a dress in this type of fishing; to strain, as through a strainer. (PCP taakeke.)
Joyful, glad, hospitable, friendly. Same as aʻa 2.
Var. of kāʻēʻē 1.
Redup. of kāʻēʻē; very joyful, glad, etc.
var. of Kaʻele 2, a wind.
A lua fighting stroke. Lit., the wing. (Also ʻEheu.)
var. of kaiehu.
Var. of kāʻai;, belt, sash; zone; ring for bobbin winder of sewing machine.
Arctic Circle.
Hatband.
Diadem, turban.
Entangled, confused, twisted; to interweave.

1. Smooth, polished, perfect, as a new canoe without knots or knobs; young, attractive, plump, desirable, as of a woman; tasty, mellow, soft, as of sweet potatoes; to rub smooth, polish, finish. Cf. mōkaekae.

2. Name of a star.

1. Same as kaʻe 1.

2. Redup. of kaʻe 4.
Pas/imp. of kaekae 1. Rare.
Same kāʻekeʻeke.

Bamboo pipes, varying in length from .3 to about 1 m; usually with one end open. A player held one vertically in each hand tapping down on a mat or on the ground. The tone varied according, to the size of the tube. Several musicians might play at once. (, Roberts 53.) Barrèrre suggests (Barrèrre, Pukui, and Kelly 11) that kāʻekeʻeke as the name for bamboo pipes seems to have originated with Emerson. She quotes Andrews (who refers to Laie) as saying the name applied to coconut-tree drums. It is also used as a verb. Also ʻohe kāʻekeʻeke or pahūpahū.
Same as Kāʻeleloli.
See Kāʻekeloi
Peeved, offended.
var. of kaola

1. Empty and hollow, as of a bowl, poi board, drum, canoe hull; hull; inside bottom as of a calabash or poi board. Also ʻele.

2. Name of a wind of Ka-lele-waʻa, Molokaʻi (For. 5:101.)

1. Darkened; cf. ʻele, black. See ex. kaʻele 1.

2. Numerous.

3. Slow, delaying.

4. A seaweed.
Star name, probably the same as Hōkū-loa, Venus, (Kep. 82.) Lit., the messenger of the dawn.
Roll, ruffle, as of a drum.
Name of a rain at Makiki, Oʻahu.

1. Name of a wet month. Cf. ʻelo, saturated.

2. Name of a star, possibly Betelgeuse.
To boast, brag, glorify, praise; boastful, conceited, proud.
Resentful, peeved, indignant, angry.

1. Full, as a food calabash. Fig., full of knowledge. See ex., ʻumeke.

2. Strong, zealous.

3. Hair gathered in a topknot on the head, as by priests in ceremonies. (For. 6:401.)
Redup. of kaʻeo, and kāʻeo.
A variety of taro.
A variety of taro.
Selvage of cloth. Lit., solid edge.
Helpful, cooperative; joyous, active larger, bigger. Cf. ʻeu.
A variety of sweet potato.

1. To scratch, mark, check, draw, sketch, cut, cut open or slice lengthwise, as fish or animals; to operate, as on the sick; to give a grade or mark to; to engrave; a line in mathematics; punctuation or other mark, as an accent mark; stripe, as in the flag or of enlisted men in the Armed Forces; a grade, as in school; checkmark, long striped cloth. See kaha kiʻi, kaha palapalaʻāina.

2. Place (often followed by a qualifier, as kahakai, kahaone, kahawai, and used without ke, as hele i kahakai, go to the beach); in legends, a hot dry shore (PH 74, 84; ).

3. To swoop, as a kite; to be poised, soar, as a bird (less used than kīkaha); to go by, pass by, to turn and go on; to surf, body surf.

4. To desolate, plunder, cheat. Cf. pākaha.

5. Stage of a foetus in which limbs begin to develop. Also mana.

6. Proud, haughty. Rare. See hoʻokahakaha.

7. A kind of tapa. (Kam. 76:111.)
Large, fat, plump, as of a well-fed dog. Rare.

1. A track of a god.

2. Abode of gods or spirits.
Circumference, parentheses, brackets. Lit., mark embrace.
See kaha 1.
Cumulus clouds, often colored, thought to be a sign of rain. Cf. ao, ʻōpua.
Redup. of kahaʻea.
Minus sign.

1. Young growth stage of the fish ʻamaʻama, about a hand's length. Also pahaha.

2. Same as aukaha, desolate.
n. and vi. Interj. of suprise, wonder, displeasure; to wonder, be surprised, astonished, amazed, puzzled; surprise, astonishment.

1. Radius of a circle.

2. Strings securing upper part of the net surrounding a calabash (kōkō).
Multiplication sign, crisscross mark; slanting lines.
Minus sign.
Multiplication sign.
Bracket combining two items, as male and female voices in music; tenor clef; plus sign in arithmetic. Lit., joining mark.
Var. of kāʻai.
A culture hero. (PNP Tafaki.)
Same as kanahaʻi.

1. Redup. of kāhaʻi.

2. Same as ʻāweoweo, a native shrub.
Star name, said to be the twentieth in the Milky way. Lit., going to Kahaʻi [hero's name].
Death by sorcery. Lit., death indeed from someone else. (Kam. 64:43).
Evil, evil place.
Plant said to have been used for medicine (no data).
Disagreeable, unpleasant.

1. Redup. of kaha 1; to mark frequently, to draw lines, scratch; to cut lengthwise or into strips; to scarify, engrave; striped, lined.

2. Redup. of kaha 3.

3. Small stone larger than a pebble. Rare.
Markings, scratchings, lines, stripes; narrow strip of cloth, usually white.
Beach, seashore, seacoast, seaside strand. (PEP tafatai.)
Boundary.
High, inaccessible, as a cliff. (For. 6:412.)
To cut or engrave in copper or brass; a worker in copper or brass; engraver.
To draw or paint a picture or draw plants; artist.
Architect; to draw building plans.
Roaring sound, as of wind, rain, or rushing waters; to roar.

1. Steep, sheer.

2. Macron.

1. To turn off one's course; to go where one pleases, trespass.

2. A unit of measure, usually said to he about 2.5 m, but in  called fifteen feet (4.5 m).
Reference mark in writing or printing to direct attention, as asterisk, dagger, arrow, blaze.

1. Amberjack or yellowtail (Seriola dumerilii).

2. Ripe, said of a gourd with stem beginning to wither.

3. Net made of strong cord, used for sharks. (Malo 213.) Also hihi manō.
Tasteless, insipid, flavorless, unpleasant tasting. Cf. hala, fault.
Underscore, underline.
Famine during wartime, with persons seeking food at night for fear of being seen. Lit., cut leap about night.

1. Sanctified stone used by at priest in ʻanāʻanā sorcery.

2. To exhibit wrath or displeasure due to jealousy.

1. Short for ʻae-o-kaha-loa, a tapa.

2. A stone brought before a priest in sorcery prayers. (And.)
To turn and then go straight for a long distance; long detour or digression.
To interrupt, break into a conversation.
Dash (punctuation mark). Lit., mark to rest.
To engrave; engraver.
Hyphen. Lit., horizontal mark.
Cutting, drawing of a line; turning point. Cf. kaha 1, 3.
Clearing, as in a forest: redup. of kahana (For. 6:61).
Cliff ledge. (For. 6:61.)
Body surfing. Cf. kaha 3.

1. Smooth-shaven, smooth, unclouded.

2. Sour, as of poi.
Sandy beach.
To draw a map.
To make a cross or X, especially in black magic (the victim becomes gravely or mortally ill by stepping on or over the mark); to crisscross; a cross or X.
Tangent of a circle. Lit., line that touches.
Circumference of a circle. Lit. mark surround.
Fat or muscle on the shoulder blade. Lit., shoulder fat.
Taboo on menstruating women, restricting them to the menstruating house. Lit., place of dark night.
Division sign.

1. The sport of hurling lightweight hau wood spears; to hurl such spears. Lit., hurl hau wood.

2. To catch edible locusts by striking (kā) the dew (hau) on bushes.
To diminish, abate, lessen, as a storm or sickness.
A lua fighting stroke. Lit., the blow enters. (Also without Ka-.)

1. Sensual dream (sickness or bad luck, as in fishing, was believed to follow shortly); to have sexual relations in a dream (Laie 459), Aikahaʻula, a dream of coition.

2. Name of a sexual goddess.
To subincise or circumcise (less used than kahe ule or Biblical ʻoki poepoe). Lit., slit penis.
A kind of ʻahi, a tuna. It is small, has a long pectoral fin, and reaches about 35 kilos in weight. Lit., dark-striped.
A lua fighting stroke. Lit., the drowned blow. (Also without Ka-.)
Stream, creek, river; valley, ravine, gulch, whether wet or dry.

1. To flow, trickle, drop, melt, menstruate; in heat, of a bitch; a run or school of fish. See ex., kaea.

2. To cut or slit longitudinally; to subincise or circumcise. See kahe ule.
First appearance of young caterpillars on vines, especially of sweet potatoes; to be eaten by caterpillars.

To call, cry out, invoke, greet, name; recital of the first lines of a stanza by the dancer as a cue to the chanter; to recite the kāhea; to give a military command; to summon; a call, alarm (kā, caus. + hea, call).
Red stains or streaks, as at dawn; bloody. (Malo 13.)
A call to come and eat; a prayer calling on the gods to come and share the food.
To call to someone who is leaving (this was believed to bring bad luck, because the departing person had to change his plans).
Fire alarm.
To flow like water. Fig., to move in great crowds.

1. To pour.

2. To catch fish with a scoop or hand net. See ʻupena kāheʻe.

3. To slip flowers from the stringing needle to the string.

4. To train or practice, as for foot races. (Malo 29.)
A lua fighting stroke.
To make a misstep, stumble. Cf. hehi.

1. Hurling, as firebrands at Ka-maile, Kauaʻi; to hurl; to put on a lei. (PCP taasei.)

2. Var. of kāʻai.
Pool, especially a rock basin where the sea washes in through an opening and salt forms; salt pan.

1. Redup. of kahe 1.

2. Method of fishing with a large net placed in deep water where fish fed or where bait had been strewn; to fish thus. (Malo 212.)

3. A method of birdcatching: all save a few lehua blossoms were plucked and the remaining flowers were gummed so that birds would be stuck; to catch birds thus.
Plural and diminutive of kāheka; small sea pool or pools; artificial salt pan.
Same as naʻinaʻi mimi.
Similar to kaheāwai, abundance.
Flow of blood, hemorrhage; to have such.

1. To lie spread out, as an individual or a wide expanse of land or sea; to sweep backward and forward, as great billows that do not break; prone, spread out, flat; summation of productive forces of land and sea (Kam. 76:30, 51). Cf. lipi kāhela.

2. See ʻami kāhela, a hula step.

3. Gourd drumbeat: the gourd is thumped down on a pad; it is then raised with the left hand and is struck with two quick slaps of the fingers of the right hand.

4. Name of a star, seen in the month ʻIkuwā.
Redup. and intensifier of kāhela 1–3; to sprawl.
Adze (And.)

1. Decorated for a journey, as with a lei.

2. To flow.
To be entangled.

1. Species of small colored shells, found particularly on Niʻihau; perhaps so called because the shells were used by chiefs.

2. Name of an ancient chief associated with Niʻihau. Lit., the royal going.
Flowing. Cf. kahe 1.
To weed and stir up the soil.
To subincise or circumcise. Lit., cut penis. Cf. ʻoki poepoe.
To miss, fail, not succeed; to hit by mistake; foiled or thwarted in an attempt.

1. To cut longitudinally, shave, plane, comb, press, rub or stroke, as in a massage, with gentle pressure of the open palm of the hand; to scrape; to run the fingers along the side of a poi bowl so as to remove the poi clinging to the side; comb; scraper, as for olonā fiber.

2. num. One, only one, alone, lone, some (sometimes following the numeral classifiers ʻa- and ʻe-, or hoʻo-); also, besides, too, single; fellow worker, wife, companion; someone, someone else, a certain (less common than kekahi); unit. See ex., kāmau 1.

3. Place, location (contraction of ka wahi, not preceded by ke with this meaning); duty; where; ill case of, approximately, about. (For use of possessives o and a with kahi, see .) Kahi ʻē, elswhere.
Old var. of kakahiaka, morning.
To polish, as a bowl. Rare.
See kahi 3.
Entanglement, perplexity, involvement, blocking; entangled, choked, as by weeds; blocked, involved, as with the law (Mat. 5.40), trapped, framed (slang). Cf. hihi.
of disapproval or disbelief; the vowels are sometimes nasalized and the last two greatly leangthened, spoken with rising inflection. Horrors! Cf. kāhāhā, kāhūhū.
Redup. of kāhihi.
Same as ka hili kolo.
Same as Ka-hili-kolo.
Zoo.
Sink (basin).
Place for cleansing; purgatory.
Buttocks. (For. 5:703.)
Redup. of kahi 1.
To stretch out smooth by rubbing, as in making tapa. Lit., rub stretch out.

1. Tahiti. Cf. holokahiki.

2. Any foreign country, abroad, foreign. (PCP tafiti.)

3. A variety of banana, common wild on Maui. Kinds are kahiki hae, kahiki mauki, and kahiki puhi.
Name of a legendary tree and place in the uplands of Kauaʻi, probably a var. of Kahili-kolo.
Name of a navigation star, said to be named for one of the eight steersmen of Hawaiʻi-loa.
Name of a district or ahupuaʻa on Maui. (Malo 6.) Lit., great Tahiti. (PEP Tafiti Nui.)

1. Old, ancient, antique, primitive, long ago, beforehand; to age; old person. (Usually in the sigular ; cf. kāhiko 2, puka kahiko.) Wā kahiko, old times.

2. Name of the first Hawaiian. (Malo 4.)

1. Finery, ornaments; to wear finery, dress up; to harness (Ier. 46.4).

2. Plural of kahiko 1.

1. Somewhat old.

2. Redup. of kāhiko, finery.
War finery, formerly, shield, helmet, feather cape.
To have lost the red glow of dawn. Cf. kahikū.
Trinity, three in one. See Kū-kaua-kahi.
Star name (no data). (Kuhelani.)
To rise higher, of the sun, to a stage between kahikole and kau i ka lolo (noon).

1. Feather standard, symbolic of royalty; segment of a rainbow standing like a shaft (also a sign of royalty); to brush, sweep, switch (kā- 2 + hili). See uhao and kāhili chants, ʻouʻou 1 and uluaoʻa 2.

2. The crape myrtle (Lagerstroemia indica), an ornamental shrub from China, with small oval leaves and panicles of pink, white, or purple crapy flowers. (Neal 618.)

3. A small tree (Grevillea banksii) from Australia, related to the silky oak, ʻoka kilika, but the leaves with fewer subdivisions and the flowers red or cream-white. This is a later application of kāhili to a plant. Flowers not used for lies on head or around neck because of it irritating hairs, but made into leis for hats by sewing alternate rows of flower clusters and own leaves on pandanus band. (Neal 321.) See haʻikū.

4. Kāhili ginger (Hedychium gardnerianum), from the Himalaya region; much like the white ginger but with a more open flower head, the flowers with narrow yellow segment and one bright-red stamen apiece. (Neal 253–4.) Also ʻawapuhi kāhili.

5. A seaweed, probably Turbinaria ornata.
Redup. of kāhili 1; to spray.
Medical combination of juices of the gourd and the puʻukaʻa sedge.
Name of a legendary koa tree on Kauaʻi said to consist of branches without a trunk. Lit., the creeping tangle.
Lua fighting stroke. (Also without Ka-; also Ka-hiki-kolo.)
Currycomb. Lit., horse comb.
Small kāhili carried in the hand.
Place to sleep, bed, cot.
Wood shavings; rubbing, cutting, etc. Cf. kahi 1 (PNP tafinga.)
To knock down, take advantage of, deceive.
Name of a legendary chief in whose time was a great sea flood (HM 315), perhaps a tsunami. See kānāwai.
Residence, address.
To rub with oil, grease, petroleum jelly; to anoint (kā- 2 + hinu), Cf. hinuhinu hoʻo.kā.hinu Caus/sim.
To lean to one side (kā- 2 + hinu). Cf. the more common hiō.
Tipsy.
High-backed comb with long prongs (ʻō) such as worn by the Spanish.
Redup. of kāhiō.
Redup. . of kāhiʻo; drunk.
Back or side comb used hold hair in place. Lit., comb to pin down.
See pule kāhiu.
Fine-toothed comb, as used for removing dandruff or head lice (ʻuku).
To shave the whiskers; barber.
Dark pupil, as of the eye (kā- + hiwa).
Sacred vine. (KL. line; 379.)

1. To strike, break; to strike of a fish at a hook (ka- 2 + hoa).

2. Same as kāhoahoa.

3. Beginning of a chant, with others then joining in; to begin a chant.

4. Same as kāhoahoa, to appeal.

1. To appeal, intercede.

2. Redup. of kāhoa 1.

1. Phantom, specter, spirit of a living person; sign in the heavens.

2. Kind of sorcery prayer spoken in a moderate or natural voice.
Unidentified star. (Johnson and Mahelona 43.)
Name of a star.
of surprise or anger. Cf. kāhāhā, kāhīhī, kāhūhū.
indicating surprise, following bases.

1. Hasty, nimble, swift, quick; to move fast, progress rapidly. Cf. holo, to run; pule kāholo.

2. To sew with long stitches; basting; sennit lashings on royal canoes (Malo 131).

3. The “vamp” hula step, more common in modern than in ancient dance, consisting of four counts: one foot is extended to the side, the other is brought alongside, (3, 4) this is repeated on the same side; then the four steps are repeated on the opposite side; to execute this step.

4. Name of a star.
Redup. of kāholo 1, 2.

1. Globe of the earth.

2. Level landing place, as after fording a stream or coming down from a cliff.

3. Dirt embankment.

The only uninhabited major Hawaiian Island. In prehistoric times 80 men, sent front Hawaiʻi, dug a well ten fathoms deep at Ke-ana-pou (For. 5:200–3). Lit., the taking away [as by currents], See Kanaloa 4 and saying, kūpala 4.

1. Honored attendant, guardian, nurse, keeper of ʻunihipili bones, regent, keeper, administrator, warden, caretaker, master, mistress; pastor, minister, reverend, or preacher of a church; one who has a dog, cat, pig, or other pet. According to J. S. Emerson; 92:2, kahu “implies the most intimate and confidential relations between the god and its guardian or keeper, while the word kahuna suggests more of the professional relation of the priest to the community.” Cf. kahu hipa, kahu hoʻoponopono, kahu mālama, kahu waiwai, and ex., ʻanāʻanā.

2. vn. To tend or cook at an oven fire; to build an oven fire; to burn, as lime in a pit; one who tends an oven, a cook. Fig., to seethe with hot rage.

3. Similar to kahukahu.

1. Foundation, base, site, location, ground, background, platform, as of a house; an open place, as for camping or for sports, as for ʻulu maika or hōlua sliding; playground, arena, stand, stage, courtyard course, camp; bed, as of a stream. fig., declaration of principles or policy, doctrine, platform.

2. Base of a quilt on which the pattern (lau) is appliquéd; this base is above the layer of cotton or wool. The pili is below it.
See moekāhua.
Name of a star.
House foundation or site.
Subject, as of a discussion, basis for work; foundation principles, is a political platform; work site.
Threshing floor.
Fire builder; to build and tend a fire.
Zoo.
Sledding course.
Radio broadcasting station. Lit., site for making voice fly.
Meeting place. Cf. hale hoʻolulu. Lit., site for shelter.
Airport.
Staging area, as in warfare.
Battleground; place used for competitive sports or contests. Lit., site for attack.
To cook taro or vegetable food; to keep the store of such food; to make poi; a keeper or cook. Cf. kahu 2. Same as kahu umu or kahūmu.
Headman of a land division.
Battlefield.
Air base.
Tennis court.
Fire station. Lit., place quench fire.
Any ball-playing area, as a base-ball diamond, football field, tennis court.
Golf course.
One who takes care of an image or a god; priest.
Playground.
See kahua leʻa
Royal guardian in the family of a high chief.
Submarine base.
Master or practitioner of sorcery and counter sorcery. See ex., ʻanāʻanā. Cf. kahuna ʻanāʻanā.
Ignoramus, one without background, trade, profession, knowledge; to be such.
Bowling alley.
Place of happiness, comfort, pleasure (named for Maliʻo, a mythical woman renowned for entertaining with music and for her ability in love magic).
Solar system.
Terra firma, the solid earth. Fig., security.
Stadium; playground or athletic field of any kind. Lit., site for play.
Deputy or regent in the days of the monarchy. Lit., government caretaker.
Pastor of a church.
Unidentified star name. (Johnson and Mahelona 43.)
Unidentified star name. (Johnson and Mahelona 43.)
Foster parent (of adopted children).
Shepherd.
Administrator.
of surprise or anger. Cf. kāhāhā, kāhīhī.
Pleiades. (Kuhelani.)
Coachman.
To offer food and prayers to a god or to the spirit of a deified person. Cf. ʻahaʻaina kahukahu.
One who tends a child, as a nurse.
Same as palahuki.
Schoolmaster, school supervisor. Cf. papa o nā kahu kula.
School superintendent.
To overturn, overthrow, capsize, upset.

1. To change, alter.

2. Land shells (Philonesia spp.).

3. Sport or mutant, as of sweet potato.
Name of a star. Cf. Ke-kau-hiwa-kā.
Revolution, revolutionist; to over-throw the government. Also hoʻokahuli aupuni.
Unsteady, shaky, rickety, variable, unsettled; to sway, reel, tip, rock, totter; tossed about, as a ship.
Coachman, groom.
Turned completely over, upside down.

1. Athletic contest, especially championship match.

2. Crescent-shaped disposition of soldiers on a battlefield. (Malo 203, Emerson note.)

3. Variety of sweet potato.

4. A lua fighting stroke.
Nurse.
Custodian, caretaker.
Warden of a district.
Housekeeper.
Legal guardian of minors.
Nurse.
Warden of a prison.
Person who cared for the chief's excrement so that it would not fall into the possession of a sorcerer. Also kahu poka.
Mate of a ship.
Var. spelling of kahu umu.

1. Priest, sorcerer, magician, wizard, minister, expert in any profession (whether male or female); in the 1845 laws doctors, surgeons, and dentists were called kahuna. See kahu and many examples below; for plural see kāhuna.

2. Oven cooking; to cook. Cf. kahu 2.

1. Plural of kahuna 1. See ex., ʻololī.

2. Same as kāhunahuna.
Filth-eating sorcerer [insulting term].
Sorcerer who practices black magic and counter sorcery, as one who prays a person to death. Cf. kahu ʻanāʻanā.
Teaching preacher, minister, sorcerer.
See hāhā.
Preacher, especially an itinerant preacher.
Medical expert who induced pregnancy. (Kam. 64:98.)

Malevolent sorcerer, as one who inflicts illness by gesture, as rubbing his own head to give the victim a severe headache or head injury. Sometimes the victim might imitate tha gesture and send the affliction back to the sorcerer. Cf. hoʻoheihei.
Agricultural expert.
Priest who increased population by praying for pregnancy.
A priest who functioned in ceremonies for the deification of a king (Malo 105) or who detected symptoms of sorcery in one sick or dead (Handy 72: 322).
To sprinkle tightly, especially with salt. Cf. huna, fine.
Place where food is cooked in an underground oven, as in a cookhouse; tending of the oven.
Carving expert, sculptor.
Canoe builder.
Caretaker of images, who wrapped, oiled, and stored them, and carried them into battle ahead of the chief.
Priest or expert who observed the skies for omens.
Medical doctor, medical practitioner, healer. Lit., curing expert.
A priest who induced spirits to possess a patient so that he might then drive the spirits out, thus curing the patient. Lit., spirit priest. (Kam. 64:138.)
High priest and councilor to a high chief; office of councilor.
High priest.
Preacher, pastor, minister, parson, priest. Lit., prayer expert.
High chief's trusted attendant of royal blood who had charge of his tobacco and pipes; he lighted them and drew a few puffs before presenting them to the chief. Lit., guardian of tobacco (Eng.)
Herdsman, keeper of cattle, cattle owner, rancher; to care for cattle.
Same as kahu moka.
Librarian, custodian of books. Also mea mālama puke.
The high chief who attended an infant chief, carried him, and sat him on his lap (ʻūhā). Also ʻūhā. (Kep. 127.)
Oven tender; to tend an oven.
One in charge of water rights and division, water master.
Wet nurse (also kahu wale). (Kep. 127.)
Trustee, executor. Lit., custodian of wealth or property.
Same as kahu waiū. (Kep. 123.)

1. Sea, sea water; area near the sea, seaside, lowlands; tide, current in the sea; insipid, brackish, tasteless.

2. Gravy, sauce, dressing, soup, broth.

3. similar to keu. My, how much! How very! How terrific! Kai ka nani! How beautiful! Kai ke kolohe! Oh, how mischievous. Cf. kainō.
Contraction ka mea i, the one who did. Cf. ka 1.
See ka i
Prefix to six kinship terms used as terms of reference: kaikaina, kaikoʻeke, kaikuaʻana, kaikunāne, kaikuahine, kaikamahine.
Swollen, bloated.
of displeasure, vexation, annoyance, prolonged to indicate greater force.
See kaī

A variety of taro, the corms of which are fragrant when cooked and, though tough, yield excellent poi. Kinds are qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, kea, keʻokeʻo (said to be reserved for chiefs), koi, nenene, pala, ʻulaʻula, uliuli, welo ʻeka. Ua ʻai i ke kāī koi o ʻEwa, having eaten of the very choice kāī koi taro of ʻEwa [said of a sweetheart one can't forget].

1. To lead, direct, lift up and carry; to walk or step in a row or procession, or as a child learning to walk; to come dancing out before an audience; the chant during which dancers appear and leave; to train, as for racing (Malo 219). Cf. ʻaha 3, alakaʻi, hākaʻi, huakaʻi.

2. To pull, as weeds.

3. Fish net or seine; snare or noose for birds. (And.)

4. Snood of a fishhook.

5. A decayed tooth that requires extraction.
Perhaps a transitivizer. Cf. alakaʻi.

1. Fast asleep (used with hiamoe.) Kāia loa ʻia ihola ʻo Wākea mā i ka hiamoe (Kep. 65), Wākea and his companion were fast asleep.

2. To swing, as arms.
Same as kāna, possessive.
To resound from a distance.
A lua fighting stroke. Lit., fish touching human skin. (Also without Ka-.)
To come in flocks, as followers to a generous chief. (Nak. 28.)
Weakened and watery fluid, as coffee, thinned-down milk; to be watery.
See Kahinaliʻi.
Same as kai a Kahinaliʻi (Kin. 6.17.)
Raging sea so dangerous that man cannot survive. Lit., supernatural sea.
Large traveling company. (For. 6:490.)
Hard type of rock, used for adzes.
Indolent, lazy, unskilled; such a person.
To support a sick or intoxicated person between two other persons. Lit., lead like a kite. Same as kauālupe.
An extreme low tide with reef exposed. Lit., dry sea.
See kai a malō
To sit in silence, as at a meeting. Cf. mū, silence. See ex., hākei.
Bonito lure made of shell; bone fishhook; barbless deep-sea hook composed of two small hooks. (Malo 79.)
Same as ʻalā poʻo malu, a basalt.
Dawn; to dawn; to enlighten (used without the article). Cf. ao, daylight. See ex., kainuʻu.
Diaper. Eng.
Tidal wave. Lit., sea of Pele. Also kai hoʻēʻe.
Rising or high tide. Lit., encircling sea.

Name of a long prayer used after the kauila celebration at a temple dedication, probably short for poʻo kea, white head or bleached skull, since the sea water (kai) used was held in a skull (Malo 167, 168, 181.)
Sea where a moving current is visible. Lit., current sea.
Sea too deep to walk in Lit., swimming sea.

1. Community, neighborhood, village.

2. Name of a pleasant, gentle trade-wind breeze, famous in song, at Wai-ʻanae, Oʻahu.
To move slowly along.
Rising tide; sea washing higher on land than usual. Lit., rising sea.
Tidal wave. Lit., mounting sea. Also kai hoʻēʻe, kai a Pele.

1. To scatter or stir up, as dust or dirt; tossed, as spray; to moisten or sprinkle with fine drops of water, as of poi being pounded. Cf. ehu.

2. To prod or poke sideways, as in digging, to prod loose; to discharge, as a servant.

3. Star name. (Johnson and Mahelona 44.)
To disturb, bother.
Same as kai helo.
Ebbing sea. Lit., decreasing sea.
To walk with feet far apart, as an infant; to straddle, as on a horse.
To take life philosophically as it comes, sometimes in poverty, sometimes in wealth.
A poetic expression referring to the channels between the islands; always follows nā. Eight is a formulistic number.
Group of relatives who faithfully serve and care for a chief during illness; perhaps related to ʻiewe, placenta.
Receding sea or wave.
Taboo place along the shore where outcasts (kauwā) or breakers of certain taboos were drowned that they might be offered as sacrifices; one such place was at Kewalo in Honolulu. Lit., slippery sea.
To walk, move, proceed, walk in line or in succession, as of a parade; to walk holding on to something or with uncertainty, as a child learning to walk; to move, as in checkers.
Any place in the sea or on the reef where a footing may be obtained. Lit., sea walk upright.
Sauce, as made of crushed shrimp and coconut cream. Lit., red sauce.
Same as kaʻi hoʻi.
Flowing sea, especially one that goes through a sluice gate into fish ponds.

1. Dizzy, dizziness.

2. To refuse to pay losses or forfeit, as in a game; to use another's property without permission; to usurp.

3. A fine meshed fish net, similar to kāʻili. (Malo 213.)
Var. of kai eʻe.
Deep sea; high tide.
Ebbing sea. Lit., returning sea.
To exit dancing, as in a hula.
Running sea or current.
Calm sea water, especially as left to evaporate in a pool so as to form a crust of salt.
Parade, procession; to march in a parade.
Sea with strong current, undertow.

1. A type of stone (no data). Lit., the snout of the pig.

2. A lua fighting stroke. (Also without Ka-.)
To drag along; to force to go against one's will.

1. Smooth, unwrinkled. Rare.

2. Smallmeshed net. Cf. ʻiʻi, small.
Hard, rigid; stingy, close-fisted, hard-hearted, harsh; to refuse help; to deny a request; to strut pompously; persistent. Cf. ʻiʻī, hard.

1. Sea-urchin sauce (the crushed shells were placed in salted water; afterwards the liquid was usually strained and added to the flesh of the ʻina).

2. Lavender, reddish-purple, so called because of the color of the sauce.

A climber (Strongylodon ruber, misidentified locally as S. lucidus), in the bean family, endemic in Hawaiʻi, with three-parted leaves and large seeds. The flowers are clustered, red, and shaped like narrow beaks. (Neal 440, 461.) Also nuku ʻiʻiwi.
Cider. Eng.
See kaika
Cultivated patch; bank of taro patch.
Rare var. of kakaʻikahi.
To lead, support, lift up; raise. Cf. kaʻi 1.
To lead against the will, as a young child; to lead here and there without permission; to waddle, move with difficulty; to carry about everywhere.

Younger sibling or cousin of the same sex, as younger brother or male cousin of a male, or younger sister or female cousin of a female; sibling or cousin of the same sex of the junior line, whether older or younger. Cf. kaina.
Carrying, leading, etc.
Relative of a junior sibling line.
Caesar. Biblical Gr.
Salt water and ʻōlena root used to remove evil influences. Lit., freeing salt water.
Girl, daughter, niece, lass.
Plural of kaikamahine.
Strong sea. Lit., male sea.
Creeping with age; aged (a proper name in some legends for an old hag). (HM 263–4.)

1. Sap, sapwood. (And.)

2. Fat, as of pork. (Isa. 34.6.)

3. White sea foam, especially as washed up on a beach.

4. Enema composed of sea water and raw crushed kukui nuts. Also kaikuehu and kaīkū.
Station of the cross (Catholic); procession of the cross.
Tide beginning to flow in. Lit., shooting sea.
A wasting disease, emaciation. (AP)
Policeman. Rare.
Sea with a strong current.

1. Fat sauce, as made from the liver of the parrot fish (uhu) and eaten with the flesh of the fish.

2. Watery fluid of the bowels.
Brother-in-law or male cousin-in-law of a male; sister-in-law or female cousin-in-law of a female. Cf. koʻeke.
Sea too shallow to float a canoe but good for seeking shellfish. Lit., thumping sea, because the canoe thumps the coral.
Shallow sea within the reef, lagoon. Lit., reef sea.

One so old that he is carried in a net; bedridden (a favorite figure of speech; cf. kani koʻo)
To enter dancing, as in a hula.

Straits. Lit., space sea.

1. Mid-tide.

2. Enema. Cf. kaikea 4.
Countryman; backwoodsman; sparsely inhabited place; countrified, rustic. Lit., back person. Cf. kuaʻāina.
Older sibling or cousin of the same sex; sibling or cousin of the same sex of the senior line, whether older or younger. (See kuaʻana.) Cf. .
See kaikuaʻana
Sister or female cousin of a male. (See kuahine 1.) hoʻo.kai.kua.hine To claim a kuahine relationship; to address and treat as a kaikuahine, as from affection.
Enema. Cf. kaikea 4.
Brother or male cousin of a female. (See kunāne.) Cf. .
A rough sea with undercurrent, as pulling back and forth on a beach, undertow. Cf. kuolo, rub.
Guards posted at the entrance to the hale nauā enclosure (Malo 191.) Emerson (Malo 200) lists this as kaikuone.
Same as kūʻono, inlet, bay.
Var. spelling of kaikuahine. (Kin. 12.13.)
See kai 1.
Style, fashion; stylish. Eng. Kū i ke kaila, stylish, fashionable.
Very dark ocean water. (And.) Lit., fire charcoal sea.
Fishing grounds.

Runner on sweet potato vine; string of fish, string or fiber of any kind on which fish are strung. Also kālī.

1. To snatch, grab, take by force, seize, abduct, usurp; to gasp, labor for breath. (See song, Elbert and Mahoe 58–9.) Kāʻili malū, to seize or abduct secretly, kidnap.

2. To cast for fish.

3. Fine net as used for ʻōpelu fishing. (Malo 212.)
Redup. of kāʻili 1, 2; snatching, pulling, especially of a newly carved canoe hauled from the mountains to the sea. Cf. kaula kāʻiliʻili.

1. To march in step or proceed in unity, as soldiers; to lead together.

2. To divide. (Luke 22.17.)
To plunder, rob, seize, as in premeditated violence. Cf. kāʻili wale.
To die suddenly, as by stroke or accident.
Tutelary star of Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.
To plunder, rob, seize, usually without premeditation. Cf. kāʻilikū.
Inland Sea (Japan).
Sea where octopuses are caught with lure, Fig., the deep sea.
Thyme (Thymus vulgaris), from southern Europe, a small plant with small leaves, in the mint family, used to flavor food. (Neal 734.) Eng.
Sea at a point or cape.

1. Low tide

2. Dead Sea.
Corpus Christi procession, so called because first communicants march. Lit., parade for-the-first-time.
Quiet sea, as in a calm cove; low tide.

Ceremony initiating boys, usually at age of six, after which they were permitted to wear a malo and join the men in the mua, men's house; henceforth they might not eat with women; to perform the ceremony. Lit., thrust to the mua house.

var. of kai koʻo, strong sea; to be such.

1. Odorous, either fragrant or otherwise; to make an odor. Rare.

3. To fish, as for uhu, parrot fish, with a square net or ulua with hook and line but no pole; net or nets dropped in a semicircle in shallow water, as for mullets or ʻōʻio.
To roll, whirl, turn over; to revolve, as a wheel; to turn aside, deviate; rolling, turning, etc. See maka kakaʻa.
To shift or roll, as the eyes.

1. Name of a place at Kohala, Hawaiʻi, celebrated in song for the tests held there for the presence of sharks: ti stalks (ʻau kī), whose bark had been beaten off (kākā), were thrown into the water; if the stalks were pulled under this was a sign of the presence of sharks and the natives climbed the steep cliff trail rather than swim.

2. Name of a stroke in lua fighting.
Redup. of kaʻawale.
Spry, lively, quick; to run. (And.)

Handle, as of a bucket, pot, basket, purse; strings by which a netted (kōkō) calabash is hung; woman's scarf (Niʻihau); to tie on; to encircle with a band, specifically, to stretch the taboo cord before the entrance of a chief's house (this cord was said to fall of its own accord if a relative approached).
See kakaiawī, kākailena, kākaioiwi, kākaipū.
To walk along with a group; to follow in line, as chickens after a hen; procession; litter, as of pigs. Cf. kakaʻi pali, kaʻi.

1. Bow for shooting arrows; crossbow; the shooting of a bow; bent, as a bow; to shoot, as a bow.

3. Redup. of kaka 1.

4. A sweet potato, usually qualified by the terms ʻili paheʻe, smooth skin, or ʻili pohole o Keawe, scraped skin of Keawe.

Our, ours (a-form, plural, inclusive). (PNP taʻa tatou, PCP taa taatou.)

1. Knifelike cartilage near the tail of some fish, as surgeonfish; horn of a fish; cockspur, thorn; rostrum, as of a shrimp; caudal or anal horn, as of a caterpillar; sharp, rough, thorny, craggy; spines on fish fins. Fig., rough, ill-natured, harsh. See kala 3, 4; ʻōkakala.

2. Octopus hook used with a stone sinker and a cowry shell.

3. Surf comber; to form combers; to blow in gusts.

Creepy sensation due to either cold or fright; to have goose flesh, shuddery feeling. Rare.

1. Thorny. (Kin. 3.18.) Lei kākalaioa, crown of thorns [as worn by Christ].

2. Gray nickers (Caesalpinia major, misidentified locally as C. crista), a straggly bramble, a pantropical vine indigenous to Hawaiʻi, with thorny branches and leaf stems and with small yellow flowers. Within each large spiny pod are two or three gray marble-like seeds, which are used for leis, also powdered for medicine.(Neal 433.) Also hihikolo.

3. Yellow nickers (Caesalpinia bonduc), today commonly called Hawaiian pearls, similar to the gray nickers, but with yellowish-gray instead of gray seeds. (Neal 433–4.) Also hihikolo. See kinikini 3.
Cormorant. (Kanl. 14.17.) (Gr.

Similar to konā. Ka-laʻe peʻe kākonakonā, Ka-laʻe hides and avoids contact [said of the timid kauā, outcasts, of Ka-laʻe, Molokaʻi].
To uphold, support, favor, assist, prop up; to bind, as with a sash or belt; support, aid, recommendation, girdle. Cf. koʻo, support.
pro. We (inclusive, three or more).

1. The barracuda (Sphyraena barracuda), as long as 60 cm. Also kūpala.

2. Gourd calabash, as used for fishing (HP 208).

3. Weft strands of mat, so called because the strands are worked (kā) to run up (kū) from the worker. Cf. kāmoe.

4. Short for kākūʻai.

1. To bind or fasten on, as a sarong or belt. Cf. hahau kākua.

2. To worship the gods, especially by food offerings; to appeal to the gods.

To sacrifice food (fish, bananas, kava) to the gods, as at every meal; to feed the spirits of the dead; to deify a dead relative by food offerings and prayer; to dedicate the dead to become family protectors (ʻaumākua) or servants of ʻaumākua (Beckwith, 1970, p. 123); to transfigure, transfiguration (Kam. 64: 64, 91). (Contraction of kākua ʻai.) See kino ahi.
Same as pāʻū-o-Hiʻiaka, a beach vine.

Saturn. Eng.

1. To loosen, untie, free, release, remove, unburden, absolve, let go, acquit, take off, undo; to proclaim, announce; to forgive, pardon, excuse; to substitute for (Kin. 22.13); counter-sorcery or sorcerer, proclamation, public crier, announcer; prayer to free one from any evil influence; to practice counter-sorcery. See kala ʻōpelu, limu kala.

2. Screwdriver.

3. Surgeonfish, unicorn fish, Teuthidae; Naso hexacanthus, N. unicornis, N. brevirostris. Varieties are qualified by the terms holo ihu loa (long nose running), lemu (buttocks), liʻiliʻi (also pahi kaua), lōlō, maoli, moe, palaholo. See hiʻikala.

4. Rough, as sharkskin.

5. Same as kākala 1–4.

6. Long ago (usually followed by loa, wale, kahiko; when preceded by ʻaʻole, ʻaʻoe, or ʻeʻoe, it means “quite a while ago,” or, “for quite a long time.” E kala loa ka holo ʻana o ka moku, the ship sailed long ago.

7. Same as hākala, gable.

8. Same as pua kala, prickly poppy.

9. See limu kala, seaweeds. For a pun on kala 8 and 9, see Neal 367.

10. A sweet potato. Kinds are qualified by the colors keʻokeʻo and poni.

11. Same as ʻākala, a raspberry.

12. Same as pākalakala, a tern.

13. Collar. Eng.

1. Taro (Colocasia esculenta), a kind of aroid cultivated since ancient times for food, spreading widely from the tropics of the Old World. In Hawaiʻi, taro has been the staple from earliest times to the present, and here its culture developed greatly, including more than 300 forms. All parts of the plant are eaten, its starchy root principally as poi, and its leaves as lūʻau. It is a perennial herb consisting of a cluster of long-stemmed, heart-shaped leaves rising 30 cm. or more from underground tubers or corms. (Neal 157–60.) Specifically, kalo is the name of the first taro growing from the planted stalk; names of generations as listed for Hawaiʻi Island (Kep. 153) are kalo: see ex., palili, ʻohā or muʻu, ʻaʻae or ʻae, ʻōnihinihi, kokole, pahūpahū.

2. Same as kalokalo.

A large-leafed weedy plant (Adenostemma lavenia), known in many tropical regions, belonging to the daisy family. Whitish flowers are borne in small round heads in open clusters. In Hawaiʻi, the leaves are used to treat fever. (Neal 829–30.)

1. A large tree (Calophyllum inophyllum), at home on shores of the Indian and western Pacific Oceans, with shiny, oblong leaves to 20 cm long, white flowers much like orange blossoms, and globose green fruits about 2.5 cm in diameter. The wood is hard and was formerly made into calabashes. (Neal 585–6.) Also kamanu, tamanu.

2. Smooth, shiny, polished, as of kamani wood.
Same as hoʻokamaniha.

The false kamani or tropical almond (Terminalia catappa), a tree from the East Indies grown widely in the tropics for ornament, shade, timber, and edible nuts. It thrives along sandy shores. (Neal 627.) Lit., introduced kamani.
Same as kamani haole.
Salmon. Eng.
Canned salmon.

A multitude of descendants; one of the names for the wondrous (kāmehaʻi) goddess Haumea, who presided over childbirth. She was thought to have borne numerous children to one husband, then to have gone to Kahiki, later returning as a young woman to bear numerous more children; she did this for many generations; hence her name is synonymous with prolificness.
Cement. Eng. Puna kameki, cement.

See "hoʻokananeʻo":  To disregard, as instruction, warning, danger, careless of danger, indifference to discomfort or health. See ex., puʻumake. Hoʻokananeʻo hoʻi ka hele i ka pō, ā laʻa lā i ke anu, insisting on going out at night against advice, then got a cold.

Law, code, rule, statute, act, regulation, ordinance, decree, edict; legal; to obey a law; to be prohibited; to learn from experience. Fig., ti leaves, as used in religious ceremonies as a plant respected by spirits. Since some early laws concerned water (wai) rights, some have suggested that the word kānāwai is derived from wai, water; this seems doubtful in view of the many ancient edicts of gods that have no relation to water (also cf. wai 4 and derivatives). Perhaps the most famous kānāwai is the kānāwai kaiʻokia promulgated by the god Kāne after the flood of Kahinaliʻi, promising that ever afterwards the sea would be separated (ʻokia) from the land (i.e., not encroach on the land). Persons swore oaths by this and other kānāwai. The kānāwai of Kū was that no one might lean backwards (kīkiʻi) during ceremonies; that of Ku-kaua-kahi that no one might bend forward (kūpou); that of Kānehekili, that no one might whisper (hāwanawana) during 
ceremonies; that of Ka-hō-aliʻi, that the white kāʻupu bird (kāʻupu kea) must be used as his symbol during the makahiki. See below and Kam. 64:13–17 and note 9.
Notes on the scale. Rare.
Penal code. Lit., laws for punishing crime.
Revised statute.
See kaiʻokia, kānāwai.
Unwritten law, common law.
Civil laws or code.
Military law, martial law.

1. Book of Deuteronomy. Lit., two laws, i.e., a repetition of the laws of Moses [the Hawaiian term is a translation of the Latin and Greek names for this book, Deuteronomium and Desuteronomion].

2. Rules for lua fighting.
Common or customary law.

1. Small endemic trees (Broussaisia arguta), with large, oval, toothed leaves, in the saxifrage family; the small flowers and berries are arranged in wide, convex clusters. The flowers of one form have bluish-green petals; of another, red, another white, An old belief was that eating the fruit helped in fecundity; the increase of chiefs was compared to a fruiting kanawao. (Neal 380). Varieties are qualified by the colors keʻokeʻo and ʻulaʻula. Also kupuwao, piohiʻa, akiahala, pūʻaha nui.

2. Var. name for nāwao 1, a taro.

3. Hard, striped pebble, found in streams and used in slingshots and as sinkers.

4. An insect.
Same as haʻiwale, a shrub.
Poor, thin, just able to walk. Cf. hīnawe, feeble.
Tinea, a fungus skin disease. Cf. kakane.

1. Male, husband, male sweetheart, man; brother-in-law of a woman; male, masculine; to be a husband or brother-in-law of a woman. See kāne o ka pō.

2. The leading of the four great Hawaiian gods: see HM 42–66. (PCP Taane.)

3. Name of the 27th night of the lunar month.

4. Name of a sacred star, seen by priests as portending great misfortune, as the death of a chief; perhaps a variable like Mira or Algol, or even a nova.

5. Name given at ʻEwa, Oʻahu, for the Tahitian banana known as polapola and hēʻī.
Loss of appetite; to have no appetite; distaste for food.

1. To place, put, hang, suspend, affix, gird on; to set, settle, perch, alight, rest, pose; to enact, impose, or pass, as a law; to levy, as a tax; to ride on or mount, as on a horse or in a car; to board, mount, get in or on; to rise up, appear, as the moon; to place in sacrifice, as a pig; to come to rest, as the setting sun; to arrive, come to pass; to hang up, as a telephone receiver.

Outcast, pariah, slave, untouchable, menial; a caste which lived apart and was drawn on for human sacrifices (these traditional meanings carried great opprobrium). Later it was used in the Bible and in formal correspondence to translate servant. Lesser chiefs who served higher chiefs were called kauā maoli (see aliʻi poʻe kauā). See haʻalele loa 2, lauʻī pekepeke, makawela, and below for insulting names for kauā, and pejorative -., Malo 68–72.

1. A native tree in the buckthorn family (Alphitonia ponderosa), found on the six main Hawaiian islands, with alternating leaves, oblong to narrow and woolly below; its hard wood was used for spears and mallets. (Neal 541.) Its wood was one of three kinds from trees on Mauna Loa, Molokaʻi, that were rumored to be poisonous from that location alone, and were used in black magic. The three trees were called kālai pāhoa; the others were ʻohe and nīoi.

2. A native tree in the buckthorn family (Colubrina oppositifolia), found only on Oʻahu and Hawaiʻi, with opposite leaves, ovate and to 15 cm long. Its hard wood was valued for spears and tools, and was not reputed to be poisonous. (Neal 541.) Called oʻa on Maui. Cf. ʻānapanapa.

3. Taboo ceremony consecrating a temple; ceremonial readorning of images with feathers.

4. Hard, reddish rock resembling ʻalā.

5. A kind of black, tough sugar cane. Also māikoiko, kō ʻeleʻele.

6. See puhi kauila.

Leash. Lit., rope held hand.

2. To rest, hang, be placed.
To sell leis; to hang leis.

Insecurity.

1. To take flight; soaring, on the wing.

2. Exclamation, stress; to accent in music.

1. To show off, play the dandy

1. Pas/imp. of kau 1, 2; hung, suspended, hanging.

2. Name of a star called the chief of the month of Ikiiki because it appears in that month.
To scatter here and there in small quantities; to divide or distribute small amounts.

Equality, equation, equity, justice; equal, impartial, just, mutual, parallel; to balance evenly, make alike, be in a similar situation, treat fairly and impartially, dispense justice; to arrive at the same time (For. 4:293); par.
Southeast.

Probably same as Liolio-i-Wawau, a star name.

1. Ledge, step, jog, as on a cliff. See ex., pali.

2. Southern Cross. Also Newe.

3. All species of an endemic genus (Pteralyxia), small trees related to maile, found only on Oʻahu and Kauaʻi, resembling hōeli (Ochrosia) with its shiny, oblong leaves. Fruits are paired, red, ovoid, and each contains one large winged seed. (Neal 684.)

4. Same as ʻālaʻa (Planchonella), a tree.

5. Same as āulu 5, and lonomea, Sapindus oahuensis, a tree.

6. Neighborhood, locality, place. Cf. kaiāulu.

7. Var. of kaunu.
Names of several stars begin thus; see below.

1. Double canoe, pair, span, yoke, two of a kind; to put together or pair, to yoke or harness together, to double in quantity; coupled. Fig., two-natured. Cf. kaukahi.

2. Name of a month. See Kep. 89.

3. One of the many names for the star Sirius; according to some reports, a constellation. The name may be qualified by the terms koko (said to be Betelgeuse), Lena (Sirius), Mōhaʻi (or Haʻi Mōhaʻi), Okaoka. See Wai-loa. (PCP Takulua.)
Slackness, delay, procrastination, hesitation; to delay, stay, procrastinate; remiss in fulfilling a promise.
To harness or put two horses together.
Ledge or terrace.

Name of the Hawaiian newspaper printed by students of the Hawaiian language at the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa, begun in 1971. Lit., the growing bitter yam [or happiness; see hoi 1 and 2 for word play].
Star name, perhaps same as ʻAʻā, Sirius.
Probably same as ʻAʻā, Sirius. (Cf. Maori Te-Kokota; the present Hawaiian form may have metathesized from an earlier ʻOkaʻoka; Johnson and Mahelona 11.)
Same as ʻAʻā, Sirius.
Var. of kaunu waha.
To decorate, adorn, especially with greenery. Cf. uluwehi.

1. Glowing, bright-colored, colorful.

2. Swarming; innumerable.

3. Taboo ceremony in honor of the akua loa, long god, of the makahiki festival.
Star name, no data. (Johnson and Mahelona 43.)

1. Heavy; weight, heaviness. Fig., sad, wretched, dismal, dreary, downcast, troubled, depressed; grief.

2. Sacrifice, offering; to make a sacrifice or offering. See ex., nikiniki 2.
Food offering to the gods.
Very heavily laden; bearing a heavy load, especially of one drenched with water. Fig., extremely sad.
Native mistletoes. Also hulumoa.
Period or time of sickness.
Similar to kau ka maka: see maka 2.

Ocean sunfish (Mola mola). Lit., big eyes placed.

1. Paper mulberry too old to be used for tapa

2. Method of catching birds by tying a caterpillar and a stick at one end of a string; when the bird swallows the caterpillar the stick lodges in his throat.
Regular session, as of legislature.
Hanger for ʻumeke, bowls.
Marks showing rhythm in songs. Rare.
Rack to hold fish poles.
Stick about 10 cm long with holes down its middle, used to hold gunwales in place while they are being sewed on with sennit.

1. To splice, mend a fracture with a splint; to fasten canoe gunwale; wooden canoe clamp.

1. Too short; shrinking away, as in distaste.

2. Count (title of nobility). Eng.;

3. Chanting.

num. Four (formerly tubers were counted by fours; four was a formulistic number). (See pākāuna.) Nā wahi kāuna ʻoʻopu (Kel. 51), several foursomes of ʻoʻopu fish.
Countess. Eng.

Quotation marks.
Var.of kaunalipo.
Same as kauana Lipo.
Perseverance; to persevere.
Var. of kaulana.
To discover, perceive (Oih. 27.39).

1. A native dodder (Cuscuta sandwichiana), belonging to the morning-glory family, a leafless, parasitic vine, growing densely on other plants. The numerous, slender, orange stems are used for orange leis to represent the island of Lā-naʻi, as designated by the Territorial legislature in 1923.

2. A mollusk (Vermetidae). Also kaunoʻa. In adult stage it becomes solidly fixed to rocks; cuts resulting from stepping on it are considered deadly poisonous by Hawaiians. The mollusk was believed somehow related to the dodder. Also kio, unaʻoa.

3. A coarse, tough seaweed (Galaxaura rugosa), calcified and inedible, resembling kaunaʻoa 1 in being yellow to gold in color.
Same as kaunaʻoa lei.
Same as kaunaʻoa 1.
Same as kaunaʻoa pehu. Lit., mālolo (flying fish) kaunaʻoa, so called because this plant was spread over mālolo caught in a canoe to keep them from escaping. Sometimes called mālolo or pōlolo.

A greenish-yellow dodder vine (Cassytha filiformis), belonging to the laurel family, cosmopolitan in the tropics. It is coarser than the native orange dodder (Cuscuta sandwichiana). Lit., swollen kaunaʻoa. Also kaunaʻoa mālolo, kaunaʻoa uka.
Same as kaunaʻoa pehu. Lit., upland kaunaʻoa.
Countess. Lit., female count (Eng.).
Slow, lagging, delaying.
To hang short. Cf. neʻineʻi, ʻekekeʻi.
Holding on precariously. Lit., resting on the edges. Also kaunukunuku.

1. Var. of kaunaʻoa 1–3. (Niʻihau.)

2. A rough seaweed (Galaxaura rugosa). Cf. pākalakala.

1. To make love; to love; thrill of love, passion; to be fascinated, absorbed.

2. Var. of kaulu 6.
A large Hawaiian bird. (And.)
Same as kaunihinihi.

1. Pole set up as indicative of taboo.

2. A lua fighting stroke.
Insincere love-making.

1. Yolk or white of an egg. Cf. kauō keʻokeʻo, kauō melemele.

2. Loud type of prayer, usually at makahiki festivals. Cf. wōwō, hoʻokāwōwō.
See kauō
An office in the king's train (And.); unarmed spy in enemy country (Malo 202, Emerson note; also kaukoʻe).

Order, command, demand, testament, decree, precept, will, message, statement; to order, command, direct, send for, subscribe, dictate, assign, decree, entrust, bequest, commit into the hands of; to summon, to order, as groceries or goods.

Old Testament.
Same as ʻōhiʻa hā.
White of an egg.

Var. of kauālupe.
Yolk of an egg.
Name for the star Sirius.
Name of a star.
To drag a canoe, especially if unfinished, from the mountain forest to the shore to be finished.
To walk straight. Rare.
To appear irregular or crooked.
Common var. of kaupoku.

Boundary, barrier, partition; dam; to serve as a boundary; to thrust aside, parry, limit; to cover an oven, especially with rocks on its edge to keep earth out; to disown or sever relationship. Lit., place ward off.
Blockage, barrier, etc.
To draw the color line; to show race prejudice. Lit., to make a skin boundary.
To limit, mark a border or boundary, restrict, moderate, set a deadline; limitation, deadline, ration.
Birth control.
Fence or boundary between one patch of land (waena) and another.
Scales, weight; to weigh. Fig., to consider, judge, estimate. Lit., place pound (Eng.). See ex., puka 7.
A generation back. Cf. kau ʻapaʻapa.
To limp. Rare.
Molokai term for taro patch (D. Barrère).
An edible brown seaweed (Chnoospora pacifica), with many slender branches. Also wāwahiwaʻa.

1. Humble, timid and cringing, crushed; to walk in a feeble, wobbly manner, as a sick or aged person.

Crisscross, interwoven.
Beloved wife or friend, beloved friendship united in such close relationship. Lit., place clinging.
A variety of native bananas, perhaps named for the place on Maui. Also waimūhea.
Median canoe-bow cover.

1. Ridgepole, highest point, roof, ceiling, attic; to set up a ridgepole. Fig., greatest. (Often used without ke; see ex., home, ʻōlepe pū.) Kiʻekiʻe kaupoku o Hanalei, the high ridgepole of Hanalei [said of conceited or willful persons; a pun on a place name at Hanalei].

2. To thatch.
Second ridgepole placed above the main ridgepole. Lit., rat ridgepole.
Anything placed on the shoulder, as a cloak or musket; to place on the shoulders, to shoulder.

1. Perhaps Laysan albatross (Diomedea immutabilis); it breeds on the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands, Niʻihau, and Moku Manu. See song, Elbert and Mahoe 65.

2. A native rather narrow fern (Polystichum hillebrandii) with scaly stems, the fronds twice divided. Also papaʻoi.

1. Same as ʻōpua.

2. Sport: swimming or diving for half-submerged objects, formerly gourds, today noni or citric fruits or green coconuts or papayas; to play this game. (Malo 233.)
To place flowers, especially on graves.
Lasso suspended from bough or gate to trap cattle.
Var. spelling of kauā.
Arbitrator.
paucal article and n. Some, a little, a few; something; some place. Cf. kau 12; wahi; kekahi.
To put or place for no reason; to ride free of charge; to ride bareback.
To jiggle, joggle.

1. Covering of ti leaves made with the stems tied together, and the leaves spread out fanwise, formerly used on the oven, replaced today by gunny sacks. Also kauwewe, kawewe.

2. Ruffle for the neck, as worn by Elizabethans.

Southwest. Eng.
Summer, hot season.
Grass, weeds hanging over fresh water.
Var. of kauwele.

1. Leaping place, as a precipice from which a swimmer leaps into a pool.

2. To assassinate, strike in the dark, kill and rob.

3. Site of a jail in Ka-lihi, Honolulu.
Distance between two points; length of time (Kel. 129).

1. To cast overboard from a canoe, as fish nets or as a victim to be executed at sea; a method of deep-sea fishing with nets.

2. Call of the curlew bird, believed to say: “I kāwaʻa, e holo, ua nui ke kai o ke aumoe, let's do canoe net fishing, sail, the sea is high at midnight.”
Canoe bailer; to bail a canoe.

1. To bring up the foot, as in sitting cross-legged on a mat; to draw to one with the foot; to trip with the foot Rare.

2. Var. name for pāʻaoʻao, a disease.

1. To treat in a mean way, to underrate others and treat them as of no value.

2. Name of a star.
A lua fighting stroke.

1. Kind of stone or coral, as used in polishing canoes, or in rubbing off pig bristles.

2. To pay out a fishline while deep-sea fishing; a binding line. Rare.

3. See Pulelehua Kāwaʻewaʻe.
Unidentified star, no data. (Kuhelani.)
Vacant; hollow; furrowed, as a sea with waves; hollowed, as a log; fissured; gap. Cf. waha, mouth, opening.
A lua fighting stroke. Lit., the mouth of the shark. (Also without Ka-.)
Redup. of kāwaha.

1. Last liquor run off in distillation, very thin and watery (wai), especially of brew made of ti root or cane; extremely weak and watery liquor.

2. Same as maniawai, drowsy.

3. Name of a navigation star (no data).
ns. Extremely watery kāwai.

1. Bonito, little tunny (Euthynnus yaito). Sometimes called pohopoho. Growth stages are kīnaʻu (immature), ʻāhua, and kawakawa (adult). (PCP tawatawa.)

2. Dampish, saturated.
Redup. of kawaū.

1. Scattered here and there, sparse, irregular, inadequate, insufficient; unintelligible, of speech.

2. To throw with force. Cf. wala, to throw, tip.
Upper stroke in club fighting (RC 59).
Redup. of kāwala.
Cavalier. Eng.

1. A variety of sweet potato.

2. , interj. To 
work in unity; exclamation urging people to work together. Rare.
Name of a constellation in the Milky Way. Lit., precipice of Makaliʻi.
Name of a star appearing in the month of Hilina-mā. Lit., the great forests of Life.
Damp, wet with cold, moist with fog, humid; wet, as in a cold sweat. Cf. ū (moist), maʻū,koʻū.

1. Same as waʻu, to scrape.

2. Name of a star.

3. Same as heaʻe, a variety of Zanthoxylum dipetalum, the wood of which was used for tapa-beating anvils.

4. Same as pūkiawe. Lā-naʻi, Maui.

5. Same as uhiuhi, a tree.

6. A native holly (Ilex anomala), a rather common shrub or tree, with shiny, oval leaves and panicles of small, white flowers and small, round, black fruits. (Neal 528.) Also ʻaiea.

7. To detain, delay, keep back. (AP)
Type of stone from which sinkers for octopus fishing were made. (Malo 19.)
A kind of fish. (And.)
To work or act slowly and in moderation, as in paddling a canoe or farming; slow, lingering, as disease.

1. Kind of chant with clear, distinct pronunciation, somewhat like kepakepa but slower; to chant thus.

2. A hula step: one foot makes a half circle forward and to the side without touching the floor; usually in combination with other steps as the holo or ʻuwehe; to do this step. Often called ʻai kāwele, kāwele style.

3. Towel, napkin, dishcloth; to wipe or dry with a cloth. (Eng., towel.) E kāwele mai i ke pā, dry the dish.
Sphyraena helleri, a smaller relative of the kākū, a fish. See saying, hauhili.
Bath towel.
Washcloth.
Same as kōwelokā.
Dish towel; to wipe dishes with a towel.
To mop or wipe with wet cloth or water.

1. Ropes, especially those attached to ʻiako, outrigger booms, to assist in righting a capsized canoe; lines attached to a fish net; person or canoe at the head of a line being pulled. Fig., to recall something almost forgotten; dim memory. Also kākāwelewele.

2. Goatee.

3. Redup. of kawele.

4. Redup. of kāwele.
A variety of sweet potato.
Name of a star said to rise during the month of Hilinehu, and to be accompanied by the star Ka-malama. Lit., the royal family.
Var. of kōwelokā.
A variety of mountain sweet potato. It has heart-shaped leaves and hard tubers, and is very sweet.
Name of a star that rises with Kau-ka-malama in the month of ʻIkuwā and disappears shortly.
To flutter, whip, as a flag in the wind.

1. A wind-blown grass (Eragrostis variabilis), famous in songs of Nuʻu-anu pali; E. niihauensis on Niʻihau. Also kalamālō and ʻemoloa. (Neal 64.) See song, kehakeha.

2. A hula step, to do this step, which is said to be named for the grass: one foot taps time with the heel, the toes being stationary, while the other foot, flat, steps forward and then a little back, twice or more; the step is repeated reversing the feet. In English this is called the Ka-lā-kaua step because the step is used to begin the hula dedicated to Ka-lā-kaua: Ka-lā-kaua nō he inoa, ka pua mae ʻole i ka lā, a name chant for Ka-lā-kaua, the flower that wilts not in the sun.

3. A seaweed, perhaps Wrangelia penicillata, which resembles the flowering head of Eragrostis variabilis.

4. A type of house thatching.

5. To hang loose, as long hair (Kel. 116).
Name of a star (no data).

1. To clatter, as dishes; to roar, as a sudden downpour; to snap or crackle; such a roaring, clatter, crackling.

2. Same as kauwawe.
To press, wring out, squeeze out, as fruit juice. (Also kōwī. Cf. ʻuwī.)
To mix ingredients, blend; to ensnare birds, as with lime; entwined, interwoven, interlaced.
To entangle, involve, interweave, entwine, interlace.
To mix ingredients, drugs, medicine; pharmacist, druggist.
Bird catcher or snarer; to snare birds.
Flour mill; to grind flour. Also kaʻa palaoa.
Redup. of kāwili.
Sewing machine worked by hand rather than by a foot treadle.
Savoy, common cabbage with curled leaves. Eng.
Seedling; thrifty young plant; sucker, shoot from a parent stalk; to multiply and thrive, as a plant or people. Fig., progeny. See hoʻohua kawowo.
See "hoʻokāwōwō":  To roar, as a wind or waterfall. Cf. wōwō, roar.
Redup. of -kāwōwō; roar, as of thunder or earthquake. (For. 6:444, 445.)

1. definite article, same as ka, often translated “the.” See . For use of ke as an alternant of ka, see ka 1. (PNP te.)

2. Contraction of ka mea e, the one who will, should, or is; the thing that (or which) is, will, should.

3. If, when (in the future; ).

4. A particle connecting certain forms, as hiki and pono, with following verbs.

1. To clang, as a bell or gong; to dingdong, strike, as a clock.

2. To flatten out, adjust to a surrounding level, as in removing a heap of earth. Rare.

3. Player of the pūhenehene game.

4. Same as kā, the interj. (1 Kor. 15.36.)

5. The letter “k'.” Eng.
Rare. suffix. Here and there. See holoholokē, holokē, lelekē.

1. White, clear; fair-complexioned person, often favorites at court (Malo 201); shiny, white mother-of-pearl shell, Cf. keakea,kekea,Mauna Kea.

2. Breast milk. See Nuʻa-kea.

3. A variety of sugar cane, among Hawaiians one of the best-known and most-used canes, especially in medicine: clumps erect, dense, of medium height; pith white. (HP 223–5.) Ua ola ā ʻō kō kea, living until kea cane tassels [until the hair turns gray].

4. Name listed by Hillebrand for kolomona (Mezoneuron kavaiense); see uhiuhi.

5. Share, as of stocks; stocks.

6. Also dea n. Hart, male deer. (Kanl. 12.15.)

1. Cross, crucifix, any crossed piece; main house purlin; sticks connecting canoes of a double canoe. Fig., to hinder, obstruct, intercept, block; obstruction, barrier; baffled (fig.). Used idiomatically like kana 2 and kaʻe 1: ʻA ʻole i keʻa mai ka hahana wela o kēia lā (Kel. 14), there was no limit to the stifling heat of this day. Cf. keʻahakahaka, keʻapaʻa.

2. Hand, as of bananas.

3. Bow, dart; to shoot with bow and arrow (For. 4:259).

4. Male animal reserved for breeding; virile male; sire.

5. Pleurisy. (AP)
Fishhook with more than one barb; small stick with hooks at each end and line in the middle, as used for small fish. Rare.
To saturate, soak in.

1. Abdomen,

2. Ladder with crosspieces, a poetic reference to the ladders used to scale Kauaʻi precipices. Rare.
A native tree (Nesoluma polynesicum), with milky sap and oblong, alternate leaves.
Name of a star that rises in the month of Welehu, accompanied by Ke-ʻalohi-lani. Lit., the firebrand.
A lua fighting stroke; fish was taboo to the learner.
Honorary cross or medal.
See kē 1.

1. Theater, drama, theatrical. Eng. Hale keaka, theater building.

2. Jack (in a deck of cards). Eng.

3. To chat, speak. Eng.
Tragedy.
Semen. Fig., child, seed.
Redup. of keʻa 1; to object, prevent, oppose; disputed.
A lua fighting stroke. Lit., the liver of Milu. (Also without Ke-.)
Pine (RSV), box tree (KJV) (Buxus sempervirens). (Isa. 41.19, Neal 520.) (Heb.
See keakula
Same as ke (verb) lā, but less common.
A stick game like peewee: one player pries a small stick up from the ground with a longer stick, hits it, and tries to run to a point and back before his opponent can catch it. Lit., wooden cross.
Name of a star. Lit., the rolling pathway,
Same as Alanui-polo-hiwi-a-Kanaloa. see alanui.
Same as Alanui-polohiwi-a-Kāne: see alanui.
The star Canopus. Lit., the chief of the south in the heavens. Also Aliʻi-o-Kona-i-ka-lewa.
Name of a star that appears on the night of Hoaka in the month of Kaʻaona after the disappearance of Pau-ahi-lani; it in turn vanishes in Welehu. Lit., the brightness.

A star that rises on the night of Mauli in the month of Welo and continues through the month of Māhoe Mua, when it vanishes on the night of Muku. A ring around it is said to portend a coming revolution. Lit., the heavenly brightness.
See "hoʻoke_amaka":  Selfish, ungracious, as one eating in the presence of others; partial; partiality.
A lua fighting stroke, Lit., the gusty one. (Also without Ke-.)
A specially built place reserved for the high chief on the platform of a double canoe.
Same as Ke-ō-lewa.
Human chest. Lit., solid cross.
Firmament. (Kam. 64:13.)
To shoot or slide arrows made of the stems of sugar-cane tassels.
Red Cross.
A variety of sweet potato.
Name of a southern star, said to be named for an ancient chief.
Perhaps the constellation Pleiades. (Kuhelani.)

1. Crookedness; fault, defect, flaw, deformity; crooked, bent, full of faults.

2. Same as keʻena; nook. Rare.

3. A stone used for adzes.
See "hoʻokēʻē":  To shun, slight, avoid. Cf. kē 1.
Any footrest, footstool, footprint; ground or floor stamped on or trodden on. (Probably keʻe + -hana, nominalizer; keʻehi 1, below, is probably keʻe + -hi, transitivizer. See papa heʻehana and .)
See keʻehana, keʻehi. (Probably PPN teke.)
Footstool (Isa. 66.1), footrest.
To farm at night, especially during the moonlight nights of Akua, Hoku, and Māhealani. Rare.

1. To stamp, tramp, step, tread; to brace with the feet; to rebel against, repudiate; to strike against, to put foot into stirrup in mounting a horse; to trip; not to tolerate, to “put the fool down” in ending a situation to get in by stepping up, as into a vehicle.

Same as ʻaʻe kaʻa.
Haughty, disdainful, assuming an air of superiority. Lit., treading brow. Rare.
Footrest, footstool, position where one stands, stance, firm position, place.
Solution, remedy.
Name of a star visible on the night of Muku in the month of Hinaiaʻeleʻele, rising with Lua-hoʻomoe.

1. Redup. of keʻe 1.

2. Same as kekē, surly, cranky.
Redup. of keʻehi 1.
Redup. of keʻehia.

Great, excessive.

1. Sour, bitter, crabbed, surly, ill-natured, turning against friends (frequently follows ʻōpū, disposition).

Office, room, booth, closet, stall, vault, studio, nook, cranny; drawer of a bureau (rare); department, board, bureau; memory (fig.).

1. Ti, a woody plant (Cordyline terminalis) in the lily family, native to tropical Asia and Australia. It consists of a branched or unbranched, slender, ringed stem, ending in a cluster of narrow-oblong, leaves 30 to 60 cm long, from among which at times rises a large panicle of small, light-colored flowers. The leaves were put to many uses by the Hawaiians, as for house thatch, food wrappers, hula skirts, sandals; the thick, sweet roots were baked for food or distilled for brandy. (Neal 203–4.) Besides green-leaved tis, which rarely fruit, many ornamental varieties are grown in gardens, having leaves wide to narrow, large to small, the colors purple, crimson, scarlet, rust, pink, or green, striped or plain. Red tis may have red flowers and berries. Green ti leaves are still believed to afford protection from spirits and to purify a menstruating woman. (Na_na_ 190–2.) See heʻe 2, hōlua kī.

2. The Spanish needle (Bidens pilosa), a weed from tropical America, a kind of daisy with simple or compound leaves, small yellow flower heads, and narrow black bristle-tipped fruits. (Neal 844.) Also kī nehe. Cf. koʻokoʻolau.

3. To shoot or aim, as with a gun; to squirt water, as with a syringe; to blow from the mouth, as a fisherman spitting chewed kukui nut on the sea to quiet it; to spit, as an angry cat; to travel fast, jet, hurry, especially on horseback (Kauaʻi). Cf. kai kī, kani hoʻo.kī Caus/sim.; to cause to shoot; to sick on, as a dog; to make a cat spit; to snort; emitted. (PCP tii.)

4. Bundle of 40 pandanus leaves, sorted for size and length and set aside for plaiting; to sort leaves for such a bundle.
