Shawl, cape, afghan; cloak of makaloa matting; rectangular tapa garment worn over one shoulder and tied in a knot; bed covering; to wear a kīhei.
Decorated cape. Lit., colored garment cape.
Redup. of kīhei; to wear a kīhei. See ex., pāʻū heihei.
Light bedspread.

Two sheets, as of printed percale or patchwork, sewn together at edges, used as bed covering over the sleeper and under the nicer quilt. In some, the lower edges are left open so that a blanket may be inserted. Lit., clinging covering.
See ʻuhane kīhei pua.
Redup. of kihe 1.
Hook; to hook; to feed poi to a child on the finger, which is bent (like a hook) so as to dislodge the poi.
Short for kiʻihelei.
To scratch. Cf. helu.
Bundle or basket of ti or other leaves, as used to carry sweet potatoes, flowers, etc.
To remove tiny weeds.

1. Outside corner (cf. kūʻono), edge, tip, extremity; apex of an angle; sharp point of a leaf; to turn aside.

2. A variety of sweet potato. Descriptive terms are lau manamana, lau nui, and lau poepoe.

3. Canoes guarding the sides of mālolo and iheihe fish nets.

4. To plug or patch a calabash or canoe. Rare.

5. Kauaʻi name for ʻamakihi, a bird.
To give lavishly. Rare.
Same as kihikau. Cf. kīkaupeʻa.

1. Corners, curves; angular, full of corners, zigzag.

2. Moorish idol, a small, brilliantly colored fish (Zanclus cornutus) with black bands alternating with yellow. Varieties are qualified by the terms lau nui or māneʻoneʻo, alo ʻula, hālena, and pōhaka.

3. A variety of sweet potato.

4. Same as kikihi 1–3.

5. Same as ʻamakihi, a honeycreeper.

1. A sweet potato. Lit., large-feafed kihi.

2. A taro.
Crooked, twisted, angular; to turn aside; one who turns aside, as to avoid others.
Name of one of the places, as under a tapa, where the noʻa stone was hidden in the game of pūhenehene.
Points or edges of the shoulders; shoulder; shoulder of a mountain.

1. Door corner.

2. Name of one of the 
places under a tapa, where the noʻa stone was hidden in the game of pūhenehene.
Slack key (the first and last strings of the guitar are tuned to D, instead of E; the strings are picked individually and are not chorded).
To lead a roving life, without fixed abode, wander; vagabond.

1. Large wood fishhook, as used for sharks and large fish.

2. Large fish net about 20 fathoms long, held by a canoe at each end.

3. Long ti-leaf food package, more commonly called holo ʻai.
Side or bank of a canal or ditch.
Staccato mark (music); small dot or wedge placed over a musical note.
Same as kī hōʻalu.

1. Image, statue, picture, photograph, drawing, diagram, illustration, likeness, cartoon, idol, doll, petroglyph; features, as of a face; plans, as for a house; carved, as end of an ʻauamo pole. Cf. akua kāʻai, hula kiʻi, kaha kiʻi, kiʻi ʻōnohi, naʻanaʻa 1, paʻi kiʻi.

2. To fetch, get, procure, send for, go after, summon, attack; to seek for sexual ends. See maka kiʻi.

3. To try and, go and (idiomatic). See ex., lolelole.

4. Hula step: one foot points to the side, front, and back; then the other foot does the same. Also wāwae kiʻi, fetching step.

5. Same as ʻalani, orange.

6. Gesture, as in hula.

1. See hākiʻi, hīkiʻi, mūkiʻi, nākiʻi, nīkiʻi, all meaning to tie, bind. (PCP -tiki.)

2. See "hoʻokiʻi":  Var. of hōkiʻi, thin, wasted. (Isa. 34.4.)
Idol, image.
Lashing of wall plate to wall post.

1. A variety of taro.

2. A variety of sweet potato.
Gadabout, wanderer; to gad about, wander, on the move. Cf. kiʻinoho.
To stand, sit, or walk with legs wide apart, straddle; straddling.
Illustration, picture. Lit., clarifying picture.
Cartoon. Lit., picture to cause mirth.
Molten or cast image.
Caricature, mocking picture.
Poster. Lit., advertising picture.
Enlargement of a picture.
Slide picture shown on a screen by a projector. Lit., image enlargement.
Scarecrow, terrifying image.
To make gestures in the hula pūʻili and hula ʻulīʻulī imitative of the words of the chant; these gestures.
Carved image, graven image.
To fetch something, as greenery for an altar, with observation of taboos.
Drifting clouds of different colors, including black and white.
Ointment made of breadfruit bark crushed with thin young coconut leaves.

1. Redup. of kiʻi 2.

2. Same as kīkiʻi.
Same as kī. ʻililī 1.
John ʻĪʻī's name for kāʻai, casket. (Ii 155.) Lit., image wicker body.
To make time-keeping hula gestures with the left hand reaching forward and back to the front of the shoulder, while tapping the ʻulīʻulī on the right lap; these gestures.
To ramble in conversation. Rare.

1. To squat on haunches; to perch.

2. To trill, of a bird. Cf. kīʻikikī, kūʻililī.
Two-faced; liar, deceiver; to deceive. Rare.
Bird's-eye view.
See kiʻi 1.
Enlarged, swollen, bloated, as of a rotting corpse.
Pas/imp. of kiʻi 2, 6; war-club stroke. See .
Homebody; to remain at home constantly. Cf. kiʻihele.
Moving picture, movie, cinema.
Pupil of the eye. Fig., beloved person. See ex., kiʻina, loloku, walania.

In a hula, tapping the lap or left hand with the base of the ʻulīʻulī; tapping the palm of the left hand, floor, back of left hand and right shoulder with end of pūʻuli; both are now called in English “common motion”; to do so.
Printed picture, as in a newspaper.
Painting. Lit., painted picture. Eng.
Stone statue; petroglyph.
To go about in idleness and mischief. [Pua was the name of a mischievous goddess of sorcery.]

1. Slippery, slimy, as with mud.

2. Also tita n. Sister. Eng.

3. Also sida n. Cider. Eng.

4. Also tiga n. Tiger. Eng.

5. Also kida n. Cassia. Eng.
Of humble position, lowly.

1. ʻŌpelu fish, when about the length of a finger.

2. Strong, energetic; having authority and force, as a magistrate. Rare.

3. Guitar. Eng.

4. Cigar. Eng.

5. The cigar flower (Cuphea ignea), from Mexico, a small, smooth shrub with narrow, red, tubular, odorless flowers nearly 3 cm. long. The flowers are used for leis. (Neal 617–8.) Also pua kīkā.
Frisky, restless; to jump here and there.
To soar, glide, poise, wheel, skim along, as a frigate bird; to turn aside, detour, veer, deviate; to maneuver, as fighting cocks; to walk along absentmindedly, ignoring everyone.
Redup. of kīkaha.

1. To splash.

2. To speak or interrupt rudely.
Redup. of kīkaha.

1. To strike with spurs, as fighting cocks.

2. To draw up with a hook, as in fishing octopus.
Various species of butterfly fishes of the genera Chaetodon and Cheilododactylus. Varieties are qualified by the terms alo lua and koʻa. See hīlia, kīʻoki, lauwiliwili.
Chicago. Eng.
Pine tree (RSV), fir tree (KJV). (Isa. 41.19.) (Heb.

1. Hip, coccyx bone; posterior; stern, as of a canoe.

2. Same as kīkala moa, a seaweed.
Pyelitis, kidney disease; sacroiliac strain; lumbosacral slipped disks. Lit., sliding hips.
Kind of fishhook.
Name of a seaweed that irritates the throat if eaten alone.
A rare idiom referring to hard-working tenant farmers in 1851.
Flat, thin buttocks.
Cigarette. Eng. See ex., meʻomeʻo.
White tapa made of wauke.
Suspicious, wary; gathering in silence, as fish about a hook they hesitate to bite. Cf. mū, silent.
Strychnine. Eng.
To sit on the heels, squat.
Jitney. Eng. Kaʻa kikanē, jitney carriage.

1. Weed (RSV), tares (KJV) (Mat. 13.25); zizania. Gr. See pōpolo kīkānia.

2. Cockleburs (Xanthium spp.), coarse herbs, bearing tenacious burs about 2.5 cm long. (Neal 838.)

3. Same as kīkānia haole.
Same as lāʻau hānō, Jimson weed.
A kind of nightshade (Solanum aculeatissimum), the round, scarlet fruits used in leis. (Neal 742–3.) Also akaaka.
Spanish clover (Desmodium uncinatum), a weedy, South American perennial herb with small clinging pods. (Neal 451.) Also pua pilipili.
To cover, bury.
Crossbar or beam used to close a door or gate. Lit., beam key.
A mandolin, usually with 12 strings. Lit., Portuguese guitar. (Eng.)
To give freely and with good will. (And.)
Same as kihikau.

A native fern (Cyclosorus [Dryopteris] cyatheoides), with pinnate fronds, 1 m high or more, used for food and medicine. Roots and young fronds eaten raw; the roots grated and salted to taste, slimy like okra. Also pakikawaiō. See ex., kiʻoa. Cf. kupukupu makaliʻi.
Var. of kikawaiō.
Kitty. Eng.

1. To rap, tap, knock; to break open, as with a hammer; to click glasses, as in drinking a toast. See ex., māmane 1.

2. To share.
Back and forth. See ʻōlelokīkē, walakīkē, pākīkē, kīkēʻōlelo. .
Crashing sound, as of lava rock (ʻalā) smiting rock, or as made by an active aa lava flow (PH 38); to sound thus.
To bend, crook; bending, zigzag; perverted.

To knock, rap, tap, pound. Cf. elelū kīkēkē and kīkoni, to tap with a single knuckle.
Same as -kīkē.
Redup. of kīkē.
Citron (Citrus medica). (Neal 482.) Eng.

To contract, shrink; to crouch or squat.
To argue, talk back, banter.

1. Tapa or sarong worn by women under one arm and over the shoulder of the opposite arm.

2. To lean over to one side, to cover one side; to turn to the side; to place in a one-sided manner; on the side, as a tapa or lei worn over one shoulder and under the opposite arm.

3. To bite sideways, snap.

4. Edge, rim, as of a canoe.

5. Pig of one solid color with a spot of another color on the shoulder.

A weed (Cassia leschenaultiana).
Dyspepsia. Eng.

1. A plug shaped like the kepa wedge but with the outer end longer, used in filling cracks in wooden bowls or canoes; to plug a hole, patch a canoe or calabash. (PEP titi).

2. To sting, as a bee; to peck, leap at, as a hen. Fig., to make disagreeable remarks.

3. Same as ʻukīkiki, a fish.

4. To kiss. Eng. Rare.

1. To flow swiftly, spout; to spurt, as water from a hose (cf. kahe wai, flowing water, as in irrigation); to eject, as octopus ink; to do swiftly. See pau kikī.

2. Slimy liquid in the blossom of the mountain ginger.

1. Redup. of kī, to shoot, as a gun; to incite or sick, as a dog; to spout.

2. To do up the hair in a type of knot.

3. Crude temporary basket or bundle, as made of ʻilima, ti, or morning-glory plants and used to carry food. Rare.

4. A bird resembling the plover.

5. Name given a shellfish. (KL. line 33.)

6. A seaweed.

1. Redup. of kīʻalo.

2. To dodge quickly.
Sudden wind gust, squall. Fig., sudden burst of passion.
Same as kiapali.

To run fast, to grow fast. Cf. holo kikī.

1. To lean back; to tilt, heel, as a ship; to stretch out, extend. See kānāwai.

1. Same as ikiiki, stifling.

Teakettle, teapot. Eng.

Acacia (RSV), shittah (KJV). (Isa. 41.19.) (Probably Heb.

Redup. of kimo 2.

1. Urging, insistence. Cf. hoʻokina.

Bent or curved, as a bird beak; humped; to bend or bow the head; to stagger forward, to weave along as a drunk. Cf. ʻiʻiwi, kiwi.

1. Dot, point, spot, speck of any kind; section of a story; cock or trigger of a gun (see ex., ala 2); punctuation mark; dot in music indicating time added to a note, also to repeat; dotted, speckled, spotted; to dot, mark, peck, hatch; to pick up food, as chickens; to injure fruit, as by a fruit fly; tattooed with dots on the forehead.

Spots, stains, blemishes; to stain, spot [contraction of kiko and kohu].

1. Rude, sarcastic.

2. To do in irregular, haphazard fashion, as skipping about while reading; irregular.
Period mark in punctuation. Lit., single dot.

To typewrite; typist. Cf. mīkini kikokiko hua.

Small adze used for smoothing and finishing a canoe; to smooth and finish a canoe; to soften wauke bark for tapa making; to pierce or lance a swelling; to peck; to blaze, as a tree; a piercing, peck, blaze; to rap on the forehead, usually with a single knuckle, especially as a gesture of rudeness or contempt, hence to treat contemptuously. Stork. (Latin Ciconia, a genus.) Also kekoleka.

Span; extent; a measure from the end of the thumb to the end of the index finger; chord of an arc; a bent bow; a long surfboard, 3.7 to 5.5 m long; to stretch, reach or stick out; extend, as the hands, or as a bird its wings; to move; to shoot, as from a bow; to step in order to reach; to pay out money, disburse, draw money from the bank. Rare. var. of kiani.

2. The black mulberry (Morus nigra), introduced into Hawaiʻi in hopes of establishing a silk-producing industry. It is a low tree bearing juicy, sweet, red to black fruits and ovate leaves. The leaves are fed to silkworms, The tree comes from the Far East. (Neal 300.) Lāʻau kilika (2 Sam. 5.23), mulberry tree. Eng., silk.
Short for kilikaʻa 1.

1. A passing, moving shower; to shower lightly and briefly.

Taffeta. Lit., rustling silk.

Redup. of kili hau; to sprinkle slightly.
Redup. of kilihuna, fine rain.

Light, soft, gentle rain; pleasant patter of gentle rain; to rain gently.
Fine, misty rain, somewhat heavier mist than the kili ʻohu. ʻO ka ua kili noe hau o Kēkē, the fine, cold, misty rain of Kēkē.
A vine with small elliptical leaves at internodes of 11.5 cm. According to C. S. Judd, this may be a native climbing shrub (Embelia pacifica), in the Myrsine family. (Neal 665.)
Fine rain and light mist.
num. Trillion. Eng.

To reverberate, rumble.

To put away for safekeeping, as bundles on a shelf. Rare.

One who fishes for octopus by looking through a glass-bottomed box; formerly the kilo heʻe spit chewed kukui nut on the sea to calm the water, then examined (kilo) the sea bottom for octopus; to fish thus. Also ʻōkilo heʻe.
To glance, gaze, as into a mirror (kilo + hi, transitivizer).
Pas/imp. of kilo.
Astrologer, astronomer, astronomy; to observe and study the stars.
To throw away, discard, throw.

Redup. of kilo; enchantment, magic, fortune telling; magical.

Oceanography, oceanographer; to observe and study the open seas.

Hook; to catch with a hook. Cf. lou, hook.
Quiet nook, lonely spot; silent (For. 6:386).

1. A small gourd or coconut shell, usually cut lengthwise, as used for storing small, choice objects, or to feed favorite children from. Used also as a quoit in the kilu game: the player chanted as he tossed the kilu towards an object placed in front of one of the opposite sex; if he hit the goal he claimed a kiss; to play this game. (Malo chapter 42.) In the Bishop Museum are stone quoits labelled kilu. See ex., eo and .

2. Same as pūniu, knee drum.

3. Unpleasant musty odor, especially resulting from a cold in the nose. Also iʻakui, ihu kilu, ihu pilau.

Cymbal. Eng. Also kumepala.

Chimpanzee. Eng.

1. A game similar to jacks: a stone is tossed into the air by the player, who quickly picks another off the ground before he catches the other; jackstones; to play kimo. The players often chanted.

Seaside heliotrope (Heliotropium curassavicum), a prostrate, perennial American herb 30 to 60 cm long, with narrow, hoary leaves, white or pale purple flowers, considered indigenous to Hawaiʻi. Formerly the plants were dried and brewed for tea used as a tonic. (Neal 718.) Also nena and poʻopoʻohina or lau poʻopoʻohina on Niʻihau.

1. Horn of an animal, antler; horn of the kala, a fish; curved object such as a sickle; curved, bent; to pull obliquely, as a fish on a line; to bend forward or sideways, as a sleepy person; to reel and stagger as in drunkenness; to fall or stumble head foremost.

Brazen. Cf. wini.

1. Sugar cane (Saccharum officinarum), a large unbranched grass brought to Hawaiʻi by early Polynesians as a source of sugar and fiber. The thick stems are full of sweet juicy pulp. In time, many different kinds of cane were produced, with many different attributes and names. Cane yields one of the most valuable plant products known. For commercial purposes the yield has been increased by hybridizing with such success that the sugar industry was for many years the largest industry in Hawaiʻi. (Neal 77–9.) For. 5:582–9 lists types of kō, all are listed in the Dictionary except kō malolo (also known as kō puhala and kō ʻailolo).Cf. kea 3.

2. Dragged, towed, wind-borne; long, as a vowel sound; to drag, push, prolong, tow, drawl; to hold a note for several beats in singing or chanting; pull, tug, massage. Cf. kani kō, lawaiʻa kō lau.

3. To fulfill, come to pass, succeed, do, complete, foreclose; to win in dispute; to become pregnant; fulfilled.

4. To break up lumps in poi by pressing against the side of a container.

5. Second note in musical scale, re.

6. A call to pigs, fowl. Also kolo, kolo, kolo.

7. Of (o-rm possessive; ). Note idiomatic use with ā, as far as, plus a direction word: kō ā uka, those of the uplands; kō ā mua, those in the foreground; kō ā hope, those behind.

8. . Your (of one person; singular possessed object; replacing both kāu and kou, often with affectionate connotation; see ). (PCP too.)

1. Brave, bold, fearless, valiant; bravery, courage. Cf. hoʻonakoa, puʻipuʻi.

2. Soldier, warrior, fighter; military, hero, martial.

3. The largest of native forest trees (Acacia koa), with light-gray bark, crescent-shaped leaves, and white flowers in small, round heads. A legume with fine, red wood, a valuable lumber tree, formerly used for canoes, surfboards, calabashes, now for furniture and ukuleles. A small koa was sometimes added to the hula altar to Laka, goddess of the hula, to make the dancer fearless. (Neal 408–11.) The name koa may be qualified by the terms kā, kū ma kua, kū mauna.

4. Name of a wind at Mālei, Molokaʻi. (For. 5:103.)

5. Land crocodile (RSV), chameleon (KJV). (Oihk. 11.) (Pronunciation uncertain.)

1. Coral, coral head. Also ʻākoʻakoʻa.

2. Fishing grounds, usually identified by lining up with marks on shore.

3. Shrine, often consisting of circular piles of coral or stone, built along the shore or by ponds or streams, used in ceremonies as to make fish multiply; also built on bird islands, and used in ceremonies to make birds multiply.
Arid, barren, rocky and unfruitful; dry or tasteless, as overdone meat. Fig., rude, nasty.
Same as kōʻā.
Koa with yellowish wood, regarded as female by Hawaiians. Lit., ginger koa.

1. The tropic or boatswain bird, particularly the white-tailed tropic bird (Phaethon lepturus dorotheae), which inhabits cliffs of the high islands. The red-tailed tropic bird (P. rubricauda rothschildi) is koaʻe ʻula; the white is koaʻe kea.

2. A variety 
of banana. (Neal 249.) Also aʻeaʻe and manini.

3. A taro; varieties are qualified by the colors ʻeleʻele, keʻokeʻo, ʻulaʻula.

4. A snapper, probably Etelis carbunculus, an important commercial fish also known as onaga (Japanese).

5. A variety of sweet potato.

A common roadside shrub or small tree (Leucaena leucocephala), from tropical America, with pinnate leaves, round white flower treads, and long, flat, brown pods; closely related to the koa. The small brown seeds are strung for leis, purses, mats; plants used for fodder. (Neal 411–2.) Lit., foreign koa. Also ēkoa, lilikoa.
Same as kōaheahe. (Nak. 102.)
Blowing gently, as the wind. Cf. kōaniani.

A native tree (Acacia koaia), much like the koa but smaller, the pods narrower and with seeds arranged vertically in the pod, rather than horizontally as in koa, and leaves averaging narrower; the wood is harder, formerly used for spears, fancy paddles, and for the iʻe tapa beater; later for furniture. Fig., person from the upland country. Also koaiʻa. Cf. huʻe.

A morning-glory (Ipomoea indica), a native of Pacific islands, with heart-shaped leaves, flowers opening blue in the morning and changing to pink later in the day. When pounded, the bitter-tasting stems and roots are used externally for bruises and broken bones, but are dangerous to take internally. (Neal 708.) Also koali ʻawahia and koali lāʻau on Niʻihau.
A tropical American weedy vine (Merremia aegyptia, synonym, (Ipomoea pentaphylla) with tawny-hairy stems and leaves, the leaves five-lobed, the flowers white. (Neal 709.) Also kuahulu.

To scratch, claw, scrape; to strike, as a match; to card wool; to strip or split, as pandanus leaves; to clean off pulp, as of mulberry bark; to pull a stick with hooks through the water to impale fish; garden rake, wool carder; stripper for pandanus leaves, formerly a thorn, now either a board with razor blades and phonograph needles over which the leaves are drawn, or a stripping machine. Heat, sultriness; sultry, uncomfortably hot. Fig., physical or mental distress or discomfort; distressed.

1. Small land unit farmed by a tenant for the chief; to be worked as a kōʻele. Also hakuone.

4. Same as kōʻeleʻele, seaweeds.

5. A small pond, reserved for a chief, where fish could be kept alive until required.

6. Less desirable portions of meat or fish. Rare.

Same as māikoiko, a sugar cane.
Pudding made by peeling and mashing cooked sweet potatoes, then adding coconut cream gradually. Also pālau, poi pālau.

1. Remainder, residue, remnant, surplus, scraps, leftovers, balance (in accounts), remains, ruins. Cf. koe 1.

Difference, remainder, as in subtraction.

1. Pacific golden plover (Pluvialis dominica), a migratory bird which comes to Hawaiʻi about the end of August and leaves early in May for Siberia and Alaska. Fig., to repeat, boast; a scornful reference to foreigners (Kel. 70) who come to Hawaii and become prosperous, and then leave with their wealth, just as the plover arrives thin in the fall each year, fattens up, and leaves; a less common figurative reference is to one who claims friendship or kinship that does not exist; in some localities the kōlea is an ʻaumakua; to call kōlea.Cf. hula kōlea and saying, kauhua 2.

2. Stepparent, as makuahine kōlea, makua kāne kōlea.

3. The mottled periwinkle, probably Littorina pintado. Also ʻākōlea, kōlealea, kūkae kōlea, pūpū kolea.

4. Native species of trees and shrubs (Myrsine [Rapanea, Suttonia]) with oval to narrow leaves more or less crowded at branch tips, small flowers, and small round fruits among or below the leaves. Uses: red sap and charcoal from the wood to dye tapa, wood for houses, logs for beating tapa. (Neal 664.)

5. Korea; Korean. Eng.
A native small tree or shrub with small leaves (Myrsine sandwicensis).

A native tree (Myrsine lessertiana) in the rain forests, with narrow to wide, large leathery leaves clustered at branch tips, bearing many small round red or black fruits usually just below the leaves. Wood is not very hard, but was formerly used for house posts and beams. (Neal 664.)

Hawaiian duck (Anas wyvilliana). Also koloa maoli, native koloa, to distinguish it from migratory or introduced ducks, also called koloa. Formerly on all main islands except Lā-naʻi and Ka-hoʻolawe; in 1976 common only on Kauaʻi; birds raised in capitivity and released have been seen on Oʻahu and Hawaiʻi; considered endangered in 1978.

1. Term of address for older sibling or cousin of the same sex, or cousin of the same sex of the senior line of a family; also sometimes used to replace the much more common kaikuaʻana or kaikuʻana. (PEP tuakana.)

2. First brewage of liquor; mixtures following are called pōkiʻi, little brother or sister.
Basin inside the reef; lagoon.
Var. spelling of kuāuna.
Canoe keel.
To wander, stray. Cf. ʻaeʻa.
Same as nēnē, a variety of kava. Lit., turtle back.
Tumor. (Kam. 64:109.) Cf. ʻeho 2.
Silent, still, lonely.
Short for kuaʻaha.

1. Six generations removed. Cf. kua-, kuakahi, kualua, etc.

2. num. Four times, fourfold.
Surging, swelling, as waves.
Anvil, as used by blacksmiths.
Proclamation, declaration; to proclaim, announce.
Large ʻōʻio, ladyfish or bonefish.
Mountain area where trees are stunted as due to altitude.
Awkward.
Var. of kū-hele-mai, a gambling game.
Huge, vast; name of a farm inland from Kai-lua, Hawaiʻi, tilled by Ka-mehameha.
Redup. of kūāhewa.
Same as kuawili.
Redup. of kuahilo.
Gray-headed.

1. Term of address for a male's sister or female cousin, sometimes replacing the more common kaikuahine.

2. (More commonly Tuahine). Name of a misty rain famous in Mānoa, Oʻahu, named for Kuahine, who turned to rain after the murder of her daughter, Ka-hala-o-Puna; the rain is also in other localities. See ex., haʻalulu, haʻanipo.
Mountain, high hill.
Name of a quilting design. Lit., turtle back.
Same as kūhonu, a crab.
Altar.
Hunchback. Lit., swollen back.
Heap, pile; heaped or piled up; rising up, as a whale's back above water. Lit., back heap (āhua).

1. Supporting rods for house purlins (Kam. 76:98), brace. Also ʻaho piʻo kuahui.

2. To cooperate, work together.

1. Same as koali kua hulu, a morning-glory.

2. Any wild vegetable eaten in time of famine; to eat such.
To scour, rub, polish, grind, scrape; to drag a scraping object; to mark a line from which marbles are shot. Cf. kuakuai. (PNP tuai.)
To remove internal organs of animals, disembowel; to clean, as chickens.
To buy, barter. Lit., to stand up food. Cf. kūkālā.
Portion of boom (ʻiako) lashed to the canoe.
Name of a star.
A famous legendary place in the high heavens, a home of the deified dead. (HM 78–80.) See ex., ʻehu 1, māpuna hoe.
To ransom. Lit., to bargain to save life.
Sale.
To flatter, cajole with flattery.
To rub back and forth.

To give up, as a riddle; to be unable to answer; expression used in riddling. The person who can not guess a riddle says: Kuailo! I can't guess the answer, you tell me. If the riddler doesn't want to give the answer, he may reply tartly: ʻEu nō ka ilo, make! Maggots move! Defeated! Kuailo ʻana, answer.
To be devoured by worms (ilo).
Twine, string. Eng.
To turn from good to evil; wicked.
Border or bank as between taro patches or cultivated fields. Cf. ioio.
A strong brew of kava. Cf. kua 8.
See "hoʻokuāʻiʻo":  Same as hoʻokūʻiʻo.
Upper ridgepole of a house above the lower ridgepole (kauhuhu).
Swipes, home-brew, as made of pineapples, mangoes, molasses, or watermelons. Slang. Eng.
To buy or sell at a loss or very cheaply.

1. Long, straight, stone wall.

2. Same as kuāuna.

1. Faded.

2. Same as akakū.

3. Cord, as of wood.

4. Quart. Eng.

5. Quagga (Eng.), zebra.
Boom, boom! ʻO ka ʻili kalakala, ʻili nākolokolo, kūakā ke kani, he kani kūpaukolo (For. 6:412), a rough skin [of shark on a drum], a rumbling skin, a boom-boom sound, a rub-a-dub sound.

1. See lani kua kaʻa

2. Team (horse or oxen) closest to the pulled vehicle. See makamua.

1. Once, singly; first; single, unwedded, unmarried. Cf. moa kuakahi.

2. Three generations removed, as great-grandparent (kupuna kuakahi) and great-grandchild (moʻopuna kuakahi), as distinguished from a great-great-grandchild (moʻopuna kualua) and a great-great-grandparent (kupuna kualua). Sometimes today kuakahi denotes two generations removed.

3. Unobstructed, unhampered, free from interference; straight to the point, without deviation, as a story.

4. Far mythical land, a rendezvous of spirits; homeland of the ancestors.
See "hoʻokuakaʻeo":  Var. of hoʻohuakeʻeo. (For. 5:561.)
One of high birth who stands by a kāhili feather standard, beside the high chief, in contrast to the paʻa kāhili who carries the kāhili.
Same as kūhākakai. Rare.
Medicine made of pua kala plant and taken as treatment for pyorrhea, neuralgia, stomach ulcers.

1. Kind of cloth with white on its edges. Rare.

2. Whorish [especially of Hawaiian women having love affairs with white men]. Lit., becoming white vagina.
Tapa-beating anvil.
See "hoʻokua kapa":  To form a boundary. Lit., make stand border.
Taboo on approaching a chief from behind. Fig., quiet, safe, peaceful, so called because of the protection and security afforded by the taboo. Cf. kuaʻā, kua liholiho, kualoi, kuapala.

Faded, bleached; white and encrusted, salt deposits left by evaporated sea water; foamy; pale, as a person without a healthy color; to bleach white, fade; foam. Cf. kea, white; poʻo kuakea. See ex., hao 4, lōpā.
To stand openly or in public; to take a public stand.
Distant legendary place, as the brink of the nether world into which spirits leaped. Also Leina-a-ke-akua. (Malo 112, Emerson note 114.)
Var. of Kuakeahu. Lit., back of the light.
See "hoʻokuakeʻeo":  Rare. var. of hoʻohuakeʻeo.
Impatient, annoyed, irritated. (Nak. 108.)

To stand with hands on hips or crossed in front, as suggestive of the stance of an image (kiʻi) considered a sign of rudeness and an indication that one wants to lord it over others, or as a sign that one will not cooperate.
Innumerable.
Transformation, as from animal to human form.
Travail of childbirth, especially bearing-down pain; to suffer labor. Fig., uncontrolled anger.

1. Five generations removed, of a great-great-great-grandparent or great-great-great-grandchild, as kupuna kuakolu, moʻopuna kuakolu, for some speakers, four generations removed.

2. Thrice, three times.
Sarcastic; sarcasm.

1. Redup. of kua 2.

2. Strip, especially space between lines of stitching in quilting; embankment between taro patches that was kept under cultivation (Malo 19, Emerson note); leaf midrib; narrow land strip; strip of fish netting; ridged cloth, as corduroy or piqué.
Redup. of kuai. Cf. moena kuakuai kāmaʻa.
Redup. of kūʻai; trade, exchange; for sale; to sell repeatedly; to give for the sake of receiving something in return.
Newly made taro patch embankment; process of packing the earth for the banks and floor of a taro patch.
Redup. of kualau, a shower.
Redup. of kuānea.
Wooden anvil, as used for beating tapa.
Abscess on the back.

1. Somersault; to fall backwards; to turn over and over or upside down; to turn somersaults; to toss with palm of hand up.

2. Interest, usury. See puni kuala.

3. Cooked, unbounded taro (same as kalo paʻa, nēʻū).

4. Pure white mother-of-pearl shell, much prized because of its rarity, as used for fishhooks or lures.
See kuala
Dorsal fin.
Compound interest.

1. Hewer of wood, axman, feller of trees; wooden beam, log, anvil; to hew down a tree.

2. Forest. Rare.
Discount on interest.
Compound interest.

1. A sea creature, perhaps Aplysia dactylomela or A. juliana.

2. To quiver, quake, as jelly.

3. Raw fish mashed to a pulp; to be hand-fed this pulp by the kau method.

4. Swelling, obesity. Rare.
Ventral fin, anal fin.

1. Lazy, indolent, bored, fatigued; roving about without a chief to support one, as a “floater” (lana); to wander.

2. To float on the back; buoyant.
Officer who watched over a sleeping or resting chief and waved the kāhili, feather standard.
Sour, especially of calabashes that have held poi and have not been soaked in the sun after washing.

1. Ridge.

2. To stretch out or project, as a cape.
Same as kuala 3.
Mumble-the-peg.
Pugilist in the high chief's court, a muscular young man who might also be asked to massage a chiefess or have relations with her.
Shower accompanied by sea wind. See ex., pāuli.
Repetitious, confusing in talk and writing.
A great talker; to talk verbosely. Lit., lip chopping.
Short for akua lele.
To stretch, as tapa to free from wrinkles; taut. Fig., to concentrate the thoughts.
White, glistening, sparkling, shining.
Redup. of kuali.
See liholiho.
Dwarfed plant or animal.
Same as kualiliʻi.
Redup. of kualiʻi, to abate, slacken, diminish, grow less.

1. Seven generations removed. Cf. kua-, kuakahi, kualua, etc.

2. Five times, especially said of medicines given once a day for five days or five successive times morning and evening.
Sharp mountain ridge.

1. To block, obstruct, hinder (less used than ālai).

2. Also sualo n. Swallow. Eng.
Anal fin. Cf. hakualo.

1. Pas/imp. of kualo.

2. Reported to be a kind of grass used in thatching.
Taboo on approaching a chief from behind (same taboo as kuaʻā, kuakapu, kua liholiho, kuapala). Lit., critical back.
See kualoi
Faded.

1. Region near the mountaintop, ridge.

2. To overturn, as an unfinished canoe. Rare.
Same as ʻalu.

1. Four generations removed, of a great-great-grandparent or great-great-grandchild, as kupuna kualua, moʻopuna kualua; for some speakers, three generations removed.

2. Twice, second.
Red cords used to decorate a chief's canoe. Rare.
Back of the temple of the head.
Having abundant offspring. Lit., generation of many faces.
Innumerable.
Redup. of kuāmano. (Kam. 64:49.)
Mountaintop.
Motions of turning hinges; motions of sexual intercourse; to turn on hinges.

1. Backbone, spine; road, trail, path (Mar. 1.3); custom, way (Mat. 10.5); canoe keel. Also iwikuamoʻo. (PCP tuamoko.)

2. Clamps used in making or repairing canoes.
Main formation of an army.
Continuous record, history, story, succession of events.

1. A variety of taro. Also kuapapa.

2. Name of a wind accompanied by heavy rain. (PH 166.)

3. Name of a goddess.

4. A tapa used in sorcery ceremonies.
To revile, blaspheme, curse, swear, damn, insult; to chant a curse or reviling song.
Position, attitude; standing.

1. A shellfish, something like the kuapoʻi.

2. Abscess in the back.

3. Hard coral used for polishing.

4. Ti-leaf sandals.
Northern heavens and its stars.
See kuanalio
Same as kauana Lipo.
Surf just before it breaks, wave crest (GP 8) (sometimes used without article).

1. Lonely, forsaken, barren, desolate, dreary. Fig., awkward, unintelligent, ignorant. Cf. kuākuānea, ʻōnea.

2. Star name (no data). (Kuhelani.)
Steep ridge.
Quantity. Eng.
See kuaniki
Parched.
Highly respected. (Malo text, chapter 16, section 15.)
To change, as color.
Thoughtful, meditative, comprehending.
Boom connecting canoe hulls of a double outrigger.
To do a thing grudgingly; bored with a tedious task; tedious, boring; to struggle with a task, as one in which one has no interest.
See kuanui
Stroke in lua fighting.
Kauaʻi name for māono, a basalt.
To fit in place.
Attendant or witness at a wedding. Lit., standing [at the] side.
Verdant mountain, where all thrives and grows.

1. Dashing, slashing, as waves on a shore.

2. Wall of a fish pond.

1. Slave, bond servant; hard labor; oppressed, enslaved; slavish, back-breaking, servile, downtrodden.

2. The chiton (Acanthochiton viridis), a small sea creature used in the māwaewae ceremony for babies.

3. A variety of destructive caterpillar.

4. Parched and dried, as breadfruit. Rare.

1. A taboo chief who had the right to carry a pala fern in ceremonies. Cf. kuaʻā, kuakapu, kualoi.

2. Sacrificial or offering stand for fruit.

3. An inedible moss applied to sores (no data).

4. Rare. var. of kākū, barracuda.

1. Heap, pile; to heap or pile up; heaped up; numerous.

2. Peace, quiet, tranquillity; union under a single ruler; peace following a treaty, armistice; peaceful, secure (usually followed by nui).

3. Same as kuamū 1.

4. Ancient, oldest.
To hew boards or planks; to hew out a poipounding board.
Group of taro patches.
Ox yoke.

1. Belt; to put on a belt. Cf. ʻili kuapo.

2. To swap, exchange, trade. Eng.

1. Weatherboard covering canoe top fore and aft.

2. Shell on back of crab or turtle.

3. Kneepan, patella; bone in arm or hand.

4. Full-fledged, feathered out.

5. A sea mollusk, Umbraculum sinicum.
Eyelid.
Taboo night proclaimed in month of ʻIkuwā during the makahiki festivals.
Small tribute to a high chief.
Belt.
Hoop.

1. Rage, fury, resentment.

2. Deep-sea fishing grounds. (Kam. 76:78.)
Abscess on the back.
Native land, homeland (same as kulāiwi).

1. Hunchback; hunchbacked; hump, as of a camel. See ex., hahaʻi lua.

2. Valve, as of clams.

1. An endemic fern (Asplenium kaulfussii) with oblong fronds about 60 cm. long, with twelve or more pairs of narrow, pointed pinnae.

2. A sea creature (perhaps Aplysia sp.).
Handle, stem, stalk, shaft, stick or mallet used in beating; shank limb of a fishhook.
Shower; to shower.
Latter rain, spring rains. (Ioba 29.23.)
To tread water. Lit., stand bathe.
Advice, counsel; advised.
Genealogy, pedigree, lineage, old traditions; genealogist, historian; to recite genealogy.
According to Emerson, same as lūauʻi.
Needle clamp on a sewing machine. Lit., large needle shaft.
Ribbed or grooved tapa, as made with a grooved board.
Verdant countryside. Lit., green back.
Arm below the elbow.
Bank or border of a taro patch; stream bank.
See kuāuna
Bundle, as of pololū spears.
Leg; shinbone. Rare.
Crank. Lit., turning handle.

1. Valley (awaawa). Used poetically, as follows: Wai-luku i ka malu he kuawa, Wai-luku in the shelter of the valley. Cf. awaawa.

2. Guava (Psidium guajava), a low tree, native to tropical America, naturalized in Hawaiʻi; it bears lemon-sized fruits which are commonly made into jelly, jam, juice and sherbet. Hawaiians make a medicinal tea from leaf buds, which has an astringent effect. (Neal 632–3.) Eng.
Hilly; filled with gullies.
A form of guava with white pulp (Psidium guajava), but otherwise like kuawa lemi. (Neal 632–3.)
Lemon guava (Psidium guajava), a form of guava with sour, pink pulp. Lit., lemon guava. (Neal 632.)
A form of guava (Psidium guajava) with sweet, pink pulp, thicker skin, and larger seeds than kuawa lemi. Lit., sweet guava. (Neal 632.)
A shrub in the carnation family (Schiedea lychnoides), endemic to Kauaʻi; leaves broad-ovate, 4 to 5 cm long, flowers many and small said to be named for a place on Kauaʻi.

1. Dark caterpillar resembling the poko, cutworm, about 5 cm or less in length; it feeds on grass and comes in great numbers.

2. Overexposure to the sun; excessive ultraviolet rays.
Dark in color. (Kam. 64:112.)
Long repetitious prayer said at luakini dedication ceremonies, hence repetitiousness in general; to repeat, wander, digress, perhaps senselessly.

1. Call to attract ʻuaʻu, petrel birds, believed in imitation of their sound.

2. Fishhook with point of hook curved inward almost to the shaft, used for large fish.

1. To push with the elbows, to elbow; to move back and forth, as a piston or as the action of the tide. Cf. haʻakuʻe. (PEP tuke.)

2. Deformed, malformed.
To oppose, resist, protest; opposite, versus, adverse, contrary, antagonistic, unwilling; objection. Lit., stand different.

1. Square. Eng. Kamaki Kuea, Thomas Square.

2. To swear. Eng. ʻŌlelo kuea, oath.

3. Squad (military). Eng.
Star name (no data). (Kuhelani.)

1. Redup. of kūʻē; disagreement, dissension, opposition, quarrel, bickering, animosity; to quarrel, bicker, disagree.

2. Double canoe with one canoe longer than the other. (Malo 131.)

To shake, stir up, as dust; to knock a club from a foe's hands; to toss up, as spray; to brandish, wave; to clear of weeds; to drive off, especially evil spirits (tapa or ti leaves were torn into strips, blessed, and passed over a patient in order to exorcise spirits). Cf. ehu, spray. See Kuehu Lepo.
See kuehu
Redup. of kuehu.
Name of a wind of Milo-liʻi, Kauaʻi. (For. 5:95.)
To shake a tapa in a way that seems innocent but that will bring a curse upon the person to whom the motion is directed. (Kam. 64:141.)
Name of a wind of Nā-ā-lehu, Kaʻū (For. 5:93) and Oʻahu (Nak. 56). Lit., dust scatterer.

1. Sweater. Eng.

2. Quaker. Eng.
To ransack, search.
Sweden; Swede; Swedish. Eng.
See Kuekena
Sound of tapping, tap, as of a mallet on a tapa anvil; to tap-tap.
Elbow, wristbone, joint, knuckle. Cf. kuʻekuʻe lima, kuʻekuʻe wāwae.
Same as kūʻēʻē.
Redup. of kuehu.
Elbow.
Eyebrow.
To push aside; to move back and forth, as a fan belt.
Redup. of kuene.
vt. To shake, tremble, vibrate, swing back and forth, as a waving kāhili, feather emblem.
Able to move only slightly, as one hurt in an accident or as one near death.
Beef joint or knuckle; soupbone.
Ankle joint, heel.
Shiftless; to vagabond. Rare.
Elbow.
Hard, cooked taro. Also kūpuʻu.
See kuelo
Eyebrow. See ex., nunu 2, and saying, ʻeaʻea.
Brow of a cliff.
To attract ʻuaʻu, petrel birds, to a net by imitating their call, kue, kue, kue!
To step back; to walk backward, as from the presence of a chief; to retreat; to shrink back, recoil, flinch, withdraw.
Glowing, burning.
Waiter, steward, treasurer; to wait on table; to supervise, put in order, arrange; to lay out, as measurements for a building.
Waiter.
Waitress, stewardess.
Completely stuffed, packed, as after overeating.
Same as kuekueni.
Insecure, unsteady, unskilled.
Redup. of kueʻo.
Vagabond, exile, wanderer; wandering, friendless, homeless, unstable.
Askew, placed obliquely.
Saliva, spittle, sputum, expectoration; to spit, expectorate. (Ioane 9.6.) Pakī ke kuha, the saliva spatters [said of one who raves and rants, or spits constantly]. (PCP tufa).
To brag, boast.
Shabby, dirty.
Narrow; in straitened circumstances.
Of high position, as one possessed by the gods. Lit., stand perch.
Swollen, fat. Rare.
Redup. of kuha. (PCP tufatufa.)
To find fault with, criticize; dissatisfied. Also hoʻohalahala.
Same as kualakai.
Aerial tubers of uhi, yam, hoi, and related plants.
Many, numerous, as of a crowd; crowded, huddled together. Cf. ʻāluka, crowd.
Each of two gable posts in the old Hawaiian house.
Lazy, indolent, do-nothing. Lit., condition of doing nothing.
A mat motif consisting of red bands internally enhanced with a continuous row of white lozenges.
Standing alone, independent. Fig., unusual, extraordinary, as rain from a clear sky.
Resembling partially; of varying or unmatched size or appearance. Lit., partly fit.
Redup. of kūhapa.
Weak, tottering, feeble.
To harangue, talk on and on urging a point but not saying much, Cf. haʻu, to puff.
Short for kuahaua, proclamation.
Redup. of kūhau.
Redup. of kūhaʻu.
Children of a high chief by a secondary wife or of second degree collaterality.

1. Same as ʻōkuhe, a variety of ʻoʻopu, a fish.

2. Of changed color, as of a bonito that is caught; black-and-blue, as after a bruise.
Var. of kāhea, to call.
Bird imitator; fowler (Sol. 6.5).
Same as laukahi, a weed.
Redup. of kuhe 1, 2.

1. An unbroken swell of the sea, drifting in without breaking; to sweep along as the sea.

2. Game played with sharp ʻūlei sticks.
Weak, feeble.
To get up and go.
Name of a gambling game.
Same as hepa, moronic.
Redup. of kūhepa.
Sudden attack, stroke, as of heart failure; apoplexy; sudden wind gust; suddenly attacked by a stroke; hit without warning or in error; to strike.

1. To point, gesture, as in speaking, directing an orchestra, or dancing the hula; gesture, pointing.

2. To suppose, think, infer, presume, assume, expect, surmise, imagine.
Pas/imp. of kuhi 1, 2.
An endemic lobelia (Lobelia hypoleuca), 60 to 120 cm high, with narrow, white-backed leaves 30 to 45 cm long, and bluish flowers in racemes. (Neal 815–6.) Also liua, moʻowahie.
Certain priests of Lono who marked land boundaries with ʻalaea coloring; to mark thus.
To explain a meaning.
To suppose wrongly, err in judgment, give wrong directions; to mistake a person for someone else; erroneous supposition, illusion. See ex., laʻahia.
To censure, condemn, especially of innocent persons; to involve, entangle, embroil, Cf. hihia.
To point out, direct.
Blundering, off one's course; to give wrong directions.

1. Redup. of kuhi; to show, demonstrate, designate, prescribe, teach, give orders; to direct heiau ceremonies; one always giving orders (Kep. 105); reference, direction, prescription, exponent; bossy. See kuhikuhi hewa.

2. Sweet, tasty, fat. (PCP tu(f,s)i.)
Work program.
Redup. of kuhi hewa; to misdirect, misinform.
Directing, pointing out, gesturing, reference, instruction, program, director.
Redup. of kuhinia.

Seer, soothsayer, necromancer, especially a class of priests who advised concerning building and locating of temples, homes, fish ponds, hence a professional architect. Lit., point out the sand dunes.

1. To point out and interpret signs in the sky; a reader of signs in the sky.

2. To keep others doing one's bidding, lord it over others, domineer, bossy.

1. To stain or dye by soaking in water containing mashed bark, as nets or mulberry bark before it is pounded into tapa. Cf. hili, bark dye.

2. To blunder. Cf. naʻau kūhili.
To wander about aimlessly; senseless digression.

Minister, premier, regent, ambassador, secretary, diplomat, cabinet member; highest officer next to the king; officer in the king's guard (2 Sam. 23.23) Cf. kuhi, ʻaha kuhina, loio kuhina. (Probably PNP tusinga.)
Minister of (public) instruction.
Postmaster general.
Minister of interior, in the days of the monarchy; secretary of interior.
Minister or secretary of war.
Secretary of state.
Minister resident.
Powerful officer in the days of the monarchy.
Minister of foreign affairs.
Minister of finances.
Fat, rich, satiated with rich or fatty food. (See kuhikuhi 2 and -nia; .) E ʻai iho ʻoe ā kuhinia, eat until satisfied with rich food.
Greasy, oily, polished; to rub with oil, polish, grease; a name applied to women (except kāhuna) because they were not permitted to make offerings to the gods with their hands (Kep. 23).
Var. of kūhepa.
Redup. of kūhipa; to mutter indistinctly; unintelligible gibberish.
Special taboo made by a chief; to be subject to this taboo.
To plop, splash, as a stone dropping into water, or as a leaping fish; sound of a deep cough.
Quartermaster of ship.
Deep ravine; deep.
Same as hohonu.
Redup. of kuhō.
An edible spotted-back crab (Portunus sanguinolentus). Lit., turtle back. Also pāpaʻi kūhonu.

1. Suddenly struck, as by disease.

2. See maile kūhonua.
To rise again, recover from illness, resurrect.
To dive headfirst.
To thicken, as scrambled eggs; to become pasty; to gel.
Var. of kuhua. Cf. lepo kuhue.
Redup. of kuhua.
Dove, turtledove (Kin. 15.9); cooing of a dove.
Goose flesh, as from chill; quaking, as during an earthquake; agitated, disturbed. See prayer, kualakai.

1. To string pierced objects, as flowers in a lei, or fish; to thread, as beads. Cf. kui lima.

2. Needle, pin, spike, nail, screw, any pointed instrument of wood or metal; to sting.

1. To pound, punch, strike, box, hit, hammer; to beat out, as metals; to churn, as butter; to boom or clap, as thunder; to smite, injure; to jar; to prod, as ʻopihi shells from rocks with a knife, formerly with sharp stones; to clash (as sound). See hula kuʻi Molokaʻi.

2. To join, stitch, sew, splice, unite; joined; seam. See niho kuʻi.

3. Artificial.

4. Back tooth, molar, tusk.

5. To disseminate news; to spread, as news.

6. Elbow of pipe.

7. Sheer, steep, tall.

8. Move in the kōnane game. See For. 4:57.

1. Pas/imp. of kuʻi 1; to meet an obstacle, stumble; to waver or be unsettled mentally; hit, hindered; attack, sudden blow (loaʻa-type word; ). Fig., disturbed or hurt mentally. Cf. haʻakuʻia.

2. Sharp, pointed stick, dagger, spear.
To pound food, especially poi; one who pounds food, as poi.
A stroke in lua fighting. Lit., people traveling at night are hindered.
God of trainees in lua fighting.
Art of lua fighting; to fight thus.
Name of a wind of Weliweli, Kauaʻi. (For. 5:97.)
Privileged and trusted persons in a chief's retinue. Lit., join [at] late night.
To carry under the arm; to escort arm in arm. Lit., string armpit.
Nail, iron spike.
To pound and shape iron; to forge; blacksmith.
Hesitating, uncertain, undecided, wavering; hurt in feelings.
Peal of thunder, thunderclap.
Candlestick.
Awl, gimlet. Lit., piercing sharp instrument.
Hypodermic needle.
Needle.
Name of a Honolulu rain.
Bone awl.
To pound smooth.

1. To swing and hit, as with a war club [this is the name of the club of the legendary hero, Ka-welo]. See ex., kāpukupuku.

2. To join together, splice.
Treaty, covenant, agreement, league, feeling of unity; united, unified; to agree.
Stroke in lua fighting. Lit., Mēhēʻula's single blow.
Reciprocity Treaty, by which Pearl Harbor was given to the United States as a coaling station. Lit., treaty equal reciprocity.
Safety pin. Lit., diaper pin.
Tack, small nail, wedge, plug.
Carpet tacks. Lit., sharp instruments for nailing mats.
Screwdriver. Commonly called kala.
Silversmith; to weld silver.

Temporary, for the time being, ad hoc, transient, makeshift, occasional, provisional, special, acting; free and independent, not bound to a chief in opinion or course. Lit., standing at the time. Cf. pōpilikia.

1. To know by sight, to understand or know in advance or beforehand.

2. Cash.

1. To toll or ring, as a bell.

2. To pound smooth, level off, raze; to strike right and left indiscriminately; to destroy completely, as in war.
Large needle, as for darning or on a sewing machine. Lit., steering instrument.
One who makes brass articles, metalsmith, tinsmith; to work with brass, copper, bronze; to pound brass.
Spikes on a spur.
Sculpturing; to carve and shape an image; ceremonial making of the makahiki festival image, Lono-makua (And.).
Quilting; to quilt. Eng. Kuiki lala, diagonal quilting.
Switzerland; Swiss. Eng.

1. Old form for kukui, candlenut, light (commonly used on Niʻihau).

2. Redup. of kui 1.

1. Redup. of kuʻi 1; boxing, prize fight; to box. See Ulu-mano, wauke.

2. Redup. of kuʻi 2.

3. Redup. of kuʻi 5.

4. Liquid medicine made of the sap of the ʻakoko tree.
Redup. of kuʻia 1.
Physic nut (Jatropha curcas).
Prayer closing makahiki festivals. (For. 6:45.)
Twill. Eng.
Wooden peg, especially as made of hardwood and used in mending bowls.
Covering made of dried ti leaves attached to a netting of olonā fibers or hibiscus, and worn as a rain cape.
Hairpin.
Name of a breeze blowing from the northwest of Niʻihau. Lit., strike Lehua (Island).
To string flowers, beads, seeds, shells into leis; a lei stringer.
One who decorates the chief in finest apparel; to decorate the chief thus; decorated elegantly. Lit., string red leis.
Molar tooth yellow with age; insulting reference to old person.
Prayer committed to memory and recited in unison during luakini (temple) dedications (Malo 171); to repeat, pray.
Crochet hook.
Same as kīʻililī 1, 2.
To go arm in arm, to hold hands; arm in arm.
See kui lima
Boxer, pugilist, pugilism; to strike with the fist.
Chief supporting a chief, a chief's mainstay. Lit., inside joint.

1. Intensive of kuʻi 1, 2; to add on, increase, punch doubly hard, etc.

2. See kuʻi a lua.
See hula kuʻi Molokaʻi.
A stringing together, as of leis.

1. Blow, punch; peal, as of thunder.

2. Joint, joining, seam, junction. Fig., center, key. Cf. kuʻinakapa.
Same as kuʻinakapa. Kauaʻi.
Tapa bed covering, consisting of five layers stitched together at one end; the inner four (iho) were white, the outer was designed (kilohana). Cf. kapa kuʻina.
Screw, large nail.
Roaring, as of the sea; to roar.
Quiet and still, without rustling; weird solitary quietness of a deep forest.
Crowded, as a street.
Queen. Eng. Ke kuini o Palani, the queen of France.
Quintet. Eng.

1. Fact, a true statement; sincerity; true. Lit., a state of truth.

2. Fleshy, fat. Lit., a state of flesh.
Stickpin, common pin; lit., pin to attach.
Thumbtack.
To pry ʻopihi limpets loose from a rock with a knife, formerly to hit a glancing blow with a sharp stone.
Lockjaw. Lit., tight molar.
Thumbtack. Lit., pushing nail.
Billiard cue.
To make palu relish or bait; to pound into fine pieces, to beat to a pulp, thresh, demolish.
Method of making a hat lei by sewing leaves and flowers to a pandanus strip; to make such a lei. Lit., string on a base.
Large, curved needle as used in sewing gunny sacks.
To beat flat. Lit., pound crush.
Deflated. Fig., discouraged. Lit., punch swelling.
To pummel, pound, abuse horribly. Lit., pound pelt.
Staple, as for wire. Lit., bent nail.
A variety of sweet potato. Lit., decayed molar.
Knitting needle.
Metal binder, as in a notebook.
An unknown word translated ‘distribute’ in For. 6:39.
Spindle. Lit., instrument spin rope (Eng.).
Coat. Eng.
Consultation, discussion; to consult, confer, discuss, deliberate. Cf. kūkākūkā.
Used only in the idiom ʻo kū! ʻo kā! This originated in Wahine-ʻōmaʻo's chant: ʻO kū, ʻo kā ʻo Wahine-ʻōmaʻo, wahine a Lohiʻau-ipo (PH 184), bam! boom! Woman-in-green, wife of Sweetheart-Lohiʻau.

1. Roll, bolt of cloth; rolled pack, as of pandanus leaves ready for plaiting; to roll up, as a bundle of cloth or tapa; to swell up.

2. Wholesale.
Raincoat. Lit., oiled coat, so called because early raincoats were made of oiled unbleached muslin.
To stand apart, be entirely different, independent.
Convoy, guard; safe, protected, convoyed; to place in custody for protection; to convoy, guard.
Excreta, dung, feces. See below for many compounds formed with kukae; lepo, dirt, is sometimes a euphemism.

A brownish substance, sometimes noticed under trees in the shape of paste squeezed from a tube; if the substance contains red, it is believed to be the excreta of the ghost of a dying person, and a sign that someone is dying. Lit., ghost excrement. Also huamai-lani, fruit from the sky.
Rust; rusty. Lit., iron excrement.

Spiny bur (Acanthospermum australe), a branching, prostrate tropical American weed, 10 to 60 cm long, bearing small star-shaped bristly fruits. (Neal 837.) Lit., sheep dung. Also called ʻihi kūkae hipa, pipili.

A rattlepod (Crotalaria incana), an erect tropical American weed, about 94 cm high, with three-parted leaves, yellow flowers, and hairy, dark-brown pods, each pod 2.5 cm or more long and containing 20 or more seeds. (Neal 445.) Lit., mule dung.

1. Small hard spots on an umbilical cord, the number of spots indicating the number of children the mother is to bear. Lit., rat's dung. Cf. piko pau ʻiole.

2. Taro found growing in inaccessible spots, as a tree crotch, believed carried there by rats.

3. Insignificant trifles.
A form of gourd having fruit green with white splotches, still grown on Molokaʻi and East Maui. Lit., dung of ʻiwa bird. See ipu.

1. Same as pūʻoheʻohe, Job's tears.

2. Same as kōlea. periwinkle.
A kind of grass.
Eggs deposited by flies, as in meat. Lit., sun excrement.

1. Toadstool, mushroom.

2. A name for unidentified wild grasses growing where horses are pastured. (For. 5:641.) Lit., horse dung.
Mildew; mildewed.
Bird dung, guano.
A small tree (Pelea clusiaefolia subsp.

1. Mole on the body, believed to be deposits of flies during infancy. Lit., fly dung.

2. Beeswax.

3. Unbleached muslin.
Same as ʻai-a-ka-nēnē. Lit., goose dung.
Same as līpuʻupuʻu, a seaweed.
Constipation. Lit., hard excreta.
Sulphur, brimstone, match. Lit., Pele's dung.
Excreta after eating pōpolo greens, a term for a chief whose mother was said to be a commoner.
A weedy, creeping grass (Digitaria pruriens), native to Hawaiʻi; some introduced species of Digitaria are also sometimes called kūkaepuaʻa, as D. sanguinalis and D. adscendens (syn.
Crab grass (Digitaria violascens) 30 to 60 cm tall, forming clumps. Lit., upland kūkaepuaʻa.

1. A weed.

2. A seaweed (And.)
A medicinal plant (no data).
Excreta and scent of ʻuaʻu birds, as left in their holes.
Ink squirted by octopus to discolor water. Fig., prostitute, as in whalers' days, so called because of their alleged cleverness at escaping from precarious situations. Lit., black excreta.
See weka 3, meconium.
To stand sideways, as in making room for another to pass.
Scolding, raving and ranting in a fit of temper.
To while the time away in pleasant conversation, jesting, laughing, and telling anecdotes; pleasant conversation, chatting. Lit., stand flowing.

1. Name of the third day in the lunar month. Cf. Kū Lua, Kū Kolu, Kū Pau.

2. Standing alone, outstanding, unique, first.
Dipped frequently in the sea.

1. To exchange, as greeting (aloha), conversation (kamaʻilio), letters (leka). (Kū 1 + -kaʻi.)

2. To appear. See ex., ila.

3. To stand guard as soldiers.

4. Rope fastening fish nets together. (And.)
Same as kūkākaʻikahi.
Faded, as cloth. Fig., boring, dull, uninteresting.
To correspond back and forth; to exchange letters.
Kamehameha's war image.
See hua kukaima.
To attempt to induce the spirit possessing a person to talk through the person and reveal the reason for the possession.
To converse, narrate; recount.
Similar to kaka 1, translated ‘purified’ by Emerson (cf. Malo text, Chapter 26, section 36).
Standing wide apart; scattered widely, as houses.
See kākalaioa, 1.
Interview, conference; to hold such, negotiate. Lit., confer chat.
Glib hanger-on, parasite; one who lives with others, depending on glibness of tongue; to be glib.
Redup. of kūkā; to discuss, negotiate.
Redup. of kūkaʻi.
To proclaim publicly, tell abroad, announce; herald. See kūkala hewa.
Auction; to sell at auction. Lit., stand dollar (Eng.).
See kūkālā
Name of a rain and wind famous at Honolulu.
False alarm.
Same as kūkahekahe. Cf. kalekale.
Boasting; to boast. (See liki 1.) Kāu mau kūkaliki (Kel. 135), your boasting.
Sycamine, a tree mentioned by Jesus; according to Harper's Bible Dictionary, a mulberry, probably the black variety. (Luka 17.6.) (Gr.
See kukamino

1. To study or consult genealogy. Lit., confer lineage.

2. To use enchantment (Oihk. 19.26). Lit., consult moʻo spirits.
A variety of banana.
To pray to the god Kanaloa, as on the Kāloa days of the month.
General name for weeds. Rare. Lit., resembling the kanawao, wild taro.
A rough lemon (Citrus limonia), liked for the fragrance of the skin, but too sour to eat. (Neal 482.) Lit., having the nature of the kane skin fungus.
Male.
Excessive, more than usual.

1. Lamentation. Lit., the wail arises.

2. A strong purge made from bark of the shrub called koko and sap of the green kukui nut; it was administered only as a last resort and often resulted in death.
Chastity; chaste; taboo-surrounded and unapproachable; in a state of taboo.
Raincoat.

Said to be an old name for the gods Kāne, Kū, and Lono. The theory of a trinity is believed due to remaking of Hawaiian legends by Kepelino, Kamakau, and Fornander to conform to the Bible. See Barrère 1969.
Deep-water fishing with hook and line; fishing grounds at about 80 fathoms depth (Kam. 76:75).
With great care, with esteem, in chiefly fashion.
Oilskin coat. Lit., varnished coat.
Raincoat (Perhaps Eng., coat and [sou']wester.)

1. To care for young plants or seedlings.

2. To spread, reach a goal (of a sorcerer's prayer).

3. To rush or gurgle, as water. Rare.

1. To nudge, push, jostle. Cf. kuke kū.

2. Thin type of adze (2.5 or 4 cm wide), as used for finer work in handicraft. Also lipi kuke.

3. Cook; to cook. Eng.

4. Customs, duty; to be on duty or watch (Kel. 115). Eng. Hole kuke, customhouse.

5. Also duke n. Duke. Eng. Duke wahine, duchess.
Customhouse inspector, customs.
Harbor duty or tax.
Var. spelling of kū ke ehu; see ʻehu 1.

1. Duchess. Eng.

2. Also Tusede. (Cap.) Tuesday. Eng. Rare.
See kukeke
To push with elbows and shoulders, as forcing a way through a crowd; to blow violently, as wind, to bluster, rage, as waves or storm.
Redup. of kuke 1. (PCP tutetute.)

1. vi. Muddy, slippery; to slip, slide, as in mud.

2. To sail, as a boat.
Duty, tariff.
See mea ʻono kuki, cookie. Eng.
Firm, steady, steadfast.
To straddle, stand with legs far apart.
Similar to kūkilakila.
Majestic.

1. Mandrake (Mele 7.13.) (Heb.

2. Also dukima Bagpipe (RSV), dulcimer (KJV). (Dan. 3.5.) (Eng.)
See kukima

1. Runner, swift messenger, as employed by old chiefs, with a premium on their speed; to run swiftly, as of a messenger; to race.

2. Close together, in great numbers, as plants.

3. Cushion. Eng.
Redup. of kūkini 2; grouped together.
Small pool of water. Lit., standing pool.
Strong desire, whether good or bad; lust, compulsion; to lust, desire; to think about, as approaching death (GP 56).

1. Temple for purification ceremonies (Malo 151–2, Emerson note 156), for prayers for food (Malo 188).

2. Name of a god appealed to in ʻanāʻanā, evil sorcery.
Kleptomaniac.
Pas/imp. of kuko.
Name of the fifth day in the lunar month. Cf. Kū Kahi, Kū Lua, Kū Pau.
Sycamore tree. (Isa. 9.10.) (Gr.
See kukomolea
Unfriendly, cross, sullen. cf. konā, haughty; mākonā, malevolent.
Redup. of kūkona.
Excessive, overmuch, deep, profound, serious.

1. To beat, as tapa.

2. Beam, as of a house; stick, as used to support and distend a net. (PCP tutu.)

1. Thorn, barb, spine, bur; barbed, thorny, prickly, burry; jabbed, pricked, hurt by a thorn.

2. Redup. of kū 1, to hit; crowded.

1. (Usually pronounced tūtū.) Granny, grandma, grandpa; granduncle, grandaunt; any relative or close friend of grandparent's generation (often said affectionately; apparently a new word as it has not been noted in legends and chants).

2. To shake in jerks, bounce, trot, as on a horse; bumpy.

3. Gourd beat; the gourd is thumped down on a pad three times, and on the third rise, it is slapped; to beat thus. Cf. ʻami kūku-, kāhela, pā 5.

4. Sea gull (RSV), cuckoo (KJV). (Oihk. 11.16.)
Faint, dizzy; to faint. (AP)
To go smoothly.
See kukua
A large grapsid crab (Metopograpsus thukuhar).
Clubfoot; one with a twisted or deformed foot. Cf. hapakuʻe.
Redup. of kūʻē and kūʻēʻē (For. 6:470.)
Redup. of kuhe 2.
Rare. var. of ukuhi, to pour.
Redup. of kūhilo.

1. Candlenut tree (Aleurites moluccana), a large tree in the spurge family bearing nuts containing while, oily kernels which were formerly used for lights; hence the tree is a symbol of enlightenment. The nuts are still cooked for a relish (ʻinamona). The soft wood was used for canoes, and gum from the bark for painting tapa; black dye was obtained from nut coats and from roots, (Nuts were chewed and spat into the sea by men fishing with nets for parrot fish (kākā uhu) in order to calm the sea: see ex., pili 1). Polished 
nuts are strung in leis; the silvery leaves and small white flowers are strung in leis as representative of Molokaʻi, as designated in 1923 by the Territorial legislature. The kukui was named the official emblem for the State of Hawaii in 1959 because of its many uses and its symbolic value.

2. Lamp, light, torch. Fig., guide, leader.

3. Star name (no data). (Kuhelani.)
Redup. of kuʻi 1, 2, 5; to punch, join, spread news; fame.
Name of a star.
General name for any nut not native to Hawaiʻi.
Lantern. Lit., light [for] going [at] night.
Physic nut (Jatropha curcas), a tropical American shrub or small tree with soft wood, milky juice, and very poisonous seeds. Like the kukui, it is in the spurge family. (Neal 512.) See kuikui Pākē.
Projector, as for lantern slides; magic lantern.
Storyteller; to recite, narrate, recount; to join words together coherently. Lit., joining speech.
Flashlight. Lit., light hold hand.
Stone lamp burning sperm oil.
Electric light.
Morning Star. Lit., early morning light.
Practice of telling stories all night, especially to a chief. Lit., spreading tales dawn.
Grandpa.

1. Pimpled, pimply.

2. Hawaiian soap plant (Colubrina asiatica). See ʻānapanapa.

1. Redup. of kukū 1.

2. Sound of boiling water; to sound thus; sputtering.
Redup. of kukū 2, standing, rising up.
Redup. of kukuhe. (For. 6:449.)
Rare. var. of kuhukukū, dove.
Redup. of kula, school; to go to school. Eng. I laila e kukula ʻia mai ai, there to be schooled.
Inactive, listless, unresponsive, dejected.
Redup. of kuli; knee; to kneel; to crouch or lie as an animal, with feet under the body (Nah. 24.9).
Same as kulukulu, to leak. (PCP tutulu.)

1. Pillar, post, side, border, edge, horizon. Also kūkunu.

2. To build, as a house; to construct, erect, establish, organize, set up; to put up, as a tent or as mast and sail; to heap up; to form, as a military unit; to found, as a society; to establish, as a name or dynasty; to lay, as an oven.

3. To tie, tether (so called because formerly horses were tied to erected [kūkulu] stakes); to park.

4. To sit with one knee raised high towards the chin, considered bad form for women.

5. Type of battle in which opposing forces were formally drawn, up in line against each other; front, as in modern warfare. (Malo 196, 203.)

1. Stilts; to walk on stilts.

2. Hawaiian stilt bird (Himantopus himantopus). Also aeʻo, Fig., a thin, long-legged person.
To pool thoughts and prayers to solving common problems, as during hoʻoponopono (Na_na_ 78–80); to set up topics for discussion, as an agenda.
Pillars of Kahiki; it was believed that the sky was supported by a vertical wall along the horizon; the section of the wall over Kahiki (formerly Tahiti) was the Kūkulu-o-Kahiki.
Region just below the horizon where sea and sky meet. Lit., pillars (or borders) of the earth. Cf. Isa. 45.22.
Region just above the horizon where sea and sky meet. Lit., pillars (or borders) of the sky.
To pile in regular order; to arrange, classify, as plants, words. Less used clan hoʻonoho papa.
A crab, often qualified by the terms kea, white, and ʻōhuluhulu, hairy.

Ray, as of the sun; radius of a circle; spoke of a wheel; antenna of a lobster; spike of hāʻukeʻuke, a sea urchin; feeler of any creature; pistil of a flower; gate, door, or gable post; end post of a Hawaiian house other than the main post and the corner posts (Malo 119).
Mangrove (Bruguiera gymnorhiza); calyx of a mangrove, as used in leis. (Neal 626.) Lit., ray of the sun.
Redup. of kuni, to burn.
Rare. var. of kūkulu, pillar, border.
Sharp, steep, conspicuous, as house roof.
To do with great enthusiasm, with might and main. See ex., kemu 1.
Redup. of kupu, to grow. See prayer, hōʻeu.
Grandma.

1. Plain, field, open country, pasture. An act of 1884 distinguished dry or kula land from wet or taro land.

2. Source; container. See kula kakalina, kula wai, kula waiwai.

3. Basket-like fish trap. Rare.

4. School, academy; to teach school, go to school; to hold school or class sessions. Eng. Kula ʻia, to be educated in school, sent to school. Specialized schools are usually kula aʻo, as kula aʻo hana lima, manual training school, school of arts and crafts; kula aʻo hīmeni, singing school; kula aʻo hulahula, dancing school; kula aʻo humuhumu, sewing school; kula aʻo kamana, carpenter's school; kula aʻo kuke, cooking school. Cf. kukula.

5. Also gula nvs. Gold; golden. Eng.
Rare. var. of hulaʻa.
Same as kula kumu.
Trade school.
Public school, government school.
Boarding school. Lit., feeding school. Also kula noho paʻa.
Day school. Lit., school daily going. Also kula lā.
Boys' reform school.

To push over, knock down, overthrow, shove, push to one side; to brush off, as a horse switches flies with its tail; to dash to pieces (Isa. 13.18); to hurl. See ex., kūpahu. (Probably kū l + -laʻi.) Kulaʻi pau, to push completely over, as would a strong wind (see ex., kikiʻi 1).
Festive, festivities; festive. See lā kulāai.
See kulāia
Redup. of kulaʻi.
To push, shove, etc., in two ways or with great force.
Pushing over, flattening; overthrow, breakdown.
Sport in which players attempted to unseat one another by pushing with their feet. Lit., foot pushing.
Native land, homeland; native. Cf. iwi, ʻōiwi.
Theological seminary. Lit., minister school.
Gasoline drum, barrel, container.
Primary school, kindergarten. Lit., children's school.
Sunday school.
High school.
Military Academy.

1. Redup. of kula 1; fields.

2. Game like ninepins.

1. Redup. of kulaʻi.

2. Chest-slapping game; the player attempts to push opponent out-of-bounds with his open palms.
Teachers' training school, normal school.
Day school. Also kula hele lā.
Plant propagated by slips or scions, formerly of pandanus aerial roots; to plant thus. Lit., stand branch.
Gathering place of birds, as near water or food; plain with birds; tree branch that is gummed or smeared to attract birds.
To tilt, rock, reel, sway, toss and pitch; wobbly, shaky, unsteady. Fig., insecure, hesitant.

Station, rank, title, condition, position, place, quality, grade, rating, reputation (see ex., kuene), stance, attitude, poise, carriage, posture, situation, patch, site; outstanding, prominent (kū, stand, + -lana, nominalizer). Cf. kūlanakauhale.
Same as kūlanakauhale; house site.
Probably the same as kūlana nalu.
Village, town, city. Lit., situation plural house.
Redup. of kulana; unsteady, tottering, unsettled, wavering, wobbly, undecided, uncertain, fluctuating. (For. 4:271.) hoʻo.kū.lana.lana Caus/sim.
Place where the waves swell up and the surf rider starts paddling and racing the wave, usually at the most distant line of breakers. Also kūlana heʻenalu (Laie 453).
Standard, as weight or money.
Jeopardy.
Prayer meeting or other religious service.
Fussy, fastidious, choosy.
Of chiefly nature.
Mythical pond or lake in the sky; its overflow comes to the earth as rain. Lit., like heaven agitated. See ex., haukawewe, kiʻo 1.
Boarding school. Lit., school staying fixed. Also kula hānai.
University, college; formerly high school. Lit., big school.

1. Earth piled on the sides of a ditch, as of a plowed furrow or as on the edge of a taro patch; to dig or plow and cast up earth or furrow.

2. To frolic, jump, or skip about in sport; to struggle, twist, turn, writhe.

1. Earring. Lit., gold [for] ears.

2. Fuchsia (Fuchsia magellanica), an introduced plant so called because of resemblance of flower to an earring. (Neal 650.)

3. Same as aloalo koʻakoʻa. Niʻihau.

4. Modern name for cocoon.

5. Same as līpepeiao, a seaweed.
Night school.
Private school. Lit., paying school.
Select school.
Watering trough, water source.
Source of income or livelihood.

1. Same as kukule, inactive.

2. Var. of ʻulae, lizard fish.

3. Var. of akule, scad.
To seize, meddle in the concerns of others, oust, remove. Rare.
Successful, competent; happily.

Right, privilege, concern, responsibility, title, business, property, estate, portion, jurisdiction, authority, liability, interest, claim, ownership, tenure, affair, province; reason, cause, function, justification; small piece of property, as within an ahupuaʻa; blood relative through whom a relationship to less close relatives is traced, as to in-laws. Cf. ʻākuleana.
Owned land (common term in wills of the 1860s).
Claim number.
Lien.
See kuleana hoʻopaʻa
Dividends. (Will 129, island of Maui, State Archives, 1856.)
Common ownership or interest.
Same as leha 1, 2.
Var. of pūlehu.
Sultan. Eng.
See kulekana
Turkey, Turk; Turkish. Eng.
See Kuleke
Crusader. Eng.
See kulekia
Secure, permanent. Cf. kuleana.
Redup. of kūlē, to seize.
To scatter as does the wind.
Insecure, destitute. Lit., wind-scattered bones.
Redup. of kūlewa.
Sulphur. Eng.
See kulepa

1. Split open from head to tail, as fish prepared for drying and salting; to slit thus; to hew out roughly, as a canoe; to make a hole or dig out.

2. To flap, flutter; strong, of wind.

3. Harelip. (Less common than ʻūlepe.)
Redup. of kūlepe 1, 2.
Moving slowly through space, as clouds; swaying, dangling, hanging. Fig., far away in space, as the ocean beyond sight of land or as its profound depths. (PCP tuulewa.)
Redup. of kūlewa.

1. Knee. (A mother would rap a disobedient child on the knee: see hoʻokuli; knocking on the knee was also a sign of stinginess: the person referred to is deaf (kuli 2) to appeal for generosity,)

2. Deafness, deaf person, noise, racket; deaf, noisy, loud.

1. Pas/imp. of kū 1; to stand, halt, etc.

2. To try, strive.

3. Outstanding, fortunate, lucky.
To desire greatly.
Var. of kūnihi 1, 2; grazed, as by a bullet; hit but not seriously hurt; hooked but escaped, as a fish.
To doze; too drowsy to hear (a deeper sleep than kulu hiamoe). Lit., sleep deafly. Rare.
Redup. of kūlihi.
Alike, identical, conforming, resembling; standing in similar fashion or in even rows.
Tight. See liki 2.
Noise, din; noisy, deafening, inharmonious; a noise. Be quiet! Keep still! Shut up! (PEP tulituli.)
Ridgelike, sharp.
Var. of kalima, cream. Eng.
Deafness, disobedience, noise.
Corn, maize (Zea mays). (Neal 81–2.) Eng.

Sweet corn (Zea mays). (Neal 81–2.) Lit., delicious corn.
Popcorn.
Cornmeal. Lit., fine corn.
Stingy, penurious.
Tulip. Eng.
Stingy, penurious, niggardly, deaf. Lit., solid deafness.
To creep along, as a sick person; to stumble awkwardly along; to walk as though weak-kneed. (PH 38.)
Dark, dank, deep, as a cave. Fig. extremely, intense, much. Cf. kumulipo, lipo.
Redup. of kūlipo.
Design with zigzag stripes, in tapas, mats, and quilts. Lit., bent knees. Also niho-wili-hemo.

1. Deep, as a voice; penetrating, profound, as thoughts; late, remote, of the distant past.

2. Same as liʻu 2.
Same as kūlōʻihi, short for kūloa.

Same as kūlōʻihi, kūlō; name of the lengthy ceremonies on the night before graduation day in hula; a “long waiting” with feasts and ceremonies lasting for hours; lengthy religious prayers, ceremonies.
Var. of Hōkū-loa, name of a star.
Prosperous, well-supplied with needs.
Languid, lounging about. Lit. state of slowness. (PCP tu(u)lohi.)
To wait a long time; to stand long; to last long, endure; to take a long time.
Local, domestic. Lit., state of being inside.
Falling, flowing, as rain or stream; flattened, as plants by rain.
Redup. of kūloku. Also kūnokunoku.
Redup. of kūlou.
Helpless, inactive, due either to infirmity or laziness; sluggish. Cf. lola.
Redup. of kūlola.

Having no wife, children, or relatives (name derived from a lone mulberry tree growing in a cave at Kūloli, Kona, Hawaiʻi, which was known as ka wauke kū kahi a Kūloli, the lone mulberry tree of Kūloli); also said of any very young wauke plant.

1. Pas/imp. of kūlō, long waiting or enduring.

2. Of changed appearance, as of plants in different seasons (Kep. 89); grief-stricken, said to apply particularly to a mourner who wears a malo or pāʻū of the deceased about his neck as an expression of grief: he is breaking a taboo and has “changed” (loli).
Name of a wind at Hāmākua, Maui. (Probably a contraction of kū kololio, gusty state.)
Pudding made of baked or steamed grated taro and coconut cream. Cf. lololo 2, niu kūlolo.
Long in doing a thing; to tell a story with many unnecessary details; garrulous.
Var. of kū_loulou.
Slow, dull, stupid, awkward, helpless.
Redup. of kūloma.

1. Sheer, precipitous.

2. Leaky, as a calabash. Also kūnono.

3. Insignificant, as an idea. Rare. Also kūnono.
To decay, as crops. (Malo 199, Emerson note.)
The long process of sweetening arrowroot starch (pia); to do this.
To bow the head, bend; to beckon with the head. Also kūnou. Cf. kūlolou, kūloulou, kūlokulou, kūʻou, haʻakūlou.
Redup. of kūlou.
Redup. of kūlou.
To bow the head; to dive headfirst.

1. To drip, leak, trickle; to flow, as tears; a drop; general name for distilled liquor. Fig., disparaging term for a chief whose mother was said to be a commoner

2. To pass, of time; time. See kulu aumoe.

3. Timber used in houses, as sticks, posts; fuel sticks. Cf. kūkulu, to build a house.

4. Drowsy (usually followed by hiamoe). Cf. kuluhio.

5. Swift.

6. Dysentery, gonorrhea.

7. To be late at night.
Pas/imp. of kulu 1, to drip.
Pairing off, as of mates; twins.
Fourth day of the old lunar month; also, the name of the 17th day and second after the full moon (Malo 35).
Late night, midnight.
Icicle. Lit., drop [of]hard dew.
Pas/imp. of kulu 1.
Similar to kuli hiamoe.
Wafted off to sleep.

1. To drip (kulu 1 + -i, transitivizer).

2. To be late at night. (For. 6:420.) Cf. kulu 7.
Endemic small trees and shrubs (Nototrichium) spp.), with small more or less hairy leaves, and downy catkin-like flower spikes. (Neal 332.)
Redup. of kului 2. (For. 6:421.)
Perfect, without error, as a prayer.

1. Redup. of kulu 1; to drip, leak, drop: leaky.

2. To multiply, become numerous.

1. Sap from green kukui nuts, used to prevent infections in cuts and as a gargle for sore throat and thrush.

2. Name of a legendary chief at Hilo.
Same as aeʻo 2, stilt bird. (PNP tuli, PCP tutul(i,u).
Same as kulu aumoe.
Flowing, leaking, dripping.
Accustomed to, acquainted with, intimate with; customary, usual, chronic.

1. Var. of hākuma 1, 2.

2. Cracking of the skin between fingers and toes, as with athlete's foot.
Prefix to numbers as ʻumi kūmākahi, ʻumi kūmālua, iwakālua kūmākahi, kanakolu kūmālua, etc. See  and kumamā-.
To work in gardens; such work.
Seen by the eye, seen, visible; eyewitness; associated with; to see for oneself.
Annual, yearly; yearly contract (see ex., lōpā 1).
Traitor, turncoat; traitorous; to betray; to abuse one who has been kind to one.

1. Windbreak; wind-resisting.

2. Same as ʻaʻaliʻi, a shrub or tree.
To lament, bewail, mourn loudly for the dead, grieve. Cf. make, death.

1. Same as ʻāhihi 2, a lehua bush.

2. Name of a strong wind.
Redup. of kuma 1, 2.
Var. of malamala, see mala.
To rise above.
See kumalauā
Reverential bowing during old prayers.
Pas/imp. of Kūmalolo.
Same as kūmā- (rare in conversation, Biblical). The origin is uncertain. Ellis (1827:479) suggests that the old term may have been kumu ma, beginning and; perhaps kumu assilated to kuma before mā.
To set in order, as in laying stones. (And.)
Water dam (rare), reservoir.
To catch sharks with bait and noose. (Malo 210, 213.)
A bur grass (Cenchrus agrimonioides). Also kāmanomano

1. Customary, usual, regular. See puʻu kālā kūmau.

2. Deep wooden bowl with a thick base, as for poi.

3. North Star.
Lazy, inactive. Rare.

1. Redup. of kūmau 1.

2. Same as maumau; constant, continuous, together.

1. Var. of kūmau, bowl.

2. Same as ʻalaea, dye plant.
Path, trail, road.
Shoemaker. Eng.
Blunt, flat, of the nose.
Cymbal.
See kumepala
Same as kualakai 1, a sea creature.
Thummim. (Puk. 28.30) (Heb.
See Kumima
Small crabs such as Lophozozymus intonsus. Varieties are kūmimi mākaʻo (Petrolisthes coccineus) and kūmimi pua (Lybia tesselata). Both were used in sorcery and are inedible.
Frail, feeble, blighted Cf. mīmī, ʻōmīmī.
Cumin (Isa. 28.25).
Large deep-sea crab (no data).
Bedstead. Lit., standing bed.

1. Long strip commencement of a mat.

2. Pile of mats; spread out as a mat or landscape.
To rise, overflow, as water.
Smooth, slippery, sheer, steep, rounded.
Redup. of kūmole.
Var. of kūmalolo. Rare.
Same as kūmolemole.
Lineage, as of chiefs or priests.

1. Bottom, base, foundation, basis, title (as to land), main stalk of a tree, trunk, handle, root (in arithmetic); basic; hereditary, fundamental.

2. Teacher, tutor, manual, primer, model, pattern.

3. Beginning, source, origin; starting point of plaiting.

4. Reason, cause, goal, justification, motive, grounds, purpose, object, why.

5. An article bought, sold or exchanged; price. Cf. kumu kūʻai.

6. Herd, flock. Cf. kumu hipa, kumu pipi.

7. Tenon (RSV), socket (KJV). (Puk. 26.19.)

1. Goatfish (Parupeneus porphyreus). The stages of growth are kolokolopā, ʻahuluhulu, kūmū aʻe, and the adult kūmū.

2. Good-looking, handsome, especially of a sweetheart. Modern slang.

3. A variety of red-stalked taro; varieties are qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, kea, kū loa poni, ʻulaʻula, welo-welo lā.
Conditions for agreement, stipulations. (For. 5:119.)
Teaching, source of learning, teacher, tutor.
Tortoise-shell handle as on a kāhili staff.
Same as kumu ʻūhā.
Subject, of a sentence.

1. Shelf.

2. Same as akua lele. (Kam. 64:134.)
Topic, subject (as topic of discourse or grammatical subject); matter. (kumu 1 + -hana, nominalizer; .)

1. Crotch. Lit., source of going.

2. Kind of lashing used on outrigger of a chief's canoe. (Malo 131.)
Flock of sheep.
Minuend.
Concoction made of gourd vine and kukui nuts.
Ancient ancestor. (Malo 3.)
Beginning of the world, creation, origin of the earth.
Example, pattern. (Heb. 8.5.)
Ransom. (Mat. 20.28.)
Means of propagation, source of progeny.
Incentive. Lit., reason [for] encouragement.

Incentive. Lit., reason [for] encouragement.

Easternmost cape, Hawaiʻi.
Origin, beginning.
Constitution, law code, provision of law. Lit., source of laws. See kūʻē.

Name of a star.
Price, cost.
Square root.
School teacher.
Land title.
Truncated stumps, roots; stubs, as of cut grass or decayed teeth; stump, stubble, as of a beard.

Same as kūlālā.
Tree.
Base of the sky; horizon.

1. Female who has produced young, as of horse, cow, pig, chicken; to have produced young, female; root with many sprouts, propagating plant (rare); major source. See ex. ʻihīʻihī.

2. Providers of ti leaves for hukilau seining.
Name of a disease, perhaps jaundice.
Loss.
Origin, genesis, source of life, mystery; name of the Hawaiian creation chant (see Beckwith 1951 and Johnson 1981); written kumu uli po in Malo text, Chapter 1, section 11.
A crab (Simocarcinus simplex) commonly found in līpoa seaweed. Lit., līpoa source. Perhaps also makua-o-ka-līpoa.
Gain, profit.
Topic, subject, essay, tract; text, as of a sermon; proposition, theory.
Any type of green Hawaiian stone, as used for maika stones.

Easterly wind at Ka-lua-koʻi, Molokaʻi and Ka-maile, Oʻahu (Nak. 57 and 70).

Rare. var. of kamumu, to crunch.
Dull, blunt, obtuse.

Coconut tree trunk.
Subject for thought.

Perhaps a net used in bag-net fishing. Also oka. (Kam. 76:63.)
Subject of a sentence.
Sandbank; sandstone, used for maika stones. Lit., sand base.

1. Principal, capital (contrasting with interest).

2. Firm foundation, ancient times, firmly established.

3. Family god (same as the much more common ʻaumakua).
Staff or five lines on and between which music is written. Cf. pākōlī.
Substitute teacher.
Mastoid process, ear bone.
Base of fish gills.
Herd of cattle (less common than pūaʻ_ pipi).

Dividend.
