Source of a stream, spring.
Grapevine.
Source of wealth; resources; capital.

1. A variety of fresh-water eel..

2. Same as kunakuna 1.

3. Schooner. Eng.
To have a grudge, bear ill will. Rare. Lit., standing intestines.
Same as nae, short of breath.
To stand firmly against opposition; unyielding.

Moldy smelling.
Weak, as from shock; dismayed, numb, dazed, shocked, horrified.

Same as kūnaʻina.

1. Itch, scabies; scabby skin condition; to itch.

2. Doorposts. Rare. Also lapauila.
Var. of kūlana, position.

1. Puzzled, stumped, at wit's end, hesitating, undecided, bewildered; uncertain. Lit., stand look.

2. Goat.

3. Same as ʻānaunau and naunau, a plant.
Same as kūlanahale.
Brother or male cousin of a female, usually used only as term of address or as an affectionate variation of kaikunāne.ngaʻane).
Insecure, unsteady, as an infant or invalid.

Ocean sunfish (Ranzania laevis, Mola mola, Masturus lanceolatus). Also ʻāpahu, mākua.
Sunday. Eng. Rare.

Filled to overflowing; to flow away.
A kind of loli, sea cucumber, perhaps a Stichopus.
Weariness, fatigue; to stagger, reel, totter with fatigue. (PCP tunewa).

1. To burn, blaze, kindle, scorch, sear, brand, earmark (cattle); to etch, in leather; blaze, scar, brand.

2. Postmark, seal; to stamp

3. Type of black magic that results in the death of a sorcerer, achieved by burning an object taken from the corpse of the sorcerer's victim; to practice kuni. Pebbles and kukui nuts used for discovering the sorcerer were wrapped in tapa such as ʻae-o-kaha-loa, ʻēkaha-loa, ʻōʻū-holo-wai, and pua-kai. (Malo, Chapter 28).

4. To pursue at full speed.
Pas/imp. of kuni 1–3.
Fire kindler; to kindle or light a fire.

1. Steep, sheer, precarious.

2. Ridge, as of a precipice; ridge of a feather helmet; ridge of uncut hair on the head; on edge; sideways; sheer; partly open, as a door. Cf. nihi.
Redup. of kūnihi 1, 2.
Redup. of kuni, to burn. (PCP tungitungi).
Pas/imp. of kunikuni.
Rare. var. of kūnihi 1, 2.
To heal one afflicted with illness from another's ʻanāʻanā. (Kam. 64:119).

A type of kuni practiced while the sick person was still alive but showed symptoms of being prayed to death. It resulted in the death of the sorcerer and saved the life of the intended victim. To practice such. (Kam. 64:36).
Same as kūnihinihi.
Var. of kūlipolipo.
Var. of kūlokuloku.
To progress or move slowly.

1. Red, bright red; fiery (see ex., welo 3).

2. Stubborn, willful, headstrong.

3. Var. of kūlono 2, 3.
Var. of kūlou. (Oih. 24.1O.)

1. A kind of loli, sea cucumber. Also hulali.

2. Var. name for kūpoupou, a fish.

1. To broil on coals, as of meat, fish. Also kōʻala..

2. To cough; a cough.

3. Same as kunukunu 1.

4. To buck, as a horse.
Whooping cough.

1. To grumble, complain; displeased, dissatisfied.

2. Redup. of kunu 1, 2. (PCP tunutunu, to broil, to cough).
Same as kunu 1.
To cry loudly, as with joy or pain; to howl, as a dog; to roar, as a lion. See uō.
See kūō
To saunter, trudge.
Love prayer used by a kahuna hana aloha to invoke love in one of the other sex. Cf. oha.
Venereal disease of genitals, either sex. Rare.

1. A large cowry, probably Cypraea reticulata. (Malo 45.)

2. Kind of fishhook, said to resemble the top of a cowry shell.

1. A variety of taro; petiole is grass-green with darker shading midway, light above.

2. Medium-sized, deep bowl.
See "hoʻokūʻoi":  Similar to ʻoi 2. ʻO ka lani hoʻokūʻoi kapu (chant), the superior sacred chief.

Steep, difficult to climb; to climb with great difficulty. Rare.
Duodecimal. Eng.

Alive and safe, as after escaping from danger.

1. To rub, scrub, polish, scour, scratch. See olo 1.

2. To tremble, as the voice; to shake, as with palsy; to vibrate, resonate, as a chanting voice. See hula kuolo.
Sagging, baggy, as clothes; old, as a person with sagging cheeks; to sag.

1. Pas/imp. of kuolo 1, 2.

2. Probably all endemic species of a genus of sedges (Rhynchospora), with tufted stems, numerous narrow leaves, and clusters of small brown flower spikelets.
Timbrel (Puk. 15.20), psaltery (Hal. 92.3).
Trilling song of a bird; to warble, trill.
Same as kuokuolo. Rare.
To walk gently, slowly, softly; to lag behind.

1. Nook, cranny, interior of a house opposite the door, inside corner of a house; gulf, bay, cove, indentation, cell (of a beehive).

2. Deep, as a cave; deep down, profound.

1. Well-off, comfortably situated, rich, wealthy, well-to-do, well-supplied.

2. Redup. of kūʻono 2 (Kel. 76).
Serious, dignified, sedate, earnest, stern, solemn (1 Pet. 1.13).
Broken fragments of sweet potato, as cut by ʻōʻō, digging stick, or spade. See ex., pūpū 5.
Possible var. of kūlou.

1. A kind of coarse tapa. Also akoa (AP)

2. Listless, uninterested. (AP)
Redup. of kūʻou.

1. Citizen, native; well-acquainted.

2. Army worm (Pseudaletia unipucta). Also peʻelua.

3. A dark-red cowry shell, as used for octopus lures.

4. Soup, stew; to boil, make soup or stew; boiled. Eng. See ex., ʻāmikamika.

5. Cooper; to do the work of a cooper. Eng.

6. Also kuba n. Cube. Eng.
Swivel adze (said to be named for a god of canoe makers); to dig, scoop, hew, till.
Steadfast, firm, constant, immovable; loyal, faithful; determined; loyalty, allegiance, firmness. See ex., -hiki.
God of canoe makers. (HM 176–7.)
Adze. See kūpā.
To soak in brine, as meat.
To eat poi or sweet potatoes with salt or relish such as ʻinamona, and without meat or greens; hence a place without fish or meat. Same as pū paʻakai.
Goodbye; to say goodbye. Eng. Rare.
Slow-moving.
Imperfect.
Same as pāhaʻohaʻo. (Kel. 107).
See waʻa kūpāhoa.
To brace oneself, as while being pushed; to hurl, as a spear.
Same as kupae. Eng.
Heap, pile, stack, lot; to pile, stack, heap up, as in a disorderly fashion.
Surprising, strange, wonderful, amazing, extraordinary, unaccountable, marvelous; astonishing situation. Also kupanaha.
To kick, thrash, as one in anger or as a child having a tantrum; to writhe, twist, struggle (Isa. 21.3); contorted.
Intensive of kūpaka.
Supercargo, bookkeeper, clerk, purser. Eng.
Crooked. Fig., contrary.
To recover, as from a nearly fatal illness, or as a dying plant (rare); resuscitation, as related in legends. (For. 5:188).

Boom, boom, as of drums.
Redup. of kūpāʻoʻi.

1. An endemic gourd (Sicyos pachycarpa). Cf. ʻānunu and pua-o-Kama.

2. Same as kākū, barracuda.

3. A wild sweet potato or morning-glory with enlarged tuber, eaten in time of famine. Also paha, ʻuala koali. (HP 214).

1. Designation for a koa tree with a thick, straight trunk, perhaps flat on one side or leaning close to the ground, good for a canoe hull.

2. Temporary heiau temple.
To quiet, soothe; soothing.

1. Congested; blocked, as stagnant water.

2. Too loose, large, as of a garment.
Defense; to defend, ward off.
To pole fish from a rock or cliff, to stand on a cliff.

1. Same as ʻalaʻala wai nui, forest herbs.

2. Small, dwarfish, diminutive; humble, of low rank; of retarded growth.

3. A variety of kava with very small leaf.
Same as kūpalaha 1, 2.
Tuberose (Polianthes tuberosa), popular in leis. (Neal 227). Eng.
To vibrate, as the ruffle of a drum; to trill; to drum with the fingers.

To stuff with food, fatten, hence to make a favorite; to attract fish by chumming, as with decayed 
pork; to mash to a pulp, sometimes said of tapa particles or cloth beaten into tapa as it is being prepared. Cf. palu.
Redup. of kūpalu. (For. 5:201.)
Same as kupaianaha.
Wind-blown, as of clothes against the body.

1. Strong permeating fragrance, as of jasmine.

2. Night cestrum (Cestrum nocturnum) and other strong-smelling plants; by some authorities Peperomia spp., Railliardia spp., and a plant used to scent tapa (see pele 3). Also ʻala anumoe, onaona Iāpana.

To speak well of one. Rare.
To limp; to travel slowly. Also kūʻoʻi.

1. To grope, feel, as when looking for flaws in a wooden bowl.

2. Hand-to-hand fight, struggle; to fight thus.
Bedrock; to stand on bedrock; depths of the earth.
Chief of the highest rank; state of heavenly foundation.
Same as papau.
Corpse, cadaver, dead body, carcass.
To stand facing the wind, as a house; exposed to the wind. Rare.

1. Entirely finished.

2. Fearful, shrinking. Rare.
Name of the sixth day of the lunar month, and last of the four taboo days of Kū.
To reverberate. See ex., kūakā.

1. To stumble, twist the ankle. Fig., to misstep, err in conduct. Cf. ʻōkupe.

2. A hula step: with the feet still and the knees bent, the body swings three times quite low down to the right, over to the left, and up.

3. Same as ʻōlepe kupe, a bivalve.

4. To steer a canoe; canoe endpieces.
Two pairs, as in poker. Eng.
See kūpē

1. Bracelet, anklet; fetters, manacles, handcuffs; to put or tie on bracelets, anklets, fetters; to hogtie.

Bracelet.
Dog-tooth anklets.
To bind feet of cattle, especially with the lasso.
To walk slowly, unsteadily, as of a sick person. Cf. pehe, unsteady.
To pelt, throw at. Cf. pehi, to throw.
An edible bivalve found at Pearl Harbor, possibly Chama species. (KL. line 29.)
Nervously afraid. Rare.

1. To knead, as bread dough or very hard fresh poi.

2. To dub out the inside of a log for a canoe hull; to scoop out, as a trench; to dig and plow, as a taro patch.

3. Concoction of juices of herbs mixed with poi, tender taro leaves, coconut cream, mashed sweet potato, and other food.

4. To fatten. Cf. pele 2.
Cypress. (Probably Gr.

Sprawling, occupying all the space so that others have no room; broad, as hips.

Camphire, camphor.

Permanent, stationary; to reside long in one place. Cf. pene.
To dip, to dye by dipping; to sop up; to dab as with a wet cloth; to plunge into water, immerse.
Redup. of kūpenu.

1. Var. of ʻūpī.

2. Abscess. Cf. kua kūpī.
Tiny, small, insignificant; to become insignificant.
Cubit. Eng. Iwi kūpika, forearm bone.
See kūpika
Agitated, raging, turbulent, as wind or storm. Fig., mentally disturbed.
Redup. of kūpikiʻō.
Crowded, packed, distressed, severe; critical, as in a crisis; in dire trouble; difficulties.
Subpoena. Eng.

1. To echo, reverberate; to mourn, wail, lament. See ex., laukanaka.

2. To crowd, throng; crowded.
Redup. of kūpinaʻi, to echo.

1. A reef fish (Abudefduf sordidus). Also ʻōʻō nui. Cf. ʻaoʻao-nui.

2. Rare. var. of kāpīpī, to sprinkle; to dash, as spray.

Round; bundled up with clothes, as in cold weather.
Calm.

To roll, wrap up, as a package; to wither and curl up, as a banana leaf.
Unresponsive, fatigued, exhausted, spiritless.
Vaulting on a long pololū spear.
Fragrance (similar to kūpaoa).
To stand a bond.

Upright, perpendicular, honest, decent, proper, appropriate, satisfactory, rightful, reliable, right, just, fair, qualified, suitable, advisable, advantageous, convenient, seemly, fit, natural, applicable, nearby; worth, merit, excellence. Cf. huina kūpono.
Unsuitable, improper, disqualified, ill-fitting, inauspicious.
Same as kūpō 2.

1. Redup. of kūpou 1.

2. Similar to kūpaʻakai. Kauaʻi.

1. To go down, walk downhill fast, stagger; to bend far forward, as one reeling drunk. See kānāwai.

2. Cigar wrasse fish (Cheilio inermis). Also poupou.
Socket in canoe for mast. Lit., stand mast pole.
Befuddled, stupefied, mentally clouded, dazed, carried away with emotion, stricken.

1. Redup. of kūpou 1.

2. Same as kūpou 2; the name may be qualified by lelo, yellowish.

1. Sprout, growth; offspring; upstart, as one rising suddenly and conspicuously to high position; to sprout, grow, germinate, increase; to occur.

2. Spirit, supernatural being. (For. 4:161.)
See "hoʻokupu":  Tribute, tax, ceremonial gift-giving to a chief as a sign of honor and respect; to pay such tribute; church offering. (Ezera 6.8.)
Thick, as gravy, or moisture-laden lomi fish; to jell.
Demigod or culture hero, especially a supernatural being possessing several forms (as Kama-puaʻa and Laenihi); one possessing mana; to possess kupua (magic) powers. Cf. kalakupua.
Name of a star. Lit., demigod beneath the heavens.

1. Rascal, scamp.

2. Hero, wondrous one, so called because the hero of tales often as a youth was mischievous and fond of plundering taro or stealing chickens (as Kama-puaʻa), a means of showing his exemption from the taboos of ordinary men. (Laie 475.)
Pas/imp. of kupu.
Evil person. (Kel. 22.)

1. Clustered, thick, rank.

2. Name of a constellation of a cluster of seven stars. Cf. Makaliʻi, Pleiades.

1. Redup. of kupu 1; to surge forth, as lava. (For. 6:545.) See ex., unu 2.

2. General name for ferns on a single stem, such as kupukupu 3.

3. Sword fern (Nephrolepis exaltata), a long, narrow fern with many lateral divisions; it was sometimes added to the hula altar to Laka, for knowledge to kupu (sprout). (Neal 14–5.) Also niʻaniʻau and palapalai on Niʻihau, and ʻōkupukupu.
Rose geranium (Pelargonium graveolens), flowers pink, leaves fragrant, used in leis with odorless flowers. (Neal 471.) Also kupukupu haole and laniuma. (Neal 471.)
Same as kupukupu ʻala.
Long, narrow fern (Nephrolepis duffii), with numerous short lateral divisions to the frond. (Neal 14–5.) Lit., small-leafed fern.
A fern (Thelypteris boydiae, synonym Dryopteris cyatheoides var.
Spring season. Lit., leaf sprouting.
Days set aside for prayer; to set aside time for prayer. (Kep. 23.)
Var. of kupa liʻi 2.

1. Grandparent, ancestor, relative or close friend of the grandparent's generation, grandaunt, granduncle.

2. Starting point, source; growing.
Plural of kupuna 1.
Rare. var. of kupuna wahine.
Grandfather, granduncle, male ancestor.
Great grandparent, great grandaunt or uncle.
Great-great-great-grandparent, aunt or uncle.
Great-great-grandparent, great-great granduncle or grandaunt.
Grandmother, grandaunt, female ancestor.
To stand around, surround. Cf. kaʻapuni.
To flourish, grow vigorously, mature early, as an adolescent.
Redup. of kupuohi.
Redup. of kūpuʻu.

Taro or sweet potatoes eaten with no preparation other than scraping or baking, i.e., without being pounded into poi or mixed with coconut cream; to take food from the oven and eat it informally; to have potluck.
An endemic genus of small trees (Broussaisia), with a few forms, in the saxifrage family. Cf. kanawao. Lit., mountain sprout.

1. vs. To release, let go, discharge, abandon, free, dismiss, give up, yield, slacken; to pay out, as a line or cable; to settle, as earth; to diminish, as stream water; to fail to help (Kanl. 31.6); to finish, as a chant; to adjourn, put down, subside. Fig., to be at peace (see idioms that follow).

2. Type of net let down from a canoe; gill net; to set or lower a net or catch in a net. Cf. kūpō.

3. My, mine (this form may replace both kaʻu and koʻu; it is frequently used before ipo and lei and kinship terms and expresses affection (see ex., kei 1).
Pas/imp. of kuʻu 1. See chant, ʻalaneo 1.
To stand a watch; watchman, sentinel, guard.
See kū uaki
Name of a wind associated with Ka-lā-heo, Kauaʻi. (For. 5:97.)
See palapala kuʻukino.
To drop to one's knees; to bend the knees, as while genuflecting.

1. Redup. of kuʻu 1; to let down gradually, slack off a little at a time. See ala kuʻukuʻu.

2. Small, short-legged spider, so called because it lowers itself (kuʻu) on a single string fiber.

3. Boomerang.

Any stone god used to attract fish, whether tiny or enormous, carved or natural, named for the god of fishermen; heiau near the sea for worship of fish gods; hut where fish gear was kept with kūʻula images so that gear might be impregnated with kūʻula mana, usually inland and very taboo. Lit., red Kū.
Unrestrained, promiscuous, wanton (Iak. 5.5); free to do as one wants, whether right or wrong.
Pas/imp. of kuʻu 2.
Rough, high, as billows.
Chilled, shivering with cold; shy, abashed.

1. Slope of a hill; let down, descended. Fig., traditional, hereditary.

2. Place where a net is set in the sea; to let down a fish net.

3. Relaxed, relieved.
Anchorage.
To release a word, make known.
To do with all one's might or strength, exert oneself;to go the limit; to release all checks, inhibitions, restraints. See ex., kaʻukaʻu lua.
Pas/imp. of kuʻupau.
Var. spelling of kū uaki.
To hang loose, dangle, as a string; to droop, to float in the wind, flutter, swing; to fall, as ripened fruit; fringed; tassel, sarong.
Redup. of kuʻuwelu.

Considerable spelling variation exists between kuw- and ku-, as kuwala, kuala; kuwelo, kuelo; kūwō, kūō. Both variants are listed in the dictionary, but the definition follows the preferred form, which is usually kū- unless the remainder of the entry exists as a separate word, or begins with a long vowel. See .

1. To make a din, talk loudly, resound. See wā 3 and chant, kūmaumau 3.

2. Prayer for special events, as trimming grass from over the door of a grass house, or completion of a new canoe or net. (Malo 184.) See ʻeleao 3.
Outside, outer, foreign.
Var. spelling of kuai.
Sinker on an ʻōpelu net.
Redup. of kuwā 1.
Var. spelling of kuala. Note derivatives after kuala.
Redup. of kuwala (and kuala); topsyturvy, handspring; to turn cartwheels.
Much, many. (KL. line 541.) Cf. makawalu, olowalu, walu 3.
Var. spelling of kuehu.
Var. spelling of kuelo.

1. Woody shrub with a long tail-like inflorescence resembling cockscomb, perhaps an amaranth.

2. Same as limu loloa 2.

3. Same as kuʻuwelu.

1. To move restlessly, embrace, pet, caress; to spin in a dance. Cf. kuili, wili 1.

2. Implement for piercing an ivory ornament.
Redup. of kūwili 1.
See uwō.
See lā 6.

1. Sun, sun heat; sunny, solar. See ex., lolo, brain.

2. Day, date.

3. A sail.

4. Fin.

5. Each of two cross sticks holding corners of the dip net called ʻupena ʻākiʻikiʻi.

6. Common demon. occurring after both nouns and verbs, and as the last part of the demon.

7. expressing doubt, uncertainty. See .

8. The letter “l”. Eng.

9. Sixth note on the musical scale, la. Eng.

10. Common refrain in songs, as in Elbert and Mahoe 90.

1. Short for lau 1, with k- of the following word omitted: lāʻalo for lau kalo, taro leaf; lāʻī for lau kī, ti leaf; lāʻō for lau kō, sugar-cane leaf. Also lāʻie for lau ʻie, lākī for lau kī.

2. Short for lau 3. Cf. lāʻā, lāʻiki, lālahi, lānihinihi.

3. Third person, in the dual and plural pronouns only, lāua and lākou. (PNP kilaa-, PEP laa-.)

1. Sacred, holy, devoted, consecrated, set apart or reserved as for sacred purposes, dedicated. Cf. laʻahia.

2. Cursed, defiled (Kanl. 22.9), bound under an oath, doomed to death or destruction, in great trouble.

3. Time, season (perhaps short for lāʻau and a missionary introduction). Cf. laʻa make, laʻa ua, laʻa ʻula, laʻa ulu.

4. Same as palai ʻula, a fern.

5. To propagate plants by inarching. (AP) Cf. kākiwi.

6. Also, together with, so, besides, such as, like.
Width, breadth, as of cloth. Cf. laulā.
Past days of youth, strength, beauty, prosperity.
Feast day.
See "hoʻolaʻa hale":  Dedication of a house; to dedicate a house.
Pas/imp. of laʻa 1, 2.
Thanksgiving Day. Rare. Lit., turkey-eating day.
Sacred light, sacred things of day, as sunshine, knowledge, happiness. Lit., light sacredness. Cf. laʻa uli.
See "hoʻolaʻalaʻa":  Var. of hoʻolāʻau. See lāʻau. Rare.
Small sticks, twigs, herbs, shrubs, bush (Puk. 3.2).
Mature taro tops too tough to eat, and good only for wrapping (contraction of lau kalo, taro leaf).

1. Varieties of small, narrow-bodied kitchen roaches including the brown-banded cockroach (Supella supellectilium) and the German cockroach (Blatella germanica or Symploce hospes). Perhaps named for Olaʻa, Hawaiʻi.

2. Var. of olaʻaloa, a variety of hard taro.
Name of a legendary people who were said to worship images and not gods, in the time of Wākea or of Hawaiʻi Loa. (For. 6:266, 271.) Also Lālālūʻau.
Season when plants die or grow slowly, like autumn in cooler climates. Lit., dead season.
Calabash tree (Crescentia cujete), introduced from tropical America, fruit used for hula rattle with aliʻipoe seeds. (Neal 771.)
Person presiding over the game of kilu. Lit., quiet day. (Malo 217, Emerson note.)

1. Tree, plant, wood, timber, forest, stick, pole, rod, splinter, thicket, club; blow or stroke of a club; strength, rigidness, hardness; male erection; to have formed mature wood, as of a seedling; wooden, woody; stiff, as wood.

2. Medicine, medical.

3. Lump or knot in the flesh, as eased by the rubbing kahi massage; to feel such a knot or stiffness; cramp. Charley horse; to have a cramp.

4. Picture frame.

5. General name for canoe endpiece. See lāʻau hope, lāʻau ihu.

6. For nights of the moon beginning with Lāʻau see below and Malo 31, 35. (PEP Laʻakau.)
See "hoʻolāʻau": To insist, urge persistently; continuously, persistently, endlessly. Hoʻolāʻau ka ʻai ʻana a ka iʻa, the fish ate ceaselessly.
Rainy season.
Chopsticks.
Castor-oil plant; Lit., oil plant. Also kolī, pāʻaila, kaʻapehā, kamākou.
Fragrant wood, especially sandalwood.
Children of chiefs by second matings; their children were termed laʻa uli. (Kam. 64:6.)
Yardstick, ruler, surveying rod, measuring stick.
Salve, ointment. Lit., rubbing medicine.

1. Asthma medicine.

2. Jimson weed (Datura stramonium), a cosmopolitan weed, related to nānāhonua (Brugmansia candida), a coarse annual herb with white or pale purple or blue trumpet-shaped flowers 5 to 10 cm long and spiny fruits about 5 cm long. The plant is strongly narcotic and poisonous. A drug called stramonium, extracted from dried leaves and flowering tops, is used to treat asthma. Also kīkānia, kīkānia haole. (Neal 750.)
Vine.
Switch, club.
Inhalant.
Drug, narcotic, soporific, medicine to cause sleep, chloroform.
Tonic, any medicine that strengthens.
Rolling pin, any wooden roller.
Drumstick. Lit., drumplaying stick. Cf. ʻuha moa, chicken drumstick.
Same as lāʻau hoʻopiʻi.
Insecticide. Lit., medicine to kill insects.
Tranquilizer.
Narcotic, drug. Lit., medicine to relax the body.
Same as lāʻau hoʻohiamoe.
Cathartic medicine.
Drug, as opium. Lit., befogging plant.
Medicine to prevent fecundation.
Emetic. Lit., medicine to make come up.
Same as lāʻau hoʻopiʻi.
Splint.
Implement for mixing poi or poi palaoa.
After endpiece of a canoe.
Any gum-producing tree or plant, as candlenut, spruce.
Bow endpiece of a canoe.
Edible herb. Cf. Roma 14.2. Lit., small eaten plant.
Cypress (RSV), fir tree (KJV) (Zek. 11.2); terebinth (RSV), elm (KJV) (Hos. 4.13); conifer.
Boom of a vessel. Lit., turning stick.
A type of faith healing of broken or crushed bones or sprains. Lit., calling medicine.
One-by-four lumber.
Lantana. Lit., thorny plant. See lākana.
Christmas tree.
Bamboo stamp for marking tapas. Lit., printing stick.
Wooden cross or crucifix; bar to hold a gate shut, brace, bolt.
Bar to hold a gate shut, bolt. Cf. kī, key.
Stick for snaring birds. Cf. kia manu.
Easel.
Ball bat of any kind.
House post, post, doorpost; mast. Rare. Cf. pou. Lit., standing stick.
Ladder, tree with crosspieces used as a ladder (PH 174). Lit., joined wood.
Coffee huller.
Wooden palu pestle.
Eighteenth day of the lunar month.
Nineteenth day of the lunar month.
Parasite. Lit., plant without foundation. A legendary koa tree with this name at Kahikikolo, Kauaʻi, was said to have only branches and no trunk.
Stocks, wooden fetters, handcuffs. Lit., bracelet sticks.
Autumn. Lit., red time [of leaves].
Chopsticks.
Boom of a vessel. Cf. lāʻau kū. Lit., down stick.
Medicine. Lit., curing medicine.
Sacred or doomed darkness, ignorance, gloom, the unknown, misfortune. Cf. laʻa kea, lāʻau aliʻi.
Small bush, plant, or stick.
Rosewood.
Spring, time of growth. (Kep. 89.)
Two-by-four lumber.
Policeman's club.
Poison.
Same as lāʻau hoʻohiamoe.
Wooden bedstead.
Toothpick. Lit., stick to pick teeth.
Bramble, briar, thorny tree.
Boom of a vessel.

Billiard cue. Lit., billiard stick.
Ball bat, tennis racket, pingpong paddle; any kind of paddle for slapping a ball. Lit., stick for beating ball.
Fighting club.
Herbs, tender vegetables.
Twentieth day of the lunar month.
Punk for mosquitoes. Lit., stick mosquito powder.
Var. of lāʻau hoʻopiʻi.
Name of a gambling game. Lit., betting stick.
See "hoʻolaʻa waʻa":  Blessing of a canoe launching; to dedicate a canoe.

1. Forehead, brow.

2. Cape, headland, point, promontory. (PEP laʻe.)

3. Wisdom; mental or emotional qualities. Cf. lae oʻo, lae paʻa, lae ʻula, and idioms pohā 1; poʻohū 1.

4. An insulting term, followed by qualifiers, referring to kauā, outcasts, who had dots tattooed on their foreheads (Malo 70–2). Cf. lae kiko, lae mamo, lae puni.
Same as laʻelaʻe 1; pure in sentiment (Hal. 19.8). Cf. kālaʻe.
Syllables repeated in chants at ends of verses to mark time and for gay effect, similar to ehehene.
Unicorn, rhinoceros. Lit., brow with protruding horn.
Same as noio, a tern. Lit., white brow.
To bow low, as the head. Lit., earthward forehead.
Kauā, outcast, with a dot tattooed on the forehead. Lit., dotted forehead.
Type of hard, red stone, as used for adzes. Also humuʻula.
Forested point, whether at sea or inland. See ex., kilokilohia.

1. Bright, shiny, clear, serene, calm, pleasant.

2. A variety of sweet potato. (HP 142.)

3. Name of a star.
Syllables repeated in songs at ends of verses to mark time and for gay effect, similar to laʻehana.
Old leaf, ready to fall or beginning to dry (a contraction of lau ʻelemakule, old leaf). Fig., aged; old age.
A kind of wine-red cotton cloth. Lit., long brow.
Prominent, as a ridge. Lit., double brow.
Mamo (bird) brow, a derisive name for kauā, outcasts, perhaps because the mamo, like some kauā, has a black mark on its brow (the yellow feathers of the mamo were prized, not the black).
Name applied to various high-headed labroid fishes of the genera Hemipteronotus and Iniistius; this name may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, kea, nēnē, pūkea. Lit., sharp forehead.
An expert. Lit., mature brow. Cf. lae ʻula.

1. Hard headed, obstinate, stubborn, closed in mind and hostile to new ideas. Lit., hard brow.

2. Term for kauā, outcast. Lit., marked forehead, probably referring to tattoo marks on forehead.
Term for kauā, outcast.
Bulging forehead.
A well-trained, clever person; expert. Lit., red brow [red being the sacred color]. Cf. lae oʻo.

1. Gourd calabash painted with patterns. (HP 208.)

2. A kind of yam with white flesh under the skin (HP 168), contrasting with those with purple-red flesh under the skin that were liked for medicine.

1. To poise aloft, as a kite.

2. Rare var. of lēhei, lēkei, to leap.

1. A variety of sugar cane, usually free tasseling, heavy stooling, and with rather semierect to recumbent growth; large, long heavy tops. (HP 222.)

Redup. of laha 1; also said of a hen covering her chickens with her wings.

Redup. of lahaina, leaping.

Slippery, muddy. (And.)

Birthday.
Rare, choice, unique; not spread, not common.

A variety of sugar cane; a pink or light red, striped mutation of lahi 2, and otherwise same as lahi. (HP 223.) Lit., pink-striped lahi.

Convex; swelling; increasing in size; erect, as male organ.
Pas/imp. of lalahū.
Redup. of laʻi.
A cutting (to plant).
Whitetip shark (Pterolamiops longimanus), up to 4 m long. Lit., white fins.

1. Rarotonga, Rarotongan. (Tahitian; the regular Hawaiian correspondent of Tahitian Rarotoʻa would have been Lalokona; the second a in Lalakoʻa probably assimilated to the preceding a; .)

2. Prayer for luakini dedication. (For. 6:27.)
With strong limbs. Lit., coral branch.
Many.
To sun, bask; sunny.
Similar to lalawe. (For. 6:523.)
Same as Laʻalūʻau. (Kep. 19.)

1. Daring, fearless, clever, as of a climber of precipices or trees.

2. To pilfer, meddle, grope, reach here and there; to be scattered here and there, as houses (Kel. 119); pilfering.

1. Spider. Also lanalana, nananana.

2. Warming, as at a fire. Cf. lala, warm.

3. Old term for London.

1. Row, rank, file, line; verse of poetry.

2. A name for the Milky Way (Kep. 81), and also of a single star. Cf. Nā-lālani-a-pili-lua.
Curve, arc.
Redup. of laʻo 1.
See "hoʻolalaʻō":  To insist on accompanying. Kaʻu poʻe moʻopuna he hoʻolalaʻō i ka hele me aʻu, my grandchildren insist on going with me.
Same as lapalapa 1, 2.
Mistake, blunder, going astray; to go astray, wander, blunder, err, gad about, have sexual affairs, miss the way. Cf. maka lalau.
To seize, take hold of, grasp, reach out for, pick up, hold fast.
Gray, stormy-looking, smoke-colored.
To wander in error, sin.
To snatch away or grab roughly or ruthlessly.
To grab in the hands, tackle, manhandle.
Prosperous, successful, well-to-do, rich.
Redup. of lawe, to carry; thrilling, overwhelmed, transported with emotion; to itch.

1. To hasten, hurry, push on; to encourage, urge on, stir up to action. See ex., ʻeka 2.

2. Legendary bird mentioned in old tales and songs as a sweet singer.
Buoy, beacon; prominent object or landmark ashore to steer by. (And.) Cf. māka, marker.
Cluster, bunch, as of bananas; assembled together, as flowers in a lei. Rare.
Redup. of lale.
Greasy, as pork fat; slippery and shiny, glittering, sparkling, bright; sticky. Cf. ali, hulali.
Detailed; to do detailed work, attend to small details.
Redup. of lali.

1. Down, downward, low, lower, under, beneath, below, subordinate; depth, lowness, west (see ex., naʻe 1); hold of a ship (frequently preceded by prepositions, sometimes joined as single words).

2. Leeward, lee, southern.
Of humble origin, lowly. (Malo 56.)
A variety of sweet potato. (HP 142.)
Name of a ravenous sea bird, perhaps a gull (RSV); cuckoo (KJV). (Kanl. 14.15.) (Gr.
See lalu
Decoration Day. Lit., day to scatter flowers. Cf. Lā Kau Pua.

1. All endemic kinds of ebony (Diospyros, synonym Maba), hardwood trees with small flowers and fruits. (Neal 674.) Also ēlama. (PNP lama.)

2. Torch, light, lamp.

3. Also rama Rum; any intoxicating drink. Eng. He kanaka inu lama, a person fond of drinking; a drinker or heavy drinker.
Mixed alcoholic drink, cocktail, highball. Lit., mixed rum.
Holiday; festive day on which people gathered for parties and celebrations. Lit., day of people's faces.
A tree mentioned in a chant in Kam. 76:118.

1. Large torch, formerly 60 to 90 cm tall, with the light coming from burning kukui nuts strung on a coconut midrib and wrapped in dried ti leaves and placed at the tips of bamboo handles; signal fires; lantern (Lunk. 7.16); sparks, as of a torch (Isa. 50.11).

2. Name for a medicine applied to sores.
Beacon, signal light.

1. Torch fishing; torch; to go torch fishing.

2. Fair-complexioned; bright-looking; animated; vivacious; to glow.
Same as lama hoʻohuihui ʻia. Lit., mixed rum.
Ramie, an introduced plant (Boehmeria nivea), related to the māmaki, and yielding a strong fiber used for rope, paper, cloth. (Neal 318.) Eng.
See lamie

1. Floating, buoyant; moored, afloat, adrift; to drift, lie at anchor, as a fishing canoe (For. 4:295); calm, still, as water; anchor. Cf. hālana, manaʻolana.

2. Lowest floor of the oracle tower where offerings were placed. (Malo 176.) Cf. lananuʻu, mamao, nuʻu.

3. To be aware of noises as one wakes.

4. Also rana. n. Frog. (Latin rana, a genus.)

1. See "hoʻolana":

2. Nominalizing suffix. Cf. kaulana, kūlana, manaʻolana. (PNP -langa.)
To float or drift with the current; to look about in every direction, wander, ramble, drift aimlessly.
Haughty, superior-acting (Isa. 2.11). Lit., proudly floating.
To drift, as a ship.
Pas/imp. of lana 1.
Land ho! Eng.
Charcoal, coal.
Crook, protuberance, hump; bent out, convex.
Cinders.
Var. of nanai, stiff-backed.
Porch, veranda, balcony, booth, shed; temporary roofed construction with open sides near a house.

1. See "Lā-naʻi":  Island. Perhaps lit., day conquest. Also Nānaʻi.

2. A variety of sweet potato. (HP 142.)
Same as nanaiea, weak.
Name of a star. Lit., the light floats.
See lākana 1.
Var. of nanakea, pale.

1. Victory, triumph; to triumph, win, overcome, beat, prevail, outwit, conquer.

2. Wind, Hau-ʻula, Oʻahu. (Nak. 57.)
To ask for insistently; to desire greatly; great desire. Cf. koi, urge.

1. Redup. of lana 1.

2. Lashings, as of ornamental sennit binding the float (ama) to outrigger booms (ʻiako).

3. Spider. (Isa. 59.5.) Also lalana, nananana.

4. Ylang-ylang (Cananga odorata). (Neal 357–8.)
Pas/imp. of lanalana 1.
See "hoʻolaʻa waʻa":  Hopeful, encouraging. (Kel. 15.) See hoʻolana under lana 1.
Var. of kānana, to strain.

1. High frame where heiau images were placed.

2. Same as lananuʻu mamao.

3. Image placed in front of a heiau (AP)
Oracle tower; the lowest floor was the lana, the second and more sacred floor was the nuʻu, and the top, where the high priest stood to conduct services was the mamao. (Malo 176.)
Unfriendly, unsociable. Same as nanau. Rare.

1. Sky, heaven; heavenly, spiritual.

2. Very high chief, majesty; host (Isa. 34.4); royal, exalted, high born, noble, aristocratic. This meaning is most common in personal names, as Lei-lani, royal child or heavenly lei; Pua-lani, descendant of royalty or heavenly flowers. Cf. kamalani, kuhilani.

3. Kinds of flowers. See below.
To warm, toast, or wilt over a fire, as young pandanus leaves. Cf. ʻōlala, ʻōlani.

1. Royal chief.

2. Same as nani aliʻi, shrubs.
Low sky, of the low sky, a poetic reference to Hāna, Maui, and its rains.
Thin, narrow. Lit., edge surface.

Individual privileged to sit with the chief while the latter ate; he might eat the remnants of the chief's food, thus preventing them from falling into the hands of a sorcerer. (Malo 61.) Lit., chief at edge.
legendary part of heaven; frequent name for residences of high chiefs, as that of Ka-mehameha III at Lahaina, Maui. (Malo 104.) Lit., lofty heaven.
Poetic name for a very high chief or the highest heaven. Lit., sky with rolling ridge [i.e., clouds].
Name of a star. Lit., chief stands [at] work.
Wind of Ka-lalau, Kauaʻi. (For. 5:95.) Lit., heaven releasing canoe.
Redup. of lani.
Highest heavens, an epithet for royalty.
Firmament. Lit., solid heaven.
A rain known at ʻUlu-pala-kua, ʻMaui.
See ua lanipili.
Dense, dark, lush, as of plants, rain; said of luxuriant growth.
Rain name. See chant, lanipō.
Both flowering and aromatic-leaved pelargoniums also called rose geraniums. Cf. kupukupu ʻala. (Neal 471.)
Similar to lemi wai, a water lemon (Passiflora foetida).

Canada fleabane (Conyza canadensis), a weedy composite herb from temperate North America, with long, straight hairy stem, hairy, narrow leaves, and clusters of small flower heads. (Neal 834.) Cf. ilioha. On Niʻihau Conyza bonariensis.
Weekday. Lit., day without taboo.
Holiday, important or big day.
Labor Day. Lit., holiday of the laborers.
Same as lananuʻu.

1. Having something in the eye, as a mote or eyelash.

2. Same as laʻo laʻu 2, 3.

3. Var. of ʻōlaʻo, to weed.

1. Same as lau kō, sugar-cane leaf.

2. A bright-colored 
greenish fish, about 1.3 cm long (Halichoeres ornatissimus).

Var. of haoa, eel-catching stick; to fish with this stick; to choke, as on a bone. (Var. pronunciations are laʻoa, haoa, and haʻoa.) hoʻo.laoa To fish for eels thus. (Var. pronunciation is hoʻolaʻoa.) Nui ka iwi, he hoʻolaoa, there are many bones, they cause choking. (PNP laoa.)

1. Pas/imp. of laʻo 1, 2.

2. Same as laoa.
Deep booming sound, as of distant surf. Rare.

1. Redup. of laʻo 1.

2. Lack of satisfaction, even discomfort, resulting from eating unaccustomed or foreign food.

3. Kindling; small sticks placed at a break in a bank of a taro patch; trash.

4. Rough, pitted, calloused.

1. Ridge, slope, steep side of a ravine; ridged. Cf. kualapa.

2. Overactive, energetic, mischievous; gamboling and cavorting, as a young animal; roughhouse; to flash. Cf. ʻālapa, ʻōlapa.

3. Bamboo liners, for tapa printing.

4. Orifice of the womb. Also lapa pūʻao.

5. Clot, as of blood.

6. A variety of sweet potato.

7. A variety of taro.

8. Male mahimahi fish.

9. To slacken off the lower section on an ʻōpelu bag net; part of the catch remains in the water, and the top part only of the net is raised to the canoe and the catch taken; a large catch would be too heavy to bring up at once.
Days of labor required of tenants. Also lā kōʻele. See paʻahao 2. (RC 378.)
Flame, blaze.
Medical practice; to treat with medicine, heal, cure; medical, medicinal.
Small drum. (Ii 137.)
Rabbit, hare. Eng. ʻIole lāpaki, rabbit.
Blood clot.
Excessively active.

1. Redup. of lapa 1; steep-ridged, many-ridged.

2. Redup. of lapa 2; to bubble, boil, blaze; to cavort.

3. Clotted. Cf. lapa koko.

4. Native mountain trees (Cheirodendron), in the panax family, conspicuous for the slender-stemmed leaves, each leaf with three to five, rarely six or seven leaflets that flutter (lapalapa) in the breeze. (Neal 652.) Also ehu, kauila māhu, māhu, ʻōlapa, ʻōlapalapa. See also hū ʻōlapa.

5. Name for a large mahimahi, dolphin.
Same as lapa 4.
Var. of hāpauea, aged.

1. Same as kunakuna, doorposts.

2. Booms joining hulls of a double canoe, corresponding to ʻiako of a single canoe.
See lapauila
Lightning flash; to flash, as lightning.
Amniotic fluid.
Agitated fresh water, rippling water, cascading water; shining water, as in the sunlight.
Shin, shank. Lit., leg ridge.
Bent, crooked, doubled up; curled up, like the tail of a pig; coiled, flexed. Same as lākeʻe.
Rabbi. (Mat. 23.7.) (Heb.
See lapi
Birthday.
Rare var. of lāpaki.
Same as lūkini, lemon grass.
Ghost (Isa. 34.14), apparition, phantom, specter; haunted; to haunt; to act as a ghost.
To pick up, as sticks for fuel; to collect, gather; to handle, tie.
Sunday. Lit., prayer day.
Bunched up, humped up, curled up; crooked, bent over, arched; head bent forward, as of a bucking horse. Also nāpuʻu.
A hump, crook, arch; a humping, arching.
Vanity, foolishness, worthlessness; worthless, mischievous, of no value; wretch, scoundrel. See ex., niho mole.

1. Leaf, frond, leaflet, greens; to leaf out.

2. Dragnet, seine, so called because formerly made of ti leaves (lau) tied to a rope. Cf. hukilau, lauahi, lauʻapoʻapo, laukō.

3. Sheet; surface; blade, as of grass. Cf. lā- 2; lauahi, lauhoe, laulā, laumania, moena lau.

4. num. To be much, many; very many, numerous; four hundred. Cf. kini, mano.

5. Pattern, as for quilts; design; print of a cloth.

6. Thatched mountain hut, as used by farmers, canoe-makers, birdcatchers.

7. Tip, as of the tongue; top (probably related to wēlau and ʻēlau, tip).

8. Sweet-potato slip or vine.
Not much remaining to do, progressing, nearly finished (commonly used after a negative).
. They, them (dual).
Counselor. Rare.

1. A fragrant fern (Phymatosorus scolopendria syn.

2. Beloved, sweet, of a lover.

3. Same as lauaʻe haole.

4. To gather together, collect.

5. Wind, Honopū, Kauaʻi. (Nak. 58.)
See lauaʻe

A fern (Phlebodium aureum), hare's-foot fern, from tropical America, much like the lauaʻe, 
but with larger, dull light-green scentless fronds. First collected in Hawaiʻi in mountains of Kauaʻi (August, 1909), probably as an escape. (Neal 26.)
Rumor, hearsay.

1. To destroy, as by fire or lava flow. Fig., quick, deft (as after lima); greedy, lecherous. See ex., one ʻā, ʻowāhi.

2. Bag net used for fish, as ʻōhua.
Salad. Lit., edible leaves.
Common; commoner. Lit., much public.
To cooperate, work together, as of experts; to concentrate on the same task; to pool talents.
Tongue tip.
Contraction of lau kalo, taro leaf.
Tapa-beater design. Lit., ʻamaʻu fern pattern.
Type of lau fishing outside the reef, seine. Lit., catching seine.

To withhold; stingy. Fig. to withhold or conceal strength, as a warrior (Malo 196, 203) or gambler; this may refer to the common tale motif of the idol hero who enters the battle only after his confederates are losing, as of Ka-welo, Pele, Panaʻewa. Another figurative use concerns a woman unattractive to males, and (AP) a lottery or game of chance. Cf. ʻauʻa.
Pagoda flower (Clerodendrum buchananii var.

1. Kava leaf.

2. First two or three taro leaves, as offered with kava leaves with prayers for a good food supply.
A gentle wind and rain associated with Hāna, Maui.
See Lau-ʻawaʻawa
A grass endemic to Niʻihau, Panicum niihauense. Lit., red leaf.
Same as pālauʻeka, pittance.
Top, as of sugar-cane tassel or of shell ginger about to bloom. Cf. ʻekī.
To wander mentally, imagine. Rare. Cf. -ele.

1. To glow with heat, anger, passion

2. See One-lau-ʻena.
Pandanus leaf, especially as used in plaiting.
Vagabond, drifter, one as useless as pandanus leaves adrift in the sea. Lit., floating pandanus leaf.
Same as laupapa 1.

Brightly colored butterfly fish (Chaetodon quadrimaculatus and C. umimaculatus). This name may be qualified by the terms kapuhili, kīkākapu, maha uli, nuku ʻiʻiwi or nuku ʻiwi, and wiliwili. Cf. kapuhili.
Leaf of hau tree.
Var. of laulele, weeds.
Same as ʻilieʻe, plumbago.

1. Blade of a paddle

2. To paddle together and uniformly, either in the same or different canoes.
A kind of ʻoʻopu, a fish.

1. A variety of poisonous gourd; to spread, of this vine.

2. Var. of lauhua, a fish.
To clear, remove, as mulch.

1. Tapa soaking, to soak tapa.

2. Name of a goddess worshipped by tapa makers.

1. Dry banana leaf; to wrap, as a bundle, with ti leaves inside and banana leaves outside. Fig., outsider, one from another locality (sometimes said disparagingly).

2. Fast, swift, as of destruction; to seize, as an ʻahi seizes a hook.
Ti leaf. Also lāʻī, lau kī. See ex., polopola 4.
A parrotfish (Scarus dubius).
A native fern (Doodia spp.), somewhat like kupukupu 3.
Var. spelling of lauwili.
Same as lāʻīpala, a tang fish (Zebrasoma flavescens).
Short, stunted it; leaves; a term of opprobrium for the kauā (outcast), as such ti leaves were of less value than long leaves.
Same as lauwiliwili, a fish.

1. Broad-leafed plantain (Plantago major), a Eurasian stemless weed, with thick broad leaves, 2.5 to 25 cm long, forming a rosette near the ground, and with tiny flowers developing in a cylindrical head at the tip of a slender stalk; used externally to ripen and heal boils, internally for diabetes and other ailments. (Neal 792). Lit., single leaf. Also kūhēkili. (Perhaps PCP rautasi).

2. Marsh pennywort (Hydrocotyle verticillata).
Mountain laukahi.
A species of laukahi. Lit., big-leafed laukahi.
A native sword-shaped fern (Elaphoglossum sp.) Lit., small laukahi.

1. Native sword-shaped fern (Elaphoglossum aemulum).

2. Broad-leafed plantain. Lit., large laukahi.
A kind of shark, possibly thresher. Lit., much hit tail.
Snowbush (Breynia disticha syn.
Same as pūnua, fledgling.
Taro leaf.
Laudanum. Eng.
See laukamana
Wind associated with Hālawa, Molokaʻi. (For. 5:103.) Lit., kamani leaf.
Uninterested in religion, indifferent to religion. Rare.
Densely populated, having many people; many people; to populate.
See "hoʻolaukanea":  Same as hoʻokanea. Hoʻolaukanea kēia piki iaʻu no ka mea ʻo ka puni kēia a kuʻu moʻopuna, I've lost appetite for this peach because it is my grandchild's favorite.
Tough, hardy. (For. 6:392.)
Planted sweet-potato vine. See lau 8.
Legendary name for broad leaves of the first taro, said to have been born of a woman. Cf. lau kapalili 2.

1. Same as hukilau, seine fishing, but reportedly used in deeper water and with yellowed ti or banana leaves. Lit., trembling net.

2. Legendary name for trembling leaves of the first taro, said to have been born of a woman. (Malo 244.) Cf. laukapalala.

1. A small tree or shrub (Claoxylon sandwicense, var.

2. Hard gray stone, used for adzes.

3. Gray with age or sickness; pale, as an invalid.
A cosmopolitan tropical weed (Cassia leschen-aultiana), a small shrub with finely divided leaves, yellow flowers, and small narrow pods. (Neal 427.)

1. Ti leaf.

2. Tea leaf. Cf. koʻokoʻolau.
Same as lāʻīpala, a fish.
Yellowed ti leaf.
Dragnet.
To feather out, as young birds.
Leaf of a koa tree.

A variety of sugar cane with green and yellow striped canes and leaves; used in sorcery, because of the meaning of laukōnā, to break the influence of the hana aloha love magic and change love into hatred. Also manini.
Hardhearted, merciless, heartless, unfriendly, implacable; furious, very angry.
Same as laukona. (HP 225.)
Redup. of laukōnā.
Fishing for young fish (pua) with fine nets.
Wind associated with Maui. (For. 5:101.) Lit., water dragnet.

1. Confused, repetitious, mixed, incoherent, as speech; miscellaneous; irregular-shaped, as some leaves.

2. To take or gather indiscriminately. Similar to hāpuku.

3. One skilled in many trades, a jack-of-all-trades.

4. Fish pond. (AP)
A native fern (Lindsaya macraena), with narrow, divided fronds.
Broad, wide; liberal; width, breadth, extent; widely known; publicly.
Spread far and wide, as news, widespread; circulated, publicized; of common or general knowledge; spread contagiously, as a disease. Lit., much spread.
Thin.
Design on a Niʻihau mat. Lit., many torches or lama tree leaves.

1. Wrapping, wrapped package; packages of ti leaves or banana leaves containing pork, beef, salted fish, or taro tops, baked in the ground oven, steamed or broiled; any cloth, net, or leaves used as a wrapper or carrier; to wrap or carry in such bundles.

2. Hat rim.

3. Pregnant.

4. Paddle blade.
Redup. of launa; sociable, friendly, gregarious, genial.
Var. of lauwili. (And.)
Peace, happiness, friendship; restoration of a disrupted friendship; happy, glad, genial, courteous, peaceful.

1. Butterfly weed or milkweed (Asclepias curassavica), a tropical American perennial herb 60 to 90 cm high, with umbels of small orange and yellow flowers and pods full of tufted, wind-borne seeds; the leaves were eaten in time of famine; the Monarch butterfly feeds on the leaves. (Neal 697.) Lit., flying leaf. Also lauhele, pua ʻanuhe. See also hī laulele.

2. Dandelion (Taraxacum officinale). See also hualele. (Neal 860.)

3. Net fishing with small nets as in shallow water (usually used with lawaiʻa or papa)

1. Dark, overcast, shady; darkness. Lit., dark sun.

2. A variety of ulua, a fish. Lit., dark fin.
A slender, prostrate shrub in the pink family (Schiedea stellarioides), endemic to Kauaʻi, with small, linear leaves, and large open panicles of small flowers. Lit., bordered leaf. Also māʻoliʻoli.
Small-leafed; qualifying term for some plants, as maile. Cf. ʻiʻo 3.
Cooperation, joint action; group of people working together; community food patch; to work together, cooperate. Lit., many hands.

1. A variety of taro, said to be the original taro brought to Hawaiʻi. Sometimes poetically called hāloa, long stalk, because a god of that name was said to have been in the form of this taro. This name may be qualified by the terms hāʻeleʻele or ʻeleʻele; ʻeleʻele ʻomaʻo, ʻeleʻele ʻula or palakea ʻeleʻele; hāʻula, koko, ʻulaʻula, or palakea ʻula; uliuli or hāuliuli; keʻokeʻo; manini; ʻōniʻoniʻo; palakea or palakea papamū; pānaʻe; poni (HP 33, TC 3). Cf. hinapū.

2. A variety of sugar cane. When young, yellow-green, striped with light yellow-brown; with exposure, a deep olive, striped with dark brown-red; broad, long, green leaves; large stalks. (HP 222, 225.)

3. Long wave or surf, as extending from one end of the beach to the other. Also kākala.

1. A long leaf.

2. Length; lengthwise.
Wauke leaf. Lit., clothing leaf.
To sway with the movement of the wind, as leaves; to move to and fro, as algae in the sea; blown here and there, as sea spray.
Insult, taunt, sneer, reproach, contempt; to insult, taunt, mock; taunting, mocking, sneering, derisive.
Puff of wind.

1. Var. of laumeki 1–3.

2. Low stroke in club fighting. (RC 59.)
A variety of sweet potato.
A divided leaf; many leaves, many branches; descendants, as of a family.
Smooth, sheer, steep, even.
Var. of laumania.
Wind, Puna-kou, Molokaʻi. (Nak. 69.) Lit., green leaves.
Design on a tapa beater, said to suggest the maʻu leaf.
Blade of grass.
Var. of laumeki 1–3.

1. A kind of barbed spear.

2. To recede, ebb, as the tide or flood waters.

3. To wilt, as plants without water.

1. To writhe, turn, twist, squirm, torture, destroy. Cf. ʻōmilomilo.

2. A species of eel, so called because its color was thought to resemble a yellow milo leaf (lau milo).

Friendly, sociable; to associate with, meet with, fraternize with, visit, be sociable. Used idiomatically with ʻaʻohe, ʻaʻole, ʻole: ʻAʻohe launa ka makaʻu, terrible fear; there's no limit to the fear; lit., no meeting the fear.
Friendly association, fellowship.
Plants, forest growth or leaves, herbs, greenery.
Marriage relationship; marital rights (RSV), marital duties (KJV) (Puk. 21.10).

1. Unequalled, incomparable, unsurpassed, superior (similar to ana ʻole and lua ʻole). See ex., lalawe.

2. Unsociable.
Correspondence; to correspond.
Bare, as of leaves.
Same as launea.
See "hoʻolaunili":  Same as luaiele.
Design on a tapa beater.
Coconut leaf, frond. See hair.
A variety of taro. (HP 33). Lit., large leaf, large design.

1. Sugar-cane leaf (same as lau kō).

2. Young white coconut leaves near the heart.
Similar to kūoʻe, to saunter.
Var. spelling of lauʻowē.

1. Sail of a vessel.

2. Dense, lush, of vegetation. Cf. ohaoha.

3. Variation in vision, depending on distance of the object seen. (AP).
Redup. of lauoha 2.
Hair of the head. Lit., head leaf. (For types of hair see hair). (PCP lauo(f,s)o.)
Hair switch, wig. Lit., added hair.

1. See "Pele's":  hair, volcanic glass spun out in hairlike form.

2. A fine, hairlike seaweed, found at Wai-kīkī.
One with dark hair, brunette; dark hair.
Olive leaves; perhaps formerly used fig. for letters.
Soil light, fertile, and easy to cultivate; alluvial soil, sandy soil. Lit., sand surface.
Shrimp net, about a fathom long, placed around a heap of rocks called ahu or imu (fish and shrimp were prodded and frightened from the rock pile into the net); this type of fishing.
Intensive of ʻowē, murmuring.
See lauʻowē
Merry, jolly, humorous, laughprovoking, funny, playful, witty. Lit., much playing.
First two leaves of a taro shoot (according to some, the first three leaves).

1. Same as laupaʻe.

2. A great many, multitude, great quantity, heap; to increase, multiply; to have much of; well supplied with.
Fading leaf turning yellow, red, or brown. Fig., person failing in health.
To shine, glitter, sparkle, as dew in the sun. (AP).

1. A broad flat, as of coral, lava, reef.

2. Board, lumber.
A kind of fish. (And.).
Same as poʻopoʻohina.
A kind of sweet potato (HP 142). Lit., red leaf.
Indistinct, as the voice of a sick person. Rare.

Stream or pond full of water; many streams: abundance of water.

1. A butterfly fish (Chaetodon miliaris).

2. Redup. of lauwili.
Butterfly fishes (Forcipiger longirostris and F. flavissimus). Lit., sharp-beaked wiliwili leaf.

1. Enough, sufficient, ample; to have enough, be satisfied.

2. Possessed of enough or ample knowledge, hence wise, capable, competent.

3. As soon as.

4. Strong, husky; strong man, as in a king's retinue. Cf. lawakua

5. To bind, make fast, tie securely..

6. White, as of a cock or dog.

7. A large shark fishhook. (AP).
White mixed with a darker color, as of a chicken; dark hair streaked with gray; white chicken with sprinkling of red feathers. Cf. aʻeaʻe.

1. Fisherman; fishing technique; to fish, to catch fish.

2. Cormorant. (Oihk. 11.17).

3. Name of a group of seven stars.
Fishing within the reef, as by women and children, with long bags of fine mesh into which fish were driven.
The old name for hukilau fishing.
Birdcatcher, birdcatching with a net. Lit., to fish birds.
Same as moa 1. See lawa 6.

1. Strong-backed, muscular, of strong physique, bulging with muscles. See ex., konapiliahi.

2. To bind or tie fast, as on the back. Fig., to be a dear friend or companion. (PH 218).

3. Name of a mountain wind at Nā-pali, Kauaʻi. See ex., noiele.

4. A lua fighting stroke.
Redup. of lawa 5.
See "hoʻolawalawa":  Redup. of hoʻolawa, to supply. Ua hoʻolawalawa i ka ʻai, supply all with enough food.
Redup. of lawaiʻa; to fish here and there.
Type of large wooden bowl.
Fish or meat bound in ti leaves for cooking; to cook thus.

1. Very strong.

2. To bind tightly.
Enough for all, well-supplied or equipped.

1. To take, transport, carry, bring, haul, 
fetch, undertake, accept (as a duty), make off with, acquire; portable; bearer. Cf. lalawe, lawe hānai.

2. Finally to become; to become. See ex., mikihilina.
Pas/imp. of lawe.
To borrow, take on credit.
Highest heavens. (For. 6:363).
To drift apart; to depart, as in death.
To bear a flag; color bearer.
Sin, sinner, delinquency, offense; evil, delinquent, sinful; to sin, transgress.
Workman, laborer; industrious; to do labor, work.
To adopt, as a child.
To take here and there.
Bearer of the feather standard of royalty (kāhili).
To act with partiality.
Cry of the kioea, curlew bird: “Kioea, kioea, lawekeō, lawelawekeō”.

1. To serve, work for, minister to, tend, attend to, do, perform, serve, transact; to treat, as the sick; to wait, as on tables; to handle.

2. To pilfer, make off with.
Function, administration.
One who cares for the bones of the dead.
Redup. of lawekeō.
To take illegally, without permission, tamper with.
To carry in the hand; to pitch in and lend a hand, help; to assault, beat, tackle; anything carried in the hand. Cf. lawelawe 2.
Mail carrier, postman; to carry mail or letters.
To carry by hand.
To study both sides of a question; to act impartially. Lit., take two.
Getting, acquiring, taking, carrying, acquisition; movement, as of dancing hands.
Same as lawe ʻōlelo.
Passenger carrier; to carry passengers.
Manslaughter, homicide; to take a life; to take alive.
Talebearer, tattle; gossip; to gossip, bear tales; microphone.
Conquest; to capture, take captive, abduct, conquer, take a prisoner, carry into captivity.
A great flow of water; water carrier; water-borne.
Extortion, seizure of property with the owner's knowledge; to extort, take without right.
Var. of lawelawe. Rare.
To go about aimlessly, to do no work; listless, lazy.

1. Goddess of canoe builders.

2. Name of a star.

1. Joy, pleasure, happiness, merriment; sexual gratification, orgasm; pleasing, gay, delightful, happy, merry; delighted, pleased. Cf. manawaleʻa.

2. Clearly, perfectly, thoroughly, successfully, Cf. kāleʻa, kūleʻa.

3. The zenith star Arcturus. Also Hōkū-leʻa.

1. Redup. of leʻa 1; to have a good time; fun, gaiety (see ex. henehene), amusement.

2. Name of a prayer to Kū, Kāne, Lono, and the ʻaumākua (family gods). (Kep. 23).

Reem; wild ox (RSV), unicorn (KJV) (Nah. 24.8). (Heb.

2. Lazy, neglectful; to loaf. Rare. Cf. palaleha.

2. Stretched, loose. (PEP le(f,s)e).

3. Deep-sea fish resembling ulua, perhaps Caranx chelio.

1. To jump, hop, as a goat over a wall; to leap, start up and fly.

2. A rain associated with Maka-wao, Maui.

3. A lua fighting stroke.

1. Lips; labia of vagina; language (Kin. 11.1; rare), mouth of the iheihe net. For fig. use cf. 
lehelehe kiʻi, lehelehe nui lehe ʻoi.

2. Redup. of lehe 2.
Fat, bulging with fat, unwieldy.
Redup. of lēhei.
Same as lepe-o-Hina, seaweeds.
Indolent talker; to do nothing but talk. Lit., image lips.
A variety of sweet potato. (HP 142.)
Thick lips.
Pouting lip.
Sharp-lipped, an epithet often applied to Pele because she devoured everything in her path; sharp-tongued, of one who makes cutting remarks.
Skilled, expert, as in fishing; deft. Cf. paulehia.
Admirable, attractive; to admire.

1. General name for cowry shell; they were used as octopus lures.

2. Callus, as on shoulders from carrying heavy loads.

3. Covetous. Cf. maka leho.
A species of cowry (Cypraea mauritiana). Lit., fire cowry.
A species of cowry (Cypraea maculifera, C. mauritiana). Lit., kōlea bird cowry, perhaps so called because its brown streaks suggest the kōlea bird.
The serpent-head cowry (Cypraea caput-serpentis). Lit., native cowry.
A species of cowry shell (Cypraea caput-serpentis), used for bracelets, kūpeʻe lima.

1. Redup. of leho 2.

2. Potbellied.
Same as leho puna, sometimes used in leis.
Same as leho ʻōmao, a greenish cowry.
The common dotted, brown cowry. Lit., genuine cowry.
A cowry with the extremities drawn out, a beaked cowry, such as Cypraea cicercula var.
A species of cowry (Cypraea granulata). Lit., rough cowry.
See ʻō.lū.palaha. (Kam. 76:152.)
A greenish cowry (diseased cowries sometimes turn green).
A species of cowry (Cypraea helvola). Lit., variegated cowry.
Same as leho ʻōkala. Lit., bumpy or rough cowry.
A cowry of a solid color, as Cypraea mauritiana.
Same as leho puna, but with a yellow hue. Lit., ivory cowry.
Cowries, as Cypraea schilderdrum, C. carneola.
A very dark-brown cowry (Cypraea mauritiana).
Earth-clinging rainbow. Also uakoko. Lit., wet cowry shell.
A white money cowry (Cypraea moneta). Lit., coral cowry.
A rare dark-yellow money cowry (Cypraea moneta). Lit., sweet-potato cowry.
The rare and highly prized red cowry, probably Cypraea sp.

1. Ashes; ash-colored or gray, as a chicken. See saying, ash.

2. A variety of sugar cane, probably recently introduced, extensively planted by Hawaiians. The stunted mature stalks look dead except for their green leaves. A gray to green-brown frosted-looking cane covered with hairs; pith green-white; both sides of leaves bearing long scattered hairs. (HP 224, 225.)

3. num. The number 400,000; numerous, very many. Cf. lehulehu.

1. The flower of the ʻōhiʻa tree (Metrosideros macropus, M. collina subsp.

2. Laden, as a lehua tree with beautiful blossoms.

3. Rainbow-colored mother-of-pearl shell used for fishing lure.

4. A variety of taro, used for red poi. Cultivars may be qualified by the terms keʻokeʻo (white) or maoli (native). (TC 4.)

5. Globe amaranth (Gomphrena globosa). Also lehua mau loa, lehua pepa, leihua.

6. A variety of yam; the stem has red wings and the tuber has light pinkish flesh. (HP 168.)

7. . Name of the small island just west of Niʻihau. As the westernmost of the Hawaiian Islands (except for the Northwest Hawaiian Islands), Lehua is associated with a setting sun (see chant, kalakalaʻihi). In poetry, the extent of the Hawaiian Islands is shown by coupling Lehua Island and Haʻehaʻe and Kumu-kahi on East Hawaiʻi (see welo 2, welona). A breeze is named for this island.

8. Pas/imp. of lehu 1.

9. Expert, as in fishing.
A variety of lehua (Metrosideros tremuloides), noted in songs and chants of Nuʻu-anu Valley, Oʻahu. Also ʻāhihi.
A kind of lehua tree bearing dark-red flowers.
A variety of taro; corm white or slightly pink; may be a sport of a true lehua. Lit., black lehua.
Same as lehua pua kea. Lit., white lehua.
Poetic reference to the lehua tree. Lit., silent lehua, so called because bird-catchers were silent when snaring birds on branches of this tree and this activity was taboo.
Red- or white-flowered species of Calliandra shrubs from various parts of America (Neal 404–5.) Lit., foreign lehua.
Ashes. Lit., fire ash.
Clover. Lit., foreign lehua.
Same as lehua pua kea.
A variety of taro called waiākea in Kona, Hawaiʻi. Lit., white lehua.
Star in the Milky Way, perhaps Antares. Lit., south lehua flower.
A variety of pink lehua taro. Lit., lehua standing in the uplands.
A variety of taro. (HP 33.) Lit., hill-standing lehua taro.
A form of lehua with sessile cordate leaves.
A form of ʻōhiʻa lehua tree with very small leaves. Lit., small-leafed lehua.
A variety or taro. (HP 33.) Lit., small-eyed lehua.
A small shrub (Metrosideros pumila var.
A form of ʻōhiʻa lehua tree with yellow flowers. Lit., mamo-bird lehua, so called because the mamo has yellow feathers.
Globe amaranth (Gomphrena globosa). Lit., everlasting lehua, so called because its flowers when used in leis do not wilt. Also lehua pepa and leihua. (Neal 334–5.)
Ash dust.
Same as lehua neneʻe, lehua maka noe. Lit., spreading lehua.
A variety of taro. (HP 33.) Lit., spotted lehua.
A variety of taro, of common upland culture in Kona, Hawaiʻi. The plant is short to medium, slender, with lilac-purple corm flesh and dark green petioles; used for poi. Also palaʻiʻi, ʻiʻi.
A native shrub or small tree (Metrosideros rugosa), found in high forests of the Koʻolau Range, Oʻahu, and distinguished by its rounded, leathery, grooved leaves.
Same as lehua mau loa. Lit., paper lehua, so called because the texture of the flowers and the fact that they do not wilt suggest paper.
A form of ʻōhiʻa lehua tree with white flowers (pua kea). Also lehua haʻakea, lehua kea.
Multitude, crowd, great number, population, legion, the public; numerous, very many, innumerable, myriad.
White-hot, as oven stones.
Volcanic ash.
Flashes of lightning; to flash.
Red ashes; reddish dust or dirt.

1. Lei, garland, wreath; necklace of flowers, leaves, shells, ivory, feathers, or paper, given as a symbol of affection; beads; any ornament worn around the head or about the neck; to wear a lei; special song presenting a lei; crown; ring around a drake's neck; yoke, as for joining draft animals, especially oxen. Fig., a beloved child, wife, husband, sweetheart, younger sibling or child, so called because a beloved child was carried on the shoulders, with its legs draped down on both sides of the bearer like a lei. Cf. lei palaoa.

2. To leap, fling, toss, spring forward; to rise, as a cloud. (Nah. 10.11.) Usually used with hoʻo-.
Crowded, full. Also lēʻiwi. See ʻī 2, ipu lēʻī, lēʻia, mōʻī, pua lēʻī.
Pas/imp. of lei 1, 2.
Abundance; full. Cf. lēʻī.
Any lei worn on the shoulders, as maile; necktie, scarf, neckerchief. Fig., beloved person, especially child or mate. Lit., neck lei. See pōhākiʻikiʻi.
Royal lei, chief's lei, crown (Hoik. 4.4), diadem.
An ancient type of prayer. (For. 6:23.)
Same as hala pepe, a tree.
Braided lei, as of ferns and flowers.
A variety of eel. See puhi lei hala.
Plaiting and tapa designs consisting of a series of inverted triangles, suggestive of a hala lei.
Lei made principally or solely of pandanus keys, sometimes considered bad luck because hala, pandanus, also means to pass away, to fail.
A plaited lei, as of ferns and maile but without leaves.
Var. of lei hili.
Necklace made of crescent-shaped (hoaka) hog's tusks, usually naturally, so shaped, but sometimes carved; a pendant of a single crescent-shaped tooth.
Same as lehua mau loa. Lit., fruit lei, so called because the flowers are round like a fruit.
Feather lei, formerly worn by royalty. Fig., dearly beloved child or choice person.
Cloth lei.
Feather lei with feathers tightly folded together so that it suggests a rope, in contrast with the flat lei papa.
Same as lei pāniʻo.
Var. of laikini. Eng.
Let go. Eng. Usually used as follows; leikō ka ʻanakā, let go the anchor.
Rosary, prayer beads. Lit., crown (Eng.) lei.
A strung lei, as of plumeria.
Kukui nut lei. Cf. ioio, ʻōmolemole, ʻōpaka.
Lei of cowry shells.

1. To wear a lei or leis.

2. Redup. of lei 2.
Redup. of leina.
Spring, leap, bound; place to leap from.

1. Dog-tooth lei.

2. Same as ʻana, pumice stone used for medicine and for polishing.
A weapon, a large shark tooth set in a piece of wood about 6.4 cm long, with a string loop for attaching to the finger (probably from lei o manō, a shark's lei).
See Ka-lei-o-manu.
Lei with spirals of several colors, as the kīkā lei.
Whale-tooth pendant that tapers down to a point, rather than being hook-shaped, as the lei palaoa; especially worn by Oʻahu chiefs. Lit., bud lei.
Tuberculosis, consumption.
Same as lei papa.

Ivory pendant, originally probably whale's tooth, rarely of stone or wood, later also of walrus tusk; necklace of beads of whale's teeth; today, any pendant shaped like the old whale-tooth pendant, such as of beef bone. Lit., ivory lei.
Lei of various colors, as feather leis. Lit., spotted, motley lei.
Flat lei, as for a hat; any lei on a flat surface, especially a feather lei. Cf. lei kāmoe.
Leis of alternating groups of flowers and leaves, entwined leis of same or different flowers; adornment of several leis, usually both on head and around neck.
Hatband.
Lei with stripes or bands of varying colors. Lit., link lei.
Var. of lei paukū.
Same as lei paukū.
See piki.
Ox yoke.
See pipipi 1.
Lei with flowers strung on stems or sides of flowers. See lei waena.
Lei worn on the head (poʻo).
Shell lei, the most famous being from Niʻihau, especially kahelelani and momi. These leis represent Niʻihau in the leis of the islands, as designated in 1923 by the Territorial legislature.
Lei of white sea-perforated shells worn by men and women about the neck, popular in Hawaiʻi since the late 1960s. Lit., perforated shell lei.
Lei strung in the center of flowers. See lei poepoe.

1. Same as lēʻī. (For. 4:337, 339.)

2. A kind of canoe with a flat manu.
A lei that is not strung (kui): the leaves or flowers are entwined about each other, as maile leis.
Pendant carved of wiliwili wood; lei of wiliwili seeds.

1. Sticky, slimy, as mucus. Cf. pīlalilali, pīlekaleka.

2. Letter; to write a letter. Eng. Ua hōʻea mai kaʻu leka, my letter has come [either the one I wrote or the one received].

3. Leek (Allium porrum). (Neal 198, Nah. 11.5.) Eng.

1. Come.

2. Also lede. n. Lady. Eng.

Jacinth (RSV), ligure (KJV). (Puk. 28.91.) (Heb.

December. Eng. Also Kēkēmapa.
Legion; a large number (Mar. 5.9, 15); used figuratively of one possessed by the devil or intoxicated. Eng. Oia inu mai nō, ā noho ʻia e ka lekeona, just drinking until possessed by a legion.

Tape for dress trimming. (Eng., lace.)
To covet.
Regiment. Eng.
Radio. Eng.
Watercress (Nasturtium microphyllum). (Neal 372.)

League. Eng.

Lettuce (Lactuca sativa). (Neal 860–1.) Eng.

1. To fly, jump, leap, hop, skip, swing, bounce, burst forth; to sail through the air, as a meteor; to rush out, as to attack; to get out of, as from a car; to dismount, as from a horse; to land, disembark, as from a canoe; to undertake; to move, as stars in the sky; to move, as in checkers; a jump, leap, attack. (For lele with emotional words, see ex., hauli, kūpilikiʻi; also cf. haʻalele.) Mea lele, flyer.

2. Contagious, as of disease.

3. Wind-blown, of the rain. Cf. leleaka, lele ua.

4. Separate, detached, as a leaf separated from a plant for ceremonials.

5. A detached part or lot of land belonging to one ʻili, but located in another ʻili.

6. Hula step: the dancer walks forward, lifting up the rear heel with each step, with slight inward movement; sometimes with the ʻuwehe step with each foot forward. This can also be done backwards; to dance thus.

7. An interval of music, the difference in pitch between two tones, always followed by a number from one to six, especially lele kolu, an interval of a third, as from C to E, or lele lima, an interval of a fifth. Minor intervals are followed by hapa, as lele kolu hapa, an interval of a minor third.

8. To dry up, to have passed the menopause; to evaporate.

9. To shrink, as clothes.

10. Sacrificial altar or stand.

11. A tall variety of wild banana (Musa xparadisiaca), formerly planted near the altar (lele). It was offered to the gods and used for love magic. Its essence was thought to fly (lele) to the gods. It was used (for weaning (cf. lele 8): the banana was placed near the child with appropriate prayers in order to obtain the god's consent for weaning. This banana was taboo to women.

12. Type of fish (no data). (KL. line 16.)

13. (followed by hapa- + digit). To count by — (digit). See below.
Prayer uttered by a priest as a chief drinks kava, so that the essence of the kava will fly (lele) to the gods.
A marine creature (no data). (PH 121.)
To hang, suspend, carry on the back, as a child or load. (And.)
Light windblown rain or mist. Rare.
See leleaka
See "hoʻoleleaka":  To project, as magic lantern slides.
Milky Way.
Flying away in groups, as migratory birds; to fly thus; to sail, as a canoe fleet.
To leap sideways; to shy, as a horse.
To speak prematurely or before one is spoken to; to jump to conclusions.
Redup. of leha 1, 2.
To count by fours.
To count by threes.
To count by fives.
To count by twos.
To count by tens.
See hauli.

1. Altar to place (hoʻokau) things on, as sacrifices, especially a temporary altar.

2. Peak, top of a peak.
Same as mōlelehu 1, 2.
A good thinker, planner.
Fine windblown rain spray, dust, mist; to fall as fine rain.
See lelehuna
To spring or leap violently, as in an attack or fright; to rush violently, plunge. Lit., to fly evil.
Same as leleiona 2, fidgety.
Same as lele kawa.

1. Shark-sucker, remora (Echeneidae spp.); it clings to large fish, such as swordfish, marlin, bonito, shark.

2. Fidgety, foolish, restless.

3. Milky Way.
A kind of shark, possibly thresher, reported by Hyde (no data), perhaps the same as laukāhiʻu.
To leap feet first from a cliff into water without splashing or into (at Kaʻū) soft earth.
To leap here and there.
Hard volcanic rock, as used for adzes.

See "hoʻolele kī":  A game played only at Malama-kī, Puna, Hawaiʻi. A player would hold a ti leaf in his hand, chant ʻO kēlā kī, ʻo kēia kī, na Ka-moho-aliʻi kaʻu kī, lele! That ti, this ti, my ti is for Ka-moho-aliʻi, fly! If the wind was right and the chant correctly rendered, the ti would fly off and return to the sender. Lit., make the ti fly.

1. Flight of tropic birds; to fly like a tropic bird. Fig., sheer, steep. See koaʻe 1.

2. Name for kauā, outcasts.
To swing; to jump rope; swinging on a koali vine rope, an ancient sport.
To leap suddenly, immediately. Fig., short-tempered, excitable, quick to fight.
See lele 7.
Name of a strong, wintry wind.
Pole vaulting; to pole vault.
Redup. of lele 1; to beat swiftly, as the heart; to frisk, hop about, romp, caper; inconstant, promiscuous; at intervals, here and there.
Same as lelele.
See lele 1.
See lele 7.
Completely severed, as a part of the body in fighting.

1. An interval of a second in music. Cf. lele 7.

2. To leap twice.
To rise and fall, as the forepart of canoe outrigger (lupe). Fig., the rise and subsidence of emotion.
See "hoʻolele lupe":  To fly kites.
A slowpoke; slow, sluggish, disinclined to get up. Cf. lemu.
To seize victims for sacrifice.
Redup. of lena 1, 3.
Redup. of leo.
Excessive, very great. Lit., excessive leap.
To leap or plunge into water feet first. Lit., piercing leap.
To dive feet first into water without making a splash. Also lele ā ʻopu. Fig., unfavorable (For. 6:59).
To leap obliquely into the water from a height. Same as lele pāhiʻa. See pāhiʻa.
One who jumps over a fence; to fence jump. Fig., nonconformer; one who cannot be restrained, especially regarding the opposite sex; wanton; to hurdle.
Singing intervals in music (pā is followed by a number). Cf. lele 7.
To leap into water with a splash; as this was considered poor diving, the expression may refer figuratively to any poor performance; to leap and land with a thud.
To praise, exalt, extol extravagantly or excessively (stronger than pailani, to praise).
To leap or fall off a cliff; to practice the ancient sport of leaping from a precipice into water.

1. To trust completely.

2. To apply oneself to, concentrate wholly on.

1. Toothed, sharp-pointed design, as in tapa.

2. Same as lepelepe 2, wattles.
To fly into a rage at the slightest provocation; to lose one's temper; hot-tempered. Lit., jump [at a] drop.
To run with a rope around a coconut tree, and when going very fast, to lift the feet off the ground. Lit., repeated leaps.
To swing on a koali vine. Lit., dragonfly leap.
Game said to resemble kōnane. (AP)
To run away in defeat; to avoid capture, as a thief. Lit., to flee capture.
To fly or jump in a curve; to fly as a comet through the sky.

1. Same as lepolepo, dirty.

2. Probably another species of Padina, similar in appearance to ʻaʻala-ʻula, a seaweed.
A species of night-flying (lele pō) mālolo, flying fish.
To pounce upon.
To die suddenly, as by stroke or accident. Cf. kāʻiliponi.
To jump carefully. Fig., to live a happy life; to transact business justly; to rise rapidly to success.
To dive headfirst.

1. A musical interval of an octave. Cf. leo lelepuni.

2. A game said to resemble kōnane.
Name of a fruitful tree (no data). (And.)
Word said to describe sexual relations. (AP)
Windblown rain.
Name of a gusty, wintry wind.
To dispel darkness; to purify or cleanse, as in a religious ceremony.

1. Redup. of lewa 2. (PEP lelewa.)

2. Hangers-on about a chief; parasitic persons.

3. Var. of lewalewa 3, Gilbertese.
A shark listed by Kamakau, perhaps the friendly shark that was said to lean (kālele) on canoe outriggers for food and company.

Transferring at sea from canoe to canoe or 
canoe to surfboard for the sport of surfing to shore. Lit., canoe leaping.
To purge, cleanse, purify with water of purification.
To fly, jump, move of one's own accord or for no reason; in ancient prayers, to speed on, as a prayer to a god.
Loud, distant cry; to call loudly.
Redup. of lele walo; to reverberate, as an echo.
Torn to shreds; broken up and scattered.
Ornamental carved figurehead on a bowsprit; a canoe with such. (Malo text, chapter 34, section 35.) Pronunciation uncertain.

1. Tongue (short for alelo, elelo).

2. Yellowish, especially the hue imparted to a whaletooth pendant (lei palaoa) by smoking.
Redup. of lelo 2.
Same as alelo puʻu.
Lemon (Citrus limonia, lime (C. aurantifolia). (Neal 482–3.) Eng. Wai lemi, lemonade, limeada.

A kind of water lemon, sweet granadilla (Passiflora ligularis), a passion fruit with heart-shaped leaves; good-tasting fruits, 5 to 9 cm long, ovoid, orange to purplish. Also lani wai, lemona. (Neal 598.)
Var. of lemi wai. Eng.

1. Buttocks (politer than ʻōkole).

2. Slow-moving, sluggish; lagging.
Rubbish scattered by flood rains. Rare.
Euphemism for ʻōkolehao. (Ii 107.)
Broken off short, as a pole; to start out to do something and not finish it.
One who sits around doing nothing, a term of reproach; also said to refer to a woman who is sexually unattractive. Lit., standing buttocks.
Same as lelemū, lemu 2.
Same as mohihihi, a vine. (Kam. 64:103.)

1. Yellow, yellowish; jaundice; bile.

2. Var. name for the ʻōlena or turmeric plant.

3. To stretch out, as to dry; to draw tight, as a belt; to sight or aim; to bend, as a bow.

4. Lazy, idle, indolent. Cf. lē, lolena.

5. Name of a star, perhaps Sirius.

Voice, tone, tune, melody, sound, command, advice, syllable, plea, verbal message; to speak, make a sound. Cf. leoleo, leo ʻole.

Song of praise, hymn.

Vowel. Lit., voiced sound.

Solo. Lit., single standing speech.

Echo.
Lofty, tall; chiefly height, rank.

A red seaweed (Halymenia formosa) with flat blades bearing fringed and irregular margins, with a variety of colors ranging from red to yellow; common allusion to swirling in water resembling movement of pāʻū in dancing. Also called leheleheʻīlio, lepelepe-o-Hina, limu-pepe-o-Hina, pāʻū-o-Hiʻiaka.

1. Dirt, earth, ground, filth, rubbish, silt, soil, excrement; dirty, soiled. Fig., common people (For. 6:391). See ex., dust.

Dust.
Dirt; rubbish carried to a pit, as to a compost pit. Lit., fed dirt.
Rust; rusty. Lit., iron dirt.

Type of clay. Lit., solidifying dirt.

Clay. Lit., thick dirt.

1. A euphemism for kūkaenalo; wax; mole (anatomical); muslin.

Hard earth; constipation.

1. Sky, atmosphere, space, air, upper heavens; aerial.

5. Name of a star.
See "hoʻolewa":  Funeral. Anaina hoʻolewa, funeral wake.
Part of a heiau temple where human sacrifices were offered.
Probably a part of the lananuʻu mamao turret.
Space just above the surface of the earth. (Malo 10.)
Highest stratum of the heavens.

2. Unconcealed penis of a boy, usually called maʻi lewalewa.

3. Nickname for Gilbertese, because their stretched ear lobes dangled.

A prefix to many kinds of seaweeds, short for limu.

Cool chill.

1. Same as liliha 1.

See "hoʻolili, holili":  Rippled surface of the sea, as caused by fish; undulation or vibration of light in the hot sun; 
to ripple, vibrate, undulate; to close or blink the eyes in bright glare. Var. of haʻalili. Hoʻolili ka ʻōpelu, the ʻōpelu ripples [the sea].
Redup. of lī 1. (PNP liilii.)
Any kind of lily. Eng.

1. Nauseated, nauseating, of rich or fatty foods only; very rich, of fatty, oily food, as of the wolu, a fish. Fig., heartsick, as over a tragedy; revolted, disgusted, as by a hideous crime; dreadful, fearful.

Prepared, supplied, outfitted. Rare.
Tiny, dainty, fine.

Passion fruit, purple water lemon, or purple granadilla (Passiflora edulis), an American vine with three-lobed leaves and edible dull-purple fruits about 5 cm long, growing wild in many forests of Hawaiʻi; said to be named after Lilikoʻi, Maui, where it was first grown. The yellow-fruited lilikoʻi (P. edulis f.
Redup. of līlā.

1. The Texas sage (Salvia coccinea), a weedy herb from southern United States, 30 cm high or more, with toothed, ovate leaves and red flowers, 2.5 cm long, borne in long narrow clusters. (Neal 736.)

2. A variety of taro (no data).
Name of a wind and rain, famous at Pālolo, Oʻahu, and Wai-ehu, Maui. Lit., lehua chill.

Grass linen. Lit., grass-clump linen.
Fine mist, rain.

1. Scorching, burning, smarting, as salt in a raw wound or pain in the eyes. (Queen Liliʻu-o-ka-lani was said to have been so named because at the time of her birth her foster mother's aunt, Kīnaʻu, was suffering with pain in the eyes.) Lā liliʻu, burning sun.

2. Niʻihau name for pua kalaunu, crown flower.
A small native herb (Acaena exigua), growing in bogs, only on top of West Maui and Kauaʻi, the narrow, fernlike leaves forming a rosette. Also, nani Wai-ʻaleʻale.

1. , vt. To accrue, be lost, gone, pass into the possession of; to relinquish; to become, turn into; to overcome; purchased, taken.

2. Busy, absorbed, occupied, engaged, engrossed, devoted, dedicated.

3. Expense, expenditure, outlay of money.

4. Far, distant, out of sight, completely, entirely (often follows a noun).

2. A long time ago. Rare.

Extremely chilly. Cf. lī 1.

2. num. Five; fifth.
Second finger. Lit., eating finger.
Right hand; right-handed; dependable helper, right-hand man.
Light-fingered, thieving.

Wind associated with Haʻena, Kauaʻi. (For. 5:97.) Lit., turning hand.

Handwriting; hand to write with.

Same as laulima, but some persons limit limalau cooperation to canoe and house building.
Pilferer, filcher. Lit., handling hands.
Idler. Lit., hanging hands.

One who handles dirty matter. Fig., an immoral wretch, as a pimp.
God of mirages.
Grabber of other's property. Lit., long arm.

A kind of seaweed. Lit., branching seaweed.
To attack violently, manhandle, assault, beat, roughhouse, administer a beating, take by force.
Big hand; thumb. Cf. lima iki.

Same as lumi 1. Rare.
