Same as hulu moa, a seaweed.

1. A general name for all kinds of plants living under water, both fresh and salt, also algae growing in any damp place in the air, as on the ground, on rocks, and on other plants; also mosses, liverworts, lichens. See saying, hailepo.

2. Tricky, deceiving, unstable (said to be named for the octopus' ability to change its color, and its waving of a tentacle to and fro like the motion of a seaweed in water).

3. Wind gust. Rare.

4. Coil, curl. Rare.

5. Soft coral.
Overgrown or covered with moss, seaweed, or any limu. Cf. ua limua.
A tree moss or liverwort.
An upland moss.
A limu, Potamogeton pectinatus (pronunciation not certain).
See ʻeleʻele 3.
A lichen (Sterocaulon sp.), with erect, branching stalks.
A red seaweed (Martensia fragilis).
A fresh-water moss.
Same as hulu ʻilio, seaweeds.
A kind of liverwort.

A soft, sometimes gelatinous blue-green alga (Nostoc commune) sometimes covering the ground in the wet season as small slippery balls, especially at Hanalei, Kauaʻi. Also limu kā-kanaka-o-Manuʻakepa. Lit., man-striking moss, so called because people are said to slip on it and fall.
Stroke in lua fighting. (Also with Ka-.) Lit., man-striking moss of Mahamoku.

Common, long, brown seaweeds (Sargassum echinocarpum), their stems covered with short branches, bearing rather stiff, twisted, more or less toothed, narrow leaves. Rarely eaten raw because of toughness (though edible); used in ceremonies to drive away sickness and to obtain forgiveness (see kala 1). May be qualified by the terms lau liʻiliʻi or lau nui. Also ʻākala.
See kala makapiʻi.

One or more kinds of dark green, slippery fresh-water algae (usually Spirogyra spp.) consisting of rows of cylindrical cells in unbranched filaments, common to fresh-water rivulets, dripping places, and taro patches. Also pālāwai.
See kalemakapiʻi.
All tiny ferns (such as filmy ferns), lichens, liverworts, and mosses growing on trees.
Moss growing on trees in rain forests.

A soft, succulent, small seaweed (Asparagopsis taxiformis), with densely branched furry tops that are tan, pink, or dark red, arising from a creeping stem-like portion; one of the best-liked edible seaweeds, prepared in balls for market. Also limo koko and for some informants līpehe, līpehu, līpaʻakai.
Same as limu kohu. Lit., blood seaweed.
Floating seaweed. Fig., a drifter, vagabond.
Redup. of limu 2–4.

1. Several species of edible red seaweeds (Gelidium), cylindrical or flattened, more or less pinnately branched, texture firm and smooth. Also ʻānapanapa, ʻēkahakaha, kūwelu.

2. A kind of edible red seaweed (Pterocladia capillacea), like 1 above but more finely divided.

A red seaweed (Porphyra sp.), growing in the winter on boulders in exposed places, with delicate, thin blades appearing in groups. Best known on Kauaʻi, but known on all the major islands. Also paheʻe or paheʻeheʻe.
A coelenterate (Palythoa sp.) containing a toxin, reported as deadly poisonous at Hāna, Maui. Also limu-make-o Muʻolea.
Same as mākole mākōpiʻi, a moss.
See manauea.
Same as hulu moa, a seaweed.
Same as limu kalawai.
Limu salted for indefinite storage without refrigeration. On Maui, usually limu līpoa. See līpaʻakai.
Landed seaweed, said of a newcomer or in a bad sense of a drifter, vagabond, or kauā outcast.
Same as pālahalaha 2.
Same as līpepeiao.
Same as lepe-o-Hina, a seaweed.
Same as ʻēkahakaha 2, a seaweed.
A red seaweed.

1. Soft; adhesive, sticky, clayey, gummy, tenacious; glutinous, as taro of poor quality. Cf. ʻnina, papālina, ʻulika, ʻulina.

2. Scar. Cf. ʻālina.

3. Ring (Eng.), hoop, race track.
Redup. of lina 1, 2.
Lynx. Eng.

1. Bright, shiny, shining with splendor, dazzling, brilliant. Cf. linohau.

2. To weave, twist, braid, tie.

3. Same as linolino 2.

4. Taut.
Pas/imp. of lino 2.
Dressed to perfection, beautifully decorated, ornamented.
Linotype, Eng.
See linokaipa
Linoleum. Eng.

1. Redup. of lino 1, 2.

2. Calm, unruffled.
Tight-fisted, ungenerous, heartless, ungracious. Rare.

1. Horse (perhaps derived from lio 2, or, more likely, a shortening of ʻīlio, formerly a generic name for quadrupeds: ).

2. Tight, taut, as a rope, or of hair or horse's ears pulled back tightly. Cf. lilio.

3. Rope tied to the bottom of a large bag net.

1. Same as ʻaʻo, a sea bird.

2. Same as liʻoliʻo 2, the sound made by the liʻo (ʻaʻo) bird.

To act wild, as a frightened animal; to open the eyes wide in terror; to quiver, leap away, shy, as a 
frightened horse. Also leiʻō.
Pas/imp. of līʻō.
Race horse.
Saddle horse.

Dark-gray horse. Lit., eagle feather horse.
Carriage horse.
Riding horse.
Stallion.
Colt.
Merry-go-round; horse on a merry-go-round; sawhorse; wooden horse, as used in quilting.
Stallion. Lit., testicle horse.

2. Var. of liʻo: name of the sound made by the ʻaʻo bird; to call thus.

3. Redup. of liʻo.
Name of a star, and name for the southern sky. (PH 206; Wawaʻu is a widely distributed Polynesian place name: see Pukui, Elbert, and Mookini, 1974, p. 229.)
Lion. Eng. Hui Liona, Lions Club.
Sea lion.
Pacing horse.
Gelding.
Mare.
Limu salted for indefinite storage without refrigeration; on Kauaʻi usually limu kohu from Niʻihau. Some consider līpehe, līpehu, and līpaʻakai as variants of limu kohu.
Same as līpahapaha, a seaweed.

A general term for sea lettuce (Ulva fasciata and Monostroma oxyspermum), common green seaweeds with delicate broad blades, usually with wavy margins. Eaten as a minor element mixed with other tastier seaweeds. Also ʻīliohaʻa, līpaha, lipāilahalaha, pahapaha (probably restricted to Kauaʻi), pakaiea (restricted to Hawaiʻi), and pālahalaha (Maui, Molokaʻi, and Oʻahu).

1. Same as pāheʻeheʻe, a seaweed. Called līpāhoe on Maui.

2. Same as limu lūʻau 1, a seaweed.
Same as līpaheʻe 1.
Same as līpaheʻe 1, a seaweed.
Liberty. Eng.
See lipaki
Same as līpahapaha, sea lettuce.
Same as līpālāwai, fresh-water algae.

Edible, green, fresh-water algae, consisting of tufts of branching threads (Pithophora spp. and Stigeoclonium spp.), or of a network of threads (Hydrodictyon), or of simple threads (Spirogyra spp.). Also līpalaʻō, nehe, palaʻō, pālāwai.

Frankincense. (Mat. 2.11.) (Gr.

A seaweed. Lit., fragrant seaweed. (GP 78.)

Same as līpeʻepeʻe.

To find, get, obtain, discover, acquire, have, take, earn, gain, incur, locate, procure, reach, receive, catch, win, succeed; gain, earnings, profit, spoils, harvest, revenue, income, winnings, receipts, wealth, product, property, success, solution, answer; to have or beget a child; to be born; to find none to compare with; unequalled, incomparable, successful (often pronounced loʻa: ). This extremely common word is a model for loaʻa-stative verbs: . See haʻiloaʻa, huina loaʻa.

1. All species of native fan palms (Pritchardia). (Neal 97–9.) Hats are plaited of its leaves bleached white. Also noulu. Cf. hāwane.

2. Umbrella, so called because the loulu palm leaf was formerly used as protection from rain or sun.

3. See "Alutera monoceros": , a fish, perhaps so called because its greenish-white skin resembled the loulu palm; used in sorcery to cause death because the name contains the word lou, to hook.

4. Type of heiau said to be built for prevention of epidemics, famine, destruction; long rituals dedicating a temple including kauila nui, fetching of the ʻōhiʻa 
logs for images (haku ʻō hiʻa), kuili and hono rituals (Ii 38).
An endemic fern (Coniogramme pilosa) with leaves somewhat like those of the breadfruit tree (ʻulu) but the divisions narrower and deeper.
A small native fan palm (Pritchardia martii), with thick trunk to 1.9 m high. (Neal 97–9.) Lit., dark loulu.
A native fan palm (Pritchardia hillebrandii), with trunk to 6 m high. Lit., yellowish loulu.
Shelter formed by an overhanging cliff. (Malo text, chapter 33, section 3.)
Betrothal gift, as sent from one family to another. Rare.

1. To scatter, throw, as ashes; to sow, broadcast; to shed, as a chicken its feathers or a tree its leaves; to push aside; to drip, as water; to shake; to cast off, as grief; to spend recklessly, squander, discard.

2. Seeds of the pua kala, prickly poppy.

4. Scalloped hat braid, as made of bamboo, sugar-cane stem, pandanus, or coconut.

1. Hole, pit, grave, den, cave, mine, crater.

2. Toilet, outhouse, bathroom, cellar.

3. num. Two, second, secondary, twice, deuce, double; doubly, much, a great deal.

4. Equal, likeness, duplicate copy, match. See lua ʻole.

5. Companion, mate. Cf. kōkoʻo.

6. A type of dangerous hand-to-hand fighting in which the, fighters broke bones, dislocated bones at the joints, and inflicted severe pain by pressing on nerve centers. There was much leaping, and (rarely) quick turns of spears. Many of the techniques were secret.
To enjoy oneself. Cf. luakaha, lualaʻi, lualuana, luana.

2. Dual number in pronouns and possessives, as ʻolua, kāua, māua.

Indefinite locative, instrumental, manner. At, in, on, beside, along, through; by means of, because of, in behalf of, according to. This very common part. is perhaps more specific than the similar i, at, in; it is written in the dictionary as a part of the following words: ʻaneʻi, hea, hope, kai, laila, lalo, luna, muli, uka. With meaning “because” it is frequently followed by o, of. (Ma is frequently pronounced mā before primary stress: .) E noho ana ma Ulu-kou i Wai-kīkī, living at Ulu-kou place in Wai-kīkī.

All kinds of bananas and plantains (for banana cultivation, see Kam. 76:37–9). Originally the banana was introduced by the Hawaiians, and native varieties were developed, some of which are still used. When the white man came, about 70 different kinds were known; today, only about half that number. These are mainly varieties of Musa xparadisiaca, especially the varieties sapientum and normalis. Some kinds are eaten raw, others cooked. (Neal 245–51.) Bananas were taboo to women except certain ones, as maiʻa iho lena and maiʻa pōpō ʻula, with yellow flesh. Bananas are not mentioned in songs because of unfavorable connotations: see līlā, ʻolohaka. It was considered bad luck to dream of bananas, to meet a man carrying bananas, or to take them in fishing canoes.
Tall, wild bananas.
Same as maiʻa koaʻe. Lit., prematurely gray banana.
A spreading sore; cancer, infection.
Maui name for maiʻa Polapola. Lit., god banana. (HP 177.)
A variety of banana with seeds. Lit., seeded banana.
An ancient variety of banana. Lit., yellow-stem banana.
A Hawaiian variety of banana; fruit with skin changing from red to green to yellow, edible when cooked. (HP 173) Lit., discolored banana.
An ancient Hawaiian variety of banana.

A Hawaiian variety of mountain banana with black trunk, the skin of which is used to make designs in mats. The fruit has orange flesh, which is edible when cooked. Also maiʻa hinu puaʻa, maiʻa poni, maiʻa Puna. (HP 173.) Lit., black banana.
A Hawaiian variety of banana, with short trunk and leaves, but taller than maiʻa Pākē. The fruit is yellow, edible raw or cooked. (HP 175.) Lit., low banana.

A Hawaiian variety of banana that bears yellow fruit, edible raw or cooked. (HP 175.) Lit., pale banana.
Same as maiʻa ʻohe. (HP 177.) Lit., whitish banana.
A Hawaiian variety of banana of medium height, the fruit maturing within the trunk. The fruits are small, ten or fewer in a bunch, yellow, sweet, edible raw. (HP 175; Neal 250.) Also maiʻa hua waena.
Same as maiʻa Polapola. (Neal 250–1.) Fēʻī is the Tahitian name.
Same as maiʻa iho lena. (HP 175.) Lit., bashful banana.
Same as maiʻa ʻeleʻele. (HP 173 Lit., hog's-grease banana.
Same as maiʻa māhoe, (HP 176.) Lit., bearing two bunches, twin banana.
Same as maiʻa moa. (HP 176.) Lit., egg banana.
A variety of banana Lit., big-fruited banana.
Same as maiʻa hāpai. (HP 175) Lit., central fruit banana.
Epidemic, pestilence.
Tuberculosis. Lit., lung-eating sickness.

A Hawaiian variety of banana, popular and common. The trunk is green, purple, and pink. Fruits are salmon-pink, edible raw cooked; one of the few bananas formerly permitted to women. Also maiʻa hilahila. (HP 175.) Lit., yellow-cored banana.
A Hawaiian variety of banana, growing wild on Kauaʻi and Hawaiʻi, rarely cultivated. The fruit is yellow, edible only when cooked. (HP 175.) Lit., snub-nosed banana.
A kind of rough-skinned banana.
A variety of banana growing wild on Maui, rarely cultivated. The trunk is tall; the fruit long, skin yellow, flesh white and edible only when cooked. (HP 175.) Lit., foreign or Tahitian banana.
A Hawaiian variety of banana, similar to maiʻa kahiki, but having short trunk. (HP 175.)
Same as maiʻa a mālei. (HP 176.)
A Hawaiian variety of banana with tall, green trunk. The fruits looks like maiʻa kahiki. (HP 175.)
Same as maiʻa puhi. (HP 177.)
Same as maiʻa-pōpō-ʻulu. (HP 177.)
An Oʻahu name for maiʻa Polapola. (HP 177.)
Same as maiʻapōpō-ʻulu-puapua-nui. (HP 177.)

A Hawaiian variety of banana. Fruit like that of maiʻa maoli, except that the young, dark-green fruit has light-green spots like raindrops; when ripe, yellow, waxy, with flesh light-yellow, good only when baked. (HP 175.) Lit., many rain drops banana.
Same as maiʻa wai mūhea. (HP 177.)

A Hawaiian variety of banana, beautifully striped leaves, trunk, and young fruit. Fruit is yellow and round; flesh yellow, edible cooked or raw. Also called maiʻa aʻea, maiʻa manini. (HP 177.) Lit., tropic bird banana.
A Hawaiian seed-producing variety of banana. Also ʻōpule.
Stars in the belt of Orion.
An ancient Hawaiian variety of banana. Lit., delicate banana.

A common wild Hawaiian variety of banana of the uplands; trunk tall, yellowish-green; fruit yellow; flesh pink, edible raw or cooked, good for piepiele, eczema. Root of shoot used in medicine. The fruit was commonly offered to gods, the tree planted to shelter the altar. It was planted far from a dwelling house, for fear it would cause the occupants to lele (fly) elsewhere. (HP 176.) Lit., altar banana.
Royal disease, leprosy (so-called because the first leper was said to have been a chief).
Same as maiʻa Polapola. (HP 177.) Lit., bud banana.
Quiet, calm, still. Same as mālie. Rare.
An ancient Hawaiian variety of banana; trunk and leaf like maiʻa lele, fruit like maiʻa iho lena. (HP 177.) Lit., droopy banana.
A Hawaiian variety of banana, the stem bearing two bunches; fruit small, yellow, flesh light salmon and very palatable. Also maiʻa hua lua, maiʻa mana lua, maiʻa pā lua. (HP 176.) Lit., twin banana.
Same as maiʻa mālei ʻula. (HP 176.)
A Hawaiian variety of banana; trunk green and pink, streaked with brown; fruit like maiʻa puhi. Also maiʻa kahiki mālei. (HP 176.)

A Hawaiian variety of banana, common both cultivated and wild in the uplands. Fibers of the stalk are used for stringing flowers for leis with a coconut-leaf needle (mānai). Ripening fruit changes from maroon (ʻula) to green to yellow; the flesh is orange, edible only when cooked. Also maiʻa mālai ʻula, maiʻa mānei ʻula, maiʻa mānai ʻula. (HP 176.)
Same as maiʻa mālei ʻula. (HP 176.)
Same as maiʻa māhoe. (HP 176.) Lit., two-branched banana.

A Hawaiian variety of banana, growing in uplands and lowlands. It has a green trunk, large leaves. The fruit is long, waxy-yellow, and has yellow flesh, edible raw or cooked. (HP 176.) Lit., indigenous banana.

A Hawaiian variety of banana with a tall, yellowish-green trunk. The fruit is large, somewhat egg-shaped, and yellow; the flesh yellow, edible raw or cooked. Also maiʻa hua moa. (HP 176.) Lit., chicken banana.

A Hawaiian variety of banana, usually cultivated; the trunk green, with pink and brown markings; fruit short, thick, yellow, the flesh cream-colored, edible raw or cooked. (HP 177.) Lit., short banana or big-mouthful banana.
A variety of introduced banana cultivated by Hawaiians for many generations. The trunk is tall, green; the fruit yellow, edible raw or cooked. (HP 178.) Lit., New Holland (Australian) banana.

Probably a distinct species of Hawaiian banana, according to W. T. Pope, being unique in producing fertile seeds. Trunk and leaves dull-green, tinted with bronze and purple; fruit inedible. (HP 177.) Also hao, ʻoa, poni.
An ancient Hawaiian variety of banana. Also maiʻa hākea. (HP 177.) Lit., bamboo banana.

The myrtle (Myrtus communis), an aromatic shrub from the Mediterranean region and western Asia, a favorite garden plant in many countries, and formerly used in Rome for wreaths to crown the victor. The leaves look like those of maile and formerly were used by Hawaiian for leis like maile, the bark being stripped from the stems in the same way, with teeth holding one end. (Neal 631.)

A tropical American annual composite (Ageratum conyzoides and A. houstonianum), both a weed and an ornamental. It is a hairy, branching, weak-stemmed herb, with light-blue (rarely white or pink) florets borne in small tufted heads. (Neal 830–1.) Also maile honohono and maile kula.

1. Eye, eye of a needle, face, countenance; presence, sight, view; lens of a camera. For idioms cf. ʻōnohi, pulakaumaka, and the following.

2. Beloved one, favorite; person. Cf. makamaka (very common), makana, pula, ʻōnohi. The pig god was affectionately called kuʻu maka by his grandmother, rather like “apple of my eye.” Kau ka maka, to desire, to long to see, to think of fondly.

3. Point, bud, protuberance; center of a flower, including usually both the stamens and pistils; nipple, teat; sharp edge or blade of an instrument; point of a fishhook; beginning, commencement; source; any new plant shoot coming up. Fig., descendant.

4. Mesh of a net, mesh in plaiting; stitch, in sewing. Cf. maka ʻaha, makaʻopihi 2.

5. Raw, as fish; uncooked; green, unripe, as fruit; fresh as distinct from salted provisions; wet, as sand. Cf.kāmakamaka.

6. Probably same as manu, canoe bow and stern pieces

7. A seaweed. See alani and below.

tense, as emotion; exhausting, wearisome, of labor. Rare.
Angry-appearing (probably a contraction of maka keʻeo, angry eyes).
Mischievous or roving eyes, naughty eyes.
See ʻewaʻewa 1.

1. Inflamed or swollen eye. (And.)

2. Pig disease. (And.)

1. Fierce, savage, ferocious; to seize property, to desolate, plunder, cheat. See kaha 4.

2. Name of a star; this star and Mākohi-lani were near the Pleiades, and were said to be patrons of fighters.

3. Same as mākāhakaha.

4. To speak disparagingly or insultingly of.
Sluice gate, as of a fish pond; entrance to or egress from an enclosure.
Same as makahehi.
Hasty; active, as a child into everything.
Name of a star.
Name of a star. Lit., eye following canoe.
Clearing, as rain.
Sunken eyes, as one long sick; deep pit or hollow; open space, as a clearing in a forest or clear space in a lava flow.
Star name (no data). (Kuhelani.)
A shrub similar to mākāhala, orange cestrum, except that the flower is bronze-red.
A marine shell (Peasiella tantilla).
To step lightly, touch lightly, to skim lightly. Cf. hani, māhani.
Rare. var. of haumakaʻiole.
Admiration, desire for, wonder; amazement; attractive, entrancing; to admire; be entangled.
Hailstone. Lit., thunder eye. Cf. huahekili.
Eye with lid drawn down; ectropion. Cf. helei.
A kind of fish. (And.)

1. One-eyed (short for maka kahi). See chant, m_akole 1.

2. Net mesh large enough to admit (the entrance of one finger; a net with such a mesh.
Roving, unsteady, restless eyes; sleepless.
Sleepy eyes; sleepy, drowsy.
First-born child, oldest child. Lit., firstborn person. (PCP mata(f,s)iapo.)

1. Year, age; annual, yearly (sometimes written MH.) See kūlana.

2. Ancient festival beginning about the middle of October and lasting about four months, with sports and religious festivities and taboo on war; this is now replaced by Aloha Week.
New Year.
Leap year. Lit., extra-day year.
Leap year. Lit., year jump ahead.
Bashful eyes; bashful, timidly averting one's gaze.
Kind of hard stone.
Bright face, cheerful look.
Eyes that dart in every direction, as if looking for mischief; a mischievously alluring look.

Name of a star, perhaps variant name for the North Star. Lit., sailing-canoe eye.
Beginning, new start.
Fine mesh or weft, as of net or mat.
See kai, ocean.
Rare. var. of mānai, needle.
Policeman, guard; to police, inspect, spy. Cf. luna mākaʻi.
A rare term defined in For. 5:165 as a swift runner; probably makaiʻa.
Revenge, vengeance, treachery, betrayal, traitor, betrayer, turncoat; treacherous. (Laie 513.) Kū hoʻi kāu hana i ka mākaia, you've behaved treacherously.

1. Whitened pupil of a blind person's eye, cataract. Lit., fish eye.

2. A kind of stone, used for adzes and poi pounders. Also māhikihiki.

3. See makaia.
A limpet, Celluna exarata; flesh within ʻopihi shells. (KL. line 27.) See ʻopihi.
Spear point.
Probation officer.
Patrolling night police. Lit., police making night peaceful.
Bowsprit of a canoe; sharp point at the bow. Lit., bow point.
Phosphorescent light seen in water at night.
Star name.
To visit, the sights; to stroll, make a tour, take a walk; to look upon (Puk. 3.4); spectator.

To see clearly and with keen powers of observation; to see more than most, especially to see supernatural things or ghosts not seen by others; to have the gift of second sight. Lit., seeing eye. Cf. ʻike maka.
Eye smaller than the other. Lit., small eye.
High sheriff.
Wind name, probably at Kauaʻi. Lit., small eye of Lea.
Detective. Lit., spying police.
Military police. Lit., soldier police.
Traffic policeman. Lit., policeman stationed at corners.
A senile pigmentation caused by sunburn of the eye, as found among Hawaiians; person with such an eye (such persons were said to be observant and critical). Lit., birthmark eye.
Rocky patches where sweet potatoes or taro were cultivated (For. 6:165); soil consisting of coarse sand, cinders, or gravel. Cf. ʻili, pebble.
Young shoot, as for transplanting.
Name of a constellation in the Milky Way. Lit., blinking eyes, twinkling eyes.
Guard; watchful.
To look at with hatred; to lose affection for one; one who looks with hatred.
Sheriff.
Same as maka līʻō, wild eye.
Name of a star. Lit., eye of the royal hawk.
Night watchman, night police.

1. Mother-of-pearl eyes, as in an image, especially of the god Lono.

2. Nine guiding stars. (Johnson and Mahelona 74.)
Police matron.
Same as maka keleawe.
Sea-washed; spray.
. Shifty eyes; to have such.
Many people, crowds of people.
Heart's desire. Lit., dew eye.
Brazen look; horse eye of a whitish color, but with good vision. Lit., brass eye.
To look at with hatred.
Proud look (Sol. 6.17); haughty air.
To look out of the corner of the eyes; eye drawn back at the corner.
Mask. Lit., image face.
Flirtatious eyes; to lure or attract with the eyes.

1. A name given to the kala poni, sweet potato.

2. Pen; steel point, as of a weapon. Lit., steel (Eng.) point.
Observant, watchful eyes; to watch with great attention.
Spy, detective, spying eye; watchful, vigilant, spying; to spy.
Bold, unafraid, fierce. Lit., brave eye.
Landmark for a fishing ground. Lit., fishing-ground point.
Wild sweet potato found in Puna, Hawaiʻi; it may have been eaten in famine times; fed raw to pigs.
Same as mākole.
Creative imagination of an artist. Rare.
Needle or nail point; stitch. Cf. maka o ke kui, eye of a needle.
To scowl, leer hatefully. Lit., pounding eyes.

1. To loosen, undo, untie, open a little, liberate or set at liberty; to remit, as a debt; to forgive; to free of defilement or uncleanness; to open or unfold, as a flower. Cf. kala 1.

2. A trail. (Malo 92.)
Short for makaʻala. Rare.

1. Myrtle. Eng.

2. Marshal. Eng.

3. See "Marshall":  (Islands). Eng.
Beach, shore, coast near a point (lae).

1. Sleepless, awake.

2. Pas/imp. of makala 1.

1. Redup. of makala.

2. Same as makalahia.
Cross-eyed, with eyes that seem to look inward. Lit., roving eyes. Cf. maka ʻāhewa.
Handsome, beautiful; to blossom forth.

1. Carbuncle, boil.

2. Cluster of spears.

3. Many buds, as on a pussy willow. Fig., many offspring.
Rain name.
Ulua fishermen; seekers of human victims for sacrifice. (Malo 92.) Rare.
Friendly, having many friends and associates; sociable.
Mackerel, canned sardines. Eng.
Twinkle-eyed, happy-eyed, mischievous.
To look about as in wonder or admiration, to glance.
, nvt. Covetous, lustful, wanton, lascivious; incontinence; to admire (Kel. 17), desire. Lit., cowrie eye, perhaps so called because the octopus clings to the cowrie.
Lehua flower petals. Fig., attractive, as young girls.

1. Fish trap.

2. Name of a supernatural tree found on Molokaʻi; portions of its root were placed by the gates of fish ponds, as they were thought to attract fish.

3. Same as melomelo, a stick lure.
Name of a major illness (no data).
Fine muslin cloth. Eng.

1. Unfriendly, suspicious glance from under the eyelid; to glance thus. Lit., drawn eye.

2. Yellow center of a flower, as of a daisy.
Dotted swiss cloth. Lit., lumped muslin.

1. Same as mali, to flatter.

2. Barely cooked, underdone. Rare.

3. Glowing, bright, as of fire.

4. To bait a hook. (PCP matali.)

1. Tiny, very small, fine, wee, smallmeshed; narrow wefts.

2. Pleiades; Castor and Pollux. See Pleiades.

3. Hawaiian month name; the six summer months collectively.
Redup. of makaliʻi.
Marguerite, daisy. Eng.

Uniform, as in color, style, clothes. Lit., 
similar face.
Eyes with epicanthic fold.
Taut, as a rope. Lit., tight mesh.

1. A perennial sedge (Cyperus laevigatus), found in or near fresh or salt water in warm countries. From a horizontal, creeping stem rise long, slender unbranched stems, each topped by a small inflorescence. Formerly the plants were valued in Hawaiʻi for making the fine Niʻihau mats. (Neal 86.) Also makoloa.

2. General name for shellfish with long sharp edges (Thais intermedia, Drupa morum). Also aupūpū, pūpū ʻawa. (KL. line 30.) See also ʻōlepe makaloa.

3. A seaweed.
Very green, as a fruit; barely cooked, very raw.
Bountiful eye (Sol. 22.9); one who looks kindly, charitably, and with good will. Lit., good-hearted face.
Eyelid turned back, exposing the under side of the lid; an insulting term, as prisoners were tortured by tattooing the exposed eyelid. Lit., turned eye.

1. Two-face, double-edged; two-fold, as a plaited mat; hypocritical.

2. Socket of the eyeball. Fig., depths of the sea.

3. Fishing net with mesh wide enough to admit two fingers. Lit., double mesh.
Hole for house posts or for planting, as taro; to dig such a hole.
A large mākālua hole.
Tired eyes, tired people, especially those who have been working hard on a community project. Cf. ʻahaʻaina maka luhi.
To plan slaughter; to determine to destroy.
Precious, of great value, highly prized, darling (Hal. 22.20).

1. Intimate friend with whom one is on terms of receiving and giving freely; pal, buddy; host. Fig., anything very helpful, as education. Cf. maka, beloved.

2. Redup. of maka, raw, fresh.

3. Buds, as forming on the corm of a taro. (HP 5.)
Friend.
Reader, as of a newspaper. Lit., reading friend.
One with a host of friends because of a genial, kindly, or hospitable nature; many friends.
Madame. Eng. Makame Pele, Madam Pele.
See makame
Indented, non-protruding nipple, as is difficult for a baby to grasp.
Mesh in mat made by plaiting over one and under one; similar style in quilting; check plait. Lit., mat mesh.
See momi 5.
Lead horses or oxen in a team.
First, beginning, commencement, first time; first child of a family. Lit., first end.
Gift, present; reward, award, donation, prize; to give a gift, donate. Cf. maka 2.
Plants growing on lava beds (probably a contraction or maka i nā ʻaʻā, budding in the lava).
Gift of friendship or love; freewill offering.
Wild, untamed; of the wilderness or forest. Lit., forest person.
Parting gift. Lit., going gift.
Same as makalau.
Twinkling of eyes. Rare.

1. Wind, breeze; gas in the stomach, flatulent wind; windy; to blow. Fig., anger, gossip; to show anger. Cf. ani.

2. Ghost, spirit. See kahuna makani.

3. Call of sentinel, similar to “all's well”.
Name of a gentle wind; it is said to permit loli to come out of their holes and feed. Lit., wind that feeds sea slug.
Ice-cold mountain wind. Lit., icy, annoying wind.
Cold wind. Lit., wind running [over] thighs. (PH 187.)
Tornado. Lit., wind revolving twisting.
Usual wind of a place.
Sudden strong wind, gust. Lit., wind arriving suddenly.
Spirit that possesses a medium and speaks through him. Lit., spirit that takes possession.
Favorable or fair wind, refreshing breeze.
Cyclone, hurricane.
Gust, strong wind.
Hurricane.
See makani uluulu
Whirlwind, twisting wind.
A variety of sweet potato. (HP 142.)
Widely spaced, as grooves on a tapa beater.
Big eyes. Cf. kiʻi maka nunui under kiʻi 1.

1. Star name (no data). (Kuhelani.)

2. A city governed by Portugal, near Hong Kong.
Same as kaʻokaʻo 3, arid. Cf. kūmimi mākaʻo.
Piercing, penetrating, sharp eyes.

1. Var. of mōkaʻokaʻo.

2. High; height.
Eyetooth; point of a dog's tooth, Fig., point of an ʻōʻō, digging stick; sprouting plant.
A sweet, lovely, or tender expression of face or eyes; also said of the eyes of the kole, a fish.

1. See "ʻOpihi":  scooped out of its shell.

2. A fine pandanus mat, of 6 cm strands. Lit., fine mesh.
Same as mākole mākōpiʻi.
A variety of taro.
Excelling eye, epithet for a councilor (kālaimoku), who had served under three rulers in three generations, and hence was regarded as full of wisdom.

1. Feeble, of light, as firelight in the daytime; shy, wild, as a bird.

2. Stones that break in a fire, not desirable for the imu.
Person blind in one eye, one-eyed; blind in one eye (it was considered bad luck to meet such a person); blind (Oihk. 22.22). Lit., closed eye.
Soft, ripe; ready to burst, of a boil.
Hollow worn in lava rock by the sea, where salt is collected, natural salt pan.
Swollen; suffering from hunger; hungry person.
Dirty face; sticky, dirty eyes. See ex., hāpuku 1, 2.
Pen point.
Fine-meshed, as a mat of medium weft, as 1.5 cm.
Running eyes, bleary eyes.
Eyes sticky with viscous matter; watery eyes; insulting epithet for one who does not find what he is lookingfor.

1. Small eyes; pregnant women were discouraged from eating pipipi shellfish lest their children be born with small eyes, hence the name.

2. Tiny, twinkling stars.
Blindness, blind person; blind. Lit., night eye.
Dizziness, faintness, lack of courage; obscure, dizzy, faint (Lunk. 8.4). Lit., dizzy eye.
Dizziness; dizzy, faint. Lit., blacknight eyes.
See "hoʻomakapū":  To frown, look with disapproval.
Breast nipple that stands out and is easy for a baby to take; pig nipple.
Fishhook with two opposite barbs, as used for eels. Lit., eel point.
Bookmark. Eng.
Variety of fish (no data). Lit., bulging eyes, hill point.
Fishhook.
Var. spelling of makaau.
Same as mākaukau. The word is related to ʻākau, right hand.
Fear; frightened, afraid, cowardly, timid, unsafe, dangerous.

1. Hardhearted, unfriendly; troubled, vexed. Lit., tough face.

2. To increase, grow larger.

3. A variety or taro.
War dead (short for make kaua).
Pas/imp. of makaʻu.

1. Redup. of makaua.

2. To toughen by drying, as hide. Rare. Lit., tough face.

1. Face tattooed solid, without patterning.

2. Tattooed eyelid, as a humiliating sign of a warrior's defeat.

3. Downcast eyes.
Pas/imp. of makaʻu.

1. Able, competent, capable, handy, efficient, proficient, versed, adept, skilled, expert, qualified; prepared, ready; competence, proficiency, efficiency, aptitude, preparation; to know how, to know well. Cf. ʻākau, right.

2. Star name (no data). (Kuhelani.)
Redup. of makaʻu.
Fear of images representing gods.
Sudden fear, panic.
Same as kāula, prophet.
Pinkeye; inflamed or bloodshot eye. Lit., red eye.
Black eye, as from a bruise.
Pas/imp. of makaʻu. (For. 6:299.) (PCP matakulia.)

1. Saving, economical, thrifty, provident; miserly, avaricious, eager to own.

2. Broad-backed, thick-shelled, of a turtle.
See "hoʻomakauliʻi":  To seek every detail; to find out even the smallest things, scrutinize. Cf. ex., kōʻalaʻala.
Name of a navigational star. Lit., eyes drawing many.
Gathering and tying, as pala fern for a heiau service, Rare.
Small shell hook, as used for ʻōpelu fishing. Lit., hook to turn away.
Grief.
Midriff, fat.
Design, as carved on a tapa beater and used in quilting.
Net mesh. Cf. ʻōpua maka ʻupena, uea maka ʻupena.
Coward, cowardice; afraid for no reason, easily frightened.

1. Excrement lying exposed on the ground. Lit., feared [by] feet.

2. Anything on which one fears to tread.
Small outlets for water through banks of taro patches; small waterways; water sources.
Watery-eyed; eyes welling with tears; tender-eyed (Kin. 29.17).
Nipple of the breast.

1. Numerous, many, much, in great quantities (sometimes used with implication of chiefly mana). Lit., eight eyes. Cf. -walu.

2. Type of fighting on plains covered with brush, with irregularly grouped warriors. (Malo 196, 203.)

1. Glowing, burning; full of hate, fury, anger. Fig. term for the despised kauā, outcasts.

2. Type of stone from which weights for cowry octopus lures were made.

3. Same as wela 3.
Redup. of makawela 1.
Glaring, threatening eyes; to glare, glower.
See pahapaha 3.

1. To die, perish; defeated, beaten, dead, killed, unfortunate; to faint (cf. make loa, definitely “to die”); death, fainting, danger of death, peril, destruction, misfortune; to kill, beat, execute; deathly, deadly, faint, deceased, extinct, late, obsolete, poisonous, venemous. A pre-Christian concept was that make signified entry into the spirit world, and that make loa was the utter annihilation of the spirit, a kind of second death (cf. For. 5:581).

2. Desire, want; to want. Cf. make ʻai, -mākeʻaka, make wai. After ʻaʻole, make expresses a weak command, as “you better not.” ʻI mai nei ke aliʻi, ʻaʻole make kaha ka ʻōpū o ka puaʻa, the chief said, better not cut open the pig's stomach.

3. Price, barter, exchange. Cf. makehewa, makepono.
Masthead. Eng.
Pas/imp. of make 1, 2.
Same as mahakea 1–3.
Hungry. Lit., want food. (PCP mate kai.)

See "hoʻomākeʻaka":  Witty, comic, funny, amusing; to cause laughter, exercise wit or humor. Hana hoʻomākeʻaka, funny antics; to do something to provoke laughter. ʻŌlelo hoʻomākeʻaka, joke, witticism. Mea hoʻomākeʻaka, joker, wit, clown.
To be very cold, chilled, freezing.
Name of a star or constellation. See Mekeaupeʻa.
Death due to mental depression. (Kam. 64:44.) Lit., bitterness within death.
Covetous, greedy, desirous to have; to prize, have affection for.
Law-abiding.
Redup. of makeʻe.
To desire to preserve the status quo; conservative.
Patriotic; desirous for the welfare of the nation.
Avarice, covetousness (Ier. 22.17); eagerness to acquire wealth.
Shish, to shish, swish, especially accompanied by flash, as of skyrockets; flash, as of lightning; to flash.
Bad bargain, vain undertaking; in vain, useless, without profit. Cf. makepono.
Pas/imp. of make 2.
Death caused by capturing the spirit of a live person. (Kam. 64:43.) Lit., death strike [the] living.
Warlike.

1. Market. Eng.

2. Black mustard (Brassica nigra), a cosmopolitan herb, a weed in Hawaiʻi, but formerly cultivated for the seeds, which are the main source of table mustard. Small yellow flowers, and later erect seed pods, are borne on tall stems. Eng. Hua mākeke (Mat. 13.31), grain of mustard seed.
See "hoʻomakekeʻeo":  Resentful.
Large market, supermarket.
Muscles. Eng.
See makela
Same as kele 1.
Material. Eng.
Matrimony. Eng.
See makelimonio
To die (in contrast to make, which may mean “defeated, faint”). For a pre-Christian concept, see make 1.

1. Desire, want, wish; to want, like, prefer, favor, wish; willing (often replaced colloquially by mamake). See make 2.

2. Redup. of make 1; defeated. (For. 6:371.)
Mathematics. Eng.
Applied mathematics. Lit., referred mathematics.
Pure mathematics.

1. Mourning, wailing, lamentation; to wail, lament, weep for joy.

2. Calm, of sea, atmosphere. Cf. make, dead.
Many, numerous; often, much.
Place where a stream disappears in the ground.
Magnet, magneto. Eng.
Complete defeat, as in card games, to be completely defeated.
To die of starvation; faint with hunger.
Bargain; profitable, reasonable in price or in conduct. Cf. makehewa.
Madness; to be mad. (Kam. 64:43.) Lit., death [from] whirling. Rare.
Thirst; thirsty. See ex., iho 7. (PEP mate wai.)
To die of itself, to die without cause, to die or wilt easily.
To march. Eng.
To roll, fold.

1. Aim, motto, purpose; to aim or strive for, to concentrate on.

2. Pin, nail, wedge, spike, stake, bolt; to nail, bolt, crucify, pin; to establish, as a kingdom; to destroy by sorcery; to drive stakes, as in surveying; to fasten.
Maybe, perhaps, probably.
Round herring (Etrumeus micropus); common in estuaries, as at Pearl Harbor. Also mikiawa, ʻōmaka.
See "Cressa cretica":  (Remy 19). Cf. Neal 701.
A service during luakini dedication. (For. 6:45.)

1. Mosquito. Eng. In Puk. 8.16, makika translates “gnats” (RSV) and “lice” (KJV). In Hal. 105.31, makika is “swarm of flies” (RSV) and “divers sorts of flies” (KJV).

2. Plant blight that attacked sweet potato, taro, and other food crops, believed caused by mosquitoes.

1. Same as kiki, to peck.

2. Type of stone used as weights for octopus lures (Malo 19), and for adzes.
Long, tall, slender, as a tree.
Maui name for mānai, needle; to string, as leis.
To crack, appear through a crack, show come to light; to come off, as shingles; cracked, split open.
A drop; to drop, as water. Cf. kilihau, kilihune, Hal. 37.25.
Redup. of makili.
To eye wistfully, to look at longingly, to beg thus; beggar.
Similar to ʻoʻopu hue, puffer.

1. Uneven, as land. (And.)

2. A kind of fish. (And.)

1. Group of spears tied together, used as a battering ram in war (from maka kini, many points).

2. Many deaths; death-inflicting, deathly (from make kini, many deaths).

3. Gourd mask, as used by canoemen.

1. Monkey. Fig., ugly person; ugly.

2. Hawaiian whalers' name for Eskimo.
Martingale. Eng.
Hilly; notched, as a ridge.
See "hoʻomākiu":  Same as makākiu, hoʻomakākiu.

1. Rough, rocky; large.

2. Similar to mākonā, mean. Rare.

1. Fearless, courageous, aggressive. Cf. koa, brave.

2. Similar to mākonā.
Coral head in the sea.
Plural of mākoʻa.
To rake, strip, scrape away. Cf. koe 2.
Var. of mākole 1. (AP)
Tedious, wearisome, difficult, as a task; hard to get along with, of a person. Rare.

1. Same as kōhi 1, to dig.

2. A red variety of taro, used for pink poi, sometimes qualified by the colors ʻeleʻele or ʻulaʻula. Also mōkohi.
Name of a star. See Mākaha 2.

1. Fishing pole; to fish with a pole (also mōkoi). Cf. mākoi kanaka.

2. Same as mākonā (AP)

3. Also Magoi n. Magi.

4. Magician, enchanter.
To teeter, seesaw; to swing on a single rope. Rare.
A sport of strength; players lie on the ground, with bodies rigid. They are lifted up from the back and hoisted to their feet.
Redup. of mākoi 1.
To hold the breath, of divers. Rare.

1. Fresh-water leech or bloodsucker. Cf. koko, blood.

2. Reddish. Cf. heʻe mākoko, loli mākoko.

3. A variety of taro, used for red poi. (HP 22.) Also nohu.

1. Inflamed or sore eye; bloodshot; red-eyed; red-hot; red or yellow, as dying leaves; red, as a tinted cloud.

2. Slightly decomposed pinkish octopus, relished by some; to turn pinkish, as octopus. Also heʻe pulu.

3. Rainbow.

4. A small, smooth, succulent herb (Nertera granadensis var.

5. To scrape.

6. Same as kahikole, a time of day.
Bold, shameless. Rare.
Redup. of mākole 1–3.
Leaf turning yellow or red, or drying.
A native moss (Thuidium hawaiense), the plants branching in one plane, looking like small ferns. Also mākōpiʻi, maka ʻōpiʻi, limu-mākolemaka-ʻōpiʻi, kala maka piʻi.
Fragment; tiny bit, as of small shavings. Cf. koli, to whittle.
Same as kolo, to creep.
Same as makaloa, a sedge.
Same as honohono, the wandering Jew. Lit., creeper.
Same as kolokolopā, young of goatfish.

1. Thick, heavy, deep, as clouds; thick-coated, as dust; laden, as a high chief with taboo.

2. Net mesh large enough to admit the entrance of three fingers; a net with such a mesh; three-ply, as sennit. Cf. mākahi, mālua.

1. Redup. of mākolu; chubby.

2. Extremely, threefold.
Redup. of mākō 1. Rare.
Mason. Eng. Hui Makona, Masons' Society.
See Makona
Hard, mean, hard-hearted, malevolent, unyielding, arbitrary, implacable, nasty; evil disposition. Cf. konā.
Same as mākole mākōpiʻi, a moss.

1. All native and introduced species of buttercups (Ranunculus), coarse herbs with subdivided leaves and small yellow flowers. (Neal 351.) Also ʻawa Kanaloa.

2. A native perennial herb (Peucedanum sandwicense), in the parsley family, with coarse leaves much subdivided and tuberous roots that were used medicinally.

3. A native fern (Botrychium subbifoliatum), with fronds fan-shaped and lobed much like leaves of buttercups.

4. To blush; red, as with sunburn; bloodshot.

5. Kukui lamps, as burned all night while court retainers told stories to the chiefs; courtiers who told such stories; venerable statesmen who had served under three kings, presumably in three generations, perhaps so called because the makou torch consisted of three strings of kukui nuts.
. We, us (plural, exclusive; ).

1. Firm, hard; thick, stiff, as molasses; jellied, solidified; to gel, harden; to settle, as dregs; to thicken, as cream; dregs, sediment, lees.

2. Same as kokiʻo, a native hibiscus.

Parent, any relative of the parents' generation, as uncle, aunt, cousin; progenitor; Catholic father; main stalk of a plant; adult; full-grown, mature, older, senior. Fig., benefactor, provider, anyone who cares for one; the Lord (God).

1. Plural of makua. (PNP maatuʻa.)

2. Same as kūnehi, sunfish.
Var. of mākuʻe, dark brown, dark red.
Progenitor, patriarch, head of a tribe.
See makua aliʻi
Mother, aunt, female cousin or relative of parents' generation. Lit., female parent.

1. Calming, soothing. See mali 1.

2. Sisal (Agave sisalana; Furcrae foetida on Niʻihau), a tropical American plant grown for its fiber; used for rope, twine, hula skirts. The plant forms a huge rosette of stiff, straight leaves (1.8 m by 15 cm). It is called malina because marine ropes were made from it; Cf. malina 4. (Neal 224–5.)

3. To splice, as rope.

4. Also marina nvs. Marine. Eng.
Calm, quiet, peaceful, pacific, as the sea; smooth, as ironing nicely done or as a canoe with a smooth finish; unwrinkled.

White loincloth, an epithet for a female priest enjoying masculine privileges and exemption from female taboos; in particular she might enter the heiau temple where female deities were worshipped.

1. General term for Hawaiian flying fishes (Parexocoetus brachypterus and others). This name may be qualified by the terms ʻēheu lā, ʻēheu ʻula, and hāpuʻu. Fig., fickle person who leaps from mate to mate. Cf. puhikiʻi, wauke mālolo.

2. See kaunaʻoa mālolo.

3. An ancient type of tapa (no data).
Same as mālohilohi.
Pas/imp. of mālōlohi.
Dry, dried up, evaporated, juiceless, desiccated; stale, as bread; drought, dryness.

A loincloth wet in fresh water; it was taboo to appear in a chief's presence in such disrespectful array, and death was said to be a penalty.
Secretly, confidentially, clandestinely, illegally, stealthily, furtive.

1. Net mesh large enough to admit the entrance of two fingers; a net of such a mesh; two-ply. Cf. mākahi.

Same as moloā, lazy.
Wind, well known on Kauaʻi, said to blow from the northwest. Lit., traveling Mālua.

Sea breeze accompanied by showers, known at Hilo. Lit., Mālua fetching water. Also Huehu, Mālualua Kiʻi Wai. Mālua Kiʻi Wai ke aloha, hoʻopulu i ka liko māmane (song), greetings to the water-fetching Mālua breeze, bringing moisture to the māmane buds.

1. Rough, bumpy, uneven, full of ruts or puddles. Cf. lua, hole.

Type of tapa stained with dye made of kukui bark.

Peace, quiet, security, tranquillity, serenity; safety; solemn awe and stillness that reigned during some of the ancient taboo ceremonies; peaceful, restful.
Tired, weary; worn out; tiresome, wearisome, fatiguing.
Name of a rain associated with Kaha-luʻu, Oʻahu. (Elbert and Mahoe 61.)

Services for consecrating (malu) adzes to be used for cutting ʻōhiʻa logs for images or canoes (also malu ʻōhiʻa); people engaged in such services. (Kam. 76:146.) See haku ʻōhiʻa, kapu ʻōhiʻa kō. Fig., shadow of death, deep gloom or shade (PH 25, ). Lit., adze taboo.
Name of a star. Lit., celestial shade.
Limp, weak, flexible; soft and fragile, as some eggshells. Cf. haʻi malule, hāpai malule.
Redup. of malule.

Shadow of death. (Ioba 24.17.)
Redup. of malu; shelter or protection of any kind, often humble; shady.

To chew, masticate (but not swallow; Cf. nau).

1. Fast, nimble, speedy of movement, quick, brisk, swift; to hasten, hurry.

2. Light, of weight. Fig., eased of pain, ache, or distress.

3. Mama, mother.
Redup. of mae; sickly, listless; weakening or withering effect of pain; wan or pale, as after illness; crestfallen, as after enthusiasm is squelched.

2. A variety of kava. (HP 202.)

1. Horizontal carrying stick, borne over the shoulders; to carry this stick.

2. A game: one person grasps his own ankles from the back; others stick a māmaka pole between his arms and his back and carry him, as they would a bundle. A more difficult variant is that one person may attempt to carry two persons single-handed.

3. Bearer, traveler.
Company of warriors. Lit., carriers of war. Cf. ʻAhahui Māmakakaua.
Redup. of makawalu. He mamakawalu lākou i loko o ʻĪ (chant), they are many in the ʻĪ family.

1. Redup. of make 1; to die, of several; to wilt, wither, of plants.

2. Colloquial for makemake, to want, like.

Small native trees (Pipturus spp.) with broad white-backed leaves and white mulberry-like fruit; the bark yielded a fiber valued for a kind of tapa, similar to that made from wauke but coarser. Often misspelled mamake. (Neal 318–9.) Also waimea. See ex., wale 1.
Redup. of mala 1, 2. See ex., puʻu lele.

1. Fragment, splinter, chip, piece.

2. Stroke, as of paddle or of war club.

3. Old name of Honolulu harbor.
Sour, as poi.
Var. of Māmala-hoe. Lit., club stroke.

Name of a particular company of warriors of Ka-mehameha and the name of Kamehameha's famous law of the splintered paddle (lit., paddle fragment) which guaranteed the safety of the highways to all, as women, children, sick, and aged; the law was so called because it was said to have been formulated after Ka-mehameha had been struck on the head with a paddle while his foot was trapped in a crevice. The law is often called Māmala hoa. According to one account (Thrum, 1906, 81–6) Ka-mehameha threw a stone at two attackers; it hit a noni tree, pierced one of the attackers and hit a precipice where it is still lodged.
Sentence, clause, phrase. Lit., speech fragment.

1. Redup. of mali

2. Young stage of ʻōʻio, a fish.
Redup. of malihini; not well acquainted, somewhat unaccustomed to or unfamiliar with. See ex., polepole 2.

1. Redup. of malu; protection, defense, shade, covering; protected, shaded.

2. Umbrella, parasol.

3. Type of mushroom.
Redup. and intensifier of make 1, to die, of very many, as in a disaster; more deaths than mamake.
Small, little, especially of work. Cf. māmala, fragment.
Same as mamo 3, a fish.

1. A native leguminous tree (Sophora chrysophylla), which thrives at high altitudes, up to the tree line, as on Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa. The leaves are narrow, compound, more or less downy, the flowers commonly yellow, the pods four-winged, yellow-seeded. Hawaiians formerly used the hard wood for spades and sled runners. (Neal 442–3; Kep. 65.) See ex., lau 4, Mālua Kiʻi Wai.

2. Attractive, said of a person sexually appealing but not necessarily good-looking, perhaps so called because of the attractive flower of the māmane tree.

3. A variety of taro. (HP 33.)

1. Far, distant, remote, high in rank; distance.

2. Third or highest platform of the lana-nuʻu mamao (oracle tower), where the high priest conducted services.

1. Greenish, light green. Cf. maʻo, green.

2. Same as mamo 3, a fish.
Redup. of mau 1–3. See ex., ʻiʻī 1.
Redup. of maua.
Same as manauea 1, 2, and māʻauea.
Same as minamina but less frequent. See ex., pulakaumaka.
Same as mio, to disappear.

1. Black Hawaiian honey creeper (Drepanis pacifica): its yellow feathers above and below the tail were used in choicest featherwork. Formerly found only on Hawaiʻi, not seen since the 1880s. A Molokaʻi species was Drepanis funerea, not seen since the 1890s; also hoa and ʻōʻō nuku mū.

2. Safflower or false saffron (Carthamus tinctorius), a branching annual, 30 to 120 cm high, from Asia, grown for its flowers, which are yellow, like the feathers of the mamo bird. (Neal 858.)

3. A sergeant fish (Abudefduf abdominalis), to about 163 mm long. Also mamamo, mamo pohole.

4. Descendant, posterity.
Descendant of a chief.
Mammon. (Mat. 6.24.)
Mormon.
Same as mamo 3, a fish.
See mua 1.
See muli.

1. Supernatural or divine power, mana, miraculous power; a powerful nation, authority; to give mana to, to make powerful; to have mana, power, authority; authorization, privilege; miraculous, divinely powerful, spiritual; possessed of mana, power. Cf. -āmana.

2. Branch, limb, crotch; crosspiece, as of the cross; a line projecting from another line; stream branch; road branch or fork, variant, version, as of a tale; to branch out, spread out.

3. Hook used in catching eels.

4. Stage in growth of fish in which colors appear; stage of a foetus in which limbs begin to develop.

5. A native fern (Hypolepis punctata), with large, much subdivided fronds. The dark-brown mature stems were used to plait the best hats, after being scraped to remove the pulp. Also olua.

6. A variety of taro used in medicine; it propagates by branching from the top of the corm. (HP 23.) Mana may be qualified by descriptive terms, as listed below.

7. A taboo house in a heiau. Cf. ʻaha hele honua.
See "hoʻomana":  Callus; callous. Kauaʻi.

1. A chewed mass, as of kava for drinking, coconut flakes or kukui nut for medicine.

2. Trait believed acquired from those who raise a child.

3. Short for haumāna, student.

1. Arid; desert. Cf. Mānā, place on Kauaʻi.

2. A native fern (Pteris irregularis), with large, bright-green, much-subdivided fronds. Also ʻae, ʻāhewa, ʻiwa puakea.
Road fork or branching.
Probably same as nae, net.
Same as nae, shortness of breath.
To the east (a direction, see naʻe 1). (Nak. 121.)
A variety of taro; petiole and leaf with red-black markings. (HP 23.) Lit., black mana taro.
To swim with paddling motions, as in learning to swim.
Power of passing judgment, jurisdiction.
A variety of taro (no data). (HP 33.)
Sad, grieving. (AP)
Needle for stringing leis, formerly of coconut midrib, now of wire; to string leis. Also called hānai on Hawaiʻi, mākila on Maui, and mōkila on Kauaʻi.
Same as manauea, a seaweed.
Redup. of mānai.

1. Same as maiʻa mālei ʻula.

2. Marriage of close relatives.
Boresome, tiresome, dull, monotonous, wearied (see ex., kahiko 1), wearisome, uninteresting; bored, uninterested.
Power of the Holy Trinity.
Same as mana keʻokeʻo.
A native variety of taro; white corm; mainly used as table taro, a favorite for making kūlolo; consistency tough for poi. (HP 23.)
See "hoʻomanakiʻi":  Idolatrous; to worship images.
Mango (Mangifera indica), a large, common fruit tree from India. Long, narrow leaves form a dense top, and large ovoid, juicy fruits develop usually between March and October. (Neal 521–3.) Eng.
Voter.
Mango chutney. Also manakō kūkāne.
Variety of mango.

1. Humble commoner, used with kanaka Rare.

2. Name of a star.
Mongoose. Eng.
A variety of taro, introduced from Samoa; chalky-white corm; a fair table taro. Lit., mana [from] southern border.
Almighty Holy Trinity. (Kel. 18.)
A native, large-leaved variety of taro, chiefly used as table taro; leaf stem pink and green below grading upward to light-green. Lit., long-leaved mana.
Native speaker, a term invented by Larry Kimura and William H. Wilson in the late 1970s. Lit., inherited language.

1. Sweet, potable, of water that may be drunk but is not deliciously cool (huʻihuʻi); firm and tasty, as taro or sweet potato.

2. Appeased, softened, mollified, as anger, curses, bad omens; safe from harm or danger; sweetness, appeasement.

3. Name reported for both Venus and Jupiter. Also Hoʻomānalo.
Same as nenue, pilot fish.
Star name (no data). (Kuhelani.)

1. Redup. of mānalo 1, 2.

2. Same as Mānalo 3.
Same as maiʻa mana lua.

1. Redup. of mana 1.

2. Redup. of mana 2; appendages, claws, branches, rays, forks; to branch out.

3. Finger, toe.

4. Third of three coconut husks tied to ʻahi fishing line. Cf. nuku and poli, the first and second husks from the bottom.

1. Index finger.

Thumb. Lit., big finger.

A kind of seaweed. Lit., red-branching.
Toe.

1. To stretch out, as arms, fingers, feet; to spread out, as the tentacles of an octopus; to protrude, as ears; to distend, as nostrils while breathing hard; swelling, as with disease (Ii 164).

2. A variety of sweet potato.
Same as mālana, buoyant.
A pleasant breeze.
Var. of mālānai, shallow.

1. Redup. of mānalo.

2. Venus.
Star name (no data).
Redup. of manaʻo; opinions or viewpoints of several persons.

Thought, idea, belief, opinion, theory, thesis, intention, meaning, suggestion, mind (Mat. 22.37), desire, want; to think, estimate, anticipate, expect (see ex., leleʻoi), suppose, mediate, deem, consider (not the intellectual process of noʻonoʻo). See manaʻo nui.
Clever thought, wise thought; spirit of wisdom. (Puk. 28.3.)
A variety of taro, same as mana ʻulu except that the petiole is pinker. (HP 24.) This term may be qualified by the colors keʻokeʻo, lenalena, melemele, ʻulaʻula.
See mana ʻoene
Something to say, thought to express, predication, theorem, problem; to predicate.
Narrow or intolerant mind; narrow-minded, intolerant.
A variety oof taro (HP 33.)
Comparison.
Superstition.
Hidden or figurative meaning.
See manaʻo hoʻonalonalo
Hidden or figurative meaning.
Evil thought or idea, hatred, ill feeling; to hate.
Faith, confidence; to have faith, confidence; to believe.
Money-minded, commercial.
Pride, conceit. Lit., high opinion.
Rebellious thoughts; disloyal.
Supposition, presumption.
Hypothesis, lemma; thought to help.
Same as manaʻo paʻa; doctrine.
Hope, confidence, expectation; to hope (manaʻo + -lana, nominalizer: ).
Broad-minded, tolerant, tolerancy.
Pas/imp. of manaʻo.
Unanimous.
Literal meaning; a real or true opinion.
Redup. of manaʻo; to meditate, ponder. (Hal. 63.6.)
Horrible, dreadful, pitiful, horrifying, gruesome, shocking; shocked, horrified; heartsick, overcome with grief or horror; heartbreaking; grief.
Important matter or idea, sense, signification; meaning (Niʻihau).
Confused, erroneous thinking, hallucination.
Conviction, determination, firm intention; convinced, determined, resolute (Laie 591).
A native variety of taro, named for a fish, ʻōpelu, the corms of which were used as ʻōpelu bait; the leaf stem is green with white streaks, becoming maroon above. (Whitney; HP 23.)
Corollary, as in mathematics.
Postscript, afterthought, forgotten opinion.
Whim, fancy, impulse, notion, random thought, thought that has come for no particular reason.
To suppose, presume.
Explanatory thought, scholium, explanation.
Var. spelling of mana ʻoene.
Supreme, absolute power.
A native variety of taro, distinguished by purple on leaf center and extending on main veins; a fair table taro. (Whitney; HP 24.)
A variety of taro. Lit., crinkled mana.
See mea ʻono puaʻa.
A variety of taro, the leaf stem mainly light green, the leaf blade with white leaf center, veins, and edges. (HP 24.) Lit., smoky-gray mana.

1. A small red seaweed (Gracilaria coronopifolia), with stiff, cylindrical, succulent stem and branches, a good alga for making food gels (KL. line 53). The term may be qualified by pala kea, pehu, or puakea. Rarely manaiea; often called “short ogo” and “long ogo” (Japanese, dialectal).

2. A variety of taro.
See manauea
Same as mana ʻoene, a taro.
See manaʻuele
A variety of taro.
A rare variety of taro, distinguished by its purplish-red flecked petioles; mainly used as table taro. (HP 24.) Also mana hāʻulaʻula.
A variety of taro, introduced from South Seas; makes good poi of yellow color. The corms are tough and rubbery when cooked. Noted for prolific branching. Lit., dark mana.

A native variety of taro distinguished by pinkish petioles. The corms have orange-yellow flesh when cooked (like fruit of breadfruit) and are used mainly as table taro. (Whitney 27; HP 24.) Lit., breadfruit mana. Cf. mana ʻoene.
Var. spelling of manauea.

1. Time, turn, season, date, chronology, period of time. Cf. haʻi manawa.

2. For a short time, infrequent.

3. Affections, feelings, disposition, heart, seat of emotions. Cf. manawahuwā, manawa ʻino, manawaleʻa, manawanui.

4. Anterior fontanel in the heads of infants; top of the head of adults at position of the fontanel.

1. Hard breathing, panting for breath, from exertion; to pant thus, breathe. Lit., rising breath.

2. Infancy before the fontanel closes. Lit., rising fontanel.
Working time or shift.
Name of a star, said to appear in the first night of the month Nana and to vanish after the night of Muku. Lit., female power.

1. Discomfort of the stomach, or indigestion, with gas and often diarrhea, thought to be caused by wrong diet or by excessive handling of animals, such as kittens or puppies, which might also become sick; to suffer thus; great grief, as over the loss of a loved one; to grieve. Lit., swollen stomach. Cf. lūmanawahua.

2. A native fern (Doryopteris spp.), about 30 cm high, with heart-shaped fronds divided into many long segments. Also ʻiwaʻiwa.
Jealous, jealousy; to bear a grudge.
See manawahuā
Warped, depressed, bent in. Rare.

1. Stream branch

2. A variety of taro. (HP 33.)
A variety of taro. (HP 33.)
Evil disposition, hard feelings, hard-hearted, time of storm.
Free time.
Eternal.
Opportune time, appropriate time, opportunity, chance.
A generous heart, charity, alms, donation; to give freely and willingly; gratis, free, benevolent, beneficent.
Bedtime, time to sleep.
Same as kolokolo kahakai, a beach vitex.

See "hoʻomanawanui": Patience, steadfastness, fortitude; to have patience, fortitude; patient, steadfast, courageous and persevering; to try one's patience. E hoʻomanawanui, be patient. He kanaka hoʻomanawanui i ka lā a me ka ua, a man who patiently endures the sun and the rain. He nohona hoʻomanawanui, a way of life that tries one's patience. (PCP manawanui.)
A variety of taro, probably the same as weo; distinguished by dark-purple petiole edges; a fair table taro.

1. Manna. (Puk. 16.31.) Eng.

2. Mina (RSV), maneh (KJV). (Ezek. 45.12.) Eng.
Hoof (Lunk. 5.22); claws; fingernails, toenails; ball of a foot; keel of a ship. Fig., dependent, underling, inferior.
Same as mānaiʻula.

1. Sedan chair, palanquin, litter, stretcher, bier (2 Sam. 3:31); to carry on a stretcher, bier, sedan chair.

2. Same as aʻe, several trees.
Litter with decorated sides on which a bride was carried to her groom's house. (Kam. 64:26.) Lit., litter [with] festive sides.
Fissures, caves, as on ocean floor; free of stones, as land. (And.)
A small native tree (several varieties of Pelea hawaiensis), with oblong leaves and four-parted fruit capsules; related to the mokihana.

1. Shuddery sensation of fear, as on looking over a precipice or if confronted by sudden danger; sensation of disgust, revulsion, or repugnance; sensation of inner quaking accompanying sexual desire; to shudder, quake.

2. A kind of small plantain or laukahi (Plantago grayana var.
Itch; itchy; smarting, as the throat after eating raw taro or certain fish; prickly, as some clothes; sexually titillated; ticklish; tickling.
Sailfish tang (Zebrasoma veliferum).

1. Redup. of maneʻo.

2. An edible seaweed, Laurencia nidifica.

1. Same as mānewanewa.

2. To breathe, as a fish. Rare.

3. A kind of grass (no data).

1. Grief, sorrow, mourning; exaggerated expression of grief, as by knocking out teeth, cutting the hair in strange patterns, eating of filth, tattooing the tongue, removing the malo and wearing it about the neck; to do such.

2. Unkind.

3. Var. of hīnawenawe, hīnewanewa, weak, spindly.

4. Name given for a beach grass; used in leis on Lā-naʻi.

1. Dull, as a blade; slick; smooth, as a water-worn pebble. Cf. hāmani.

2. To cool off, of heat. (And.) E mani ka umu, let the oven cool.

1. Shuddering sensation as on looking down a great height, or hearing a saw filed; dizziness; dizzy; to shudder; to be contracted.

2. Inactive, drowsy, sleepy.

3. Same as mani 1. (PCP mania.)

4. Same as mani 2.

5. Lump, as on the skin. (Kel. 13.)
Acidity; tart, acid.
Redup. of mania.
Drowsy, sleepy, especially after bathing.
Var. of mania.

1. Bermuda grass (Cynodon dactylon), a fine-leafed, cosmopolitan grass, much used for lawns in Hawaiʻi. (Neal 67–8.)

2. Short for mānienie ʻakiʻaki.

3. Bare, barren.

4. Same as māniania.

1. Seashore rush grass (Sporobolus virginicus). Also ʻakiʻaki, mānienie māhikihiki, and mānienie maoli. (Neal 66–7.)

2. Buffalo grass (Stenotaphrum secundatum), a coarse-leafed grass from the southern United States, used for lawns in Hawaiʻi. Sometimes qualified by haole and also called mānienie māhikihiki. (Neal 72–3.)
Wire grass (Eleusine indica), a weed in lawns and waste places, a strong, smooth, tufted grass, with pale-green, flattened stems. Lit., chief mānienie. (Neal 67.)

Bermuda grass (Cynodon dactylon), said to have been introduced by Dr. G. P. Judd about 1835; called mānienie because it creeps like buffalo grass (see mānienie ʻakiʻaki), which the Hawaiians originally called mānienie. (Neal 67.)
See "Cymbopogon refractus": . Niʻihau. See Neal 79.
Same as mānienie ʻakiʻaki 1, 2. Lit., mānienie for exorcising evil spirits.
Same as mānienie ʻakiʻaki (Sporobolus virginicus). Lit., native mānienie.

A small, stiff, weedy grass (Chrysopogon aciculatus) from southeastern Asia, found in some Pacific islands; it forms mats and bears a narrow head of reddish, barbed spikelets, which stick to animals' coats. Also piʻipiʻi, pilipili ʻula. (Neal 80.)
Same as kamaniha, sullen.
Var. of manuheʻu, bruised.
Manila hat, named for the city.
Ashamed, humiliated. Rare.

1. Very common reef surgeonfish (Acanthurus triostegus), also called convict tang, in the adult stage. In legends manini ʻele kuhō. For younger stages see ʻōhualiko, ōhua kāniʻo, palapōhaku, and kākala manini, and maninini.

2. Stingy. Cf. Fijian manini-taka, to hoard up like a miser.

3. A kind of banana generally eaten cooked; leaves and fruits green and white striped. Also aʻeaʻe, koaʻe. (Neal 249.)

4. A variety of sugar cane, named for the fish. Also laukona.

5. A variety of dryland taro with striped petiole. The name may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, hā kikokiko, hā uliuli, kākau, kea, lau kikokiko, uliuli.

6. A variety of sweet potato.

7. Wrath, anger; angry.

8. To pour, spill; irrigated.

9. Hawaiian name of a well-known Spanish immigrant, 
Francisco de Paula Marin, who knew Ka-mehameha for more than 25 years (Kuykendall 429.)

1. Stage of manini, a fish, said to be larger than ʻōhua and smaller than manini.

2. Redup. of manini, to pour.
A taro cultivar. (TC 4.)
A taro cultivar. (TC 3.)
Var. of malino, calm. (PNP malino.)
Redup. of manino.

The cassava or manioc (Manihot esculenta), a bushy herb or shrub 1 to 2.8 m high, from Brazil, widely grown for its tuberous, edible roots, like sweet potatoes. The roots also yield a starch, tapioca. Cf. pia manioka. (Neal 513–4.) Eng.

1. num. Many, numerous, four thousand; thick. Cf. kini, lau, lehu, manoa.

2. To throw, as stone; to aim at and hit. Rare.

3. Short for Mano-ka-lani-pō.
See "hoʻomano":  A name given to the kāmanomano plant when used in hana aloha, love sorcery.

Shark (general name). Many kinds are listed below. Reef sharks may attain a length of 1.5 m. Fig., a passionate lover. Sharks were ʻaumākua to some; they were said to have never harmed and frequently to protect those who fed and petted them. Cf. ʻai ā manō, hula manō, niuhi, pua 1.
Dam, stream or water source, headwaters, place where water is obstructed for distribution in channels, channels (Isa. 8.7). Cf. māno wai.
Numerous, very many. Cf. mano 1.

1. Thick, solid, vast; depth, thickness.

2. A large Honolulu valley.
Redup. of manoa and mānoa; dull-witted, stupid, calloused, coarse, numbed, as the tongue from chewing kava.
Large fleet of canoes.
Intensifier of mano 1.
Thresher shark (Alopias vulpinus). Rare. Lit., tail-hitting shark.
Coconut oil, perfume. (Perhaps from Tahitian; the Samoan cognate is manongi, and the normal Hawaiian equivalent would be manoni: .) Kou mau mea manoʻi (Isa. 57.9), thy perfumes.
See manō.
Name of a chief of Kauaʻi.
See manō.
Hammerhead shark (Sphryna zygaena). Lit., angular shark.
Shark, perhaps Squalus fernandinus, sometimes called dogfish; considered harmless. Lit., white-fin shark.
A shark, possibly thresher. Lit., shark that frequently strikes tail.
lelewaʻa.
Redup. of mano 1; great; greatness; four thousand times four thousand; myriad.
Mixed feelings as of joy and sorrow, unhappiness. Cf. noni 3.
Pas/imp. of manoni.
See niuhi.

1. Red, as sunburn. Cf. nono, red.

2. Redup. of mano 1.

3. Same as nono; to seep; to wane, as the moon.

4. All species of an endemic genus (Gouldia) of shrubs or small trees belonging to the coffee family. (Neal 793.)

5. Block set athwart a canoe to which ʻiako (outrigger booms) are lashed.

6. Laid across one another, as mats.
Young of the kawakawa, a fish.
A shark. Lit., black-smudged shark.
A shark. Lit., thick-necked shark.
A shark. Lit., red shark.
Same as māno. Fig., heart and circulatory system; source of water and of life.

1. Bird; any winged creature; wing of a kite. Fig., person.

2. Bruised, broken, scarred, injured.

3. Ornamental elliptical expansions at the upper ends of the bow and stern endpieces, distinguished by mua and ihu, “forward” or “bow,” and hope, “stern.”

4. Salty, pungent, acrid. (And.)

5. Game similar to fox and geese. Also punipeki.

1. Pas/imp. of manu 2.

2. Same as mana kūkulu hema, a taro.

3. Manure (Eng.); any kind of fertilizer.

1. Wounded, bruised; to wound.

2. Man-of-war, warship, battleship. Eng.
See manuā
Piled, accumulated.

Gratis, gratuitous, free of charge; adulterous. (This word is said to have originated from the name of a Hawaiian merchant famous for giving good measure with his sales.) Keiki manuahi, illegitimate child.
See manuahi
Partridge. (Ier. 17.11.) Lit., thieving bird.
Ricebird (Lonchura punctulata), introduced from the Malay Peninsula in about 1865. Lit., rice-eating bird.
Linnet, house finch, or papaya bird (Carpodacus mexicanus frontalis), introduced before 1870. Lit., papaya-eating bird.
See manu-ʻai-mīkana
Scavenger bird, mynah bird. Lit., filth-eating bird. See pihaʻekelo.
Manual. Eng. Ka Manuale Kakolika, the Catholic Manual.

1. Lovebird.

2. Parrot, so called because it extends greeting (aloha).
Rare. var. of mānaʻonaʻo.
To dislike, despise. Cf. manu heʻu, manumanu.

1. Careless, blundering, slipshod, awkward. Rare.

2. Center support of a house. Rare.
Thundercloud. Rare.
Penguin. Lit., bird that walks upright.
To feather out, of young birds. Fig., to leave home, as young people.
Bruised, injured, damaged, dented; in bad condition, as an old building; to bruise, damage, injure, deface; to bite with the teeth and peel off, as bark.
Wild, ravenous bird. (Isa. 46.11.) Lit., angry bird.
Tailorbird.
Swallow. (Ier. 8.7, Isa. 38.14.) Lit., chirping bird.
Lagging, dilatory, slow, blundering.
California valley quail (Lophortyx californicus californicus), an early introduction, common in the 1890s. Lit., whirr bird.
Dove, including Chinese dove (Streptopelia chinensis); rock or wild pigeon (Columba livia). Lit., coo (Eng.) bird.

A native variety of sugar cane, the stems green striped with yellowish and reddish brown, the pith brown, the leaves purplish. Used medicinally, also in love sorcery. See ex., kāʻawe. (HP 221; Neal 79.) Lit., flying bird.
English sparrow; European housefinch (Passer domesticus); introduced before 1870; little bird. (Hal. 102.7.)
Rough, irregular, nicked; dull, blunt, not sharp, as a knife; bruised; scarred, as by smallpox (Kam. 64:106).
Songbird, especially canary (Serinus canaria). Cf. kenele.
Possibly a local name for a small sedge (Cyperus brevifolius). Lit., goose bird. See kiliʻoʻopu.

1. To creak or break, as bones; tremor, as of an earthquake.

2. Numb.
See "hoʻomanunu":  To break out, as with a skin eruption. (Kam. 64:105.)
Redup. of manunu 1, 2.
Dove. (Hal. 55.6.) Lit., cooing bird.
Carrier pigeon. Lit., dove carrying letters (Eng.).
White tern, fairy tern, love tern (Cygis alba rothschildi), a small, friendly sea bird, pure white except for a black ring around the eye. Lit., bird of Kū.

1. Same as mānuʻunuʻu.

2. Sick, weak, in pain. (And.)
Crane. (Ier. 8.7.) Lit., groaning bird.
Cardinal, redbird. Lit., red bird.
Vast, great, without measure, multitudinous. Cf. nuʻu.
See manuā.

1. Cleared, as rain; alleviated, assuaged, as grief; to clear up, as rain; to pass, as sadness.

2. To fade, as cloth.

3. Type of fish. (KL. line 158.) Cf. maomao.
Because of, due to, by means of, through. Cf. ma, at.

1. Green. Cf. mamaʻo, maʻomaʻo, ʻōmaʻomaʻo.

2. The native cotton (Gossypium sandvicense), a shrub in the hibiscus family, bearing yellow flowers and seed cases containing brown cotton. (Neal 566.) Also huluhulu. Cf. pulupulu haole.

3. The hoary abutilon (Abutilon incanum), a small native, velvety shrub, in the hibiscus family, with small heartshaped leaves, small pink and red flowers, and small dry fruits. (Neal 550.)

4. The hairy abutilon (Abutilon grandifolium), a weedy, hairy, South American shrub, with large, broad leaves, orange, ʻilima-like flowers, and ten-parted, black, dry fruits. When green and soft, these fruits are used in making ʻilima leis, one for each end of the lei. (Neal 550.)

5. Same as ʻōmaʻo, thrush. (PCP mako.)
See ʻō, there.
Chafing from friction, soreness from rubbing; to chafe, rub, become sore from rubbing. (PCP maoa.)

See "hoʻomaoe":  To ask indirectly; to hint or suggest, as in asking; to imply, allude. Ke nīnau hoʻomaoe nei nā kānaka i ke kumu o kona make ʻana (Kep. 45), the people are now asking indirectly the cause of his death.
Lazy, uninterested in work. Rare.
Same as maoa.
Grayish, especially when contrasted with black, as of bird feathers, cloud-capped mountains, graying hair.
Similar to ohaoha.
The native yellow hibiscus (Hibiscus brackenridgei), a small shrub with broad, lobed leaves and with large yellow flowers that turn green on drying. (Neal 560.) Lit., green traveling hau.

1. Tall and spindly, as trees in a dense forest that reach up for light, or as bamboo; straight and tall, as of a fine physique. Cf. ʻohe, bamboo.

2. A variety of sugar cane.
Same as ohiohi 1; to grow vigorously.
A native mint (Stenogyne rugosa), found only on the island of Hawaiʻi, a shrub with smooth, ovate, toothed leaves and reddish flowers grouped in whorls of six to ten at leaf bases.
Misty.
Same as mahaʻoi, bold. (2 Kor. 11.21.) hoʻo.mā.ʻoi To act bold, impertinent.

1. Redup. of māʻoi.

2. Uneven, notched, zigzag.
Var. of maoli 1.
Anything cut into pieces, streaked (less used than māʻokiʻoki).
Redup. of maʻoki, sometimes with idea of small pieces.

1. Native, indigenous, aborigine, genuine, true, real, actual; very, really, truly.

2. A variety of ʻahi, a fish that may weigh about 90 kilos; it has light, slightly pinkish flesh.

3. A native variety of banana, with tall, green trunk; the fruit forming large, compact bunches, having thick yellow skin and sweet yellow flesh; edible cooked or raw. (HP 176.)

4. A variety of sweet potato.
A native variety of banana. Lit., thin-skinned maoli.

1. Same as ʻoliʻoli, joy.

2. Same as laulihilihi, a shrub.
Same as maʻaloa, a shrub.

Large-meshed net used at makahiki ceremonies. It was filled with food and held at each of the four corners. The priest prayed, and the net was shaken. If the food did not fall out, the priest predicted famine. Perhaps this was named for a legendary net called kōkō a maoloha. During a famine Waia miraculously lowered this net from heaven and filled it with food. He shook the net, and food was scattered for the benefit of the starving people. (Malo 151, 155.)
Boggy, squashy; yielding to pressure, as a soft cushion. Cf. ʻolu, elasticity.
A kind of red tapa.

1. Type of fish (KL. line 158), perhaps same as mamo, mamamo, mao.

2. Rare. var. of mamao, far.

3. Calm, clear. Rare.

1. Green, greenness.

2. A green tapa, as of māmaki bark.
Probably same as maomao, a fish.
(usually pronounced but not written māʻana). vs. Satisfied after eating, full, satisfying; to have eaten, to eat one's fill. Fig., intoxicated. For a rare use of māʻona as a noun, see kuenenuʻu.
A gray basalt, used for pounders. Rare. Also kuanuʻu.
Same as māʻopaʻopa (Nak. 75, 115).
Tired, aching, of legs; to limp.
To understand, recognize, realize; clear; plainly, clearly; understanding.
Same as ʻopu, to dive.
Marble (Eng.), granite.
Var. of māpala. Ma nā puka māpela (hymn), at the marble gates.
See māpela

1. Thatched heiau (temple) for the worship of Lono and the increase of food; the offerings were of pigs, not humans. (Malo 160.)

2. A shrub, Cyrtandra cyaneoidea. (Kam. 76:125.) (Cf. For. 6:430, 444.)
Same as pū, rope tied to a canoe endpiecea.
Fragrance, especially, wind-blown fragrance; wafted; bubbling, splashing, as water; dipping, swooping. Fig., surging, as emotion.
See koloa māpu.
Ape, baboon.
Same as māpu. (Probably māpu + -ana, nominalizer: .) Onaona māpuana o ka loke, the soft wafted fragrance of the rose.
Redup. and intensifier of māpu.
Bubbling spring; froth, as of a rough sea; source. Fig., surging of emotion.
Dip of a paddle.
Utterance, expression, wafted voice; few words.
See māpuna leo
Redup. of māpuna.

1. Always, steady, constant, ever, unceasing, permanent, stationary, continual, perpetual; to continue, persevere, preserve, endure, last; preservation, continuation.

2. Stopped, as menstruation; snagged, caught, as a fish or hook; retarded; grounded, as a canoe; set, as a wager; stuck or stalled, as a car.

3. Conceived, as at the very moment of conception.

4. Person who carried the wand and chanted in the ʻume game. (Malo 215.)

5. marking plural, used principally after the k-class possessives and demonstratives, numerals, and he. See .
See "hoʻomau":  A variety of sweet potato.
Same as ʻamaʻu, a native genus of ferns.

1. Damp, wet, humid, moist, cool, refreshing. See ex., huʻahuʻa kai.

2. Same as māʻau, to sprout. Cf. wao maʻukele.

3. A little, of some little value, of slight use but better than nothing. Cf. maʻū wale, pohō maʻū.

1. Failure to give a return gift; to receive without giving in return; illiberal, ungrateful, close-fisted. Cf. mamaua.

2. Native forest trees, Xylosma hawaiiense. See aʻe 6. (Neal 592.)

3. A type of prayer for luakini dedication. (For. 6:23.)

1. Lame, stiff, sore.

2. Fallen tree or plant that sends up new branches; shoots from fallen trunks. See ohiohi 1.
See mauā
. We, us (dual, exclusive).
Careless, as of clothing, mats, tapa, property.
Powerful, strong, of superior strength, athletic; to exercise strength, to use force. Rare.
Var. spelling of māwae, crack. (Puk. 33.22.)
To intrude, transgress, break taboo, interrupt, meddle in the concern of others; to step over; to flaunt, as authority; to override, as a veto; such action. Cf. ʻaʻe, to break taboo.
Redup. of mauʻaʻe; lawless.
Var. of mahuakala, disbelieving.
Tough, leathery, as skin of the old; old.
To clear, as brush.
See mauele
Lazy, without energy.
See maʻuele
To clear, as brush; tangled, snarled, Kā ke ala, mauelekā! Cut a pathway! Cut and Clear!
See mauelekā
Weary, aching, tired.
To abandon, leave, as one's family; to cease, as sinning; to pass on, die.

1. Pas/imp. of mauhaʻalele.

2. A prayer to a forest god before cutting down a tree to be made into an image.

1. Heavily burdened, weighted down. Rare.

2. To bore, pierce, as a hole in a rock. (And.)
Grudge, resentment, spite; unforgiving, to nurse revenge.
Entangled, snarled, interwoven. Cf. hili.

1. Name of one of the Hawaiian islands. Cf. Māui, the demigod.

2. A variety of sweet potato.

1. The demigod and trickster who snared the sun.

2. Name of a star near the Pleiades.

3. Sprain, bruise; sprained, bruised; pitripened, of bananas. See prayer, nūpolupolu.

1. To ask continually, frequently. Cf. ui.

2. Redup. of māui, bruise. (PNP maauiui.)
See uka, inland.
Same as māʻukaʻuka.
Same as milikaʻa.
Unskilled person; not adept, awkward, said derisively of an unsuccessful suitor.
Place name at Puna, Hawaiʻi.
Rain-forest area.
Same as maoli, native.

1. To ration food or water, as in time of drought.

2. Small, thin, fine, as a thread.

3. Stilled, hushed, as worshippers.

4. To offer to the gods, as food.

5. Constant, persevering. Rare.
Name of a star, perhaps related to Kona-mau-kuku.

1. Same as ʻulaʻula, red.

2. Red earth, as used in coloring.
Faint, faint-hearted; dispirited, weak; fainting.
Calloused. Cf. leho, callus.
Flotsam and jetsam. (For. 4:75.)
Redup. of maʻule.

1. Life, heart, seat of life; ghost, spirit.

2. Fontanel.

3. Twenty-ninth of the old month. (Malo 32.) (PCP mauli.)
Same as uli, dark.
Descendant of old chiefs of a land; established, ancient, as a family.
Hiccough; dying gasp; to hiccough, gasp in dying.
Hanging precariously, fastened slightly.
Failure; failing; to fail. Rare.
Place name at Kī-lau-ea Volcano, Hawaiʻi. (PH 94.)
Breath of life, power of healing.
Redup. of māuli, dark.
Same as māʻuluʻulu. See puehu 1.
Difficult, hard.
Upland forest, said to be similar to uka wao lāʻau.
Lame, stiff, as from exercise; tired.

1. Redup. of mau 1, frequent, often.

2. Not sticky, not tenacious; of poi of medium texture, neither hard nor watery.
Same as ʻāmaʻumaʻu, ferns.
Redup. of maʻū, moist.
Pas/imp. of maumau 1; to do it continuously, repeat; repetitious; repeating (Kel. 59).
Doubtful. (And.)

1. Mountain, mountainous region; mountainous.

Waste; mistreatment; wasteful; injured; abusive; to waste, injure, mistreat.
The highest mountain on Hawaiʻi. Lit., snow mountain.

1. A sea bean, Dioclea wilsonii, a vine from Brazil growing wild in Hawaiʻi, the blue or white flowers used for leis, the beans for medicine. (Neal 463.)

2. Canavalia cathartica, a vine from the Mascarene Islands, the white, lavender, pink, or reddish flowers commonly used for leis. (Neal 464.)
The second highest mountain on Hawaiʻi; a mountain and village on Molokaʻi. Lit., long mountain.
Redup. of māuna; extravagant, wasteful, prodigal.

1. Rocky Mountains.

Bait; objects used in black magic, as hair, spittle, parings, excreta, clothing, food leavings.
To molt; to change skin, as of snakes; to change from a chrysalis state, as to a butterfly; to remove bristles, as of a pig for baking. Cf. unuunu.

1. Redup. of māunu.

2. Name of a strong, blustering wind associated with Wai-ʻalae and Puʻu-loa, Oʻahu.
Teeth worn with age; aged, worn-out, Cf. niho mauole.
General name for grasses, sedges, rushes, herbs; kava strainer; strand of pandanus plaiting, as in hat making.

See "hoʻomauʻu":  To give nothing of value (probably related to the fig. meaning of mauʻu Hilo. ʻO ka mea e hoʻomanawaleʻa aku, ā momona ia, a ʻo ka mea e hoʻomauʻu aku, e hoʻomauʻu ʻia, mai ʻoia (Johnson 1976, p. 288), he who freely gives shall be enriched, and he who gives nothing of value shall receive nothing of value.

1. Same as maʻūmaʻū.
