A sedge (Fimbristylis pycnocephala).
A grass (Echinochloa colonum).
A grass (Andropogon barbinodis).

Hilo grass (Paspalum conjugatum), a creeping perennial from tropical America. Though it is a coarse, weedy grass, it may serve as a lawn grass. It spreads rapidly and has become a pest because cattle do not eat it and it smothers slower-growing, desirable plants, especially in native forests. It first appeared in Hilo, Hawaiʻi, about 1840. (Neal 73.) For fig. use, see he aha sananā and wēkenanā.
Same as mauʻu lāʻili, a native iris. (Neal 232–3.) Lit., grass reddening skin; see mauʻu lāʻili.
McCoy grass (Cyperus gracilis), a small, fine-leafed sedge from Australia, used for lawns in Hawaiʻi, (Neal 85–6.)

The yellow foxtail (Setaria geniculata), a weedy tropical American grass. The yellow or brownish, cylindrical flower heads are smooth and soft, and in Hawaiʻi are used for leis on hats. (Neal 75.) Lit., California grass.

Velvet grass (Zoysia tenuifolia), a turf-forming lawn grass from the Mascarene Islands (Mauritius and Réunion). It is a dense, dark-green, fine grass, soon forming hummocks. Lit., Japanese grass, (Neal 67.)
A kind of crab grass (Digitaria pruriens), used medicinally. Lit., hog excrement grass. See kūkaepuaʻa. (Neal 72.)
Same as ʻumeʻalu, bur grass. Lit., prickly grass.
Rice grass (Paspalum orbiculare), a coarse, tufted, perennial grass, possibly native to Hawaiʻi. It was used like pili for thatching houses. (Neal 73.)

1. A native iris (Sisyrinchium acre), with long grasslike leaves and small yellow flowers, found on Maui and Hawaiʻi between altitudes of 1,000 and 2,000 m. (Neal 232–3.) It grows in the Kī-lau-ea Volcano region, and formerly the sap was used to stain the skin so that travelers could prove to others at home that they had been to the volcano. Also mauʻu hōʻula ʻili.

2. Name of a kind of calico with tiny figures, so called because of resemblance to mauʻu lāʻili stains.

The swollen finger grass (Chloris inflata), an annual weedy grass from tropical America, 30 to 60 cm high. Two to eleven feathery, purplish flower spikes radiate from the top of the stem; they are used for hat leis. (Neal 69.)
Wilted grass; name of a taboo on men, said to last ten days (sexual union was forbidden, and each man urinated in a particular spot only, where the grass wilted, hence the name of the taboo).
Hay, straw, any dry grass.
A sedge. Same as kiliʻoʻopu.

The bristly foxtail (Setaria verticillata), a hairy grass from Europe and Asia, growing like a weed in Hawaiʻi. The green, cylindrical flower heads are full of barbed bristles that cling to animals and clothing. Lit., sticking grass. (Neal 75–6.)
A grass (Panicum maximum).
Same as puʻukaʻa, a sedge.

Attractive.
Mule, ass (Kin. 36.24). Eng.

Orange and white champak (Michelia champaca and M. longifolia), tall trees with smooth gray trunks, from the Himalayas, related to the magnolia, bearing many-parted, orange or yellow flowers (M. champaca) or white flowers (M. longifolia), which are especially fragrant at night. (Neal 357.) The orange and white species may be distinguished by qualifying miulana with the colors melemele and keʻokeʻo. The Chinese name for the white species is pak-lan, but Cf. pakalana.
Short for moku 1, 2.

1. Short for moʻo, succession. Cf. moʻolelo, story.

2. Short for moʻo, lizard.

3. Var. of mā-, ma, stative prefixes, but less common. See mōʻali, mōhai, mōhaʻi, mōʻiu, mōkila, and others.

1. Chicken, red jungle chicken (Gallus gallus), fowl, as brought to Hawaiʻi by Polynesians; for some people, an ʻaumakua.

2. A native banana fruit with large and plump skin and flesh yellow, edible raw or cooked, growing in a small bunch. Also huamoa. (HP 176.) (Probably PPN moa.)

3. Tufted, green, leafless plants (Psilotum nudum and P. complanatum), about 30 cm long, with many slender branches, growing in most tropical countries, both on trees and on the ground. Hawaiians used them medicinally (the spore powder as a purge), and their children played a game with them. (Neal 1–2.) Sometimes called moa nahele, pipi.

4. Children's game played with moa twigs; the tiny branches were interlocked, and the players pulled on the ends; the loser's twigs broke and the winner crowed like a rooster (moa).

5. A dart, tapering at one end, usually 25 to 60 cm long, used in a sliding game on which bets were made. Cf. paheʻe 3.

6. Var. of pahu, trunkfish (Ostracion meleagris).

7. Stone fastened to rope, used as a war weapon, said to be triangular in shape.

8. A small gastropod mollusk. Also kāmoa.
Cooked; burned, as by sun; cooking, cooked food; made brittle, as tobacco leaves over a fire.
Completely black chicken, so called because the mudhen (ʻalae) was black.
Var. spelling of mōwae.
Trade wind.
Trade wind.
Bantam, any short-legged chicken.
Var. spelling of mōwahowaho.
Broody hen.
Bending over, arching, as a tree. Rare.
Same as mōakaaka.
Clear, plain, intelligible, manifest; clarity.
See mōakaaka
Cock with sharp spurs. Fig., warrior who is a good fighter.
Rooster, cock. Lit., male chicken.
Cooked rare, as beef.
First cock crow. Lit., chicken rising first. Also moa kū kahi. Cf. moa kualua, second cock crow.
To raise to the mouth, as poi, or as a Chinese feeds rice into his mouth. Rare. Cf. ala, to rise.

1. An edible crab found in ponds and shallow water, probably Podophthalmus vigil.

2. To relish food, as after having lost the appetite. Rare.
Going here and there, as one asking for handouts; to gad about. Rare. Cf. kōʻalaʻala, quick.
Well-cooked, as pig.
Impression, trace, scar, mark, as left by a knife cut; furrow, rut, track, groove, thread, welt, strand; small, fine. See ex., puahilohilo.
Redup. of mōʻali.
To cherish and cultivate.
Fighting cock. Fig., successful warrior.
Barely cooked. Lit., cooked raw.

1. To act the part of a cock; to care for, attend to; to supply with food, as a child or ward.

2. Sharp point at the stern of a canoe.

3. Paper nautilus. Also ʻauwaʻalālua, ʻaumoana, moamoa waʻa.

4. Same as pahu, trunkfish.

1. Ocean, open sea, lake.

2. Campground, consultation place for chiefs.

3. Broad, wide, extended, expansive, spread out.
Arctic Ocean.
Antarctic Ocean.
Redup. of moana 3.
See moa 3.
Salt sea (Nah. 34.3), salt lake; deep sea.
Salt sea (Nah. 34.12), salt lake.
Fresh-water lake; sea (Mat. 8.27).
Speckled chicken, so called because of resemblance to the nēnē, goose.
Light or gentle breeze, usually associated with fragrance; wafted fragrance; to blow perfume. (See chant, kokoe; Mele 1.12.) Moani ke ʻala o ka ʻawapuhi, wind-blown is the ginger perfume.
Name of a land breeze that wafts out to sea at Puna, Hawaiʻi. Lit., fragrant breeze, so named for the fragrance of pandanus.
Redup. of moani.
Name of a rain or wind associated with Puna, Hawaiʻi. Lit., wind that wafts the fragrance of lehua blossoms.

1. Goatfish (Parupeneus multifasciatus). The young are called ʻāhua or ʻōhua; the red color was believed caused by eating lehua flowers. The name may be qualified by the terms ʻau kī, kea (P. chryserydros), pāpaʻa, ukali, ukali ulua.

2. Pale red color, as of the moano fish. Fig., to bloom.

3. A native variety of sugar cane, named for the fish; a red cane becoming dark-purple; pith dark-brown. (HP 224.)

4. A variety of taro. (HP 33.)
Young moano, goatfish.
A chicken with yellow feathers. Lit., hau-flower chicken.
Stretched or spread out.
Waterfall, Hālawa, Molokaʻi, and wind there.
Predominantly red chicken.
Short for moana uli, dark blue sea.
Hen. Lit., female chicken.

1. To sleep, lie down; to lie in wait, ambush; to prostrate oneself, as before a chief; to lay down, as cards; to sit on eggs; horizontal, phone. See ex., ʻoni, death.

2. To marry, mate with, sleep with, cohabit; marriage.

3. Bed, sleeping place.

4. Dream.

5. Calm, as the sea.

6. Same as moea 2. Cf. kāmoe.

1. Pas/imp. of moe 2, 3.

2. . To press onward, go straight toward.

1. A variety of sweet potato.

2. Wind name, Ke-kaha, Kauaʻi. (For. 5:95.)
Sodomy, sodomist; to commit sodomy (1 Kor. 6.9). Lit., friend mating.
One who gets up long after sunrise; a late sleeper; to sleep late.
To sleep in the hālau (shed), sometimes said of a lazy, uncooperative person. See ex., lola.
To sleep restlessly; to fidget, talk, or walk in one's sleep; disturbed in one's sleep; night mare; to have a nightmare. Lit., wrong sleeping.
Reclining chair, deck chair, chaise lounge; to sleep in a reclining position, as in such a chair.
To doze.
Nightmare; bad dream; to toss, turn while sleeping, have a nightmare.
To have an affair; to sleep with a lover; to commit adultery; fornicator (1 Kor. 6.9).
Trundle bed.

1. To sleep alone.

2. To lie or incline in the same direction, of several; in order, sequence.

3. A maile, before it forms branches.
Same as moe ʻino.
Child's crib or bed.
To go to bed early, to sleep quickly.
Adultery; to commit adultery, fornicate; adulterous. Lit., illegal mating.
Striped, of three colors of about the same width and lying parallel. Cf. moelua.
Bed.
Viscous matter in the eyes. Cf. hūʻalu.
Same as leleiona, shark sucker.
Earth sleeper; to sleep in the earth. Fig., the dead; dirty, shiftless individual.
Rain name.
Hammock, cradle. Lit., swinging bed.
To sleep in a similar way; parallel.
To oversleep, sleep a long time.

Striped tapa; an outer sheet (kilohana) for bed covers, as made by laying a red cloth or tapa over a white tapa in long panels with intervening white spaces, and then beating it into the tapa; striped. Cf. paʻiʻula.
Striped, of two colors of about same width and lying parallel, as of tapa. Cf. moekolu, weke.
Mating of child with its parent, as by Wākea and Hoʻohoku-ka-lani; to mate thus.
Cradle. Lit., rocking bed.
To lie abed sick; bedridden; sickbed.
To lie at death's door; to be sick unto death; to lie in a dead faint.
To live with a mate out of wedlock; spouse. Lit., constant mating. Cf. moekolohe, a short affair, and noho manuahi.

1. Ambush, to lie in ambush; to lurk.

2. To sleep (a rare plural).

3. Same as hōlua, sled.
To dream or fancy; fantasy; dream of a cherished wish, whether good or bad.

1. Mat. Cf. moe, to lie down.

2. Couch, bed.

3. Resting place, position of anything lying down; place for setting (hoʻomoe) a fish net.

4. Same as moe 6.
See ʻahu ʻao.
Fine mat. Lit., fine garment mat.

Very fine mat made of the bracts of hala blossoms (hīnalo).

Table mat, place mat.
Door mat.
Mat made with wide wefts.

Door mat, foot mat, so called because its fibers suggested coconut husk (pulu niu).
Soft carpet of any kind. Lit., velvet (Eng.) mat.

1. Small worm that hides in the sand.

2. Same as pākiʻi, flounder. Lit., sand lying.
Folding cot or bed, camp bed.
Cradle. Lit., rocking bed.
Union of brother and sister of high rank; to make such a marriage. (Malo 54.) Lit., bent marriage, supposedly of a thing bent against itself. Also piʻo 2. Cf. nīʻaupiʻo.
Determined. Lit., lay [the] head.
See "hoʻomoepū":  To place artefacts with the dead. Mai lawe wale i nā mea i hoʻomoepū ʻia, don't wantonly take things placed with the dead. Lit., put to sleep with.
To offer oneself as a death companion. (Na_na_ 133.)

Victim slain at the secret burial of a chief, so as to reduce the number of witnesses; victim who commits suicide or has himself killed in order to show love for a dead chief; death. Lit., lie [in a] heap. (Malo 226.)
Dream; to dream. Lit., soul sleep.
See pahulu.
Cot, small bed, camp bed.
A dream of a canoe, formerly considered bad luck. Fig., bad luck, disappointment; to dream thus or have bad luck.
Bright, clear, shining. Rare.

1. Fully developed, as a flower; spreading widely, as plants; of fine physique, as a person.

2. See koloa mōhā.

1. Redup. of mōhā 1.

2. Redup. of mohā, bright.
Same as mōhalahala.
Sacrifice, offering; to offer a sacrifice. Cf. hai, haiau.

2. To break, as a stick. (And.)
Burnt offering. (Puk. 29.25.)
Meat offering (Puk. 40.29); food offering.
Free-will offering (Kanl. 12.6); love offering.
Trespass offering (Oihk. 7.37); sin offering, offering that a sin may be forgiven.
Wave offering. (Puk. 29.24.)
Offering or sacrifice in fulfillment of a vow, or after a wish has been granted. (Nah. 15.3.)
Wave offering.
Peace offering. (Oihk. 3.3.)
Priest's portion (RSV), heave offering (KJV). (Puk. 29.27.)

Burnt offering. (Nah. 15.8.)

Unfolded, as flower petals; blossoming, opening up; spread, as a turkey's tail; blooming, as a youth just past adolescence; shining forth, as a light; appearing clear, as a thought; evolved, developed; freed or recovered, as from fear, worry, illness.
Redup. of mohala.
Blossoming of flowers or youth.

1. Loose, slack; at ease, unrestrained, at liberty; comfortable.

2. Twelfth day of the month and first of the Kāne taboo, liked for planting flowers because it was believed the flowers would be round and perfect like the moon on this night.

3. To open, unfold, as flowers. Also mohala.
Redup. of mōhalu 1, 3.
Mohammed, Mohammedan. Eng.
See Mohameka

1. A variety of sweet potato, sometimes qualified by the colors keʻokeʻo or ʻulaʻula.

2. A native mint (Stenogyne scrophularioides), more or less shrubby and climbing, leaves ovate, flowers reddish.

A herbaceous leguminous vine (Vigna marina), established on tropical shores of the world. Leaves are three-parted, the flowers yellow. (Neal 467–8.) Also lemuomakili, nanea, ʻōkolemakili, pūhilihili, pūlihilihi, wahineʻōmaʻo.

1. Redup. of mōhio.

2. Plant name. (And.)
Same as moe hihiʻo: see hihiʻo.
Draft, gust of wind.

1. Same as mohihio.

2. Red, as from sunburn.

1. Candidate, as in politics; representative selected to participate in a race, wrestling, or betting contest, champion.

2. Hawaiian rail (Pennula sandwichensis), an extinct flightless bird. See ex., pūhili 1.

3. To unfold, of leaves, especially upper leaf of a plant, as sugar cane, taro (PCP mo(f,s)o.)
See "hoʻomoho":  To stalk; to lie in wait, as a cat ready to pounce; to trail or follow behind, sneak. Kaʻū.
Same as moho 2.
Var. of mohala.
Var. of mahole.
Redup. of mohole.

1. Threadfish (Polydactylus sexfilis). Stages of growth: moi liʻi, little moi, 5 to 8 cm long; pālāmoi (Kauaʻi) or manamoi (Hawaiʻi), about 13 cm; moi, adult, 45 to about 97 cm. On Hawaiʻi the pālāmoi was about 30 cm. This fish was much esteemed for food. A large school was an omen of disaster for chiefs. See ʻehu 1.

2. White birthmark.

3. A native variety of taro, with short, stocky growth, the leaf stems light green, the base pinkish, and base of leaf blade whitish; used for poi and table taro. Also neʻeneʻe. (HP 25; Whitney 69.) This name may be qualified by the colors ʻeleʻele, keʻokeʻo, and ʻula.

4. A variety of sweet potato. (PCP moi.)
To remain long in one place. (Kam. 64:109.)

1. King, sovereign, monarch, majesty, ruler, queen. (Perhaps related to ʻī, supreme. According to J. F. G. Stokes, the word moʻī, king, is of recent origin and was first in print in 1832.) Temple image (Malo 162); lord of images (Malo 173); according to Kepelino and Kamakau, a rank of chiefs who could succeed to the government but who were of lower rank than chiefs descended from the god Kāne (For. 6:266). See ikū nuʻu. The term mōʻī was apparently not used in the Fornander legends collected in the 1860s nor in RC

2. Same as ʻawa mōʻī.
To interpret dreams; dream interpreter.
Churning, roiled, as water.
Far, at a distance; venerated. Cf. kōʻiuʻiu.
Redup. of mōʻiu. Cf. kōʻiuʻiu.
Queen.
Offal, waste matter, refuse, filth.

1. A plant resembling kiliʻoʻopu, a sedge. (KL. line 246.)

2. Same as mōkaekae.
Gratifying to the taste, tasty, as mealy sweet potato. Cf. kaekae.
Mosaic. Eng.

Scattered, littered, disheveled; disorder, untidiness, mess, chaos.

Hard and lacking moisture, as of tasteless bananas, taro, meat, poi.

Mosque. Eng.

To spurt, shoot forth.
Bundle; to wrap in a bundle. Rare.

Short for moʻo kiha.

1. A native tree (Pelea anisata), found only on Kauaʻi, belonging to the citrus family. The small, leathery, cube-shaped, anise-scented fruits, which change from green to brown, are strung in leis; they represent Kauaʻi in the leis of the islands, as designated in 1923 by the Territorial legislature. The large leaves are also fragrant. (Neal 478.)

2. A variety of kava famous on Kauaʻi; it has short, stubby internodes. It is named for the mokihana fruit because of its fragrance.

3. A native variety of taro. (HP 33.)
A small native tree (Pelea hawaiensis) with red leaf stems; when bruised its leaves have a lemony odor; found on several islands. P. h. var.

1. See "Kauaʻi":  name for mānai, needle; to string, as leis.

2. Similar to kilakila.
Redup. of mōkī.

1. To pucker or contract, as the lips for whistling, or the nostrils after diving.

2. To steal something and dash away; to head straight for a destination.

The name for ʻāweoweo seeds.

1. Same as mokomoko.

2. Flooded, filled with water, as a taro patch.

3. Lizard. Rare.
Same as lana, to float. Rare.
Same as mākohi, a taro.
Var. of mākoi 1, 2.
Motorcycle. Eng.
Var. of mākole.
Rough, hand-to-hand fighting of any kind, whether boxing (kuʻi) or free-for-all wrestling; prize fight; a fighter, pugilist, boxer; to box, fight. (PCP motomoto.)

1. Remaining long in one place, stationary; tied to a stake, as in punishment; to hold in one place, as to drown; to be anchored or stationed, as ships in a harbor.

2. Method of fishing pāpaʻi crabs with bait and a net; to fish thus.
Dividing into factions, strife, opposing sides; disagreement.

House set apart, as for training practitioners of sorcery or healing. (Kam. 64:106.)

1. Lizard, reptile of any kind, dragon, serpent; water spirit.

2. Succession, series, especially a genealogical line, lineage. Cf. moʻo aliʻi.

3. Story, tradition, legend (less common than moʻolelo).

4. Narrow strip of land, smaller than an ʻili. Also moʻo ʻāina.

5. Small fragment, as of tapa, not attached to a large piece. Cf. moʻomoʻo.

6. Narrow path, track; raised surface extending lengthwise between irrigation 
streamlets.

7. Ridge, as of a mountain.

8. Young, as of pigs, dogs; grandchild.

9. Brindled, as a dog, favored for sacrifice to the moʻo spirits; streaked, tawny, as cattle; color of a tabby cat. Cf. ʻīlio moʻo, brindled dog, and moʻo ʻīlio, puppy dog.

10. Side planks fitted to the middle section on each side of a canoe hull, technically termed gunwale strakes.
A faint path. (And.)
Fiery flying dragon, as in European fairy tales. Lit., flying fire lizard.
See moʻo-ahi-lele
Land parcel.
Legend or tale concerning the gods; god-like lizard.
Black lizard, gecko. Lit., rock lizard.
Var. of mōʻali.

1. Genealogy of chiefs, history of chiefs, chiefly line of succession.

2. Same as moʻo kāula. Lit., royal lizard.
Trail, road.
Counting, enumeration, recitation.
Budget, sum or list of expenditures or receipts. Lit., money list.
Scorpion (Hoik. 9.3), poisonous serpent. Lit., lizard with bitter tail.
Same as moʻo kaʻalā.
Same as moʻo ʻalā.
Same as kaʻao, tale.
Genealogy of succession of priests; history of the priesthood.
Long-tailed lizard, found on trees. Lit., lizard that strikes trees.
List or succession of commoners, as for taxation. See ex., kumalauā.
A variety of gray lizard. Lit., prophet lizard.
Same as moʻo 1.
Epithet for a sorcerer who practices black magic. Lit., pecking lizard.
Priests of the lineage of Kū, devoted to the worship of Kū.
Genealogical succession, pedigree.
Ancestral genealogy.
Chinese dragon, as in a Chinese gambling game. Lit., sky lizard.

1. Many lizard gods, monsters, spirits, dragons.

2. Having many descendants (Cf. moʻo 8; moʻopuna); female; woman.
Flying serpent, dragon (Kanl. 32.33); viper (RSV), adder (KJV) in Kin. 49.17; great owl (Isa. 34.15); frog (old term).

. Story, tale, myth, history, tradition, literature, legend, journal, log, yarn, fable, essay, chronicle, record, article; minutes, as of a meeting. (From moʻo ʻōlelo, succession of talk; all stories were oral, not written.) Puke moʻolelo aupuni, public records.
Congressional record. Lit., national legislative journal.
Fiction; an invented story.
Short story, anecdote.
Same as mōlio; narrow, small, as a path where only one person can pass at a time.
Sea horse. Lit., horse reptile.
To hear report after report; succession of reports.
Priests of the lineage of Lono, devoted to the worship of Lono.

1. Same as ʻolu, comfortable, cool.

2. Boggy; yielding, as a soft chair. Rare.
Small fish released in patches (mahi) to grow and multiply.
Same as moʻo kāula.
Deadly reptile; dead lizard; viper, adder (Hal. 91.13), asp (Isa. 11.8).

1. Same as moʻo 5; strips of wauke bast beaten together from which tapa sheets are to be made (Kam. 76:113).

2. Ridges (plural of moʻo 7). Rare.

3. Young, of animals.
Spiral design in featherwork. Cf. ʻoni.
Scorpion (Scorpionida); viper, asp (Kanl. 32.33). Lit., lizard with bitter tooth.
Big lizard, dragon (Hal. 91.13), alligator, crocodile.
Same as moʻolelo.

1. Same as ʻōmolemole, smooth. (And.)

2. Bottle-shaped calabash used as a receptacle for fishing gear, larger than the hue wai. (AP)
Adder. See ex., papani, Hal. 58.4. (Heb.
See moʻo pekena
Adder (RSV), cockatrice (KJV). (Isa. 11.8.)

1. Grandchild; great-niece or -nephew; relatives two generations later, whether blood or adopted; descendant; posterity.

2. Short for moʻopuna-a-ka-līpoa.
A fine red seaweed (Griffithsia sp.), consisting of branching hairlike tufts; edible. Common in Kaʻū and Kona, Hawaii. Lit., grandchild of the līpoa. Also aupūpū.
Grandchild of a sibling or cousin. Lit., generation grandchild.
Grandson.
Great-grandchild, as distinct from great-great-grandchild; today a grandchild is sometimes called moʻopuna kuakahi.
Great-great-great-grandchild.
Great-great-grandchild.
Granddaughter.
Stretched. Rare.
Narrow or faint path, track.
Same as moʻo 10.
Same as kuhi-ʻai-ka-moʻo-wahie, a plant. Lit., fragment of wood for burning.
Account, as in a bank; inventory.
Boa constrictor, Lit., twisting lizard.

1. Small, fine, like the filaments of a spider web; tapering into a fine end, as a hair.

2. Dim, as vision; partial blindness.
Melodious, pleasant, of a voice. Rare.
Var. of mouo.
Vile-smelling, dirty. Rare.
Redup. of mōuki. Cf. ukiuki, annoyed.
Buoy; float, as on a fishing net; board or anything to float on; a calm place in the sea where one may float; to lie at anchor.
Same as mouo.
Var. of māwae.
See mōwae
Var. spelling of Moaʻe.
Afar, very far.
See mōwahowaho

1. General name for destructive insects that eat wood, cloth, or plants; cane borer, weevil, tamarind borer, moth (Mat. 6.19); caterpillar in the cocoon stage; germ, bug.

2. Silent; to shut the 
lips and make no sound.

3. Gather together, of crowds of people. Cf. mui, mumulu.

4. A crab (Dynomene hispida).

5. Legendary people of Lāʻau-haele-mai, Kauaʻi, often called Mū ʻai maiʻa, banana-eating Mu. Cf. Nāmū, Nāwao.

6. Bigeye emperor fish (Monotaxis grandoculis), perhaps named for the Mū people. (PNP muu.)

7. Public executioner; he procured victims for sacrifice and executed taboo breakers; children were frightened by being told that the mū would get them.

8. Var. name for the kōnane game. See papamū.

9. Name of a small, yellow bird (no data).

10. The letter “m”.
Var. of mā- 4, prefix indicating quality or state, but less common. See mūʻekekeʻi, mūhea, mūheʻe, mūkiʻi, mūkoʻi, mūlehu, mūʻolo, and others.

1. Before, ahead, forward, in advance, future, front, first, former, foremost, primary, principal; previously, beforehand; oldest, older brother or sister; senior branch of a family; leader, senior partner, senior; more than.

2. Men's eating house.

1. Feeding mouth-to-mouth. Cf. kau, pūʻā.

2. Bottle-necked gourd, as used for drinking.
A kind of caterpillar.
Name of a mythical people; they were not tiny like the Menehune. Lit., banana-eating Mū. Also Mū, Nāwao.
Rusty flour beetle (Tribolium ferrugineum) and its grub. Lit., flour-eating borer.
Bookworm.
Crack or split in wood due to drying.
First offering, as of fruit or fish. Lit., first placing.
Unfriendly, unsocial. (And.)
Front, forward.
Var. of muʻemuʻe.
Bitter.
To shrink away, as in fear, pain, disgust. Cf. ʻeʻeke, to shrink.
Tight-fitting and short, as a dress; drawing upward, receding (probably mū- + a redup. of ʻeke 2 + -ʻi, transitivizer: ). Cf. ʻekekeʻi, short from the ground up.
Var. of mūʻekekeʻi.
Redup. of muʻe.
Tepid, lukewarm; insipid, tasteless.

1. Cuttlefish (Sepioteuthus arctipinnis). Fig., fickle, changeable, unsteady, so called perhaps because of the backward-forward movement of the cuttlefish.

2. Mother-of-pearl lure, usually qualified as below, perhaps so named because the colors of the shell suggested those of the cuttlefish.
Pearl-shell lure named for the branching coral.
Yellowish pearl-shell lure.
Pearl-shell lure spotted like the kīkākapu, a fish.
Pearl-shell lure with three streaks like those in the tail of the koaʻe bird.
Pearl-shell lure with curves suggesting those on the head of the laenihi fish; considered a very fine lure.
Pearl-shell lure with reddish tinge suggesting the red of the heʻe mākoko, a red octopus.
Pearl-shell lure with streaks that suggested the legs of the ʻōhiki, a sand crab.
Pearl-shell lure with reddish tinge suggesting a fading hau flower (pua hau).

1. Same as more common mumuhu.

2. To swarm, as insects or people. Cf. mū 3, mumulu.

1. Assembled, gathered together, an assembly (mū 3 + -i, transitivizer: ).

2. Silent (mū 1 + -i, transitivizer: ).
Pas/imp. of mui 1, 2.
Cramped, as on a narrow seat; to crowd together.

1. Redup. of mui 1, 2.

2. Var. of muli. (PH 114, For. 6:493.)

1. Pas/imp. of muimui.

2. Inharmonious, of juxtaposed colors, as on tapa or quilt.
Swarm of fish.
An annelid worm, resembling a centipede.
Sound of lips popped open; clicking sound, as in urging a horse to speed up; smack, as in eating. Cf. KL. 205 line 687.
Anything jutting or hanging over, as the brow of a precipice; rim (2 Oihn. 4.2), edge, as of a pit; circumference; bare toothless gums.
Same as nakakaka, cracked.
Redup. of mūkā.
A fish of the family Bramidae.
Silent.

1. Chirping, as sparrows (perhaps related to kekē, scolding. Cf. mūkā.

2. To thump. Rare.
Homely, monkey-like in appearance. Cf. keko, homely.

Sucking noise made by pursing the lips and expelling or drawing in the air, as in kissing; to play on the hōkiokio, wind instrument; to squirt water through the teeth; to suck into the mouth, as when lighting a pipe; to sip, as birds sip honey. Cf. mūkā.
To tie; tether. Also nākiʻi, hīkiʻi.
Redup. of mūkiʻi.
Redup. of mūkī.
To thump. Rare.
Redup. of mūkī.
Same as nūkoki.

Pipe lighter, the one who attended 
to the chief's tobacco supplies and lit his pipe for him, a responsibility since the lighter put the pipe into his own mouth. (Kep. 131.)
Sharp, projecting, of the forehead, not considered attractive. Cf. koʻi 1.
Same as nūkoki.
Red, raw, galled, as an open sore; inflamed. Cf. kole, raw.
Redup. of mūkole.
A variety of ʻōmilu, a fish.

1. Cut short, shortened, amputated; at an end, ceased; anything cut off short; short, brief, quick (rare).

2. A measure of length from fingertips of one hand to the elbow of the other arm, when both arms are extended to the side.

3. Broken section of a wave or crest. See lala 1.

4. Same as Mumuku, a wind.

5. Thirtieth night of the moon, when it has entirely disappeared (muku). (Malo 35.)

6. Starboard ends of ʻiako (outrigger booms), hence starboard sides of a canoe.
Weasel. (Biblical: probably derived from the genus name Mustela, hence from Latin.)

Redup. of muku 1.
Probably a kind of triggerfish (no data). Lit., big-mouthed cut-short.
Myrrh. (Mele 4.14.) Eng.

1. Bitter, as herbs; insipid, warm.

2. Rare. var. of mumule.
Same as mule 1. (Puk. 15.23.)

1. Rare. var. of mōlehu.

2. One of three stars in a triangle, the others being Polo ʻUla and Polo Ahi Lani; they may be Alpha, Beta, and Gamma Cassiopeiae. In one account Mūlehu is a variant name for Venus.

1. Bird name (no data).

Myrtle tree. (Zek. 1.8.) (Gr.

Redup. of mule. Fig., unpleasant person, one with a sour disposition.
After, behind, afterward, by and by; last, because, following behind; younger, youngest; follower; thin end of a pearl-shell shank; stern of a canoe, back.

Younger brother, sister, or cousin. Fig., genitals.
River, river mouth; pool near mouth of a stream, as behind a sand bar, enlarged by ocean water left there by high tide; estuary.
Thud-like sound, as of footsteps. Rare. Cf. kamumu.

1. To rinse out the mouth, as with water; to swish water about in the mouth.

2. Silent, mum.

3. Dull, blunt, rounded, as an axe. Same as kūmūmū.
Buzzing, as of mosquitoes, perhaps a higher tone than the mumuhu.

Leaf bud; to bud, of a leaf; soft tip of aerial pandanus root; younger branch of a family.

Name of a star. Lit., heart eager to rule as a lord.
Kind, thoughtful, forgiving, loving, possessed of aloha, beneficent, benevolent, loving heart.

1. Easterly, windward (used in some localities only, as on Molokaʻi). See aʻe 2, 4.

Croup. Lit., gasping croup.
Soft, thin.
Bag nets of fine-meshed nae (netting) consisting of rectangular pieces joined together; a stick (kuku) was used at each end of the foot or lower rope.

1. Rock crevice, as in the sea; full of holes, chinks.

2. Stretched out of shape; yielding, soft, miry, spongy; misshapen; swamp, mire, bog; to stretch.

Redup. of naele, crevice. (And.)

1. Var. of nāhelehele.

2. Rotten, as timber. Rare.
Redup. of nae 1.

1. All species of native genus in the daisy family (Dubautia), which are shrubs or small trees with narrow leaves and small yellow, orange, purple, or white flower heads borne in large cone-shaped clusters. (Neal 845.) Also hanupaoa, hina-ʻai-ka-malama, neʻineʻi.

2. Fragrant, as the naʻenaʻe bloom. (But cf. nae, fragrant.)

3. Design on outer sheet of a sleeping tapa.

4. Fish of surgeon family (Acanthurus olivaceus).

5. Quick, alert.
Redup. of naele 2.
A kind of naʻenaʻe (Dubautia paleata), from Kauaʻi, with large round flower heads, each head with 25 or more light yellow becoming purplish florets. Lit., white-flowered naʻenaʻe.
A kind of naʻenaʻe (Dubautia laxa). Lit., yellow-flowered naʻenaʻe.
A kind of naʻenaʻe (Dubautia raillardioides) from Kauaʻi, with white to purplish flowers. Lit., red naʻenaʻe.
Severe asthma.
A disease, accompanied by shortness of breath (nae). Cf. waiʻōpua.
Var. spelling of nae ʻoaikū.
Same as nae 3.
Same as nae ʻoaikū.

1. Bent, curved, bowlegged.

2. Union of a chief with his half-sister; their offspring was entitled to the kapu noho; to take part in such a marriage. (Malo 55; Kamakau 64:9–10, 22.) Later naha was changed to mean what Malo calls hoʻi.

1. Cracked, broken, as a dish; smashed to bits, as masonry; to act as a purgative; to split; loss of virginity. See ex., koʻokā.

2. To blot out from sight.

1. Torn, rent; tear; to rip or tear (said figuratively of emotions). See hae 3. (PCP ngasae.)

2. Branching out, as a family.

Redup. of nahā.
Redup. of naha 1.
Redup. of nahā.
Redup. of nahae.

A shell (Brachidontes crebristriatus). Lit., small nahawele.
Rare var. of nahenahe.
Snake.

Rattlesnake. Lit., tail-sounding snake.
Forest, grove, wilderness, bush; trees, shrubs, vegetation, weeds. Cf. hoʻomakanahele.

Nettle. (Isa. 34.13.) Lit., itching plant.
Soft, sweet, melodious, as music or a gentle voice; soft, as fine cloth; softly blowing, as a gentle breeze; gentle-mannered, soft-spoken, suave.

1. paucal article. Some, few, the, the little (contraction of nā, the, and wahi, little). See ex., pōkaʻakaʻa 2.

2. The fires (contraction of nā ahi, as in the name Nāhi-ʻenaʻena).
Constellation of the Big Dipper. Lit., the seven.
Blundering, confused, perplexed, wandering off the course; careless, awkward.

Hollow, as a cleft where fish hide; deepset, as eyes of a starving person; eye sockets.

See Māhana.
Constellation of five stars forming a circle; they are said to be near Nā-hiku, the Big Dipper. Lit., enclosure stars.
To flee, of several; to run away; gone away (2 Sam. 23.9).

1. Redup. of naholo. (PNP ngaasolosolo.)

2. Name of a star, perhaps Venus.
Redup. of naho.

1. To bite; to have a tendency to bite, as a dog; to sting, as beating rain; pain, as of stomachache or of childbirth; bite.

2. Inexplicable bruise seen on the body, believed caused by the ghost of a living person who was about to die. Also nahu akua. (Na_na_ 156–7.)

1. Pas/imp. of nahu. See ex., ʻapoa.

The Pleiades. Also Nā-huihui-a-Makaliʻi, the clusters of Pleiades.
Labor pains. (Mika 4.9).
Fattened, as a dog for offering.
Bite.

To bite into with relish.

2. To strive to obtain, endeavor to examine or understand.
A rare transitivizer. Cf. hili, to wander, and hilinaʻi, to believe; pī, to sprinkle, and pīnaʻi, to fill a crack; ..
Insecurely tied. Rare.
Same as the poss.
Porpoise, dolphin. (KL. line 138).
To add to, join to. Rare.
To remove, take out. Rare.
To refuse to see, especially a relative or friend; to disown.
Knight. Eng.

Same as nāʻīʻike.
Similar to ʻaikola, hoʻonaʻaikola.
Conquering, endeavoring, etc. Cf. naʻi 1, 2.
Rare var. of nanai and nānai.

1. Redup. of naʻi 1, 2.

2. Crabbed, bitter, cross, of sour disposition; morose; ill-disposed; opposing. Rare.

3. To shorten, to make short. Rare.

4. Similar to pīnaʻi 1. Rare.

5. Variety of fish (no data).
Contest in urinating by small boys. Lit., urine striving.
Same as naʻinaʻi mimi.

1. Pinworm, as in the rectum; white specks in feces; larvae, as of mosquitos; worm in dung or in taro. See pala naio. (PCP ngaio).

2. Inferior taro left in the field after the crop is removed.

3. The bastard sandal-wood (Myoporum sandwicense), a native tree, with hard, dark yellow-green wood, scented like sandal-wood. Leaves are narrow-oblong, pointed, grouped at branch ends; flowers are small, pink or white; fruit, small, white, round. (Neal 791). Cf. ʻaʻaka.

4. Name of a seaweed.
Dung-eating pinworm, said contemptuously of slanderers.

A native variety of taro, with long, blackish leaf stem; blades large, dark-green; grown in uplands, valued for its red poi. (Whitney 48; HP 25). Also ʻeleʻele and also qualified by the colors ʻeleʻele and ʻulaʻula.
Mosquito larvae.

1. To quiver, quake, tremble, shake, as jello or as with cold or fear; shaky, unsteady, shivering, shaking.

2. To crack open, as earth from the heat; cracked and peeling, as the skin of one who has drunk kava to excess.

3. A land shell (Thaumatodon nesophila).

4. A sea creature. (Perhaps PPN ngata).

A tropical American shrub (Brugmansia candida), known as the angel's trumpet; it bears white, trumpet-shaped, pendent flowers to about 25 cm long. Though flowers and leaves are poisonous to eat, the plant is grown for its high ornamental value. (Neal 748–9.) Lit., earth-gazing. Cf. lāʻau hānō.

To pull away from; contrary, disdainful (perhaps from nanā, surly, and huki, pull).

The four o'clock (Mirabilis jalapa), from tropical America, a shrubby herb with fragrant, red, white, yellow, or striped flowers, opening in late afternoon, and used by Hawaiians for leis in the evening. The plants have medicinal properties. (Neal 335–6.) Lit., evening beauty. Also pua ahiahi.
Allamandas with large yellow flowers (Allamanda cathartica and some varieties), from Brazil, ornamental climbing shrubs. Also lani aliʻi. (Neal 687.) Lit., chiefly beauty.
An indigenous ʻoʻopu fish, Awaous genivittatus.

An everlasting or strawflower (Helichrysum bracteatum), from Australia, an annual, 30 to 90 cm high. The conspicuous parts of the daisy-like flowers are the many overlapping white or yellow to red scaly bracts, which are long lasting. Lit., everlasting beauty. Also pua pepa. (Neal 836–7.)

1. Redup. of nani 1.

2. Same as nalinali, to gnaw.
Soft stone used in making lūheʻe, squid-fishing sinkers. (Malo 19.)
Same as wilelaiki. Molokaʻi.
A kind of Torenia (T. asiatica), a blue-flowered ornamental annual, belonging to the snapdragon family, used in leis. (Neal 759.)

A native violet (Viola kauaensis) found only in high bogs on Kauaʻi and on Oʻahu. The plants are 10 to 20 cm tall, with few broad leaves and one or two white or pale-blue fragrant flowers. Lit., Wai-ʻaleʻale beauty. Also kalili, liliwai, pohe hiwa. (Neal 591.) See waioleka.
Var. of nalo 1.
Var. of nonō.
A dark-red or purple seaweed, said to be same as nanea.
Var. of nalowale.

1. Var. of nalulu.

2. Rising, as smoke. Rare.

1. Ripple; ridge, as of twilled cloth or a tapa beater; groove; streak on tapa; grain of wood or stone; thread of a screw; crevice, as in rocks; grooved. See nao-hoʻopaʻi.

Kind of endemic ʻoʻopu or goby (Sicydium stimsonii); so called because it is said to cling (pili) to stones; used in weaning and housewarming ceremonies so that luck will cling (pili). Called nōpili on Kauaʻi.
Mashed soft, as finely pounded poi that is free of lumps; glutinous, gluey; dented, as by hammering.

Cavity, hollow, rut, depression; armpit; hollow at the juncture of the wing with the body of a fowl; to sink, go down, set (of the sun), to enter or sink into out of sight. Cf. poʻo, depression.

To chew, munch, masticate, gnash the teeth; grinder, as of a sugar mill; feed dog on sewing machine that holds cloth at the needle. Fig., surly, full of hatred, as eyes. Cf. mama, to chew without swallowing, as kava.

1. Same as nānū

Sighing deeply; to prolong the breath, especially in a children's game at Kona: children would make a prolonged u-sound just at sunset, believing that the sun would not set as long as they held their breath; to play nāʻū. Hāʻule naoa ka wai a ke kēhau, ke nāʻuā lā nā kamaliʻi (chant for Ka-mehameha II), the water of the kēhau mist falls rippling as the children play nāʻū.

5. Variety of fish (no data).

1. Sudden shower; showery; to shower. See ex., haehae 2.

Native species of shrubs (Scaevola) found in mountains and near coasts, conspicuous for their white or light-colored flowers that look like half flowers. (Neal 819–21). (PCP naupata.)

The beach naupaka (Scaevola taccada), a spreading, succulent shrub found on coasts of tropical Asia and some islands of the Pacific. Flowers are white and may be streaked with purple. The berries are white and about 1.3 cm long, looking like hailstones. (Neal 820–1). Also huahekili; aupuka (Niihaw).
Same as naupaka kahakai.
All mountain species of naupaka. (Neal 819–20). Cf. ʻohe naupaka.

Weak, feeble, infirm, limp, frail; weakness, feebleness. Cf. hāwali.

Same as neo, ʻōnea. (PCP nea).
Same as neoneo, ʻōneanea.

Moving along little by little or by fits and starts; to step, march, creep, hitch along; to push along, as work; to squirm.
To creep along, as a child or octopus. Lit., octopus hitch.
To retreat, move backward; to back up, as a car (less used than peki).
To advance, go forward, progress.

Movement, moving.

1. Redup. of neʻe.

2. A native variety of taro. Also moi. (HP 33, Whitney.)

1. Redup. of neʻeu. See ex., wahi 2.

2. Stative verb showing superlative or comparative degree.
To move as a whole or unit; moving or working together in unison; spreading all over, as a lava flow or vine; combined, united; swarming; flank movement.

1. To rustle, as leaves or the sea; rumbling; groping with the hands, as in searching.

2. Taffeta, so called because it rustles (nehe).

3. Same as kī nehe (Bidens pilosa); young plants, just before flowering, are cooked for tea. Also kī, kī pipili. Cf. koʻokoʻolau 2.

4. Native shrubs and herbs (Lipochaeta spp.) in the daisy family, with yellow flowers. (Neal 840).

5. Some kinds of pond scums (Spirogyra spp.), fine fresh-water algae, consisting of rows of single-celled filaments, each cell containing ribbonshaped spirals. Also limu kala wai, līpalaʻō, līpālāwai, palaʻo, pālāwai.
Gaseous condition of the digestive tract, occasionally audible; to belch.

Yesterday (usually preceded by locative particle i and not air article; ).

Play language, and to use the play language with order of syllables of most words reversed, as nehiwa from wahine, or as in this example: ʻohe uʻo kemakema iā eʻo, for ʻaʻohe oʻu makemake iā ʻoe, I don't like you. Also wehiwa.
Var. of nahoa.
Anchovy, a fish (Stolephorus purpureus), used for eating and to chum bonito. This name may be qualified by the terms kū lani, maoli, pākiʻi, pala. See ex., pōʻieʻie.
Same as lehulehu.

1. To rumble, as an earthquake; sighing, soughing, as of the wind; indistinct sound, as of distant shouting. See ex., nākolo.

2. Same as kōʻeleʻele, a seaweed; according to Reed 116, same as limu uaua loli.

3. occurring in several positions with several meanings.

similar to kēia, this, but mostly Biblical.

1. To chirp, as a cricket; to croak, as a mudhen; crying, as in distress; whimpering, as a sleeping infant; rumor, gossip; to be attracted to; cherish, think of, as with affection. Cf. hōnēnē; nē, fretting; nēnē hiwa. ʻO nā kānaka Hawaiʻi, he poʻe makeʻe haku, he poʻe nēnē ʻili kapu, the Hawaiian people are people who cherish their lords, people constantly thinking of the sacred skin [of chiefs].

2. Hawaiian goose (Nesochen sandvicensis), 
protected and rare on Maui and in Hawaiʻi uplands (down to 40 at one time and about 1,000 in 1978).

3. Mat pattern: two vertical rows of triangles, with the bases below, and the apices touching the bases above.

4. A variety of ʻawa, stems green with dark-green spots. Also kuaʻea.

5. Same as ʻai-a-ka-nēnē, a plant. (Neal 803.)

6. Probably same as nēnē ʻau kai.
Sea gull, rarely seen, so named because of its resemblance to the Hawaiian goose, nēnē. Lit., sea-travelling goose.
Var. of nanea.
Redup. of neʻe, but less used than neʻeneʻe; low-growing, spreading, creeping, as a ground vine.

Prized, beloved, precious.
Warped, bent out of shape. Cf. hū, swollen.

2. Ramrod

3. Billow. Rare.

A true jew's harp, made of a thin strip of wood, about 10 cm long and 2.5 cm wide, with a coconut midrib (nīʻau) or bamboo strip lashed lenghtwise; played something like the ʻūkēkē.
Offspring of the marriage of a high-born brother and sister, or half-brother and half-sister. Lit., bent coconut midrib, i.e., of the same stalk.
Broom straw. Lit., broom (Eng.) coconut-leaf midrib.

To keep asking questions; inquisitive, curious, plying with frivolous questions (often used in pejorative sense, as of a busybody asking things that do not concern him); to quiz, pump; question. 1. The coconut (Cocos nucifera), a common palm in tropical islands of the Pacific and warm parts of eastern Asia; coconut meat or oil. Hawaiians used all parts of the tree. (Neal 119–2l.) Coconut water and coconut cream (the white liquid squeezed front ripegrated coconuts) were both called wai niu and wai o ka niu. In For. 5:596 niu ā wali was translated ‘milk of the coconut’.

2. Spinning, whirling, dizzy. Cf. niniu, niua, niuniu, make ulu niu.
Pas/imp. of niu 2, with connotations of niuniu, niniu.

Somewhat dizzy; sad, unlucky. Cf. niua.

Man-eating shark, Carcharodon carcharias; any Hawaiian shark longer than 3.5 m is probably a niuhi. Catching niuhi was the game of chiefs; it was a dangerous sport and special techniques were used. Its 
flesh was taboo to women. See ex., holopapa 2, kāpapa 2.ufi, PEP niufi.)
A variety of coconut, with husk of fruit dark green when mature and shell black. Used ceremonially, medicinally, and for cooking. (HP 190.) Lit., dark.
A variety of coconut, with very numerous small, sweet fruits. Lit., coconut with many fruit.
Same as niu ʻōkaʻa.
Date palm. Lit., foreign coconut.
A disease characterized by loss of hearing and dizziness, perhaps Ménière's disease. Lit., dizzy [and] deaf.
Stop talking! See niu 1. Lit., coconut-pudding.
A variety of coconut with fruit reddish and shell yellow, used in many ways, but not ceremonially or medicinally. (HP 190.) Lit., yellow coconut.

Native geraniums (Geranium spp.), shrubs and small trees found only at high altitudes in Hawaiʻi. They have small, ovate, green or silvery leaves, edged or tipped with teeth, and reddish or white flowers. Lit., cold dwelling. Cf. hinahina 4.
To rule; a reign, ruler.
House occupant, owner, sitter, appointee, legatee; to act in such capacity; fig., ashes. See ex., ʻimi hale 1.
To be unemployed, inactive; to sit alone.
To sojourn briefly and then go on elsewhere; to travel with brief stopovers.

intensifying part. (nō + hoʻi).

The yellow oleander or be-still tree (Thevetia peruviana), an ever-blooming shrub or small tree from tropical America, with long narrow leaves and yellow funnel-shaped flowers. All parts of the plant are poisonous to eat. (Neal 693.) Lit., be still.

Couch, divan.
Residence, dwelling, seat, mode of life, existence, relationship.
A pretense to knowledge or skill; bluff, false front. Also poupou noho niʻo, which Emerson (Malo 73) translates ‘tale-bearing’.

1. Scorpionfish (Scorpaenopsis cacopsis and other scorpaenids) with poisonous spines. The fish is edible.

2. A prostrate, hairy perennial (Tribulus cistoides), found on coasts of tropical regions around the world. It has spiny dry fruits, yellow five-petaled flowers; each leaf has about twelve leaflets. (Neal 477.) Also nohunohu.

3. A native variety of taro. Also nohu ʻeleʻele, mākoko. See ex., hanoa.

To ask for something, request, solicit, appeal, apply, make a motion, move, propose, plea; proposal, request, petition, motion (in documents of the 1860s, often preceded by the article ke). Cf. nīnau, to ask a question, noinoi, nonoi.

Noddy tern (Anous stolidus pileatus), larger than the tern, noio; sooty, except top of head, which is light gray. The name is possibly from noio kōhāhā, plump noio.

1. The Indian mulberry (Morinda citrifolia), a small tree or shrub in the coffee family, a native of Asia, Australia, and islands of the Pacific. Leaves are large, shiny, deep-veined. Many small flowers are borne on round heads, which become pale-yellow unpleasant-tasting fruits. Formerly Hawaiians obtained dyes and medicine from many parts of the tree. (Neal 804.) See kōhi 1, pūhai.

2. Troubled, agitated, perplexed, confused.

3. Same as ʻānoni, to mix. Cf. manoni. Rare.

4. Poor appetite, as of an invalid; to take food unwillingly. Rare.

1. Big, large, great, greatest, grand, important, principal, prime, many, much, often, abundant, bulky; plenty, a lot, maximum, most, size, number, amount, bulk, volume, magnitude, quantity, dimension, extent, area, entirety, greater part, enough, sufficiency. Before a noun, nui may mean ‘group’, as nui manō, group of sharks, or nui manu, flock of birds. Cf. ʻano nui, haʻanui, hapa nui, mea nui, nui kino.

2. Name of a star (no data).

Awry; twisted to one side, as a mouth; crooked, as a bill. See ex., hoʻolehelehe kiʻi.
New Zealand. Eng.
Snub-nosed, homely, of facial features; pugnosed. Cf. kokikoki, mūkoki.

1. Beak, snout, tip, end; spout, beak of a pitcher; mouth or entrance, as of a harbor, river, or mountain pass or gap. See idioms, hapahapai and huapala 2.

1. Group of Hawaiian honey creepers (Hemignathus lucidus lucidus, H. l. hanapepe [endangered sp.], H. l. affinis [endangered sp.]) with long curved upper mandible and shorter lower mandible of the beak, with subspecies on Kauaʻi (hanapepe), Oʻahu (lucidus), and Maui (affinis), and a closely related endangered species (Hemignathus wilsoni) on Hawaiʻi. Plumage is brownish-green on the back, yellow-green below. The Hawaiʻi species is also called ʻakihi poʻo lāʻau. Cf. ʻakialoa, ʻiʻiwi. Lit., hunched beak.

2. Protruding lips; to pout the lips. Fig., to speak evil of others, do them evil.

1. To answer, reply yes, agree, say, talk; halloo, yes (in reply); tinkling, tolling, or chime of a bell; resonance, as generated by the thumping of a gourd drum on a pad; sound of whistling (Kauaʻi); sound of peacocks; to make such sounds.

2. To remain, endure, survive, continue, go on, exist; continuing. See oia, oia mau nō, malu.

3. Food provisions for a journey, especially at sea; sea rations.

4. Sprit of a sail or spar.

5. Short for one, sand, in place names, as Ke-ō-kea, the white sand.

6. Imperative marker, perhaps less emphatic than the more common e. See ex., ʻī 1.

7. Short for the part. iō, as after prepositions.
marking the subject, being especially common before names of people, the interrogative wai, and the pronoun ia.

Same as ʻō- (cf. ʻolalau); pronounced ʻow- before e (ʻoehuehu); the -w- need not be written unless the following vowel is the initial sound of a recognizable base, as ʻowala, to turn over (cf. wala, to tilt). (PCP ko(o)-.)

1. . There, yonder, beyond (usually visible or pointed to; cf. laila, usually invisible and anarphoric; often following ma-, i, mai, ).

2. Any piercing instrument, fork, pin, skewer, harpoon, sharp-pointed stick, pitchfork, fishing spear; coconut husker; sharp darting body pain; to pierce, vaccinate, prick, stab, thrust; to flash, as lightning; to extend; to dip in, as the finger; to reach, to appear; to force a way out; to fall into, tumble out; to tassel, as sugar cane. Cf. ʻōahi, ʻō lima.

3. Similar to kuni ola but with less elaborate ceremony. (Kam. 64:37.)

4. A hula step in which the hip is quickly thrust (ʻō) outward; similar to the kāwelu except that the foot pivots while turning to the opposite direction.

5. To hail, whoop, a hail; (commonly preceded by ke).

6. To fly, as a kite.

7. The letter “o.” Eng.

1. Cretan brake, a fern (Pteris cretica), widely distributed in warm parts of the world, growing wild in Hawaiʻi. Long-stemmed, ovate fronds rise about 60 cm from creeping underground stems, and each frond has four to six pairs of long narrow divisions. (Neal 17.)

2. Var. spelling of ʻōwali 1.
See ʻōali

Maidenhair spleenwort, a fern (Asplenium trichomanes) found on high mountains of Hawaiʻi and also present in many temperate regions of the world. Wiry-stemmed, narrow fronds grow in dense tufts 10 to 30 cm high, the fronds consisting of numerous small, round divisions on two sides of the stem.
See ʻoāliʻi
A native fern (Schizaea robusta). Called haili-o-Pua on Hawaiʻi.

1. Oʻahu and Maui name for a freshwater ʻoʻopu fish (Eleotris sandwicensis) called ʻōkuhe elsewhere. See ʻōkuhe for other names. The name ʻoau is said to be so called because of a tale: a fisherman caught a lot of these fish, but they disappeared; the fisherman called for them and a voice answered “ʻo au, ʻo au” (it's me, it's me) and the fish turned into lizards and scampered off.

2. A cat, so called because of its cry: to mew.

3. A variety of taro.

4. A moss.
See ʻoau
See au 14.

To go faster. See au 3.

Prolonged sound or thing; sound of chanting, vibration, whistle of a train; whistling of a bull-roarer; drawn out wail of an infant; long, prolonged. Fig., to assume a superior air. (Preceded by ke.) Nānā aku ʻoe, ke kūkulu maila ke oe, look, acting superior there.

Twill plaiting, as in hats, mats. Cf. ʻahu ʻoʻeno, hoʻohewahewa.

Taro corm growing from the older root, especially from the stalk called kalo; tender plant (Isa. 53.3), shoot, sucker, branch (Isa. 11.2). Fig., offspring, youngsters (; cf. ʻohana). Also muʻu. See kalo for names of generations.
Native lobelias. Also ālula, hāhā, ʻōhāhā, ʻōhā wai. (Neal 815–8.)

1. Flourishing, fully developed, plump, healthy. See ex., konūnū.

2. Distinct, clear sound or voice. Rare.
Same as ʻōhā, lobelia. (Neal 815–8.)
Same as ʻōhā kēpau.

1. Monkeypod or rain tree (Samanea saman), a large leguminous tree from tropical America, grown in Hawaiʻi for shade and street planting; flowers pink, tufted. (Neal 401–3.) See saying, luhea. (PCP koofai.)

2. A native legume (Sesbania tomentosa), a low to prostrate shrub with hairy, pale leaves and red or orange flowers about 2.5 cm long. (Neal 450.) (PCP koofai.) White monkeypod (Albizia lebbeck) on Niʻihau. Cf. Neal 403.
Imperfectly healed, as a broken limb. Cf. haʻi 1.
The pride of Barbados (Caesalpinia pulcherrima), an ornamental leguminous shrub with red and orange flowers. One variety has yellow flowers. (Neal 432.) Lit., royal ʻohai.
Name given to a kind of sled obtained from Captain Cook; it is said to have had supernatural qualities. (And.)
The sesban (Sesbania grandiflora), a leguminous tree from tropical Asia with pea-shaped flowers about 7.5 cm long and pods to 60 by 1.3 cm. (Neal 449–50.) Lit., white ʻohai. (PCP koofai.)

The royal poinciana (Delonix regia), a legume from Madagascar, one of the showiest ornamental trees in Hawaiʻi because of its bright-red canopy of flowers, which are common and prolific in early summer. One form has yellow flowers. (Neal 430–2.)
The red-flowered variety of ʻohai keʻokeʻo (Sesbania grandiflora var.
Same as the more common ʻolohaka.
To polish lightly, as a spear; a stick for polishing. (And.)

A native lobelia (Clermontia hawaiiensis), a shrub or small tree; the gum was used to catch birds which yielded feathers for featherwork. (Neal 816–7.) Lit., gum ʻōhā. Also ʻōhāhā wai nui, ʻōhā wai nui.
Probably same as ʻohā (perhaps a pas/imp., ).
Same as puʻuhau. Rare.
Green, immature, as fruit. Rare.

1. Same as halahala 1; to grumble.

2. Redup. of ʻōhala. Rare.

1. Family, relative, kin group; related.

2. To gather for family prayers (short for pule ʻohana).
Name of a stroke in lua fighting. Lit., make the cross, is good.
Brood.
To stir, as fire, or earth in a garden. Rare.

1. Swelling, dropsical condition; swollen.

2. Dog's neck. Rare.

Rare var. of ʻōlaʻo, to weed.
