Insulting term for kauā, outcasts; they were likened to dogs (ʻīlio) tied (ʻōhao) and waiting to be baked; similarly kauā wore small gourd pendants as insignia that they were to become human sacrifices.
A kind of lobelia. Lit., cliff ʻōhā.
A fruit tree listed by Thrum (no data).
Water dripping down a cliff as to a pool.
Same as ʻōhā, native lobelias.
A native lobelia (Clerimontia arborescens), similar to ʻōhā kēpau.

1. All kinds of bamboo; reed (Mat. 27.48); flute; pipe, hose, tube; bamboo tube for preserving fish.

2. A coarse, jointed, native grass (Isachne distichophylla), to 190 cm high, with stiff, pointed leaves and open flowering panicle.

3. A native bamboo-like plant (Joinvillea ascendens), with stem about 3 m high, 2.5 cm or less in diameter, unbranched; leaf blades 60 to 90 cm by 8 to 13 cm, pointed and plaited; flowering panicle about 30 cm long. (Neal 166.)

4. A native tree (Reynoldsia sandwicesis), an araliad, with leaves about 30 cm long, each leaf with seven to eleven broad leaflets with scalloped edges. (Neal 652.) The wood of this kind of tree growing at Mauna Loa, Molokaʻi, was reputed to be poisonous, was used for making poison images, and is the tree form of Kapo, a goddess. See kālaipāhoa, kauila. This tree growing elsewhere was not considered poisonous and was used for making stilts, hence it was also called ʻohe kukuluaeʻo or ʻohe-o-kai or ʻohe-ma-kai.

5. A native variety of taro, thriving at altitudes above 450 m; leaf stem light-green, tinged with reddish-brown (perhaps like some variety of bamboo); the corm pink-tinted, making excellent poi. (Whitney 58.) The term may be qualified by the colors ʻeleʻele, kea or keʻokeʻo, ʻulaʻula.

6. Variety of fish (no data).

1. Drowsy, apathetic, as after eating a big meal. Fig., weak, ineffective.

2. Warm, tasteless, as water exposed to the sun.
Redup. of ʻōhea 1, 2.
Sweet cane (Isa. 43.24).
Same as alaheʻe, a small tree.
Octopus spearing; to spear octopuses.
Somewhat lazy. See heha, maheha.
Same as hano, nose flute.
Native bamboo (Schizostachyum glaucifolium) with long green joints, and large leaves. Wood soft, makes best pūʻili, rattles; formerly made into straw for hats. (Neal 62.)
Microscope. Lit., tube magnifying vision.
See kāʻekeʻeke.
Bamboo with short, green joints and large leaves. Wood hard, used for knives, fishing poles, house construction. Introduced from Tahiti. (HP 213.)
Flute. Lit., playing bamboo.
Piece of bamboo carved for printing tapa; bamboo stamp. Lit., printing bamboo.
See ʻohe kāpala
Somewhat modest, shy. Cf. heke.

A native tree (Tetraplasandra waimeae), found only in forests of Kauaʻi above Waimea; about 9 m tall, with few branches, the leaves about 30 cm long, each leaf with five to thirteen large, oblong leaflets, and like some other araliads, with many flowers in umbels. Lit., straggly bamboo.
Same as ʻohe 4.
Similar to helahela.
Small-leafed bamboo.
Dwarf bamboo.

1. A small native shrub (Vaccinium reticulatum), in the cranberry family; it has many branches with many small, rounded, toothed leaves, and bears round, red or yellow berries, which are edible raw or cooked for sauce. Formerly sacred to Pele, to whom offerings were made by throwing fruiting branches into the fiery pit at Kī-lau-ea. Wind-dried leaves are still used for tea. (Neal 662–3.)

2. To move rapidly this way and that or back and forth, as a stick poking an oven; to ram; ramrod. See helo 1, ōnoʻunou, pae 1.

3. A hula dance; the dancer leans over on one side, supporting himself with one hand, and with the opposite foot and arm making a sawing motion; many mele ʻōhelo have sexual import. Also hula helo.

4. General name for Vaccinium spp., found on all islands but not common around Kī-lau-ea Crater. Fruits are edible but smaller than ʻōhelo 1.
Same as ʻōhelo 1. Lit., edible ʻōhelo.
Blackberries.
Pink, rosy, of the color of ʻōhelo berries.
Name of a seaweed.
Flexible gummed rod used for extracting ʻuaʻu fledglings from their holes. Lit., rod for pulling birds.
Same as ʻaeʻae, a shrub.
A native bush (Vaccinium calycinum) related to the ʻōhelo 1 but taller and having larger leaves and less palatable fruit. Lit., ʻōhelo placed on trees.
A native strawberry (Fragaria chiloensis var.
A small native tree (Tetraplasandra oahuensis), found only on Oʻahu; much like its relative, the ʻohe-o-kai, but having oblong, entire leaflets. Lit., upland ʻohe.

1. Weak, as resulting from dysentery.

2. Rare var. of hoʻohemo. See hemo.
Redup. of ʻōhemo.
Spyglass, telescope, microscope. See ex., ʻōhuna. Lit., tube for looking.
A native naupaka (Scaevola glabra and S. kauaiensis), a shrub or small tree of the mountains, with yellow, curved, tubular flowers, about 2.5 cm long.
Same as ʻOlu-ʻEkeloa-hoʻokaʻa-moena, but a guardian of the opposite sex of the high chief or chiefess whose sleeping place was guarded.
Tall and straight, as a tree; precipitous, steep. See hau oheohe.

1. Tall native trees (Tetraplasandra kavaiensis and varieties), closely related to the ʻohe mauka, and found on all Hawaiian Islands. (Neal 652.) Also Reynoldsia sandwicensis (Niihau).

2. Same as pūʻoheʻohe, Job's-tears.

3. A variety of sweet potato.
Same as ʻohe kukuluaeʻo.
Moronic. See hepa.
Siphon. Lit., bent bamboo.
Bamboo fire-blowing tube.
Flute. Lit., flute (Eng.) bamboo.
To sprout, as young seedlings or as a young man's beard; to weed fine young seedlings.
Redup. of ʻōheu; fuzzy.
Delirious, incoherent, as a drunkard.
Redup. of ʻōhewa; psychotic.
Water pipe, hose; bamboo water container.

1. Young animal, usually female; maiden just entering womanhood; youth; youthful growth. See puaʻa ohi, wohi.

2. To peel, as bark. Rare.

3. Shoots from roots, as of the wauke plant. See wohi.

1. To gather, harvest, cull, pick, select; to collect, as wages or taxes; to take away or usurp, as land; to draft, as soldiers; to buy; gathering, selection; bundle, as of taro leaves.

2. To gush, chatter aimlessly and ramblingly, gabble. See hāpuku 2; ʻohikui, puaʻohi, waha ʻohi.
Pas/imp. of ʻohi 1.

1. Two kinds of trees: see ʻōhiʻa ʻai and ʻōhiʻa lehua. (PCP k(a,o)(f,s)ika.)

2. Tomato. See ʻōhiʻa lomi.

3. A native variety of sugar cane: deep-red and green striped cane when young, becoming bronze-red and yellow-brown on exposure (like leaves and flowers of the ʻōhiʻa ʻai, the source of its name); leaves somewhat variegated. (HP 222, 225.)

4. A variety of taro.

5. A red birthmark, said to be caused by the pregnant mother's longing for mountain apples (ʻohiʻa ʻai) and eating them.

6. Tabooed, as food patches during famine, so-called because people did not eat from their taro patches, but from upland ʻōhiʻa ʻai, ti, and sweet potatoes (Ii 77).

The mountain apple (Eugenia malaccensis), a forest tree to 15 m high, found on many islands of the Pacific. It belongs to the myrtle family, has large oval leaves, tufted flowers growing from trunk and branches, and cerise, apple-like fruits. Formerly Hawaiians prepared the fruit, splitting and drying it in the sun. (Neal 636.) Lit., edible ʻōhia.
See ʻāhihi 1.
A rare form of ʻōhiʻa ʻai (Eugenia malaccensis Cf. cericarpa) with white blossoms and white fruit.
Same as ʻōhiʻa lehua except that the blossom is dark-red. Perhaps the name refers to the redness of the ʻapapane, a bird.
Same as hā 7, a native species of Eugenia (E. sandwicensis, Neal 635), reported by Thrum as kauokahiki and by Rock as pāʻihi (Maui).
Same as ʻōhiʻa kea.
Same as lehua hāmau.
Tomato. See ʻōhiʻa lomi.
An ʻōhiʻa ʻai or ʻōhiʻa lehua with white blossoms.
ʻŌhiʻa log dragged (kō) from the uplands to the sea to be made into a canoe.
A native filmy fern (Mecodium recurvuum) with narrow, subdivided fronds, to 30 cm long, growing on trees in damp forests. Lit., standing [on] ʻōhiʻa.
Same as ʻōhiʻa lehua.
A legendary ʻōhiʻa tree that bore only two flowers, a red one on an eastern branch and a white one on the western branch; the wood was believed endowed with mana.
See lehua.
An ʻōhiʻa lehua with white flowers.
A poetic name for ʻōhiʻa ʻai. Lit., voice ʻōhiʻa, so called because these fruit trees were not taboo. Cf. lehua hāmau.

The rose apple (Eugenia jambos), a tree from tropical Asia, to about 9 m high, bearing round, crisp, edible fruits 2.5 cm or more in diameter, which are yellowish and pink and have a roselike odor. (Neal 635.) Lit., rose (Eng.) ʻōhiʻa.
The common table tomato (Lycopersicon esculentum var.

The currant tomato (Lycopersicon pimpinellifolium), resembling the common table tomato but with small round red fruits only about 1.3 cm in diameter. A native of Peru, it has long been growing wild in Hawaiʻi. Lit., ʻōhia in the brush. (Neal 478.)
An ʻōhia ʻai with red fruit.
Similar to ʻōhiʻa lehua puakea but with red flowers. (For. 5:623.)
See hāpuku 2.
A hold in lua fighting.
To listen in order to gossip; to gossip; a gossip.

1. To probe, pry, pick out; to prod, as the earth with a digging stick; to shell, as peas; to pick, as the teeth or nose; to clean out, as the ears.

2. Sand crab, probably Ocypode ceratophthalma and O. laevis.

3. Tapa design.
Crabs found in the open ocean, possibly of the genera Planes or Pachygrapsus (P. marinus). Lit., ocean-swimming ʻōhiki.
Redup. of ʻōhiki 1; to pry into the past, especially an unsavory past. Cf. lāʻau ʻōhikihiki niho.

1. A variety of edible crab (no data). Lit., long-eyed ʻōhiki.

2. Name of a stroke in lua fighting.
Toothpick.
To talk ramblingly.
Somewhat ashamed, shy. See hila.
To collect revenue; revenue collection.
Gathering, collecting; selection. Cf. ʻaupapa and ʻohi, to pick.

1. Shiny, greasy; piece of roasted meat; roast; grease.

2. To roast or broil lightly. (For. 5:277.)
Redup. of ʻōhinu.
Gusty, windy; to let wind. Fig., uncertain, vague, flighty. Cf. hihio.

1. To grow vigorously, flourish; young shoots, as of wauke (Kam. 76:110) or from natural layering of olonā branches on fallen trunks.

2. To show, of wood grain.
Redup. of ʻohi 1, 2. (PCP ko(f,s)iko(f,s)i.)
Redup. of ʻohia.

1. Tipsy. Cf. kāhiʻo.

2. A seaweed.
Var. of ʻōhepa.
Same as puaʻohi, to chatter.

1. Same as ʻōhiki; to dig up the past, especially past sins of others.

2. Stick used as a needle in thatching; to thatch thus.

1. Redup. of ʻōhiʻu.

2. Var.. name for blue uhu, parrot fish, so called at Ka-wai-hae, Hawaiʻi.
Toothpick. Lit., probe tooth.
Bundle of wauke bark.

1. Hair of the head; leaves of plants; fronds of ferns (see ex., ʻūpalu); to leaf out, sprout. Cf. lauoho.

2. To call out, cry, yell; outcry; to leap up, as startled birds.
Pas/imp. of oho 2; enthusiasm; enthusiastic, delighted, pleased; enthusiastic acclaim.
Wig, switch. Lit., added hair.
Same as āholehole, a fish. Rare.
Same as holi 1, 2.

1. Abundant, luxuriant, as plants or hair tresses; lush.

2. Name of a tapa design.
Same as homa 1–3.
Slightly offensive odor, as of bog, marsh. Cf. honohono.
Redup. of oho 2; to acclaim.
To begin to form, of tubers (Kep. 87). Rare.
Mist, fog, vapor, light cloud on a mountain; adorned as with leis.

Swelling, as of the sea, especially a small comber that rises without breaking, but of sufficient strength to speed a surfboard; protuberance, bump on the head; hillock, knoll, elevation; to swell, rise in a lump, protrude; to rise, of a wave before it breaks.

1. Retainers, dependents, servants, inmates, members (of a family), visitors or sojourners in a household; passengers, as on a ship.

2. Young of such fish as hīnālea, humuhumu, kala, kūpou, manini, pualu, uhu; also the ornate wrasse (Halichoeres ornatissimis). 
Cf. ʻāhua.

3. To slide, slip, ricochet, glance, as an arrow.
Same as palapōhaku, young of manini.
Young of the fish kala.
Second growth stage of manini, with stripes. Lit., striped young.
Cabin (Eng.) passenger.

Young of the fish humuhumu. Lit., pig excrement young; said to be so called because of the tale that the demigod Kama-puaʻa disguised himself as one of a school of humuhumu; when Peleʻs family caught some of the humuhumu he appeared as a human and taunted them as grasping his excrement.
Earliest growth stage of manini, which is transparent.
Young fish feeding on līpoa, a seaweed.
Young, probably of ʻāwela, a fish. Lit., big-toothed young.
Deck passenger.
Young, probably of ʻāwela, a fish.
See palapōhaku, manini young.
Young of uhu, parrot fish. Fig., a clever person who gets away with mischief. Lit., slippery young.
Same as ʻōhua palemo. Lit., big-scaled young.
To twist, as in pulling out a tooth; to extract, pull out. Rare.

1. Somewhat cool. See huʻihuʻi.

2. Redup. of ʻōhuʻi.
Same as huku.

1. Bald; bald person.

2. Defeated without getting a single score, whitewashed, skunked; loser in the card game build.
Meeting point of receding and incoming waves. Rare.
To feather out; to grow, especially of vines growing from discarded or broken bits of sweet potato; watery and of poor quality, as such potatoes.
Seal hunter; to spear seals. Lit., spear fur.
Hairy (of body hair), shaggy.
To grumble, complain, find fault, conspire, plot; conspiracy. Cf. ʻōhumuhumu.
Redup. of ʻōhumu; to relate one's woes, as to a sympathetic friend.
Conspiracy or plot to rebel.

1. Secret, hidden thing. See huna 2.

2. Same as ʻōhune 1, 2.

1. Skin rash.

2. Small goby. See ʻōlohe 6.

3. Same as hune, tiny.

4. A kind of seaweed.
A heat rash, prickly heat.

1. Redup. of ʻohu.

2. White tapa with black dots and figures.
Redup. of ʻōhū.

1. To move; to turn sideways, as contemptuously; to slouch along, gyrate along; to pull away, as in anger; motion of leisurely swaying (less common than oioi). Cf. -oio, oioi.

2. Same as ō 2, oia.
Var. spelling of ōwī 1–3.

1. Sharp, acute; sharpness; a sharp sign in music which raises the pitch of the following note a semitone.

2. Best, superior, superb, main, prominent, exceeding; to exceed, excel; left-over, extra, remaining, above, odd.

3. Same as ʻoiai 1, 2 but rare.
To limp.
Same as ō 2 and oi 2; to keep doing, persevere, continue. See neʻe, oia mau nō.

1. Truth; true. Often used idiomatically to mean this, namely this, namely, thus, that's it, that's right, go ahead; start, begin, go (as shouted by referee at beginning of games). See ʻoia ana.

2. ʻo + ia 1.
Idiom indicating recent action. Just, just now.
Let me see! Show me! I dare you (sarcastically)! (Usually shortened to ʻoiana or ʻoliana.)
It's the same result; regardless.
Is that so! So that's it!
All right, then; so that's it after all. (About the same as ʻoia hoʻi: see ʻoia 1.)

1. While, meanwhile, during.

2. Although.
True; truth, fact; truly, firmly, certainly, genuine, real, sure, verily, authentic; faithfulness (Hal. 92.2). Cf. ʻiʻo, palapala hōʻoiaʻiʻo.
Same as ever, continuing the same, just the same (often said in answer to Pehea ʻoe? How are you?) See ō 2; oia.
See ʻoia ana.
Same as ʻoia hoʻi hā. See ex., ʻoia 2.
See ʻoia.

1. Occupation, trade, job, employment, position, career, service (as religious or military), ministry, rite, industry, business, bureau, customs, activities, department, agency, office; Biblical book of Acts; professional.

2. Tools, utensils. (Puk. 38.3.)

1. Duty or office of chief or king.

2. Book of Chronicles (Old Testament).
Mint. Lit., moneymaking department.
Trade.
Clergy. Lit., pure profession.

1. Educational system, profession.

2. Department of Instruction.
Society of Masons.

1. Priesthood, office and duties of a priest, minister, or sorcerer.

2. Book of Leviticus in the Old Testament.
Registration office. Lit., copyrighting office.
Finance.
See ʻoihana kālā
Department of Interior, in the days of the monarchy.
Commerce, mercantile profession.
Judicial department.
Fire department; job of putting out fires. Lit., fire-extinguishing job or department.
Secret service, department of secret police.
Military service.
Real estate business.
Postal department.
Manufacturing. Rare.
Aviation.

1. Water works.

2. Department (or Board) of Water Supply.
Same as ʻoia hoʻi hā.
To go downwards, as deep sweet potatoes. (For. 6:125.)
Somewhat small, narrow.
Somewhat hot, warm. Cf. ikiiki.
To heave the shoulders, as during an attack of asthma; to wallow, strain; spasm of pain.
Short for ʻōʻili lepa, a fish.

1. To appear, come into view; appearance.

2. Heart (of emotions).

3. Filefish, including Cantherhines dumerili; see below. (PEP kookili.)
Redup. of ʻōʻili; appearing here and there, once or successively.
Squaretail filefish (Cantherhines sandwichiensis); black with reddish-yellow fins. Lit., flag appearing, so called because of top fin.
Prominent, conspicuous, clearly seen.
Said to be same as ʻōʻili ʻuwīʻuwī. Lit., long-necked ʻōʻili.

Fantail filefish (Pervagor spilosoma); yellow with black dots on its body, a diagonal stripe on head; the tail is orange; this fish is seldom seen but occasionally appears in great numbers and by some is considered an omen of the future death of royalty; sometimes they are washed ashore; seldom eaten but sometimes the dried fish are used for fuel. Lit., squealing ʻōʻili, so called because of the noise it makes.
To appear for no apparent reason, especially of premature birth.

1. Seedling; to germinate, sprout.

2. Young, as of ʻōʻio or of eel. (PEP kooʻilo.)
Two-edged, as a dagger.
Name given for a section of a canoe rim, pronunciation unknown. (For. 5:612–3.)
Rare var. of noio, a tern.
See "hōʻoio":  To show off, boast; to assume an air of superiority, as a child who cuts capers; conceited; affectation, conceit. Cf. ʻoi. Hōʻoio leʻa, to show off with delight.
Procession of ghosts of a departed chief and his company. More commonly called huakaʻi pō.

1. Ladyfish, bonefish (Albula vulpes). Stages of growth are: pua ʻōʻio, finger length; ʻāmoʻomoʻo, forearm length; ʻōʻio, adult, 60 to 90 cm long. See ex., halalē.

2. Soft jelly-like coconut flesh, so called perhaps because of its resemblance to mashed ʻōʻio.

3. Kind of braid or plaiting, as in hat bands, so called because it was thought to resemble the backbone of the ʻōʻio.

4. Stone used for polishing and as octopus lure.

5. Long bundle of salt or fish. (And.)
Fork (Puk. 38.3), flesh hook.
Redup. of oi 1; to squirm.
To rest. (For. 5:499.) Cf. oʻioʻina.

1. Redup. of ʻoi 2; superior; a superior person.

2. Full of sharp points, pointed, sharp; thorn; to protrude, stick or jut out.
Redup. of ʻoʻi, to limp.
Redup. of oikū.
Point, peak, cape, promontory, headland.
Resting place for travelers, such as a shady tree, rock (PH 20); to rest.
To chitchat, chirp. Cf. ʻioʻio.
See "hōʻoioleʻa":  Conceit; to show off.

1. Native, native son. Cf. iwi, bone; kulāiwi.

2. Physique, appearance; to appear.

3. Self; own. See ex., pūpū 5.

1. Dregs, crumbs, sediment, hulls, grounds, small bits or pieces. Also ʻāoka.

2. Var. of kumuoka, net.

1. Oak. Eng.

2. Also ota Oats. Eng.

3. See ʻoka kilika.

1. Overcome by emotion, as fear; speechless with emotion. Fig., destroyed (rare).

2. To set a decoy. Rare.
To revolve, spin; to roll, as a mat; a top; a roll; a dry coconut whose meat has detached itself so as to make a rattling sound.
Same as o kana (always used with ʻaʻole).
Same as ʻōkaikai.

1. Large night moth. See ex., ʻāolo.

2. Tendrils of a plant; to grow, interlock, interweave, as tendrils. Cf. wiliʻōkaʻi.

3. Same as kaʻi, procession. See 
ex., ʻeʻa 1.

4. Blossom container of bananas. Cf. ʻeʻa 2.

5. Cords on the mouth of a fish net, as for iheihe fish.

6. Small oblong net connecting two larger fish nets. (AP)
Rough, as the sea; angry, bad-tempered; rough seas (sometimes preceded by ke).
A particular company of soldiers belonging to Ka-mehameha.
Same as hūkākai, insipid.
Follower, as in a retinue.
Redup. of ʻōkala 1, 2.
Oxalic acid. Eng.
See ʻokakalika ʻakika

The silky or silver oak (Grevillea robusta), a large tree from Australia, used for reforesting in Hawaiʻi. The leaves are subdivided like some ferns; the orange flowers are abundant in early summer. (Neal 320–1.) Lit., silk oak. Eng. Also haʻikū keʻokeʻo and on Niʻihau, ʻoka.
October. Eng.
See ʻOkakopa
Coffee grounds.

1. Goose flesh, creepy or shuddery sensation; to bristle, stand up, as hair. See ex., ʻoehuehu.

2. Rough, coarse, as cloth, shark skin.

3. See leho ʻōkala.

4. Same as ʻōkole 2, a sea creature.

5. A rather small red seaweed (Galaxaura rugosa), regularly and densely branching, the branches hollow and marked with rings; not edible. Also pākalakala (Galaxaura spp.)
Wood shavings, sawdust.

1. Redup. of ʻōkala 1, 2; rough, boisterous in manner. See kani 1, bristle.

2. To undo evil influence by prayer.
Watery, as inferior poi.
See kana 2.

1. District or subdistrict, usually comprising several ahupuaʻa; portion, as of food. See ʻoki, to cut.

2. Organ. Eng. ʻOkana wili lima, hand organ.
Organdy. Eng.
See ʻokanaki
Organic (said of the Organic Act). Eng.
Redup. of oka.
A bad odor, as of garbage.
Insipid, tasteless, especially of freshly pounded poi.
Chaff. Lit., wheat sediment.
Same as kāʻhili, haʻikū, gingers.
Octave. (MK 7.) Eng.
See ʻokawa
Rotten, as wood, cloth. Rare.

1. White sand or gravel (contraction of one, sand, and kea, white). Cf. Ke-ōkea, a place name.

2. Hot, as stone heated to whiteness.

3. A bird (KL. line 432, no data).
To place cross sticks, as to block an entrance; cross sticks.
To veer, as the wind; to change, as direction; to eddy.
Ostrich. Eng. ʻAkolika is more common.
See ʻokekelika
Ocher. Eng.
See ʻokele
Muddy.
Ostrich. Eng.
Same as kenikeni, small change.
Redup. of ʻoke. Rare.
Osprey. (Oihk. 11.13.) Eng.
See ʻokepela
Vulture (RSV), ossifrage (KJV). (Oihk. 11.13.)
See ʻokepelaka
See ʻokepelaka

1. To stop, finish, end. Cf. uoki.

2. Extraordinary, wondrous, superlative, much (usually but not always in an unfavorable sense, sometimes with idea: not at all, none, all gone). See ex., kolihana, oki 1.

3. To take effect, as ʻawa intoxication. See ex., oki 1.

To cut, especially the hair (see below); to sever, shear, snip, slit, trim, hew, mow, fell, separate, annul, cancel, divorce; to cut, as cards; to operate, amputate; to excommunicate; a cut, division, limit, operation, amputation; stanza (called paukū today).

1. Pas/imp. of ʻoki, See kaiʻokia.

2. Wind name, Hālawa, Molokaʻi. (For. 5:103.)
Angular, slanting.
To cut only the ends of the hair. Lit., cut tail.
To mutilate.
Orchid. Eng.
An orchid (Dendrobium anosmum). (Neal 281–2.)
Oxygen. Eng.
See ʻokikene
To cut the hair on one side of the head, formerly a sign of mourning.
A variety of sweet potato.
Same as kilo.
See oki 2.
To cut the hair leaving a strip down the middle. Lit., helmet cut.
Divorce; to divorce. Lit., cut marriage.
To mow the grass.

1. Cutting off, ending, severance, separation.

2. Glottal stop.
Redup. of ʻoki; to cut into pieces, prune, chop, slash, carve.
To bob the hair. Lit., smooth cut.
See oki 2.
To bob the hair. Lit., round cut.
Subincision, to subincise; circumcision, to circumcise (a Biblical euphemism, Kin. 17.10; the Hawaiian terms were kahe ule and kaha ule). Lit., cut roundness.
See pohe 1.
To behead.
Forest clearing (term noted in Oʻahu land records).
To cut the throat; cutthroat.
To move ahead of others; to try to be better than others, surpass.

1. . Different, separate, unrelated, another; whole; entirety; a whole note in music; entirely, wholly, completely; altogether, fully, independently, exclusively. Cf. haʻina ʻokoʻa, holoʻokoʻa, kaʻaʻokoʻa, kūʻokoʻa. See ex., kuli 2.

2. To be early or continuing, of time of day.
To form a scab, as a sore; swollen, as tonsils.

1. Redup. of ʻōkohe.

2. Barnacle, such as adhere to rocks, ship bottoms, floating timber.
A variety of sweet potato, said to have been introduced during whaling days.
Whaling; to whale, harpoon whales. Lit., pierce whale. Cf. moku ʻō koholā.
Two-pronged post-European fishing spear.
Stroke in lua fighting.
Var. spelling of okooko.
Filled, as a canoe.

1. Anus, buttocks (less polite than lemu).

2. A sea creature, eaten cooked, perhaps a sea anemone.

3. A kind of birthmark; round, black, and raised higher than the surface of the skin; believed caused by the mother's eating an annelid when pregnant.
A sea anemone. Lit., shrinking ʻōkole.

1. Liquor distilled from ti root in a still of the same name; later, a gin as made of rice or pineapple juice. Lit., iron bottom.

2. Iron try-pot still.
Same as ʻōkole emiemi. Lit., tied ʻōkole.
Rascal anus, an insult chanted by Kama-puaʻa. Also kole kaʻaka.
A play language something like pig Latin. Example: e hesele ana ʻoutou sele ihesele, for e hele ana ʻoukou i hea? Where are you going? [sele is added at random.]. See language.
Same as mohihihi, a vine. Lit., cracked buttocks.
To turn one's back on someone who has aroused one's anger; to walk to and fro with back towards the object of anger; to scorn; one who does this. Lit., moving buttocks.
Marigolds (Tagetes spp.). (Neal 849.) Lit., jutting buttocks. Cf. melekule.
Bustle-style dress. Lit., humped buttocks.
Same as kolo.
To insert, include; to calk, as a ship; to inlay.
Redup. of ʻōkomo.
Automobile. Eng.
Red hot, blazing hot; burning, smarting, as an itch.
See okooko

1. To stand erect, protrude, emerge, hold upright (Nak. 79); to wield with vigor, as paddles.

2. Thunderstruck, taken aback, horrified, agitated.

3. Young stage of kūmū, smaller than the ʻāhuluhulu stage.

4. Live bird used as decoy; to decoy. Rare.
Knuckles. See kuʻekuʻe.
A fresh-water ʻoʻopu (Eleotris sandwicensis), a fish. Called ʻoau on Oʻahu and Maui. Also ʻakupa, ʻapohā, kuhe.
Young ʻokuhe, after the hinana stage.
ʻŌkuhe with yellow tinge.

1. Redup. of ʻōkū 1, 2.

2. Same as ʻōkū 3.
Filled to satiety, as with fat or sweet food; rich, fat. Rare.
Redup. of ʻōkupu.
Plural and frequentative of ʻōkuʻu 1, ʻOkukuʻu ka noe i ka mauna, the mist settles on the mountain.
Somewhat kukule, listless.
Same as ʻokukuli.
Rough, coarse, as scarred or pitted skin; close together; dark and lowering, as clouds. Cf. kumakuma, hākumakuma.
Redup. of ʻokuma.

1. Pommel; canoe end-piece. Cf. makuʻu.

2. Stump; stumpy, blunt, cut off short, coarse.
Redup. of ʻōkumu 2; stumps here and there; uneven, as stubble.
To have a cough, to cough constantly.
Redup. of ʻōkū; to pitch, as a canoe tossed by waves; to rear and pitch, as a horse.

1. A method of digging holes with a stick, prodding the earth to one side, as for taro (Kep. 153); to dig thus.

2. To trip in walking, stumble, make a false step; to err in conduct, go astray morally.

3. A bivalve (Spondylus tenebrosus).
Redup. of ʻōkupe 1, 2.
To sprout, as seeds; to send out shoots, as ti plants; to come forth, as clouds; sprouting, stubbles.

1. Redup. of ʻōkupu.

2. Same as kupukupu, niʻaniʻau; any fern growing on a single stem, as the sword fern (Nephrolepis exaltata).
A fern (Doodia kunthiana) much like Nephrolepsis exaltata, ʻōkupukupu, but hairy. Cf. lauʻiʻi.

1. To squat on the haunches, crouch, sit hunched up: to perch, as a bird; to settle, as mist.

2. Disease at time of Ka-mehameha I, perhaps cholera, and perhaps so called because it was dysenteric, and people were squatting (ʻōkuʻu) much at stool.

3. To swing in aku (fish) on a line so they fall from the lure directly into the canoe.

4. A method of catching birds by gumming artificial lehua blossoms made of leʻie to a tree.
Same as ʻōkuʻu 2. Lit., running excrement ʻōkuʻu.

Life, health, well-being, living, livelihood, means of support, salvation; alive, living; curable, 
spared, recovered; healed; to live; to spare, save, heal, grant life, survive, thrive. (See .) Ola loa, long life, longevity.
See "hōʻōla":  Small piece of tapa; tapa in general (Kauaʻi).
Gurgling; to gurgle.
A weedy raspberry (Rubus rosaefolius) native to southeastern Asia. (Neal 391.) Also ʻākala, ʻākalakala.
A variety of hard taro. Also laʻaloa.
To strike with sticks, as beaters driving fish.
Small cape, promontory.

1. Redup. of ʻōlae; a number of small capes, promontories. Also ʻālaelae.

2. Bitter, acrid; a bitter gourd (rare).
Earthly life, life on earth; to live.
To revive, recover, restore to health, resuscitate, save a life; resurrected; resurrection.
Bible spelling for ola + ai.

1. Earthquake, tremor. See ex., lua 4.

2. Light porous stone or pumice, as used for polishing canoes or for scraping off hair of pig or dog to be roasted.
State of health, constitution.

1. Lean, thin; stunted, as plants.

2. Same as lala 2; to wilt, as pandanus leaves over a fire for plaiting.
Frail, delicate. Rare.
Redup. of ʻōlala 1, 2.
Somewhat lalau; wrong, incorrect; mistakenly. See manaʻo ʻolalau.

1. To glide smoothly along, as a ship on the sea or as a fish slipping through one's hand.

2. Bright, shiny, glistening; brightness.

3. Skilled person.

4. Young stage of hou, a fish.
Redup. of ʻōlali 1, 2.
Long life; completely cured or recovered.
Immortal; to live long.
Nauseating; seasick; nausea.

1. To toast over a fire, broil, warm in sunlight.

2. Var. of ʻōlali 4.
To weed and work the soil, to hoe; to gather, as ʻopihi shells; to extract.
Redup. of ʻolā. See ex., lohena.
To weed, dig, as with an ʻōʻō or spade.
Redup. of ʻōlapa 1.

1. To flash, as lightning; to blaze suddenly, flare up; to rumble uneasily, as a queasy stomach.

2. Several native species and varieties of forest trees (Cheirodendron), with opposite leaves, each leaf divided palmately into three to five (rarely six or seven) leaflets, and with flowers borne in umbels. (Neal 652.) Also ehu, kauila māhu (on Maui), lapalapa, māhu, ʻōlapalapa. Cf. hū ʻōlapa.

3. Dancer, as contrasted with the chanter or hoʻopaʻa (memorizer); now, any dance accompanied by chanting, and drumming on a gourd drum.

4. Name for the āholehole (fish) used as sacrifice for love sorcery (hana aloha), or for sorcery that sends a bad spirit to plague another (hoʻounauna), probably so called because of the desired rapidity of the spirit's actions.

5. Same as ʻōlapalapa 3.

1. Redup. of ʻōlapa 1.

2. Same as ʻolapa 2.

3. Full of ravines, projections, cornices, ridges.
Redeemed, ransomed, saved; to redeem.
Rare var. of hōlapu.
Name of a wind (For. 5:93) on Hawaiʻi (Nak. 55) and at Ka-pālama, Honolulu (Nak. 57). Fig., promiscuous. Lit., coconut-leaf piercing.

1. Eyetooth, fang.

2. Same as hole, to squirm.

1. Not, without, lacking; to deny; zero, nothing, nought, negative; nothingness, nobody; im-, in-, un-. Cf. ʻaʻole, mea ʻole, ʻole loa.

2. For nights of the moon beginning with ʻOle see below and Malo 31, 32, 35. Collectively these nights were called nā ʻOle; they were considered unlucky for fishing, planting, or beginning any important activity because ʻole also means nothing.

1. Conch shell (Charonia tritonis); trumpet; crochet pattern with a design suggestive of a trumpet. Cf. ʻolēʻolē.

2. To talk indistinctly or garrulously.

3. Tapa beater. (Kam. 76:109.)
Same as ʻoliana 2.
See "hooleaʻi":  Old spelling for hōʻole + ai.
Dazzled, bleary-eyed, as one ill or drunk; dazzling.
Cheerful singing, as of birds in treetops. Rare.
Redup. of ʻōleha.
Seventh and twenty-first nights of the month. (PEP Kolekole Tuu Tahi: cf. Marquesan.)
Ninth night of the month. (PEP Kolekole Tuu Tolu.)
Eighth and twenty-second nights of the month. (PEP Kolekole Tuu Lua.)
Tenth night of the month.
Drowsy, sleepy. Cf. mōlelehu.
Same as ʻōʻili lepa, a fish.
Same as lelepā.

Language, speech, word, quotation, statement, utterance, term, tidings; to speak, say, state, talk, mention, quote, converse, tell; oral, verbatim, verbal, motion (in early House of Nobles regulations). Cf. hoʻonui ʻōlelo, hua ʻōlelo, kuʻu ʻōlelo, luna ʻōlelo, mahele ʻōlelo, piliʻōlelo, uwea ʻōlelo.
Not at all, void, not in the least, none whatsoever; of no value, worthless.
Resolution, joint resolution.
Counsel, advice, precept, instruction; to advise, counsel.
Foreign language, incomprehensible lingo; mention of a matter other than the subject under discussion.
Foreword, preface. Lit., word told first.
Mistaken word, slip of the tongue.
Accusation; to accuse, charge.
Encouraging word, slogan.
Affidavit; testimony, as of a witness; evidence.
Curse, defamation; to curse, revile.
Comparison, simile.
Oath, vow, promise, pledge.
Verdict (as of a jury), judgment, decision, resolution, conclusion. See saying, hehikū.
Judgment.
Advertisement, ad, notice.
Acknowledgment.
Joke, witticism.
Reminder, cue.
Figurative language; obscure speech with puns and poetic references; to speak thus.
Figurative speech, riddle.
Stipulation. See ʻōlelo paʻa.
Accusation.
Comment.
Threat; terrifying talk; to threaten.
To speak again, repeat.
Secret language, speech with hidden meaning.
To speak in irritation, sharply, curtly; to snap.
Decree, order, commandment; to order, decree.
Mandate.
Dialogue, repartee, conversation; to engage in such. Cf. kīkēʻōlelo.
Same as ʻōlelokīkē.
Consultation, discussion; to discuss, consult, deliberate.
A play language originated by Hawaiian guano (kūkae manu) diggers in the South Pacific to keep their bosses from understanding; this speech has substitution of forms as well as transpositions.
Term once used (and rarely) for a “language” containing words known only to a few, perhaps priests; not the same as kake; basic or original language.
Ordinance, legal decree, judgment, statute.
See lalau.
Good word, gospel.
Mother tongue. (This name is often used for the Hawaiian language.)
Introduction, preface.
Riddle, parable, allegory.
Proverb, wise saying, traditional saying.
First estimate.
Precept, command, vow, promise, oath, statute (Hal. 119.117).
Joke, jest, banter.
Pidgin English, pidgin Hawaiian. Lit., hard-taro speech.
Word of encouragement, exhortation, commandment (Mal. 2.1).
Appendix, supplement, added words, postscript, addendum.
Defense, as in a trial; to defend.
Wireless message.
Same as lemu 1, 2.
Base section of a gourd.
Vagabond, rover. Lit., rolling backsides.

1. The turmeric (Curcuma domestica, also incorrectly called C. longa), a kind of ginger distributed from India into Polynesia, widely used as a spice and dye in foods, to color cloth and tapa, and medicinally for earache and lung trouble. A cluster of large leaves rises from thick, yellow underground stems, which are the useful part of the plant, either raw or cooked. (Neal 255–6.)

2. Same as lena, yellow.

3. Also orena n. Ash tree. (Heb.

4. A small mountain tree on Kauaʻi (Coprosma waimeae), with yellow wood.

1. Yellow, sallow. See lenalena.

2. Dye made of ʻōlena plant.
Rack or branched post on which wooden bowls or netted calabashes were hung; a coat tree.
See "hōʻoleʻole":  To deny repeatedly. (PCP korēkore.)

1. A small conch shell. Cf. ʻolē 1.

2. Redup. of ʻolē 2; to rant.

3. Wide-mouthed grin, as of an idol; to grin thus.
Redup. of ʻolēhala. Rare.
Same as oleole.
To quarrel or speak noisily, raise a din.
Stormy, tempestuous, agitated.
Same as ʻOle Kū Pau.

1. To turn, as on hinges; to shut and open, as Venetian blinds; to peel off, as shingles in a gale; to upset, overturn, tear asunder.

2. Any kind of bivalve, as a mussel or oyster. See below and ex., maka 
mua.

3. Garden balsam or impatiens (Impatiens balsamina), from southeastern Africa, an annual to about 90 cm tall, grown ornamentally for its pink, red, yellow, white, or spotted flowers. (Neal 539–40.)
Bivalve, possibly Codakia punctata and Ctena bella. Cf. kupe, ʻōkupe.
Redup. of ʻōlepe 1; shutters, Venetian blinds, lattice work (Mele 2.9); diaphragm between chest and stomach (rare). See hula ʻōlepelepe.
A kind of ʻōlepe 2 (Martesia striata); also makaloa.
Any large bivalve, Tridacna.
A kind of ʻōlepe 2 (Barbatia (Acar) divaricata). See pāpaua.
To overturn completely. Cf. ʻōlepe.
A rock borer (Gastrochaena cuneiformis). Lit., big-mouthed ʻōlepe.
Rare var. of ʻōlepolepo.
Somewhat dirty, murky, sullied; to sully. Fig., to offend.
To discard.
Swinging. Fig., fickle, changeable, not firmly established or fixed, variable.
Not at all! Of no interest, value, use.
Redup. of ʻōlewa. Fig., hungry.
Chant that was not danced to, especially with prolonged phrases chanted in one breath, often with a trill (ʻiʻi) at the end of each phrase; to chant thus.
Joy, happiness, pleasure; happy, joyful, gay. Cf. hauʻoli.

1. A common ornamental shrub (Nerium oleander and var.

2. A variety of sugar cane, like lahaina in type of growth and color, but the pith dark-brown and the leaf sheath covered with red-brown hairs. (Eng., Oriental.) Also ʻoleana.

3. Let me see! Show me! Also aliana, inane, ʻoia ana.
Same as ʻoia paha, maybe so. Rare.
Somewhat liliha.
Shiny, sparkling, bright.

1. To bud. Cf. liko.

2. A small tree, possibly Rapanea helleri, Myrsine hosakae (syn.
Redup. of ʻōliko 1.
Somewhat lile.
Shiny, sparkling, shimmering, as moonlight. Cf. hulili.
Withered, stunted, poor, as fruit. Cf. more common mālili.
Redup. of ʻoliko and ʻōliko 1; shimmering.
Arm vaccination. Lit., arm piercing.
To make merry; joyous, rejoicing, merrymaking.
Ordination. Eng.
See olinakio

1. Bright, brilliant, dazzling, gleaming; brightness, glare.

2. Parched, dry.
Redup. of ʻōlino 1, 2; shining, radiant. (2 Sam. 22.13.) E lilo nō ka lepo ʻōlinolino i wai ʻauʻau (Isa. 35.7), the parched ground shall become a bathing pool.
Redup. of oli; chanter.
Redup. of ʻoli; delight, enjoyment. See ex., malakia.
Somewhat liʻoliʻo, dazzling.
Orion. (Ioba 9.9.) Eng.
See ʻOliona

1. Blurred, indistinct. Cf. kōliʻuliʻu, liʻua.

2. Brackish.

1. The olive tree (Olea europaea), from the Mediterranean region, a small tree grown only, ornamentally in Hawaiʻi, where it rarely flowers or yields fruit. (Neal 677–8.) Eng. See lau ʻoliwa. Called ʻoliwa haole on Niʻihau.

2. Same as ʻoliana, oleander.
See ʻoliwa

Air plant (Kalanchoe pinnata, also Bryophyllum pinnatum), a succulent growing wild and cultivated in Hawaiʻi and other tropical countries. New plants develop along the edges of the thick scalloped leaves. The tubular green and red flowers hang lantern-like. The Hawaiian name was given because the first plants seen in Hawaiʻi grew near the beach. (Neal 376–8.) Lit., beach-standing olive.

1. To rub back and forth, grate, saw; a saw (also pahi olo). Cf. hale olo papa.

2. To resound, sound long. Cf. olo ʻawa, olo pihe.

3. Long surfboard, as of wiliwili wood. (Laie 449.)

4. Hill (rare now except in place names, as Olo-kuʻi, tall hill; Olo-mana, divided hill; Olo-walu, many hills).

5. Shelf. Rare. Cf. oloʻewa, olohaka.

6. Large foreign glass beads, said to be so called from a Hawaiian name given to the British ship, Queen Charlotte Mary, which came in 1786 under the command of Captain Dixon; this ship is said to have introduced the beads. Rare.

1. Long gourd container used as a receptacle, as for kava or water; long body of a gourd used as a hula drum cf. heke, ipu). Cf. ʻolo ʻawa.

2. Double chin, sagging skin, jowls, calf of leg; scrotum; wattles of a turkey; fat part under the jaws of an eel; pendant; pendulous; to roll with fat; to sag, hang down.
See ʻolomeka, ʻolomene.

1. Same as maʻaloa, maʻoloa, a shrub.

2. Fine white tapa, said to have been placed over an image during prayers (Laie 467); perhaps a verb to make ʻoloa tapa (For. 6:444).

3. Gift to a child at birth.
Reported as a bird name (no data).
Splashing on rocks, as a rough sea.
Var. spelling of olowalu.
An address to a deity accompanied by an oblation of kava.
Coconut shell cut lengthwise as a cup for kava.
Shelf.
Shelf.
Empty, sunken, hollow, as eyes or cheeks; emptiness, deficiency, deficit.
var. of ʻolohani.
To strike, quit work; mutiny, riot (said to be from Eng. “all hands”).
Cannon. Lit., iron noise. Rare.

1. Bare, naked, barren; hairless, as a dog; bald; destitute, needy.

2. Skilled, especially in lua fighting, so called perhaps because the beards of lua fighters were plucked and their bodies greased; bones of hairless men were desired for fish hooks because such men were thought stronger; also said of hula experts; skilled fighter (Kel. 115).

3. Pale.

4. Sick, as after childbirth.

5. Ghost; image, as in clouds.

6. A small salt-water ʻoʻopu, a fish, found with the ʻōhune.
Redup. of ʻōlohe 1.
Demented, deranged; delirious, incoherent.
Pas/imp. of olo 1, 2.
Same as ʻālohilohi.
To move quickly, as a gust of wind. Rare.
To cultivate, weed. Rare.
Same as ʻulu maika. (For. 4:259.)
Same as hua pōpolo, fruit of the pōpolo.
To rub, grate, run aground, run over (olo 1 + -i, transitivizer: ). Rare.
To move swiftly.
To shake or quiver, as flesh of a fat person. Rare.

1. To roll along, as a wheel; to remove; to transfer, as a debt. Cf. paukū ʻolokaʻa.

2. Stake to which a live rat was tied as a decoy in an owl-catching trap. Rare.
To sound.
Clamorous, incoherent, excited in speech or sound. Cf. holokē.
Cross, gibbet, gallows (Eset. 5.14), scaffolding; ladder made of sticks tied horizontally; crisscross, crossed; bones of a corpse buried with knees tied to breast. Fig., contrary, antagonistic.

1. Same as ʻiʻiwi, honeycreeper.

2. A kind of tapa associated with Nā-pali, Kauaʻi. (GP 8–9.)
Bog, swamp.
Immature olo-kele, bird.
See olokele hōkiʻi
To slide, skid; to saw, rub fast. Rare.
Same as the more common ʻoʻolokū.

1. Broad. Cf. ʻololī.

2. A small flying fish resembling the puhikiʻi.
All right. Eng.

1. Acclaimed, as a chief.

2. Poetic for coconut tree. (Kam. 76:118.)
Narrow. See ex., ʻololā.
Somewhat soggy, as taro.
Var. spelling of oloolo.

1. Dejected, downcast. Rare.

2. . n. Name of a star (no data).
Old man. Eng.
The endangered Lā-naʻi thrush (Phaeornis obscura lanaiensis), and Molokaʻi thrush (Phaeornis obscura rutha).

1. A native shrub or small tree (Perrottetia sandwicensis) with ovate, red-veined leaves, and many tiny greenish flowers and red fruits borne in panicles. The wood is hard and formerly was used with soft hau wood to produce fire by rubbing. It is one of the plant forms of the pig god Kama-puaʻa. (Neal 530.) Also waimea; see also puaʻa olomea.

2. Brown, with darker stripes or spots, of pig or dog.

3. Kind of wauke tapa dyed with ʻōhiʻa bark, hōlei, and coconut water.
Dumping ground, refuse or rubbish dump. (For. 6:373.) Rare.
Old maid. Eng.
See ʻolomeka
Old man. Eng.
Tapering, narrowing; to start to form a crust, as a wound; to go quickly, vanish.
Foreskin (Ier. 4.4; changed to ʻōmaka in later editions of the Bible).
Uncircumcised; prepuce or foreskin cut off in circumcision; bud.

A native shrub (Touchardia latifolia), with large, ovate, fine-toothed leaves, related to the māmaki. Formerly the bark was valued highly as the source of a strong, durable fiber for fishing nets, for nets (kōkō) to carry containers, and as a base for ti-leaf raincoats and feather capes. See ōpuhe and ex., kaekae 1. (Neal 319–20, Kam. 76:44–7, 52–5.) Cord of ʻolonā fiber; flax (Sol. 31.13), hemp, linen; muscle ligament. sinew (Kol. 2.19).

1. Redup. of olo 1, 2; to saw back and forth; corrugated; roiled, as streams.

2. Long and narrow, as a head; elongated, oblong, oval.

3. A variety of watermelon.

4. Rough, as the surface of a washboard.
See oloolo

1. Redup. of ʻolo 2; to hang too low, as a petticoat; to hang loose and long; to hang (as coconuts).

2. To overflow, flood, as streams. See hāʻoloʻolo.

3. To loiter, lag.
Type of weeded taro patch. (For. 5:681.)
Redup. of ʻolokā.
Redup. of ʻolokaʻa.
Redup. of olokē.
Redup. of olonā; fibrous, tough; cords, muscle, ligaments.
Sagging under a weight, overladen, loaded down; a burden. Rare.
Calf of the leg. Also ʻolo wae.
Same as ʻulupā.
Old fellow. Eng. Hoʻokolohe lua nei mau ʻolopala, these old fellows are very, very, mischievous.
To saw wood.
Falling; ruin, overthrow, demolition, humiliation; to overthrow, fall. Rare.
Larvae of dragonfly.
Same as pīʻao 1. Rare.
To cry out, shout, wail.

1. Inflated, billowed out, as a sail in the wind; puffed out, as cheeks of one eating; blistered, as hands from work; mouthful of food or water.

2. A native shrubby violet (Viola chamissoniana).

3. Adze for cutting ʻōhiʻa logs for images. (Ii 42.)

1. A large native tree (Osmanthus sandwicensis), to 19 m high, in the olive family. It bears narrow or oblong leaves, yellowish flowers, and blue 1.3 cm- long fruits. The hard wood, dark-brown with black streaks, was used for spears, adze handles, and digging sticks. Cf. nonohina. Also pua, ulupua. (Neal 676–7.)

2. Lovelorn, heartbroken. (Laie 521.)
To strike, as the forehead. Rare.
Overstuffed with food, an insulting epithet. Lit., sagging intestine.
Space. Rare.
Var. of holowaʻa.
Calf of the leg. Also ʻoloʻolo wawae.
Pāwehe mat pattern listed by Brigham.
Gourd water container.

1. Joint action; simultaneous sounds; din of many voices, sounds, as of horns or roosters; to rush or attack in concert; a group, as of hills (olowalu puʻu). Cf. makawalu, -walu.

2. Storehouse, as for chief's property. Rare.
See olowalu
Var. of ololī.

. Cool, refreshing; soft, supple, flexible, pliant, elastic, slack, springy; pleasant, comfortable, at ease; polite, kind, courteous; coolness; softness, grace, slackness; comfort, amenities; courtesy, kindness. Cf. ʻoluʻolu.
Soft-shelled, as of a crab (pāpaʻi) or lobster (ula).
Same as mana 5, a fern.
. You two.
Short for ʻao lūʻau.
To slacken, ease. Fig., mental relaxation.

Guardian of the sleeping place of the high chief or chiefess (said to be an expert lua fighter and of the same sex as the chief or chiefess). Lit., ʻEkeloa breeze coolness that rolls mats. Cf. ʻohene.
Sagging, drooping, as a potbelly; limp; flabby; soft, as a crab that has shed its shell.
Same as lulelule. Cf. hōlule.
Pas/imp. of ʻōlulelule.

1. Castaway; shipwrecked; storm-beset at sea.

2. Similar to hōlū and ʻōlū, soft.

3. Gourd container, as for bamboo stamps used for marking tapas.

4. Statue, figure, idol. (And.)
Var. of ʻōlulelule.
A lobelia (Brighamia insignis). Also pū aupaka. Cf. ālula and Neal 816.
To shake (lūlū) with fat; one who so jiggles.

Name reported for a minor illness (no data).

1. To strike with the hands and arms, as in swimming. Rare.

2. High officer of the chief. Rare.

3. Variety of mahimahi, a fish (no data).

1. Oven, baking pan; to roast, bake; roasted. Fig., sacrificial victim.

2. To open the mouth, as though to speak, or as a child about to nurse at the breast; to ask indirectly. Rare.

3. Female mahimahi fish; but cf. oma 3.

4. Same as ʻoʻoma, concave.

5. Small adze. (And.)

6. Space between opposing armies where sacrifices were offered; preparations for war; first men killed in war. (And.)
Sickly, weak, ailing, not well.
Redup. of ʻōmaʻi; chronic sickness.

2. Nipple.

4. Hilo name for the makiawa, herring.

5. Belted wrasse fish (Stethojulis balteata).

Redup. of ʻōmaka 1; to leaf out or bud afresh.

Same as male, the young uhu, a fish.
Same as ʻōmale.

Same as ʻōmakamaka.
Same as ʻōmale.
Redup. of ʻōmalu.

Name of a seaweed. Lit., seaweed that wilts easily.

1. To pin on, fasten (same as ʻōmou); to gird or bind on, as a sword (Lunk. 3.16); to tuck in, as a sarong; to sew or baste together; a doubling over, tuck.

To wither, droop; to burn weakly, as a candle. Cf. hōmī.
Saline, salty, as soil near the sea. Cf. miko 1.

To twist, turn, curl; to shape, as a canoe hull; to taper, as a baby's fingers by rolling the tips between thumb and index finger; to spin, as thread; to produce abortion, destroy; abortion, foeticide, drill. Cf. milo 2.
Redup. of ʻōmilo. Cf. train 1.

1. Kind of ulua, a fish, probably Carangoides ferdau, C. gymnostethoides, C. ajax.

1. To suck, absorb; suckling; to gasp (Kep. 116); to evaporate, as water; absorbent; suction tube, rubber nipple.

4. Gourd, as used for a container.

5. Same as alaia, type of surfboard. Rare.

Tapa design. Cf. mōhā, migratory duck.

Lamp chimney.

Var. of ʻumoki, stopper.

4. His, hers, its (o-form, zero class; ).

5. Plural marker preceding the last of two or more things (goods, not people) and usually preceding mau. And., and also.

1. Drunk, dizzy and unsteady; intoxicating; intoxication.

2. Owner, possessor, proprietor; to own. Eng. Cf. ʻona miliona.

Weak, awkward, unskilled. Cf. ʻīnana, kīnana.
Softly fragrant; soft fragrance or perfume, aroma; gentle and sweet, as the eyes or disposition; inviting, attractive, alluring, lovely. Cf. maka onaona, friend.

2. Bad-smelling, as stagnant water; unpalatable.

Name of a Kauaʻi wind. Lit., sand carrying.

Here, local. See ex., ʻaneʻi 1.

Vast, great, without bounds.

Fixed, immovable, motionless, steadfast, established, firm, resolute, determined (this was the motto of Ka-mehameha V and of Liliʻu-o-ka-lani. Lit., fixed movement. See ex., makehia.

1. A spinning top; to spin a top; informal game with dancing and top spinning; spinning, whirling.

2. See ʻami ʻōniu, a hula step.

3. To set, as type.

To ward off clubs, as in mock warfare.

1. Large mackerel type fish (Acanthocybium solandri), to 1.5 or 1.8 m in length; choice eating. Known in Florida and the West Indies as the wahoo.

2. num. Six; sixth.
Delicious, tasty, savory; to relish, crave; deliciousness, flavor, savor. Cf. mea ʻono.

1. The eyeball; center; setting, as of a ring. Fig., eyes. See ex., hehelo.

2. Patch or fragment of a rainbow. (Laie 351.)
Cataract of the eye. Lit., eyeball like fish, so called because of alleged similarity of a cataract to a fish eye.
Black moss found in fresh water (no data). Lit., eyeball of the fish, awa.
Stroke in lua fighting. Lit., rainbow patch that does not move, puzzling the fisherman on a stormy day.
A mother-of-pearl lure that was said to catch fish by day or night without fail.
Pupil of the eye.

1. Same as ʻōlohilohi, ʻālohilohi.

2. A variety of sweet potato.
Red eyeball; red rainbow segment; cloud with red hues of rainbow; variety of red tapa; fig., fury, anger.

Similar to noninoni, agitated, and ʻānoninoni, mixed. See ex., wehiwa 2.
Redup. of ʻono.
Redup. of ʻonou; to force upon.
To shove, push, force into, thrust on; to persuade; to give secretly or underhandedly; to offer in secret. See kui ʻonou.
Same as the bird, ʻōʻū.
To shove or push into something headlong, regardless of consequence. Lit., shove head.
Thirsty; to crave water.
A swelling, protuberance, hill; rising of the surface; bucking; erection of the male member; to swell.
Tainted, unsavory.

Matured, ripe, as fruit; of mature age, middle-aged, elderly; to mature, ripen, or grow old; an adult human, maturity (see ex., ʻeʻelekū). Cf. oʻo ʻole.
To crow, as a rooster; cock-a-doodle-doo.

1. Redup. of ʻō 1; to pierce, lance, poke, put in, insert; to pierce the fetus in the womb with a sharp instrument in order to practice infanticide; to abort; to cut, as to let blood; to hurl, as a spear.

2. Digging stick, digging implement, spade. (PCP kookoo.)

3. A black honey eater (Moho nobilis), with yellow feathers in a tuft under each wing, which were used for featherwork; endemic to island of Hawaiʻi, now extinct.

4. A type of fish, perhaps a swordfish.
The endangered Kauaʻi species of ʻōʻō, honey eater (Moho braccatus); on Hawaiʻi, said to be the name for the male ʻōʻō. Lit., dwarf ʻōʻō.

1. Redup. of ʻōahi.

2. Fire poker or shovel; to poke the fire.
Redup. of ʻoʻe. Rare.
Harrow. Lit., harrow (Eng.) digging implement.
Iron tool for digging, plow.
Plow. Lit., new digging implement, or poking, digging implement.
Stoop-shouldered, bent, as with age.
Redup. of ʻōhū, swelling.

1. Redup. of ʻoi; prickly; sting, as of scorpions (Hoik. 9.10); to protrude, as eyelashes.

2. An inedible seaweed. Also called popohe makaliʻi.
To hurl spears or javelins; sport of spear throwing.

1. Redup. of ʻoki.

2. To take effect, as intoxication.
Steel spade.
A rake; to rake. Lit., scratching digging implement.
A name for the female ʻōʻō, honey eater.

Variety of bird, perhaps the maʻo, thrush.
Redup. of ʻolopū; to change, as appearance. See ex., kohu 1.

1. Two edible, fragile, red seaweeds (Champia sp. and Chondria tenuissima). They melt in fresh water, hence must be cleaned in sea water.

2. Thin, feeble.

3. Rare frequentative of ʻolu.

4. A variety of taro.
Concave; concavity, spout, gouge, flare of a bonnet; oval-shaped chisel; large sharp nose. Cf. pāpale ʻoʻoma.
Leather covering of stirrups.
Same as moa 3.
Same as kūpīpī, a fish.
Same as mamo, a honey creeper. Lit., ʻōʻō with sipping beak.

1. Parsimonious, careful of one's property.

2. A small dipper for bailing, as a coconut shell.
Redup. of ʻoʻō, to crow.
Immature, minor.
Same as ʻoʻoʻō.
Lame, crippled; a cripple, lame person; to limp, be lame.
Trowel. Lit., flat digging instrument.
A plow; to plow. Lit., plow (Eng.) digging implement.
Redup. of ʻope. (For. 5:665.)
Spade. Lit., spade (Eng.) digging implement.

1. General name for fishes included in the families Eleotridae, Gobiidae, and Blennidae. Some are in salt water near the shore, others in fresh water, and some said to be in either fresh or salt water. Varieties 
include bluespotted goby (Quisquilius eugenius) and indigo hover goby (Ptereleotris heteropterus).

2. Name of a wind associated with Wai-heʻe, Maui. (For. 5:101.)
Name for black bass, introduced in 1901. Lit., foreign ʻoʻopu.
A variety of large deep-sea fish said to be related to the ʻoʻopu. Lit., ʻoʻopu of the hāpuʻupuʻu [family].
A variety of fresh-water ʻoʻopu. Lit., red-tailed ʻoʻopu. It is believed that this fish drives other fish away, and hence must be thrown out of a net with an exclamation of disgust.
Same as ʻoʻopu hiʻu kole.
Strong concoction made of green gourd and kukui nut, used as an enema.

Swellfishes, puffers, balloon fishes, globefishes (Arothron meleagris and Chilomycterus affinus); not related to ʻoʻopu; these fish contain poison which is sometimes removed by those who like the flesh, especially the Japanese; the poison is sometimes fatal; considered by some an ʻaumakua. Lit., gourd ʻoʻopu. Also makimaki.
Same as pilikoʻa, a fish.

A native variety of taro, so named as the leaf stem is similar in coloring to the salt-water ʻoʻopu (the fish), being yellow-green with dark-purple markings. The corms are used mainly as table taro, the leaves often for lūʻau. Grown chiefly in uplands of Kona, Hawaiʻi. The name may be qualified by the colors keʻokeʻo and ʻulaʻula.
Same as poʻopaʻa, a fish.
Var. of ʻoʻopu, a fish.
Var. of ʻoʻopu kāniʻo.
A brackish-water ʻoʻopu. Lit., striped ʻoʻopu.
A variety of ʻoʻopu.
Same as ʻoʻopu hue.
Same as ʻoʻopu ʻumiʻumi. Lit., spiked ʻoʻopu.
An introduced fresh-water black fish with sharp spines near the gills, said to have been introduced from China. Lit., spiny ʻoʻopu.
Female nākea variety of the fish ʻoʻopu. Lit., small source ʻoʻopu.
Same as ʻoʻopu lehe.
Large male of the nākea variety of ʻoʻopu, so called because its lip (lehe) is said to show when it hides in the mud.
A variety of ʻoʻopu. Lit., red-eyed ʻoʻopu.
A variety of ʻoʻopu. Lit., indigenous.
A variety of ʻoʻopu smaller than the kāniʻo, perhaps named for the moʻala, a crab.
A variety of ʻoʻopu. Lit., ocean.
Same as nākea.
Same as nāpili.
Same as nōkea.
Same as nāpili. Kauaʻi.
Spiny puffer fish, Diodon holocanthus.
A stroke in lua fighting; fish was said to be taboo to those learning the stroke. Lit., alive ʻoʻopu.
Same as pilikoʻa.
Same as poʻopaʻa, a fish. Lit., hardheaded.
A variety of ʻoʻopu. Lit., eel.
Same as iʻa Pākē, an introduced ʻoʻopu. Lit., bearded ʻoʻopu.
To hail, halloo. Rare.
A fish (Stethojulis albovittata), evidently of the ʻōmaka type.
Same as ʻoʻopa, māʻopaʻopa. (PCP kopa.)

1. To press, squeeze, knead, as in massaging or in working dough.

2. To ache, as from sitting in a cramped position.
General name for shrimp. For some persons, ʻōpae were ʻaumakua. See ex., lolena 2, punau. (PNP pae.)
A shrimp (Palaemon).
An indigenous shrimp, Palaemon debilis, almost transparent, found in brackish ponds. Lit., small shrimp.
See ʻōpae huna
Any sea shrimp.
A spiked shrimp.
Species of fresh-water shrimp, Atya bisulcata. Also ʻōpae kuahiwi, mountain shrimp, and ʻōpae kolo, crawling shrimp.
A shrimp (no data).
See ʻōpae-kala-ʻole.
See ʻōpae kolo
Brackish-water shrimp or prawn (Penaeus marginatus).
A variety of salt-water shrimp.

1. Clawed shrimp (Macrobrachium grandimanus), found in inland streams and taro patches, perhaps endemic. Lit., crooked-walking shrimp. See ex., ʻīnana.

2. An indigenous crab (Matapograpsus thukuhar, not M. messor).
Same as ʻōpae huna.
A variety of soft (ʻōlulo) fresh-water shrimp.
Small, endemic reddish shrimp used for ʻōpelu bait.
Lopsided, flattened on one side, dented, bent in, caved in, misshapen; dent, cavity.
Redup. of ʻōpaha.

1. To flap, as wings; to shake, tremble, as the earth. Fig., feeble.

2. A sea gull (very rarely seen).

1. Cut in evenly matched vertical facets, often eight, as of a bowl, spittoon, kukui shell in a lei; facet, prism. See ʻumeke ʻōpaka.

2. Mountain ravine. (PCP (k)o(o)pata; cf. Marquesan opata.)

1. Blue snapper; Pristipomoides sieboldii, P. microlepis, Aphareus furcatus, A. rutilans; the four stages of ʻōpakapaka were ʻūkīkiki, pākale, ʻōpakapaka, kalekale.

2. Redup. of ʻōpaka 1.

3. Rough, as breadfruit skin; crinkled, as crepe; wrinkled.
Opossum. Eng.
Trash, rubbish, refuse, litter, waste matter, junk, garbage, muck; littered (said also of “trashy” people); riff-raff.
Redup. of ʻōpala; bits of trash and rubbish.
Trashy pebbles. Fig., persons of no account.
A place with many precipices; having many cliffs, cliffed; mountainous, hilly.
Similar to palupalu.
Redup. of ʻopa.
Redup. of ʻōpā 1, 2.
Smooth, floorlike, as pāhoehoe lava. Rare.
Same as ʻōpalipali.
Bundle, package; to tie in a bundle (sometimes preceded by ke).
Feeble; feebleness. See pē 1.

1. To twist, bind, or cross the hands, as behind the back; to throw over the shoulder, as a shawl; to overturn, overthrow; to evict, as a tenant; to trip, as with a spear thrust between the legs. Fig., to deceive, trick, treat treacherously; treachery.

2. Scrotum.

3. Small boom or spar to extend and elevate the sails of a canoe.

To cross the hands behind the back, a gesture considered rude because it was thought to bring bad luck to a fisherman or one beginning a venture. It signified: “May your disappointment be so great as to weigh down your back.”
Baggy and ill-fitting, as clothes; loose, sagging. Lit., slack bundle.
Same as Ka-ʻōpeʻa-panipani.

1. General name for starfish.

2. Bat.

3. Half-leaf, said of a taro plant remaining on the stalk after the top half has been removed for cooking; so called because its form suggests that of a bat.

4. Window shutters, Venetian blinds.

5. See iwi ʻōpeʻapeʻa.

6. Canoe sails. Rare.
A native fern (Elaphoglossum aemulum variety), a small variety of ʻēkaha ʻula.
Opossum. Eng.
See ʻopekama

1. Swollen.

2. Protected by taboo, so named for ʻŌpele, the patron of the fish ʻamaʻama, who lived near Kolekole Pass, Wai-ʻanae, and who called ʻamaʻama by prayer to certain places where they would be protected from fishermen by taboo for several months. Rare.
Redup. of ʻōpele 1.

1. Mackerel scad (Decapterus pinnulatus and D. maruadsi); an ʻaumakua for some people. See kala ʻōpelu, pepenu.

2. A variety of taro.

3. See "Lobelia hypoleuca": , a plant named for the supposed resemblance of its leaf to the fish of the same name.
A variety of taro.
A variety of small deep-water ʻōpelu. Lit., rough ʻōpelu with leis.
A variety of large ʻōpelu.
Young stage of ʻōpelu, about the length of a finger. Lit., strong ʻōpelu.
Same as ʻōpelu palahū.
Variety of ʻōpelu.
Offense. Eng. See ex., paha 6.
See ʻopeni

1. Redup. of ʻope; bundles, packages, baggage; to fold, as clothes (Ioane 20.7); pillow (Kauaʻi). See ex., palale.

2. Same as ʻōpeʻa.
Bundle that is hung, as bones of a relative.
Fold, crease; wrinkled; bend of a wave; sunken, as the jaw of a toothless person; to fold, crease. See ʻopi wai. (PNP kopi.)

1. Rare var. of ʻūpī.

2. Short for ʻōpili.
Rare var. of ʻōpihapiha.
Uncomfortable fullness after overeating; gaseous; somewhat full, as a pool.

1. Limpets, Hawaiians recognize three kinds: kōʻele (Cellana talcosa, the largest), ʻālinalina (C. sandwicensis), makaiauli (C. exarata). Scientists also recognize C. melanostoma. (Kay 43–46.) Also kāʻala. For some persons, ʻopihi are an ʻaumakua. Cf. makaʻopihi.

2. Salted and dried abalone from the mainland. Also ʻopihi malihini.

3. Design for tapa and mats consisting of small triangles, probably named for the limpet.
Yellow-meated ʻopihi. Lit., scarred ʻopihi. See ʻopihi mākuʻekuʻe.
Small bitter ʻopihi, perhaps Cellana sandwicensis, nonedible, used in sorcery, perhaps hoofshells. Lit., bitter ʻopihi.
Limpet, umbrella shell (Siphoneria sp.). Lit., horseshoe ʻopihi [this name post-dated arrival of horses in Hawaiʻi]. Called naka kua poʻi in some areas.
See kōʻele.
See makaiauli.
Same as ʻopihi ʻālinalina. Molokaʻi.

1. A mere trifle, small thing; tiny, trifling, as a fish or worthless sweet potato.

2. Kind of mat, as used for sails.
Short for ʻOpikanalani or ʻOpikananuʻu.
Name of a mythical faraway place, higher than ʻOpikananuʻu.
Name of a mythical, faraway place. Cf. ʻOpikanalani.
Same as more common ʻūpiki, trap.
Anxiety, mental disturbance; agitated, as the sea. Cf. pikipikiʻō.

1. Same as kōpiko, a native genus of trees.

2. Same as ʻōpikopiko 1,

1. Spotted, dotted, as with tattoo marks; stained, as by the grip of an octopus tentacle. Cf. ʻāpikapika.

2. A form of syphilis, in which skin is said to be spotted.
Cramped or numbed, as by cold or sitting long in one position; aching; clamped together, as leaves of a sensitive plant when touched; a cramp; to clamp or close together. Cf. ʻūpili.

1. Same as ʻōpilopilo.

2. Sick, especially when suffering a relapse; breaking out afresh, as a sore. Rare.

1. Bad-smelling, as stagnant water; a marshy odor; halitosis.

2. Scraps, fragments. Cf. pilo, any kind.
Fold, bend, crease. Cf. ʻopi.
Youth, juvenile; youngster; young, junior. Cf. pio 3.

1. Redup. of ʻopi; to fold; folding.

2. A seaweed.
Young, immature, juvenile; unripe; fresh, as a dress nicely laundered; youth, young person.

1. Opium. Eng., See ex., māilo.

2. The Manila tamarind (Pithecellobium dulce), from tropical America, both cultivated and wild in Hawaiʻi. It is a medium-sized tree, a legume, with long slender branches, four-parted leaves, whitish flowers in small round heads, and red, twisted pods. Round, flat, black seeds embedded in white, edible pulp were thought to resemble commercial opium, hence the name. (Neal 399–401.)
Stream embankment.
To lay a foundation, as of stones; to dam up, as water. Rare. Also hauʻopo.

1. To dive into the water, feet first, without making a splash, an ancient sport (used only with lele 
or lele a); one so skilled. Cf. maʻopu.

2. Rare var. of ʻupu.

1. Clump, as of sugar cane, bananas, kava; cluster. Cf. pū 4. See ex., ʻahuʻawa.

2. To open, as a flower; to rise, as water; to swell, as waves; to grow, as a foetus; to sit with knees gathered up.

3. To rest, hover, live idly or lazily, exist; existence, rest.

4. A tower in a heiau. See drawing, Ii 57.
Belly, stomach, abdomen, tripe, giblet; bag, as of a net (see ex., mahola); gizzard, bladder, crop of a bird (Oihk. 1.16), maw of an animal, womb; disposition.
Puffy clouds, as banked up near the horizon, often interpreted as omens; cumulus or billowy cloud, cloud bank; to form such clouds. See sayings, clouds, proud.
See naeʻōpuakau, waiʻōpua.
Patient; patience; a patient person. Lit., disposition of great breath.
Same as ʻōpū ʻaiʻai.
Stomach; craw, as of a bird.
Cloud bank containing images.
Same as naʻau aliʻi.
Mackerel sky with cloud flakes; cirro-cumulus clouds. Lit., net-mesh cloud bank.
Cluster of clouds.
Same as naʻauao.
Beef tripe. Lit., spotted stomach.
Hut, as in a forest.
Bladder (euphemism for ʻōpū mimi).
Hunger pains. Lit., stomach longing for or missing something.
Three species of endemic trees (Urera), related to the olonā, the bark of which was also formerly used for fishing nets. (Neal 320.) See also hona, hōpue.
Quiet, tranquil, calm, disinclined to work, lazy; tranquillity. Cf. ʻōhea.
Same as ōpūhea.
Same as ʻawapuhi, a kind of ginger.
Round, low calabash. Lit., calabash clump.

A “turned stomach,” believed caused by falls, especially of small children, resulting in a kink or turning of the stomach, with attendant vomiting; a symptom is said to be a shortening of one leg; the cure is massage and binding of the stomach; this diagnosis and treatment are said to have been learned from the Portuguese.
Beef tripe. Lit., hairy belly.
Same as naʻau ʻino.
See ʻōpū ʻino
var. of ʻōpūkeʻemoa. Lit., chicken-edge stomach.
A large, strong, superior variety of sugar cane, the stalks yellow, sometimes rose-flushed, the pith white. (HP 223.)
Hardhearted, mean. Lit., chicken crookedness gizzard.
Same as naʻau kopekope.
Frowning, wrinkled; lowering, as clouds. Cf. pukupuku, pupuku.

1. Case and larva of case moth (Tineola uterella), found on cement walls of basements or in caves, so called perhaps because the interior of the case is sometimes lined with hair. Lit., head-hair womb.

2. A strange malady, the only symptoms of which were fine tracings of blood vessels on the stomach at birth which vanished shortly afterward. One with such tracings would grow up to be sterile, if a male, or if a female, would not have a child that lived more than a few months.

1. Same as ʻōpulepule 2.

2. A wrasse (Anampses cuvier, A. godeffroyi); the name may be qualified by the terms lā uli and uli. (Malo 46.)

3. Same as maiʻa koana.
Stroke in lua fighting.

1. Moronic, somewhat crazy, psychotic. See pule and ex., ʻōhewahewa.

2. Spotted, speckled, mottled.

3. A spotted land moss.
Bellows. Lit., wind belly.
Beef tripe. Lit., net mesh belly.
Shady clump; a humble way to refer to one's house.
Bladder. Lit., urine belly.
Cluster or clump of any growth; thicket.
Jealous. Lit., jealous disposition.
Corpulent, large-bellied; corpulency; big belly.
Disease in which the abdomen becomes enlarged and hard, while the limbs are enervated; dropsy. Cf. ʻōhao 1.
Beef tripe. Lit., folding belly.

1. To belch; filled, as a calabash.

2. Redup. of ʻopu 2.

The ability to go a long time without eating; to fast for a long time; one who can go long without eating. This was believed due to a belated dropping off of the umbilical cord in infancy. Lit., solid stomach.
Potbellied, pumpkin-bellied.
Idle, indolent, eating food without working; potbellied. Lit., sweet-potato-leaf stomach; said to be so called because it took little effort to cook sweet potato leaves.
Beef tripe.
Pig intestine; tripe.
See punalua.

1. A bud, the budding breasts of a girl, the budding spur of a young cock; to bud; a child; a geometric cone.

2. A whale-tooth pendant, not tongue-shaped like the lei palaoa. See ex., hulali 1.

3. A large surf, swell.
A cut diamond, as for a ring.
Of limited ability, importance, or strength, as once said of women and children. Lit., small disposition.
The root bud and buds of a banana plant, and the sheaths enclosing them.

1. Lumpy, bumpy, hilly, rough, as cloth or a road.

2. Knuckle, as on fingers, wrist.

3. Shore fish listed by Malo (no data). (Malo 46.)
Clump of grass, a polite depreciatory way to refer to one's home, however magnificent it may be.

1. Float, as on a net. Rare.

2. To lean on something, hide. Rare.

3. Your, yours (o-form, zero-class, singular; ).oʻou.)

1. A fish (no data).

2. Mine, my, of me (o-form, zero-class; ).

1. To pinch or nip off, as a bud.

2. To perch, as on a tree. Fig., lazy.

3. A finch-like Hawaiian honey creeper (Psittirostra psittacea), with an almost parrot-like bill, endemic to the main Hawaiian Islands, but becoming very rare. Its green feathers were used for making cloaks and leis. See ex., kuaola. Cf. ʻōʻū lae oʻo, ʻōʻū poʻo lapalapa.

4. To hump up, as an octopus out of its burrow.
Var. of ʻouo.
Same as ua ona o.

1. Showery, somewhat rainy.

2. Somewhat tough, rubbery.
Same as ʻōʻū-holo-wai-o-Laʻa. (For. 5:565.)
See ʻō
Kauaʻi ʻākepa (Loxops coccinea caeruleirostris), a bird.
A well-known kind of tapa said to have been associated with the goddess Laka and to be used in kuni ceremonies.
. You (plural), ye.
Rare var. of ʻaukuʻu, a heron.

1. A small oʻu, a fish.

2. Small, petite.
A variety of ʻōʻū, a bird similar to ʻōʻū poʻo pāpale. Lit., mature-headed ʻōʻū.
Orangutan. Eng.

Sign, omen, portent, prognostication, nature, symptom, character; mood in grammar. Also aouli, ʻōmea.
Indicative mood.
Symptom, prognostication.
Growth.
Leader, as in battle or other activity; scout.
Same as unauna, hermit crab.
Young animal, plant or person; young woman, pullet, cock, youth; youthful, sprightly; immature, as a coconut.

Fearless, courageous. (And.)

2. A sharp sound, as of a tapa mallet or of a tapping knee drum; to sound thus.

3. Same as ʻou 2. (PCP koukou.)
Same as ʻōʻū 3.
Growing thriftily, as plants.

1. Beaten down, as by storm; to cast down (2 Oihn. 25.8).

2. Extreme lower end of a canoe paddle. Rare.

1. To deceive, fool, vex, trouble.

Redup. of ʻōʻupē.
A variety of ʻōʻū, a bird. Lit., square-headed ʻōʻū.
Variety of ʻōʻū, a bird. Lit., head-crested ʻōʻū.
Person living with strangers. (And.)

Same as awaawa.
Same as ʻāwaʻawaʻa.

Murmuring, rustling, soughing, whining, as of surf, leaves, water, wind, a bullet; to pitter patter, as rain; to sound thus; sound of tearing, as of cloth; buzzing of insects. Cf. wewe 2.

Waving slightly, streaming. Cf. kōwelo.

Red; to redden. See ex., pūnoni.

1. A weedy kind of verbena (Verbena litoralis), from tropical America, with square stems 30 cm to 2 m high, toothed oblong leaves, and narrow flower spikes bearing tiny blue flowers. Hawaiians use it for cuts and bruises, applying the juice externally and later sprinkling the affected area with powdered pia root. Also haʻuōwī. (Neal 721–2.)

2. The Jamaica vervain (Stachytarpheta jamaicensis), another kind of weedy verbena also from tropical America, similar to the above, but with oval toothed leaves, and tiny blue flowers borne on longer, narrower spikes. It is not used medicinally by Hawaiians. (Neal 725.)

3. Cry of the bird ʻōʻū; to cry, of the ʻōʻū.
See ōwī

1. Roll, bolt, as of cloth or paper; scroll of binder, as of a sewing machine; skein, coil; to roll up, twist, coil, wave; to fold, as the arms.

2. Surfboard of wiliwili wood.

3. Powder horn. See holowaʻa ʻōwili.
Same as wiliʻōkaʻi 1, cocoon.
Redup. of ʻōwili 1.

1. Fence, wall, corral, pen, sty, enclosure, courtyard, patio, arena, (house) lot, yard, extremity; to build a fence, enclosure. Cf. pānini, Pā-lama (place name), fence built of lama wood.

2. Dish, plate, pan; elongated food bowl used for meat or fish; flat basin; phonograph record, disk (preceded by ke). Cf. halepā.

3. Mother-of-pearl shell (Pinctada margaritifera); pearl-shell lure; fishhook (cf. pā ʻiʻo, pā kau ulua). Both ke and ka are used with pā 3.

4. , nvi. A broadly used loaʻa-type word, said of drinking, hearing, feeling, and activity of wind, sun, moon; also used as a noun with similar meanings (see ex., pualalea). To touch, get, contact, reach, gain control of, hit, experience; to blow (as wind), shine (as moon or sun), hear, drink. Cf. pā kāhea, pā wai.

5. . A sound; to sound; beat, rhythm, as of a dance; stroke, as of an instrument; thump of a gourd down on a pad, with one quick slap of the fingers as the gourd is raised; signal to begin a dance or drumming.

6. Barren, as a female; to have ceased bearing; parched, as land.

7. Flat top of a hat.

8. Lowest and highest note in the musical scale, do.

9. Temporary, fleeting.

10. Section of net attached to a bag in certain types of fishing.
Prefix to many bases, with general meaning of “in the nature of, having the quality of.” Cf. pāheahea, pahemo, pāhemahema, pāhaʻohaʻo, etc.
See pa-
Prefix to numerals: at a time, at once, number of times; to divide by. Cf. lele 7.

1. A common and broadly used loaʻa-type word; many meanings depend on qualifying words. Firm, solid, tight, solidified, adhering, durable, fast, fixed, stuck, secure, closed, jelled, congealed, frozen, hard, sound (as wood), busy, occupied, engaged, definite, steadfast, permanent; finished, completed, whole, complete, learned, memorized, mastered, retained, kept permanently; stubborn, determined, constipated, solid or fast, as colors; sturdy, as cloth, furniture; strong and vigorous; versed in, learned in; one who holds, a bearer; to hold, bear, keep, detain, withhold; a solid, as in geometry; to wear well, as clothes; to look well or not show age, of a person. See paʻa kāhili.

2. Pair, couple; couplet. Cf. paʻa kāmaʻa, paʻa lio, paʻa male.

3. Suit of clothes.

4. Stratum, foundation, especially paʻa-i-lalo, earth, and paʻa-i-luna, heavens.

5. Extremity, border.

6. Type of sweet potato, pronunciation not certain. (For. 5:664–5.)

1. Same as paʻaʻā 1, 2.

2. Dry and rocky.

1. Fiber, as of sugar-cane stalk or of banana sheath (probably a contraction of paʻa, solid, and ʻaʻa, fiber).

2. Var. of pāpaʻa 3.
See paʻaʻā

1. First stage of growth of the fish akule, 6 or 7 cm. long. Cf. halalū.

2. Inferior tapa made from small lengths of bark.
A carrier of mats (Kep. 129), a heap of mats.
See paʻa ʻahu
Landholder; to hold land.
Same as paʻaloha.
See "hoʻopaʻa haʻawina":  To study the lesson; studious.

1. Industrious, busy, hard-working; workman, laborer, worker, industry.

2. Implement, tool, utensil, furnishings (Nah. 7.1).

1. Prisoner, convict; to be imprisoned.

2. Proceeds (as pigs, sweet potatoes or taro) paid to holders of land on which tenants worked; penalty for failure to pay was imprisonment. Cf. lā paʻahao, loʻi paʻahao.
Shovel (RSV), fire pan (KJV) (Ier. 52.19.) (Preceded by ke.)
Pas/imp. of paʻa 1.
Spread here and there.
Heptagon.
Same as pāhono.
Var. of paʻa ʻahu.

The castor-oil plant (Ricinus communis), an introduced shrub with large lobed leaves and dry prickly seed cases. The seeds contain a dangerous poison. The Hawaiians use the leaves, rubbed on the face, to relieve fever. (Neal 509–10.) Also kaʻapehā, kamākou, kolī, lāʻau ʻaila.
The earth below.
A solid, usually with number of sides following, as paʻaili hā. Lit., surface solid.
Four-sided solid (this term was said to be used formerly for a pyramid).
Paʻaʻili with equal sides.
A twenty-sided solid.
Oblique parallelepiped. Lit., solid leaning similarly.
Cube or rectangular parallelepiped. Lit., straight solid.
Six-sided solid, cube; cubic. See ex., iā, yard.
Cube. Lit., equal six solid.
A twelve-sided solid.
Heavens above.
Bearer of the chief's spittoon.
Bearer of the royal feather standard; to carry a kāhili.

1. Salt; encrusted discharge in the inner corners of the eyes, as after sleeping. Types of salt are paʻakai lele wai, very fine, dried salt; paʻakai walewale, slimy salt; paʻakai puʻupuʻu, coarse salt; paʻakai lepo, salt mixed with earth; paʻakai ʻulaʻula, salt mixed with ocherous earth. Cf. alaea 1.

2. A variety of taro, usually grown in the uplands, the plant short and stocky; petioles dark-green, edged with red; corm flesh white, used chiefly for poi.

3. Same as līpaʻakai, a seaweed.
Copperas. (Hae Hawaii, May 13, 1857.)
A fish, said to be one of the Hemiramphidae. Lit., scattered salt.
Lye (RSV), nitre (KJV) (Ier. 2.22.) Lit., washing salt.
Smelling salts.
Effervescent solution.
Epsom salts. Lit., drinking salt.
A variety of taro.
Alum. Lit., bitter salt.
Pair of shoes.
Limestone, coral beds, as found on the leeward sides of the islands. Lit., white hardness.
Hard, tough, unyielding; arbitrary, inflexible, compact, difficult, stubborn (Kanl. 9.27), obstinate.
Dry lowland plain. (Kep. 87.)
See "hoʻopaʻakope":  Copyright; to copyright.
To jell, set firmly, congeal; to clot, as blood; to stiffen, as hard poi; avaricious.
Fish pond for trapping akule, fish.
See "hoʻopaʻa kuleana":  nvt. Copyright; to copyright.

1. Smooth, water-worn ʻalā rock.

Keepsake, memento, souvenir. Also paʻaaloha.
Suit of clothes. Also paʻalole komo.
Uniform, as of military.

Formal, according to rule, decorous; to observe rules, as of etiquette; one who observes such rules.

Regular, customary, usual. Lit., continually fixed.
