Landing place, as of canoes (paena waʻa) or of waves (paena nalu); landing. Cf. pae 2. (PCP paenga.)
Row of teeth.

1. A support, prop, stool, pavement, house platform; plate of a house on which the rafters rest; block to keep an outrigger float off the ground; log or wooden horse that supports a seesaw; to support, hold up, sustain; rows.

2. Redup. of pae 2.

3. Boom of a ship. Cf. kaula paepae.

4. Same as iwi ʻaoʻao.
Redup. of paʻē; to publicize.
Ti-stalk fence (the stalks are crossed and a stick put into the notches made by the crossings).
Axle of a wheel (1 Nal. 7.33). Lit., support where wheel enters.
Threshold (Isa. 6.4). Lit., door platform.
Window sill.
Footstool. (Iak. 2.3.)
To sound together, a deafening roar.
Row or cluster of hills.
Crooked, misshapen, bent, uneven, odd, imperfect; wrong, incorrect; error, mistake.
Redup. of paʻewa; biased, partial, unfair, prejudicially.

1. To improvise a chant; an improvised or conversation chant, as the kepakepa. (PCP pa(f,s)a.)

2. Uncooked young taro leaves. (PH 74.) Cf. lūʻau, pēʻū.

3. Same as kūpala, a plant.

4. A kind of surfboard. Rare.

5. Short for pahāha. Rare.

6. Maybe, perhaps, probably, possibly, may, might (very common, used to make speech less blunt and more conciliatory, something like English use of the conditional mode; it frequently follows ʻaʻole and pēlā, and never occurs after a pause).
By fours, four at a time, four times; to distribute to four; to divide by four.
Short in stature.

1. Redup. of pāhaʻa.

2. Same as noʻunoʻu, a gourd.
Young stage of the mullet, also called kahaha. (KL. line 173.)
Swollen, as the neck or the cheeks of one with mumps; to strut, walk proudly. Rare. Cf. ʻauwaepahāha, manō pahāha.
Name of a design on Niʻihau mats consisting of squares with corners touching and forming a line.
A method of making mulch soil by placing pandanus (hala) branches and leaves in holes in rocky soil containing mulch, and then burning the hala for fertilizer.
See "hoʻopāhala":  Sceptical. He kanaka hoʻopāhala, he manaʻoʻiʻo ʻole (Kep. 107), a skeptical person of no faith.
House lot, yard, fence.
Tray (preceded by ke). Lit., plate for carrying.
A hundredfold, by the hundred; to distribute to a hundred.
See pāhaneli

1. Iron fence.

2. Iron dish, pan (preceded by ke).

1. About the same as the more common pāhaʻohaʻo.

2. Name of a guessing game. Rare.
Mysterious, puzzling, incomprehensible; transfigured.
See akepahaola.

1. Redup. of paha 1, 5. (PCP pa(f,s)apa(f,s)a.)

2. Same as līpahapaha, sea lettuce.

3. Oʻahu name for a kind of stone used for poi pounders. Called makawī on Kauaʻi.
A liverwort (Dumortiera sp.).
A kind of pahapaha said to be found only at Poli-hale, Kauaʻi; after drying it was believed to revive when immersed in sea water; it was made into leis.
A sea lettuce (Ulva sp.) with narrow frond. Found where sea and fresh water meet.

1. Striped flatfish. (KL. line 156.)

2. Person who cared for chief's food and clothes; well-cared for, as clothes. Rare.

3. To filch. Rare.

1. Enclosure or fence of hau trees.

2. White pearl-shell lure or shell.
Soft-spoken, soft-mannered; soft and about to spoil, as fruit; pulp, of fruit. See the more common waipahē.
To call, especially to invite someone to eat; hospitality.

1. Slippery, smooth, as a surface; soft, satiny; to slide, slip, skid; sliding, slipping. Cf. holo paheʻe, pakika, pōhaku paheʻe ʻānai.

2. Cleared area, bare dirt.

3. Spear throwing; dart-throwing; sport of sliding a stick over a smooth surface; the dart itself. Buck describes the darts as from 34.5 to 67 inches (about 85 to 170 cm) long, tapering at one end, with the greatest diameter of from 1 to 1 1/2 inches (2.6 to 3.9 cm). Cf. moa 5.

4. Shallow hole or grave, as for flexed burial. (For. 5:571.)

5. Same as pāheʻeheʻe, seaweed.

1. Redup. of paheʻe 1.

2. A green cushion-shaped solid seaweed (Porphyra sp., formerly Dictyosphaeria). Also līpaheʻe, līpaheʻeheʻe, līpāhoe, paheʻe.
To bowl; bowling.

1. A snare, noose, trap; to ensnare, trap; deceit, treachery.

2. Same as mānai, needle.
Wind off Wai-ʻanae, Oʻahu (PH 161), and associated with Naue, Kauaʻi (For. 5:97). Lit., pandanus ensnarement.
Redup. of pahele, snare.

1. Var. of pakelo.

2. To peel, as taro.
About the same as hemahema: awkward, unskilled.
About the same as hemo; loosened, slipping off; to loosen, get loose; weakening, as a voice.
Redup. of pahemo.
To ridicule, laugh at, make fun of, mock, scoff.
Redup. of pahē.
A fish (no data).

1. Knife, flint; to skin, as cattle. (PCP pa(f,s)i.)

2. To stand on edge. (And.)
How many to each? How many in a group?
A slipping, falling down; oblique cut; obliquely, as of clipping, cutting, falling; to miss.
Redup. of pāhiʻa. (PCP paasikasika.)
Bonito hook.
Cleaver, chopping knife. Lit., striking knife.
To spread, as vines; to stream, as water over a cliff.
Cane knife, machete. Lit., striking knife.
Razor. Cf. more common pahi ʻumiʻumi. Lit., shaving knife.
Sickle, scythe, cutlass. Lit., bent knife.
Knife made of a piece of hoop iron. Lit., sounding knife.

1. Same as kala liʻiliʻi, a fish (see kala 3).

2. A long narrow bivalve, possibly the Pinna shells (Pinnidae).
Sword. Lit., war knife.
Cutlass. Lit., flat war knife.
Sickle.
To pass quietly, go lightly, touch gently.
Carving knife.
Sevenfold, by sevens; seven times; to distribute to seven or divide by seven.
To stagger. Cf. hilala.
Untrue, false; untruth (contraction of pāhili, variable, and lau, much). Cf. ʻalapahi.
To braid. Fig., to confuse, entangle, deceive.
To blow strongly, as a wind, especially of a veering wind; to lash, as a storm.
Same as puāhilo.
Sharp knife used for dressing beef. Lit., knife for skinning beef.
Proud, strutting. Rare.
Double-edged sword or knife.
About the same as hinu.
Leaning, slanting, stooping; tall, slender (And.). See hiō.
Dagger. Lit., piercing knife.
Carving knife.
Butcher knife,
Paper knife.
A saw; to saw.
Whipsaw.
An unknown type of saw mentioned in wills during the 1850s.
Sheepfold.
Drawknife. Lit., knife solid [at] chest.

To slap hands; to play “peas-porridgehot”; this game; a game formerly played by children: a rotten object was buried in the sand and others were asked to dig for it, while the leader said “kōhi kōhi kūpā, no wai, no wai ka lima i hawahawa,” gather, gather, dig, whose hands, whose hands are dirtied.
Pruning knife.
Chopping knife of any kind.
Jackknife, penknife, folding knife.
Short-bladed knife. Lit., cut head knife.

1. A game: throwing darts at a target, or pushing a stone with sharp sticks to a goal; to play this game.

2. A type of sorcery. (Kam. 64:131, 140.)
Drawknife.
Razor. Lit., beard knife.
Dark, to darken (note that hiwa is a sacred, desirable black that contrasts with uli).
Flaming sword (Kin. 3.24); saw sword. Lit., shining knife.
Var. of pohō.
Short dagger; sharp stone, especially as used for a weapon; Moloka'i name for stick for beating clothes; taboo sign.
To paddle; to drive fish into a net by beating the paddles rhythmically against the canoe; paddler. Cf. homa 3, kāpapa.

1. Smooth, unbroken type of lava, contrasting with ʻaʻā; to turn into pāhoehoe lava (see ex., namu 2).

2. Satin.

3. Redup. of pāhoe.
Hooks used in catching sea turtles. (And.)
Soup plate, deep dish (preceded by ke).

1. To spread about, extend, diffuse; spread too thin, dissipated. Cf. hohola.

2. To stupefy fish by drugging with ʻauhuhu, the poison spreading (pāhola) through the water.
Redup. of pāhola 1, 2.
Same as pohole.
Redup. of pahole.
Legendary name for kava. (For. 5:607.)
To appear in great numbers, as octopuses. Rare.
An enclosure for animals, as a dog pound.
Wash pan or basin (preceded by ke).
To mend, sew up a tear, patch, darn, repair.
Redup. of pāhono.
Phonograph record.
Torn tapa. (And.)
Saucepan (preceded by ke). Lit., boiling pan.
Central corral.
Same as pāʻouʻou, young of the fish hou.

1. Box, drum, cask, chest, barrel, trunk, tank, case, ship binnacle, collection box, keg, ark, coffin, dresser, bureau, cabinet; bald heads were sometimes ridiculed as drums. Cf. hulipahu, pahu pāpale.

2. Stake, staff, stick, post, pole. Cf. pahu hope, pahu hopu, pahukū.

3. To push, shove; to thrust or hurl, as a spear or javelin; to pierce with a sharp instrument, as in letting blood; to fall overboard (For. 5:123). Fig., to bruise the feeling of others.

4. To cut off short; odd-numbered. Cf. ʻāpahu, ʻoi 3, pahupū.

5. Trunkfishes, boxfishes, cowfishes (Ostracion). Malo says that pahu were taboo to women (Malo 29). Also moa.

6. Name of a region below the ʻilima and above the kula.

7. Gill net used in shallow water. (Malo 213, Emerson note.)
To explode, burst; explosive, blast, thud; outburst. Cf. pōkā pahū. See ex., walawala.

1. Pas/imp. of pahu 3. See hula Pahua, a spear dance.

2. Downtrodden, as grass where cattle have stamped. Rare.
Unsuccessful, ineffective, ruined, spoiled; lack of success.
Similar to kīpuka 1, said especially of clear areas in pastures where it is easy to rope cattle.
See "hoʻopāhuʻa":  To move sideways; to sail to windward. Rare.
Glass box, especially a glass-bottomed box for fishing; glass case, as in a museum.
Flagpole.
Safe, strong box. Lit., iron box.
Icebox, refrigerator.
Temple drum.
Ark of the testimony. Lit., testifying box.
Final goal or stake.
Final goal. Lit., catching goal.
Young of the fish uhu.
To gush, ooze forth, as blood.
Hula drum.
Small aquarium box for fish.
Var. of pāhiʻuhiʻu, a game.
Juice extracted from a green gourd by pounding, said to be used in an enema.
Ashes. Also lehu, noho hale.

1. Sham battle with sharp weapons. (Malo 66.)

2. See "Herald":  who announces (kala) war.
Safe-deposit box.
Prayer drum (perhaps from pahu kala loa, drum proclaiming to a distance).
Ark of the testimony. Lit., legal box. Cf. pahu hōʻike.
Drum; tabret (Kin. 31.27), eardrum (Kel. 115; translation from Eng.). Fig., bald head. Lit., sounding drum.
A stake beyond which it was taboo to pass; sanctuary. Lit., taboo stake.

1. Goal or stick at the starting place of a race.

2. Reserve of an army, especially a rear guard.

3. To repel, as in war.
Same as pōhuku.
Hypodermic injection; to be injected. Lit., needle piercing.
Coffin. Lit., corpse box.
Hula troupe, hula studio, place reserved for hula dancing.
Clothes chest or trunk.

1. Nightmare (named for a chief of evil spirits on Lā-naʻi who was killed by Ka-ulu-lāʻau; his spirit enchanted certain fish, especially goatfish (weke); if a weke head is eaten near bedtime, nightmares are said to result; the closer to Lā-naʻi the weke is caught, the worse the nightmare); ghost; haunted; unlucky.

2. Exhausted, worn-out, of over-farmed soil; such soil.

3. Volunteer sweet potatoes, sweet potatoes of the second growth.
Demented, to behave as if crazy.
Somewhat rainy, showery. Rare.
Intersection, crossroads. Lit., branching stake.
Beehive.
A pushing, thrust, hurling, piercing, etc., as of an ihe spear. Cf. pahu 3.
Box, as at a theater.
Phonograph. Lit., speaking box.
Meat safe, cupboard. Lit., dish box.

1. Redup. of pahu 3.

2. Billiards, pool; to play billiards or pool.

3. Redup. of pahu 4; blunt, dull.

1. Redup. of pahū; firecrackers.

2. Same as kāʻekeʻeke.

3. Tiny and worthless taro offshoot from an offshoot of several generations. (Kep. 153.) See kalo.
Small sharkskin hula drum. Lit., beating drum.
Camera, kodak. Lit., box for printing pictures.
Tobacco box or container.
Writing desk; formerly a container for the coloring liquid used in printing tapa. Lit., document box.
Binnacle.
Hatbox; wooden block upon which a hat is plaited; such hats are called pāpale pahu.
Ark of the covenant (Ios. 3.3). Lit., covenant box.
. Keg. Lit., small-headed barrel.
Cut in half, cut in two, severed, cut short, chopped off.
Bookcase.
Drawer, bureau, buffet.
Water barrel, tank.
Clothes chest or trunk.
Chest of drawers, cabinet, bureau.

1. To urge, encourage, rouse, stir up, excite.

2. To raise, lift up, increase. (PCP pai.)

3. To laud, praise, exalt. Cf. pai aliʻi.

4. To pamper, spoil, as a favorite child; to make a pet of.

5. A funnelshaped wicker basket used for catching shrimps and small fish, so called because it was lifted (pai) from the water. Also ʻapai, ʻāpua.

6. A native fern (Adenophorus hymenophylloides) with clustered, narrow, pinnate fronds, 5 to 13 cm long, growing on trees at rather high altitudes. Also huna palai, palai huna.

7. A 
kind of snail shellfish said to be poisonous to touch (no data).

8. Same as pānānai. Rare. See kīkala pai.

9. Pie, tart. Eng. (1 Sam. 17.18.)

1. To slap, spank, beat, hit, clap; to print, publish; to snap, as pictures; to break, as a taboo; a slapping, slap, stamping, printing (several old types of tapa begin with paʻi: paʻipaʻinahā, paʻiua, paʻiʻula; preceded by ke). Cf. paʻi ā paʻi, paʻi kiʻi, paʻi puna.

2. To tie; a draw; equal; to make an agreement (said to be so called because champions slapped each other's open palms after they had agreed on the terms of a match or race, and with a draw it was as though they had no more than concluded the terms). Cf. paʻi ā paʻi.

3. To mix, as ingredients; to mingle.

4. To put clothes to soak, as in soapy water.

5. A bundle, package, especially of food; to tie up such a bundle; bunch, cluster, as of grapes (preceded by ke). Cf. paʻi aʻa, paʻi ʻai, paʻi palaoa, paʻi ʻuala; paʻi waina.

6. Rare. var. of paʻipaʻi; to strip, as bark.

7. Lining, as of pandanus or sugar-cane leaves, inside thatching of pili grass; to line thus.

8. Decaying, of fruits or plants; blight. Rare. Cf. kāpaʻi, poultice.

9. Short for paʻi malau.

10. A heap.

11. To evict, as from land.
Wall, side of a house, clearing in a forest (often translated bower); walled in, as by vegetation.
Bracken, a fern (Pteridium aquilinum var.
Temporarily deaf, as from ascending to a high altitude.
Fenced in; struck. Cf. pā 1, 4.
Root system, rootlets, small branches.
A variety of taro.

1. Short, dumpy, as a person or animal.

2. Dancing, surging, undulating, as the sea; tossing, as a canoe in a rough sea.
Hard, pounded but undiluted taro; heavy, as poorly made cake.
Deafening.
Tossed here and there, as by a rough sea; to carry back and forth, to and fro, up and down, as a boat or kite; to tote. (For. 5:548.) Lit., lift unto space.
To laud or praise a chief; to elevate one's own ego by recounting one's association with chiefs; name-dropping.
Wind inland of Hāna, Maui.
Printing, edition.
Equal, as of two persons; to tie, have a draw. Cf. paʻi 2.
Apple pie. Eng.
To slap the chest, as in grief. Fig., to show grief, wail in lamentation. .

An edible crab, found where the ʻaʻama is found, but with a harder shell and shorter legs fringed in front with short, stiff hair; perhaps one of the grapsids; one of the names of Ka-mehameha I. Fig., a star athlete.
Same as ʻihaʻiha.
Var. of paiāhaʻa 1, 2.
Printing, as contrasted with handwriting (kākau); form, questionnaire; blank, as on a questionnaire. Lit., space printing.
To thatch or line a house. See paʻi 7.
Misprint, typographical error; to make such an error. Lit., mistaken printing.
Trickling water, as down the face of a cliff. Rare.
vt. Clear, bright, cloudless; neat, tidy, well dressed in one's best; to honor; set, as a ship's sails (often preceded by hao ā).

1. A small weed (Nasturtium sarmentosum), related to watercress; used medicinally and as a tapa dye. (Neal 372.) Cf. ʻihi kū kēpau.

2. See "Maui":  name for ʻōhiʻa hā.

1. Redup. of paʻihi. See ex., mikihilina, oki 2.

2. Same as pāʻihi 1, 2.
See pā

1. To project, as a bone through flesh. Rare.

2. To make hand signals. Rare.

3. Peeled, as skin.
Flapping, of a malo. Rare.
Custard pie, egg pie, fruit pie.

1. Bundle of fruit; fruit cluster, as of grapes.

2. Bulge, as in canoe sides. Rare.
Cake of figs. (1 Sam. 25.18.)
Cluster of grapes. (1 Sam. 25.18.)
See nenue.

A small, light-green, oblong fern (Dryopteris dentata), tapering at both ends and divided into many long, narrow divisions, widely distributed in woods of temperate and tropical countries. In Hawaiʻi it also volunteers in gardens. (Neal 20–1.)
Redup. of paʻina.
Fight; to fight. Eng.
To make a great pet of; to treat with great favor.
To march, drill, parade, pass to and fro; to practice firearms.
Equal. Rare.
To go gadding about from house to house.
Name of a star. See Au-haele.
Rare. var. of pakaulei.
Pas/imp. of paikaulei.
Bag, suitcase, satchel, pocketbook, purse. Eng.

1. Hollow of the hand. Rare.

2. Cramped, pressed close, crowded. Rare.
To take pictures, photographs; photographer. Lit., snap pictures. Cf. pahu paʻi kiʻi, pepa paʻi kiʻi.
Bicycle (usually follows kaʻa, vehicle). Eng.
Fashion, style. Eng.
Baseball bat, tennis racquet; to hit a ball.
Handbag.
To trim, cut short.
A kind of dark tapa cloth dyed with juice from kukui bark, said to be from Hālawa, Molokaʻi (Ii 83). According to Andrews, a pale yellow tapa made on Molokaʻi. Also paʻipaʻi kukui.
Those in charge of a chief's property. (And.)
To have connections with important or influential persons. Rare.

1. Pile, heap; to heap up. Eng. Kū ka paila, a big pile [work to do].

2. Also baila To boil, percolate.
Pilot; to pilot. Eng. Iesū, e pailaka iaʻu (hymn), Jesus, pilot me.
See pailaka
Similar to mailani, to praise, but often pejorative; to spoil.
Dry pandanus leaves still clinging to the tree. Lit., cut red leaves. Rare.
Woodpile, pile of firewood.
Swelling, as of newly made tattooing. Rare.
To touch the skin.
Cemetery, graveyard. See ex., wailua 1.
Same as pailaka, pilot.

1. A variety of sugar cane. Also hou, pakaweli.

2. Name of the channel between Molokaʻi and Maui.
Nausea; nauseating, abominable.

1. Portuguese man-of-war (Physalia).

2. A fleet of canoes fishing for aku with the malau, bait carrier.

1. See "-Na":  form of pai 2; to lift; lifting, swelling or breaking, as waves.

2. Fine cloth like serge.

3. Pine trees and all kinds of conifers; ironwood; cedar (RSV), ash (KJV) (Isaia 44.14). Eng.

4. Pint. Eng.

1. To crackle, snap, click, tick, pop, resound; crackling, etc; brittle, easily torn. Cf. kānepaʻina, ʻuʻina.

2. Hawaiʻi Island name for pohā 2, cape gooseberry.
Meal, dinner, small party with dinner; to eat a pāʻina.
Evening meal, dinner, supper.
French tamarisk (Tamarix gallica), shrub or small trees.
A stroke in lua fighting. Lit., deafening crackle.
Wedding feast or reception.
Poi lunch or supper.
Same as paina kahakai. Niʻihau.
To dress in tight-fitting garments; buttoned up tightly. Cf. niki, to tie.
Coconut pie.

Some native Hawaiian lilies (Astelia spp.) with long, narrow, silvery or tan leaves forming rosette-shaped plants growing either on the ground or perching on trees. Small yellow or greenish flowers develop in a panicle on a stalk shorter than the leaves. Formerly, Hawaiians braided hat leis out of the shiny outer layer of the leaves and wore them as a sign that they had visited Kī-lau-ea Volcano, where one species is common. (Neal 192). Also used, rarely, for house thatch (For. 5:655).
A very thin type of tapa.

1. To carry on the hip or back, as a heavy child; to lug, as a heavy object that must be hitched up now and then.

2. To boast. See ex., ʻēkā.
To quarrel, argue, fight; combat, argument, conflict, strife, battle, struggle; to contend, as conflicting winds.
Fishhook baited with flesh; to remove flesh from bones, as of fish. Cf. pā 3.
Tall, slim. Cf. leioa.
A variety of sweet potato.
See paioea
Basket trap for fishing ʻōhua. Cf. pai 5.
Debate, argument.
Food left for rats on a tray (pā).
Pioneer. Eng.
Basket trap for fishing ʻoʻopu. Cf. pai 5.
Redup. of pai 1, 2; to lobby; to rock. See noho paipai.

1. Redup. of paʻi 1; to applaud, clap; applause; to sprinkle coloring matter (as charcoal or red cloth) on tapa and beat it in.

2. Redup. of paʻi 3; mixed, diluted.

3. To trim, prune, cut, clip, as a plant or the hair; to strip off, as leaves. See ex., ʻōlaʻolaʻo.
Same as pepeieʻe.
See papaʻiole.
Same as paʻi kukui.
To clap, applaud; applause, clapping.
Memorial, revived memory (Puk. 30.16).
Redup. of pāʻina.
Tapa cloak worn over the shoulder like a cape.
Bible; Biblical. Eng. Wehe i ka Paipala (Nānā 204), open the Bible [at random, select a passage and interpret this as help or solution to a problem].
See Paipala
Pumpkin pie.
Cakes of fine flour. (Nah. 6.15).
Printing press; to print.
Loaves. (1 Sam. 25.18).
Pipe, faucet. Eng. Paipu lawe ʻino, sewage system.
Pumpkin pie.

1. Calabash, wooden dish in general, cooking utensil, bowl (Ier. 52.18) (preceded by ke). Cf. waihona pā ipu.

2. To beat a gourd drum; the drum itself and accompanying chant and sitting dance by the chanter; also hula kuolo.
To whitewash, plaster. Lit., to slap coral.
To fete a favorite (punahele), especially by composing songs in his honor, and staging dances and feasts for him; an expression of love for a favorite.
Fine, white tapa.
Cooked and compressed sweet potatoes allowed to ferment slightly and used as a substitute for poi when poi was scarce. Also poi ʻuala by analogy with poi.

1. Tapa made by beating red rags or tapa pieces to form a mixture of white and red (as outer or kilohana sheet for bedcovers). Also welu ʻula. Cf. moelola.

2. Calabash receptacle for sarongs, (AP)
Chest-slapping hula. (PCP paki umauma; cf. Marquesan pakiuma).
Nine times, nine at a time, to divide by nine or distribute to nine.
Cluster of grapes.
A draw or tie; to have a draw or tie. Cf. paʻi 2.

1. To remove the dregs, such as fibers, from herbs used for medicine; to strain.

2. To criticize constructively, as chanting; to look for flaws in order to perfect; to teach, correct.

3. Raindrops, patter of rain, especially of big drops.

4. Same as kākala, cartilage.

5. Kaʻū name for ʻōpakapaka, a fish.

6. Tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum), a hairy annual herb from tropical America, which may grow nearly 2 m high, introduced to Hawaiʻi in about 1812. It was tried out unsuccessfully from 1908 to 1929 as a possible industry. Plants are now growing both wild and cultivated. (Neal 752). Wild tobacco (Nicotiana glauca). (Neal 751).

7. Butter (usually follows waiū). Eng.

8. Also bata n. Curds. (Kin. 18.8, KJV). Eng.

9. Bugger. Eng.

1. Park. Eng.

2. To park, as a car. Eng.

1. Var. of pākaʻa 1.

2. To cut in long slices, to hack, as pig or fish for salting; to cut back, as a plant.

3. To scramble, as eggs.

4. To surf, as with canoe, board, or body; to skim, as a surfing canoe; to skip stones.

5. Sinker on a fish line for deep-sea fishing. (For. 4:293).

6. To fish with hook and line but no pole, as ulua. Also kākā.

7. Var. of pākākā 1.

8. Wrinkled. Rare. Cf. pākāeaea, pakalua.

9. Same as hoka, to strain. Rare.

1. Lean, as meat.

2. Var. of ʻākaʻa.

3. To converse, tell interesting tales or anecdotes. Rare.
Forty at a time; to divide by forty or distribute to forty. See ex., pāhoe.
Same as pākaʻuwili, kaʻawili; spiral.
Wrinkled. Cf. pākā 8.

A native herb (Lepechinia [Sphacele] hastata) found only at altitudes of 600 to 1800 m on East Maui. It is a mint, 1 to 1.5 m high, more or less downy, with large leaves and clustered, narrow red-violet flowers. (Neal 732.)

1. To cheat, fleece, plunder, rob, raid; robbery, raid, etc. See song, ʻānulu.

2. A kind of shell, perhaps a conch. See maile pākaha.

A native fern (Pleopeltis thunbergiana), with related forms in Asia and Africa, common on forest trees. A creeping, underground stem bears erect, short-stemmed, narrow fronds 15 to 30 cm long. (Neal 25.) Also ʻēkaha ʻākōlea, puaʻakuhinia.
Snuff. Lit., inhaling tobacco.
Welcoming call; to call in welcome.
Singly, once, one at a time, one by one, respectively, separately, apiece, individually; to distribute one at a time or one apiece.
Snuff. Lit., smelling tobacco.

1. Spleen amaranth (Amaratihus dubius), a coarse, erect, spineless, weedy, tropical herb; it looks much like spinach, and the young plants are similarly used.

2. Slender amaranth (Amaranthus viridis), resembling the spleen amaranth and used for greens. It differs in its habit of spreading close to the ground. (Neal 334.) Called ʻāheahea in some localities and pakapakai on Niʻihau.

1. Same as līpahapaha, sea lettuce.

2. Same as halāliʻi, a variety of sugar cane; named for the seaweed.

3. A variety of taro.

4. Name of a wind at Wai-ʻanae, Oʻahu.

5. Name of a type of wave at Kai-mū, Hawaiʻi.

A fish, perhaps an ʻōpakapaka.

Spiny amaranth (Amaranthus spinosus), a widespread, weedy herb, 30 to 70 or 80 cm high, with many branches bearing narrow or ovate leaves, each leaf with a pair of spines at the base, and male flowers in long spikes. (Neal 333–4.)

1. Low and broad, especially of a wooden bowl or door; a low, wide wooden bowl, according to Buck the largest ever made.

4. To inflate, blow up, as a balloon with air.

1. Gray-backed tern (Sterna lunata), also called the bridled, spectacled, or gray wide-awake tern. The forehead is white, as is a broad stripe over the eye; the nape, the top of the head and a stripe through the eye are black; the upper parts are dark ashy, with white beneath.

2. Same as pākala 1, 2.

3. A coarse, nonedible seaweed (Galaxaura spp.) Cf. kaunoʻa, ʻōkala, pākolekole, pilikoʻa.

1. Ripe, mellow; yellow, as leaves; soft, as an infected boil; rotten, as taro corm. Cf. huapala, pala ʻehu, pala heheʻe, pala lau hala.

2. Daub, smear, smudge, blot; dab of excreta (cf. pala kūkae). Cf. also ʻai pala maunu, hāpala, kāpala, pala niho, pala ʻole.

3. Underdone.

4. Coated, as the tongue. Cf. waha pala.

5. A form of gonorrhea.

6. Intoxicating drink made of watermelon juice.

7. A native fern (Marattia douglasii), with a short trunk and large, long-stemmed, much divided, dark-green fronds. In time of famine, the thick, starchy, hoof-shaped bases of the frond stems, which cover the short trunk, were eaten after being baked in an imu over night. The mucilaginous water resulting from slicing and soaking the raw stems in water was used medicinally. Pieces of the fronds mixed with maile leis enhanced their fragrance. The fern was used also in heiau ceremonies. (Neal 6, 7.) (PNP pala.)

8. A variety of sweet potato.

9. A variety of taro.

10. Seaweeds or scum.

11. Parlor. Eng.

1. A native fern (Microlepia setosa), growing wild and cultivated, 95 to 130 cm high. The lacy, ovate fronds look much like those of the palaʻā but are somewhat hairy instead of smooth. (Neal 12.) The palai was one of the important plants placed on the hula altar to Laka, goddess of hula; it is famous in song (see wilia). Also palapalai. See ex. popohe.

2. To turn the face away, as in embarrassment, confusion, humility; bashful; to conceal one's true feelings; to cloak dissatisfaction or feign friendship; hypocritical (Kel. 130) (often used with maka).

3. Also parai, farai vt. To fry; frying, fried. Eng. Palaoa palai, pancake.
A variety of palai, a fern.

1. Flexible, inconstant, changeable.

2. To play the game of loop and ball; the game itself: a flexible stick made of braided coconut leaflets with a 
loop at one end and a tapa ball on a string attached below the loop, the object being to catch the ball in the loop; this game was often played to a chant.
A native filmy fern (Vandenboschia davalioides), climbing on trees in damp forests, with narrow dark-green fronds, 13 cm long or more, divided three times. Lit., creeping palai.

1. End, closing, closure, very last, conclusion, finish, cessation, breaking off or cutting short; definitive, classic.

1. The prickly pear (Opuntia megacantha), a Mexican branching cactus about 4.5 m high, with a cylindrical trunk, and green, succulent, flattened, oblong to ovate joints, from which protrude many spines 
about 2.5 cm long. Flowers are yellow or orange, large; the fruit is ovoid, about 8 cm long, yellow or purple, spiny. This cactus is a weed in Hawaiʻi; the fruits are eaten or made into liquor. Lit., fence wall. (Neal 607–8.) In some localities called pāpipi.

2. A variety of sweet potato.
The true aloe (Aloe vera syn.
The name of a seaweed.
Same as niniʻo, spotted.

The night-blooming cereus (Hylocereus undatus), a Mexican cactus with succulent, green, jointed, three-winged stems that climb on trees and walls. About 1830 it was brought to Hawaiʻi, where during summer and fall it bears large numbers of large white flowers which open in the evening and last only until the next morning. (Neal 609–11.) A famous hedge is at Puna-hou School (formerly called Ka-puna-hou). Lit., Ka-puna-hou cactus. Also pāpipi pua.
Smooth.
Same as niʻo.
Late var. of paniolo, cowboy.

1. A variety of sweet potato.

2. A variety of taro.

1. Cowboy (sometimes called paniolo pipi to distinguish from paniolo 2.

2. Spaniard, Spain; Spanish. (Spanish, españnol.)
Bottle stopper, cork.
Redup. of pāniʻo.

1. Redup. of pani, to close.

2. Coition, or to practice such (vulgar).

3. Small outrigger canoe. Rare.
Cat's-eye. Lit., shell closure.
Var. of panepoʻo.
Plug or wad of a gun. Rare.
Door, gate; cover of an opening; beggar sitting near a doorway.
A cat's-eye, operculum, valve or round substance that closes a shell. Lit., shell closure.
Dam, sluice, levee, dike.
Dark, as clouds; obscure, black, shiny-black, deep blue-black. Fig., unapproachable as the unknown, said of very high chiefs believed to be of divine descent. Cf. pano paʻu.
Barren, arid, desert, dry, hot, parched. Also ʻanoa.

1. Easily taken, of a woman at the beck and call of any man. Lit., touch freely.

2. Lightweight wood. Rare.
Full of holes, cracked. (And.)

2. Scarce, very rare.

1. The young of the nenue, a fish.

2. A seaweed.
Full of holes, cracks; cracked. Rare.

1. Same as hoʻomanaʻo.

2. Same as pānoanoa.

3. A seaweed.
Redup. of pano.
Glossy, glistening black, sooty-black; black streaks in grain of wood.
Somewhat wet. Rare.
Short, stumpy, thick.
Somewhat wet. Rare.

1. Probably same as pānuhunuhu 1.

2. Thrifty, as of plants. Rare.

1. Stareye parrot fish (Calotomus sandvicensis), said to be second growth stage of uhu. Also pōnuhunuhu, p_auhu.

2. Same as pānuhu 2.
Perhaps the same as pānuhunuhu, or a different type of uhu.

A native member of the gourd family (Sicyos cucumerinus), a more or less climbing herb with variable leaves, which range from entire and rounded to many-lobed. The fruit is narrow, about 2.5 cm long, grooved, one-seeded.
Same as pānuhu 1, 2. Rare.

1. To scoop out, dub out, as a log for a canoe, or as of the action of the sea on the coast; to peck, chisel out, gouge, undermine, erode, bore. Fig., blunt, cruel, harsh in speech; to rebuke; digging, scooping, etc. (preceded by ke). Cf. paokeʻe, paokoke, paomoni.

2. To insert, stick in, as wood into a fire; to stoke, as coal into a furnace. Cf. imu pao, pao ahi.

3. Cave, pit, cavern.

4. Arch of a bridge, bridge.

1. Strongly odoriferous; a strong odor, whether pleasant or unpleasant.

2. Unlucky, unsuccessful, as in fishing or sex; bad luck. [But cf. iwi paoa under paoa 1.] Na wai e ʻole ka paoa, ua kāhea kua ʻia, who can help having bad luck, when called from behind the back.

3. To have a taste or desire for (usually used with waha, mouth), Paoa ka waha i ke kanaka, the mouth loves the taste of man [said of a shark].

4. Rare. var. of pawa, predawn. See ex., alaula.

The divining rod by which Pele tested the suitability of areas for excavation on the island of Nihoa, at various places on Oʻahu (Salt Lake, Punchbowl, Diamond Head, Maka-puʻu), and on Maui. Finally she planted the staff at Pana-ʻewa, Hawaiʻi, and it became a tree. (PH x–xii.)
To stoke a fire; stoker. Lit., fire inserter.
Imperfect, as in speech. Rare.
To limp.
Powder. Eng.
See paoka
To slander, betray, defame; slanderer, traitor.
To betray one's relatives or those close (koke) to one.
Quick recovery from sickness; quick healing; to recover or heal quickly. Cf. pāmake. Rare.
Rare. var. of pūʻolo.
To contend with, make war on, Rare.
Pound (Eng.), balance, scales, weight. Cf. kaupaona.
Balance, scales. Lit., equally placed poundage.
Baby scales.
Disagreement, argument, contention; to argue, quarrel; envy (Biblical).
Redup. of pāoni.
By sixes, sixfold; to divide by sixes; to have six or distribute to six.

Name for several varieties of ʻoʻopu, especially Istiblennius zebra, Entomacrodus marmoratus (marbled blenny); also called rockskippers because of their ability to leap across stretches of rocky shoreline. The name may be qualified by the terms kauila (Exallias brevis, shortbodied blenny), luahine, puhi. Pāoʻo figure prominently in legends and for some are ʻaumākua. See ex., haʻapupū. Also pānoʻo. (PEP paoko.)
Broken or discarded portions of sweet potatoes; sprouting bits of these fragments.
Redup. of pao 1, 2.
A species of ulua, a fish (Caranx speciosus); green and yellow with vertical green bands; considered one of the best fishes for eating raw.
See paʻopaʻo
Name of a star (no data).
Name given to young of the hou, a fish.

1. Flat surface, stratum, plain, reef, layer, level, foundation, story of a building, floor, class, rank, grade, order, table, sheet, plate, shelf (rare), face (of a watch); flat, level; to be a great many. Cf. aliʻi papa, noho papa 1, papa aliʻi.

2. Native-born, especially for several generations (see noho papa 2); offspring of the mating of an individual of piʻo, naha, or nīʻaupiʻo rank, with one of kaukaualiʻi rank; the lowest ranking aristocrat.

3. Set close together, thick together, as of growing plants; in unison, all together. Cf. holopapa, kāpapa, neʻepapa, papapū.

4. Board, lumber; wooden.

5. A variety of kava. The name may be qualified by the colors ʻeleʻele, kea.

6. Middle portion of a fishing net, bag net.

7. Wind associated with Honua-ʻula, Maui. (For. 5:101.)

8. Stone used as sinker for lūheʻe, octopus lure. (Malo 19.)

9. Wafer. (Puk. 29.2.)
See "hoʻopapa":  Purification of woman after childbirth, involving medicinal herbs bound to the abdomen, and a taboo on sex relations. (Malo 138.)
To blow, as the wind; to sound, echo; to shine, as sun or moon. Cf. pā 4.

1. To forbid, prohibit, taboo.

2. To touch, as of two objects; contest (same as hoʻopāpā [a]).

3. A small, active green-colored crab, perhaps Percnon planissimum.

4. Papa (introduced by white missionaries, who thought it rude for children to call father by first name). Eng.
Redup. of pā-, preceding numerals.
Redup. of paʻa 1; tight, secure, especially of a walled stronghold; to hold back.

1. Cooked crisp, as pig; overdone, burned, parched; scab, of a sore; crust. Cf. palaoa pāpaʻa, pāpaʻa palaoa and saying, kūmau 2.

2. Slice, as of bread; uncut piece. Cf. pāpaʻa hao, pāpaʻa lepo, pāpaʻa palaoa, pāpaʻa pelena.

3. Cluster of tiny red and yellow feathers tied together fanwise, as presented to a chief to be used for featherwork. Also paʻaʻāa 1.

4. A red sugar cane with light-brown fibers; it has an odor similar to burnt sugar, hence its name. Used in love sorcery.

5. Bark, as of trees.

6. Same as pākiʻi 2, fish.

7. Wind names. See below.

Scrap iron.

To crackle, snap; crackling, snapping; sharp crack, as of something breaking, or of crackling sound of feet walking over a crusty surface; to crack, as joints; brittle, easily broken. Cf. ʻuʻina.
A gentle Kauaʻi wind with rain that reaches Niʻihau.

Slabs of salted and dried goat meat.

1. Foundation or surface, as of the earth; floor, as of ocean; bed, as of a stream; bottom.

3. A disease with severe constipation (AP) or accompanied by vomiting, back pains, belching, red eyes (Ka Leo a ka Lahui, Feb. 7, 1893).

1. All species of a native genus (Charpentiera), shrubs and small trees, belonging to the amaranth family. Formerly on the north coast of Kauaʻi, Hawaiians used the wood, which is light and inflammable, for fireworks, throwing burning pieces from cliffs. (Neal 332.)

2. Firebrand, as hurled from the cliffs in the famous Kauaʻi sport, so called because pāpala wood was often used.

3. Haze, fog; hoarse, as the voice. Rare.
Board, plank, any large wooden platter, lumber.
To fence, to hit repeatedly with sticks.
Plank. Lit., wide wooden board.

Name of a lua fighting stroke, perhaps from pāpala kāʻili ʻula, red snatching firebrand.

Three native species of trees in the four-o'clock family, belonging to the genus Pisonia. (Neal 335.) Lit., gum pāpala; the gum was used for bird catching. See also āulu 3.

Hat made by plaiting a long strip, as of coconut or bamboo, which was then sewn into a hat. Some of the braids were alahaka-o-Nuʻalolo, ʻekeʻeke, iwi-puhi, kala hale, lū, haka-o-Hale-a-ka-lā. Lit., basket hat, so called because the narrow strip is similar to that used in making the basket ʻie.
Mitre, priestly hat. (Oihk. 8.9.)
Felt hat. Lit., California (Eng.) hat.
Cap. Lit., cap (Eng.) hat.

1. Low, flat, as a reef. Cf. hāpapa.

(Used in loaʻa-type constructions, , as: E pau nō kēia hana iā kākou, we will finally finish this work; also an intensifier before verbs: see pau ʻeka, pau kilo, pau lehia, pau ʻono, pau pāʻele.

1. A native beach vine (Jacquemontia sandwicensis), in the morning-glory family, with pale blue or white flowers and small rounded leaves. Lit., sarong of Hiʻiaka, so named because the goddess Pele, on returning from a long morning's fishing trip, found that this little vine had spread itself over her baby sister, Hiʻiaka, whom she had laid on the beach, and had protected the baby from the sun. (Neal 710.) Also kākua-o-Hiʻiaka.

2. A kind of red seaweed with wide, thin thallus. Perhaps same as limu hāʻula.

3. Same as lepe-o-Hina, a seaweed.

4. A variety of taro: petiole and leaf have smoky look; corm white, used to make good, gray poi.

5. A variety of sweet potato.

Cooked taro leaves. (PH 74.) Commonly called lūʻau.
Pas/imp. of peu 1, 2.
Dull, blunt. Fig., stupid, dull.

1. Same as pepeu.

2. Same as peue.

1. Tail of fish, shrimp, lobster. Cf. hiʻu.

2. Rectangular patch or wedge used for mending bowls, perhaps so called because of a resemblance to a fishtail.

3. Rare. var. of pawa 1, usually following huli.

4. Clump or group, as of trees near a forest.

1. Pectoral fins of a fish; to move or vibrate these fins.

2. Redup. of pewa 4.

1. Stingy, miserly, niggardly; stinginess (sometimes preceded by ke).

2. Sputtering, smoldering, as green wood that burns poorly; to snort, as a horse; to sniffle or have difficulty breathing due to a congestion in the nose, as caused by a cold; to break wind with a slight sputtering sound. See maka pī.

3. To sprinkle, as water with the fingers.

4. Peas, lentils (2 Sam. 17.28); a kind of bean; hyacinth bean (Dolichos lablab) or Lima bean. Eng. Called pāpapa in some localities.

5. The letter “p.” Eng.

1. Polynesian arrowroot (Tacca leontopetaloides, formerly known as T. pinnatifida), an herb known in the eastern tropics, formerly cultivated in Hawaiʻi for the starchy tubers, which were used for medicine and food. In spring or summer, a few leaves rise on long stems from a tuber and die back in the winter. The blades are much divided, about 30 cm wide, somewhat like papaya leaves in shape. Cf. māʻili 2. (HP 212, Neal 228–9.)

2. General name for starch; starch made from arrowroot is called pia Hawaiʻi to distinguish from other starches; pia is used in haupia pudding, as medicine, and as talcum powder.

3. Pale yellow. Cf. hala pia, a pandanus, and hēpia, of the ʻilima flower.

4. A variety of taro. (HP 34.)

5. A variety of sweet potato. (HP 142.)

6. A kind of stone, as used for adzes.

7. Also bia n. Beer. Eng. Bia nui, lager beer.

8. Stork.
A kind of yam (Dioscorea pentaphylla), a climber with lobed leaves known throughout Pacific islands and in tropical Asia. It bears small aerial and subterranean, edible tubers. (HP 215, Neal 230–1.)

1. Cluster, as of bananas, grapes. Rare.

2. Measure of one hand's distance. (For. 5:645.)
Small fish, as ʻōhua manini.
See pia 2.
Same as piʻa.

1. Same as pīʻao 1.

2. Any berry-like fruit, as of māmaki, olonā, ʻōhelo. Rare.
Young manini fish.
Wrinkled with age, as with sagging eyelids or jowls; a term of reproach for a man who has lost his sexual potency; an impotent male.
A type of stone used for adzes. See pia 6.
Starch made of manioc.
Piano. Eng.
Same as pī wai anuhea, sweet pea.

1. To fold ti leaves into a cuplike package, as for dipping water or for baking food in the oven; such a package.

2. Curling or shriveling, as of leaves in the heat; crumpling up, as of meeting waves. (Isa. 25.5.)

Alphabet; name of an early spelling book; this word is said to have derived from the method of teaching Hawaiians to begin the alphabet “b, a, ba.” The Hawaiians pronounced “b” like “p” and said “pī ʻā pā.” See ex., puana 2.

1. The encrusted white matter in the eyes, as from sleeping or sore eyes, “sand” in the eyes; to get such matter in the eyes; an abusive epithet applied to one who was unwashed, said to refer to genitals.

2. A variety of taro.

3. A variety of sweet potato. (HP 142.)
Var. of piele 1. Rare.
Rare.

1. Mattery eruptions or eczema on the scalp; to have such eruptions.

2. To trade, peddle; trader, peddler.

3. Pudding of grated taro, sweet potato, yam, banana, or breadfruit, baked in ti leaves with coconut cream.
Redup. of piele 1–3.
Offensive to smell, stinking. Rare.
Fiery-tempered; to shy, of a horse. Cf. ʻena.
Redup. of piena. Rare.
Redup. of pīʻena.
Redup. of pie. Rare.

1. Redup. of piele 1–3.

2. To do small favors in order to receive greater ones; to flatter or fawn in order to receive something.
Eczema, a name for kauā, outcasts.
Full, complete, filled, loaded; full-blooded; completion, capacity, fullness; pregnant. Cf. piha makahiki, pihapiha, piha pono.

1. Material of any sort carried by flood waters or sea, flotsam and jetsam, driftwood, floating debris.

2. A round herring (Spratelloides delicatulus); the largest is about 8 cm long; preferred dried and salted.

3. To belch.

4. Poi pounder. (AP)

1. Same as pīhā 1.

2. Same as pīhā 2.
Mynah bird (Acridotheres tristis), introduced from India in 1865. Lit., full of ʻekelo sound. Also ʻekelo.
Spirited, enthusiastic.
Brimful, jammed full, packed tight, crowded.
Handful.
Yearly anniversary; to have an annual anniversary. See ex., pewa 3.
Fullness, filling up, completion. See ex., heana 2.
Silent, weak-voiced.

1. Full, complete; filled; full and flowing, as a garment; filed, as cards; completed, as a questionnaire.

2. Gills of a fish.

3. Ruffle, fringe, as on a dress. (Nah. 15.38.) Lima pihapiha, ruffled sleeve.

4. Var. of ʻōpihapiha.
Ruff.
Pleated ruffle. Lit., whaler's ruffle, so called because such ruffles were stylish in whaling days.
See "hoʻopihapiha ʻōlelo":  To stir up dislike for another, to turn against another, as by telling tales or gossip.
Completely full, complete.
Completely filled.
Spoonful.
Jam-packed, packed tight, full, crammed.

1. Temporary bed made of dry ʻilima branches, dried banana leaves and grasses, over which a mat or two were spread.

2. Full of grass, but thin, said of a grass-eating animal that does not put on flesh.
A fish (no data).
Din of voices, crying, shouting, wailing, lamentation; to mourn, shout, etc.
Pas/imp. of pihe.
Inflamed, of eyes. Cf. heka.
Redup. of pīheka.
Grated, mashed, pulverized; to grate.

1. Scab, scar.

2. Button, badge; to button (preceded by ke). Cf. huka pihi, pihi pūlima.

3. Blunt, dull, as a wooden digging stick. Rare.

4. Fish. Eng. Ua loaʻa mai ka pihi nui (song), got the big fish.

1. Redup. of pihi 1; scarred.

2. Redup. of pihi 2; any small objects shaped like buttons, as washers (preceded by ke).

3. To skip stones on the surface of the water; stone skipping.

4. Redup. of pihi 3. Rare.
Cuff button.

1. Swamp, mire; swampy.

2. Var. of piholo, to swamp, as a canoe. (For. 5:541.) hoʻo.pihō Caus/sim.
Dizzy. (And.)
Same as pihōpihō.
Same as ʻaukoʻi, a plant.
Same as pīhoihoi.
Disturbed, excited, worried, agitated, alarmed, perturbed, upset, uneasy, astonished, emotional; worry, anxiety, astonishment. (Dan. 5.6.) Hana pīhoihoi, exciting event, adventure.
To fidget, as a child; to paw, as a drunk; to squirm, flirtatiously sidle up to a man; restless.
To sink, founder, drown, be swamped, shipwrecked.

1. Redup. of piholo.

2. Watery, as poi. Rare.
Bishop; Episcopalian. Eng. Hoʻomona Pīhopa, Episcopalian religion.
See pīhopa
Redup. of pihō; to bob up and down or swamp, as a canoe.
Hairy, fuzzy.

1. To go inland or overland (whether or not uphill), to go or walk up, climb, ascend, advance, mount, rise; to grow up, as a child; to fall, as one shadow on another. See ihu piʻi.

2. To experience personally, or appear, as heat, cold, emotion. See ex., maneʻo.

3. Same as piʻipiʻi 3, curly. (PEP piki.)

4. Same as pipiʻi, expensive.

5. Intercourse; to practice intercourse; to mount, as of male animals.

6. Triangular piece inserted in a holokū skirt to add width, or inserted at the base of the legs of bell-bottom trousers.

7. Taros. See below.

See "hoʻopiʻi":  To sue (see ex., mālama ola), bring suit, bring a complaint to one in authority, accuse in court, prosecute, petition; appeal, lawsuit, court case, petition. Cf. palapala hoʻopiʻi. Mea i hoʻopiʻi ʻia, accused. Hoʻopiʻi ʻāina, to have a suit over land matters. Poʻe (mea) hoʻopiʻi, plaintiff. Poʻe (mea) hoʻopiʻi ʻia, defendant, accused party. Hoʻopiʻi poho, suit for damages.
Pas/imp. of piʻi 1.

A native variety of taro, one of the oldest varieties grown in Hawaiʻi; formerly known as one of the royal taros and desirable as an offering to the gods; today, an important wet-land poi taro. Leaves and corm are tinged with pink. (HP 28, Whitney.) This name may be qualified by the colors ʻeleʻele, keʻokeʻo, ʻulaʻula. See ex., hanoa.
To claim chiefly blood, whether or not it exists.
A variety of taro. (HP 34.)
To become light, as the day; to begin to gray, of hair.
To claim honors not rightfully due, to seek preferment, to aspire to the best or to more than is one's due; to claim to be of higher rank than one is. See ex., loaʻa … kāu.

1. To climb a steep slope; to climb, as a coconut palm by grasping the trunk with the hands and walking up with the feet; a steep climb.

2. A medicine made of the sap of young kukui nuts, used as a gargle for sore throat and thrush; if swallowed it causes nausea and looseness of the bowels.

3. Transpiration, water drops on leaves of plants. Rare. Cf. wai hua.
A type of ancient prayer. (For. 6:23.)
Haughty, proud. Lit., forehead rising. Rare.
Octave. Lit., eightfold ascent.

1. Redup. of piʻi 1; bubbling forth, as water (Kanl. 8.7); to overflow, as charged water; effervesce.

2. Redup. of piʻi 2. Cf. piʻipiʻi kai, piʻipiʻi ʻōlelo.

3. Curly, curled, wavy.

4. Same as pipiʻi, expensive.

5. Redup. of piʻi 5.

6. Same as mānienie ʻula, a grass.
Redup. of piʻialiʻi.
To rise, of a strong sea. Fig., to flare, as anger.
Same as ʻanaliʻi, a fern.
Words of anger, emotion, controversy.

1. Short for pīkaʻo 2. Rare.

2. Pitcher (Eng.), vase.

3. Beet (Beta vulgaris). (Neal 331.) Eng.

4. Picul; half. Eng.

5. Hot, as peppery food (said in pidgin Eng.).

To sprinkle with sea water or salted fresh water to purify or remove taboo, as formerly done after a 
death or after a boy's subincision. (Na_na_ 179–82.) Pī kai kea, to sprinkle with white sea [from waves, and not with salted fresh water].
Redup. of pī kai.
To sprinkle with sea water or salt water, with a bit of ʻōlena root, to purify or remove taboo.

1. Smooth, polished. Rare.

2. Same as pīkaʻo 1. Rare.
Var. of pākākā.

A rattlebox (Crotalaria pallida, formerly known as C. mucronata), known in many tropical countries, a small, weedy, shrubby legume with three-parted leaves, yellow flowers striped with red, and many-seeded pods to 5 cm long. (Neal 443, 445.)
Redup. of pīkaʻo 1.

1. The Arabian jasmine (Jasminum sambac), introduced from India, a shrub or climber, with rounded, dark-green leaves and small, white, very fragrant flowers used for leis. Since Princess Ka-ʻiu-lani was fond of both these flowers and her peacocks (pīkake), the same name was given the flowers. (Neal 680.)

2. Peacock, peafowl (Pavo cristata), said to have been introduced to Hawaiʻi about 1860. They are wild on Niʻihau and at Wai-ʻanae, Oʻahu.
A creeping pīkake.
A low shrubby plant (Clerodendrum philippinum), from China, a weed with broad, downy leaves and white or pink, scented, double flowers. (Neal 731.) Lit., bad smelling.
The star jasmine (Jasminum multiflorum), a shrubby, somewhat downy vine, from India. Leaves are ovate or cordate; flowers white, 2.5 cm wide, starlike, with four to nine lobes. (Neal 679–80.)
The single-flowered form of pīkake.
The yellow jasmine (Jasminum humile), a shrub from tropical Asia. It has compound leaves and yellow flowers about 2.5 cm wide. (Neal 681.)
The double-flowered form of pīkake.
Same as pīkake hohono. Oʻahu.
Pickle. Eng.
Sticky, as water on a poi board after poi has been pounded on it; the watery residue.
Redup. of pīkale.
Var. of pīkananā.
Quick-tempered, snappish, cross; raging, storming.
Small, very little. Rare.
Var. spellings of pikiniki, picnic.
See pikanika
Small (slang, from pickaninny).

1. Dehydrated food, as yam cooked, grated, dried, packed in banana fiber, used on long sea voyages; dried up, juiceless, parched (applied jestingly to old hags). (For. 6:386.) Cf. pokaʻo.

2. Canoe hold under both the foreward cover and after cover.

1. Suction cups on octopus tentacles.

2. A kind of lava rock with points said to resemble the suction cups of an octopus.

3. Variegated, spotted; of varying colors, as the ocean.
Flower container, vase. Lit., flower pitcher.
To pick up, as a rooster picks up food. Rare.
Water pitcher.
Pistachio (Pistacia vera). (Neal 524.) Eng.
See pikekakio
Name of a skin eruption.
Pitcher. Eng. Rare.
Same as pīkanele. Rare.
Redup. of pīkele. Rare.

1. Shrunk, shortened, irregular.

2. The peach (Prunus persica), possibly a native of China, introduced to Hawaiʻi but not common. (Neal 395–6.)

3. Beet. Eng. Also pika.

1. Fiji; Fijian. Eng.

2. Also P.K. n. Provisional Government. Eng.
Redup. of piki 1. Rare.
Bituminous; coal. Eng. Lānahu pikimana, bituminous coal.
Business. Eng. ʻAʻohe ou pikineki malaila, you have no business there.
Picnic. Eng.

1. To pinch or squeeze, as in milking. Rare. Cf. ʻūpikipiki. (PCP pitipiti; cf. Marquesan.)

2. Same as pikipikiʻō.
Rough, stormy, choppy, as the sea. Fig., agitated in spirit.

1. Navel, navel string, umbilical cord. Fig., blood relative, genitals. Cf. piko pau ʻiole, waiʻolu.

2. Summit or top of a hill or mountain; crest; crown of the head; crown of the hat made on a frame (pāpale pahu); tip of the ear; end of a rope; border of a land; center, as of a fishpond wall or kōnane board; place where a stem is attached to the leaf, as of taro.

3. Short for alopiko.

4. A common taro with many varieties, all with the leaf blade indented at the base up to the piko, junction of blade and stem. (HP 29.)

5. Design in plaiting the hat called pāpale ʻie.

6. Bottom round of a carrying net, kōkō.

7. Small wauke rootlets from an old plant.

8. Thatch above a door.
A native variety of taro, with darkpurple petioles; common poi and table taro; the leaves are good for lūʻau. Also helemauna.
Slipknot. Lit., loop rope-end.

1. Core, as of breadfruit or pandanus. Also ʻīkoi.

2. A tripping club, as of wood or stone, with a rope attached; this was hurled at the foe to encircle his arms or legs and render him helpless. Also ʻīkoi.

3. Wooden floats attached to upper or head cord of gill nets. Cf. ʻalihi pīkoi.

1. Var. of pīkokoi.

2. Onanism, masturbation; to practice onanism or masturbation; one who does so. Fig., to work hard with little produce. (PCP piitoitoi.)
A type of dagger, perhaps used by lua fighters.
Rare. var. of pīkake, peacock. (1 Nal. 10.22.)
A native variety of taro widely planted; an important poi taro, especially on Oʻahu, distinguished by whitish piko and by leaf stems light-green with pinkish base. Also piko keʻokeʻo.
To swarm, as small fish coming to the surface with open mouths.
A native variety of taro, with leaves dark-green and crinkled below; the corms with lilac-purple flesh, yielding the popular lehua red poi; the leaves good for lūʻau. Lit., curly red piko taro.
Double crown of the head, a sign that a child will be persevering and determined.

1. Cord attaching floats to a fishing net.

2. Same as pīkoi 1.
Begonia (garden variety). Eng.
Type of braid used in the pāpale ʻie.

1. Equator.

2. Same as Ka-piko-o-Wā-kea.
Rat-taken navel cord, i.e., a chronic thief. It was believed that one became a chronic thief if his navel cord was stolen by a rat. Rats were famous for thieving.
Same as pikapika 1, 3.

A native variety of taro, one of the hardiest piko taros and perhaps the only kind common in upland culture; yields good grade light-colored poi; distinguished by dark-green leaf stems with a pinkish base.
A native variety of taro, distinguished from piko lehua ʻāpiʻi by having leaves smooth below; corms yield red poi of good grade.
Same as haehae 3, a taro.
Fig (Ficus carica). (Neal 309–11.) Eng. See ex., pāpalu.
See piku
Same as pikimana, bituminous; coal. Eng. Lua pikumena (Kin. 14.10), slime pit.

1. Any string instrument, formerly the fiddle; violin. Eng. Hoʻokani pila, to play music.

2. Also bilanvt. A bill; to make out a bill. Eng.

3. Also fira n. Fir. Eng. Lāʻau fira (Mele 1.17), fir.

4. To build, in a card game. (Eng. pile.)
String musical instrument.
Voucher.
Appropriation, allotment bill.
Autoharp. Lit., fiddle harp. Eng.
Thin, slim, frail, delicate.
Redup. of pīlahi.
Short for ʻūpī laho.
Promissory note. Lit., bill to extend credit.
Check, draft, bill.
Money order. Lit., post-office draft.
Blanket warrant.
Requisition.
Violin. Lit., rubbing fiddle.
Redup. of pīlahi.

1. White and black feathers under the tail of the ʻōʻō, a bird; used for kāhili, feather standards.

2. A seaweed.
Sticky, gummy, slimy, greasy.
Honey in a banana blossom, fed to small children.
Camphor. Lit., fragrant gum.
Thin, delicate, rickety. Rare.
Dried juice of prickly pear chewed as candy.
See pīlali pānini
Var. of pila ʻume ʻume.
Somewhat bad-smelling, not quite spoiled.
Harmonica, mouth organ. Lit., blowing fiddle.
Rot, stench, rottenness; to stink; putrid, spoiled, rotten, foul, decomposed. Cf. pilo, popopo.
Accordion. Lit., tugging fiddle.
Account, reckoning, as of an estate; invoice.
Gummy, sticky, gluey, moldy; mold.

1. To cling, stick, adhere, touch, join, adjoin, cleave to, associate with, be with, be close or adjacent; clinging, sticking; close relationship, relative; thing belonging to. Cf. ʻauipili, pili wale.

2. A grass (Heteropogon contortus) known in many warm regions, formerly used for thatching houses in Hawaiʻi; sometimes added to the hula altar to Laka, for knowledge to pili or cling; thatch (preceded by ke). (Neal 80.) Hale pili, house thatched with pili grass.

3. To refer, concern, relate, pertain, apply.

4. Shingles, so called because they replace the pili grass of the roofs of the old houses (preceded by ke).

5. A wager, bet, stake; to bet, wager. See piliwaiwai.

6. Border, edge of time units, especially of late night.

7. Uncolored sheets in a kuʻina, sleeping tapa.

8. Lining of a quilt under the layer of cotton or wool.

9. First stage of poi-pounding, with taro beginning to stick.

10. A narrow or precarious pass. Rare.

11. Same as ʻume, the game, so called because the wand touched (pili) the players. (Malo 215.) Rare.

12. Same as ʻōpili, numb.
Pas/imp. of pili 1, 3.
Rain name, Kani-kū, Hawaiʻi. (For. 5:93.)
Var. of piliʻaikū. Rare.
Cramped, stiff, numb. Rare.
Shore; interisland.
Bosom friend, beloved wife. Cf. pilikua.
Close friendship, beloved companionship, beloved relative; loving association; to have a loving or tender relationship, to be in a bond of love, romance.
To cling like a lizard, as on a cliff.
Present participle.
Past participle.
To resemble in character or nature.
Mate, spouse, common-law mate with whom one lives openly.
Wind associated with Ka-ʻawa-loa, Hawaiʻi, (For. 5:93.) Lit., near pandanus.
House shingle (preceded by ke).
Corrugated iron, as used for roofing (preceded by ke). Lit., iron shingles.
To become involved in gambling, usually disastrously; in the old days, to bet one's life or wife; to be involved in an entangling affair of any sort.
Love affair.
Sad, sorrowful, dejected, astonished, confused (Ier. 14.9), bewitched (Oih. 8.9); weary.
Shore, especially the area between high and low tides; near the shore.

1. A vine (Stictocardia tiliaefolia) in the morning-glory family, native from India eastward, possibly into Polynesia, long known in Hawaiʻi, as on roadsides and rocky shores. Flowers are funnel-shaped, rose-purple, about 5.1 cm in diameter, the leaves heartshaped. (Neal 702.)

2. The wood rose (Merremia tuberosa), another kind of morning-glory, with deep yellow flowers and five-to seven-lobed leaves, grown ornamentally in Hawaiʻi for its dry, brown, rose-shaped fruit. (Neal 709.)
Relationship by friendship rather than by blood or adoption. Lit., added-on relative.
Relation, relationship, kin, family. (Probably pili, to cling, + -kana, nominalizer; .) (PCP pilitanga.)

Trouble of any kind, great or small; problem, nuisance, bother, distress, adversity, affliction, accident, difficulty, inconvenience, perturbation, tragedy, lack; in trouble, troubled, bothered, cramped, crowded (2 Nal. 6.1), unsafe. Cf. -pau pilikia, wahi hoʻopau pilikia.
Personal, private, subjective, worldly.

1. Hawkfish (Paracirrhites forsteri, Cirrhitops fasciatus, Amblycirrhites bimacula), 18 cm or less in length and light-pink in color, Lit., coral clinging. Also Cirrhites pinnulatus and Oxycirrhites typus.

2. A native variety of sugar cane named for the fish; stems yellow-green, with pale brown-red stripes when young, changing to bronze-yellow with darker brown-red stripes.

3. A stiff kind of pākalakala, a seaweed (Galaxaura lapidescens).
To be closely related; to be very close, intimate.
Blood relationship, blood relative; related by blood.

1. Giant, large strapping fellow, country person, one living in the country; countrified.

2. Beloved husband. Cf. pilialo.

3. To fight in single combat. Rare.
To cling to the back.

1. Wooden house shingle.

2. Edge of a forest.
Dark green pandanus leaves with white bases, above the lāʻele, old leaves.
Of wide application, of broad or general interest.
A guessing game: to guess the contents of another's folded hand. Lit., wager hand.
A close relative, closely related; concerning local places.
A close companionship of two; to associate, of two; related in two ways.
Name of a pair of stars, said to bring ʻōpelu fish.

1. A native variety of sugar cane, a yellow-green mutant of ʻakilolo; used in hana aloha, love sorcery, with the prayer for love to cling and hold fast.

2. A variety of taro.

3. A variety of sweet potato.
Same as Ka-pili-maiʻuʻu, a stroke in lua fighting. Lit., clinging to fingernail.
Same as hoʻopilimeaʻai. Lit., close association [for] food.
Name of one of the tapas in the game of pūhenehene.
Article, the part of speech: ke, ka, he, nā.
Elder relative; preferred friend or companion; former associate.

1. Association, relationship, union, connection, meeting, joining, adhering, fitting. Cf. pili 1.

2. Springs, as of a mattress, watch, car. Eng. He manaʻo koʻu i ke kano koʻele; ua haki ka pilina a ʻo luna iho (song), my thought is of the snapping affair; the upper springs [of the automobile] were broken.
Rain name.
Bedsprings.
Kinship.
Family or social structure.
Billiards. Eng.
See piliʻoki
Unrelated, not concerned with.
Grammar, word or sentence structure.
Alongside a fence or enclosure; hedge (Luk. 14.23). See ex., kūpuku.
To stick firmly, associate constantly; to live in harmony; to fit closely, tenacious.
Shingle roofing.

1. Redup. of pili 1; any sticky matter, adhesive; pasty, gluey, viscid.

2. Same as pipili 2, an herb.
Close to land.
See "hoʻopilipili aliʻi":  To claim relationship to a chief, as of one only remotely related, or of one desirous of favors.

1. Thin ends of octopus tentacles, as braided together when dried.

2. Octopus or squid ink sac (ʻalaʻala) molded about a fishhook for bait.
Redup. of pilikana.
Same as pilikoʻa 3.
See "hoʻopilipili ʻōlelo":  Word play, punning; to illustrate a point with parables, stories, anecdotes.

A close blood relationship to one of high rank; this was said by persons entering the hale nauā, desirous of asserting their royal blood. (Malo 199, Emerson note.) Lit., red relationship [red was a sacred color].
Same as mānienie ʻula, a grass; also Desmodium uncinatum on Niʻihau.
Philippines; Filipino. Eng.
See Pilipino
Corrugated iron roofing.
A fish (no data).
To be close to the bosom or heart (affectionate).
Well-suited, well-matched; close-fitting, as clothes; to refer exactly or concisely.
To unite, join, cling to; hard-pressed, as in danger.

1. The period between midnight and dawn. Lit., near appearance [of the sun].

2. One of the tapa covers in the pūhenehene game, which were named for different parts of the night.
Spiritual.

A stiff, tufted, native grass (Trisetum glomeratum), 0.3 to 0.9 m high, with leaves 10.2 to 25 cm long and flowers crowded in narrow spikes; a good forage grass, growing only at rather high altitudes. On Hawaiʻi this is apparently called heʻupueo.
Gambling, betting, gambler; to bet, gamble. Lit., to wager wealth.
To cling, etc., for no reason or cause; often used in unfavorable sense of living off other people.
To believe. Eng. ʻA ʻole i piliwi ʻia (song), [it] was not believed.

1. Swampy, foul odor, as of a swamp; halitosis; polluted.

2. Some species of native shrubs, in the coffee family (Hedyotis [Kadual]), the leaves bad-smelling when crushed. See also kōī (Coprosma kauensis) and au 13.

3. All Hawaiian species of Coprosma, a genus of shrubs and small trees belonging to the coffee family, with narrow to rounded leaves, tiny greenish flowers, and yellow, red, or black berries.

4. Same as maiapilo (Capparis sandwichiana).

5. Any kind, any whatsoever (used with ʻaʻohe).
A small native tree or shrub (Platydesma spathulata), in the orange family; leaves large, thick, oblong, more or less pointed; flowers few, creamcolored; fruits small, dry, four-lobed.
A native shrub (Platydesma rostratum), with long, narrow leaves, clustered, axillary flowers, and beaked, four-lobed fruits.
Weak, small. Rare.
Redup. of pilo 1.
To shake, quiver, vibrate. Rare.

1. Redup. of pilu. Rare.

2. Overdressed, richly and elaborately overdressed, perhaps in a ridiculous way. Rare.
Beam, as for scales. Eng.
See pima
Pimento (Capsicum annuum). Eng.
See pimeneko
Rare. var. of pine.
See Holoholo-pīnaʻau.

1. Again and again, repeatedly; to come or do repeatedly, constant; to wear out a welcome by repeated visits; close together, crowded. Cf. kūpinaʻi, lele pīnaʻi.

2. To patch, fill up a crack or hole, as in wood.
To climb; a climb. See ex., ʻoe 1.
Same as pīnauea 1, 2. Rare.
Var. of pinapinaʻi.
To turn aside, as the head, or as the bow of a ship when struck by a large wave. Rare.

1. Dragonfly, (KL. line 290.) Cf. lelepinao. (PCP pingao.)

2. Flying gurnard, a fish (Dactylopterus orientalis). Also loloaʻu.

3. Blurred, as eyes of a drunkard. Similar to pōnalo 2.

4. Broad jump.

5. Perhaps a swing. (For. 6:374.)
Redup. of pinao 3.
A variety of dragonfly. Lit., red pinao.
Redup. of pīnaʻi.

1. To recoil, snap, as a rope. Rare.

2. See lelepinau.

1. Weak; of dim vision, as of an aged person.

2. Short and skimpy, as a skirt or pāʻū. Rare.

1. Pin, compass needle, peg, bolt, picket; stanchion to hold animal's head with yoke and pin; to pin. Eng. Kui pine, common pin.

2. A tame bullock tied to a newly captured wild cow or bull. When released it would lead the wild animal to a pen.
Falsehood, lie; liar; to lie. Rare.
Same as pine niho puaʻa. Rare. Lit., crescent pin.
Safety pin. Lit., diaper pin.
Clothespin. Lit., hanging pin.
Peanut (Arachis hypogaea). (Neal 450–1.) Eng. ʻAila pineki, peanut oil.
Vagina. Rare.
Hog's tooth pin. Formerly also called pine hoaka. Lit., pig tooth pin.
Stickpin, brooch.
Fence picket.
Frequent; often, many times, frequently. (PNP pine.)
Breast pin, brooch.
Vinegar; an intoxicating drink made of fermented molasses and water. Eng.
Var. of pilo 1, 2.
Var. of pilopilo.
Pigeon pea (Cajanus cajan).

1. Captive, prisoner, victim, prey; conquered, captured, made prisoner; game of tag; to play tag.

2. Extinguished or out, as a fire or light (used in pidgin English); disappeared, as a ship at sea; to have gone out of sight; to die down, as a wave.

3. To peep, chirp; to whistle with fingers on the mouth; to pipe on any flutelike instrument; peeping, peep.

4. A measure of three iwilei (yards), especially of cloth.

1. Arch, arc; bent, arched, curved; to arch, of a rainbow.

2. Marriage of full brother and sister of nīʻaupiʻo rank, presumably the highest possible rank. Their offspring had the rank of naha, which is less than piʻo but probably more than nīʻaupiʻo. Later piʻo included marriage with half-sibling. Cf. moe piʻo. (Malo 54.)

3. Same as kāpiʻo 1.
Tactless.
General name for barnacles. (KL. line 24.)
Same as pīnauea 1.
Long and sharp, as a pin; long and thin, spindly.
Same as pīʻoe.
Same as kanawao 1, small trees.

1. Kauaʻi name for hoi, the bitter yam (Dioscorea bulbifera).

2. See "Hawaiʻi":  name for edible fruit of the lama (Diospyros spp.) or perhaps kukui.
Half-shut, as eyes; to look with half-closed eyes.
Column of dust, cloud of dust. Lit., dirt arch.
To rub back and forth, saw; to pucker and unpucker the lips. Fig., to go over and over in the mind, to mull over, think. Cf. olo.
Short for piʻoloke.

Alarmed, startled, perturbed, vexed, disturbed, confused and excited, agitated, harassed; in 
noisy consternation; confusion, alarm (sometimes preceded by ke).
Intensifier of piʻolo.

1. Redup. of piolo. Rare.

2. Same as ʻapu, medicinal concoction; to feed such a concoction. Rare.

1. Same as piʻoloke. See ex., keʻele.

2. Same as pioloolo 2. Rare.
Redup. of piʻoloke.

1. Redup. of pio 1–3.

2. Same as pāpiopio, a fish.

3. Call to chickens.
Redup. of piʻo 1.

1. Alongside, as of a road, sidewalk, or river; to go along the side, turn to the side, dodge; sidewalk.

2. Kāʻeʻe bean and purgative made from it; the bean is also strung in leis.

3. Precipice, cliff. (And.)

4. Star name (no data).
Redup. of pīpā 1.

1. Hawaiian pearl oyster (Pinctada radiata); in songs this is known as the iʻa hāmau leo o ʻEwa, ʻEwa's silent sea creature [it was believed that talking would cause a breeze to ripple the water and frighten the pipi].

2. Feelers of an insect, as of an ant.

3. Same as moa 3 (Psilotum).

4. A kind of tapa.

5. Body depression; eyeball. Rare.

6. Lower part of an adze. (Malo 51.) Rare.

7. Also bipi Beef, cattle, ox. Eng. See pipi kāne, pipi wahine.
Redup. of pī 2; squinting; twinkling, as stars. Fig., barely surviving.

1. Redup. of pī 1, stingy.

2. Redup. of pī 3; to urinate (Eng.) A īnā e pīpī ʻia ke koko ona ma ke kapa komo (Oihk. 6.27), when there is sprinkled of the blood thereof upon any garment.

3. Female ʻōʻō, a honey eater.
Ox yoke.
Same as piʻipiʻi 1–5; the commonest meaning is “expensive, high-priced.” Wai pipiʻi, bubbling water, charged water, fountain.
To draw away, shrink away, as an octopus tentacle on a fire; to crinkle up, contract: to turn aside so as not to meet, avoid.
Bull. Lit., male beef.
Jerked beef (beef salted and dried in the sun, broiled before eaten). Lit., rope beef.
Ox. Lit., dragging beef.
Calf. Lit., child beef
Shrunk, crinkled; tight, cramped. Cf. piki 1, pipika, ʻūpiki.
Broiled beef, steak.
Yearling cow or bull.
Stew beef, beef stew.
Bison. Lit., beef [with] humped back.
Bull.
Some kinds of green seaweeds (species of Enteromorpha).

1. Same as pilipili; tenacious.

2. Drymaria (Drymaria cordata), a slender, weedy herb, with rounded leaves, tiny flowers, and tiny one-seeded dry fruits with sticky stems, which catch on passersby. It is a tropical shade-dwelling plant. (Neal 345.) Also pilipili.

3. Same as ʻihi kūkae hipa, kūkae hipa, a weed.
Redup. of pilikia.
Redup. of pilo 1. (PCP pipilo.)
Roast beef. Eng.
Var. of pipine.
Promiscuous; promiscuous person.
Miserly, stingy. Lit., stingy often.
To rain continuously; to jibber jabber, talk and argue continuously. Lit., constant sprinkling. Rare.
A kind of squash with edible shoots and fruit, commonly fed also to pigs, called chayote and pipinella by Neal 813, and Sechium edule. (Probably Portuguese pepineiro.)
Redup. of pio 1–3.
Redup. of piʻo 1.
See ohi 1.
Redup. of piʻolepo.
Water buffalo, carabao. Lit., Chinese beef.
Beefsteak. Lit., fried beef.

1. General name for small mollusks, including Theodoxus neglectus. (KL. line 32.) Lei pipipi, lei of pipipi shell, a new type of lei; formerly kūpeʻe ornaments were called lei pipipi because of a superficial resemblance. (PCP pipipi.)

2. Small and close together, as stars or pipipi shells; small, squinting, as eyes.

3. See hale pipipi.
Same as ʻākōlea 2.
See pipipi ʻākōlea
A mollusk (Planaxis labiosus). Lit., long-necked gourd ʻākōlea shell, so called because of its shape.
Redup. of piʻi 1–5.
Periwinkle (Littorina pintado, L. scabra). Lit., kōlea-bird shell, perhaps so called because ot its color. Also pūpū kōlea.
Periwinkle (Planaxis labiosus).
Steer. Lit., castrated beef.
Bull. Lit., bull beef. Eng.
Cow. Lit., female beef.
All species of a genus of sedges (Eleo charis). (Neal 87.) Also kohekohe.
To percolate, ooze, of water; to sprinkle water.
Milk cow.
Same as pī nūnū. Lit., Puerto Rican pea.
Pewter. (Nah. 31.22.) Eng.
Beauty. Eng.
See piuke

1. Mule, donkey (Molokaʻi).

2. A card game; the player must follow suit in discards, and if he cannot, he draws from a pack; the object is to play all of one's cards, and the player left with a card at the end is the piula. Also kēkake.

3. Tired, exhausted, worntify.

4. Pewter, tin (Nah 31.22), corrugated iron as used for roofing; any metal suggesting pewter. Eng. See pili piula.
Faucet, water tap, hydrant. Lit., water metal.
To fish ulua from the shore with a line but no pole.

1. Also fiwa Fever. Eng. Piʻi ka piwa, to have a temperature or fever.

2. Also biwa Beaver. Eng. Pāpale piwa, beaver hat.
Black plague.
Dengue fever.
Beaver hat. Eng.
Typhoid fever. Lit., weakening fever.

1. A variety of wild duck.

2. A type of hard rock used for adzes.
To sprinkle water. See ʻahaʻaina pī wai.
Sweet pea (Lathyrus odoratus). Also pī anuhea. (Neal 455.) Lit., cool, fragrant pea.
Yellow fever.
Scarlet fever.
Same as pō-. See poale, pohole, pokaʻi, poluhi.

1. Night, darkness, obscurity; the realm of the gods; pertaining to or of the gods, chaos, or hell; dark, obscure, benighted; formerly the period of 24 hours beginning with nightfall (the Hawaiian “day” began at nightfall, cf. ao 1.) Fig., ignorance; ignorant. Cf. Halāliʻi, Pōʻakahi, Pōʻalua.

2. Thick, dense, of flowers or heady fragrance; to issue perfume. See ex., niniu.

Time of, state of. See below, especially poʻeleʻele, pōhae, pōhihi, pōhina, pōʻino, pōkaʻa, pōkaʻo, pōlena, pōlewa, pōluku, pōmaikaʻi, pōnalo, pōniho, pōniu, pōpilikia, pōule. Also po-. (Probably PCP po(o)-.)
Robber, pirate; to rob, plunder. See ex., For. 5:489.
See pōā

1. Castrated, emasculated; eunuch. Cf. lio poʻa, pipi poʻa.

2. A sudden sound, as of flapping wings of a rooster, or of the thumping sound of the palms of the hands pressed together with fingers locked, or of hands striking the surface of the water; to make such sounds.

3. To dig under, undermine.

1. Redup. of pōʻaha 1.

2. The same as wauke, but the leaves commonly smaller, entire, and rounded. The leaves of wauke are commonly lobed.
To thump, as a drum with the base of the hand. Rare.
Same as poahi 1, 2. Rare.
Redup. of poaʻe.

1. Armpit.

2. Axil of coconut frond. (For. 5:595.)

1. Circle, as of flowers; ring, as of tapa about a sore that prevents friction; a round support for a calabash made of pandanus or ti leaves wrapped into a ring and bound with a cord.

2. General name for trailing plants.
Thursday; Congregational church meetings held weekly on Thursdays. Lit., fourth day.
Halo. Lit., light circle.
Hollyhock. (And.)

1. Dim, obscure.

2. To revolve, spin, go around; to rotate, of hips in a hula. Rare.
Redup. of poahi 1, 2.
Circle, circuit, hoop, girdle; group, as of friends; to go around, make a circuit, encircle, girdle, coil, wind up; circulating; encircled, surrounded. Also pōhai. See ex., poʻaha 1.
Redup. of pōʻai.
Monopoly. Lit., greedy circle.
Arctic Circle. Lit., north cold circle.
Antarctic Circle. Lit., south cold circle.
To go around, make a circuit, circumnavigate.
A rain famous at Kaha-luʻu, Oʻahu. Lit., surrounding pandanus.
Var. of Pōʻai-hala. Lit., surrounding house.
Semicircle, half circle.
Same as pōʻai haele.
Horizon. Lit., sky circle.
Firmament. Lit., air circuit.
Ellipse, oval. Lit., long circle.
Tropic of Cancer. Lit., northern cool circle.
Tropic of Capricorn. Lit., southern cool circle.
To travel around, circumnavigate, go completely around, encircle, besiege.
Blindman's bluff. Lit., circle surrounding blind.
Equator. Lit., circle middle earth.
Scar; mark, as of tattooing or tapa design.
Monday. Lit., first day.
Wednesday. Lit., third day.
Ash Wednesday.

1. Same as pōkaʻa.

2. To sail off and on, as a vessel. Rare.

3. To gargle. See ʻai pōʻala.
Redup. of pōʻala 1–3.
A variety of fish (no data).
Deep, open, as a hole or sore; absorbent. Cf. ale 2.
Redup. of poale; pierced; wound. Cf. aleale.
Same as mōʻali.

1. Friday. Lit., fifth day.

2. Work on the chief's plantations, so called because this work was done on Fridays; the chiefs' plantation where the people worked on Fridays; to work thus (For. 5:709).
Good Friday.
Good Friday.
To gouge out, scoop out, pluck, extract; to shell, as beans; to reach up at.
To gouge out the eyes; an eye gouge for torturing criminals. Fig., an ungrateful person who repays kindness by unkindness, especially by stealing a mate.
Tuesday. Lit., second day. See ʻauhau Pōʻalua.

1. Same as poʻa 3.

2. Weary, sore, lame, fatigued. Rare.
Redup. of poʻana 2. Rare.
Saturday. Lit., sixth day.

1. Redup. of pōʻai.

2. A worm shell, a marine mollusk of the family Vermetidae. Also kio poʻapoʻai, pōhakupele, pohokūpele.

To gad about from house to house, especially of persons who cat constantly at houses of others. Rare.

1. Round; rounded.

2. A sweet potato.

3. Stone poi pounder. Rare.

5. Also boe n. Boy. Eng. He poe mai au no Hawaiʻi (song), Iʻm a boy from Hawaiʻi.

6. Buoy. Eng.

1. People, persons, personnel, population, assemblage, group of, company of.

2. Plural marker.

3. Var. of poʻi 5. (Kep. 157.)

4. A native purslane (Portulaca selerocarpa), with narrow, succulent leaves which have many hairs in their axes and white flowers.

Same as poʻe 2.

Var. spelling of powehi.
Var. spelling of powehiwehi.
