Merchants.
Black, dark; dark night. Fig., ignorant benighted. (PCP po(o)kele; cf. Maori pokele.)
Redup. of pōʻele.
Bellboy. Eng..

1. Round, rounded, circular; compact, compressed; full, as the moon; sphere, globe; to gather together in a circle.

2. A euphemism for penis in the phrase ʻoki poepoe, subincision, circumcision.
Redup.
Flat sphere; oval. Lit., sea-urchin round.
Globe of the earth.
Same as pōʻeleʻele.
Oval; sphere. Lit., core roundness.

1. to burst, crack, break forth, crash, pop, bang; to ferment (of poi); bursting, cracking, as of explosives or of a whip; flashing of light, breaking of bubbles.

2. The cape gooseberry (Physalis peruviana), a South American perennial herb in the tomato family, growing wild. Flowers are yellow; round, orange, many-seeded fruits develop singly within the heart-shaped, papery, enlarged calyxes; they are edible raw and are also cooked for jam. (Neal 740–1.) Called paʻina on Hawaiʻi.

3. Same as pohāpohā, a seaweed.
Short for pōhaku, stone.
Torn, easily torn, fragile.
Redup. of pōhae.
Same as pōʻaha 1. Rare.
Redup. of pohā 1; volcanic ejecta of any kind. See ex., mūkā.
Fireball.
Bubble. Lit., water bursting.
Circle, group, as of people, trees (For. 5:287); gathering; to gather about in a circle. Also pōʻai.
Splotch, spot, dot; small area, as a bald spot; a spot in a design.
Rolling stone; thunder, peal of thunder, so called because thunder was believed caused by the gods hurling stones in the heavens.
Sunbeam.

1. Anchor. Rare.

2. Stone that travelers rest on. Rare.
Bursting forth of light, as dawn.
White stone, as limestone.

Stone used as a landmark, as of a land boundary, or for locating a fishing ground; stone with a knob at the top, used as a weight for deep-sea fishing; fishing grounds about 260 m deep (Kam. 76:75, 90).
Balancing stone, said to be the name of a water game, in which one person sank with a stone in his hand and tried to pull others down.
To carry on the shoulders, as a favorite child who holds on to the head, with legs dangling down in front. See lei ʻāʻī.
Var. of pōhākialoa.
Same as ʻIkuwā, a month of storms; also said to be the name of a rain occurring in that month (For. 5:663). Lit., break forth in storms.
Firm rock or obstruction; prominent cliff. Rare.
Rock avalanche. Rare.

1. Rock, stone, mineral, tablet; sinker (see ex., pīkoi 3); thunder; rocky, stony. See haku 3.

2. Weighted with rocks, hence stationary, not moving.

3. Type of crab. See below.
Stone rubber.
Stone for rubbing off singed hair of pigs.
Stone believed possessed by an ʻaumakua god.
See ʻeho.
A species of crab, perhaps one of the Leucosiidae, as Nucia sp. Lit., stone-fetcher.
Stones at Kū-kani-loko, Oʻahu, and Holoholokū, Kauaʻi, against which chiefesses rested as they gave birth, hence called birth stones.
Stone anchor.
Var. of pōhaku hali.
Stones for weight lifting, weight lifting.
Stone to sharpen tools, as adzes.
Foundation stone. (Ier. 51.26.)
Touchstone.
Millstone, rolling stone.
Same as pōhaku kīkēkē; also said to refer to rumbling thunder (For. 6:449).
Stone hammer used to tap chisels in making lashing holes in canoe parts.
Flat stone used for skipping.
Marble. (Hoik. 18.12.) Lit., white stone.
Cornerstone. (Ier. 51.26.)
A kind of large stone that is resonant when struck. Lit., knocking stone.
Stone for tamping canoe gunwale strakes.
Stone breadfruit splitter.
Bath rubber. Lit., stone for rubbing back.
Poi pounder.
Stone muller for charcoal.
Whale-tooth pounder.
Same as pōhaku kuʻi ʻai.
Stone canoe breaker used in warfare; it had deep grooves in the middle, in which ropes were placed, and was hurled into opposing canoes and hauled back with the rope so as to be thrown again.
Mooring rock for anchoring canoes, said to float, perhaps of pumice or perhaps mythical. (For. 4:295.) Lit., floating stone.
Adobe, brick (Puk. 1.14). Lit., dirt rock.
Fine-grained dark ʻalā stone, as used for adzes; water-worn basalt. Lit., cooked-taro green rock, so called perhaps because of the dark color.
Stone weight fastened to the octopus lure, lūheʻe; general name for soft or porous stone.
Precious stone. (Hoik. 18.12.) Lit., good stone.
Gem, precious stone.
Perforated stone tied to the end of the bag in the pākuʻikuʻi net to hold it in place. Lit., base rock.
Stone monuments that were places of refuge (puʻuhonua) where families made offerings, such as pig, red fish, kava, and tapas, to atone for wrong-doing. (Kam. 64:32–3.) Lit., stone of Kāne.
Land-dividing rock.
Emerald. (Hoik. 4.3.) Lit., green stone.
Firm, solid rock, basalt; general name for hard rocks, such as were used for adzes. Cf. pōha-ku lūheʻe.
Firestone, flint, agate. (Ezek. 3.9.)
Stone rubber.
Stone chisel.
Same as poʻapoʻai 2. Lit., volcanic rock.
Any lava rock, especially rock containing olivine crystals.
Same as pōhaku lūʻau. Lit., pōpolo berry stone, so called perhaps because of the dark color of these berries.
Short for pōhaku kuʻi ʻai puka (see pō-haku kuʻi ʻai).
Round coral piece, as used for polishing or rubbing; concrete.
Brick, tile (Ezek. 4.1). See ex., inā 1. Lit., red stone.
Bullets or pellets from bursting bullets. Lit., gun stone.
Stone hammer used under water to break enemy canoe hulls in war.

1. To revive after fainting, recover consciousness; to recover from sickness; relieved of worry; relief, rest, recovery.

2. To open, as flower petals.

3. Same as hoʻopāhala.
Full, uncomfortably filled, as one who has overeaten. Cf. kēkē.
Same as poale Cf. halehale.
Redup. of pohale.
Var. of puhalu 1.
Wheezy. Rare.

1. Redup. of pohā, to burst, pop. Cf. kūlina pohāpohā.

2. A kind of passion flower, called running pop (Passiflora foetida), a tropical American weedy vine, the hairy leaves commonly three-lobed; the fruit, enclosed in lacy bracts, is round, red or yellow, popping when crushed. (Neal 599.)

3. A non-edible, green seaweed (Dictyosphaeria cavernosa), small, round, hollow, that bursts with a pop when stepped on. Also līpohāpohā pohā.
Redup. of pōhaka.

1. Same as popohe.

2. The marsh pennywort (Hydrocotyle verticillata), a small weed known in many parts of the world, the stem creeping, leaf blade round, scalloped, attached near its center to the stem. (Neal 659.) Also pohepohe.
Killed by a fall from a precipice. Fig., to die mysteriously or by accident.
Landslide caused by rain; to slip or fall due to rain. (And.)

The nasturtium (Tropaeolum majus) hybrids, a smooth, succulent, creeping herb, grown for its bright-colored flowers, the leaf blade round and attached near the center to the stem. (Neal 474.) It grows wild at middle elevations.
Same as pūheheo.
Same as nani Waiʻ-aleʻale, a native violet.

1. Forced out, squeezed.

2. Same as pōhekeheke.
Plump.
The Asiatic pennywort (Centella asiatica), a small, weedy creeper, with round, scalloped leaves indented at the base, and white flowers and seeds. (Neal 660.)
Knob or knoblike object; head of a penis (insulting if said of a male; see heoheo).
Knob; any round, smooth, knoblike object; head of a rafter; nail, pin; rounded top of a poi pounder, rounded head of a cane.

1. Redup. of pohe 1.

2. Same as pohe 2.
Nether region, place of torment. Rare.
To sink, settle, ebb. Rare.

1. Same as pohihihi. Cf. hihi.

2. Ancient name of a plant used for medicine (no data).
Obscure, entangled, mysterious, intricate, confused, confusing, bewildering, baffling, complex; mystery, obscurity. Cf. hihi.
Evasive, obscure, difficult to grasp or comprehend.

1. Gray, misty, foggy, dimly visible, hazy. See ex., kāluʻu.

2. To fall prone, topple.

3. Same as Polo Ahi Lani, a star.

4. A variety of sugar cane, red or brown, similar to uahi-a-Pele but less vigorous, dying back after tasseling. (HP 223, 225.)

5. A variety of taro.

6. A variety of sweet potato.

1. Redup. of pohina 1.

2. Same as kolokolo kahakai, beach vitex.

1. Hollow or palm of the hand, hollow of the foot, depression, hollow; container, receptacle, pouch, as for tobacco; box, as for matches; hollow of a canoe, divided into three parts (mua, waena, hope). See ex. below. Poho kai, hollow where sea remains at low tide. (PCP po(f,s)o.)

2. Mortar; to knead, as bread or poi (Kep. 165).

3. Patch, as in clothes; a wooden patch inserted into a calabash, as to mend a break; to patch, mend.

4. To belly out, puff out, as clothes on a line or a sail; to hollow or dub out, as a wooden container.

5. Chalk, chalky white earth, as of limestone.

6. A unit of measure equal to half a span (kīkoʻo). Rare.

7. A bundle of tapa pieces (moʻomoʻo). Rare.

1. Loss, damage; out of luck; vain. See ex., keakea.

2. Bog, swamp, mire, slough; sunken, sinking; to settle, as earth. Cf. onepohō.
Matchbox. Lit., fire container.
Container for fishing lines.
Land basin.
Glass container or jar.
Same as holowaʻa.
Same as paheʻe 4.

The introduced carnation or pink (Dianthus caryophyllus), a plant widely cultivated for its attractive and spicy-fragrant flowers, one of the commonest flowers used for leis. The Hawaiian name resulted from confusing the English name with “coronation” (Neal 345–6.)

1. Dizzy, giddy; dizziness; to rotate, whirl, spin, revolve, gyrate.

2. Same as lolo, coconut sponge.

3. The balloon vine or heartseed (Cardiospermum halicacabum), a slender, herbaceous, tropical vine, with finely subdivided leaves, small white flowers, and 2.5 cm-wide balloon-like fruiting capsules, each with three seeds (black with a white heart-shaped scar). Hawaiians formerly used the whole plant as a magic remedy for dizziness, wearing it as a lei and eating a little, before throwing it away into the ocean. (Neal 532.) Also hale-a-ka-iʻa, ʻinalua, pōhuehue uka.
Redup. of pōniu 1; grief-stricken (Kel. 57).

Young stage of dragonfly, between the larval stage (lohelohe) and adulthood (pinao); beggarticks. Lit., great sun head.
A native species of koʻokoʻolau (Bidens cosmoides), on Kauaʻi only, with yellow flowers 5 cm across.
Leaf base; butt end of a leaf.
Postage stamp. Lit., letter head. See ex., ʻiliʻili.
War-savings stamp. Lit., war stamp.
Short for poʻoʻōlelo.
A half note (music). Lit., arm note.

A rain associated with Ka-lihi, Oʻahu, and Hilo, Hawaiʻi (For. 5:119). Lit., adzelike head, said to be so called because this heavy rain forced the people to spend so much time sleeping that their heads were sharpened as though by an adze.
Blister; to billow out, as wind-filled clothes.

Child sired by other than the husband, but accepted by both husband and sire; this acceptance increased the number of relatives of the child who gave their loyalty to him as kinsmen; it thus fostered the prestige of children of chiefs; translated “adulterous” in the 1843 Bible (Mar. 8.38), but changed in later editions.
Same as poluluhi. Lit., tired head.
Crest, as of a bird. Lit., helmet head.
An eighth note (music). Lit., branching note, named for the stem mark.
A thirty-second note (music). Lit., triple branching note.
A sixteenth note (music). Lit., doubly branching note.
Topic, title, theme, heading, headline; subtitle, as of law. Lit., thought heading.
Bait remainder.
Cut off, severed, shortened. See ex., kāpala.
Dizzy head. Same as pōniuniu.
A thinker, a thoughtful head.
See poʻo noʻo

1. A variety of ʻahi, tuna fishes, with a short body and thin tail.

2. Top-heavy, as a house. (Kam. 76:97.)
Name of a cold, continuous rain. (Kep. 97.)
Hangover, worried head, worry; to be a “headache” or source of trouble (Kel. 45).
Illegitimate. Lit., no head.
Title, as of an article; text, as of a sermon. Lit., speech heading.
Shrimp head, an opprobrious term because the shrimp's excretory organs are said to be in its head.

Hawkfish (Cirrhites pinnulatus), about 10 to 22cm long with large scales on body and small scales on face, colored in blotches of blue, brown, and red with white vertical bars; eaten raw, broiled, or salted and dried. Lit., hard head. Also ʻoʻopu kai, ʻoʻopu poʻopaʻa, pilikoʻa. See ex., hōkai.
Hardheaded, stubborn, obstinate, unreasonable, set in one's ways.
A kind of white shell (no data). Lit., ivory head.
Name for highest tip of the canoe endpiece.
A drooping crest, as of some birds. Lit., hat head.
Flathead, a name for lesser gods. (Kep. 19.)
Redup. of poʻo 3; sunken, as eyes of a sick person; indented, deep (as a bay penetrating the coastline); nook, cranny.
Same as kīpūkai, seaside heliotrope. Also lau poʻopoʻohina. Both names on Niʻihau.

1. Head pupil in a hula school. Lit., pig head, so named because the head pupil provided a pig or pig-head offering. Cf. .

2. Image of a pig, carved of wood such as kukui, placed on the stone heap marking the boundary of an ahupuaʻa land division.

3. Offering. See ex., puaʻa 1.
Any depression in the head, as a sunken temple.
Bulging head; hilltop. Fig., sullen, unsocial person.

1. Wrasse (Cheilinus rhodochrous). Varieties are qualified by the colors kea and ʻula.

2. Same as ʻaʻawa, wrasse.
Honeycreeper (Melamprosops phaeosoma), discovered in 1973 by Tonnie Casey and James Jacobi, upper Hāna rainforest, Maui, named by Kawena Pukuʻi. Lit., black head.
Water source or head, dam. Cf. ʻiole poʻo wai.
Small, of man or woman. (And.)

1. Pope; papist, Catholic. Eng. Hōʻole Pope, Protestant; lit., deny Pope.

2. Poppy. Eng.
Poplar. (Kin. 30.37.) Eng.
Trouble, distress, tribulation, straits, disaster, calamity, ordeal, hardship, adversity, misfortune.
Same as popopo.

1. Ball, round mass, wad; cluster, bunch, as of flowers; to shape or wad up into a ball or bundle; baskets of ʻieʻie vine as used by nehu fishermen to collect nehu (For. 6:481). Cf. kinipōpō, Pōpō-kapa, Pōpōua.

2. Short for ʻapōpō, tomorrow.
Fireball.
Ball of poi or other food.
Ball of pulverized ʻauhuhu as inserted in coral to poison fish. Fig., poison, danger, venomous attack.
Redup. of poe 1.

The hydrangea (Hydrangea macrophylla), an eastern Asiatic shrub, grown for the large, rounded or flat-topped clusters of pink, white, or blue flowers. In Hawaiʻi it succeeds at high, cool altitudes. (Neal 381.)
Snowball, ball of snow.
A large sedge with edible seeds.
Round, shapely; neat and trim, as flowers; roundness, a round or clean-cut object.
Same as ʻoʻoi, a seaweed.
Inside corner. Cf. kihi.
Bundle of bones, as preserved of beloved relatives.
Rain name. Lit., tapa bundle, so-called because people bundled up tapa during rains to keep it from becoming wet. Also Pōpō-ua.
Ball of medicinal herbs used for massage.
Var. of pokepoke.

1. Var. of pokipoki 1, 2; short, thick.

2. Name of a lua fighting stroke, said to be used by women as well as men.

Cat (noted in Arago's 1819 vocabulary; said 
by some to be derived from English “poor pussy”).
Medicine wrapped in leaves.

An ixora (Ixora casei) from Kosrae (Kusaie Island), a shrub ornamentally for its large round clusters of red flowers, which are used for leis. Each flower has a narrow red tube about 5 cm long, tipped with four short lobes. (Neal 802).
Arched, curved, warped. Rare.
Ball of seaweed, cleaned and salted, as sold for food.

1. The black nightshade (Solanum nigrum, often incorrectly called S. nodiflorum) a smooth cosmopolitan herb.3 to .9 m high. It is with ovate leaves, small white flowers, and small black edible berries. In Hawaiʻi, young shoots and leaves are eaten as greens, and the plant is valued for medicine, formerly for ceremonies. (Neal 744). Also polopolo. The fruit is hua pōpolo. ʻolohua, polohua, pūʻili. Because of its color, pōpolo has long been an uncomplimentary term: see lepo pōpolo. In modern slang, Blacks are sometimes referred to as pōpolo. See pōpolohua..

2. An endemic lobelia (Cyanea solanacea), a shrub to 2.5 m high; in young plants the leaves are large, sinuate, thorny on both sides; in mature plants the leaves are unarmed; flowers 5 cm long light-colored; fruit a large orange berry.

3. The native pokeberry. See pōpolo kū mai.

4. Same as maiko, a fish.

A shrub or small tree from Kauaʻi (Solanum kauaiense), without thorns and with large ovate or oblong, sinuate leaves, densely downy on the under side. Cream- and purple-colored flowers less than 2.5 cm in diameter are borne in erect clusters, The fruit is a berry. Lit., pōpolo eaten by the god.
Very dark, as pōpolo berries.

1. Purplish-blue, as the sea; dark, as a bruise.

2. Same as pōpolo 1 on Niʻihau.

Apple of Sodom, yellow-fruited or thorny pōpolo (Solanum sodomeum), from the Mediterranean region, a small, thorny, somewhat shrubby weed, with lobed leaves, violet flowers, and yellow or orange fruits resembling small tomatoes. The plant is slightly poisonous. (Neal 743–4).

1. The native pokeberry (Phytolacca sandwicensis), a small shrub with rather large, ovate leaves, many small flowers borne in long, narrow racemes, and dark-purple berries. The berries may have been used for dye. (Neal 340).

2. A low shrub (Solanum incompletum var.
Same as pololei 1 .
Courageous, bold. Rare.
Var. of polopolona.
Redup. of poni 2.
Redup. of poʻo hina.
Redup. of poʻo kea.
Wad or plug of tobacco.
Round loaf of bread.
Loaf of bread.
Rot, as of wood or cloth; decay, as of teeth; moth-eaten; worm offal; rust (Bible); rotten, decayed. Cf. pilau.
Redup. of pono, goodness.
A wet bundle, as of laundry; to wrap up wet, as laundry that is not allowed to dry.
Name of a rain. (PH 109). Also Pōpōkapa.
Dense, gray, puffy, as smoke, fog. Lit., smoke ball.
Same as maiʻa pōpō ʻulu.
Clusters of cloud banks.
To girdle, tie tightly or constrict in the middle. (AP).
Problem. Eng. He Mau Poropoleme, Some Problems [book title, Judd, Bell, and Murdoch 222].

1. Post, pole, pillar, shaft..

2. Ridge, as of nose; lump (Kam. 64:108).

3. Mast of canoe.

4. Machine gun.

5. Part of snood lashing on composite hook, as for bonitos; sometimes shaft of a hook is so called.

6. Spool pins on a sewing machine.

7. Same as poupou 1.

8. A canoe, broad for its length and wide and blunt at the ends, used for baggage.

9. An internal hardening or tumor.
Same as paʻū, drenched.
House wall posts, front row of posts.
Var. of pouomanu..
Post set in the middle of each end of the house, supporting the ridgepole. Fig., support, mainstay, as of a family..
Short, stout. Var. of pau hananuʻu.
Name of a star. Lit., low post.
Var. of paʻuhia.
Bent corner post, probably as supporting the ridgepole of a canoe house.
Hitching post.

1. Var. of pāuhu, a cowry.

2. Homely, ugly. Rare.
Var. of pauka, powder. Cf. paula.
See pouka
Corner post.
Mildewed, moldy, musty. Rare.
Cleats supporting canoe seats.
House wall posts, back row of posts.
Gable post. See kukuna.
Male flower of the breadfruit. Cf. ule, penis.

1. Dark; darkness, dark night. Fig., ignorance.

2. Eclipse.
Redup. of pouli 1; murky, gloomy.

1. Bark of tender breadfruit shoots, as used for less fine tapa.

2. Euphemism for pōule.
Shaft of the lūheʻe, octopus lure, perhaps so called because one side has a stone attached, with a cowry on the other side. Lit., double shaft.
Var. of paona, pound. (Luka. 19.13.) Cf. paona, paona kaulike.
See nanahua 2.
House post; post designating place of human sacrifice, said to be named for an ancient deity.
Fishing net. (Malo 212).
Bag net with meshes two fingers wide, similar to but larger than the luelue.

1. Short and stocky, stout, thickset. Cf. noho niʻo.

2. Same as kūpou 2, a fish.
Same as noho niʻo.
Var. spelling of pōā.
Dim, obscure, indistinct, vague, faint, unclear. (KL. line 135.) hoʻo.powehi Caus/sim..
See powehi
Var. spelling of poeko.

1. Large triton conch or helmet shell (Charonia tritonis) as used for trumpets; any wind instrument, as horn, trumpet, cornet. The instrument may be distinguished from other pū by the qualifier hoʻokani, sounding.

2. Gun, pistol. Cf. pū aloha.

3. General name for pumpkin or squash. Also ipu pū, palaʻai.

4. Tree, cluster of several stalks, as of bananas, pandanus, or kava; clump, as of sugar cane (always precedes a noun). Also ōpū. (PCP puu).

5. Head of octopus or squid.

6. Canoe endpiece, both fore and aft.

7. Coil of hair, topknot of hair; rope or line, as attached to sticks in an ʻōpelu net; rope attached to the front of an unfinished canoe to haul it to the shore; olonā string used in the game pū kaula; snotter holding the end of the sprit of a sail; to coil; to gather in, as sails; to form a topknot.

8. To divide by lot: pebbles or seeds were placed under a tapa, and divided unseen into heaps, and the players drew to get the largest heaps.

9. To eat a little, share potluck, said in a humble invitation, as Mai kākou e pū ʻai, come and have a little food with us [take potluck].

10. A variety of sweet potato.

11. Inactive, sluggish, quiet, dejected, bored (often following noho)..

12. Together, entirely, completely, also with, together with..

13. Probably a rare var. of puoho, startled. (GP 66).

1. Short for puna. See pūhau.

2. Also pu. A simulative prefix to a great many roots with similar meanings, as ʻalu, pūalu; hano, puhano; haʻu, puhaʻu; hemo, puhemo; hene, pūhene; hili, pūhili; hole, puhole; koʻa, pūkoʻa; koko, pūkoko; lama, pūlama; lawa, pūlawa; lewa, pūlewa; liki, pūliki; mehana, pumehana.

1. Flower, blossom, tassel and stem of sugar cane; to bloom, blossom.

2. To issue, appear, come forth, emerge, said especially of smoke, wind, speech, and colors, hence to smoke, blow, speak, shine. Cf. pua ahi, pua ehu, pua ʻehu, pua ʻena, pua hina, puana, puka.

3. Progeny, child, descendant, offspring; young, spawn, fry, as of āholehole, ʻamaʻama, ʻanae, awa, kāhala, ʻōʻio, uouoa, to produce progeny or young.

4. Arrow, dart, sometimes made from flower stalks of sugar cane.

5. Same as olopua 1, a tree. (Perhaps PPN pua).

6. Float, buoy. Rare.

7. Short for ʻōpua, a cloud bank.

8. A Molokaʻi sorcery goddess.

9. A fishhook for turtles. (And.)

1. Same as hōkiokio, a whistle.

2. To excrete. See puʻa hana lepo, puʻa kiʻo, puʻa mimi.

1. Flock, herd, drove; to flock.

2. Sheaf, bundle, as of grain or fuel that is not wrapped; binder, bunch, package; clump, as of sugar cane (Kel. 116); to tie in bundles, bind.

3. To feed by passing directly from mouth to mouth, of masticated food such as fish or poi; infants and the aged were fed thus.

4. To cut crosswise.

5. To besiege. (Pua in 2 Sam. 11.1 of the 1843 Bible was changed to pue in later editions; cf. puʻe.)

1. Pig, hog, swine, pork. Cf. hula puaʻa, wilipuaʻa, ulepuaʻa. . Many references to puaʻa are to Kama-puaʻa and his plant forms.

2. Formerly a general name for introduced quadrupeds; see below and .

3. Banks of fog or clouds, often as gathered over a mountain summit, a sign of rain and believed to be the cloud forms of Kama-puaʻa.

1. Scattered, dispersed; to flee in disorder and fright. Also pūkākā. Holo pūʻāʻā, to scatter in excitement, stampede.

2. Redup. of pūʻā 2, 5; bundles, sheaths; to tie many; to besiege frequently.
Red pig, a poetic name for ʻāmaʻumaʻu, ferns. The demigod Kama-puaʻa took this form when he ran from Pele to the forest of ʻamaʻu ferns and turned into a fern himself.
Ham.
Blood-stained pig, hence a sacrificed pig, also said of human sacrifice.
To blow gently; light, as work.
See pua aheahe
Name of a star. Lit., fire flower.
To glow like fire. For figurative use see koʻikoʻi.
See pua ahi
Same as nani ahiahi, the four-o'clock flower.
Greasy pig. Fig., human sacrifice.
A solid-black pig, much desired for sacrifice.
Young āholehole.
The Tahitian name for horse, perhaps used at one time in Hawaiʻi. Lit., pig runs [on the] ground.
Hairless pig, a figurative name for taro leaves, since they might sometimes replace pig as sacrifice.

Porcupine (Isa. 34.11), hedgehog 
(Zep. 2.14) (RSV); in KJV, both references, bittern, heron.

An endemic long-branched plant (Stenogyne rotundifolia) in the mint family, found only on Mount Hale-a-ka-lā; the 2.5 cm long flowers woolly, purple-tinted, in whorls of six; the leaves round and rough.
Same as Ka-puaʻa-kā-huluhulu.
Certain fish (as āhole, ʻamaʻama, ʻanae, humuhumunukunukuapuaʻa, kūmū, pualu) used as substitute for pig offering. Lit., sea pig.
Boar.
Hog offered as sacrifice.
Same as pākahakaha, a fern.
Carved log of kukui wood placed with hard taro (paʻi ʻai) on the altar marking boundary of ahupuaʻa. (Malo 163.)
Sow, pig who has borne young.
Same as ālula, lobelia.
Boar; term of reproach for a lecherous male, named for the pig demigod, Kama-puaʻa. Lit., scrotum hog.

Name for plants that might replace pig in some sacrifices, a favorite being young taro leaves. Others were ʻamaʻu, hāpuʻu, kūkaepuaʻa, kukui, olomea, and ʻuhaloa. They were considered the plant forms of the pig demigod, Kama-puaʻa. Lit., leaf pig.
Descendant of a chief.
Hibiscus flower. See aloalo.
Larvae of dragonfly (lohelohe) used ceremonially as an offering.
Small pig.
Extremity of life, extreme old age.
See puaaneane
Same as laulele, butterfly weed (Asclepias). Lit., caterpillar flower.
Horse (old name, Lā-naʻi). Lit., big animal hairy tail.
A young female pig that has not borne young.
Hedgehog. Lit., rough pig.

1. A striped pig.

2. Poetic name for the olomea, a tree.
A name for the ʻilima flower. See ʻāpiki.
Early name for cattle when brought to the islands by Vancouver. Lit., beef (Eng.) pig.
Spotted pig. Lit., coral head pig.
Pig offering at the death of a chief as a plea to the ʻaumākua gods to receive the spirit of the departed. Lit., fulfillment pig.
Great hunger. Rare. Lit., issuing sourness.
Sow.
See saying, maka helei.
To expire, breathe one's last.
To blow spray or dust.
To shine brightly, as reddish flowers.
To glow brightly.

1. A medium-sized bowl, as used for serving poi, named for a supposed resemblance to a pandanus key (pua hala).

2. A variety of sugar cane.
Design in tapa and patchwork quilts.
Bright yellow base of a pandanus (hala) key that may be used for leis.
Same as puʻu kiʻo.
Same as kanawao 1, small trees.

1. Blossoms of hau, a tree.

2. Yellow, as a malo.
Var. spelling of pua aheahe.
One of the native loosestrifes (Lysimachia hillebrandii). Lit., thunder flower. Cf. kolokolo kuahiwi.

1. Var. spelling of pua ahi.

2. Same as puahia spry, quick.

1. Spry, quick.

2. Hazy, gray.
Var. spelling of pua ahiahi, a flower.
Redup. of puahia 1, 2.
The sensitive plant (Mimosa pudica var.

1. Fine, slender, frail as a spider's web, delicate.

2. To chap, peel, crack, as skin.
Redup. of puāhilo 1, 2.
Gray.
To come and go swiftly, as a puff or gust of wind.

1. Redup. of puahio; whirlwind, gust. Fig., worthless talk. See ex., koʻiʻula, For. 5:93.

2. Wind, Nuʻuanu, Oʻahu. (Nak. 57.)
Lamb. Also hipa keiki.
Flock of sheep.

A tropical American herb (Laurentia [Isotoma] [Hippobroma] longiflora), 30 to 60 cm high, with few or no branches, with long, narrow, lobed leaves, and starlike flowers with 7.5 cm long tube. The plant is related to the lobelias. It is poisonous, especially to stock. (Neal 818.) Lit., star flower.

The waxflower (Hoya bicarinata), an ornamental vine from Samoa, Tonga, and Fiji, in the milkweed family. Leaves are thick, broad-oval, paired, at their bases bearing short clusters of waxy, fragrant, white and pink, star-shaped flowers used for leis. (Neal 700.) Lit., entangled star flower.
Var. spelling of pua āhole, young of āhole.
A term of contempt; perhaps literally rising octopus head; said also to refer to erections not followed by satisfaction. Rare.
Same as pupuāhulu.
To flow out, as water; to bubble or gurgle, boil; to vomit; to appear, as a color; to utter, as speech (probably pua 2 + -aʻi, ). (Mar. 7.15; Ier. 6.7.) Puai wai, fountain.
To share a little food, take potluck. See puʻu 9.
Adam's apple (probably from puʻu ʻāʻī, neck lump).
Fish spawn.
Same as pūailewa.
Tiny fry of fish.
Same as puleileho.

1. Suspended in the air, as clouds.

2. To breathe with difficulty, gasp.

3. Name of a drastic remedy made of pāpaʻahekili bark. Rare.
See pūailewa
ʻIlima flower; eaten as a mild cathartic, especially by children.
Flowing, bubbling, boiling, etc. See puaʻi.
Thin, weblike, weak.
Same as puanaiea.
Small Kauaʻi thrush (Phaeornis palmeri).

1. To bind, tie. Rare.

2. To work hard without reward or appreciation. Rare.
Redup. of puʻaka 1, 2.
Dart made of the stem of sugar-cane tassel smoked reddish-brown (kaʻaona).
Small kāhala, a fish.

1. Same as pūkai 1.

2. Red of tapa or malo dyed with noni juice (Malo 49); a red tapa used in kuni ceremonies. See wauke puakai.
Rain name. Probably same as Kaiāulu.
Howland Island, a name used by Hawaiian guano diggers there in about 1856. Lit., the ʻilima flower. See song, Pukui and Korn 80–2.

1. To assume the appearance of kala seaweed, said of octopus in the sea.

2. A kind of crab.

1. The beach or prickly poppy (Argemone glauca), a Hawaiian species closely related to a southern United States species, a gray, prickly plant with stiff, lobed, toothed leaves and fragile, white-petaled flowers. Formerly, Hawaiians used the yellow juice to relieve pain. Lit., thorny flower. Also kala, naule, pōkalakala. See lū 2, Neal 367.

2. A native prickly lobelia (Cyanea solenocalyx), a shrub with large ovate or oblong, prickly leaves and hairy, purple flowers, found in gulches of Molokaʻi.

3. The spear thistle (Cirsium vulgare), a coarse, prickly European weed, 60 to 150 cm high, with large, spiny, lobed leaves, and dark-purple, spiny flower heads about 5 cm (Neal 857.)

The crown flower (Calotropis gigantea), a large shrub, native from India to the East Indies, belonging to the milkweed family. The crown-shaped flowers, white or lavender, are commonly used for leis, and the plants for hedges in dry areas. (Neal 698–9.) Called liliʻu on Niʻihau.
A lua fighting stroke. Lit., the smoke blows, the birds rage.
Same as ʻāwikiwiki, a vine.

1. A variety of taro. (HP 34.)

2. A variety of sweet potato.

1. Pale-colored, especially a tint between white and pink, as sunset clouds; the color of a buckskin horse. Cf. naʻenaʻe pua kea.

2. To spread, as a ship's sails or as fog.
A spiny climbing vine (Caesalpinia sepiaria) from India, first grown in Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, by Father Celestino. (Neal 434.) Lit., Celestino flower.

A shrub or small tree (Fagraea berteriana), from the South Pacific, grown ornamentally for foliage, flowers, fruit. The flowers are 5 cm long, white, changing to orange, fragrant, and used for leis. The 2.5 cm-wide berry is orange or red. (Neal 682.) Lit., ten-cent flower, so-called because at one time the flowers are said to have sold for ten cents each.
Bougainvillea. Lit., devil flower [so-called because of thorns].

1. Same as puakiʻi 1.

2. A young eel.

3. A red seaweed (Liagora decussata), somewhat calcified but flexible, branched; not edible; related to pāpaʻakea.
Flower of the ti.

1. Stingy; antisocial, suspicious and distrustful of others Rare.

2. Lines meeting on a mast. Rare.
Same as pūkiawe.

1. Thin, skinny. Cf. hōkiʻi.

2. To take, as without permission. Rare.
Same as ʻōpua kiʻi.
Cigar flower. See kīkā.
Same as puʻu kiʻo. Molokaʻi.
Stem and tassel of sugar cane (the stem was used in making hats).
A tapa colored by beating in sandalwood. (Kam. 76:157.)
Red, as lehua blooms.
Blossoms of kukui.

1. Same as pūʻā, sheath.

2. Overcooked, as taro. Rare.
Short for puʻu ʻālaʻa, heap of small taro tubers.
A choice and rare flower. Fig., a beloved person. Lit., flower not widespread.
Single flowering. Lit., thin flower.
To scream, shriek, cry out, bleat; to cry loudly like a baby. See ex., ʻuwīʻuwī 5.
Clear, bright.
Descendant of a chief.
To carry on the hip, as a child. Rare.
To divide. Rare. Lit., bundle split.
Flowers for leis; cherished blossom or child.
Flower that attracts many (lēʻī), as a lehua that attracts birds.

1. The sow thistle (Sonchus oleraceus), a weedy herb in the daisy family, from Europe. It is 30 cm tall or more, the leaves narrow, lobed, toothed, the flower heads clustered, yellow, about 3 cm in diameter. The light seeds are tipped with hairy tufts. The plant is sometimes fed to pigs and the leaves eaten by people during famine. (Neal 860.)

2. A weed (Emilia fosbergii, misidentified as E. javanica).

1. Yellow color; to appear yellow, as said of dawn or muddy water.

2. Lazy; to loll about.
Unsettled, unfixed, always on the move; upset stomach.

1. Warrior, soldier, so called because Hawaiian fighters tied (pūʻali) their malos at the waist so that no flap would dangle for a foe to seize; army, host, multitude. Various types of military formations are listed below.

2. To gird tightly about the waist, as of malo-clad warriors, or as corseted women; compressed, constricted in the middle; grooved, notched; irregularly shaped, as taro; notch; tight belt (see kōkī for example).

3. Isthmus.

4. Slender abdominal stalk on a wasp's body.

5. In music, a decrescendo followed by a crescendo.

6. Irregularly shaped ravine.

7. A vague term for an adopted man or boy who had no servants. (Ii 38.)
Redup. of pūʻali 2; of varying thickness, as a cord or ʻilima lei not carefully woven.
Salvation Army. Lit., saving army.

1. Var. spelling of pua aliʻi.

2. Kind of tapa used for loincloths and sarongs.
Temperance league. Lit., waterdrinking host.
Infantry. Lit., war army proceeding afoot.
Cavalry.
See pūʻali kaua lio
Armed forces, troops, regiment, brigade, corps.
Honor guard.
Cavalry. Lit., horse-soldier army.
Short for pua aloalo.
Gun salute.

1. A species of surgeonfish (Acanthurus xanthopterus and A. mata), up to 15 and 20 cm in length and brown or dull-gray in color. It resembles the palani in tough skin and strong smell but may be distinguished from the latter by a blue line across the soft part of the fin.

2. Var. spelling of puwalu 1.
See pualu
Loose, stack; crumpled, crinkled, as ruffles. Cf. ʻalu.
Redup. of pūʻalu.
Annual flower.
Same as akaʻakaʻawa, a begonia. Lit., large-eyed flower.

A kind of vine (Stephanotis floribunda), in the milkweed family, from Madagascar. It has oval, leathery, paired leaves and clustered, fragrant, white, tubular flowers, which are sometimes worn by brides in Hawaiʻi. (Neal 699–700.) Lit., wedding flower.
Caret sign of omission.
Same as ilioha, horseweeds.
See melia, plumeria.
Same as puʻu mimi. Molokaʻi.

1. Attack or beginning of a song; in music, the tonic or keynote; to begin a song; summary refrain, as of a song, usually at or near the beginning of a song; theme of a song. See ex., pō 1.

2. Pronunciation, utterance.

3. To surround, encompass, crowd.
Same as pūʻaliʻali.
Front of the neck and throat.
Weak, sickly.
The star Rigel, tutelary star of West Maui.
A tree (Solanum auriculatum syn.

The common sunflower (Helianthus annuus), a coarse annual herb, 1 to 4.5 m high, from the western United States. It is a member of the daisy family and has flower heads from 8 to 35 cm across, the yellow ray florets surrounding a brown-purple center. (Neal 840.) Lit., flower looking [at] sun.
Name of a star.
See "hoʻopuananu":  To rise as a wave. Ua hoʻopuananu ʻia kou umauma, your breast rises and falls like a wave [grief].
Mournful.
Var. spelling of puaaneane. See ex., kāhoahoa.
Rare. var. of puanaiea.
Young taro, taro tops. (AP)

1. To bind tightly.

2. Small wooden bowl, as for an individual serving of poi.
A tapa dyed with coconut, probably oil; a tapa dye (Kam. 76:109).

1. Coconut flower.

2. Color of the coconut flower; ivory-colored.
Cold, chilly, damp and shivering.
Bluster, onslaught, as of high wind or dashing waves; rude, abrupt speech; to speak thus.

1. Mesh about 0.5 to 1.3 cm wide, of mats.

2. Womb. Cf. lapa pūʻao.
To chatter, gush, ramble verbally; chattering, chatterbox.
False daisy (Eclipta alba). (Neal 838.) Lit., flower of the chief [or heaven].
A gourd (Sicyos niihauensis), first collected and identified by H. St. John. Cf. kūpala and Neal 808.
Same as ʻāwela, a flowerless (pua ʻole) sugar cane.

A genus (Chrysanthemum) in the daisy family, including many species of ornamental annual and perennial herbs, with small to large flower heads, which are white to red, yellow, or purple. Most species are from the Eastern Hemisphere. (Neal 850–1.) Cf. haleloke, wailuku.
Dwarf pua Pākē.

1. The everlasting or straw flower. Lit., paper flower. Also nani mau loa.

2. Bougainvillea (Bougainwillea spectabilis).

All kinds of zinnias, especially one (Zinnia elegans), a Mexican annual grown ornamentally for the flowers. The flower heads are 5 to 13 cm across, single and daisy-like, or double and somewhat round, and of various colors. In Hawaiʻi is also found a wild species (Z. pauciflora), from Mexico and South America, with 2.5 cm-wide, single flower heads, the central florets yellow, the rays yellow, red, or purple. (Neal 838.) Lit., button flower.

The Spanish clover (Desmodium uncinatum), a South American herb, long established in Hawaiʻi. It is good fodder. The plant is 30 to 90 cm high, each leaf having three ovate leaflets with a light area along the midrib. Flowers are small, pink or whitish, pea-shaped. Pods are narrow, flattened, chainlike, 2.5 to 5 cm long, clinging to clothing and animals. (Neal 451.) Also kīkānia pipili. See pilipili ʻula.
Same as maiapilo, a plant.
Herd of cattle.
Comb or crest of a bird, as of a chicken. Lit., head issue.
Same as apuapu, file.

1. Tail feathers, as of a cock; rump, as of a chicken; streamer; coattails; this word is used as a means of avoiding answering questions: Aia ʻoia i hea? Aia i ka puapua.

2. Redup. of pua 2.

3. Spike in the back of sphinx moths.

4. Same as pupua 3.

5. A variety of banana.

6. Same as ʻāpua 2, fishhook shank.
Tasteless; not tasty.
Redup. of pūʻā 1, 5.
Plural of puaʻa 3.
Piglet.
Redup. of puahi 1, 2.
Redup. of puaʻi; to pour continuously or often.
Redup. of pūʻala 1, 2.

1. Long-tailed dinner coat. Also pupuamoa.

2. A kind of adder's-tongue fern (Ophioglossum pendulum), found in Polynesia westward into Madagascar, commonly growing on trees. It has ribbon-like fronds, erect or bent and hanging, 60 cm long or less, some bearing short, narrow, spore-filled spikes.
Tall feathers of a chicken.
A variety of banana.
Double flowering.
Ti-leaf blossom stem. (HP 206.) Rare.
Young kūmū or ʻāhuluhulu, fish.
Natal grass (Rhynchelytrum repens), grown for forage; highly ornamental. (Neal 74.)
Same as ʻalulu.
Masturbation; to masturbate. Lit., to pull issue.

1. Same as pua awa, young awa, fish.

2. Same as kuawa, guava.

1. Young white pandanus leaves that are good for plaiting.

2. Bitter; bitterness.
Kava plant or root portion, formerly used as offerings: see ʻike 1.
Redup. of pūʻawa 1.
Spittle, slobber, spray. Rare.
Same as awe, thin, soft. Rare.
Redup. of puawe. Rare.

1. To huddle or sit crouched, as with cold.

2. Feathers on the back of a bird above the puapua, tail feathers.

1. Hill, as of sweet potatoes; dune; to hill up. Cf. puʻe one.

2. To attack, force, ravish, rape, compel.

3. A lobelia (Lobelia gaudichaudii var.
To shrink away from; to shorten, contract; to grimace.
Glowing, as fire.

1. Scattered, dispersed, routed, gone, tousled; fine, crumbling; every which way, as hair in the wind.

2. Peeling, as sunburn.

3. Remainder, remnant; to remain.
Redup. of puehu 1–3; tousled; flaky.
Same as pūliki, to gird.
A long tapa strip, as used for a marker or banner; narrow, thin, as a banner.

1. Hawaiian short-eared owl (Asio flammeus sandwichensis), regarded often as a benevolent ʻaumakua (HM 124).

2. Short (perhaps so called because the owl's neck was short). Cf. hue nuku pueo.

3. Same as ʻaho pueo, main purlin of a house.

4. To rock a child on the foot; while doing this one amused the child by chanting pūeoeo.

5. Shroud of a ship or canoe.

6. See papapueo, a taro. Other names recorded (HP 34) are pueo hālenalena and pueo keʻokeʻo.

7. House lashing. (Kam. 76:97.)
Redup. of pueo 4; to rock a child.
Sand dune, sand bar.
Redup. of pue 1.
Redup. of puʻe 1, 2.
Same as pūehuehu.
To float, drift, as carried by wind or tide; a vagabond. Rare.
Agitated water, as under a waterfall or at the meeting of stream and sea. Cf. heʻe puʻewai.
To force, attack, rape.

1. Abscess, burst sore, ulcer; to break, burst.

2. Hollow, as a tree.

3. To belch, burp, clear the throat, hawk up phlegm.

4. To breathe air, as a sea turtle.

5. A brown seaweed (Colpomenia sinuosa), cushion-shaped, hollow, surface smooth and uneven; not eaten. Cf. nakeke.
Spots, as uncooked spots in taro; light spots on a cowry shell; to burst forth, as light. Rare.
Malo's spelling of pūhakakaiea. (Malo 40.)
Redup. of pūhā 4. Fig., to speak loudly, harshly, or evilly of others.
Redup. of puhalu.
Shallow, of roots.
To stare without replying, as to a question. (And.)

1. Loins, waist.

2. Same as hakahaka, empty. Rare.
Redup. of pūhaka 2. Rare.
Same as noio, a sea bird. Rare.
Pandanus tree. See hala.
Hollow in a tree.
To run away, dash by, whiz by.
Same as pōhalakē. Rare.

1. Large, flabby, fat, bloated, obese.

2. To cry out, as a bird. Rare.

1. A kind of fragile sea shell, possibly Janthina or Argonauta. Lit., carried shell.

2. Stingy. (And.)

1. Soft, flabby, loose, sagging, sunken, deflated; to loosen, deflate, sink, sag. Fig., unenthusiastic, relaxed, weak. Also halu, uhalu.

2. To stare wide-eyed. (AP)
Redup. of puhalu 1, 2.
To beautify, glorify. Rare. Cf. hano, hano-hano.
To catch the breath after exertion. Cf. hanu.
Cool spring.
To puff out, billow out, swell out. Cf. haʻu.
Redup. of puhaʻu. Cf. lima pūhaʻuhaʻu, lole wāwae pūhaʻuhaʻu.
To flee. Cf. heʻe 2.
Octopus head; figurative name for a small fontanel (cf. wāwahi).
To steal or filch and run away.
Round and swirling, as a full skirt or pāʻū with many folds. Also pōheheo. Cf. heo 1.

1. Loose, set free, released, taken off. Cf. hemo 1.

2. Weak, listless.

1. To tease, giggle. Rare. Cf. hene 3.

2. A crude basket, as for carrying food. Rare.

3. Same as pūhenehene.

To play a game: a stone or piece of wood called noʻa was hidden on the person of a player, and the other players tried to guess on whom it was hidden; the game itself (Malo 218; For. 6:197–9), sometimes accompanied by gambling (Kam. 64:128–9).

1. A whistle sometimes blown during the game of pūhenehene; the answer of the players when addressed by the guesser in the game of pūhenehene (Malo 218) and perhaps also in the game of kilu.

2. Same as pūheheo.
Same as ʻenaʻena 2, cudweeds.

1. To burn, set on fire, bake (preceded by ke), Cf. hale puhi palaoa.

2. To blow, puff; blowhole; spouting, as by a whale; to smoke, as tobacco. Cf. puhi ʻole.

3. To extract, as water from steam; to distill, brew.

4. Eel (see below). A hitherto undescribed eel was identified in 1978 as Gymnothorax ruepelliae. Some persons considered puhi as ʻaumākua. Cf. waʻa puhi and saying, eel.

5. Same as maiʻa puhi, a banana.

6. Sticks supporting a pākuʻikuʻi net, called the puhi nui and the puhi ʻuʻuku (or puhi iki). Nets forming the ʻupena papa had the same names.

7. Uncircumcised foreskin.

8. See kua puhi, puhi kaokao.
Pas/imp. of puhi 1–3.
To burn, set on fire, cremate; arson, fireman who tends to the fire of a steam engine. See wahi puhi ahi.
An eel (Muraena pardalis). Also puhi kauila.
Barred moray eel, Gymnothorax ruepelliae (formerly G. petelli); the Hawaiian name was coined in 1978 by Mary Kawena Pukui.
An eel, Gymnothorax pictus.

1. To whirl, blow, as wind; gusty.

2. To break wind noiselessly.
Same as puhi palahoana, a fish.
A variety of eel. Lit., stick-like eel.
See puhi 6.
Infant eels, about the size of a lead pencil; catching infant eels with the hands. Lit., pinching eels.
Blowhole.
Active venereal sore.
An eel called by some voracious and fierce, perhaps Echidna nebulosa.
A species of eel (Gymnothorax pictus), or perhaps a variant of puhi kāpā.
A variety of eel. Lit., salt lightly eel.
Same as puhi ao, an eel.
According to some, young of all flying fish; according to others, same as mālolo.
A variety of small, white eel, mentioned in chants as eating fallen pandanus keys.
To burn cane trash or a cane field; burning cane.
A variety of white eel. Lit., morning-glory eel.
Poor, destitute; poverty.
A variety of sand-colored eel. Lit., sandstone eel.
A variety of eel (Myrichthys maculosus). Lit., wood eel.
A variety of eel (Lycodontis undulatus), highly relished. Lit., milo leaf eel.
To cremate, burn and reduce to ashes.
A variety of eel. Its coloring suggests a lei of pandanus keys. Lit., pandanus-lei eel.

1. To veer, as the wind. Cf. hili 2.

2. Confused, thwarted, frustrated, set to naught.

3. Same as pūhilihili, a vine.
Same as mohihihi, a vine.
Same as puhi 1–3; blowhole (preceded by ke).
A black and white eel that attacks and bites. Lit., cracked eel.
A variety of eel. Lit., food chewer.
A variety of eel.
See puhi 6.
A variety of eel. Lit., red-mouth eel.
A brightly colored eel (Muraena pardalis) up to 60 or 90 cm long. Cf. Marquesan puhi aʻoa, ʻoʻoa (Lavondès).
To play a wind instrument; a player of a wind instrument; a flute.
Same as pūhihio.
Infant eel.
A name applied to priests versed in all branches of the profession, as divining, meteorology, healing. (For. 6:59.) Probably lit., to blow to bits.
An eel mentioned by Kepelino (no data). Lit., bare eel.
A variety of eel. Lit., smooth eel.
To paint in spotted colors, as tapa.
Whitemouth moray eel, Lycodontis meleagris, 50 cm in length. Lit., spotted eel.
Same as puhi pule.
A variety of eel (Gymnothorax petelli).
See puhi ʻou
To smoke tobacco; one who smokes; smoking.
One of the commonest of the larger eels, Lycodontis flavimarginatus, perhaps up to 1.2 m long, considered dangerous by some. Cf. Marquesan puhi pata (Lavondès).
A shallow-water fish (Brotula multibarbata). Also puhi hoana, palahoana.
Tall, thin, emaciated. Rare.
Baker.
A variety of eel (no data).
A variety of eel (no data). Lit., burned eel.
Blown away; completely burned; to blow or burn away.
Redup. of puhi 2, to blow.
Redup. of puhi ahi. Fig., short-tempered.
A small, spotted eel. Lit., eel variegated in color.

1. To break wind audibly (cf. hio 3), considered rude; to cause failure by audible flatulency; a term of contempt for show-offs.

2. Irreverence; rude.
A variety of eel (Conger cinereus), mustache conger. It has a white ventral side and darker dorsal side and is nearly 1 m in length; greatly favored by some to eat.
A variety of eel (no data). Lit., calico (Eng.) ūhā eel.
Redup. of pūhiʻu 1, 2.
Name of a legendary eel; according to one authority, a Conger cinereus eel. Lit., red eel.
See puhi 6.
A variety of eel (no data). Lit., warm eel.
Same as pūhā 1.
Windy; to blow strongly, as through an aperture; a sweep of wind. See ex., polikua.
Same as pohole, hoʻopohole. Cf. hole 1.
See puhole
To steam, especially by stuffing flesh, as of pig, with hot rocks and placing in a sealed calabash; to take a sweat bath; to steam a corpse so that the flesh (pela) will separate from the bones.
Redup. of pūholo.
Conch trumpet; any wind instrument, as trumpet, cornet, saxophone. Lit., sounding triton shell.
Var. of pōhuehue, morning glory. (And.)
To grow thick, of huli, taro shoots.

1. Hairy, shaggy, downy, hirsute, bushy.

2. Same as hulu ʻīlio 1, 2, seaweeds.
Same as puʻipuʻi.
Sweet-smelling, diffused, as fragrance; permeated with perfume, fragrant.
Same as iheihe, a fish.

1. Difficult to acquire or do.

2. Packed, crowded.
Same as puhikiʻi, young flying fish.
Var. of pūliki 1.

1. Bamboo rattles, as used for dancing.

2. To clasp, hold fast in the hand, embrace, grasp firmly.

3. A type of tapa-beater pattern: tips of zigzag ridges in adjacent surfaces meet and form sunken lozenges. Cf. koʻeau, in which the ridges are parallel.

4. Berry of the pōpolo plant. Also ʻolohua.

5. A game played with sugar-cane flowers. Rare.
Pūʻili design with one or more hāluʻa ridges or strips between the panels of the beater.

1. Short for puʻu ʻiliʻili.

2. Similar to pūʻuluʻulu; to collect.
Pūʻili and koʻeau designs combined.
Plump, stout, stocky, heavy-set, sturdy, husky.
Redup. of puīa.
Startled, surprised, astonished, aghast, frightened; surprise, amazement, fright.
Redup. of pūʻiwa; to shy, as a horse; excitable, as a horse that is easily frightened.

1. Hole (perforation; cf. lua, pit); door, entrance, gate, slit, vent, opening, issue. Cf. pukaihu, puka kui, lei pūpū puka.

2. To pass through, appear, emerge, come out, get out of, issue, come into sight; to rise, as the sun.

3. To graduate.

4. To say, utter, speak.

5. To gain, win, profit; to draw interest; winnings, gain, profit.

6. Trap, snare. Cf. kīpuka.

7. Almost.
Mounted cannon, artillery. Lit., rolling gun.
To distribute evenly, as a fish catch. (And.)
To seal an affinal relationship by the birth of a child. Lit., appear to eye.
Exit, Exodus (in the Bible).
Window. Lit., transparent opening.
See pukaaniani
Door of a house; window (Isa. 60.8).
Same as pūpūkahi; sometimes said of the three Hawaiian gods, Kū, Kāne, and Lono.
Sheep market. (Ioane 5.2.)
Socket. Lit., hole for entering core.
A kind of fish. (And.)

1. Lime bleach for hair; to bleach.

2. Salty tears. Rare.
Trumpet leading an army.
Hole in pearl-shell shank.
Nostril. Lit., nose aperture.
To lift, as the feet in dancing; to swing on the foot, as a child. Rare.
Buzzard. Eng.
See pukaka
To cackle, cluck.
To flee, as in fright; scattered.
Anus opening. Lit., ancient hole.
Rare. var. of ʻōkalakala.
To gush forth, ramble. Rare.
Eye of a needle.
Needle slot of a sewing machine.
Anus aperture (vulgar).
To appear daily; daily.
Rough, boisterous, as wind; ruffled, mussed, tousled, disheveled, uncombed, as hair. Fig., bad temper; gruff.
Same as kalalī.
See "hoʻopukalia":  To bring forth. Ē ke ao uli, hoʻopukalia mai kīnohinohi (Kep. 29), O blue heavens, bring forth beauty.
Hook hole, noose, loop.
Opening for ventilation, window (1 Sam. 19.12); anus. Lit., wind hole.
Skylight.

A low, shrubby plant (Lythrum maritimum) native to Peru, with slender branches and small narrow leaves. Sometimes the bark is stripped off and wound around leis for its mild fragrance and small pink flowers. It belongs to the crape myrtle family. (Neal 617.) Also nīnika. Some persons qualify the name by lau liʻi and lau nui.

1. Outlet, exit, issue, exodus, descendant.

2. Keepsake, memento, remembrance, souvenir.
Souvenir of a beloved, gift from a loved one, keepsake.
Sunrise.
Source of water, especially from the ground.

Large woody vines (Bougainvillea spp.) from Brazil, bearing during their long flowering time masses of bright-colored bracts, which accompany small hidden flowers. Flower bracts are purple-red, rose-red, brick-red, and orange to whitish. (Neal 337–8.) Eng. Also pua kepalō.

1. Fine white leaves in the center of a cluster of pandanus leaves; fine soft sleeping mats made of these leaves.

2. Rare. var of wīkani.
Trumpet (1 Oihn. 13.8), any wind instrument. Lit., sounding horn.
Var. spelling of pukaaniani.
To oppose; strong; intensive of pūkani 2.
Tooth cavity.

1. A large opening or hole.

2. Var. of ʻāpua; basket of ʻieʻie vine aerial roots for carrying fishing gear.
Gate. (Ier. 17.24.) Lit., fence opening.
Osseous vagina. Lit., closed opening.
Gate of a city or house lot. Lit., house enclosure hole.
To rebuke mildly, as because of affection.
See pākākā 1.
A pore, as in the skin. Lit., dripping hole.
Buttonhole.
Turnstile. Lit., turning door.

1. Redup. of puka 1; many holes, filled with holes, chinks, cracks; pock-marked, as due to small-pox; porous, as stone; cells, as in honeycomb. See ex., papa manamana.

2. Redup. of puka 2–4.

3. Redup. of puka 5.
General, war leader, champion; second in command; fortress.
Artillery.
Smokestack, chimney.
Sliding door or gate, movable door, turnstile.
A bag or bundle carried on the back. Rare.

An old guessing game: a knot was tied in a cord and the two ends given to two persons to hold; the onlookers guessed and wagered whether the knot could be loosened by pulling on the ends of the string. This game was sometimes called in English slip trick. Many kinds are listed by Dickey.
Gun carried on the shoulder.
See puka 2.
Water outlet; eye of a coconut.
Book, volume (in a series). Types of books are listed below. Eng.
See puke
To strike, hit, beat. (Dan. 5.6.) I ka pūkē iki, i ka pūkē nui (PH 195), by the small onslaught, by the great onslaught.

1. Same as ʻainakea, a sugar cane.

2. See laenihi, a fish.
Text book, instruction book.
Spelling book.
Accounts book.
Reader, book or magazine to read.
Savings bank book.
Catalogue.
Folder, paper holder.
Memorandum, memoirs, diary, journal.
Book listing names, directory of names.
Postal savings deposit book.
To touch glasses, as before drinking.
Manual, book of directions.
Same as pūkeleʻai.
Handbook.

1. Var. of ʻūkele, muddy.

2. Bushel. Eng.
Small package of unmixed poi. (Paʻi ʻai is larger, and holo ʻai still larger.)
Catalogue.
Pocketbook. Eng.
Atlas.
Dictionary. Lit., book to explain words.

1. Boot. Eng.

2. “Broke,” out of funds (probably from Eng. boot).

1. Same as kōkō, a carrying net.

2. To check, curb, pull back, as an unruly horse.

1. The black-eyed Susan (Abrus precatorius), a slender climbing legume, long known in the tropics, especially for its small round red and black seeds, which are used for leis, rosaries, and costume jewelry. Though the seeds are edible when cooked, when raw and broken they are poisonous. Flowers are 
small, light-colored; leaves small, compound. (Neal 455–6.) Also pūpūkiawe, pūkiawe lei, to distinguish from pūkiawe 2 and pūkiawe ʻulaʻula on Niʻihau.

2. Native shrubs and small trees (Styphelia [Cyathodes], all species and varieties), 1 to 2 (rarely 4.5) m high, common near Kī-lau-ea Volcano, bearing narrow leaves 1.3 cm long, tiny whitish flowers, and many round red to white fruits .6 cm in diameter. The leaves were used medicinally for cold or headache. (Neal 663–4.) Also ʻaʻaliʻi mahu, kānehoa, kāwaʻu, maiele, pūpūkiawe.
Abrus precatorius f.
See kihi.
A variety of flying fish.

1. To tie. For variants see nīkiʻi.

2. Same as puhikiʻi.

1. Portuguese. Eng. Pukikī ʻeleʻele, dark-skinned Portuguese.

2. A tight-waisted dress, supposedly worn once by Portuguese.
Strong, boisterous, stormy, as wind.
Shotgun. Lit., gun that shoots gunshots.
Pudding. Eng.
Bookkeeper. Eng.
Water gun, squirt gun. Lit., gun shooting water.
See pū kī wai
Same as puaʻō; driven away.
Clump of sugar cane. Cf. pū kō koʻo.

1. Coral head.

2. Spotted, as in several colors. Cf. puaʻa pūkoʻa.

3. To rise, blow, as smoke.

4. Same as puʻukaʻa, a plant.

1. Redup. of pūkoʻa 1, 2.

2. A somewhat calcified green seaweed (Halimeda sp.), erect but not stiff, about 10 cm high, branching and spreading in fan shape, with round to triangular, flattened joints. Used medicinally, pounded up with laukahi (Plantago) and applied as a poultice to boils. The name may be qualified by the terms lau liʻi and lau nui.
Red, of tapa, as dyed with noni juice (Malo 49).
The lashing that holds the canoe spreader (wae) in place on a canoe.
To appear red, as sunset glow or blood.
To cackle, coo; cackling, cooing. See more common kokō.
Sugarcane clumps held up with sticks to prevent the long stems from falling down and taking root. Also pūkoʻo.
Team, as of oxen or mules putting a plow.
Name of a star.

1. Trio, triplet.

2. Triple canoe. (Laie 461, Malo 131.)
Strong, husky, muscular, virile, tough, mighty. Cf. konakona.
Same as pū kō koʻo.

1. To gather together, pucker; shrunken, contracted. Cf. pukupuku, pupuku, hāpuku.

2. Final offering; to end.
Pas/imp. of puku 1 and puku 2; to offer, as a fish.
Winter crookneck squash (Cucurbita moschata). (Neal 813.)

1. To collect, assemble, as people, things (puku + -ʻi, transitivizer: ).

2. Council, assembly, as of chiefs or gods, especially of the major gods, Kāne, Kū, Lono, and Kanaloa (pūkuʻi akua).tuki).

3. To sit doubled up, as for protection from the cold; to nestle together, as in embrace; to hug, huddle.

4. Hub, as of a wheel.
Redup. of pūkuʻi. 3.
Collected sweet-potato vines. Poetical, a stormy or whirling wind.

1. Redup. of pūkuʻi 1, 3.

2. A fish (no data).
Pas/imp. of puku 1.
Saving, miserly. Rare.
Cannon. Lit., gun burning fire. See ex., nākuʻi.
Redup. of puku 1; wrinkles, crumples, frowning; to wrinkle, frown, purse, as the lips.

1. Particle, as dust; particle in the eye, mote, speck; to have something in the eye. Cf. pulakaumaka.

2. Leafy branch, as of coconut, pandanus, or ʻilima, used as a broom to drive fish into a net and to poke into reef crevices in order to frighten out the fish.

3. Kindling; to start a fire with kindling.

4. A fish, perhaps Pempheris mangula.

5. Also pura n. Pur (see M. S. Miller and J. L. Miller, Harper's Bible Dictionary). (Eset. 3.7.)
Ti-leaf whistle.
A variety of sweet potato. (HP 142.)

A person one thinks of constantly, either because of affection or from a desire to injure or take revenge on; obsession, fixation. Lit., mote resting eye [one is as conscious of the individual as of a mote in the eye].
Cinder, as in a fire.

1. To hurry, rush; to hasten, as to touch, possess. Cf. lale 1.

2. Same as pula 2.
Redup. of pūlale.

1. Torch.

2. To care for, cherish, treasure, save.
Object of hatred. Lit., hot mote in eye. Cf. pulakaumaka.
To float; a floating object.
To bluff, as in poker; to fool. Eng. Pūlapu i ka wahine, to fool the woman.

1. Seedlings, sprouts, cuttings, as of sugar cane.

2. Descendant, offspring.

3. Annoyance, an offense to the eyes; to offend (used with maka) Cf. pulakaumaka.
Many Cf. pūliʻuliʻu 2.
Same as ʻōpūlauoho 1.

1. Foggy, cloudy. Rare.

2. Enough, ample, well-supplied. Rare.

Redup. of pūlawa 1–3.

1. Prayer, magic spell, incantation, blessing, grace, church service, church; to pray, worship, say grace, ask a blessing, cast a spell. (Probable derivatives are pulepule, pupule, and ʻōpulepule.) Many types of prayer are listed below.

2. Week.

3. Same as ʻōpule 1.
Same as ʻaha 3.
See ʻanāʻanā.
Sacrificial prayer.
Silent prayer.
See hana aloha.
Loose, insecure. Rare.

An octopus prayer: according to Emerson (Malo 111), such prayers were said to an octopus lying spread on the ocean floor (heʻe mahola) while it was being tempted with a cowry hook; the octopus once caught was offered to a deity for the curing of a patient; the prayer might also be said over the patient. Emerson gives such a prayer.
To gather together, as canoes. Rare.
An elongated type of cowry (Luria isabella); worn in leis. Rare.
A yellowish pūleho cowry. Lit., hōlei tree cowry, so named for the yellow dye extracted from the hōlei bark and root.
A streaked pūleho.

1. A small pūleho. Cf. kuiki.

2. A calus, as from carrying burdens on the shoulders.
Closing prayer, as in Christian service or in hana aloha sorcery.
Prayer to heal life.
Dedicatory prayer.
Prayer of thanks, benediction, grace; to say grace, to offer a prayer of thanks.
Same as pule hoʻouluulu ʻai; to continue praying. (Malo 177) Lit., continuation prayer.
Prayer to lift or free from taboo.
Prayer calling on a god to possess an individual or a hula altar.
A blessing; to ask a blessing, grace.
Prayer to insure good crops. (Malo 177.) Lit., prayer to make food grow.
Prayer sending gods or spirits of deified persons on errands of destruction. Lit., sending prayer.
See wilimoʻo.
An ivory-colored pūleho.
A red pūleho

1. To broil, as sweet potatoes, breadfruit or bananas placed on hot embers. Cf. kōʻala, to broil flesh.

2. Waterspout. Rare. Cf. waipuʻilani (PCP puulefu.)
To gum lehua flowers for the purpose of catching birds.

1. A prayer in unison.

A purification prayer. (Malo 97.)

1. Dusk, twilight. Cf. mōlehulehu. (PCP puule(fu)lefu.)

A storm at sea; rough, as the sea.

Gourd prayer offered during ceremonies, accompanying removal of a boy from his mother to the men's eating house; the sacrificed pig's ear was placed in a gourd hanging about the neck of an image of Lono; the child was referred to in the prayer as a gourd.
Rancid, musty. Rare.
Prayer calling on family gods.
A prayer for victory in battle.
See kāhoaka.
A fast prayer spoken in a moderate or natural voice. (Kam. 64:140.)
Purgatory. Eng.
See pulekakoli
Prayer of protection from any evil, as of hula teachers before a program. Cf. also Malo 113. Lit., removal prayer.
A black magic prayer, as to destroy a victim.
Bulletin. Eng.

See kuili.
Prayer uttered as a part of kuni, black magic.
Scrofulous neck sore.

1. Butterfly, moth, the Ka-mehameha butterfly (Vanessa tameamea). (KL. line 288.) See ex., ʻāolo.

2. Blown in the air, as spray.
Var. name for Pulelehua Kea.
The Greater Magellanic Cloud. Lit., white butterfly.
The Lesser Magellanic Cloud. Lit., dark butterfly.
To float, wave, rise, as a flag or fire (often used in sense of triumph after ʻōʻili).

Family prayer; to pray, of a family.
Prayer to ward off evil influence. Lit., protecting prayer.
To turn over, reverse. Rare.

1. Same as pupule.

Light, as wind. Rare.
Same as pūhilihili. (AP)
Puritan. Eng.

1. Short for pūholo.

2. Also buro n. Bureau, agency. Eng.
To pass by, especially of one alone; lonely. Rare.
Species of octopus that comes out at night, with longer head (pū) and tentacles than those of the common octopus; it is used for bait rather than for food.
Bureau of Emigration. Lit., bureau for boarding ships.
Visitor's bureau.

1. Comely (Ier. 6.2), tender (Isa. 47.1), as of a virgin. (PCP pulotu.)

1. To cover the head; head covering.

1. Redup. of pūloʻu.

2. A tapa-covered ball on a stick (pahu) carried before a chief as insignia of taboo.

3. A steam bath, as for certain illnesses.

1. Wet, moist, soaked, saturated.

2. A soft, glossy, yellow wool on the base of tree-fern leaf stalks (Cibotium spp.). It was used to stuff mattresses and pillows and at one time was exported to California. Hawaiians stuffed bodies of their dead with pulu after removing vital organs.

3. Any greenery or underbrush cut to be used as mulch, as well as the mulch itself; coconut husk, coconut fiber, raw cotton, tapa pulp; cushion; fine linen; tinder, kindling; soft, padded; to kindle, as fire (preceded by ke). See ex., ʻē 1.

4. Low branch, as of certain trees such as ʻohai, koa, ʻōhiʻa.

5. Also bulu n. Bull. Eng. Keoni Pulu, John Bull.

6. nvs. To fool; fooled; fool. Eng. Cf. kamipulu.
Two persons together, as for mutual help.
A snare used to catch shrimps and small fish, made of sennit and coconut midrib. Lit., sennit husk.
Odor of perspiration combined with dirt, body odor; to have such.
Drenched, soaked.
Drenched. (Perhaps pulu 1 + -hi, transitivizer.)
Flute. Eng. Rare.
Soaked, drenched.
Same as pulukā.

Hazy, foggy, cloudy. Fig., befogged, as with sleep.

1. Also buruminvt. Broom; to sweep; to sweep away, as foe (For. 5:721). Eng.

The cotton plant (Gossypium barbadense), a shrub in the mallow family, from tropical America. The leathery seed cases contain black seeds, which yield a valuable oil, and masses of white cotton fiber, used for cloth. (Neal 565.) Also pulupulu.
Common people. Lit., human mulch.
Land patch. Rare.
Small opening or door, as in a chief's sleeping house. Rare.
Var. of pumehana. (Ioba 31.2O.) hoʻo.puma.hana Var. of hoʻopumahana.

Stalk with many branches, said of a person with many descendants.
Warm, warm-hearted; warmth, affection.
Boom or spar, as of a ship. Eng.

Machine gun.

1. Spring (of water). Cf. pūnāwai.

Mortar. Lit., plastering coral.

A favorite or pet; to treat as a favorite (children were often treated as favorites; they might be carried on the grandparent's shoulders, and songs were composed for them); favoritism. (This word may have the loaʻa-type of construction; see .) No kēia punahele o ʻAu-kele i kō lākou makuakāne, because their father made a favorite of ʻAu-kele.
Moldy, mildewed.

A barely visible rainbow. (GP 8.)
White coral, as cast ashore by the sea. (GP 16.)
Teaspoon.
Ladle. Lit., dipping spoon.
Formerly, spouses sharing a spouse, as two husbands of a wife, or two wives of a husband; also, wives of brothers, husbands of sisters (no sexual privileges); sister-in-law (Ruta 1.15).

1. Nest, gathering place, shelter, hive; to nest. Fig., home.

2. A variety of sweet potato.

3. A process of making women's pāʻū; white tapa.
Same as nanā, surly.
White tapa used for making pāʻū.

A fern (Asplenium caudatum), 60 cm high or more, known from Polynesia west into Africa. It resembles the kupukupu, but the narrow-oblong divisions of the frond taper to sharp points, and the spores are borne in oblique lines, not in dots. Lit., bird nest.
Beehive.

1. Same as nananana, a species of spider.

2. Spider's web.
Large spoon, serving spoon (preceded by ke).
Gypsum.

3. Scattered, wind-blown, pulverized. Rare.
Short for puʻunaue
Water spring.
Rain name. Lit., spray [of] rain.
Fine, as a spider's web; thin.
Cobweb, spider web; spinning spider.

1. Movable couch; pew (rare), table (Mar. 7.4). Cf. the immovable hikieʻe.

Redup. of pūneʻe 2.
To cluster, as leaves. Rare.
Same as nenelu. Rare.
Same as ʻai-a-ka-nēnē, a plant.

1. Surrounded, controlled; overcome, as in battle or by emotion; to pervade, gain control of; to enclose (loaʻa-type construction; ).

2. To be fond of, desire, covet, like, be partial to; devoted; a favorite thing, delight, love. Cf. puni ʻai, puni kālā, puni kaua, puni koko, puni leʻaleʻa, puni nani, puni waiwai.

3. Deceived, deluded; to believe a lie. Cf. puni wale.

4. Completed, terminated, as a period of pregnancy; completely, all.

5. A fine-meshed net. Also nae, naepuni.

6. An even number; to be such. See ʻoi 3.

1. Pas/imp. of puni 1–4.

2. Head cold.

3. A kind of coconut, the husk of which is chewed for its sweet juice.
Fond of eating; glutton.
Fearful, afraid; to run off in fear.
Same as hoʻokamaniha.
Ensnared, entangled, caught, as in a trap; gullible, easily tricked; captivating, fascinating, entrancing.
Fond of going about from place to place, addicted to travel.
Lofty, majestic, dignified. Rare.
To bristle, as sea urchins. Rare.
Studious, fond of study.
Black-skinned, Negroid. Cf. nika, nigger.

Avaricious, mercenary, commercial-minded.

Avaricious, covetous, desirous of wealth.
Gullible, easily deceived, swayed, influenced. See also other meanings of puni.

1. To rise, as smoke, mist; to billow out, as a ship's sail; to spread out, as a shrub with low branches or as a cloud, to whiffle; such rising.

3. Slate pencil sea urchin. Also hāʻueʻue.
Smoke, clouds rising and spreading.

Affable, good-natured.
Red dye from noni-root bark; red, as tapa dyed thus.

Same as puaʻō; to blaze up, as fire; to bend, as coconut fronds in a wind; to lift up; to bloom.

Job's-tears (Coix lachryma-jobi), a coarse, branched grass closely related to corn, growing in many tropical regions, either wild or cultivated. It is an annual.3 to 1.8 m high, with long, pointed leaves, and, at stem tips, hard, round, beadlike seeds—black, gray, or white—which are used for leis, mats, food, medicine. (Neal 80–1.) Also kūkaekōlea, ʻoheʻohe, pūpū kōlea.
Startled; to cry out in alarm; fright, shock; to explode, as a lava flow; to wake suddenly; sudden appearance, as a burst of fragrance.
To rage, burn hot.

To place high, or in a lofty or sacred place. Rare.
Conch horn.
Bundle, bag, container, parcel, packet; bale, as of hay; to tie up in a bundle. Cf. kiʻoʻōpae, mālama pūʻolo.
A kind of grass. (And.)
To save, preserve. (And.)
A shell (Partridge tun).
Redup. of puʻō; to blaze up and die down; to bob up and down, as a canoe in the waves.

Toy gun, popgun.
Roebuck (RSV), fallow deer (KJV). (1 Nal. 4:23.) Eng. Cf. pāpulō.

Pistol. Lit., snapping gun, revolver.

Bubonic. Eng. See ex., hoene.

1. To stall; to move slowly and with difficulty, as a canoe or invalid; to remain near; stuck, blocked, Pupū ke kaʻa, the car is stalled.

6. See ʻupena papa.

1. To crouch, as a cat about to pounce; to draw up the legs, as for warmth.

Same as puʻipuʻi.

Ugly, unsightly, unseemly, unattractive, homely, wicked (frequently pūpuka for emphasis; if said with a friendly or admiring intonation among friends, it meant the opposite, i.e., beautiful, attractive; this was due to reluctance to express admiration for fear a sorcerer would in jealousy bewitch the admired person; it is also said in answer to the question pehea ʻoe, how are you, with meaning that one is improving but hesitates to say he is well for fear of bad luck).
United, as in harmonious co-operation.
Perhaps a Kauaʻi var. of pūpū kani oe. (Kel. 61.)
A land shell (Partulina physa). Lit., shell that sounds long, so called because of the belief that land shells sing.
A stone used as an octopus lure.
Same as pūkiawe 1, 2, plants.
A rare land shell (Succinea olaaensis). Lit., tropic-bird shell.

1. Same as pūʻoheʻohe, Job's-tears.

2. Same as kōlea, periwinkle.
A land shell (Partulina confusa). Lit., inland-plover shell.
Same as pukupuku.
Land shell.
A land shell (Lamellaxis oparanum). Also pololei. Lit., mountain ridge shell.
A marine shell (Natica gualteriana). Lit., pin shell.
A marine shell (Trachycardium orbita, Periglypta reticulata). Lit., native shell.
Topknot.
Crazy, insane, reckless, wild (sometimes pūpule for emphasis; probably derived from pule, prayer: see haihaiā, ʻōpulepule). Cf. holo pupule.
A cowry shell (Cypraea moneta). Lit., cowry or calloused shell.
A bead of any kind, a shell for a shell lei.
A marine shell (Mitra litterata).
A marine shell (Hydatina amplustre, Bursa granularis). Lit., pandanus-lei shell.
Same as pūpū Pākē. Lit., irrigated-terrace shell.
Auger shell. Lit., long shell.

1. Same as pulupulu.

2. Same as mumulu, to swarm. Rare.
A marine shell (Turbo sandwicensis). Lit., moon shell, so called because the operculum is round like the moon.
A marine shell (Rhinoclavis sinensis, Cerithium nesioticum). Lit., sennit-mesh shell.
A marine shell (Morula granulata). Lit., sour-faced shell.
A marine shell (Turbo sandwicensis).
A marine shell (Strombus maculatus).
A small mother-of-pearl shell (Spondylus tenebrosus). Lit., pearl shell.
A chiton mollusk. Lit., lizard shell.
Redup. of puni 1–4.
Broom made of coconut midribs tied together at one end. A later name is pūlumi nīʻau.
Small shells, especially Columbella and Leptothyra used in Niʻihau shell leis; known as momi or momi-o-kai on Niʻihau.
A marine shell (no data). Lit., sitting shell.
A shell (Fusinus nicobarus, Latirus nodatus). Lit., long-beaked shell.
A shell (Trochus histrio). Lit., Hāʻupu-hill shell.
Trochidae shell. Lit., sharpbuttocks shell.
A marine shell (Terebra maculata, Pyramidella sulcata).
A marine shell (Cymatium muricinum).
A marine shell (Tapes japonica). Lit., bivalve shell.
A marine shell (Haminoea sp.). Lit., milkfish-eyeball shell.
An introduced edible shellfish (perhaps Viviparus sp.), found in taro or rice patches; Chinese snail. Also pūpū loʻi.
A marine shell (Janthina fragilis). Lit., cork shell.
A marine shell (Acanthochiton viridis); used in māwaewae ceremonies for first-born babies. Lit., caterpillar shell. Also kuapaʻa.
Var. of pūpū ʻalā. Lit., dizzy shell, perhaps so called because they were considered poisonous.

1. Numerous, crowded, thick, teeming, congested.

2. Double-flowering, as hibiscus, hollyhock, pīkake.

3. Temporary hut, as for shelter from the sun for beating tapa; hovel; covering.

4. White tapa.
Redup. of pupua 2.
Redup. of pupue 1.
Same as pupuhi.

1. Sundial shell (Solarium sp.), Called hālili in some localities.

2. Conch shell. Lit., shell to blow.
To double up, draw the limbs together; foetal position, hence, fig., the womb; position of an infant able to get up partially on its knees.
See pupuʻu.
Pas/imp. of pupuʻu.
A shell (Bulla sp.). Lit., longmouthed shell.

1. Clump of grass; clump of greenery, especially as placed on the hula altar to the goddess Laka.

2. A chant prayer to Laka after a period of training in the hula to free the taboo.

1. Any kind of a protuberance from a pimple (puʻu 2) to a hill: hill, peak, cone, hump, mound, bulge, heap, pile, portion, bulk, mass, quantity, clot, bunch, knob; heaped, piled, lumped, bulging; pregnant; to pucker. Fig., obstacle, burden, problem, discomfort, trouble, sorrow. Cf. alelo puʻu, ʻōkolepuʻu, puʻu kālā.

2. Any of various round parts or protuberances of the body, as pimple, wart, mole, callus, lump, Adam's apple, throat (see ex., burn), larynx, tonsils, heart, stomach, fist, knuckle, ankle joint; gizzard, as of chicken; hard stomach, as of some fish. Cf. puʻu kohekohe, puʻupuʻu, puʻupuʻu lima, puʻupuʻu wāwae, puʻuwai.

3. A desire, need, as for evacuation (used with hī, kiʻo, mimi, pūhiʻu).

4. Any earth bug, beetle, especially as found in dry earth; rose beetle, Olinda beetle, stinkbug, ground beetle.

5. Hand of cards, stack of cards, deck or pack of cards. Cf. puʻu pepa.

6. Stack, shock, as of grain. (Lunk. 15.5.) Nā puʻu hua palaoa (Puk. 22.6), stacks of grain.

7. Head, as of cabbage or lettuce; to form a head, sprout.

1. Rain; to rain; rainy. See rain. Rain was beloved as it preserved the land; it was called kāhiko o ke akua, adornment of deity. For symbolic connotations of rain cf. wai 1, rain, and Elbert 1962. Many rains are named and associated poetically with particular places. Many rain names refer to the action of rain on plants, as Hehi-pua-hala, Kani-lehua, Kinai-lehua, Lū-lau-kō, Moaniani-lehua, Moe-lehua, Pōʻai-hala. Other names show the supposed effects of rain on people or their possessions, as Poʻo-lipilipi, Poʻo-nui, Popo-kapa, Pupū-hale. See hikikiʻi 1, lehua, Hilo. Rains are often referred to with ua preceding a base, as ua Kuahine. They are entered in this dictionary without initial Ua. (Ua- is retained before prepositions, as Ua-ma-ka-lau-koa.) Ua liʻiliʻi, light rain, drizzle.

2. Aforementioned, the one talked of.

3. Common part. preceding verbs and denoting completed or recently completed action; to become.
Indicator of the dual number in first and third persons of pronouns and poss. only (kāua, māua, lāua). Cf. -lua 2 and .

1. The sweet potato (Ipomoea batatas), a perennial, wide-spreading vine, with heart-shaped, angled, or lobed leaves and pinkish-lavender flowers. The tuberous roots are a valuable food, and they vary greatly in many ways, as in color and shape. Though of South American origin, the plant has been a staple food since ancient times in many parts of Polynesia, as well as in some other regions. (HP 131–66, Neal 706–7.) (PEP kumala; cognates elsewhere in Polynesia may be borrowings from PEP.)

2. A variety of sugar cane, a yellow mutant of ʻakoki with large stalks; often called pilimai and similar to it but stronger. (HP 221, 225.)

3. See uhi ʻuala, a variety of yam (Dioscorea alata).

The white or Irish potato (Solanum tuberosum), a weak-stemmed herb about .9 m high, with lobed leaves. The white, starchy, underground tuber is a valuable food in many countries. A native of the Andes, it was introduced to Hawaiʻi in the early 1800s. (Neal 745.) He Hawaiʻi ʻuala kahiki, an Irish-potato Hawaiian [one who apes white men instead of appreciating his own culture]. 1. To jerk, pull, twist, pry, turn, sway. Cf. naue.

2. A hula step: the caller announces the step to drummer (who changes the beat) and dancers by calling e ue (e imperative and ue). The right foot is extended forward with toes pointing, while both arms are brought forward to chest level with hands crossed and fingers tipped upward; the left hand stays up, while right arm and foot swing back in an outward arc. Then the right arm and foot are moved forward, and the step is repeated to the left. Then three short steps are taken forward. 3. The yam (Dioscorea alata), from southeast Asia, a climber with square stems, heart-shaped leaves, and large, edible, underground tubers. The plant is widely distributed through islands of the Pacific, where it is commonly grown for food. (HP 166–172, Neal 230.) Also pālau, ulehihi. In the past botanists have applied the name uhi incorrectly to the hoi kuahiwi.

4. Mother-of-pearl bivalve, mother-of-pearl shank.

5. Turtle shell piece used for scraping olonā.

6. Mark made by the gall of raw pūpū ʻawa (a shellfish) on tapa or on the skin as an ornament. (PCP u(f,s)i.)
Pas/imp. of uhi 1.fia.)
A variety of yam, the tuber having white flesh and skin; grown in Puna, Hawaiʻi. (HP 168.)
To debate, argue. Rare.
Patchwork cover or spread.

A variety of yam, the tuber with mottled red and white flesh and white skin; grown at Hāʻena, Kauaʻi. (HP 168.) Also uhi ʻōniʻoniʻo.
A variety of yam, grown throughout the islands; tuber with white flesh and skin. (HP 168.)
Body covering, garment, shield.

Grasshopper. (Oihk. 11.22.) (Gr.

Sonorous puffing and blowing sounds, as accompanying the surging of volcanic fires; to puff or blow thus; shish-shish. See ex., nome.

1. Redup. of uhi 1.

2. An endemic legume (Mezoneuron kauaiense), a tree with pink or red flowers and thin, broad, winged pods (Neal 435). The wood is hard and heavy and formerly was used for hōlua (sleds), spears, digging sticks, and house construction. Also kawaʻū, kea, kolomona, and the weedy herb Phaseolus lathyroides (Niihau).
Whine, as of a child; to whine.
A yam, probably the same as uhi lehua.

1. Heavy fog, mist. Lit., water covering.

Plural of hole; to strip, as tough skin of fish such as manini, humuhumu.
Plural of holo, to run.
Plural of honi.

1. The parrot fishes, of which Scarus perspicillatus is among the most abundant and largest; uhu are plant eaters, the teeth are strong and beaklike, well fitted for clipping off food from coral. The name may be qualified by the terms aʻa, ʻāhiuhiu, ʻahu ʻula or ʻula, ʻeleʻele, halahala, kuwalakai or pālukaluka, lā uli, pānoa, piko ʻula, and uliuli. Name of growth stages are 
ʻōhua (very young), pānuhu or pōnuhunuhu (medium), and uhu (mature). Variant names are male and ʻōmale for a young stage. The colors of this fish are so pretty that it is sometimes compared to a sweetheart: Momomi wale kuʻu ʻono i ka uhu māʻalo i kuʻu maka, my craving makes my mouth water for the parrotfish passing before my eyes.

2. A variety of sugar cane.

3. To bolt, break away, as a horse; to pull, strain, chafe under restraint; willful, headstrong.

, interj. To sigh, moan, groan; to grunt as a pig (often used after kani); interj. of scorn (Kel. 20), huh! Kani ʻuhū aʻe ana i ke aloha ʻole o kuʻu kaikamahine, sighing over the heartlessness of my daughter.
Rare var. of ʻuao.

Rustle, roar; to rustle (ʻuʻina and nākolo).

A variety of musical bow, 40 to 60 cm long and about 4 cm wide, with two or commonly three strings drawn through holes at one end. The strings were strummed. According to Roberts (see Bibliography), the old experts made no sound with the vocal 
cords, but the mouth cavity acted as a resonance chamber. The resulting sound suggested speech and trained persons could understand. It was sometimes used for love making. To play the ʻūkēkē. Cf. nīʻau kani.
Jew's-harp. Lit., striking musical bow.
Jew's-harp. Lit., metal musical bow.
Same as ʻukeke, ʻakekeʻe, a bird.
Muddy; oily; slush.

Small change. Eng. Kaʻū.

All cultivated forms of Gladiolus (as G. blandus), ornamental plants in the iris family, with sword-shaped leaves and one-sided sprays of large colorful flowers. (Neal 235.)

1. Cold sores, any sores about the corners (kihi) of the mouth; to have such. Fig., to talk too much.

Dianella sandwicensis, a native member of the lily family, with a short stem and long, narrow leaves, from among which arises a cluster of white or bluish flowers. The attractive fruits are blue, long-persistent berries formerly used to dye tapa. (Neal 191–2.)
Redup. of ʻukī.
Perhaps the same as ʻŪkiu, but a rain associated with Hikilei, Kauaʻi. (For. 6:454.)

To enter together. See komo.
Same as kole, a fish.
Same as ukokole 1, 2.

Useless, of no use.

1. Pay, payment, wages, fee, fare, toll, commission, reward, recompense, compensation, remittance, tuition, prize, fine, tax, installment, tribute; to pay, remunerate, compensate, repay, revenge. Many types of uku are listed below.

Tick, mite (Acari).

Tiny, small, petite; wee; small flea or louse.
