1. Place in the grass house where host and guests visited, between the sleeping place and the door.

2. Name for that portion of a canoe between forward and after outrigger booms.

1. Spiny lobster (Panulirus marginatus and P. penicillatus). Varieties are qualified by the terms hiwa, koaʻe, and poni.

2. A flame; to flame, blaze.

1. Red, scarlet; brown, as skin of Hawaiians; to appear red.

2. Short for koaʻe ʻula, red-tailed tropic bird.

3. Sacred; sacredness; regal, royal (probably so called because red was a sacred color). Cf. ʻaha ʻula, ʻūlāleo.

4. Blood.

5. Agate. (Puk. 30.12.)

6. Same as ʻula ʻai hāwane.

8. Ghost, spirit. Cf. ʻūlāleo.
Var. of hulaʻa, kulaʻa.
Fire flames.
Same as ʻula hiwa.

A small red Hawaiian honey creeper, with black crown, wings and tail and gray neck (Ciridops anna), formerly endemic to the island of Hawaiʻi, probably now extinct. Lit., red bird eating hāwane fruit.
Chiefly blood.
Lizard fishes of the family Synodontidae, Synodus spp., Saurida gracilis, common reef fishes. Varieties are qualified by the terms niho ʻā, ʻula, and uli.
Faded red.
To appear and disappear quickly, as steam. Rare.
Purplish red, dark red, as of a Rhode Island Red chicken; a red cock; formerly, a black cock with red neck feathers and red rump feathers. See ex., uakea 2.

Red streaked or dotted with dark, said of red feathers and a type of red feather cloak; to be such.

A reddish-hued rain associated with Haʻikū, Maui, and Mt. Kaʻala, Oʻahu. Also a wind at Piʻiholo, Maui (Nak. 68).
Yellowish-red.
An intense emotional appeal to the gods, as in chant; a voice from the spirits.

1. Measles; red spots of measles

2. Dotted swiss or other cloth with red spots; red spots.

1. To plait, weave, knit, braid; plaiting, weaving. Also unala, nala, unana.

Blood-red.

A bright-red percale; a vivid red, brandy red.
A gray crayfish (Parribacus antarcticus). Lit., flat ula.

1. Redup. of ʻula 1; bay, as a horse.

2. Various red snappers of the family Lutjanidae as Etelis marshi. Varieties are qualified by the terms hiwa, koaʻe (tropic bird, perhaps named because of the long streamer on the fishʻs tail thought to resemble the bird), maoli, ʻōpūlauoho.

3. A native variety of taro, with red or purple petioles, small leaf blades with purple piko, reddish flowers, the corms used for both poi and table taro, grown in wetland and upland culture. (Whitney 50–52.) ʻUlaʻula may be qualified by the terms kumu, moano, and poni.

4. The cardinal, Kentucky cardinal (Cardinalis cardinalis), established in about 1930

5. Blood.

6. A red tapa.

7. A variety of sugar cane. (HP 222, 225.)
Redup. of ʻulaʻa.
Dark red, formerly said of dark bay horses.

A child whose sire was a chief and whose mother a commoner. Lit., birthmark red.

See ʻulaʻula 1.
To fish, of many persons or often.
Wine-red.
A glowing red, as from fire.
Dark-red.

1. Penis. For imaginative compounds see ʻaʻawa 1, ʻaweule, ulehala, ulehole, ulepaʻa, ulepuaʻa, uleʻulu.

1. A native spreading shrub (Osteomeles anthyllidifolia), closely allied to other species found on some other islands of the Pacific. It has compound leaves, small white roselike flowers, small round white fruits. The wood is tough and formerly was used for digging sticks, fish spears, and the ʻūkēkē (musical bow). (Neal 387.) Also eluehe.

2. Digging stick of ʻūlei wood. See ex., wali.
Subincised or circumcised penis. See kahe ule.

1. To leap at, get into action, do quickly, do at once; one moving swiftly.

2. To set, as type.
A type of sugar cane, unknown in 1978, once used as a salve (For. 5:585); perhaps the same as ʻawela melemele and uluhui. (HP 225.)
A male who has not known a woman; not to have or have had relations with a woman. Lit., bound penis.

1. Harelip. Also kūlepe.

2. Erect, as a cockʻs comb; to stand erect; to bristle with anger.
Same as wilipuaʻa. Lit., pig penis.
Same as ʻeleu.

1. Pendulous, hanging. (PCP uleule.)

2. Sty, as on the edge of the eyelid.
Same as ule hala.
Spry, active, nimble. Rare.
Redup. of ʻuleu.
Male breadfruit flower. Lit., breadfruit penis. Also pōule and pōʻulu.

1. Name of a goddess of sorcery, said to have come from Kahiki. See HM 574, PH 144–7.

2. Early stage in the development of a foetus, as the body begins to form.

3. Name given by Malo for subjects of the chief; Emerson says they are black-haired persons. (Malo 194, 201.)

4. To steer; steersman.

5. Short for ʻōuli, omen.

6. Crowing of a cock. Rare.

7. Type of sweet potato (no data). (For. 5:664–5.)
To rattle, especially of seeds in the ʻulīʻulī, gourds; to gurgle.
Accident; sudden; to come upon suddenly.
Fitness, aptitude; preparedness, as for running. Rare.

1. A small endemic shrub (Phyllostegia glabra and varieties), in the mint family. Leaves are ovate, 7 to 15 cm long; flowers are small, white, tubular, abundant, in racemes.

2. Feebleness, of old age. Rare.
Tiny, wee, petite.
Soft, sticky, claylike, glutinous, adhesive, gluey.
Redup. of ʻūlika.
Bruises or wounds of a warrior.

1. Wandering tattler (Heteroscelus incanum), a slender regular winter migrant to Hawaiʻi, slaty above and white with dusky bars and streaks beneath. It breeds in Alaska and the Yukon. The cry of the bird; to cry thus.

2. Police whistle; ancient type of bamboo whistle; sound of these whistles. The whistles are said to be named for the cry of the tattler.

3. A bamboo tube used for blowing on a fire; to use this tube.

4. A musical instrument consisting of three gourds pierced by a stick; a whirring sound is made by pulling a string, thus twirling the gourds.

5. Hula step similar to ʻuwehe, except that only one heel at a time is raised; this step has a distinctive beat.

6. Same as hū, small gourd used as a spinning top; to spin this top.

7. Steep, as a mountain road.

8. Firm.

9. A religious ceremony in ʻanāʻanā, sorcery.

10. Var. of hulili.

11. Poles separating bannisters, as on stairs; rails of hōlua sleds.
Flooring inside a peleleu canoe where paddlers might rest their feet.
Urim. (Heb. or Eng.) (Puk. 28.3O.)
See Ulima
Soft, rubbery, plastic. Cf. papālina.
Redup. of ʻūlina.

1. Same as uli 1.

2. A kind of rock from which adzes were made. (Malo 19.)

3. Name of a star (no data).
A gourd rattle, containing seeds with colored feathers at the top, used for the hula ʻulīʻulī (at one time there were no feathers); to rattle.
A stroke in lua fighting. Lit., the cliffs of great Tahiti are green.

1. Rare variants for ʻūlili 3, 7.

2. Same as pūʻulīʻulī, a gourd.
Same as lohi, slow.
To cry out, as a prayer or lamentation; such crying.
A prayer as to a god not an ʻaumakua, family god.

1. To grow, increase, spread; growth; increase or rising of the wind; to protect (PH 116, For. 6:474). Also unu. Cf. mea ulu.

2. Possessed by a god; inspired by a spirit, god, ideal, person, as for artistic creation; stirred, excited; to enter in and inspire. Also unu.

3. Grove (see ulu kanu, Ulu-kou, ulu kukui, ulu lāʻau, ulu niu); assemblage, collection, or flock, as of stars (ulu hōkū), birds (ulu manu), ships (ulu moku), canoes (u!u waʻa).

4. Same as the more common uluulu 3.

5. Stick used in spreading hot oven stones; to spread the stones.

6. Kind of tapa made at Wai-piʻo, Hawaiʻi; name of a quilt design.

7. Center, as of a canoe or net. Cf. uluna 3.

8. A name used repeatedly in For. 5:703–9 for Ka-weloʻs warriors whose names begin with Ka-ulu (Ka-ulu-kauloko, Ka-ulu-kau-waho).
See uluna 1.

1. The breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), a tree perhaps originating in Malaysia and distributed through tropical Asia and Polynesia. It belongs to the fig family, and is grown for its edible fruits, sometimes for ornament. The leaves are large, oblong, more or less lobed; fruits are round or oblong, weighing up to 4.5 kilos, when cooked tasting something like sweet potatoes. (Neal 302–4.) See ex., pakī, and saying ule 1.

2. Round, smooth stone as used in ʻulu maika game; bowling ball; bell clapper; dice.

3. Muscles in calf of leg.

4. Name for konāne stone.

1. Certain species of crevalle, jack, or pompano, an important game fish and food item. Cf. ulua aukea, ulua ʻeleʻele, and paʻopaʻo. Unidentified ulua are qualified by the terms kaha uli, kihikihi (or kihi or huli pū), lā uli, mahai, mohaʻi (AP), nuku momi, uli. Growth stages are pāpio (or pāpiopio), pāʻūū, and ulua, the last attaining a length of 1.5 m and a weight of over 45 kilos. This fish was substituted for human sacrifices when the latter were not available, probably because of word magic and the meaning of ulua 2. Since an ulua replaces a man, ulua also means “man, sweetheart,” especially in love songs (see ex., wewehi).

2. Similar to ulu 1, 2.
Similar to pāʻuluʻā. Rare.

1. Same as ʻuluʻulu.

2. Same as ʻunua.
A variety of ulua, probably Caranx ignobilis, one of the largest of ulua. Also ulua kea.
A variety of dark-skinned ulua, probably most commonly Caranx melampygus. Lit., black ulua.

1. Mania, delusion, craziness; deranged; somewhat crazy, sometimes believed due to possession by a spirit.

2. Overgrowth; to grow wild and lush; bushy.
See "hoʻoulu ʻai":  To grow food plants; a prayer to bless crops. Heiau hoʻoulu ʻai, temple where first crops were offered. Kahuna hoʻoulu ʻai, a priest who made such offerings, agricultural expert.
Same as ulua paʻopaʻo. Lit., striped ulua.
A variety of ulua, Alectis sp.
Probably a species of ʻōmilu, a fish. Lit., beeswax ulua.
Offering, especially as made to priests for them to offer to the gods.
Genealogist in the hale nauā. (Malo 200.)
Officer in the hale nauā. (Malo 200.)

1. Confusion, mob, disturbance, riot; tumult; gathered in excitement and confusion.

2. Jungle; growing in wild profusion.
Probably same as ʻōmilu, a fish.
A wind associated with Wai-ākea, Hawaiʻi (Nak. 53.)
Name of a stormy Maui wind.
See paʻopaʻo. Also ulua kāniʻo.
Brush, undergrowth, forest. Rare.
Name recorded by Thrum for a tree with hard wood.
Same as haʻehaʻe, intense feeling.
Elevated place in the high chiefʻs house where those of rank might rest. (For. 6:418.)
Lumpy, as of poi; knotty, bumpy, pimply. Cf. ʻuʻuluhaku.
Same as moku hale. (Kam. 64:106.)
Of the same age group, contemporary, Lit., birth growth.
Rough, jagged, as rocks. Cf. hāoʻeoʻe.
Same as ulu haʻo.

All Hawaiian species of false staghorn fern (formerly known as Gleichenia spp., now listed under three genera: Dicranopteris, Hicriopteris, Sticherus), weedy, creeping, branching ferns, forming dense thickets. (Neal 9.) Also unuhe.
A large species of false staghorn fern (Hicriopteris pinnata, formerly known as Gleichenia glauca).
Pas/imp. of ulu 1, 2.
Constellation.
Vexed, annoyed, discouraged, displeased (1 Nal. 20.43), harassed, weary, offended, angry.
See ʻāwela melemele and uleʻohiʻu.
See "hoʻoulu iʻa":  To cause fish to be numerous, as by prayer.
Same as ulu 4; to stir up an oven. (For. 4:259.)
Water chestnut. Lit., sea growing.
Var. of hōkake, to disturb.
Clapper of a bell.
Garden patch.
Unexplained acquisition of prophetic and interpretive powers without visible possession by a god. Lit., placed inspiration.
See "hoʻoulu kauō":  To inspire canoe haulers by chant and prayer.
Name of a star. Also Uluʻoa.
First victim slain in battle.

1. Site of the MoanaHotel, Wai-kīkī, Honolulu.

2. An old name for Howland Island. Lit., kou tree grove.
Disturbed, upset, restless, depressed, nervous, agitated, perturbed; nervousness, agitation; to disturb. See ex., hana aloha.
Same as ulukū.
Candlenut grove.
Ostrich (RSV), owl (KJV). (Kanl. 14.15.) (Lat., ulula.)
Forest, grove of trees.
See ulu 1.
A chiefʻs favorite. (AP)
Name of a star, said to appear on the night of Muku in the month of Māhoe-Mua. Cf. Pauwala.
Var. spelling of uluulu.
Festive, attractively adorned and arrayed; to make a fine appearance, decorated, pleasing.
Stone used in maika game; to play the ʻulu maika game; bowling, bowling ball.
A strong wind blowing from a given direction in each locality, as a strong southeast wind in Kaʻū and Puna, Hawaiʻi, and at Kāne-ʻohe, Oʻahu. Also ʻAoʻaoa. Lit., blowing hard.
Flock of birds.
Same as ulupō 2. (Kam. 64:91.)
Fleet, collection of ships.

1. Pillow, cushion, formerly made of pandanus; to use as a pillow (Kin. 28.18). See ex., welehu 2. Also ununa.

2. Upper part of the arm.

3. Center part of a net, as of a large ʻupena iheihe, (net used for iheihe fish). Cf. ulu 7.
Wilderness, place of wild growth.
Coconut grove.
Upright, erect. Rare.
Var. of Ulu-koa. (See  for alternation of glottal stop and k.)
To break to pieces, burst forth, dash to pieces (Hal. 2.9), raze to the ground, destroy, beat; to rage, as a storm; to slam shut, hurl down.
Cooked but unpounded breadfruit.
Talus slope, transitional slope between cliffs and base.
To gather together; to go everywhere. See ex., holokahiki.
Same as pulu pē; intoxicated.
To shiver, shake, tremble, as with cold or fright.
Rotten breadfruit, a term of abuse for kauā (outcasts) at Puna, Hawaiʻi, since they were said to live in caves and hollows, as breadfruit fallen on the ground to rot.

1. Dark or dense as growth.

2. Sudden sickness or stroke, the sign of which is a cock crowing at untimely hours; such crowing was also believed to indicate the arrival of visitors or a ship. (Kam. 64:91.)

3. A fish said to resemble the pāpiopio. Also lūpō.
Bruised breadfruit; fig., bruised, buffeted.
To grow well; progressive, thriving, successful, Rare.
Same as olopua, a tree.
Flower garden, growth of flowers.
A variety of breadfruit with oval, rather than round fruit.
Overcome by emotion, hysteria, passion, or an occult influence.

1. Redup. of ulu 1; growing things.

2. Redup. of ulu 2.

3. Tangled, snarled, snagged, mussed, ruffled, frayed; angry, violent, agitated. See ex., kūʻulukū.

4. Same as unuunu 1, to singe.

5. Diving or scoop net, its mouth being held open with two sticks. (Malo 213.)

6. Sea cavern. Rare.

7. To munch. (AP)
See uluulu
Collection, gathering, assembly.
Leis offered to the gods.
Fleet of canoes. See ex., honu peʻekue.
To grow easily or without care; spontaneous. See ulu 1, 2.
Lush and beautiful verdure; a place where beautiful plants thrive; festively adorned. Lit., decorative growth. Cf. uluwehiwehi.
Redup. of uluwehi.
Same as kauluwela.

1. Hand wrestling: each tries to force his opponentʻs hand to the mat; to push, press, grip; to pry, as a lever.

2. Stern of a canoe. Rare.

3. Curve. Rare. Cf. pā uma.
Same as māmaka 1, carrying pole. Rare.
Same as mala, aching.

1. Apoplexy, stroke. Rare.

2. Same as umaumalei, a fish.
Brow of a hill or cliff; shade under cliff or hill; to frown, cast shade.
Chest, breast. Fig., heart, character.

A fish similar to but darker than the palani or pualu. It has bright orange-red spots around the gills and side fins and at the base of the caudal fin where the spike is set. Lit., lei [for the] chest.
Same as kala, a fish.

1. To draw, pull, attract, entice; attractive, alluring; attraction. (Mele 1.4.) ʻUme i ka ihu, to pull on the nose, as with a handkerchief or with the fingers, causing the nose to discharge, said of one who weeps in sorrow.

2. A sexual game for commoners, the counterpart of kilu, the chiefs' game. (Malo chapter 41.) It was called ʻume, to draw, because players of opposite sex were drawn to one another. To pair off in the game.

3. Fermata in music, hold, pause; to lengthen, as a sound.

4. An overlaid or braided thatching used on corners and ridges of a house. (AP)
Bur grass (Cenchrus echinatus), a weedy grass bearing round burs, which stick to passersby. (Neal 76–7;.) Also mauʻu kukū.
Gravity. Lit., weight attraction.
Bowl, calabash, circular vessel, as of wood or gourd.
Poi bowl. Fig., source of food, of the uplands.
Bowl, as for serving meat or salty meat.
Bowl with horizontal flat panels. Lit., wedged bowl.
Wooden bowl.
Very small bowl, as formerly used for poi by favorite children. Lit., poi mouth-fed bowl.
Bowl with vertical panels with vertical edges between them. See ʻōpaka 1.
Thick-bottomed wooden calabash. Lit., firm-dabbed bowl, perhaps so called because dabs of poi are held firm in this type of calabash that does not upset.
A decorated gourd bowl, as made on Niʻihau.
Gourd calabash.
The attraction that draws two solids and makes them one.
The attraction that draws liquids up through narrow tubes, capillary action; siphon. Lit., hair attraction.
Somewhat decomposed, as fish. Cf. melu.
The attraction or pull of a magnet.
An attraction, pulling. See ʻume 1.
Same as ʻūpepe.
Redup. of ʻume 1–3. (PCP kumekume, to pull.)

1. To strangle, choke, suffocate, stifle, throttle, smother, suppress; to repress, as desire.

2. num. Ten, tenth (num. from 11 to 19 are listed below).
Pas/imp. of ʻumi 1.
Offering of pig between two armies before starting battle. (Malo 197.)
Clamp, clip, clasp, staple, clutch, buckle, vise, trap; to pinch, clip, clasp, clamp, squeeze; sharp body pain, pang, or cramp, as in the side. Also ʻumiki.
Rattrap, mousetrap.
Introduced sugar-cane leafhopper (Perkinsiella saccharicida).
Belt buckle.
Nutcracker.
Hair clasp.
Paper clip, clamp, staple.
Same as ʻumi keiki.
Infanticide; to strangle infants; foeticide.
Same as ʻūmiʻi. Cf. ʻUluʻoa.
Redup. of ʻumiki; to crumble.
An element compounded with numbers from one to nine to indicate 11 to 19. See . Cf. ʻumi kumamā.
num. Fourteen.
num. Seventeen.
num. Nineteen.
num. Eleven.
num. Thirteen.
num. Fifteen.
num. Twelve.
Same as ʻumi kūmā-. Numbers one to nine are suffixed to this also.
num. Sixteen.
num. Eighteen.
Strangling, choking, etc. See ʻumi 1. (PNP kominga.)

1. Whiskers, beard, goatee, mustache; tendril; barbel or feelers on lower jaw of a fish; suckers that fasten bivalves such as the nahawele to rocks; rope used for hauling unfinished canoe hull from the forest to the shore.

2. Redup. of ʻumi 1. (Possibly PNP kumikumi, PCP kumikumi.)
Same as hinahina 2, Florida moss. Lit., Dole's whiskers.
Sideburns.
To flush, of a toilet.
To moo, bellow; to bark, of seals; mooing.

1. Cork, stopper, plug, bung; to cork, stop up; wad of a gun; partitions in bamboo water containers; to shoot an arrow so that it hits a mark squarely. See wili wehe ʻumoki.

2. To plant taro shoots in small holes made by a stick. (Kep. 153.)
Redup. of ʻumoki 1, 2; to puff at a pipe or cigar, so called because of the movement of the cheeks.
Oven, furnace (Ezek. 22.20); a heap of rocks placed in the sea for small fish such as the manini to hide in: this was surrounded by a net and the fish were caught. More commonly called imu.
Fire pit.
Same as waiakua, aloof.
Earth oven.
Same as imu loa.
Var. of ʻōmuʻo, to nip.
Same as imu pao.

1. Shell of turtle or tortoise, carapace.

2. Same as haha kā ʻupena (net gauge or spacer) so called because some were made of turtle shell.

3. Var. of une.

4. Dice.
See "hoʻouna":  To send, transmit, send on an errand, command, put to work; to mail; to send spirits on an errand, especially of destruction. See hoa una. Hoʻouna na ka mokulele, to send by air mail.
Fatigued, weary (Lunk. 4.21). Cf. nā 1.

1. The lumpy sea cucumber (Stichopus chloronotes).

2. Worn thin and lumpy, as a mattress, or formerly, the dried leaves under the sleeping mat.

1. Same as nahe; light breeze.

2. A foliose lichen (Parmelia perlata).
Same as nahenahe, soft.
vt. Scales of a fish; scaly; to scale. (PNP ʻunafi.)
Rough scales, especially from midbody to tail of certain fishes; scute.
Redup. of unahi; many scales.
Cracked and peeling, of the soles or heels of the feet.
Young pipi shellfish.
Lichen growths on stones. Lit., stone scales.
A variety of sweet potato.
Var. of ulana 1–3.

1. Var. of unala, to plait.

2. Wee, tiny. Rare.

3. A bird (no data). (KL. line 321.)

4. A plain. Rare.
Same as kaunaʻoa, a mollusk.
Plural of naue. See ex., polikua.
Hermit crabs in general. Also pāpaʻi iwi pūpū.
See "hoʻounauna":  Redup. of hoʻouna; sorcery. (PNP ungaunga.)
Redup. of unā.
To scale, of fish.

Lever; lever on a sewing machine that raises or 
lowers the presser foot; to pry. Fig., to urge, disturb, harass.
Nausea, exhaustion (Nak. 103).
Redup. of unea.
Shift lever for bobbin winder of a sewing machine.
Honk of a goose; to honk.
Same as nenelu, marsh.
Redup. of une.
Same as uneanea, nausea.
A kind of sitting wrestling with thighs of contestants shoved back and forth. Lit., prying thigh.
Adult ʻūhini, locust; cricket.
Same as uwinihapa.
Var. of ʻūhini 1, 2.

1. Spirit of a dead person, sometimes believed present in bones or hair of the deceased and kept lovingly.

2. Same as ʻuhinipili 2.
Unitarian. Eng.
See unikalio
Graduation exercises, as for hula, lua fighting, and other ancient arts (probably related to niki, to tie, as the knowledge was bound to the student).
Var. of ʻūlina.
Redup. of ʻūnina.
Union, labor union. Eng.
Same as manu 3, canoe projections.
Var. of unoʻo.
Plural of noho 2, 3.
Same as kōʻeleʻele, seaweeds.
Plural and frequentative of noho 2, 3.
Redup. of noke.
Scorched, partly consumed by fire, inflamed. (Probably PPN ʻunoko.)
Same as unoʻo.

1. Small stone, pebble, stone chip; wedge, prop. Cf. unu pehi ʻiole.

2. Altar, heiau, especially a crude one for fishermen or for the god Lono.

3. Rare var. of inu, to drink (PNP unu; cf. Nukuoro.)

4. Rare var. of ulu 1, 2.

5. Name given for a section of canoe endpiece. (For. 5:612–3.) Cf. ulu 7.
To shorten, hoist, jerk upwards; to pull or draw together, as the hair.
Pas/imp. of ʻunu.
Same as uluhe, ferns.
To take out, withdraw, as money from a bank, or a drawer from a desk; to unsheath, extract; to take off, as a ring; to translate, interpret.
Pas/imp. of unuhi.
Literal translation; to make such.
Free translation; to make such.
Translation.
To translate or interpret; translator, interpreter.
Close, literal translation; to make such.

1. A wind famous in song noted on Kauaʻi, West Maui, and Niʻihau; according to Emerson, the trade wind. See ex., puka, puʻupā, wiliʻōkaʻi 2.

2. Name of a star.

1. See "Kauaʻi":  name for nāpili, a fish.

2. A wind, Puna, Hawaiʻi.
Var. of uluna 1–3.
Var. spelling of unuunu.
Rat-pelting pebble, insulting epithet for a person of no consequence.

1. To singe, as the feathers of a chicken before dressing it, or the hairs of a pig or dog by rolling it over hot oven stones; to pluck, as feathers from a fowl. Also uluulu. (PCP (u)ngu(u)nu.)

2. Var. of uluulu 3, tangled.

3. Stick erected as a taboo sign. (AP)

4. Young ʻōhiʻa timber, as used in making images. (AP)
Redup. of ʻunu.
Agricultural heiau.

1. A group of feathers tied together in a small bunch, to be made into a feather lei or cloak; to tie thus; to tie into a lei; to string on a needle; to splice, interweave, as strands of a rope; seizing turns in lashing.

2. Same as ʻuoʻuo 1.
See ʻuo
To bellow, roar, shout loudly, howl. See kūō, leo uō.
See uō

1. Same as uouoa, a fish.

2. Name given for an unknown disease, characterized by aching shoulders.
To move along, of many; to slouch along together.
Idiom used only in commands. Stop it! Quit! Don't touch! Be careful (see ex., hāmama)!
See uoki
To call out; a loud calling.
Tough.
Redup. of uō.
See uōuō

1. Adhesive, sticky, but without lumps, as good poi; tough, strong.

2. To string, as leis.

A fish (Neomyxus chaptalii), known as the false mullet or false ʻamaʻama, distinguishable from the true mullet by its narrower and tapered mouth and creamy rather than silvery pectoral fins. The head, when eaten, was supposed to cause sleeplessness and nightmares.
Shadows and gloom of a forest; weird, ghostly, fearsome. (AP)

Any instrument that opens and shuts, as shears, scissors, tongs, bellows, carpenter's compass; to beat, as the heart; to open and shut, as the mouth champing food; to slam, bang, as a door. Fig., a furious attack, onslaught.
Tongs for picking up hot coals.
To play together.
Tall, thin. (And.)
To flap, as wings, clothes in the wind; to bend in the wind, as a branch; to walk with a flapping movement.
Redup. of ʻupaʻi; to hover.
Candle snuffers. Lit., scissors cutting off candlenut.

1. Gentle, mild, soft-spoken, soft, tender, fragile, languid.

2. A soft-bodied 
 holothurian (Opheodesoma spectabilis), sea cucumber.

3. A bird (no data).

1. Redup. of ʻūpalu 1.

2. According to Malo, a type of fishing; translated by Emerson as “ordinary angling.” (Malo 210, 213.)
Bellows.
Grass shears.
Fingernail or manicure scissors.
Shears.
Pinking shears. Lit., shears for cutting points.

1. Same as ʻūpalupalu 1.

2. The larger cardinal fishes, Apogon spp., Apogonichthys perdix, Foa brachygramma. A var. name is ʻupāpalu maka nui.
Nippers.
Pliers.
Redup. of ʻūpā; to rub clothes up and down a washboard.
Crushed, flattened; humble, bashful; dry and juiceless, as sugar cane. Cf. .

1. Same as io, a rib on a paddle.

2. Spear point.
Mucus. Fig., tears, grief. Also hūpē.
Swollen, bloated; inflammation. Cf. pehu 1.
Fishing net, net, web. Fig., trap.
Same as ʻupena uluulu.
Dip net. Cf. lā 5.
Net held open by supporting stick. Cf. kuku, puhi.
Name given for a net spread over a patient by a medical kahuna in order to catch evil spirits.
Gill net.
Tapa-beater design.
Tapa-beater design, with stripes and shark-teeth motifs.
A type of net or snare (no data).
Throwing net.
Gill net stretched at high tide across fish runs in shallow water. Lit., suspended net.
Set net.
Net made of fibers of hau and ʻahu-ʻawa. Lit., scoop net.
Net for ʻiao, bait fish.
Net similar to the pākuʻikuʻi. Lit., flow net.
Scoop or hand net. See kāheʻe.
A type of net or seine (no data).
See kākā 4.
Net about forty fathoms long used in deep-sea fishing with canoes.
Throwing net.
Throwing net.
Seine. Also hukilau. Lit., rope-pulling net.
Immense bag net said to be from sixteen to twenty-four fathoms deep. Lit., towing net.
Gill net, set net.
Hair net.
Small net, baited, weighted down, and set on the sea floor; fishermen dived (luʻuluʻu) to bring it up.
Net made of hau fiber. Lit., jagged net.
A net used for destruction, as by robbers to snare victims.
A large net used in deep water with the melomelo lure. Lit., far net.
Net that is baited and left in the sea, as for pāpaʻi, crabs.
Spider web.
Net used for young palemo, a fish. Also nae.
Same as ʻupena ʻākiʻikiʻi.

Bag net, said to be a combination of three nets, with the puhi nui at the opening (meshes two or more fingers in width), then the puhi iki (meshes half as large), and at the end the pūpū, which was also called the mole. Lit., stratum net.
Net for catching pāpāʻi, crabs. Also ʻupena mōkū.
Two nets attached to either side of the opening of the pākuʻikuʻi. Lit., joining net.
Bag net. Lit., head net.
Same as ʻupena nananana.
A tapa-beater design with net meshes enhanced with small circles.
A scoop net with two parallel sticks for a frame. Probably lit., frayed net.
Redup. of ūpē.
Flat-nosed. Also ʻūmene, kūmene.
Same as ʻūpehupehu.

Sponge; syringe, enema; to squirt, squeeze, spray through an orifice; to squish-squash, as the noise made by walking with shoes full of water; to extract by pressing and wringing; to express; to give an enema.
Plural of piʻi, to go up.

1. Trap, snare, clamp; treachery; to snap or clamp together, as a trap, the jaws, or a bivalve; to shut or close, as a flower; to pinch, as with pressure of thumb and fingers. Same as ʻōpiki. See ex., pahele.

2. A tapa stamp.
Rattrap, mousetrap.
Handcuff.
Redup. of ʻūpiki 1.
Testicle squeezing, said of male homosexuality.
Cramped, crowded, packed tight. Cf. ʻōpili.
Redup. of ʻūpī; to soften an octopus, as by holding the head and working the tentacles up and down in a container with salt.

1. Same as poho; the sound produced by clapping the body with cupped hands. Cf. kai ʻūpoho.

2. Bagpipe.
Same as poʻi 1–5; to move, as a bird its wings. (Isa. 10.14.)
Eyelid.
Same as poʻipoʻi.
Moist.
Recurring thought, desire, attachment, hope, expectation; to desire, long for, covet, keep thinking of with anticipation. Cf. hāʻupuʻupu, nahele.
Rare var. of ʻīpuka.
Sandpiper; lapwing (KJV), hoopoe (RSV) (Oihk. 11.19).
Redup. of ʻupu.

To strip, as leaves or maile bark; to draw in, as a line on a ship; to draw out, unsheath, as a sword; to draw back, as the fist preparing to strike, or as the foot about to kick; to hoist, as a sail; to practice masturbation; to answer back sharply or rudely; to pour suddenly, as rain.

1. Redup. of ʻū 1; to stutter, stammer.

2. Redup. of ʻū 2; impregnated partially, as fish with salt. (Ho-ʻomaʻū is used today for soaking.)

3. All soldier-fishes of the genus Myripristis; some were considered ʻaumākua.

4. Star name (no data).
Slippery, slimy.

Redup. of ʻuʻina 1.
Tiny, small; few. See ʻuku.
Lumpy, bumpy, coarse, said of some skin diseases. Cf. ʻuluhaku.
Bloated, swollen, dropsical.
Redup. of ʻumi 1, to strangle. See ex., auka. (PNP kokomi, PCP kukumi.)
Short, deficient, defective. (AP)
Redup. of ʻunu.
To sway, teeter, as the mast of a ship at sea.
Redup. of ʻuʻu.
Same as ʻūʻū 1.
Var. spelling of ʻūʻua.
To shout, cry out, yell, sound loud, shout, racket. See wā, noise.
To dig or dredge a trench or furrow. Cf. waʻa, trench.
Var. spelling of uahi.
Var. spelling of uai.
Water-soaked, soggy.
Var. spelling of uaki.
Var. spelling of ʻuala.
Same as wali, soft, smooth. Cf. uwaʻuwali.
To call out, as for help; to resound; a call. Cf. walo.
See uwalo
Same as walu, to claw.
Var. spelling of uāniʻi.
Var. spelling of ʻuao.
Var. spelling of uapo.
Same as waʻu, to grate.
See uwaʻu
Var. spelling of ʻuaʻu, petrel.
Redup. of ʻuwā.
Var. spelling of uauai. See uai.
Soft, limp, weak.
Var. spelling of ue.
Var. spelling of uē.

1. To open, uncover, reveal, untie; to pry open, as a bivalve; to remove evil influence, as by prayer. Cf. wehe.

2. Hula step: one foot is lifted with weight shifting to opposite hip as the foot is lowered; both knees are then pushed forward by the quick raising of the heels, with continued swaying of the hips from side to side (a difficult step); to do this step.
See ʻuwehe
Same as ehehene.
Dirty, bleary, as the eyes. Cf. weka.
See uweka
Same as ʻuwehe 1, 2.
Bad-smelling, musty. Also weko.
See uweko
Redup. of uweko.
See uwekoweko
Var. spelling of uene.
Unclean in habits. (AP)
Var. spelling of uepa 1–3.
Var. spelling of uē.
Redup. of uweko.

Var. spelling of ʻueʻuele.

1. To squeak, squeal; to gnash, as teeth; such sounds. Cf. wī.

2. To twist, squeeze, wring, grind; to express, as juice from fruit; to milk, as a cow.
See ʻuwī

1. Pas/imp. of ʻuwī 1, 2.

2. A split in a tree.
Var. spelling of ʻuiki 1–4.
Var. spelling of uila.
Var. spelling of winihapa.

1. Redup. of ʻuwī 1, 2.

2. A variety of triggerfish (family Balistidae), so called because it is said to make a squeaky sound. Also humuhumu.

3. A ceremony to insure sharp teeth for infants: after an infant's tooth is pulled, it is passed under the knee of the child while chanting: ʻUwīʻuwī ka niho o ke kanaka no ka ʻiole, ka niho o ka ʻiole no ke kanaka, e ʻoi ka niho o [name of the child], grind the tooth of the person for the rat, the tooth of the rat for the person, so the tooth of [name] will be sharp. The tooth is thrown away so that a rat will find it and grant the sharpness of its own teeth to the new tooth that will grow in the child's mouth. To perform this ceremony.

4. Fermented liquor, swipes.

5. Same as ilioha, horseweeds; to use as a switch; to beat.
See ʻuwīʻuwī
Same as ʻuwīʻuwī 4.
Var. spelling of ʻuiʻuiki.
A variety of ʻuwīʻuwī, triggerfish.
To milk, as a cow.
Var. spelling of uō.
Var. spelling of ʻuo 1, 2.
Var. spelling of uoki.
Var. spelling of uōuō.
Var. spelling of ʻuoʻuo.

1. Period of time, epoch, era, time, occasion, season, age.

2. Tense, in grammar. Cf. wā ʻānō.

3. To make a noise, roar, din; noisy, loud; to talk much, as of gossip: to talk loudly back and forth; to reason. Cf. wawā.

4. Space, interval, as between objects or time; in music, one of the four spaces of the staff; channel. Cf. kōwā.

5. Fret of an ukulele, guitar, or similar instrument.
To retch. See ex., haʻanou.

1. Canoe, rough-hewn canoe, canoemen, paddlers; a chant in praise of a chief's canoe.

2. Trench, furrow, receptacle. Fig., a woman. (PCP waka-.)

3. Moving masses of liquid lava, so called because of similarity to a moving canoe. Rare.

4. Same as more common waʻawaʻa 3, stupid.
Starboard hull of a double canoe.
See waʻa ʻākea
Tribute canoe; a basket filled with food and set adrift during the makahiki ceremonies, said to represent the canoe in which Lono returned to Tahiti (Malo 151).
Same as lāʻaeʻoia.
A rain in Nuʻu-anu and Mānoa Valleys and the name of a ridge separating Mānoa and Pālolo Valleys. See saying, puʻipuʻi.
Sleigh. Lit., canoe running on snow.
A wide canoe.
A canoe with little sheer. Lit., equal-sea canoe.
Head fisherman's canoe.
War canoe; an army formation (Malo 197).
Canoe for fishing aku.
Single canoe, as contrasted with the kaulua. Lit., single-placed canoe.
Double canoe. Lit., double-placed canoe.

1. Unpainted canoe set to sea after the taboos were lifted during the makahiki harvest festivals. (Malo 151). Lit., white canoe.

2. Same as waʻa ʻākea.
Vessel of papyrus (RSV), bullrush (KJV).
A long, thin canoe. Rare.
Toy canoe made of ti leaves.
Pas/imp. of hoʻowaʻa, to dig a trench.
Toy canoe made of coconut sheath.
Present tense.
Skiff, rowboat; ferryboat (2 Sam. 19.18). Lit., board canoe.
Same as waʻa kūpāhoa. Rare.
Said to be a large or double canoe with three ʻiako.
A small, slim canoe used for surfing. Rare.
A chief's canoe with red sails.

1. Redup. of waʻa 2; full of gulches, gullies, grooves; gullied, furrowed, grooved. (PCP wakawaka.)

2. Muscular, one whose back bulges with muscles.

3. Stupid, ignorant; ignoramus, simpleton, fool. Cf. hāwāwā.

4. Upper end of a lobster's leg.

5. Hollow at meeting of bones below the Adam's apple.

6. Desolate, uninhabited.
Pas/imp. of waʻawaʻa 1.
Same as waʻawaʻa 3.
Same as waʻalia.

1. To choose, select, pick out, sort, discriminate, separated, cull, nominate; to draft, as soldiers; to preen, as of a chicken; finicky, fussy; to reflect, meditate; appointment.

2. U-shaped canoe spreader. See ex., pūkōkeʻe.

3. Leg. Rare. See wāwae.

4. Rib of a ship.
See māwae, ʻōwae.
Same as ʻaʻae, third generation taro.
Selection, choice.
Future tense or time.
To weed, clear, remove grass or weeds.

1. Middle, between, center, central, intermediate, medial (often preceded by i, ma-, mai); mean, average. Cf. leo waena, paʻapū. (PEP waenga.)

2. Cultivated field, garden, vegetable plot.
Center, middle, midway.
Amidships.
Same as wae 2.
Redup. of wae 1; selective. See kūlana waewae.

1. Cloven hoof, as of cattle, goats, and deer.

2. Head fisherman in charge of kuʻula, stone gods.

1. Mouth, opening, inner surface of a bowl, open top of a canoe, muzzle of a gun, oral, one who talks too much (see ex., hewa 4). See kakaʻo, waha wale, wahāwahā.

2. Neck of a dress.

3. To carry on the back, as a child; a load so carried.

4. Square notch cut in the upper part of house posts, in which the wall plates (lohelau) were placed; tenon (For. 5:651).
Sharp-tongued, rude; to speak heatedly and rudely. Lit., burning mouth.

A bitter (ʻawa) and sadistic person who makes impulsive vindicative statements about the one he hates, attempting to strike at his weaknesses or guilts, and usually predicting misfortune that often comes true. (Na_na_ 197–200.)
Smeared mouth; smutty-mouthed, evil-tongued.
To lie; lying, deceitful, false; a lie, liar. Lit., slippery mouth. See ex., keu.
To drool at the mouth, talk excessively, gush; one who does so.
Garrulous, noisy, boisterous and obstreperous in speech; such a person; to rant.
Garrulous, clucking mouth; to gabble.
Past tense.
To scold, utter scathing remarks; one who does so. Lit., blazing mouth.
Wide open, as a door; too large, as the neck of a dress. Fig., to exaggerate. Lit., wide mouth. Also uhalehe.
Finicky, of eating. Lit., tight-mouthed; such a person.
Screen, shutter. Rare.

1. Voice of authority, person in authority. Lit., powerful mouth.

2. One who digresses from subject to subject; to digress. Lit., branching mouth.
Same as hāwane, seed of the loulu.
A big mouth; to talk too much, tattle; tattler.
To talk in a foolish, silly, senseless manner; such talk; such a talker.
See Ka-waha-o-ka-manō.
To slander one's own blood. Lit., mouth that pierces blood.
Spokesman, mouthpiece, herald; speaking mouth.
To goad, tease, banter; argumentative. Lit., hard mouth.
A coated mouth, said in derision of an ignoramus, especially one who does not know the chants honoring his chief.
Halitosis; foul mouth.
To be unable to speak; not to dare to speak, speechless. Lit., imprisoned mouth.
Protruding lips; unintelligible speech, as of one who has had a stroke. Lit., lumpy mouth.
To nibble and pick at food without appetite. Lit., red [sore] mouth.
To treat with contempt, scorn, despise, abhor, ridicule; be disgusted, defy.
To talk glibly, brag. Lit., watery mouth.
Deceitful, lying. Lit., slimy mouth.
Glib-tongued.
Time when heʻe (octopus) abound.
Time of beardless youth, preadolescence. Lit., time without whiskers.

1. Place, location, position, site, setting. (Ka wahi contracts to common kahi).

2. Paucal article. Some, a little, a bit of.

3. To say, according to (usually followed by the possessive a or by a zero-class possessive and not preceded by either verb or noun particles).
Wrapper, envelope, case, covering, sheath; a ti-leaf bundle; to wrap, cover, bundle up, fold up, roll up, swathe; to dress, as a wound. Cf. ʻili wahī, kīpē.
To cleave, split, burst through, break through; to change, as money; to have sex relations with a virgin, deflower. Cf. wāwahi.
Pas/imp. of wāhi.
Time to sleep, bedtime.

1. Fuel, firewood; to serve as firewood.

2. Stroke in spear or club fighting.
Upper stroke in club fighting. (RC 59.)
Bandage.

Lignum vitae (Guaiacum officinale), a small tree from tropical America, with heavy, hard wood, useful for many purposes. The resin yields medicine and stain. The tree is also ornamental, each leaf with two or three pairs of rounded leaflets, the flowers blue and clustered, the fruits yellow and heart-shaped. (Neal 476.)
Workshop, place to work.
Cattle ranch.
See wahi hānai holoholona
Private parts.
Dump, garbage pile.
Shelter.
Toilet, rest room.
Vacant place, vacancy.
Lookout.
Anchorage.
Brief case.
Envelope.
Shelter.
Glasses case.
Dairy.
Bed (Hal. 132.3), place to sleep.
Lookout.

1. Woman, lady, wife; sister-in-law, female cousin-in-law of a man; queen in a deck of cards; womanliness, female, femininity; feminine; Mrs.; to have or obtain a wahine; to become a woman, as an adolescent. In some chants, as those about Pele, the word wahine has a connotation of goddess (see ex., ʻolokaʻa). Cf. wāhine.

2. Plant names. See below.
Plural of wahine.
Female servant.
Mermaid. Lit., fish-tail woman.
Platonic wife, an old Hawaiian relationship. Cf. kāne hoʻokāne. Lit., pretended wife.
Widow. Lit., woman with dead husband.
Spinster, woman without a husband, single woman.
Taboo woman, goddess (specifically Pele—not a woman who might not have sex relations, as some believe, Nānā 200–3).
Untidy woman, slattern.
Fighting woman, woman in the armed services, Amazon.
A gray lichen.
Older woman; older sister-in-law or female cousin-in-law of a man.
Wardrobe mistress.
Married woman, bride, wife.
See manuahi.
An endemic shrub (Isodendrion hawaiiense) in the violet family, having the petals equal and without spurs. Lit., woman dwelling [on the] plains. Cf. aupaka.
An endemic fern (Adenophorus tamariscinus), with finely subdivided narrow-elliptical fronds 10 to 40 cm long, growing on trees and on the ground. Lit., mountain-dwelling woman.
Wife of the night. Similar to kāne o ka pō but less common.
Without a wife or sweetheart; bachelor.
Same as mohihihi, a vine.
Young woman; younger sister-in-law or female cousin-in-law of a man.
Dwelling place, address.
Legendary place.
Crematory, incinerator.
Clothes hamper.
Outside, beyond, out, outer, outward, exterior (frequently preceded by particles ʻo, ma-, mai). See ex., make 1.
To take without consent, as food at a feast; to ensnare, trap. (AP)
Same as ahulu, ovrcooked.
To interlock arms, as while walking. (AP)

1. Water, liquid or liquor of any kind other than sea water (see ex., koni), juice, sap, honey; liquids discharged from the body, as blood, semen; color, dye, pattern; to flow, like water, fluid.

2. Place names beginning with Wai-, river, stream.

3. Grain in stone.

4. To retain, place, leave, remain, earn, deposit (see more common waiho, waihona, waiwai, and less common wailana; waina 2, wai ʻūlili).

5. (Also spelled ai.) interr. pronoun; Who, whom, whose, what (animate antecedents).(.) ʻO wai! Who? ʻO wai kou inoa? What is your name? ʻO wai ia? Who is he? (angrily) Who does he think he is? Kō wai, kā wai? Whose? No wai? For or in honor of whom? Na wai? By whom? Kō wai kaʻa k_elā? Whose car is that? Iā wai ʻoe i kamaʻilio ai? To whom did you speak? Na wai nō i ʻōlelo iāʻoe e hele malaila? Who told you to go there?

6. Type of house with thatch purlins separated by a width of two fingers. (For. 5:645.)
Same as wāhi, to break, end.

1. Disgraced; shame, dishonor.

2. Name of a star.
Season in which fish are numerous.
Same as wai ʻaʻapu.
Rare var. of wai ʻapo.
Same as waiehu.
Pool of water.
Water showing a reflection; name of a Nuʻuanu pool.
Same as lehua keʻokeʻo, a taro.
Acid.
Distant, aloof, unsociable, exclusive, as of a chief too high to mingle with others. Lit., godly blood.
Perfume, cologne, toilet water. Lit., fragrant liquid.
Name of the highest mountain on Kauaʻi.
Rippling water, artesian water.
Chiefly water; royal liquor, gin (in Kalākaua's song, Koni au).
A variety of Molokaʻi sweet potato.
Crystal-clear water, artesian water.
Same as anuhea. See pī waianuhea.
Tepid water, neither hot nor cold.
Name of a soft porous stone, as used in medicine or for octopus sinkers. (Malo 19.) Rare.
Water caught in a taro leaf, often used in ceremonies as it was regarded as pure in not having touched the ground. Fig., a beloved mate, spouse. Lit., caught water.
Swirling water of a current.

Bath water; bathing place or pool. A figurative use follows: he wai ʻauʻau ia nona, it 
was like bath water for him [of heroes dodging spears or engaged in fights; the hail of spears is as pleasant as splashing water].
Poisoned or bitter water; bitter. Fig., same as poli ʻawa.
Redup. of wai ʻawa.
The yellow strawberry guava (Psidium cattleianum f.

The purple strawberry guava (Psidium cattleianum), a small tree from Brazil, with smooth bark, smooth, shiny, obovate leaves about 5 cm long. The purplish-red fruit is round, about 2.5 cm in diameter, and has white pulp, good to eat raw or made into jam or jelly, tasting like strawberries. (Neal 633–4.)

1. Aerated water.

2. Small house at the entrance of a heiau temple, where the ceremonial ʻaha (cord) was stretched. (Malo 162.)

3. Sea water used for purification. Lit., water of life.
A file; formerly a rough stone used to grind and polish.
Spraying water.

1. Black tapa dye; tapa so dyed.

2. To drug fish with ʻauhuhu.

1. Black dye.

2. Ink.

3. A dark-skinned person.
Well water, well. Lit., dug water.
Water upon which the breath (hā) of the priest has been expelled in order to impart mana; to give mana by breathing upon an image or person; to request earnestly in prayer. See ex., waipā.
Agricultural land term commonly used in the 1840s, especially on Maui; meaning unknown.
Small well from which brackish water was taken and poured into shallow pools called wai kū; this water later was placed into shallower pools and allowed to evaporate, leaving the salt.

1. A heiau where hogs, bananas, and coconuts were sacrificed, but not human beings; a heiau for moʻo spirits.

2. A small, tight bundle; to do up in such a bundle. Rare.
Ice water.
Water oozing as from a precipice or trickling down. Lit., purging water.
Short for wai ʻihi.
Water obtained by shaking the dew or rain drops from the leaves of plants or trees, as was said to have been done in dry areas. Lit., hit water.

To leave, lay or put down, place before, present, refer, submit, place in nomination, file, deposit, set aside, exclude, evacuate, abdicate, desist, cease, stop, omit, quit, resign, abandon, remain; to table, as a motion; a leaving, depository, etc. (Coalescence of wai 4 and the directional iho.) Cf. palapala waiho ʻoihana, waihona, waiho wale and .
Pas/imp. of waiho.
Toilet water, liquid spice, scented extract. Lit., liquid that perfumes.
To lie or place in full view; easily seen, obvious.
See waiho akaaka
Holy water.
To lie widespread before one.
To abandon completely, give up.
Flood.
To lie fallow.
To lie sick, remain sick.

Depository, closet, cabinet, vault, file, receptacle, savings, place for laying up things in safe-keeping; internal organs of the body, funds, treasury; fiscal. (Wai 4 + iho, directional, + -na, nominalizer.) Numerous types of waihona are listed below.
Position of the land, lay of the land, position of the earth, landscape, panorama, scenery, topography.
Memory.
Playroom, parlor; private rooms of the captain of a ship.
Intelligence.
Cupboard, place to keep food containers; bases supporting bath basins in Solomon's temple (1 Nal. 7.35).
Treasury, money depository, fund; fiscal. Lit., dollar depository. See ex., kūpilikiʻi.
Womb.
Candlestick, lamp stand.
Burial vault.
Arsenal, arms depository. Lit., war goods depository.
Coalbin.
Place for sacred objects; treasure (Neh. 7.70).
Honeycomb. (1 Sam. 14.27.)
Place for keeping money, treasury. Rare.
Mind, mentality.
Dump, garbage container.
Cupboard.
Archives. Lit., depository of ancient documents.
Bank account, depository.
Library.
Treasury, depository for goods, property; treasurer. (2 Oihn. 5.1.)
Digestive juice.
Water color.
To spare the life, to remain living.
Color, dye, coloring liquid; to impart scent.
Disinfectant; any kind of cleaning liquid, cleansing liquid, liquid soap.
To leave without reason; to leave about carelessly; to set aside as useless; to neglect, to expose to view.
Gushing spring, overflowing water.
Water-drop caught as in a taro leaf, much liked for purification and medicine, as it has not touched the earth. Also called wai ʻapo.
Water for purification.
Sacred blood, as of royalty. Fig., prominent, royal.
A kidney disease that impedes urination. Lit., little water.
Drinking water, potable water.
Stream (Hal. 124.4); to flow, overflow, as a stream. Lit., flowing water. See ex., mokuhia.
United, of one dye. See ex., kāoʻo.

1. A calliopsis (Coreopsis tinctoria), an annual ornamental herb, in the daisy family, from central United States, the ray flowers yellow with dark-red at the base. (Neal 842.) Lit., change [of] color.

2. See aloalo, hibiscus.

3. See melekule wai kāhuli.
Brackish or salty water.
Quicksilver, mercury; silver, silver-colored. Lit., silver liquid.
Having ways of ordinary folk. Rare. Lit., human pattern.

1. A war temple.

2. Same as waiwai kaua.
Juice of fresh kukui nuts, as mixed with fresh or brackish water and used as an enema. Lit., white liquid.
Same as wekekē, whiskey.
Leucorrhea. Lit., white liquid.

1. Gun. Rare. See pōhaku waikī.

2. Enema of a concoction consisting of the juice of the poisonous gourd, water, salt, and other matter, drastic and painful. Cf. the more mild waikea.

3. Gonorrhea, of males; painful urination, perhaps due to cystitis. Rare.

4. One whose father was a chief but whose mother was not, a term of contempt. Rare. Cf. ʻahunāliʻi.
Water in which tea has been brewed, tea.
Place name used as a direction marker in Honolulu. Lit., spouting water.

1. Water with a strong current.

2. Sugary water.
Buttermilk.
Waterspout. Cf. waipuʻilani.
Cold wind associated with Mt.
Tears that seem to cling to eyelashes. Lit., liquid supporting eyelashes. Poetic.
Same as nae waikū. (For. 6:451.)
See wai hānai.
Gold-colored.
An old name for syphilis.
Alcohol.
Dart, as for war. Rare.

1. Sap of plants.

2. Liquid medicine.

1. Calm, quiet, as the sea; still water.

2. Banished, as for unworthy conduct; exile. (Perhaps wai 4, to leave, + -lana, nominalizer; .)

3. A prayer uttered to free a taboo period.
Rain water, especially as used for medicine and purification. Cf. wai hua.

1. Large leaf bundles of food, as poi, for carrying.

2. An ancient variety of tapa. (For. 5:112.)
Place names on Hawaiʻi, Kauaʻi, and Molokaʻi.
Water carried in folded taro leaves.
Name of a morning star.
Waterfall, cataract, cascade. Lit., leaping water. (PCP wailele; cf. Marquesan vaiʻeʻe.)
Lemon juice, lemonade, limeade.
Bile. Lit., yellow water.
Coconut water. Lit., hanging water. See riddle, lewa 1.
A decorated tapa. Lit., small colors.
Same as wailiʻulā.

1. Mirage.

2. Of changing color, as taffeta or a stone; taffeta.
Name of a star near the Pleiades, said to be a member of the group called Kaulua. It is also said to be a name of an ancient chief. Lit., long stream.

1. Spirit, ghost; remains of the dead.

2. An ancient variety of sweet potato, presumably introduced from Wai-lua, Kauaʻi.
Perfume. Lit., Russian liquor, so-called because musk was obtained from Russians in early days, the wet product being perfume. Cf. hualūkini, For. 5:656.

1. Name reported for an ulua fishing line.

2. Same as haleloke, a chrysanthemum.
A West Maui city, site of a late eighteenth century battle. Lit., destructive water.
To strip the flesh from bones, as for burial.
Tears. Lit., eye water. See ex., pania. (PEP waimata.)
Name of a minor illness (no data).
Waterdrops from the ʻōhiʻa lehua tree; euphemism for menstruation. Also waimaka-o-lehua.

1. An endemic fern (Thelypteris keraudreniana), with large, broad, pale, subdivided fronds, the last divisions triangular or oblong, the spores arranged in small dots scattered on the frond back. Also alaʻalai.

2. A native fern (Pteris excelsa), with large, broad, bright-green, subdivided fronds, in general like waimakanui 1, but the last divisions longer and subfalcate, and the spores arranged in a line under the curled frond margin.
Pele's tears.
Services to get rain. (For. 6:153.)

1. Stone from which octopus sinkers were made. (Malo 19.)

2. Adobe. (AP)

1. See "Maui":  name for olomea, a shrub.

2. See "Kauaʻi":  name for a kind of māmaki, having leaves with red veins and stems resembling those of the olomea.
A place name. Lit., reddish water. See ex., pā ʻili.
Slop.
Honey. Lit., bee liquor.
Urine. (2 Nal. 18.27.)
Soda water, sweet water.
Same as kaupō, a native banana.

1. Place with water.

2. Depository. See wai 4.

3. Pyorrhea, bleeding gums.

4. Wine. Eng. See pā waina.

5. Isabella grape (Vitis xlabruscana), a strong-climbing vine, bearing blue, loose-skinned fruits. This is a hybrid that succeeds best of any grape introduced to Hawaiʻi; little interest has been shown in the past in the grape industry. (Neal 542–3.) See hua waina.
Star name, sometimes called the patron star of Hilo.
Raisins. Lit., dry grapes.
Coconut water or cream (the distinction was not clear; cf. kai niu, wailewa).

1. Probably similar to waipahē.

2. Safe, safety. (And.)
A large flow of water; excessive flow of saliva; to flow in great quantities, juicy.
Same as ohaoha, joy.
A variety of sugar cane.
Juice or cider of mountain apples; cider in general; tomato juice.

All kinds of cultivated dahlias (Dahlia spp.), named for a town on Hawaiʻi where the plant was first grown. (Neal 843–4.) Pika waiohinu, vase or pitcher of dahlias [name of an old quilt design showing a pitcher containing dahlias].
See pāpale waiokila.
Fragrant cultivated violets (as Viola odorata). (Neal 591.) Eng. See nani Wai-ʻaleʻale (native violets).
Violin. Eng. See ex., nē.
Cello.
Bass viol.
A Kauaʻi wind. (For. 5:97.)
Careful, cautious about what one says. Rare.
Cool, pleasant, attractive, soft, gentle, pleasing.
Intoxicating liquor or spirits.
Honey, sweet liquid.
Type of tapa.

1. A disease similar to pulmonary consumption.

2. Leucorrhea.
Name of a pleasant breeze at Wai-lua, Kauaʻi. (For. 5:97.) Lit., water of cloud banks.
Mirage. Lit., deceiving water.
Request, prayer, as to the gods.
Ice. (Ioba 6.16.) Lit., hard, solid water.
Salty water, brine.

Courteous, gentlemanly, polite, modest, gentle, good-natured, easygoing, agreeable, complacent, gracious. This word is usually used in a favorable sense, but occasionally pejoratively: he wahine waipahē wale ma nā mea ʻano ʻino, a woman complacent indeed in the ways of sin.
Gunpowder. Lit., explosive liquid.
Spouting water, geyser.
Mixed liquid, solution, or drink of any kind (lama paʻipaʻi is more common for alcoholic drinks).
Name recorded for a variety of sweet potato.
A kind of tapa. Lit., soft dye or pattern.
Cool breeze famous at Wai-mea, Kauaʻi. Lit., scooped water.
Var. of waipahē.
Rising water, overflow of water, flood (Ier. 46.7); to flow, overflow.
Redup. of wai piʻi; charged water, bubbling water.
See wai piʻipiʻi
Water from a faucet.
Gunpowder. Rare.
Honey from flowers.
Wind-blown water or spray, as of a waterfall; name of the “upside-down” waterfall in Nuʻu-anu Valley.
Waterspout (perhaps from wai puhi lani, heaven-blown water).
Spring water. Fig., a sweetheart.
Water in leaves, as of taro, that could be carried; coconut water. Lit., bundled water.

column2: wai pūʻolo i ka lau lāʻau
column3: wai pūʻolo i ka lau lāʻau
column4: An ancient name for ice. Lit., water in a package of tree leaves, so called because ice was said to be brought down from the mountains in leaves. (Malo 241–2.)
Milk; a wet nurse; breast. Lit., breast liquid.
Rain water.
A breast that sags, but not long or pendulous. Lit., broken breast.
Clabbered milk, cottage cheese. Lit., lumpy milk.
Caked breast.
Milk combined with other ingredients, as for a baby or person on a liquid diet; formula. Lit., mixed milk.
Flowing breast or milk.
Breast filled with milk.
Condensed milk. Lit., deer milk, so called because the first cans of condensed milk had a picture of deer on the label.
Canned milk.
A breast that has milk from the beginning of pregnancy to long after weaning.
Red liquid, blood, menstrual flow; rain runoff red with soil.
Name of a wind, Honolua, Maui. (For. 5:101.)
To fix firmly. Cf. ʻūlili 8.
Milk shake.
Cheese. (1 Sam. 17.18.) Lit., solidified milk.
Diluted milk.
Butter.
See waiūpaka
Cheese. Lit., solidified butter.
Budding breast, as of a young girl.

Goods, property, assets, valuables, value, worth, wealth, importance, benefit, estate, use; useful, valuable, rich, costly, financial. (Probably related to wai 4, to retain, rather than to wai 1, water.) See kumu waiwai, waiwai ʻole.
Tithe, tithing. Lit., one-tenth property.
Inherited property, heritage, estate.
Exports.
Security, fixed assets. Lit., solid property.
Imports.
Smuggled goods.
Profits.
Assets. Lit., combined wealth.
Par value, as of stocks. Lit., name value.
True worth, as of heirlooms; marked value, as of stocks.
Merchandise.
War goods, spoils.
Par value, just value.
Wealth taken to cause by sorcery the death of an innocent person—this was punishable by the sorcerer's own death. (Kam. 64:120.) Lit., live blood goods.
Wealth taken to cause by sorcery the death of a sorcerer who had prayed others to death. (Kam. 64:120.) Lit., foul blood goods.
Imports.
Investments. (Will 129, 1856, State Archives.)
Movable or personal property; liquid assets; chattel.
Tribute or wealth from the uplands.

The lemon verbena (Aloysia triphylla), a South American shrub, with rough lemonscented, narrow leaves, and small white or lavender flowers in spikes. Formerly the plant was a favorite in Hawaiian gardens, and was used in leis. (Neal 724.) Eng.

The paper mulberry (Broussonetia papyrifera), a small tree or shrub, from eastern Asia, known throughout the Pacific for its usefulness. It belongs to the fig or mulberry family. The bark was made into tough tapa used for clothing, bed clothes; it lasted longer than māmaki tapa. (Neal 301.) Cf. poʻaʻaha 2. (PCP (w)aute.)
Bast from fully mature wauke that required more beating (kuʻikuʻi) than younger wauke (wauke ohiohi). (Kam. 76:40.)
A wauke that was used medicinally, perhaps as a substitute for the mālolo (flying fish) often used in sacrifices.
Wauke bast dyed red for use as coloring material in tapa. (Kam. 76:114.)

A cosmopolitan tropical club moss (Lycopodium cernuum), a far-creeping mosslike plant, growing .3 to 1.5 m high. Its stems and many branches are covered with short, narrow-pointed leaves, and are made into Christmas wreaths. Eight other species of club mosses also bear this name. (Neal 2–3.) Other analysts call wāwaeʻiole, Codium edule, and list ʻaʻala- ʻula and ʻalaʻula as variant names. Some equate huluhulua-ʻiole and huluʻiole with wāwaeʻiole.
Same as kiʻi 4, and wāwae 2, a hula step.
Redup. of waele.

1. Crack, narrow opening; to open a crack, as a door; to separate, loosen, free.

2. Certain species of the Mullidae, surmullets or goatfish. All weke have large scales and are usually found in reefs, sometimes in deep water. Both red and light-colored weke were popular as offerings to the gods to turn away curses: see weke 1. For the connection of weke with nightmares, see pahulu 1. Unidentified varieties of weke are qualified by the terms koaʻe, lāʻō, moelua. See also weke ʻā or weke keʻokeʻo, weke ahulu or weke pahulu or weke pueo, weke nono, weke ʻula.

3. Rare variant of waka, to flame, flash.

1. Pas/imp. of weke 1. Rare.

1. Famine; to suffer a famine.

2. To squeal (For. 4:457), squeak, tinkle; the sound of wind, of gnashing teeth; any high shrill sound. Cf. pule wī.

3. . The wī tree (Spondias dulcis), a smooth, gray-barked tree in the mango family, from islands of the South Pacific. The round or ovoid orange fruits, called wī apples, are 2.5 or more cm in diameter, have apple-flavored, yellow pulp surrounding a core with a few seeds. (Neal 523.)

4. The tamarind (Tomarindus indica), a large leguminous tree from tropical Africa and possibly Asia, grown for shade and ornament, and for the wood and fruit. The brown pod contains a few seeds embedded in sticky, brown, acid pulp, which is eaten or made into a drink. (Neal 417.) Sometimes called wīʻawaʻawa.

5. See hīhī wai 1, a grainy snail.

The Christmas-berry tree (Schinus terebinthifolius), a rather small tree, from Brazil, the leaves compound, each leaf having about seven leaflets, the flowers whitish, small, in large bunches, the small red fruits of the female tree abundant, resembling those of the pūkiawe. Named for Willie Rice, who during political campaigns wore a hat lei of the red berries. (Neal 525.)

Each leaf has three ovate leaflets; flowers are clustered near branch ends and range in color from red to orange, yellow, white; pods contain red, oblong seeds, used for leis. The wood is very light and formerly was used for surfboards, canoe outriggers, net floats. (Neal 458–60.) See ex., pua 1.
